Subject: Camp Nelson Becomes Kentucky's First National Monument
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Open a plain text version
News from Representative Barr
￼
 
Home
About
Services
Media Center
Contact
 
 
Sixth District Report
￼ 
Dear Friend, 
After more than four years of collaboration with families of those who lived and worked at Camp Nelson, along with community stakeholders and others, I was proud to welcome Department of the Interior (DOI) Secretary Ryan Zinke to Jessamine County on October 27, 2018, to announce that President Trump has designated the Camp Nelson Civil War Heritage Park as Kentucky's first National Monument. 
This designation, the first President Trump has signed, will provide the community with resources to preserve and share the story of Camp Nelson for generations to come. 
I am proud to advocate for Camp Nelson, a site which has the ability to unite the American people. I appreciate the community stakeholders and Camp Nelson descendants for their dedication to securing this designation and I would like to thank President Trump and Secretary Zinke for their recognition of this historical site. 
To read more about this historic day for the Commonwealth, click here. 
Fighting Kentucky's Opioid Crisis 
￼ 
On October 24, 2018, President Trump signed into law the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, another significant legislative package to address our nation's opioid crisis by strengthening our communities' prevention, treatment, and recovery initiatives.  
In 2016, more than 1,400 Kentuckians died of an opioid overdose and we owe it to these families to provide the resources needed to combat this heartbreaking crisis that is devastating communities throughout the Commonwealth. After months of bipartisan work, this critical legislation will provide Kentucky with the tools to prevent the flow of illegal drugs into our communities and better equip our law enforcement and local officials with the support needed to stop drug trafficking and substance abuse throughout Kentucky's communities. 
I was proud this legislative package included my bill, the CAREER Act, which was inspired by the work of many successful transitional housing models in the Sixth District, such as Chrysalis House, Recovery Kentucky, St. James Place, and Shepherd's House. Specifically, my legislation will encourage businesses and treatment centers to form partnerships to secure job training, employment, and housing options for individuals in recovery. To read more about this historic legislation, click here. 
Discussions on the Importance of Border Security   
￼ 
On October 17, House Committee on Homeland Security Chairman Michael McCaul (TX-10) joined me and other law enforcement officials for a roundtable to discuss the importance of border security in the fight against drug trafficking and substance abuse in Kentucky's communities. 
The Commonwealth is particularly devastated by the flow of illegal, illicit drugs into our communities. Throughout this crisis, I have heard from law enforcement officials about the need for stronger border security to better control this epidemic and save Kentucky lives. It was a pleasure to have my friend and colleague Chairman McCaul in the Sixth District and it was a great opporunity to hear from those on the front lines of this crisis. 
Helping Secure Grants Across Central and Eastern Kentucky 
This month, I had the honor of joining many organizations throughout the Sixth District to announce the awarding of multiple federal grants. One of my priorities in Congress is to ensure federal dollars are returned back to the community. 
￼ 
Our communities' first responders put their lives on the line every day to keep Kentuckians safe. For this reason, it was great to join the City of Irvine Fire Department to announce a $27,500 grant which was used to purchase a new fire engine. Thank you go all of our first responders for serving our communities!  
￼ 
On October 24, I was proud to visit the City of Campton to announce the awarding of a $635,367 Appalachian Regional Commission grant to begin the Campton Tank Replacement Project to provide residents, businesses, and one public school with access to clean water. 
￼ 
I was also proud to help secure a $500,000 Appalachian Regional Commission grant for the City of Stanton to update the it's sewer service line, which will better equip the city's infrastructure for even further economic development in the future. 
￼ 
On October 11, I congratulated Chrysalis House and Executive Director Lisa Minton, pictured above, for receiving a $29,740 grant, which will be used to expand their residential substance abuse treatment centers by establishing a new facility for pregnant and postpartum women and their children overcoming addiction. 
￼ 
Finally, I joined Voices of Hope in Lexington to announce the awarding of a $129,120 State Targeted Response grant, which will be used to support its new community center and peer-to-peer recovery coaching for those overcoming substance abuse throughout Central Kentucky. 
Additional Photos and Videos Around Kentucky's Sixth District
￼ 
It was great to discuss the results we are delivering to Kentucky families and small businesses with the Rotary Club of Lexington on October 25. As a result of our pro-growth policies, unemployment is the lowest since 1969 and consumer confidence is at an 18-year high.
￼ 
I had the honor of attending the AgTech Scientific Industrial Hemp groundbreaking in Bourbon County on October 18. I am proud to support the Industrial Hemp Pilot Program as it has created vast economic opportunity for the Commonwealth, and I look forward to the future developments and research advances this new facility will contribute to a variety of hemp products. 
￼ 
I joined UK Federal Credit Union to discuss the new era of economic prosperity and the importance of community credit unions in giving Kentuckians' access to credit to finance their American Dream.    
￼ 
During opening weekend of Keeneland, I joined TVG to discuss Kentucky's signature thoroughbred industry and the benefits of our new tax code for this key industry. I also discussed my advocacy for equine-assisted therapy, which pairs our veterans with horses, including retired thoroughbred race horses, as a way for our returning heroes to recover from the invisible scars of combat. Click the image above to watch my full interview! 
Mobile Office Hours  
To better serve the people of central and eastern Kentucky, my staff conducts regular traveling office hours in every county of the Sixth Congressional District.  These office hours are not town hall meetings, but rather are a resource to help constituents who are in need of assistance and want to speak to a staff member in person.     Click here for a complete schedule of all upcoming dates and times for mobile office hours.  
Please continue to let me know your thoughts and concerns about issues facing our community, and I hope you will forward my weekly newsletter to your friends, family and neighbors. 
You may also visit my website, Facebook and Twitter, where you can find regular updates about my work at home in the Sixth District and in Washington. 
Thank you and have a great week! 
Sincerely, Andy Barr

Subject: Congressman Bob Latta's Fifth District Family Values Watch October 2018
Message:
https://latta.house.gov/ ￼ 
Home   |    Serving You   |    Contact Bob   |    Our District   |    Issues & Legislation   |    Newsroom   |    About Bob 




October 31, 2018

Fifth District Family Values Watch

Congressman Latta's monthly newsletter tracking life and family news from the Nation’s Capital
Wednesday, October 31, 2018
This month I had the opportunity and privilege to visit communities across Northwest and West Central Ohio and listen to your concerns and discuss issues that are most important to you and your families.  I want to assure you that I am committed to continue working with my colleagues to provide true reforms that will keep the federal government in check, responsibly address the federal budget, and provide fairness to all hardworking American families.   Furthermore, it is imperative we remain steadfast in protecting family values and the sanctity of life.  
Please feel free to forward this e-newsletter to share pro-life and pro-family news in your community.  It is my great honor to serve as your Member of Congress and it is my number one priority to represent you and the best interests of the Fifth Congressional District.  Please do not hesitate to call, write, or e-mail me in the future with any of your concerns or questions.  For federal-related issues, you may reach my Washington, D.C. office by phone at (202) 225-6405, or my District office at (800) 541-6446 for constituent services.  I encourage you to visit my website at http://latta.house.gov where you can sign up for my e-newsletter.  Also, feel free to follow me online at www.facebook.com/boblatta/ or on Twitter at @boblatta, which helps bring my work in Washington, D.C. home to you.
Sincerely,
￼

Congressman Bob Latta


ABORTION RATES ON THE RISE IN OHIO
The Ohio Department of Health (ODH) recently released a report entitled “Induced Abortions in Ohio.”The annual report contained statistics on the 20,893 induced pregnancy terminations that occurred in Ohio in 2017.  This new figure indicates a one percent increase in induced abortions from 2016 to 2017. Furthermore, of the 14 counties I represent, in full or part, in Northwest and West Central Ohio there were nearly 1,200 abortions obtained last year.  
In addition, there were 454 abortion involving pregnancies of 19 or more completed weeks of gestation.  It’s saddening to know that many of these 454 abortions could have been stopped if H.R. 36, the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, became law.  In October 2017, I joined 236 of my colleagues in the House of Representatives to pass H.R. 6, which would prohibit abortions on unborn babies 20 weeks or older. Medical evidence suggests that at 20 weeks an unborn child can feel pain by this stage of development.  Unfortunately, the Senate has yet to act on this legislation. 
While an increase in abortion is discouraging, there is hope in knowing that since 2001 there has been a steady decline in pregnancy terminations with an annual decline averaging approximately 830 per year.  I will continue to fight alongside advocates and pro-life Members of Congress to support a culture of life and encourage the end of elective abortion.    ODH REDUCES FINE ON TOLEDO ABORTION PROVIDER
On October 10th, the Ohio Department of Health (ODH) released a Hearing Examiner’s Report and Recommendation that proposes reducing the fine levied against the Capital Care Network of Toledo from $40,000 to $3,000.  You may recall that Capital Care Network was fined after ODH determined the provider put a patient’s health and safety in danger.  The report indicated that it was unclear to the physician if the patient suffered from a perforated bowel due to a botched abortion performed at Capital Care Network.  The physician determined that the patient should receive further testing at a hospital and then had a staff member drive the patient to a hospital in their personal car.  However, after further investigation ODH could not prove many of the violations outlined in their original report, which led to a recommendation to the ODH Director to reduce the penalty to $3,000.   2019 MARCH FOR LIFE
Please mark your calendars to attend the 2019 March for Life rally on Friday, January 18, 2019 in Washington, D.C. I will be hosting an open house for constituents who are visiting the area to support the pro-life movement.  Please be on the lookout for more details in next month’s newsletter.    

                
News Releases: 
October 23: Latta to Attend Signing of Opioid Legislation at White House  October 23: President Signs Legislation Containing Latta's Clean Drinking Water Provisions Into Law  October 22: Latta: Ohioans Benefitting From Economy on the Rise  

Follow Congressman Latta online! He regularly updates his profiles with the latest news and developments from around Ohio and Capitol Hill.

Subject: Legislative Update: Congressman Panetta
Message:
￼￼ 

  Dear Neighbor,   
As your United States Representative, I am providing you with an update about some of the work that I have done on behalf of the central coast of California over the last couple of months. From authoring and introducing legislation that benefits our local economy, to voting to fund clean energy priorities and raise our troops’ wages, to encouraging community members to participate in the public comment period on the Administration’s public charge proposal, to earning a 100% rating from the Human Rights Campaign for my record to support LGBTQ Equality, it is an honor to serve the people of the Central Coast and represent our values in Washington, D.C.  

In our nation, there are certain groups and people that thrive on divisiveness. In order to overcome such disunity and hate, we not only must stand up and speak out against any violence, rhetoric, and racism, but we also must step up to make our voices and choices heard. Throughout the history of our nation, our leaders provided guidance during difficult times. Unfortunately, there also are those that fail to confront moments of crisis with moral leadership and clarity. That is why it is important to demand that all elected officials, no matter what office they hold, promote civil discourse and the ability to be bipartisan in order to set the tone and mood for our communities and country. By ensuring that our political leaders are civil, we are upholding our civic duties and responsibilities of living in this democracy that is of, by, and for the people.
  Authored Legislation To Support Veterans   I am proud to have authored and introduced two bipartisan bills to support our student veterans on college campuses. The Veterans Resource Center Act would authorize grants for Veterans Resource Centers to advise, assist, and support military-connected students and encourage priority registration for veterans. I co-introduced the GI Bill Transfer Extension Act, legislation that will increase flexibility for service members seeking to transfer their GI Bill education benefits. I will continue to work to support veterans and their families in their pursuit of higher education.  ￼  Announcing the introduction of my legislation on the Veterans Resource Center Act at California State University Monterey Bay.   Authored Legislation To Support Our Agriculture  I authored and introduced the Farmworker Housing Improvement Act to increase Central Coast farmworkers’ access to affordable housing. My legislation will address current challenges by strengthening the Farm Labor Housing Loan and Grant Program, improving access to information for local non-profits, and increasing quality housing options for our farmworker community.  I authored and introduced the Specialty Crop Mechanization Prize Challenge Act to spur innovation of agriculture technology to support our local agriculture industry and improve farmworkers’ harvesting methods. The legislation encourages the private sector to engage with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to develop mechanization technology that can alleviate stress on farmworkers or automates activities where workers are not available. It does so by directing the Secretary of Agriculture to establish prize competitions that incentivize the development of this technology.  ￼  Joined Rep. Rodney Davis (R-IL), fellow co-chair and co-founder of the Agriculture Research Caucus, to speak to the United Fresh Produce Association about bipartisanship, the Farm Bill, immigration reform, and the benefits of research in agriculture.   Authored Legislation To Protect The Special Counsel  I authored and introduced the Special Counsel Security Clearance Protection Act to prevent the unwarranted revocation of the security clearances of Special Counsel Robert Mueller or his any of his team during the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. Currently, the Office of the President claims the authority to revoke an individual’s security clearance for any reason at any time. The legislation requires independent judicial approval of any decision to revoke the security clearance of a special counsel. Moreover, any revocation must be for cause and consistent with U.S. national security interests.   Secured Funding For Pajaro River Levee Repairs  I fought for and secured federal funding in order for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to repair damage to the Pajaro River levee caused by the winter storms in 2017. I was pleased to tour the recently completed restorations. I will continue to work with local stakeholders to break through federal bureaucracy to ensure improved flood protection for the residents of Pajaro and Watsonville.  ￼  Viewing the recent repairs to the Pajaro Levee in Watsonville.   Secured A Grant For Housing On The Central Coast  I fought for and secured a federal grant totaling $205,950 from the U.S Department of Housing and Urban Development for the Housing Authority of the County of Monterey. The grant provides Mainstream housing vouchers for affordable housing and an array of supportive services for non-elderly persons with disabilities.    Secured A Grant For Substance Abuse Treatment On The Central Coast  I fought for and secured a federal grant totaling $504,691 from the Department of Health and Human Services Center of Substance Abuse Treatment for Janus of Santa Cruz. These funds will be used for an integrated residential substance use disorder treatment program for pregnant and postpartum women and their families in Santa Cruz County.   Secured Grants For Agriculture On The Central Coast 
 I fought for and secured a USDA grant totaling $40,000 for the El Pajaro Community Development Corporation and a USDA grant totaling $38,000 for the Agriculture and Land-Based Training Association. The grants will be used to increase economic security in the region and provide skill building and business education opportunities for aspiring entrepreneurs. In order for the central coast of California to remain the Salad Bowl of the World, investments must be made to ensure that the next generation of farmers, ranchers, and small business owners have the resources that they need to succeed. These grants will help our agricultural industry and rural economies continue to thrive by providing opportunities for entrepreneurs on the Central Coast.   Fighting For Immigration Reform On The Central Coast  I was proud to welcome U.S. Senator Dianne Feinstein to the Central Coast, where we toured Monterey Mushrooms, Inc. in Royal Oaks. We spoke with farmers from the Central Coast and California’s Central Valley and farmworkers, including the leadership of the United Farm Workers, about the challenges they face due to the lack of immigration reform. The Senator and I talked about the importance of passing immigration reform, including the Blue Card Bill, which she introduced in the Senate and I was an original co-sponsor in the House. That bill would provide farmworkers with a work authorization and an earned legal status if they show consistent employment in U.S. agriculture. During the discussion, the Senator directly asked for my continued leadership on the bill. I look forward to continuing to work with the Senator and others in Congress to pass legislation on immigration reform that benefits those who contribute so much to our community and country.  ￼  Touring Monterey Mushrooms with Senator Feinstein, farmers, and farmworkers.   Working To Protect And Improve Our Healthcare  I met with local healthcare leaders on the Central Coast to discuss ways to protect and improve the Affordable Care Act (ACA), including the preservation of coverage for pre-existing conditions. I shared the bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus principles to save the individual market with the group. I will continue to meet with our local experts to gather evidence for ways to improve access to healthcare and lower healthcare costs.  ￼  Discussing the challenges facing our healthcare markets and developing solutions that improve options in Monterey County. 
 The 2019 Open Enrollment Period for the Affordable Care Act runs from Thursday, November 1, 2018, to Saturday, December 15, 2018. Learn more here.    Mobile Office Hours For October And November  
Mobile office hours are an opportunity for members of the community to meet with Congressional staff, and are offered in addition to meetings in the Salinas and Santa Cruz Congressional offices. Congressional staff members will be available to assist with issues concerning Social Security, Medicare, federal employee retirement, immigration services, veterans' services, passports, searching for military records, and any other federal matters. To schedule a meeting, please call our Salinas District Office: (831) 424-2229.
 Veterans Mobile Office Hours

117 Fourth Street Gonzales, CA 93926    Providing Opportunities For The Next Generation On The Central Coast  If you or somebody that you know from the Central Coast would like to intern at one of my offices in either Washington, D.C., Salinas, or Santa Cruz, please call those offices. It is a great opportunity to volunteer and provide service to the people of California’s 20th Congressional District.   Election Day Information 
Next Tuesday, November 6th is Election Day. You can find more information here.   Newsletters Can Only Contain Information About Official Business  The information in this newsletter only pertains to my official, rather than political, role and highlights my duties and obligation to serve everyone in our Congressional District as your United States Representative.   If you would like to get similar updates in the future, please sign up for newsletters by clicking here. You can also find more information about legislation, votes cast in the U.S. House of Representatives, or the legislative process here.  If you have any questions or issues that I or my staff can help you with, please call or contact my Congressional offices in Salinas, Santa Cruz, or Washington, D.C. or through https://panetta.house.gov. Please do not hesitate to reach out and let me know how I can continue to serve you.    
Sincerely, ￼   JIMMY PANETTA Member of Congress

Subject: Rothfus Report: Stronger than Hate
Message:

News from Representative Keith Rothfus
￼

 
SERVING 
YOU
CONTACT KEITH
OUR 
DISTRICT
ISSUES & LEGISLATION
NEWSROOM
ABOUT 
KEITH
 


Dear Lindsey, 
Over the weekend, we witnessed a vile attack on our community unlike any we have ever seen: An armed gunman driven by hatred and anger entered the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh and opened fire on the gathered congregation, killing 11 individuals and injuring six more. These victims were wives, husbands, mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, and grandparents. One fallen victim was a constituent of the Twelfth District. Anti-Semitism is a scourge on humanity and assaults every American value we cherish.
￼   There is no place for violence in our country. This evil must end. To the entire Jewish community of Pittsburgh, and all our Jewish friends, we stand with you in solidarity against this hatred. 
No one should have to fear for their lives when practicing their beliefs. No one should have to endure what the congregation of the Tree of Life Synagogue did. The perpetuated violence on the Jewish community of Pittsburgh was not just reprehensible, it was pure evil.
The people of Pittsburgh, Western Pennsylvania, and all America are strong and resilient, and we will not be beat down by this hatred. Elsie and I continue to pray for all those affected by this tragedy, and that our criminal justice system will also act swiftly to bring justice against this criminal. Together, the community of Squirrel hill and all Western Pennsylvania will stand resolved and united in rebuilding a culture of dignity and respect. 
If there is anything my staff and I can do for you, please do not hesitate to reach out to my office at 412-837-1361 or go to my website at rothus.house.gov.  
 Sincerely,  ￼                                                Keith

Subject: restoring civility & rebuilding trust
Message:
￼

Good afternoon, 

Last night, I was with the congregation of Temple Beth Shalom in Spokane. Together, we prayed for strength for the Jewish community in Pittsburgh and for their friends and families. We also prayed for a return to civility and for peace. That requires everyone doing their part to see the best in others, not the worst. It requires not giving into fear, and requires protecting and preserving the values we so deeply cherish as a nation. 

This is not a nation of antisemitism. This is not a nation of violence and hatred. America is where you are free to speak, free to worship, and free to dream - and we must stand up to anyone or anything that tries to prevent that. 

That's why, in a time where there is so much anger and hostility - when the political discourse and rhetoric threaten to tear our communities apart - I have made it a priority to bring people together and work to bridge the gaps that divide us. My goal is to help lead the healing that needs to happen in our country and in our community. 

Over the past year, I've been hosting Unity Dinners with people throughout Eastern Washington. The dinner table has a way of breaking down barriers between people. Everyone has a story to share. Many people have experienced deep pain, heartache and loss whether financial, health or family. But by being kind and caring for one another, we can offer each other hope and encouragement to continue on.

I have also co-hosted the Peaceful Community Roundtable here in Spokane to bring a diverse group of leaders together and discuss priorities for Spokane to build a stronger, safer community. We don't just talk about problems, we talk about solutions.

It's important to remember that there is more that unites us than divides us. Our shared values of liberty, justice, and equality of opportunity are stronger than anything. We can't and shouldn't go at it alone. 
Thanks, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress
P.S. Click here to read my latest column in the Spokesman-Review titled, "There is more that unites us than divides us." 
 
￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: We Must Stand Together Against Hate
Message:
￼ 
  

Dear Lindsey, 
Our nation is in mourning. 
We mourn the eleven lives stolen from us in the anti-Semitic attack at the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh. We mourn the two African Americans killed in a racially-motivated shooting in Kentucky.
And all of us were horrified by the mail bombs targeting prominent Democratic officials and the media. 
Sadly, these are not isolated incidents. Just one year ago, white supremacists marched on Charlottesville, leaving a young woman dead and dozens injured.
Hate is on the rise. And rather than combat it, the White House has further sown the seeds of division. 
Time after time, President Trump has exploited xenophobia and racism for political gain. 
We must demand better from our elected officials. 
This is a time for our nation to reject hate, and for our leaders to bring us together. 
The election is next week. You can make your voice heard. 
Please know that I am here for you. I will keep fighting in Congress to ensure all people -- regardless of their skin color, their religion, or their zip code -- are treated with dignity and respect.
As always, my office is happy to assist you and your family. If you need help with a federal issue, please call my Oakland office at (510) 763-0370. You can also connect with me via email, facebook, twitter, and Instagram. 
In Solidarity, 
￼ 
   

￼

Subject: Major Federal Grants Announced for Rural Medical Delivery
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Oct 31, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158

Major Federal Grants Announced for Rural Medical Delivery

Munising - The United States Department of Agriculture is awarding over $400,000 in grants to increase access to health care services. Two of these grants have been awarded within Michigan's First District. Congressman Jack Bergman stated, "The rural nature of the First District provides many challenges when it comes to quality healthcare delivery. I'm grateful for the work and resources that our federal partners at USDA continue to invest in rural Michigan. This announcement is great news for the First District."
 In April 2017, President Donald J. Trump established the Interagency Task Force on Agriculture and Rural Prosperity to identify legislative, regulatory and policy changes that could promote agriculture and prosperity in rural communities. The goal is to align the federal government with state, local and tribal governments to take advantage of opportunities that exist in rural America. Increasing investments in rural infrastructure is a key recommendation of the task force.  The recipients of these grants are listed below:  Munising Memorial Hospital - $303,337 
This Rural Development investment will be used to purchase telemedicine equipment for six sites in Marquette and Angler counties. New 3D tomosynthesis mammography equipment will replace the outdated 2D mammography equipment technology. The new technology improves cancer detection by 40 percent and will speed up the diagnosis and treatment. The new telemedicine capabilities will impact a population of 2,927 and decrease travel time for patients and provide the most comprehensive breast imaging services, which are not usually available in rural communities. 
Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Service - $102,987
This Rural Development investment will be used to help purchase telemedicine equipment for Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services which will provide a telehealth network to rural areas of northern Michigan. Rural sites will be connected with larger Pine Rest facilities in Grand Rapids and Traverse City, which provide psychiatry services. The project will also provide access to substance misuse providers based in Marquette and Sault St. Marie. Thirteen sites will have access to state of the art treatment services provided by nine hub sites that have capability of providing a broad range of medical services and treatment options to its service area of 242,191 residents

Subject: Protecting our Veterans
Message:
News from Representative Brat 
￼ 
Website 
Subscribe
To Newsletter 
Constituent
Services 
Legislative
Resources 
Press
Shop 
About 
Dave 
Contact
Dave 



Dear Friend, 

Taking care of our veterans should always be one of our highest priorities. So when I met with Brian Tally and heard his story about his problem with the VA system, I knew I had to take steps to close this loophole.  

Brian Tally went to the VA for debilitating back pain in January 2016. At the VA he was seen by an independent contractor who sent him away with a bag of pills for the pain. A short time later Brian's condition worsened and he began to fear for his life. He paid for an MRI, and learned he had a staph infection in his spine - an ailment normally discovered through a simple blood test. Brian returned to the VA and was able to get an emergency operation through the VA Choice Act, but the infection had already caused permanent damage - leaving Brian crippled for the rest of his life. 

Brian filed a claim at the VA but since the independent contractor was at fault the VA couldn't do anything for him. His only option was to sue the contractor for medical malpractice. By the time it was all sorted the statute of limitations had already run out, and Brian was prohibited from filing suit and receiving compensation. If the malpractice had been done by a VA employee, he would have had an additional year to bring his case to court. 

                       ￼   ￼

So, I worked with Brian and wrote legislation to bring independent VA contractors under the same medical malpractice procedures for other federal employees at the VA. It will increase accountability for employees and contractors who provide care for our veterans. It also ensures that veterans who have been misdiagnosed, neglected, or experienced malpractice will not be left without recourse. 
￼

Brian's story is heartbreaking and should have never happened. But we can make sure his story is not wasted and that all our veterans in the future are protected from this shameful loophole in our system. 

To read more about the legislation and Brian's story click here. 

Thank you,

￼

Congressman Dave Brat

Subject: Bonamici Bulletin
Message:
￼ 
Dear Lindsey, 
This is a pivotal time in our country on many issues; it is important for people to participate and make their voices heard. Thank you to everyone who attended one of my 6 fall town hall meetings in Seaside, Tualatin, Newberg, Banks, Scappoose, and Portland!  
                                    
￼
 I also met with younger constituents—students—at their schools, on Manufacturing Day, and at other events. I enjoyed hearing directly from you and look forward to continuing to work on your behalf in Congress.  ￼ 

Improving the health of our oceans
￼
The ocean is resilient and we can help it heal, but we cannot continue to ignore the garbage polluting our oceans and shores. I worked with my House Oceans Caucus Co-Chair, Congressman Don Young, on the bipartisan Save Our Seas Act, which passed both the House and Senate with strong bipartisan support. This bill was signed into law in early October, and will assist local communities and states in removing garbage and debris from our oceans and coastline. Marine debris is preventable, and this law will help protect the health of our oceans. 
I was also thrilled to help enact a provision to restore more than 50 acres of salmon habitat on Clatsop County’s Walluski River. This provision was signed into law as part of the new bipartisan Water Resources Development Act. Salmon are an important part of our heritage in the Pacific Northwest, but old, unnecessary levees on our rivers and waterways have turned some salmon habitat into farm or pasture land. Because of this provision, the Columbia River Estuary Study Taskforce will be able to lead habitat restoration projects and smart infrastructure upgrades to protect the environment and make sure that salmon will continue to be there for generations to come. 
 ￼ 

Strengthening protections for airline passengers
When people travel by air, they often experience lost luggage, delays, or other complications that are entirely out of their control. Thanks to a provision I led that was signed into law, the Federal Aviation Administration will create a new Aviation Consumer Advocate position to make sure that all airline passengers have someone on their side to help tackle problems they face while flying. The Advocate will help consumers navigate the system, resolve difficulties, and alleviate some of the stress that comes with unexpected complications. 
 ￼

Standing up for student loan borrowers
￼
Education is always one of my top priorities, and this includes protecting the rights of student loan borrowers. This month, Senator Elizabeth Warren and I led our colleagues in the House and Senate to send the following message to Sec. Betsy DeVos: stop putting profits ahead of students. We demanded that Sec. DeVos provide the full set of documents that the Department of Education used as the basis for the Department’s decision to reinstate an accreditor that has a troubling history of failing to protect students from predatory for-profit colleges. I will continue to hold Sec. DeVos accountable. 
 ￼ 

Helping constituents
If you have trouble with a federal agency, my office is available to help. I’m honored to have played a part in reuniting the Nguyen siblings, who struggled with the legal immigration process for decades. Mr. Nguyen and his father sacrificed for the U.S. during the Vietnam War and beyond, yet our policies kept his family apart for more than 40 years. If you or a family member needs help navigating federal government agencies on immigration, veterans, Medicare, Social Security, or other concerns, please call my office at (503) 469-6010. 
￼ 

You can find more updates about my work around NW Oregon and in Washington, DC on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and YouTube. You can also contact my Oregon and Washington, DC offices with questions, comments, or for assistance with a federal agency. This mailbox is not monitored. To contact me via email, please use this secure web form.

Subject: An update from Congressman Chris Collins
Message:
￼ 
Dear Friend,
Here is a quick update on what I have been working on during a busy few weeks in Washington D.C. and Western New York.

￼ 

President Donald Trumped signed H.R 6 SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act into law
On October 24th, President Donald Trump signed into law H.R 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act. This bipartisan legislation is crucial for the fight against the opioid epidemic that is devastating the lives of Americans across the country. Included in this package are several bipartisan legislative initiatives I have or co-authored with my colleagues.
Read More 
President Donald Trump's Revision of NAFTA
President Trump reached a new trade agreement with Mexico and Canada called the U.S-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). This agreement will make important changes to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) that will put the U.S. on a more equal playing field with other nations. Importantly, this will end Canada's unfair Class 7 pricing that harms Western New York's diary industry. 
Read More 
The NRA score of A+
￼ 
The National Rifle Association has given me an A+ rating for protecting the Second Amendment rights and freedoms. I am honored to receive this rating once again because I believe in the  law-abiding gun owners constitutional rights. 
National Federation of Independent Business Award
￼ 
I’m honored to have received the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Guardian of Small Business Award. This award represents my record of voting for policies that support small businesses in our communities. I’ve always been a strong supporter of small business and free enterprise and thank the NFIB for their advocacy efforts. 

￼ 

Meeting with WNIL Inc. 
￼ 
Todd and Michael, from WNYIL Inc., stopped by my office to discuss how we can improve services for people with disabilities in our community.
Toured Newtex Industries  
￼ 
I toured Newtex Industries that is located in Victor, New York. Newtex is a global leader in extreme heat resisting materials. Their products are used by our nations military, firefighters, and companies all over the world. I would like to thank Jerry Joliet and the rest of the Newtex team for showing me around the facility. 
Visited the Veterans One Stop Center 
￼ 
I visited the Veterans One Stop Center which is a non-profit place for veterans and their families to have access to social and health services. They bring in organizations and resources to improve the lives of veterans as they integrate into the working field. This allows veterans to have confidence and support while transitioning. They serve over 100,000 veterans in Western New York and it was a great honor to be invited to take a tour of the facility.
Canandaigua Boy Scouts Clays Shoot 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
I spent time with the local boy scouts for the Canadaigua Boy Scout Clays Shoot. As an Eagle Scout myself, it is great  to spend time with future leaders of this organization.
Agricultural Round Table 
￼ 
I met with farmers and members of Western New York's agriculture community. This was an opportunity for me to sit down and discuss what Congress still needs to do to improve the lives of our nations farmers. During this meeting, we discussed the future of diary and the upcoming Farm Bill. Additionally, we discussed the impacts of the United States Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA) and how it will assist the agricultural industry in the near future. There are still some inattentive issues regarding the impact of  tariffs on our farmers, which I will be working on when Congress is back in session. 
Toured the Dialysis Center Construction at the Livingston County Nursing Home
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
I had the opportunity to visit the Livingston County Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation. Currently, they are building a dialysis center which will improve the lives of their patients and provide them with comfort. After the tour, I spoke with residents of the community and they presented me with a commemorative plate as a token of their gratitude for visiting. I am pleased to see the improvements the Livingston County Center is making for the community and I want to thank the everyone who I met with.

Capitol Hill Visitors
￼ 
The Northern Border Customs Brokers Association, The NY/NJ Foreign Freight Forwarders, and the Brokers Association stopped by my office to discuss a variety issues that impact Western New York. 

￼ 
I met with the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network to discuss how we can continue to battle this disease. Thank you for stopping by my office during Cancer Lobbying Day! 

￼ 
My constituents, Nicholas and William, and their colleagues with the National Stone, Sand, & Gravel Association came by my office to discuss the importance of aggregates to the future of America and I thank them for making time to visit.

Dear Friends,

November 1st will mark the start of Access Health CT’s open enrollment period for 2019 coverage. 

From November 1 until December 15, you can purchase a plan or renew your coverage through AccessHealthCT.com. Once you sign up, you will get coverage that starts on January 1, 2019. 

Here are four facts you need to know about enrolling in coverage or renewing your coverage:
	•	The open enrollment period for Access Health CT for 2019 begins on November 1 and ends on December 15. Beat the rush and sign up early.  
	•	Coverage could be more affordable than you think. That’s because financial help is available. During last year’s enrollment period, 7 in 10 people qualified for financial help.   
	•	If you had coverage through Access Health CT for 2018, make sure to head back to update your information and compare your options for 2019, by December 15. Every year, plans and prices change. This year, it’s more important than ever to shop around! You may find a plan that fits you better, at a lower cost.  
	•	Free help is available. If you have questions about signing up or want to talk through your options with a trained professional, free help is just a call or click away. The Call Center is open Monday-Friday from 8 am-4 pm at 1-855-909-2428. Or visit learn.accesshealthct.com/locations where you will find organizations in your area that have trained enrollment assisters.
Take the time to learn about your options and if you have any questions, I hope that you will feel free to stop by or call my District Office. The office is located at 59 Elm Street, New Haven, CT 06510-7004; the telephone number is (203) 562-3718. 

Sincerely,

Subject: Making Prescription Drugs Safer and More Affordable
Message:
News from Representative Walden

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
 
ABOUT GREG
ISSUES
CONTACT
NEWS
LEGISLATION
 
Dear Friend: 
Every day, thousands of Oregonians make the trip to their local pharmacy to fill prescriptions for medications that are vital to their well-being. Unfortunately, patients and their families often pay far too much for prescription drugs that may very well be the difference between life and death. 
That’s why as Chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, I’ve championed policies that would make these drugs more affordable while also holding companies accountable for their actions. 
Earlier this month, President Trump signed into law two bills that would give patients and pharmacists the ability to find the lowest price when deciding what medications to buy. I first heard about the gag clause issue from Michele, an independent pharmacist from Grants Pass. 
She told me that as a pharmacist she was precluded -- under certain insurance contracts -- from telling a patient that their cash price would be cheaper than going through their insurance. Michele told me that she once even received a cease and desist letter for trying to help a child with a terminal disease access his medication. That is simply unacceptable. 
These new laws pave the way for pharmacists to responsibly advise their patients on the cost of various medications, free from restrictions imposed by take-it-or-leave-it contracts with insurers. Community pharmacists must have the ability to work with their patients to provide them the best access to the medications they need, and these bills will help them do just that. 
It is also vital that we increase competition and spur innovation in order to bring costs down for consumers and provide the next generation of treatment and cures. That’s why my committee led the charge to pass the Food and Drug Administration Reauthorization Act (FDARA), legislation I authored which establishes a pathway to speed the approval of competitive generic drugs and increase competition in the marketplace. We have already seen generic drugs come to market through these new pathways, and prices beginning to drop for consumers on a variety of medications. 
We also must acknowledge the role of prescription drugs in our nation’s opioid epidemic. Each day, nearly 200 Americans die of overdoses and millions more battle addiction often sparked by prescription opioids. 
That is why last year, I opened a bipartisan investigation into the distribution of prescription opioids by wholesale drug distributors and the enforcement practices by the Drug Enforcement Administration during the opioid epidemic. Our investigation uncovered instances where massive quantities of pills were shipped to small, rural towns, and we are now working to develop legislation to ensure this can never happen again. 
Additionally, I opened a second bipartisan investigation into the companies that manufacture opioids. Several of my Republican and Democratic colleagues joined me in sending letters to Insys Therapeutics, Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals, and Purdue Pharma regarding their companies’ internal procedures during the height of the prescription opioid crisis. 
While it is vital patients suffering from severe or chronic pain are able to receive the medication they need, every one of us, large companies included, must do everything in our power to prevent over-prescribing of these powerful drugs. We are still in the middle of this investigation, and I will do everything I can to hold these companies accountable for their role in this epidemic. 
Despite the progress that has been made, there’s no doubt that families across Oregon are paying too much for prescription drugs. President Trump has made a commitment to bring these costs down and recently announced several new initiatives to help level the playing field for consumers. 
I commend the President’s steadfast commitment and will continue working with him and my colleagues in Congress to ensure the vital medications so many Oregonians rely on are safer and more affordable than ever and that the United States remains the leader in medical innovation.
It is an honor to represent you in the U.S. Congress. 
Best regards, 
Greg Walden U.S. Representative Oregon's Second District

Message:
News from Representative Cooper

￼
 
ABOUT JIM
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
SUBSCRIBE
 
Top 10 at 10                                    
October 31, 2018

￼ 



￼
￼
Trump’s visit to Pittsburgh after synagogue massacre creates tensions in grieving city   The Washington Post  President Trump visited a grief-stricken Pittsburgh on Tuesday in a trip meant to unify after tragedy, but his arrival provoked protests from residents and consternation from local officials in the aftermath of the synagogue shooting that left 11 people dead.
First Up if Democrats Win: Campaign and Ethics Changes, Infrastructure and Drug Prices   New York Times  Democrats would use their first month in the House majority to advance sweeping changes to future campaign and ethics laws, requiring the disclosure of shadowy political donors, outlawing the gerrymandering of congressional districts and restoring key enforcement provisions to the Voting Rights Act, top Democratic leaders said on Tuesday.
Obamacare enrollment opens facing pressure from new Trump attacks   POLITICO The Obamacare sign-up season starting Thursday is the second one overseen by the Trump administration — and the first since the GOP Congress scrapped the controversial individual mandate once thought to be the law’s linchpin.
Two generations of humans have killed off more than half the world’s wildlife populations, report finds   The Washington Post  Human activity has annihilated wildlife on a scale unseen beyond mass extinction, and it has helped put humans on a potentially irreversible path toward a hot, chaotic planet stripped clean of the natural resources that enrich it, a new report has concluded. 
Trump’s proposal to end birthright citizenship is unconstitutional   The Washington Post  Sometimes the Constitution’s text is plain as day and bars what politicians seek to do. That’s the case with President Trump’s proposal to end “birthright citizenship” through an executive order. Such a move would be unconstitutional and would certainly be challenged. And the challengers would undoubtedly win.
How the rise of conspiracy theory politics emboldens anti-Semitism   Vox  An environment where conspiracy theories flourish and find new ground is the perfect environment for anti-Semitism itself to flourish and find new acolytes. Anti-Semitism is a distinct form of hate, one deeply rooted in conspiracies about the role Jewish people play in shaping public life. But moreover, anti-Semitism itself is a conspiracy theory.
Low-Income Students Still Struggle To Pay for College, Four Years After Tennessee Promise's Start   WPLN  Tennessee has been praised for making community college more accessible by giving graduating high schoolers free tuition. But schools in the state have found the free college initiatives are not helping many of the lowest-income students, and some are trying to find ways to fill in the gaps.
Ten years later, what has bitcoin achieved?   QZ  Ten years ago today (Oct. 31), Satoshi Nakamoto posted a white paper on a cryptography mailing list, outlining the plan for “Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System.” In the decade since this seminal work, bitcoin has spawned a sprawling cryptocurrency industry, attracted billions of dollars from speculators, and raised fundamental questions about financial privacy and freedom. It also inspired blockchain hype, the results of which we are yet to see.
Edmund Zagorski's life on death row: 'He is the embodiment of spiritual grace'   Tennessean  Edmund Zagorski is guilty of killing two men in 1983 — he doesn't dispute that. But many who have encountered him during his decades at Riverbend Maximum Security Institute said he has forged a new identity as a peacemaker behind bars. 
America is warming fast. See how your city’s weather will be different in just one generation.   Vox  Our world is getting warmer. This we know. But how much will temperatures in US cities change by 2050? By then, scientists say average global warming since preindustrial levels could be about twice what it is in 2018 — and much more obvious and disruptive.                                     Sincerely, ￼  Jim Cooper

Subject: Bringing the Senate to Montana: Fighting to protect our National Park communities
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





Listening to community leaders at an official Senate Hearing in Gardiner 
￼ WATCH highlights from the Gardiner field hearing
What's New:
As Chairman of the National Parks subcommittee, I recently held an official Senate hearing in Gardiner, Montana, to discuss the challenges communities surrounding National Parks face with the increase in visitation to our National Parks. The public hearing was held at the Gardiner Public School, which partially sits inside Yellowstone National Park, where we heard from the Superintendent of Yellowstone Park and community leaders from Gardiner, Cooke City, West Yellowstone, and the Flathead Valley. These communities have seen first-hand the economic benefits from more tourists visiting our National Parks, but they have also faced growing challenges maintaining infrastructure due to more people traveling through their communities.  Why it matters:  Montana’s National Parks bring tremendous economic opportunities. For example, according the National Park Service, visitors spent approximately $275 million in Glacier National Park and $500 million in Yellowstone and the surrounding areas just last year. This comes as we have seen record numbers of visitors to all of our National Parks. This increase comes at a cost, including more people driving on small town roads and using utilities in small towns. However, the towns remain small, sometimes with less than 100 residents. These residents are the ones that have to foot the tax bill to fix or upgrade infrastructure like roads, water and waste water systems, schools, and emergency responders. In many cases, they simply do not have the resources. There is a real need to find practical solutions to balance the needs of our gateway communities.  
￼
Hearing testimony from community leaders and the Yellowstone National Park Superindendent
What's Next:  The official hearing I held in Gardiner is just the beginning of the conversation. As Chairman of the National Parks Subcommittee I will continue to work to find real solutions to real problems. Our National Parks are treasures and the communities that serve them are the first impressions visitors have. We need to make sure they have the tools they need to serve their residents and the millions of visitors that travel to and through them each year.  
Survey:
Do you believe the Federal Government needs to support our gateway communities? 
Yes
No

Subject: Sen. Collins Authors Law to Prohibit Pharmacy "Gag Clauses"; Attends Bridge Dedication for Cpl. Cole; Joins Celebration of New Simulation Center at NMCC; and More
Message:
Can't see the images? Make sure your e-mail is set to download pictures in order to see the full content of this e-newsletter  ￼ 

￼   ￼   ￼   ￼ 
Item 2
October 30, 2018 


Bipartisan Bills Authored by Senator Collins to Prohibit Pharmacy “Gag Clauses” are Signed into Law
The bipartisan legislation bans an egregious practice that can conceal lower prices from consumers, causing them to needlessly overpay 
Last fall, Senator Collins was troubled to learn from a group of Maine pharmacists about a practice that can conceal the least costly way to purchase a prescription drug. Known as “gag clauses,” these terms included in some contracts between insurance companies or their pharmacy benefit managers and pharmacies actually prohibit pharmacists from telling consumers if their prescription would cost less if they paid for it out of pocket rather than using their insurance. A recent study of 9.5 million insurance claims found that nearly one out of four prescriptions filled through insurance ended up costing more for customers than if they had paid out of pocket.  
￼
Senator Collins, who has made increasing the affordability and accessibility of prescription drugs one of her top priorities, worked with Senators Claire McCaskill (D-MO) and Debbie Stabenow (D-MI) to author bipartisan legislation to ban the use of pharmacy gag clauses. Earlier this month, their bills, the Know the Lowest Price Act and the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act, were signed into law.   “Insurance is intended to save consumers money. Gag clauses in contracts that prohibit pharmacists from telling patients about the best prescription drug prices do the opposite,” said Senator Collins. “Who would think that using your debit card to buy your prescription drugs would be less expensive than using your insurance card? It’s counterintuitive. Americans have the right to know which payment method provides the most savings when purchasing their prescription drugs. I am delighted that my legislation to help increase transparency and reduce the cost of prescription drugs received overwhelming bipartisan support and is now law.”   Click HERE to learn more about Senator Collins’ legislation. 
￼ 
Senator Collins Joins Norridgewock Community in Honoring Corporal Eugene Cole
￼ 
Senator Collins joined the community of Norridgewock at a bridge dedication ceremony to honor Somerset County Sheriff’s Deputy Corporal Eugene Cole, who was killed in the line of duty in April. Senator Collins, along with members of Corporal Cole’s family, law enforcement, and local and state leaders, delivered remarks paying tribute to the fallen police officer. The Cole family also led a procession across the bridge and unveiled signs memorializing Corporal Cole.   “It was an honor to join Corporal Cole’s family, friends, colleagues, and community to dedicate a bridge in his name in Norridgewock,” said Senator Collins. “Corporal Cole served the citizens of Somerset County for 13 years with commitment, compassion, and valor. The dedication of a bridge in his name is a fitting tribute. For generations to come, all who pass over it will be reminded of his dedication to others. May God bless Corporal Cole and all who step forward to protect and to serve.” 
￼ 
Ribbon Cutting for Northern Maine Community College Simulation Center
￼ 
“Collins helps mark celebration of simulation and tech centers at NMCC”  The County  
￼
￼
“U.S. Sen. Susan Collins gave brief remarks Friday during a ribbon cutting ceremony for the new allied health simulation center at Northern Maine Community College and also visited the precision machining technology lab.   “‘Today’s ribbon cutting ceremony is more than a landmark moment for health care education in our state,’ Collins said in her remarks. ‘It’s about the values of optimism, hard work, and community found at Northern Maine Community College.’   “The simulation center, located on the second story of the Christie Complex on NMCC’s Presque Isle campus, provides ‘the highest quality clinical experience for students and current health care professionals,’ she said.   …  
￼
“Collins toured the new facility and also visited a class at the college’s precision machining technology lab.   “‘The faculty and staff at Northern Maine Community College are dedicated to creating opportunities for students in Aroostook County and throughout Maine, and I congratulate them on this outstanding accomplishment,’ Collins said.   “The senator helped secure funding for the machining technology program that allowed NMCC to become Maine’s first and only HAAS Technical Education Center, according to a press release issued by Collins’ office. The college’s collaborative relationship with HAAS Automation, Inc., affords students access to state-of-the-art machine tools to support training in both entry-level and advanced machining processes...”   Click HERE to read the full story on The County’s website. 
￼
Senator Collins Delivers Keynote Address at the Aroostook Agency on Aging Annual Meeting in Caribou
￼
Senator Collins, the Chairman of the Senate Aging Committee, delivered the keynote address at the Aroostook Agency on Aging’s Annual Meeting at the Caribou Inn and Convention Center. Approximately 130 people attended the event, including Board Members, community members, organization staff, volunteers, community partners, donors, and municipal leaders.  
￼
“Recent Census data confirm Maine is the oldest state in the nation, and Aroostook County has a higher median age than the rest of our state. We are working together to build a shared vision for aging that is centered on health, wellness, and community,” said Senator Collins. “The Aroostook Agency on Aging is dedicated to empowering our seniors to stay in the homes and communities they love, for as long as possible, in safety and security. There is truly no place like home, and your commitment, energy, and compassion make it possible.”   Senator Collins has made it a priority to improve health and wellbeing to enable aging in place; stop fraud and financial exploitation targeting seniors; lower the soaring cost of prescription drugs; improve financial security for retirement; and increase funding for biomedical research for diseases and illnesses such as diabetes, heart disease, cancer, and Alzheimer’s.   A non-profit serving Aroostook County since 1972, the Aroostook Agency on Aging’s mission is to improve the quality of life, maximize the independence, and promote the well-being of older individuals in northern Maine. 
￼
Sweeping Opioids Package Becomes Law, Includes Key Provisions Authored by Senator Collins
In response to the opioid epidemic that is claiming the lives of tens of thousands of Americans and hundreds of Mainers each year, the bipartisan SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act was signed into law this week after being passed by overwhelming margins in Congress. Senator Collins, a member of the Senate Health Committee, authored two of the provisions that were included in the final legislation and cosponsored several others.   Congress has appropriated $8.5 billion this year towards fighting the opioid crisis. The SUPPORT Act will help states and communities expand access to addiction treatment, encourage evidence-based prevention strategies, and improve detection and seizure of illegal drugs like fentanyl.   “It is imperative that we work together to combat the opioid crisis, which killed 418 people in Maine last year and led to nearly 1,000 babies being born addicted to opioids and other drugs in our state alone,” said Senator Collins. “I am pleased that my bipartisan proposals to allow the safe disposal of unwanted drugs in hospice and bolster peer support networks were included in this comprehensive legislation. By supporting prevention, treatment, and recovery, this all-of-the-above approach will provide vital assistance to individuals and families who are struggling with addiction.”   Click HERE to learn more about the SUPPORT Act and Senator Collins’ provisions. 
￼ 
Senator Collins Secures Largest-Ever Increase for Alzheimer’s Research
Following a concerted push by Senator Collins, a senior member of the Appropriations Committee and a founder and co-chair of the Congressional Task Force on Alzheimer’s disease, Congress passed and the President signed into law a $425 million increase for Alzheimer’s research—the largest increase in history—which brings the country’s total investment to $2.34 billion for fiscal year 2019. This amount surpasses the $2 billion per year experts have said is needed to prevent and treat Alzheimer’s by the year 2025.  
￼
“We have made tremendous progress in recent years to boost funding for biomedical research, and this legislation builds on that momentum by providing the largest-ever increase for Alzheimer’s, exceeding our $2 billion goal,” said Senator Collins. “I have long championed increased investments for Alzheimer’s, which hold great promise for putting an end to this disease that has a devastating effect on millions of Americans and their families. I am encouraged by the sustained, bipartisan commitment for this research.”   Due to Alzheimer’s exorbitant human and financial costs, fighting the disease is one of Senator Collins’ top priorities. More than five million people across America—and about 28,000 in Maine—are living with Alzheimer’s. In addition, Alzheimer's and other dementias cost our nation an estimated $277 billion a year, including $186 billion in costs to Medicare and Medicaid. If we remain on our current trajectory, nearly 14 million seniors are projected to be living with Alzheimer’s in 2050, and the cost will surpass $1.1 trillion annually. 




OFFICE OF SENATOR SUSAN COLLINS  
413 Dirksen Senate Office Building Washington, D.C. 20510 Phone: (202) 224-2523 Fax: (202) 224-2693

Subject: On track for the best economy since 2005!
Message:
￼ 
  

On track for the best economy since 2005!

Dear Lindsey,
Individuals and families in the Second District and across the country have been seeing the benefits of our pro-growth agenda, including the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and various regulatory reforms. Hard-working taxpayers are finally able to keep substantial savings for vacations, education, or even an extra trip to the grocery store, thanks to increasing paychecks and economic growth.
In the most recent example of our country’s increasing prosperity, our economy grew at the fastest back-to-back pace in 4 years! Growing at an annualized rate of 3.5%, our GDP grew at a faster rate than expected, reflecting a healthy job market and high consumer confidence. Our economy is on track to have the best year of growth since 2005.
As our economy continues to expand, employees are thriving across the board as well. According to the Wall Street Journal, in the second quarter of this year low-income workers saw earnings 5% higher than the same period last year, in addition to expanded benefits and bonuses.
Job opportunities are also on the rise, as the national unemployment level hit 3.7% in September—the lowest it’s been in almost 50 years! Here in Minnesota our unemployment rate is now at 2.8%. Minnesotans are finding jobs and filling much-needed positions as businesses continue to expand and grow thanks to a competitive and nurturing economic environment spurred by nationwide reinvestment in local companies.
Reinvestment in local businesses not only shows that people have more money to spend, but it shows that our country’s consumers have enough confidence in their current fiscal situation to invest more of their money in goods and services.
Implementing good policy that delivers fiscal relief to Americans is the catalyst, but economic optimism and reinvestment is what keeps our economy strong. I’m proud to work on behalf of members of the Second District to help you keep more of your hard-earned money.
As I work on this and other issues, I always like to hear directly from you.  Please share any thoughts you may have through my website, and sign up for my e-mail newsletter for the latest updates from Washington, D.C. and around the district. You can also stay on top of my work by following my Facebook and Twitter pages. Please feel free to call my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2271 or my local Burnsville office at 651-846-2120 with any comments or for assistance with a federal agency.

Sincerely, 
￼
Jason Lewis
Member of Congress

Subject: quick update:
Message:
￼ 
Lindsey – We’ve thankfully come a long way since the 2008 economic crisis. But I know we still have so much more to do.

Today, many folks just aren’t earning enough to make ends meet. Health care keeps getting more expensive and paychecks aren’t keeping up. New technology and an interconnected world means our economy is increasingly changing, and we have to do a better job of keeping up. 

We need to help everyone get ahead in our economy. That’s why I’ve worked to make a positive impact in people’s lives by supporting crucial infrastructure projects, new jobs, and local businesses. 

I’m pleased to say we’ve delivered results to give area families and our economy a boost. Here’s a quick update on how we’re Making Government Work for Sacramento County: 


Rebuilding Our Infrastructure: 

￼
I saw the latest progress on infrastructure upgrades being made to the Folsom Dam earlier this year, which I’ve long voted to support.

To create jobs and build an economy that works for the middle class, we need to invest in our infrastructure. I’ve worked to help rebuild infrastructure that will modernize our economy, help local businesses, and make our communities safer.

• Upgrading the Folsom Dam: I’ve consistently voted to support major upgrades at the Folsom Dam. Formally known as the Joint Federal Project, these upgrades include building a brand new auxiliary spillway and other significant improvements. Many upgrades are underway or have been recently completed.

This project has brought hundreds of new jobs to our region and infused tens of millions of dollars into our local economy. Ultimately, it will let the Folsom Dam store more water and give it the ability to release water more safely and strategically. This could help with future droughts and provide better flood protection. 

• Strengthening our levees: I voted to fortify the Natomas levees to keep our communities safe and create new jobs. The bipartisan Water Reform, Resources, and Development Act, which is now law, authorized federal support for the Natomas Levee Improvement Project. Thanks in part to these efforts, the Army Corps of Engineers has now completed miles of levee repairs to protect Sacramento County.

• Improving the Mather Airport: I helped secure millions of dollars to upgrade Mather Airport, which is a vital part of Sacramento County’s aviation and cargo infrastructure. Among many improvements, these grants will help resurface pavement on the runway and upgrade drainage systems to improve safety and efficiency.


Creating jobs

￼
I recently had the pleasure of touring the Siemens facility in Florin, which supports hundreds of local manufacturing jobs.

• Supporting manufacturing jobs: I was proud to be a part of bringing hundreds of high-skilled jobs to Sacramento by helping with a contract between the Rail Division of Siemens and the U.S. Department of Transportation. Thanks in part to this contract, Siemens’ Florin facility has continued to build new, high-performance diesel-electric locomotives for public transit systems around the country.

• Hiring more firefighters and first responders: I helped secure more than $5 million in federal homeland security funding to hire and train first responders, secure regional transit, and help high-risk community organizations build their preparedness. Thanks to these funds, the Cosumnes Fire Department is finally able to hire eight new firefighters.


Supporting local businesses

￼
Visiting Green Acres Nursery & Supply in Elk Grove, a family owned business. They created 85 new jobs in part because of the help they received from the Small Business Administration.

Instead of being an obstacle, government should be a strategic partner with businesses to help them grow and hire. I’ve seen how hard our local businesses work and am committed to doing all that I can to support them and help bring new jobs to our region.

• New Small Business Development Center: I fought to bring a new small business development center to Elk Grove. This center provides technical assistance for local small business owners including help to create business plans, access to low cost loans from the Small Business Administration, and more. My office has held several workshops for small business owners to connect them with resources and help.

￼
At the grand opening of the Small Business Development Center in Elk Grove.

• Connecting local businesses with federal contracting: The federal government procures thousands of contracts with private businesses on a range of services – from food, to printer ink, to jet engines. This can be an incredible growth opportunity. My office helped bring new federal resources to our community to assist local businesses in competing for government contracts.


My job is to serve you – regardless of the politics – and to put people’s needs ahead of special interests. I’m proud of how my staff and I have made a positive impact for local families – you can learn more about it in my office’s new special report.

It’s an honor to serve you in Congress. Please feel free to contact me at any time to ask a question or share your views.

Be well,
￼
Ami Bera, M.D.
Member of Congress
P.S. Your thoughtful suggestions always help my office do a better job of serving you.

Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
 
￼

October 30, 2018 

 
Upcoming Events
Manchin Mobile Monday  
Every Monday, my staff members are available in easily accessed locations across the state to assist with constituent services and to take your thoughts and concerns directly back to me.  Below are next week's times and locations for Monday, November 5.       
       
Poca:            
Poca Community Library  
2858 Charleston Road 
Time: 1:30 p.m. - 3 p.m.     
Staff: Brian Aluise 
     
Morgantown:     
Morgantown Public Library  
373 Spruce Street
Time: 11 a.m. – 1 p.m.   
Staff: Michael Garcia  

To invite the Senator to your event, click here. 



  
 





























Manchin's Mountain Message
Hinton Railroad Festival  
I’m so glad the Collis P. Huntington Railroad Historical Society had another great and successful Hinton Railroad Days Festival. Every year, the New River Train adds an estimated $5 million to West Virginia’s economy. When Amtrak announced they would be ending the services, I brought both parties together to ensure that we would not lose the New River Train.  Since then, I have kept in touch with both parties and included language in this year’s Transportation Appropriations bill to make sure that Collis P. Huntington can stay open this year and beyond.  Hundreds of thousands of West Virginians and people from out of state enjoy this festival every year, and I will continue to work to make sure that it goes on for years to come.  Be sure to mark your calendars for next year's festival!
The annual festival is hosted by the Collis P. Huntington Railroad Historical Society, a 59-year old non-profit organization that operates private railroad cars through Amtrak. 
This April, Amtrak announced it would no longer accept private and charter trains, which the Collis P. Huntington Railroad Historical Society uses for the Hinton Railroad Days Festival. After bringing together Amtrak and the Collis P. Huntington Society to explain the adverse impact this new policy would have on West Virginia communities, Senator Manchin helped broker a deal to continue providing service for the Hinton Railroad Days Festival. 
 
On the Road
Last week I had the pleasure of speaking at the Executive Seminar for West Liberty University about leadership and ways to make a difference in our communities. I appreciate everyone in attendance for your excellent questions! 
 ￼
Senator Manchin speaks at West Liberty University. 
  
One of my Regional Coordinators, Brian Aluise, attended a celebration for Wilbur "Bud" Cassell for his dedicated work with the Cass Scenic Railroad State Park for the last 55 years. Other than when he enlisted in the Army, Bud has lived in the beautiful Town of Cass all his life. He is a treasure within the state park system and if you're ever visiting the park, make sure to pay him a visit. 
￼ 
Brian Aluise attends the celebration for Bud Cassell for 55 years of service with the Cass Scenic Railroad State Park. 
  
Key Federal Resources
When West Virginians compete, they win. 
Below are a few grants that were recently awarded through the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA).  I encourage West Virginia communities to apply for federal funding opportunities, and will be happy to provide a letter of support for eligible applications.  For further information, please contact my Martinsburg office at 304-264-4626 or click here to email me. 
	•	West Virginia University, USDA, NIFA, Food Safety Outreach Program grant award will be used for The WV C.H.I.P. (Commercial/Home/Incubator-kitchens and Food Producers) Project.  It will allow for statewide Food Safety Modernization Act efforts and food producer services to expand to other agricultural service providers - including commercial/ home/incubator-kitchens & food producers.  This Project aims to address a knowledge gap in labeling, processing, and local supply chains by developing a hands-on experience in food hub activities from production, processing, labeling, marketing and distribution of local foods.  - $148,462.00 grant.
	•	West Virginia University, USDA, NIFA, Organic Transitions Program grant award will be used for the purpose of overcoming barriers to transitioning small ruminants to organic production: Effects of feeding birdsfoot trefoil on parasite control, nutritional status and profitability.  Small ruminants provide a profitable niche for organic growers.  However, certain intestinal parasites, specifically gastrointestinal nematode infections, are the major factor limiting organic production.  - $499,817.00 grant.
  
	•	
  
To learn more, call my office Toll Free at (855) 275-5737, email me,or find me on social media:

Subject: Standing for those with dyslexia and more in this eNewsletter...
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼  
￼
WEBSITE | ABOUT | CONTACT | ISSUES | MEDIA CENTER | SERVICES
Congressman Bruce Westerman’s eNewsletter Tuesday, October 30, 2018
￼
￼
WASHINGTON – Congressman Bruce Westerman (AR-04), along with 16 bipartisan co-sponsors, introduced a House resolution Tuesday (October 30) which would designate October as “National Dyslexia Awareness Month.”
“Dyslexia is a learning disability which affects one out of every five individuals,” Westerman said. “It is important for schools, state and local educational agencies, and Congress to recognize the significant implications that accompany dyslexia. It is my hope that this bipartisan House resolution raises awareness of America’s most common learning disability and highlights the need for continued research into effective interventions.”
The following Members of Congress are original co-sponsors of this bill: Debbie Wasserman Schultz (FL-23), Julia Brownley (CA-26), Larry Buschon (IN-08), Ted Deutch (FL-22), French Hill (AR-02), Derek Kilmer (WA-06), Sheila Jackson Lee (TX-18), Zoe Lofgren (CA-19), Jim McGovern (MA-02), Jerry McNerney (CA-09), Seth Moulton (MA-06), Rick Nolan (MN-06), Eleanor Holmes Norton (DC-At Large), Steven Palazzo (MS-04), Mark Takano (CA-41), and Kevin Yoder (KS-03).
Westerman was recently named a co-chair of the Congressional Dyslexia Caucus. Brownley is the Caucus’ other co-chair. In the 114th Congress, Westerman co-sponsored H.R. 3033, the READ Act, which authorizes multi-directorate, merit-reviewed, and competitively awarded dyslexia research projects using funds appropriated for the National Science Foundation Research and Related Activities account and the Education and Human Resources Directorate. The legislation was signed into law February 18, 2016.
