Subject: Getting My Marching Orders, Stopping the Caravan, & More
Message:
Having trouble viewing this email? View it as a Web page.
￼ 
Website                          Media Center                        Contact Me
Dear Friend,   Thank you for the opportunity to update you on the work of the 115th Congress. I trust this finds you and your family well, as we work together to bring Hoosier common sense to Washington.

In This Week's Rokita Report
	•	Frankfort Town Hall
	•	Stopping The Caravan
	•	America's Safe Schools Week
Recent Photos
￼
Indiana thrives because of its family values and the time we spend with our loved ones. Kathy, Teddy, Ryan, and I had a great time as a family picking pumpkins at Beasley’s Orchard in Danville.
￼
Like many Hoosier families, Ryan and I love fishing together. Ryan was excited to catch his biggest fish of the season. I see how fishing teaches him the importance of patience and hard work. 
￼
As the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education, I visited Beverly Hills High School to learn about their school safety routine. 

Frankfort Town Hall
￼
On October 21, 2018, I had the privilege of meeting with constituents at my Frankfort Town Hall. During my eight years in Congress, I have been proud to serve and fight for all Hoosiers so they can build better for themselves and their families.  
I have enjoyed representing Hoosiers in Washington, but my favorite part of the job has been traveling over 125,000 miles throughout the 4th District to meet with all of you over the years. It is my constituents who give me my marching orders. It is always an honor to meet and speak to all of you who come to my events and voice your opinion.  
I want to thank everyone who came out to the Frankfort Town Hall to discuss the issues most important to you. A wide variety of issues were discussed, including health care, the Farm Bill, and immigration. Local issues, like the need for a weather radar in the district for safety purposes, were also brought to my attention.  
I learn so much by talking to each of you. I will take what we discussed there and bring it back to Washington. It has been the honor of a lifetime serving my constituents, and I will continue to fight on your behalf until my last day in office.  
Stopping The Caravan
The caravan making its way to America is around 7,000 strong and about 1,000 miles away from our border. A nation is only sovereign if it has secure borders. I applaud President Trump’s leadership in taking a strong stance to protect our border from the caravan. In recent days, President Trump has announced that he is deploying hundreds of soldiers to our southern border to stop these illegal immigrants. 
For too long, our immigration laws have been ignored. We have allowed millions of people to come here illegally and seek asylum in sanctuary cities. I have been a strong proponent of tougher immigration laws by introducing the SLAP Act, which would punish any elected official in a sanctuary city who refuses to comply with our immigration law. Until we build the wall, illegal immigrants will continue to threaten our security and the integrity of our laws. 
America's Safe Schools Week
As the Chairman of the House Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education, I understand the importance of cultivating a safe environment for our children to learn and grow. Our children's well-being is of utmost importance, and it should be a priority to equip professionals entrusted with our students' lives with the tools they need to keep our children safe.
I believe that we need to continue to come together as a community of professionals and learn best practices to keep our children out of harm’s way. I have hosted School Safety Summits in the past, and I look forward to my upcoming summit to speak with law enforcement and other education professionals on the skills and tools we need to further protect our students. 





In Case you Missed it
	•	Rokita Stands By Israel
	•	Rokita Receives American Spirit Award
	•	Rokita Delivers Hurricane Michael Relief
	•	US World's Most Competitive Economy Again
 

Thank you for your continued interest in Congress and for supporting my efforts to bring Hoosier common sense to Washington. Take care.
Sincerely,
￼

Subject: Solutions to Combat the Opioid Crisis
Message:
￼ 
  

SOLUTIONS TO COMBAT THE OPIOID CRISIS

This week, President Trump signed into law our bipartisan package designed to combat the opioid epidemic. Included in the package were three bills I introduced. My bills help patients receive treatment for addiction through telemedicine, remove barriers to abuse deterrent medications, and provide pharmacists with tools to address fraud, forgery and abuse.

Overall the legislation, the SUPPORT Act, works to combat the opioid crisis by addressing prevention, advancing treatment and recovery initiatives, and improving efforts to fight illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl. 

I am excited and proud that this package was signed into law. While working with members on both sides of the aisle to create these solutions to combat this crisis, I learned from constituents, colleagues, and others that everyone and every community has been impacted by this epidemic in some way. 

For me, as a pharmacist for more than 30 years, I saw addiction end careers and ruin lives and families. That is what has driven me to work so hard on this legislation to address prescription drug abuse while ensuring those who truly need the medications maintain access to it. 

It is great news this package is now law, and I am committed to continuing this strong bipartisan work to end this crisis once and for all.

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CLXXXV

Monday, October 22, 2018:  Finally, this past weekend we enjoyed fall like temperatures!  I took full advantage of it beginning on Saturday as I headed to Hinesville in Liberty County for the First Presbyterian Christian Academy’s annual fall festival.  One of the highlights of this great family event is the chili cook-off challenge as I tasted all the entries and am glad I didn’t volunteer to judge because they were all delicious. 
￼
Rep. Carter at the FPCA Chili Cook-off
Afterwards, I headed to Delegal Marina at the Landings in Savannah for the annual Sons of the American Revolution Oyster Roast as I was a guest of my good friend Frank Hardeman.  Oyster roasts are great anytime in Coastal Georgia but when the weather starts to turn cooler, there’s nothing better.  On Sunday, I stopped by Bible Baptist Church in Savannah for their annual Friend Day and enjoyed seeing the many family events they had set up as well as the music of Sounds of Liberty.  Later in the afternoon, I enjoyed meeting with constituents in Ardsley Park in Savannah.  This morning, I’m in downtown Savannah as I have the pleasure of meeting with Savannah’s new police chief, Roy Minter.  Chief Minter is an intelligent, articulate man who brings a wealth of experience to the job and I am certain he will do an excellent job.  Next, I head to Rincon for the Effingham County Chamber of Commerce Business Summit where, along with my Congressional colleague from the 12th District, Rep. Rick Allen (R-GA), I bring the group up to date on Washington issues. 
￼
Rep. Carter speaking at the Effingham County Chamber of Commerce Business Summit
Afterwards, I head to the offices of the Savannah Morning News where I meet with the editorial board.  Later, I meet with members of the Savannah Homebuilders Association before heading out to Tybee Island where I meet with constituents.
Tuesday, October 23, 2018:  I’m on Hutchinson Island in Savannah bright and early this morning for the Georgia Chamber of Commerce Statewide Tour and have the opportunity to address this great group of business leaders and bring them up to date on Washington issues.  Afterwards, I head across the river for the Eastern Wharf groundbreaking.  This long awaited project promises to be a great addition to the River Street area and will add to the vibrancy and beauty of downtown Savannah.
￼
Rep. Carter at the Eastern Wharf groundbreaking ceremony
Next, I head to my Savannah district office where I meet with Dr. Van Crisco of Intent Solutions to learn more about the exciting technology that this start-up company is developing.  Afterwards, I meet with Jared Hall, a musician in Savannah with the Recording Academy which represents performers, songwriters and studio professionals across the country and in the district.  After a great meeting where we discuss policy issues important to music creators, I head to Derst Baking Company, the oldest continuous manufacturing business in Savannah.  Now owned by Flowers Foods out of Thomasville, GA, Derst Baking Company was founded in Savannah in 1867 by Captain John Derst who was a Captain with the Savannah Fire Department.  Captain Derst fought in the Civil War but, after being injured, walked from Atlanta to Savannah where he went to work for the Fire Department and opened a small bakery. 
￼
Rep. Carter touring Derst Baking Company
Today, Captain John Derst’s Old Fashion Bread as well as other baked goods from the company can be found throughout the Southeast.  My final stop of the day is in downtown Savannah where I meet with constituents.
Wednesday, October 24, 2018:  I’m out on Wilmington Island early this morning for a meeting with constituents before heading to the airport and flying to Alma in Bacon County to meet with constituents.  Afterwards, I head to Waycross in Ware County where I meet with constituents before heading to Offerman in Pierce County to also meet with constituents.  My final two stops meeting with constituents are in Jesup in Wayne County and Ludowici in Long County before I head back to Savannah.  On my way back to Savannah I have a phone interview with a student from the University of Mississippi College of Pharmacy to discuss how I became involved in the political process and how other pharmacists can become involved.
Thursday, October 25, 2018:  I have the honor this morning of speaking to the Coastal Law Enforcement Officers Association in Pooler and bringing them up to date on law enforcement issues in Washington, including the opioid legislation that was signed into law yesterday by President Trump.  
￼
Rep. Carter speaking at the Coastal Law Enforcement Officers Association meeting
The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act is a combination of 58 bills that were passed out of the Energy and Commerce Committee that I serve on and address the opioid epidemic.  I sponsored three of these bills and, while there is no silver bullet that will cure this epidemic by itself, these bills will help tremendously.  Afterwards, I head to Jekyll Island in Glynn County for the annual Brunswick State of the Port Address where we hear of the great progress that continues at the number two roll on- roll off-port in our country.  Combined with the great leadership from the Georgia Ports Authority, everyone in attendance is reminded that the success of this great port can be largely attributed to the dedicated workforce that takes so much pride in their work.  Afterwards, I head back to Savannah and during the drive I have a phone interview with a student from the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism before heading to the airport for a trip to Houston, TX, where I will be the keynote speaker at the Pharmacy Compounding Centers of America (PCCA) annual meeting.
Friday, October 26, 2018:   PCCA is headquartered in Houston and provides more than 3,200 independent community compounding pharmacy members across the United States and worldwide with drug compounding ingredients, equipment, education and assistance. 
￼
Rep. Carter speaking to PCCA
I work closely with this group on their issues in Washington and have great respect for the important work they do for their patients and the services they provide.  I am honored to have the opportunity this morning to address the group and bring them up to date on issues in Washington.  Afterwards, I head to Shenandoah, TX, for a tour of The Woodlands Compounding Pharmacy owned and run by Jasper and Keisha Lovoi that specializes in preparing customized compounded medications.  After learning about the wide range of services that this state of the art facility provides and touring their impressive lab, I head to the airport for my return trip home.

Subject: Opportunities for Third District Youth
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: October 27, 2018  
￼ 
I enjoyed this beautiful Nebraska sunrise on my way to Kearney High School last week. 
 
Opportunities for Third District Youth 
As I travel the Third District and visit our schools, I never cease to be amazed at the intelligence and drive of our students. Their informed curiosity over key issues facing our country has left a particularly strong impression on me this summer and it is this curiosity I seek to nurture through my outreach efforts.   College students interested in gaining firsthand experience in the legislative process are invited to apply for an internship with one of my offices during the spring, summer, or fall. Interns are provided the opportunity to assist with constituent services, attend events, and work side-by-side with my staff on policy issues.  Another way I interact regularly with students is through the Third District Youth Advisory Council, which is open to high school juniors and seniors. Through in-person meetings, Facebook forums, and conference calls, I meet with this group throughout the school year to discuss the matters they find most important. Applications for the 2019-2020 school year will open in the spring.  I also take great pleasure in welcoming school groups to Washington, D.C. on the steps of our nation’s capital. From 4-H groups to Close-Up programs and others, the summer is the busiest time of year for these visits. If you have a group of young people who would like to visit Washington, D.C., my office is always available to assist in arranging tours of the Capitol, White House, and other national sites.  For White House tours, I encourage your group to contact my office three months in advance to comply with its security protocols.   As a young person, my interest in politics was sparked by my grandfather who served as a Seabee during World War II and it is because of him that I cherish our responsibility to bring the next generation of Nebraskans into civic participation. If you know someone who would be interested in applying for an internship with my office, please encourage them to do so.   I welcome active engagement from Third District students of all ages and always appreciate hearing their ideas for America’s future.    
Meet with Me This Week
I'll be holding mobile offices in Chadron and Sidney this week to meet with constituents and discuss important issues such as the Farm Bill, trade, and tax reform. I hope you'll join me. 
Monday, October 29 
Dawes County Mobile Office Dawes County Courthouse – Downstairs Courtroom 451 Main Street, Chadron 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. MDT  Tuesday, October 30 
Cheyenne County Mobile Office Cheyenne County Courthouse – Commissioners Room  1000 10th Avenue, Sidney 1:30 p.m. to 2:30 p.m. MDT 
If you have any questions about these events, please contact my Grand Island office at (308) 384-3900 or my Scottsbluff office at (308) 633-6333.  As always, feel free to forward my e-newsletter to family and friends, or let them know they can sign up to receive updates from my office on my website at AdrianSmith.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  ADRIAN SMITH Member of Congress

Subject: Opioid Legislation Passed, Wage Growth and More!
Message:
Click here to forward this email    Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window    Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A message from Georgia's 6th Congressional District
￼

Home
About District 6
How Can I Help?
Issues
Newsroom
Contact


 
October 27, 2018
President Trump Signs Vital Opioid Legislation into Law!
This week, President Trump, with First Lady Melania Trump by his side, made an incredible announcement ... H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, was signed into law! This legislation included more than 70 initiatives to address this crisis that is affecting far too many families here in the 6th District and across the nation. Specifically, this new law: 
	•	Will help stop the flow of fentanyl into the US by requiring the US Postal Service to obtain the same basic information from all international shippers that is already required of private shippers like FedEx;
	•	 Expands treatment options by expanding Medicare coverage of medically-assisted addiction treatment and easing some of the federal restrictions on Medicaid funds used for residential treatment centers with more than 16 beds;
	•	Provides significant new resources in federal grants for additional awareness, prevention, treatment, and long-term recovery.
While new reports just out this week indicate that number of fatal drug overdoses has fallen for six consecutive months, these new resources and reforms will help ensure that we continue to make progress. One life lost to opioid addiction is one too many.
American Wages Growing and Rising Faster
A stronger economy has been fueled by tax cuts and regulatory reforms, and this stronger economy means greater opportunities for all Americans.
In fact, the lowest-income earners are seeing a rise in wages. The bottom 10% of full-time salary and wage workers have seen an average of 4.9% annual growth over the past 4 quarters. Wages are just one part of a worker’s overall compensation package. Benefits and bonuses matter too. That’s why it is so encouraging to see companies continuing give bonuses and expand employee benefits.
In September, unemployment dipped to its lowest since 1969. We continue to have more job openings than people actually looking for work. 
You can see the Joint Economic Committee’s full report by clicking here. 
Just In: 3rd Quarter GDP is 3.5%
This week, the Bureau of Economic Analysis announced that GDP growth for the 3rd Quarter hit 3.5%. This continues the strong growth trend following the enactment of tax cuts earlier this year. As the holiday season approaches, consumer confidence remains at its highest in decades.
Honored to Stand with the Johns Creek Veterans
￼ 
What a great evening catching up with the veterans of Johns Creek and the Johns Creek Veterans Association’s monthly meeting. One of the most important aspects of any congressional office is the casework — our work to help the every day citizens of the district. We’ve handled hundreds of cases in the past year and a half, with about 20% of that casework focused on helping our veterans.
If you or a loved one could use assistance navigating the VA, we are honored to help you. We are here to help you and your family with any issue related to the federal government. 

 ￼ 
It was awesome to get the chance to meet with two groups of Girl Scouts this week. Hmmm...could there be a future Congresswoman among these bright young ladies?! 

Thank you for taking the time to read this note. To stay current on what's going on in Congress, please follow me on Facebook by clicking here or visiting Facebook.com/RepKarenHandel. If you find this update helpful, please take a second to forward it along to a few of your friends and neighbors.  
In addition, because of rules from the House of Representatives, I will not be able to conduct live tele-town halls after August 8th through Election Day. As always, feel free to call (202) 225-4501 or (770) 998-0049 if you need assistance from me or anyone in my office.

Sincerely, ￼  Karen C. Handel Member of Congress

Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you. 
Sincerely, ￼  Warren Davidson Member of Congress 
Ohio Work Week
Congressman Warren Davidson is working from Ohio this week as Congress is not in Session.  
On Monday, Congressman Davidson toured the high-tech facilities of 80 Acres Farms in Cincinnati. The firm recently broke ground on a new indoor farming facility in Hamilton that will grow and sell fresh produce. 
On Tuesday, Congressman Davidson was invited to speak at Midwest Electric's Political Action Breakfast. He spoke with attendees about the current economy and the opioid crisis. Read more here.  
On Thursday, Congressman Davidson was invited to Springfield to speak at the Clark County Jail Chaplaincy Breakfast. He spoke about the importance of second chances and work opportunities for those reentering the workforce. Later in the day Congressman Davidson was invited to speak at a groundbreaking ceremony for the new Spooky Nook Sports Complex in Hamilton. The new complex will be one of the biggest in the world. 
On Friday, Congressman Davidson spoke at a luncheon hosted by the Springfield Chamber of Commerce. He gave attendees an update about issues in Washington. 
The following is a picture of Congressman Davidson speaking at the Midwest Electric breakfast. 
￼ 
￼
Mail Package Bomber, New Opioids Law
On Wednesday, Congressman Davidson reacted to news about the mail package bomber on his Facebook page. 
On Thursday, President Trump signed a new Opioids law. Congressman Davidson said he was pleased President Trump signed the legislation and that the law is good news for Butler, Preble, Darke Mercer, Miami, and Clark Counties and help efforts to combat the opioid epidemic gripping the state. He went on to say that we all have a part to play in rising up and compassionately defeating this crisis.

Subject: Let's Do Our Part to End Political Violence
Message:
￼ 
Website  |   About  |   Contact Me  |   Serving You  |   Media Center  |   Legislative Work  |   Our District  |   Resources 
  

October 27, 2018
THE SCALISE CAPITOL REPORT
Let's Do Our Part to End Political Violence These past few weeks we've seen reports of Republican officials being physically assaulted, and Democrat leaders being targeted with mail-bombs. Thankfully, a suspect has been caught in the mail-bomb attacks. Once again, the men and women of our law enforcement community have proven that they are the best in the world, and I join President Trump in expressing my sincere gratitude to them for their swift apprehension of the man suspected of these acts of terror. Let this serve as another reminder that threats and violence have absolutely no place in American politics, or anywhere else in our society.  The violence and threats that we have seen run in direct contradiction to the free exchange of ideas and perspectives that is so vital to the health of our great democracy. If we are to stem the tide of violent acts and violent rhetoric, then it is crucial we all do our part to break down the divisions in our country and remember always to treat those with different beliefs than our own with the same respect that we would treat our neighbor who might disagree with us.
Read more of my thoughts on this growing problem in an op-ed I wrote for FoxNews.com by clicking here. Click here to watch as I discuss this on Tucker Carlson Tonight.

￼
 Meeting with Louisiana businesses I was excited to meet recently with Louisiana businesses during a conference hosted by the Louisiana Association of Business and Industry (LABI). Small businesses are the backbone of Louisiana’s economy, and we discussed issues ranging from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that was enacted earlier this year, to the success we’ve had in Congress working with President Trump in rolling back unnecessary, costly, job-killing regulations in Washington. The latest economic news continues to confirm that Republican pro-growth reforms are working to create high-paying jobs and get this country back on the right track. Just last week, the World Economic Forum ranked the U.S. economy as the most competitive in the world! The benefits to hard-working families are clear, and wages have continued to go up. This summer we saw pay and benefits increasing at the fastest pace in 10 years! We need to keep this growth going, and as your Congressman, I will continue fighting to advance a bold vision that does just that!
￼
 Helping Our Neighbors in Florida Recover From Hurricane Michael Over the years, so many people across this country have given their time and donated to charities so families in Louisiana could recover from storms. Last week, I helped return the favor as we traveled to Florida’s panhandle to provide meals to those working to rebuild from Hurricane Michael. I joined with New Orleans restauranteur Tommy Cvitanovich (from Drago’s) to provide 2,000 meals to families, and to thank the law enforcement officers who are working day and night to help rebuild and to keep those communities safe. In America, we all stick together and help our neighbors in need. With all of our help and prayers, the strong and resilient people of Florida will fully rebuild and recover from this latest storm. 
￼  ￼
  It is an honor to represent you in Congress. For more information please visit my website, Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook pages.   God Bless,
￼

Steve Scalise
House Majority Whip

It’s a massive, unprecedented look in slow motion at almost every aspect that makes up our broken immigration system...KEEP READING HERE 


WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH

Last week Piedmont celebrated its Ozarks heritage with a parade and festival. It was the 49th annual celebration and this year also commemorated Wayne County's 200th birthday. I love the quote on the wagon: "Those who preserve history are just as important as those who make it."

The Jackson Indians High School Football Team made history with their first undefeated season since 2007! It's the 6th undefeated season in their program's impressive 100-plus year history. Congratulations to all, and good luck in the playoffs!

An important piece of American history was found at the VFW post in Farmington. Tucked away in the attic, members found a flag from the USS Missouri, the battleship where Japan surrendered to the United States and ended World War II. Read more about this treasure of a find and what's next for the flag in Farmington.

Subject: Weekly Update: I Support Our Children’s Future
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
CONTACT
Weekly Update: I Support Our Children’s Future By Congressman Rob Wittman October 27, 2018  Strengthening America’s education system is important in fostering innovation and promoting our economic security. This week, I held two Career and Technical Education (CTE) Symposiums in two areas in the district. The first took place on Monday at Germanna Community College in Fredericksburg and the second one in Hanover at American Legion Post 175. I’ve held these symposiums in order to connect education institutions with local businesses and the private sector, and to help ensure the curriculum for our students reflects the needs of the workforce. 
￼
 Currently, businesses across America are facing a severe talent shortage due to a lack of vocational education and technical training. One of my top priorities is promoting CTE and STEM programs as a way to cultivate skillsets needed in today’s workforce and connect students with good-paying jobs. We must be preparing our young people and provide them with the necessary skills and knowledge to compete in a global economy.  These symposiums are a great way for students to see what opportunities are available to them after high school. Not all students are on the path to a four-year college degree. By 2020, demand for STEM jobs will be higher than any other occupational focus including healthcare and service industry, with an estimated 9 million jobs. Almost of half of these jobs will require less than a four-year degree, paying an average of 15% more than non-STEM related jobs to people with similar academic background.  I have made it my mission to meet with all of the CTE programs in the First District and we have a had a lot of success. In May, I held my first symposium at the University of Mary Washington’s Stafford campus, where, again, teachers, businesses, students, and education officials came together to discuss partnership opportunities and ways Congress can help our students cultivate tangible skill sets. With students facing record education-related debt averaging $37,000, and less than 30 percent of college graduates working in jobs related to their major, CTE offers a great alternative. 
￼

Congress has been working hard to bring even more, real change to our students. I was proud to support the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act, which is now signed into law. The Perkins CTE program controls over $1 billion in grants for federal, state, and local CTE programs. The reforms include expanding access to CTE programs, helping schools create partnerships with the business community so students can cultivate skills in demand by the labor market, improving and modernizing schools’ CTE programs, and giving states and localities more control over how to spend CTE dollars.

Last year, my legislation, the Domestic Maritime Centers of Excellence Act, passed the House as part of the National Defense Authorization Act and was signed into law by the President. This bill advances the capabilities of two-year community and technical colleges to assist the federal government and industry in securing the talent pipeline for domestic maritime industry jobs. This bill not only helps promote participation in STEM and CTE but will create a talent pipeline for our shipbuilders and repairmen in order to sustain and grow our Navy's Fleet.

It is our responsibility to prepare students for the demands of our current society and to provide unemployed Americans with an outlet to reintegrate into the workforce. I will always continue working for what is right for our young people.
￼

Subject: Dr. Allison's Step Towards a Cure
Message:
THE TEXAS TIMES
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
ABOUT
FOR TEXANS
ISSUES
NEWSROOM
CONTACT
 Dr. Allison's Step Towards a Cure



Earlier this month, the esteemed 2018 Nobel Prize winners were announced from Stockholm, Sweden.  In accordance with Swedish scientist Alfred Nobel’s will, the Nobel Prize celebrates those who “have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind” within five fields: Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Literature, and Peace.  Just a handful of exceptional men and women have been honored each year since 1901. 
This year, among the brilliant men and women honored from around the globe is Houston’s own Dr. Jim Allison. 
￼
Dr. Allison was shocked when he heard the news.  The boy who grew up in Alice, Texas – and who lost his mother and uncle to cancer at a young age – had been working to find alternative treatments to radiation and chemotherapy, but he never dreamed he’d one day make a groundbreaking discovery towards cancer’s cure that would merit a Nobel Prize. 
Through their research of T cells, Dr. Allison and Japanese immunologist Tasuku Honjo found a way to unleash a patient’s own immune system to fight against cancer cells.   
Now known as the Godfather of Cancer Immunotherapy, Dr. Allison has helped create drugs to treat common forms of cancer like melanoma, lung cancer, and Hodgkin's lymphoma.   
But don’t let Dr. Allison’s resounding success let you think it’s been easy.  “Science is a long and frustrating road,” he announced at a press conference.  “There’s no instant gratification… You’ve got to be comfortable with a lot of failures to get there.” 
Dr. Allison also acknowledges how critical teamwork is when it comes to medical research.  Without funding through the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas (CPRIT) and private funding, he says many of the therapies that currently treat millions of cancer patients worldwide simply wouldn’t exist.   
Thanks to the perseverance and dedication of Dr. Allison and his team, scientists are one step closer to curing cancer.  And thanks to them, it’s not a question of if we will cure cancer, but when. 
I’m proud this discovery came from Texas.  But Dr. Allison is not the only Nobel Laureate from the Lone Star State.  There are at least 10 Nobel Laureates living in Texas today, and even more Texans who have been honored with Nobel Prizes since they were created more than a century ago.  
In 1946, former University of Texas professor Hermann J. Muller won a Nobel Prize for his research showing X-rays can cause genetic mutations, proving the danger of radiation for the first time. 
Jack Kilby, inventor of the handheld calculator and thermal printer, won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2000 for building the first integrated circuit while working for Texas Instruments in 1958.  He then went on to teach electrical engineering at Texas A&M University. 
Just last year, University of Texas alum Michael W. Young won a Nobel Prize for his discovery of the gene that controls our biological clock, including processes like sleep and metabolism throughout the day.  
Each of these incredible discoveries, and many more being made each day at labs across our state, have pushed the needle forward on our understanding of the world we live in.  But there’s always more we can learn.  Thomas Edison once said, “When you have exhausted all possibilities, remember this: you haven’t.”   
There’s so much more we can discover, and with science advancing at practically lighting speed thanks to minds like Dr. Allison’s, I know we’ll have more answers soon. 
I encourage all young boys and girls – from Alice, Texas, and all across our state – to look up at Dr. Allison and all of Texas’ Nobel Prize winners and know that whatever you set your mind to, the sky is the limit.




                  




517 Hart Senate Office Bldg.  Washington, DC 20510  Main: 202-224-2934  Fax: 202-228-2856

October 27th, 2018

COMBATING OPIOIDS FOR OK-02 
On Wednesday President Trump signed the federal opioid bill, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act. The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act included a number of my office’s priorities including: 
·         The Every Prescription Conveyed Securely Act (H.R. 3528)
·         The Tribal Addiction and Recovery Act (H.R. 5140)
￼

The Overdose Prevention and Patient Safety Act (H.R. 6082) passed the House by a vote of 357-57, but was not included in the final package. I am continuing to push the Senate to pass H.R. 6082 before the end of the year. 
SERVICE ACADEMY NOMINATIONS 
Do you know anyone who may be interested in joining a service academy? Attending a U.S. service academy is an invaluable experience that shapes young men and women into strong leaders and military officers. Nominations are available for the U.S. Military Academy, U.S. Naval Academy, U.S. Air Force Academy, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. Click here to learn more on the service academy nomination process.   CONSTITUENTS IN WASHINGTON 
￼
The Ferrens at the Will Rogers statue. 
I am sorry to have missed you!
￼
The Golbek Family on a tour of the Capitol. 
I hope to see you next time!
MY WEEK IN OKLAHOMA
I had the opportunity to cut the ribbon for the Build Your Future program and address students from across Northeastern Oklahoma. Build Your Future is a program put together by community leaders to expose high school students to career technology education and the opportunities in the construction field. Currently unemployment is at a historic low of 3.7% and the construction industry is expected to grow by 25% in the next year. These jobs can average in the $50,000 and $60,000 pay range. A very good wage for young Oklahomans willing to work hard. 
￼
Thank you for having me at the Build My Future ribbon cutting!
￼
This week I was able to speak to  students about the dangers of opioids.
￼
Drew Bowen, a junior at Valliant High School, is heading to the Special Olympics USA Summer Games in Seattle, Washington. 
His classmates and I couldn’t be more proud of him!
￼
Enjoyed answering questions from seniors in McAlester!

This week I held a social security information event in McAlester. Social Security is not an entitlement. It is earned and I am working hard to make it sustainable for future generations.Thank you to everyone that came out to participate. 

See more from my week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way.
Thank you, ￼

Subject: Jackie's Reads for October 27, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

Given these turbulent political times, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.   
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world. When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change. 
Happy reading and all the best,    ￼

￼

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
Guns in America
325 million people. More than 265 million guns. 35,000 deaths a year. And one 227-year-old constitutional right.
A Time and JR Project
￼
To tell this uniquely American story, TIME partnered with JR, the artist and photographer known in part for his murals around the world that portray communities in all their complexity. In three U.S. cities profoundly affected by guns—Dallas, St. Louis and Washington, D.C.—we invited people to share their views and describe their experiences in a search for common ground.

In all, JR filmed and photographed 245 people—hunters and activists, teachers and police officers, parents and children—to create this mural for TIME’s November 5, 2018, cover.
To read the complete Time interactive article, please click here. 
If You’re Not Scared About Fascism in the U.S., You Should Be
￼
When fascism starts to feel normal, we’re all in trouble.
By Jason Stanley
Video by Adam Westbrook and Japhet Weeks
The author is a professor of philosophy at Yale University.
While calling President Trump a fascist may seem like an exaggeration, it might not be that far from the truth. Should we be worried? Jason Stanley has spent the past decade studying fascism, from Mussolini to Duterte. In this video op-ed, he argues that yes, we should be worried: If Americans are not vigilant, fascism could become a new reality in the United States. 
To watch the New York Times op-ed video, please click here. 
Women Are Running for Office—And Funding Democrats—Like Never Before
A wave of women is grabbing 2018 by the ballots.
By Kara Voght and Dave Gilson, Mother Jones
“The women are in my grill no matter where I go,” Rep. Dave Brat (R-Va.) groused in early 2017 as he was dogged by some of the many grassroots activists spurred to action by the election of President Donald Trump. Since then, the women-led “resistance” has fueled a wave of Democratic candidates and sparked hope that female voters will stop Trump in his tracks.  See Jane Run
1992 was declared the “Year of the Woman” after 24 women won House seats for the first time and four new women joined the Senate. In 2018, there has been a surge in women running for Congress. Three-fourths of them are Democrats, and 68 percent are challengers or running for open seats.

Subject: An Update from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez to Constituents of the 15th District of Texas
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues

About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
The past couple of weeks have proven to be very busy, but I wanted to take the time to update you on our recent work in Washington, D.C. and the 15th District of Texas. 
It is an honor to serve as your congressman.
Holy guacamole! Seguin High School’s Mighty Matador Marching Band just scored a FIRST Division rating at the Region 12 UIL Marching Contest! Join me in congratulating every student and faculty member who practiced countless hours to achieve this victory. Can you all play a little Sinatra the next time I’m around? Maybe some Jimmy Gonzalez? Keep up the great work!
￼ 
Recently, I had the honor of meeting with Guadalupe County Commissioners Greg Seidenberg (Precinct 1) and Judy Cope (Precinct 4) to discuss ways we can partner to create opportunities for residents of the 15th District of Texas.
￼ 
Recently, I had the opportunity to speak with the incredible people of the Community Action Partnership in Seguin, Texas. Together, we can work to improve communities in the 15th District of Texas and provide residents with the tools to become self-reliant and successful.
￼ 
￼
On Wednesday October 24, 2018, I led Congressmen Henry Cuellar (TX-28) and Filemon Vela (TX-34) and Senators John Cornyn (TX) and Ted Cruz (TX) in a letter to Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Administrator William ‘Brock’ Long requesting that FEMA reconsider their denial of damages reported by Cameron and Hidalgo Counties in their applications for Public Assistance (PA) resulting from this summer’s recent severe storms and flooding. 
I thank local, state, and federal officials for their continued efforts to assist in recovery efforts for Cameron and Hidalgo Counties and for calling on us for aid. I urge Administrator Long to reconsider the current damage assessments and recognize the flawed process that made these determinations. Our constituents are not asking for favors, only the consistent application of law to the facts.
Read the full letter below or click on the link here. 
￼
￼ 
Recently, I visited the newest Pic N Pac location in Seguin, Texas and met with members from the Texas Food and Fuel Association (TFFA) and the National Association of Convenience Stores (NACS). More businesses in Central and South Texas equal more jobs and a stronger economy. I thank TFFA, NACS, and Pic N Pac for having me!
￼ 
￼ 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.
  
Sincerely,
￼
Vicente Gonzalez Member of Congress

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Saturday, October 27, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week I attended various ceremonies and events with different individuals and organizations, including the Serving Children and Adults in Need (SCAN) Grant Announcement, the Eagle Ford Shale-a-Bration, and several Department of Homeland Security Operation Stonegarden Grant Announcements, amongst others. 
I also have included a video from The Texas Department of Insurance, in conjunction with the State Fire Marshal’s Office, regarding trick-or-treat safety for this Halloween.
As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Rep. Cuellar Announces Grants to SCAN in Laredo
￼

On Thursday, October 18, I announced more than $2.8 million in federal funding for Serving Children and Adults in Need (SCAN) Inc. in Laredo, awarded by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) through their Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) grant program. For more information click here. Pictured from left are Congressman Henry Cuellar, SCAN Mental Health Awareness Program Trainer Sandra Contreras, SCAN Vice President Dr. Christopher Craddock, SCAN Executive Vice President Luis Flores, SCAN CEO Isela Dabdoub, and SCAN Program Director Enrique Manrique. 


Eagle Ford Shale-A-Bration 
￼

On Friday, October 19, I spoke alongside energy representatives and officials at the “Shale-A-Bration” luncheon in San Antonio, Texas, to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the discovery of the Eagle Ford Shale. Participants discussed the discovery of the Eagle Ford by the Petrohawk Energy Corporation as well as its future. I also held a media availability to provide media partners from San Antonio with an update on legislative priorities and to discuss topics such as Appropriations and Immigration. Top photo from left are Congressman Henry Cuellar, U.S. Secretary of Energy Rick Perry and San Antonio Business Journal Publisher Jimmy Holmes. Bottom photo from left are First Rock President Gregg Robertson, R&J Graham Energy President Robert Graham, San Antonio Mayor Ron Nirenberg, Congressman Henry Cuellar and Port Corpus Christi Chief External Affairs Officer Omar Garcia. 


Rep. Cuellar Presents USDA and DHS Grants to Floresville and Wilson County Reps 
￼

On Friday, October 19, I attended a ceremony recognizing the completion of the City of Floresville’s newly constructed U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) and to announce $888,556.85 in Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) funding for Wilson County. Construction of the Floresville wastewater treatment plant was made possible with $9.47 million in federal funding from the USDA through their Rural Development Program. Following the ceremony, I announced more than $888,000 in FEMA funding for Wilson County for damages from the 2015 Memorial Day Weekend Flooding. 


Rep. Cuellar Announces Grants for the City of Mission
￼

On Monday, October 22, I announced two grants for the City of Mission; a $1,022,828 federal grant to the Mission Fire Department from the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s (FEMA) Staffing for Adequate Fire & Emergency Response (SAFER) Program as well as a $500,000 grant for the City of Mission from the National Park Service (NPS) for the revitalization of Birdwell Park. FEMA’s SAFER grant will help strengthen the fire department’s emergency response through increased funding to hire nine additional firefighters. The NPS’s Land and Water Conservation Fund works to provide funding for local and state park projects. These funds will be used to reinvigorate Birdwell Park, including adding new tennis courts and a revitalized trail system with distance markers, water fountains, and other amenities. 


Rep. Cuellar Announces Funding for City of Roma’s Bus Terminal
￼

On Monday, October 22, I announced $700,000 at the groundbreaking ceremony for the City of Roma’s New Bus Terminal. The new terminal will decrease traffic congestion, create a new economic anchor for Grant Street, open up a new hub for transportation coming in from Mexico, and will serve as a link to job opportunities. I have diligently followed this infrastructural need since funds were initially earmarked by Congressman Doggett in 2005, and will continue to serve the transportation needs of the district. 


Operation Stonegarden Announcement in Hidalgo
￼

On Tuesday, October 23, I announced $4.5 million to Hidalgo County through DHS’s Operation Stonegarden. These funds will work to supplement the border efforts in the county, including paying out over-time, covering equipment costs, and reimbursing interagency operations. As a longtime supporter of border protection, a focus of my work on the Homeland Security Appropriations subcommittee has been aiding the men and women who protect our nation every day. 


Operation Stonegarden Announcement in Starr County
￼

On Tuesday, October 23, I announced $2 million in funding to Starr County through DHS’s Operation Stonegarden to strengthen coordination between agencies on all levels so that we may continue to fortify our borders. I worked diligently to secure this funding through my efforts on the Homeland Security Appropriations Subcommittee as a continuation of my dedication to the men and women who protect our nation along the border every day.


Operation Stonegarden Announcement in Zapata
￼

On Tuesday, October 23, I announced $300,000 to Zapata County through the Department of Homeland Security’s Operation Stonegarden. This funding will supplement the efforts of the U.S. Border Patrol through equipment cost reimbursement, coverage of interagency operation costs, and overtime funds. As a longtime supporter of security for our borders, these funds will cover agency costs and strengthen agency operations. Congressman Cuellar (TX-28) presents DHS Operation Stonegarden grant in Zapata on Tuesday. Pictured from left are Border Patrol Agent Juan Galindo, Zapata County Sheriff Alonso Lopez, Congressman Henry Cuellar, Zapata County Judge Joe Rathmell, District Attorney Isidro “Chilo” Alaniz, Chief Deputy Raymundo del Bosque, and Zapata County Commissioner Precinct 2 Olga Elizondo.


Staff Spotlight: Constituent Service Representative Alexis Gallegos
￼

Meet our Constituent Services Representative Alexis Gallegos. Alexis is based in our Mission District Office and has been providing services for over five years to constituents in Hidalgo and Starr County. What she enjoys most, is providing resources and favorable solutions for constituents dealing with federal issues. She is always ready and willing to assist you with anything that you may need. During her free time, she enjoys spending quality outdoor activities with her loving family and DIY decor and craft projects. 


Intern Spotlight: Beck Amodeo
￼

Beck Amodeo is a junior at Walt Whitman High School in Bethesda, Maryland. Beck completed his internship this summer in my Washington, D.C. office. To learn more about Beck and other interns click here. 


Halloween Safety Tips from the Texas State Fire Marshall
￼

This video from the Texas State Fire Marshal explains steps parents can take to ensure their kids celebrate Halloween in a safe way.  

 
 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

October 27, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review
 



October 23

Small Business Legislation: Last month, the House passed two bills by overwhelming margins. I voted no on both bills because they would advantage some small businesses over others. My belief has always been that government shouldn’t pick winners and losers in the commercial marketplace.
They’re both benign sounding bills with good intentions…but unfortunately bring with them the unintended consequence of picking favorites. And I think that’s a bridge too far for those of us who believe in market principles and limited government.
H.R. 6368, the Encouraging Small Business Innovators Act, would change the formula that the federal government uses when rating subcontractors. It passed 389 to 6.
The bill would change the formula by which federal government subcontractors are rated in a way that benefits companies that have taken part in one of the Small Business Administration’s grant programs - either the Small Business Innovation Research program or the Small Business Technology Transfer program. Click here to read more.
￼

October 24

2018 Water Resources Development Act: Yesterday, the president signed the 2018 Water Resources bill into law. There were several wins for the Lowcountry in this bill, but before I get to that, I wanted to share two observations. 

One, the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) is one of the few examples of regular order in Congress these days. As you may remember, regular order means taking an idea through the full committee process of debate rather than air dropping an idea into the Floor with none of the back-and-forth that the committee process guarantees. These bills have been coming up for regular two-year authorizations, and in this regard, the Water Resources Development Act represents Congress functioning as it should. 

Two, it’s also one of the rare instances of financial responsibility in Washington, given that the bill is fully offset by deauthorizing old projects to make room for new ones. Again, what this means in plain English is that you stop spending on other things so you can spend on this thing. Obviously that’s not the way Congress has been working for quite some time, given the view that says we can spend on both without any decrease in other areas of spending. 

Our office was able to work with the Committee on the inclusion of three important topics that have direct impact on the Lowcountry. Click here to read more.

￼

￼
 Click above to watch the video

￼

October 25

National Debt as a Threat to National Security: “The continually increasing debt is the biggest threat we have to our national security.”
That’s what Admiral Mike Mullen, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said...and I’ve mentioned this on more than one occasion because of the geometric growth in our debt. It’s something I have long believed and long championed, and it’s for that reason that this summer, I joined with 34 of my Republican colleagues in signing a resolution introduced by Congressman Andy Biggs to recognize the national debt as a threat to national security.
It took us 200 years to accumulate $5 trillion in national debt. It took just eight years for it to double from $5 trillion to $10 trillion under the presidency of George W. Bush. It doubled yet again from $10 trillion to $20 trillion under President Obama. And it’s just over $21.2 trillion today…
...and these numbers are on an upward trajectory. Click here to read more.

￼


October 26

Every Kid Outdoors Act: Under the category of more circling back and catching up on past votes, I wanted to circle back to one vote that I missed when I stayed home in anticipation of what then looked to be a monster storm hitting our district. As it turned out, Hurricane Florence never materialized, and I went back up for votes. But I was struck by this vote for the way it’s another example of government waste, inefficiency, and redundancy.
Not everything that government does has to be codified by law.
Law should be reserved for things that matter, not scoring political points in an election year. But that’s not how things work, so many laws passed in an election year are about political gain rather than policy change.
Such was the case with H.R. 3186, the Every Kid Outdoors Act. It would codify an existing program at the Department of Interior that provides 4th graders free entrance to National Parks around our nation. The bill passed 382-2, but I would have voted against it, because I do not believe that there is a need to codify this program into law. It’s something the agency already does, and has discretion to do based on existing law.
Here are a few more details that may lead you to the spot I found myself in observing what happened here…. Click here to read more.

Subject: Investigation Update
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window
 Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative John Ratcliffe 
￼ 

WEBSITE
SERVICES
CONTACT
FACEBOOK
INSTAGRAM



￼ 
Hi Friends,  
  
This week, I questioned President Trump's former campaign adviser, George Papadopoulos, as a part of the ongoing joint investigation into the troubling actions of the DOJ and FBI leading up to the 2016 election.  
  
As you know, many claims have been made that the unverified dossier compiled by Christopher Steele and paid for by the DNC was not the basis of the Trump-Russia investigation led by former FBI Agent Peter Strzok.  
  
According to these folks, there were many other legitimate reasons to investigate then-presidential candidate Donald Trump – one of them being George Papadopoulos. But after my questioning with him under oath, I can say I find it very hard to believe this is the case. 
  
￼ 
  
Rep. Ratcliffe speaks with Dana Perino on Fox News about George Papadopoulos questioning 
  
What my questioning did confirm is that Papadopoulos was a 28-year-old policy adviser who'd been on the job a month at the time the Trump-Russia investigation was launched, and to this day he's never been to Russia nor met knowingly with anyone associated with the Russian government. 
  
This poses further questions that must be answered about why the FBI allegedly used him as the basis to launch the one of the highest profile investigations in recent times, and I’m committed to continuing my work on this important investigation until these questions are answered.
  
Tune into Sunday Morning Futures on Fox News Sunday at 10 a.m. to hear more about my questioning with George Papadopoulos. 
  
For more updates on my work in Congress, click here. 
Sincerely, 
￼ 
John Ratcliffe U.S. Representative for Texas’ Fourth District

Subject: Today is National Take-Back Day
Message:
District Update | October 27, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Today is National Prescription Take Back Day
 
￼
Do you have old or unused prescriptions laying around the house?   Today, is National Prescription Take Back Day which is a safe, convenient, and responsible way to dispose of excess prescription drugs, while also raising awareness of the opioid crisis and the potential for abuse of medications.  In April, the DEA collected more than 470 tons of unused prescription drugs at nearly 6,000 collection sites nationwide. These medications, when not collected or properly disposed of, easily fuel the opioid crisis gripping our nation, and cause harm to family and friends.  Help fight the opioid epidemic and safely dispose of unused prescriptions.   CLICK HERE to find a take back site near you.   
Historic Legislation to Fight the Opioid Epidemic Signed Into Law
 
￼
The opioid crisis is wreaking havoc on communities in my district and across the country and Congress took action. This week, President Trump signed comprehensive legislation to combat the epidemic from all angles.   This is the most significant congressional effort against a single drug crisis in history.  H.R. 6, the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act will help in our efforts to advance treatment and recovery initiatives, improve prevention, protect our communities, and fight illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl.   I’ve held numerous roundtables in the district asking first responders, law enforcement, and health care experts what they need from the federal government to help address this issue locally and this package contains many provisions that will address those issues.  Some of the highlights include:  -Expand access to treatment and recovery services, including establishing comprehensive opioid recovery centers -Improve data to identify and help at-risk patients and families -Give law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of our communities -Improve access to federal resources for local communities -Crack down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs  Click here to learn more about this legislation and more action Congress is taking to fight the opioid epidemic.  


￼
This week, I visited The Pavilion Behavioral Health System in Champaign and met with the staff who are on the front lines of the opioid epidemic. The legislation signed into law will help to fight the epidemic from all angles, including increasing access to the treatment services people need to overcome addiction. 
 
￼

Everywhere I travel in the 13th district, I hear stories like Elisha's. Everyone has their own stories as to how opioids have affected them or their loved ones.

This historic legislation is an important step in our continued efforts to fight the opioid epidemic. While we are making progress, there is still much to be done and I will continue to fight back so we can ensure no family loses a loved one to addiction or an overdose.

Subject: We Must Restore Civility
Message:
Share on: 
￼￼ 
 
￼
￼


Dear Friend,  America is the world’s greatest democracy and beacon of hope to millions across the globe.  Sadly, our democracy was attacked this week through attempts to terrorize and harm former Presidents Obama and Clinton, Vice President Biden, Secretary Clinton, the media, and other public figures. These heinous acts are reprehensible, they have no place in our country, and those responsible must be brought to justice.  I am grateful for the swift action of the Secret Service, FBI, and local law enforcement in intercepting these packages and thank them for their continued work and selfless efforts every day to guard against these threats and keep us safe.  This week’s events are also an important reminder to all of us.  Our common beliefs in liberty, justice, free speech, and the right to peaceably assemble bind us together as Americans and make our nation stronger.  We must restore civility in political discourse and remember there is far more that unites us than divides us.  A Truly Humbling Honor  On Tuesday, I was incredibly honored that the City of Maple Valley renamed 231st Street in Maple Valley, "Dave Reichert Way." It means so much that the citizens of Maple Valley have sought to recognize my work on their behalf over the last five decades, first in the King County Sheriff’s Office and today as their Member of Congress.   It is especially meaningful to me that Maple Valley chose to rename the street on which the King County Sheriff’s Office Hicks-Raburn Precinct resides.  Sergeant Sam Hicks and Detective Mike Raburn were my dearest friends and partners in the Sheriff’s Office.  Sadly, both men lost their lives in the line of duty while courageously serving their community. The precinct honors their memory, service, sacrifice, and friendship.  It has been my great privilege to serve the community alongside such incredible citizens and leaders, and I am truly humbled and appreciative of this exceptionally kind tribute. 
￼
Recognizing World Polio Day  On Wednesday, we paused to imagine a world without polio.  While the United States is polio-free, children around the world continue to suffer.  Here at home we must also continue to be vigilant, because with an increasingly mobile global citizenry, it only takes one traveler to reintroduce the disease to the U.S.  On World Polio Day, we recommit our efforts to once and for all put an end to this disease.  As Co-Chair of the Global Health Caucus, I have proudly championed efforts to fund polio eradication programs, and will continue to do so as Congress finalizes its work on the Fiscal Year 2019 spending bills.   Bipartisan Comprehensive Opioids Package Signed Into Law  Communities throughout Washington’s 8th District, the state, and nation continue to struggle with the growing opioid crisis.  Fortunately, there is new reason for hope as additional help from the federal government is now on its way to local communities and those on the front lines fighting this crisis every day.  The President signed into law comprehensive opioid legislation to combat the crisis from all sides.  The law helps communities most in need, provides new tools for law enforcement to crack down on synthetic opioids, and helps stop the flow of drugs across our borders and into our communities.  I am proud the package also includes the STOP Act that I supported to end the shipment of opioids through the international mail system.  While we have more work to do, enactment of this opioids law is an important step forward, and we will not stop until we beat this crisis.  
￼
 TODAY - National Prescription Drug Take Back Day  One way that each of us can help combat the opioid crisis is through the safe disposal of unused prescription drugs to help prevent diversion into the wrong hands.  Today is the Drug Enforcement Administration’s (DEA) National Prescription Drug Take Back Day. In April, during DEA’s last take back day, nationwide over 949,000 pounds of prescription drugs were collected – that is 474.5 tons of drugs taken out of communities, creating safer environments for all of us. Click HERE find a collection site near you to dispose of unwanted, unused, or expired prescription drugs. 
￼
 Major Water Infrastructure Legislation Becomes Law  This week, I was also glad to see America’s Water Infrastructure Act signed into law. This important legislation supports critical water infrastructure projects in Washington State. As a state that shares a border with the Pacific Ocean, our ports, inland waterways, locks, and dams must be continually held to the highest standards to protect Washingtonians. This law provides funding that could benefit local projects such as the Tacoma Harbor Navigation Project and the Seattle Harbor Deepening Project.  District Happenings   Saturday: Halloween Harvest Festival   Come out to the Halloween Harvest Festival and Les Gove Park Trunk-or-Treat! The event welcomes kids ages 2-10 and their families. There will be games, crafts, a photo booth, and Trunk-or-Treating around Les Gove Park's trail.   EVENT DETAILS:  When: Saturday, October 27, 2018, 2:00pm - 5:00pm Where: Auburn Community & Event Center, 910 9th Street SE, Auburn, WA  Wednesday: Trick or Treat in Ellensburg  Join the community for a safe, family-friendly Trick or Treat in Ellensburg! Vendors in Downtown Ellensburg will be providing candy and treats for costumed trick-or-treaters. Look for a sign in the windows of downtown businesses, which indicates participation.   EVENT DETAILS:  When: Wednesday, October 31, 3:00pm – 6:00pm Where: Downtown Ellensburg (Between 1st Ave & Main St. and 5th Ave & Pearl St.), WA  Thank you all for joining me for this week!  Sincerely,
Dave

Subject: Together, We Can Stop Harmful Discharges
Message:
News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼ 
THE TORTURED COAST
￼ 
Lindsey - 
I introduced the Stop Harmful Discharges Act because the current management of Lake Okeechobee is putting special interests ahead of the health and human safety of the communities east and west of the lake. 
We cannot tolerate water managers continuing to keep an artificially high level of water on Lake Okeechobee that results in toxic discharges destroying our community and putting people's lives at risk.
The Stop Harmful Discharges Act makes public health and safety, including prevention of toxic cyanobacteria and the integrity of the Herbert Hoover Dike, the primary project purpose for the management of Lake Okeechobee. 
More than that, the bill ensures that clean water reaches Everglades National Park, the Florida Bay and the Caloosahatchee Watershed to help restore the natural habitat. It does all this without diminishing the importance of the stability of the Herbert Hoover Dike, water access for the Miccosukee and Seminole Tribes, or ongoing Everglades restoration projects. 
That's why, since we introduced the bill, we've been building widespread support from other Members of Congress, environmental groups like the Rivers Coalition and clean water advocates like Erin Brockovich. 
Together, we can finally force the Army Corps to prioritize the health and safety of our community. To learn more about the bill, watch our newest episode of the Tortured Coast here: 
WATCH NOW 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media: 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman 
P.S. You can read the bill here.

Subject: Working to Eliminate Veteran Suicide
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Working to Eliminate Veteran Suicide
The men and women in our armed forces provide an invaluable service to our nation; protecting us from danger and ensuring we can keep the freedoms we hold dear. Unfortunately, all too often when these same men and women return home from war or after separating from service, they feel left behind with nowhere to turn. As a Vietnam-era veteran, I saw many of the young men with whom I served return from overseas to protests and a nation that did not appear to want to welcome them home or appreciate the sacrifices they made to protect our freedoms while they were gone. While the climate for our returning servicemembers is fortunately not the same as it was in the 1960s and 1970s, too many of our veterans still feel there is nowhere to turn, and that suicide is their only option. I want to tell all our nation’s veterans: you are not alone, and suicide is not your only option.  
As Chairman of the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs (HVAC), I promised to do everything possible to ensure our country takes care of those who served in our defense, and I will continue to follow through on this promise. Last month, HVAC held a hearing on the persistent and heartbreaking topic of veteran suicide. In a recently released report, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) stated that in 2016, approximately 20 veterans took their own lives every day, and sadly that number has not changed. As a physician and veteran, I believe it is extremely important to not only continue to raise awareness, but to seek out innovative solutions, partner with communities, and improve VA health practices to help veterans learn of other treatment options and services available if they are in need.  
Over the past several years, VA has increased funding and invested resources to address the high number of veteran suicides; and despite our efforts the amount of deaths has not decreased. In the recent HVAC hearing, the Committee reviewed the research released by VA to come up with a plan on ways to better expend resources to reverse this trend. One statistic I found completely staggering was 14 of the 20 veterans who committed suicide did not seek medical care from the VA. Why is that? Unfortunately, we cannot ask these veterans why they didn’t seek treatment or what they found lacking in VA health care; we can only work to reform the system and make it more accessible to those veterans in the most need. It is one thing to outline how a program should work, but for every veteran who is not properly referred for treatment, for every veteran who is not admitted due to a shortage of staff or beds, for every veteran who feels they have been ignored or dismissed, we run the risk of needlessly losing another veteran to suicide.  
The issue of veteran suicide is not a new problem, and it’s one I’ve worked on since I first arrived in Congress. Along with HVAC Ranking Member Tim Walz, I founded the Congressional Invisible Wounds Caucus, which seeks to prioritize the needs of servicemembers who are suffering from the invisible wounds of war, such as PTSD. Over the years, the caucus has been able to highlight several innovative approaches to treating veterans in crisis, but these statistics continue to show more needs to be done.
We need to target the cause of these suicides by identifying those at high risk; recognize the unique barriers that certain veteran populations face; and use that information to advance our approaches that offer the promise of preventing suicides among veterans. I, along with my colleagues, have worked tirelessly to follow through on our promises to veterans – to provide the best possible care our service men and women deserve. In 2007, VA launched the Veterans Crisis Line (VCL), a 24-7 toll-free phone line to connect veterans contemplating suicide or otherwise in crisis with qualified crisis responders. Unfortunately, there was mismanagement of the program and action was needed. In an effort to fix the problems plaguing the VCL, I supported the No Veterans Crisis Line Should Go Unanswered Act, a bill that was signed into law on November 28, 2016. Thanks to the implementation of this law and follow-up Committee hearings, VA has increased the number of VCL call centers from 2 to 3, increased the total number of VCL employees, and decreased the number of VCL calls that are transferred to a backup call center from a 30 percent rollover rate in 2016 to a .16 percent rollover rate to-date in 2018.
More recently, Congress and the Trump administration established key laws to improve VA’s mental health services. VA is now expanding mental health services to all separating servicemembers for 12 months following separation from the military, the time frame shown to be the highest-risk period for suicide among veterans. Thanks to the work of HVAC, veterans with Other-Than-Honorable discharges now have the ability to seek VA mental health services for conditions that possibly contributed to their unfavorable separation status, a critical lifeline for which they were not previously eligible.  
The past two years I have championed the VA MISSION Act, a transformational piece of legislation that I introduced and was signed into law on June 6, 2018. The VA MISSION Act will ensure veterans seeking VA care – including mental health and suicide prevention support – are able to access the care they need, when and where they need it.  Additionally, this law contains provisions that establish peer specialists in patient aligned care team settings to increase services for mental health, substance use disorder and behavioral health in a primary care setting. To meet the needs of veterans at-risk of suicide, VA has requested and Congress funded $8.6 billion for mental health care in fiscal year (FY) 2019, an increase of 5.8 percent over FY 2018. This reflects a trend of significant annual increases in VA mental health funding going back several years. We still have work ahead of us, but as Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I will continue to make caring for our veterans my highest priority.
If you are a veteran and are having suicidal thoughts, please do not hesitate to reach out to the VCL. The VCL toll-free phone line (1-800-273-8255, press 1 for veteran) and is staffed 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 

My door is always open to East Tennesseans. Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

Subject: Working Together
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | News | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | CONTACT
WORKING TOGETHER TO FIGHT HUMAN TRAFFICKING
￼
Human trafficking is modern-day slavery, and we all need to work together to fight it. 
This week I met with local law enforcement leaders, community organizations, and advocates to discuss identifying, reporting, and preventing sex-trafficking.
I was grateful for the chance to hear about lessons learned, the barriers they face, and what more we can do to end this scourge.
Congress took action earlier this year by, passing the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (FOSTA), which was signed into law in April. It gives law enforcement new tools and makes it easier for states to crack down on websites that support and facilitate trafficking.
I look forward to continuing to work with these dedicated Hoosiers who make our community a better, safer place.
SIGNED INTO LAW: BIPARTISAN OPIOID BILL
￼
For too long, families and communities across the country have been devastated by the opioid epidemic. This week we took a big step toward ending this crisis.
H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, was just signed into law. This bipartisan, comprehensive legislation will provide critical tools and resources to help those on the front lines of this fight. 
￼
It will also build on the legacy of Dr. Todd Graham with provisions named in the Hoosier doctor’s honor.
Before he was tragically killed last year over an opioid prescription, Dr. Graham was dedicated to treating patients not only for their pain but for the underlying causes. That is why I worked to include this measure to advance the model of care he championed.
￼
I’m hopeful we can help end the opioid epidemic by improving access to non-opioid pain treatments and enabling doctors to better treat patients and prevent addiction.
The opioid epidemic is taking a terrible toll on our communities. This vital new law will help Hoosiers work together to prevent and treat addiction and assist in recovery. 
HEARING FROM HOOSIERS
I am inspired by the hardworking Hoosiers I meet around our community who truly make a difference in people’s lives. I’m grateful to work with them to find commonsense solutions for our communities.
Here is a little more about some of the great work I learned more about this week:
￼
Senator Todd Young and I met with Hoosiers who have benefited from a great program called Homes for Heroes that gives back to local heroes like first responders, servicemembers, veterans, teachers, and health care providers.
￼
Bailey’s Cabinets in North Judson is a family-owned business that creates jobs and keeps our economy moving. I got an inside look at how this local business is working to expand its capabilities and hire more hardworking Hoosiers.
￼
The services provided at Bella Vita Pregnancy Resource Center are life-changing to many Hoosier women and families.
￼
The Goshen community came together at the annual Ride to Remember to honor our fallen police, firefighters, and servicemembers who answered the call to serve. 
￼
While their children are being treated, Michiana parents can feel a sense of comfort and hope thanks to the wholehearted commitment of the Ronald McDonald House staff and volunteers. 
As always, it is a privilege to represent 2nd District Hoosiers in Congress.
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website and join me on social media:
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Sincerely,
￼
Jackie Walorski U.S. Congresswoman
