Subject: Quincy Riverfront Development, A Positive Step for Free Trade, Honoring Our Veterans, and much more
Message:
News from Representative Darin LaHood

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward
￼ 
 
WEBSITE 
CONTACT
SERVICES 
NEWS
 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼




Dear Lindsey, 
From Quincy to Peoria and many stops in between, it was a great week in the 18th District. I was provided an update on the Quincy Riverfront Development project, joined Peoria veterans leaders in unveiling a new memorial in Peoria, and visited the pumpkin canning facility, Seneca Foods in Princeville, to get a fresh look at what exactly goes into our pumpkin pies! Please continue scrolling along to read about the rest of our week in the 18th District. 
Around the District
Riverfront Development in Quincy
            
￼
￼
It was great to be in Quincy with Mayor Moore and the Quincy Park District to discuss ways we can drive economic development at the riverfront. As your Representative, I will continue to advocate for our local communities in Washington. 
Quincy Herald Whig: LaHood touts tourism, international trade during visit to Quincy 
A Positive Step Towards Free Trade
￼ 
As I have stated time and time again, free trade is vital to the economic prosperity in Illinois' 18th District. With 95% of the world’s population living outside of the United States, expanding and opening markets around the world for our exporters will allow them to remain competitive in the global economy. The Administration's announced intent to enter trade negotiations with Japan, the EU, and the UK is an important step towards high-standard trade. I look forward to consulting with both the Administration and my colleagues on the Committee on Ways and Means to ensure the needs of farmers and businesses in central and west-central Illinois are priorities in these negotiations.
Release: Rep. LaHood Statement on the Administration’s Intent to Enter Trade Negotiations with Japan, EU, UK 
Honoring Our Veterans
￼  ￼ 
I joined Peoria leaders to unveil the new war memorial downtown named, “The Final Salute.” The memorial honors post-WWII casualties from the Korean War, Vietnam War, Gulf War, as well as current and future conflicts.   Freedom is certainly not free and this memorial will serve as a strong reminder that many members from our community have given the ultimate sacrifice to protect our freedoms.   Special thanks to all who attended today, including Medal of Honor recipient Hal Fritz, Memorial Committee Chair Steve Sonnemaker, and Vice-Chair Bruce Thiemann.
CI Proud: Peoria County Veterans rememebred during memorial service 
ICYMI: Economic Boom Continues
￼ 
Wall Street Journal: "Country regains top spot in World Economic Forum rankings thanks to strong economic growth"  
Seneca Foods Visit
 ￼ 
Illinois' 18th Congressional District produces almost all of the pumpkins found on store shelves around the country, making central Illinois the pumpkin capital of the world. I had the pleasure of stopping by one of the producers, Seneca Foods in Princeville, to tour their facilities last week. I enjoyed our discussion about the company and the importance of global trade to the agricultural community.
Attention Students Interested in a Service Academy Nomination
￼ 
Don't forget, for those interested in applying for a Service Academy Nomination, the deadline is less than a month away on Friday, November 9, 2018. 
Students interested must reside in Illinois' 18th District and meet the minimum eligibility requirements by July 1, 2019. If you are interested in finding out more about the application process and the requirements necessary to apply for a nomination, please head to my website to learn more:https://lahood.house.gov/services/students#academy. 
If a student is interested and qualified to apply, please contact my Military Affairs Advisor & Academy Nomination Coordinator, Mike in my Peoria District Office by telephone at (309) 671-7027, in order to request an application. 
￼   Sincerely, ￼  Darin LaHood Member of Congress

Subject: Buy America Reform Championed by Baldwin Now Law
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email


￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
Due to Senator Baldwin’s continued efforts, bipartisan legislation including a requirement that federally funded water infrastructure projects use American-made iron and steel was signed into law this week. 
Senator Baldwin has long championed stronger Buy America standards and her Made in America Water Infrastructure Act requires that 100 percent American-made iron and steel is used in water infrastructure projects funded by the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund. The bipartisan Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) signed into law this week by President Trump includes a five-year extension of Buy America requirements for water infrastructure projects funded by the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund. 
“A five-year Buy America standard is better than the status quo and President Trump has taken an important step forward on our shared goal of making sure taxpayer money is not spent supporting foreign workers,” said Senator Baldwin. “I will continue fighting for a permanent Buy America commitment from Washington that rewards our Made in Wisconsin workers and manufacturers.” 
On April 18, 2017, while visiting Kenosha, local media asked President Trump if he supported Senator Baldwin’s permanent Buy America standard. President Trump said “I do,” and also said, “I agree with her 100 percent.” The bipartisan WRDA legislation signed into law this week includes a Buy America requirement through at least 2023. 
“As we invest in our nation’s water infrastructure, American taxpayers expect—now more than ever—that the iron and steel products incorporated into these taxpayer-financed projects will be melted, molded and made in America by American workers and the foundries and mills that employ them,” said Neenah Foundry’s Municipal Products Group Vice President Scott Hoffman. “On behalf of Neenah Enterprises of Neenah, Wisconsin, our deep appreciation goes to Senator Baldwin for her leadership in securing a five-year extension of the procurement preference for American-made iron and steel products for drinking water infrastructure. Senator Baldwin has been a leader on a multitude of Buy America efforts to ensure that taxpayer-financed public infrastructure uses castings produced in American foundries like Neenah.”
The Drinking Water State Revolving Fund is a federal-state partnership that acts as an infrastructure bank to help ensure safe drinking water in all 50 states and territories. Baldwin’s legislation would require all of these projects to use American-made iron and steel. Eligible projects include improving drinking water treatment; fixing or replacing old pipes; improving the source of the water supply; replacing or constructing finished water storage tanks; or any other infrastructure projects needed to protect public health. 
Read more about Senator Baldwin’s leadership to push for a permanent Buy America commitment from Washington that rewards our Made in Wisconsin workers and manufacturers here.

Subject: My part in Time magazine’s “Guns in America” special report
Message:
￼
   ABOUT ERIC | MY WEBSITE | E-MAIL ME | SUBSCRIBE
￼￼￼￼
 
Dear Neighbor,   Too many times in recent years, we’ve learned of a new mass shooting horror - Aurora, Newtown, San Bernardino, Orlando, Las Vegas, Sutherland Springs, Parkland, and so many others. Each time we hug our loved ones close and ask, “When will this end?”  We can only reduce the risk of these massacres if Congress acts, but that means a lot more than just holding a moment of silence. It means passing common-sense gun violence prevention legislation to expand background checks for gun purchases. It means no longer letting the NRA get in the way of even the most basic legislation like banning bump-stocks and providing funding for gun violence research. And, I believe, it means acting to remove military-style weapons of war from our communities.  I shared my thoughts with Time recently as part of the magazine’s tremendous Guns in America project. Time journalists interviewed 245 of Americans with varying views on guns and gun violence, as renowned artist JR filmed and photographed us. The result is the cover story for the Nov. 5 edition of the magazine and a stunning online interactive experience that truly delves into where we stand on this vital issue. Take a look and hear the voices: 
￼
As you’ll hear, I believe we must listen to the kids whose lives have been indelibly marked by gun violence.  This issue divides us deeply, even within our 15th District. But for as long as we can’t speak to each other reasonably about it, more Americans will die needlessly. We don’t have the luxury of silence and inaction.  As always, it is an honor to serve you in the U.S. Congress. Please visit my website or contact my East Bay office at 510-370-3322 if we can be of service in any way. To stay connected, join me on Twitter @RepSwalwell and Facebook.  Sincerely,   ￼ Eric Swalwell Member of Congress

Subject: Better Off Now
Message:
News from Representative Jeff Duncan

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward to friend
￼
 
ABOUT ME
CONTACT ME
SERVING YOU
MEDIA CENTER
LEGISLATIVE WORK
OUR DISTRICT 
RESOURCES
 

October 25, 2018
￼
 
￼

￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

Friends,
Our economy hasn’t been this good since the Reagan Era! We are making history with the lowest unemployment rate ever, middle class tax cuts, record-setting deregulation, monumental strides in our foreign relations, strengthening our military, reforming the VA, combating the opioid epidemic, confirming conservative judges, and the list goes on. The American people wanted a leader that was going to deliver on their promises, and that is just what we got with President Trump. While there is still work to be done, there is no denying that our nation is better off now. I am proud to support a President that continues to make the people’s priorities his own. The progress over the last 20 months has been enormous – take a look HERE. 
I have been getting a lot of feedback on the positive impact President Trump’s actions have had on South Carolina’s economy. Bottom line – we are absolutely soaring on the job front. Since President Trump took office, more than 3.5 million jobs have been created, and our unemployment rate is the lowest it’s been in decades. We are coming up on the sixth straight month of having more job openings than job seekers. South Carolina is looking at a 3.3% unemployment rate, and our employment gains are on the rise. According to the South Carolina Department of Employment and Workforce (DEW), just in September 2018 we had over 300 new jobs created in the construction industry, over 200 in the education and health services industry, and over 200 in the manufacturing industry. While many were sadly interrupted by Hurricanes Florence and Michael, our state has luckily had an incredible amount of support from Governor McMaster’s office and businesses have been able to get back up and running again. For more information, check out the DEW’s statement that was released last week.   
President Trump and Congressional Republicans have ushered in an era of huge economic success for our country – it’s truly remarkable what will happen when you cut taxes, eliminate red-tape, and implement pro-business, free-market policies: 
	•	US regains title of world’s most competitive economy (Fox Business) 
	•	US job openings climb to record 7.1 million – exceed number of unemployed Americans (Market Watch) 
	•	September US unemployment rate hits lowest since 1969 (Financial Times) 
	•	US economy grew at a brisk 4.2% annual rate last quarter (AP) 
	•	The US manufacturing job market hasn't been this strong in over 20 years (Business Insider) 
	•	Worker pay rate hits highest level since 2008 (CNBC) 
	•	Report: Regulations being cut at record pace, savings double (Washington Examiner) 
	•	Workers Hardest Hit by Recession Are Joining in Recovery (New York Times) 
	•	Americans haven’t been this confident in the economy since 1990s Internet boom (Market Watch) 
	•	Youth Unemployment Hits 52-Year Low (Wall Street Journal) 
	•	 Small business optimism at 35-year high (Fox News) 
	•	U.S. Small-Business Owners' Optimism at Record High (Gallup)
	•	 Job satisfaction hits 51 percent, highest level since 2005 (The Hill)
	•	‘Rip-roaring hot' jobs market sees private payrolls surge by 230,000, highest since February (CNBC)
As always, it is an honor to serve as your Congressman. Your feedback is invaluable as it helps me better represent you in Congress. Should you have any comments or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to one of my offices in South Carolina or Washington. Also, don’t forget to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for real time updates on my work for the Third District.

Subject: Update from Rep. Collins: Local Wins and the Opioid Battle
Message:
￼ 



October 25, 2018 

Dear Friends,
I hope this finds you well as we reflect on the progress we've made on issues important to Northeast Georgia, including winning local television programming for orphan county residents, passing a landmark bill to battle the opioid epidemic, and honoring fallen heroes. 
Delivering Relief to Opioid Victims 
Earlier this year, I introduced the Substance Abuse Prevention Act to deliver practical solutions to people impacted by America's opioid crisis. This week, President Trump signed that bill into law as part of the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act. The Substance Abuse Prevention Act reauthorizes funding for drug courts—which we've seen help Georgians by rescuing people from addiction and lessening the strain on the justice system—and for federal, state, and local law enforcement task forces to fight drug trafficking, among other initiatives. 
By passing the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, Congress has prioritized American families and directed more than $8 billion to fight the opioid epidemic, which steals thousands of lives each year. Working with the Trump Administration to invest in a healthier, safer America by treating and preventing opioid addiction is a promise that I'm proud to have kept on behalf of people across Northeast Georgia. 
  
￼ 
  
Winning Access to Local TV for Georgians 
For years, I've been fighting alongside residents of Georgia's orphan counties, who have been asking for access to Georgia programming. Currently, these communities are limited to satellite TV coverage from North or South Carolina, but that's finally changing. I authored language in the 2014 Satellite Television Extension and Localism Act Reauthorization Act to give orphan counties the chance to petition the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to move into a different TV market area if their residents support that change.   
My team and I worked with Franklin County to help the county petition the FCC to join a Georgia media market so that residents have access to news, weather, and sports coverage from their own state. The FCC granted Franklin County's request this September, which is great news for that community and other orphan counties who want to receive in-state programming. I look forward to continuing these efforts with Northeast Georgians who want improved access to local coverage. 
  
￼
Two years ago, the Carothers family lost a father and husband in the line of duty. U.S. Marshal Patrick Carothers was a hero who ran toward danger in order to serve others, and we honored him this week with the Congressional Badge of Bravery.
  
Fighting for Handicap Access and Community Control
Northeast Georgians rely on their local post offices each day, but Elberton's post office remains inaccessible to residents with limited mobility. Last October, I wrote to the U.S. Postal Service because there was no ramp, walkway, or elevator available to individuals with limited mobility.  
Now, a year later, the Postal Service has still not made the post office fully handicap accessible. In fact, it has also declined a common sense request from local residents who wanted to use local resources to open the facility to everyone. 
I am more concerned than ever that people who depend on the Elberton Post Office are being denied a solution that would enable residents with limited mobility to access a public facility, so I've formally asked the U.S. Postal Service for answers about what's behind their decision and their inaction. I hope that we can make progress on this front soon, and I will continue advocating for a solution for the Elberton community. 
  

￼
The AP Government students at Cherokee Bluff High School asked me insightful questions about the issues that matter to Northeast Georgians this week. We talked about free speech, student loans, and becoming active, inquisitive readers.
  

Representing the priorities of Georgia's 9th District remains a humbling responsibility. If you'd like to keep up with the latest news about the policy improvements I support and why they matter to Northeast Georgia, I invite you to sign up for my regular newsletters. You can also follow me on Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube. 
Yours in service, 
 ￼ 
Doug Collins 
Member of Congress 
  
 ￼

 ￼

Subject: This Week’s E-Newsletter – Opioid, FAA, Water Resources bills signed into law; Social Security announces 2.8% increase
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
Can't see the pictures? Select "Always display images" or view this message in your browser 
￼

 
October 25, 2018
 
￼ 
Dear Friend,
Welcome to your weekly update. As always, you can learn more about these and other legislative issue at my website: lance.house.gov. 
Landmark Opioid Legislation Signed Into Law 
A sweeping bill to combat the nation’s opioid crisis is now law. President Donald Trump signed the the “SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act” at a ceremony Wednesday at the White House.
The new law represents the largest legislative effort to combat a single drug crisis in history. 
Among other things, it allows the United States Postal Service to scan packages for illicit opioids, increases funding for comprehensive recovery centers, and allows Medicaid to cover a larger array of treatment options for patients struggling with addiction.  The measure strengthens efforts to stop the flow of illegal narcotics such as fentanyl and to cut down on opioid prescriptions in favor of non-addictive painkillers.
I am most proud of the fact that the new law includes legislation – the Eliminating Opioid-Related Infectious Diseases Act – that I authored to confront the rising cases of HIV, hepatitis C and other infections stemming from drug-use. 
Social Security announces 2.8% increase 
I am pleased to announce a 2.8% Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) increase for more than 67 million Americans in 2019. 
The COLA is one of the Social Security’s most important protections, which ensures benefits keep up with inflation. 
Social Security also recently expanded their Compassionate Allowance List, which has enables them to identify and fast-track cases where individuals have diseases that are most likely to be approved for disability benefits.
Social Security is an earned benefit that Americans have paid into throughout their entire lives and I am committed to preserving and strengthening this vital program for today’s and tomorrow’s seniors. 
Clean Water legislation signed into law
President Trump recently signed into law water resources legislation authorizing projects to improve infrastructure at ports, inland waterways, locks, dams and flood mitigation. 
Included in the new law are two provisions I authored.  One measure would instruct the Army Corps of Engineers to expedite a study of the feasibility of removing the Warren Glen Dam in the Musconetcong River between Warren and Hunterdon counties.  The dam is often cited as an environmental hazard and is decades out of commission. In addition to making the Musconetcong Watershed area safer, removal of this dam would also foster a larger habitat for fish like the American shad which have been declining.
A second measure concerning the Rahway River and expediting completion of the Army Corps’ study for better flood risk management was also part of the new law.  That project has been stalled for years but is facing renewed interest at my request. 
Federal Aviation Administration Reauthorization signed into law 
The President recently signed the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act into law. 
This five-year reauthorization provides long-term stability for the Nation’s aviation community, continues investment in airports across the country, improves America’s competitiveness in the global aviation sector, strengthens passenger protections, and ensures the safety of the system for the traveling public. 
Also tucked in the FAA reauthorization is my legislative language forcing the FAA to create a plan to better manage local pilots inconvenienced by flight restrictions around Bedminster during visits by the President. 
Back in New Jersey 
With no votes in the House this week, I am hard at work in the Seventh Congressional District. 
Yesterday I joined Mayor James Dodd in touring the damage along West Blackwell and North Warren Streets following Monday’s massive fire in Dover.  I was also Succasunna this week to praise Habitat for Humanity and the volunteers who will help provide homes to those in need. 
I also announced more than $600,000 in federal FIRE grants for Raritan Township, Quakertown, Clinton and High Bridge fire departments.  And I visited the Cranford campus of Union County College to congratulate the school on receiving a $1.5 million award from the National Science Foundation (NSF).
To stay up to date on my work here at home, follow my Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. 
Best personal wishes,  ￼  Leonard Lance 
 

￼ 



Should you have further questions, please visit the “Contact” section of my website  This mailing was prepared, published and mailed at taxpayer expense.   Unsubscribe  
  

￼￼

Subject: Capitol Hill Update from Congressman Castro
Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
We are excited that early voting started this week in Texas, and a historic turnout is expected. Early voting runs through November 2nd, and y'all should visit votetexas.gov to learn more.  
Issues with Early Voting in Bexar County 
Our democracy only works if people actually have the opportunity to cast their ballots and show their political preference. So far, this election has not been run very smoothly in Bexar County. I joined State Senator José Menéndez (District 26) this week in a press conference to shed light on early voting issues we’ve seen.  
 ￼ 
This includes outdated voting machines with no paper records, system glitches, incorrect voter information, staffing shortages and lack of accommodations for disabled voters. You can read a transcript of my remarks here.  
You can read coverage about this press conference in the San Antonio Express-News. You can also listen to coverage on Texas Public Radio or watch my interview with KENS5.  
The Administration's Treatment of Migrant Children  
It was great to join my colleagues on the House Judiciary Committee in a letter to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary Alexander Azar and the Department of Justice (DOJ) Attorney General Jeff Sessions on a new video teleconference hearing initiative requiring detained unaccompanied immigrant children to appear in their immigration court proceedings by video. 
The challenges to due process for vulnerable immigrant children that are posed by these hearings are too numerous and severe to overcome. That’s why we called on DOJ and HHS to terminate this initiative. You can read the full letter here. 
District Update 
Team Castro hosted senior office hours at the Willie M. Cortez Senior Center; attended the opening of the Texas Department of Transportation open-house; joined the National Disability Employment Awareness Month as the City of San Antonio issues a City Proclamation; and met with the Recording Academy.
￼ ￼￼ ￼ ￼  
Featured Constituent 
I am proud to see a San Antonian—Laura Reilly—competing in the Broadcom MASTERS STEM middle school competition with her project on the use of tilapia skin in treating human skin wounds. It was great to have you come by my D.C. office, and know we will be rooting for you!
The Fight to End Alzheimer’s 
It was great to join the Alzheimer Association’s Walk to End Alzheimer’s in San Antonio. Alzheimer’s is a truly terrible disease and we must continue working together to fund research and find a cure.
￼ ￼ 
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov.  
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress

Subject: Drug Take-Back Day this Saturday
Message:
￼ 
Thursday October 25, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼

National Drug Take-Back Day
Friend,

This Saturday, October 27th, is the Drug Enforcement Administration's (DEA) Drug Take-Back Day. Mark your calendars: from 10AM - 2PM, you can properly dispose of expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs at certain locations in our communities, hosted by local police and sheriffs' departments.

Drug Take-Back Day is part of the effort to fight the opioid epidemic impacting so many of our friends, families, and neighbors here in Ohio's Second District. Fighting the opioid epidemic starts at a local level, with members of the community helping each other with both recovery and prevention. It is up to each of us to raise awareness and take steps to cut the supply of prescription opiates, which too often act as a gateway to heroin and other dangerous drugs.

￼

Locations all across southern and southwest Ohio will be collecting unwanted prescription drugs for disposal this Saturday. Click above to find a nearby collection site. For more information about National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day in our communities, check out the DEA website here.

In your service,
￼

P.S. President Trump just signed the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, our biggest commitment yet in the fight against opioid addiction. This bipartisan package of bills is targeted towards advancing treatment and recovery initiatives, improving addiction prevention, protecting our communities, and bolstering efforts to fight deadly synthetic drugs like fentanyl.

Subject: Federal Grant Awarded for Opioid Response Program Planning In 14 Michigan Counties
Message:
￼
 
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Oct 25, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158


Federal Grant Awarded for Opioid Response Program Planning In 14 Michigan Counties

Washington - Yesterday, President Trump signed H.R. 6 into law. This sweeping legislation addresses the opioid crisis that has ravaged our nation. Today, HRSA awarded $400,000 in grants to Michigan, with $200,000 designated to The Michigan Center for Rural Health. Congressman Jack Bergman released the following statement:  "The opioid epidemic has swept our nation, tearing families apart through the grasps of addiction. Unfortunately, rural communities in Michigan's First District are no exception, and in some cases, have even higher rates of opioid addiction than urban or suburban communities. It's imperative that state, federal, and local officials continue to work together with community leaders to best address this crisis in our neighborhoods. I''m proud of the work our rural health clinics do, and I'm pleased HRSA provided this grant to this great organization," said Bergman.  Over the last 20 months Rep. Bergman has held multiple roundtables across the First District of Michigan with Healthcare providers, law enforcement officials, EMS leaders, county officials, addiction treatment professionals, and those fighting the chains of addiction to discuss best practices to address this crisis in our back yard.   See below for the Michigan Center for Rural Health release on today's Grant announcement:
The Michigan Center for Rural Health (MCRH) was awarded a $200,000 Rural Communities Opioid Response Program (RCORP) planning grant by the Health Resources & Services Administration (HRSA) to focus on opioid use disorder in the following 14 northern MI counties (Alcona, Alpena, Cheboygan, Clare, Crawford, Gladwin, Kalkaska, Lake, Montmorency, Ogemaw, Oscoda, Otsego, Presque Isle, Roscommon). Over the next year, MCRH will help facilitate the work of the newly formed Northern Michigan Opioid Response Consortium (NMORC).
The NMORC was assembled to coordinate efforts, and identify areas of best practice for replication and expansion, pinpoint gaps in care and develop solutions, leverage state resources to address system and policy issues, and reduce the duplication of efforts in 14 northern MI counties. The planning grant will focus on the areas of prevention, treatment, recovery and workforce. NMORC is governed by a Board of Directors and consortium members include hospitals, community health centers, local public health departments, community mental health agencies, local community-based organizations and state of MI agencies dedicated to addressing opioid use disorder.  
bergman.house.gov  
###

Subject: Another forest management project stopped by environmental extremism!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





My fight to combat fringe litigation and reduce red tape
￼
Within the Fleecer Mountains Project area, spruce budworm-defoliated Douglas-fir regeneration with Douglas-fir beetle-killed trees, Jerry Creek. Photo: fs.usda.gov
What's New:  A federal judge in Montana recently maintained an injunction against an important forest management project in the Beaverhead-Deer lodge National Forest. The Fleecer Mountains Project would improve forest resiliency and support wood products jobs by providing over 34 million board feet of timber. Planning for this project began in 2009—and nearly a decade later it is still being blocked due to fringe litigation!  The court said the Forest Service did not adequately consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service following new sightings of lynx in the forest. This rationale was based off the terrible standard that the Ninth Circuit’s Cottonwood ruling imposed. The Forest Service has already completed another round of analysis concerning the lynx, but now they’re being told the “new information” requires even more paperwork. Both the Trump Administration and the Obama Administration disagree with the Cottonwood ruling, and I have introduced legislation alongside Montana Representative Greg Gianforte to fully reverse that disastrous decision.  Why It Matters:  The Beaverhead-Deer lodge National Forest is experiencing the devastating consequences of insect infestation, and forest health continues to deteriorate. Because of this court ruling and the underlying Cottonwood decision, the Forest Service cannot begin its commonsense project to allow targeted salvage of the dead and damaged trees and create a more resilient landscape. This hurts the environment and local economies surrounding this National Forest.  What’s Next:
The Forest Service must now go back to the drawing and do MORE paperwork in response to the court’s ruling. It’s appalling that this project—which was created with public input and support—is still not being carried out. I will continue to fight against fringe litigation and to fully reverse the disastrous Cottonwood decision and I urge all Montanans to join me.   
Survey:

Subject: Homegrown Innovation
Message:
￼
￼
PHOTO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich tours the upgraded facility of SolAero Technologies in the Sandia Science and Technology Park in Albuquerque, October 23, 2018.
October 25, 2018
Dear Friend,
New Mexico has long played a leading role in protecting our national security and advancing scientific innovation. As I work to bolster the missions at our state's military installations and national labs, I am also focused on boosting the private tech industry, improving the process to transfer innovative technologies from research and defense labs to the private sector, and creating new high-tech jobs.
This week, I was pleased to tour a great example of a homegrown business that is creating good-paying jobs and positioning New Mexico as a national leader in emerging high-tech fields. SolAero Technologies manufactures solar cells for space power applications. The company has worked with the Air Force Research Laboratory at Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque to develop more efficient solar cells for small satellite and low-Earth-orbit missions. SolAero's cells can provide more power for less weight to satellites used by the military and commercial space companies.
On the Senate Armed Services Committee, I have been an ardent supporter of the small-satellite and space testing missions at Kirtland that are replacing current systems with with an agile, low-cost system architecture resulting in lower production costs and increased performance. These missions are saving taxpayer dollars, making us safer, and creating opportunities for innovative local companies like SolAero to develop and supply our military with state-of-the-art technologies. SolAero recently completed a $10 million upgrade to its facility in the Sandia Science and Technology Park, where it now employs 320 people, up from 250 in early 2017.
I am committed to doing all I can to foster opportunities to grow new high-paying science and manufacturing jobs. That's why I am advancing policies that help mature technologies developed at our national labs to build high-tech manufacturing businesses with great potential to grow. We also need to educate our students and retrain our labor force for a lucrative high-tech job market.
If we are going to diversify and strengthen New Mexico's economy, we must target areas where we have the potential to create jobs and major new industries. If we support creative homegrown companies like SolAero and build a skilled workforce, we can build a vibrant and thriving economy.
Sincerely,
￼
MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator

Featured Funding Opportunities and Grant Assistance:
HHS is proud to announce the launch of the Niche Assessment Program for the 2018-2019 program year. Designed to help small businesses strategically position their technology in the marketplace, Niche provides an in-depth report on potential applications of participants’ technology. All active HHS (NIH, CDC, and FDA) SBIR/STTR Phase I awardees and Phase I Fast-Track awardees (by grant or contract) are eligible to apply. Registration is on a first come, first serve basis! The Niche Assessment Program provides market insight and data that can be used to help small businesses strategically position their technology in the marketplace.
 
20th Annual U.S. Department of Health and Human Services SBIR/STTR Conference - October 30 - November 1, 2018 Dallas, Texas. This national conference is the cornerstone of the HHS’s congressionally mandated outreach efforts. This three-day national HHS SBIR/STTR Conference is designed to educate attendees about the America’s Largest Seed Fund and how to apply for these research and development dollars. With over $1 billion dollars of annual HHS funding, this is one of the largest sources of early-stage capital for technology commercialization in the United States. The HHS’s SBIR/STTR programs allow US-owned small businesses to forge academic partnerships and build productive businesses. With this funding, the partners can engage in research and development that has a strong potential to deliver products and services, including medical devices, diagnostics, digital health, biotechnology and pharmaceuticals, to improve the health of Americans.

Subject: Share Your Thoughts on Mail Delivery in Chicago
Message:
District Update | October 25, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friend,
Throughout 2018, my district office has received countless calls from constituents sharing their troubling experiences with poor mail delivery service. From damaged packages to mail arriving at the wrong address or going missing for weeks at a time, these serious issues are prevalent and persistent across the Fifth District. You deserve to have confidence in the delivery of life-saving medicines, bank statements, passports, and other important documents.
I brought up these complaints with Postmaster General Megan Brennan in August, and despite verbal assurances that the U.S. Postal Service would address the problems, Chicagoans continue to suffer. That’s why I recently sent the Postmaster General a follow-up letter demanding immediate answers regarding the causes of delivery issues and additional information on the steps the USPS will take to prevent these problems going forward.
Now, I want to hear from you. After an outpouring of feedback on a recent Facebook post, I’ve created a survey to learn more about your experiences with mail delivery and ways you believe USPS can improve the situation. I hope you will share your thoughts, and I thank you for calling attention to these failures that demand our attention.
Click here to take the two-minute survey. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Mike Quigley

Subject: Signed into Law
Message:
￼ 


Hoosiers,  Yesterday, President Trump signed the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6) into law. I pushed for the strong, comprehensive approach that H.R. 6 takes on our nation's continued fight against the opioid epidemic.  The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act is a compilation of more than 50 bills to forge ahead in our historic fight to provide tools to Hoosier families and communities hit by the scourge of opioid addiction. H.R. 6 addresses:
	•	Treatment and Recovery. Improves and expands access to treatment and recovery services and establishes comprehensive opioid recovery centers.  
	•	Prevention. Encourages non-addictive opioid alternatives to treat pain and addresses high prescribing rates while enhancing prescription drug monitoring programs.  
	•	Protecting Communities. Gives law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of our communities and the resources to better intercept illicit opioids at international mail faciliites.  
	•	Fight Fentanyl. Cracks down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs and provides grants for local communities to combat fentanyl.
We all know someone, whether it's a family member, a friend, or a neighbor, who has been affected by this crisis. That's why I won't stop fighting for commonsense measures, like H.R. 6, to curb the tragedies caused by illicit opioids in our country.

Be of good cheer,
￼


P.S. Saturday is Drug Take-Back Day. From 10AM-2PM, you can properly dispose of expired, unused, and unwanted prescription drugs to support ongoing efforts to combat the opioid epidemic that is facing our communities. Click here to find a drop-off location near you. 

Be sure to connect with Trey online:

Subject: by the numbers - serving you
Message:
￼

Hello, 

As your voice in Congress, I've always made it a priority to be accessible and available across all ten counties in Eastern Washington. This Congress, which began in January 2017, I've had 12 town hall events, and hosted nearly 1,000 meetings with constituents. 

Just last week, I launched an interactive map on my website to be more accountable and transparent to you. 

￼ 
To date, I've logged thousands of miles listening to people across Eastern Washington, and I'm taking action to deliver results for you. Here is a look at my work this Congress by the numbers (as of October 19, 2018): 

113,620 - Emails, letters, and phone calls to constituents who reached out 
3,232 - Constituents who enjoyed a Capitol tour from my staff 
926 - Total meetings held with constituents 
546 - Total number of constituents and their families helped through casework 
187 - Flags ordered through our office and flown over the Capitol 
146 - Veterans my office helped navigate the VA to receive the care they earned 
102 - Local media availabilities 
98 - People who received checks from the Social Security Administration with my office's help 
12 - Town halls to listen to your stories and hear your concerns 
10 - Number of my bills that passed the House of Representatives 
6 - Number of my bills signed into law 

Embracing change, being innovative, and seeking to provide excellent constituent services all comes back to one thing: my mission to restore trust and confidence in representative government for you and the people of Eastern Washington. 
Thanks, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress

Subject: Honoring Jennifer's Legacy
Message:
If you are using an iPad or iPhone, click here to view this email in your Web browser. 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

Dear Friends, 

It’s hard to believe that it’s been a year since Jennifer Kepner – a loving mother, devoted wife, and U.S. Air Force veteran – passed away from cancer caused by her exposure to burn pits. 

I remember sitting at Jennifer’s kitchen table like it was yesterday. Despite her ongoing battle with pancreatic cancer, Jennifer’s first concern was for her husband Ben and their two young children. Her second concern? The many veterans who – like her – contracted rare cancers and chronic conditions resulting from their exposure to toxic burn pits in Iraq and Afghanistan. 

￼ 

Jennifer’s final wish was for her fellow veterans to be spared the pain she and her family endured. Her empathy is the reason we are fighting to end the use of burn pits and get exposed veterans the care they have earned and deserve. For the first time in nearly a decade, we’ve gotten new legislation on burn pits signed into law, and a renewed focus on burn pits thanks to the formation of the bipartisan Burn Pits Caucus. Because of Jennifer, the momentum is on our side. 

Jennifer lived a life defined by service and patriotism. Her legacy inspires me to this day and pushes me to work harder to live up to her memory and carry forward her final wishes. 

Thank you for joining me to remember Jennifer, 

￼
Raul Ruiz, M.D.
Member of Congress

Subject: Growing Washington's Space Industry
Message:
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT SUZAN  |   HOW CAN I HELP?  |   NEWSROOM  |   ISSUES  |   CONTACT 
GROWING WASHINGTON'S SPACE INDUSTRY
Dear Friend,
Washington state boasts a diverse range of innovative sectors, including an exciting local space industry. Our space industry supports more than 6,000 jobs and generates $1.7 billion for our economy. To sustain economic growth in our region, we must have an open dialogue between policymakers and industry leaders to understand the challenges and opportunities ahead and how we can best prepare for those.
That’s why I joined House Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer (D-MD), whose district includes NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, for a roundtable discussion hosted by Aerojet Rocketdyne along with other companies leading Washington state’s space industry. The dialogue focused on how to continue developing our space expertise and Congress’s role in supporting new innovations to benefit all Americans. The discussion was part of Rep. Hoyer’s “Make It in America” initiative, which aims to produce favorable conditions for U.S. businesses and expand economic opportunity for American workers. 
Retaining a competitive workforce, supporting STEM research, and enhancing the workforce pipeline are critical to producing a robust economy. Learning from space companies about their challenges and which strategies can help foster success was an invaluable experience. I remain committed to supporting policies that encourage entrepreneurship and advancement in this new and growing sector.
As always, my office is here to serve you. If you have questions or comments about the topics that matter most to you, I encourage you to contact me through my website. You may also keep up-to-date on what I’m doing by following me on social media or signing up for my eNewsletter. If you need assistance in dealing with a federal agency, such as the VA, IRS or Department of Education, please do not hesitate to contact my Bothell office at (425) 485-0085.  Sincerely,  Suzan

￼

￼   Landmark Opioid Legislation Signed Into Law
I joined President Trump and the First Lady at the White House for the bill signing of H.R. 6, the SUPPORT Patients and Communities Act, with a bipartisan group of U.S. Senators, Members of Congress, NIH Director Francis Collins, Loudoun County Sheriff Mike Chapman, and other Cabinet Members and Administration officials. 
This is the culmination of years of work by thousands of people to address our nation’s opioid crisis. As a member of the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force, I have advocated for Federal policies that support our local law enforcement, healthcare treatment providers, and help address the root cause of this epidemic. Congress appropriated unprecedented funding of $6 billion this year to address this public health crisis and included as part of H.R. 6 are provisions of my bill, H.R. 5473, the Better Pain Management Through Better Data Act, to facilitate better clinical data and standards on non-opioid alternatives. I got to speak with NIH Director Collins about the research that NIH is doing on non-opioid alternatives and the increased funding we provided for it. 
Thank you, ￼  Barbara Comstock Member of Congress

Subject: 2018 Economic Report
Message:
News from Representative Brat 
￼ 
Website 
Subscribe
To Newsletter 
Constituent
Services 
Legislative
Resources 
Press
Shop 
About 
Dave 
Contact
Dave 



Dear Friend, 
Four years ago, I came to Congress as an economist and a college professor. I believed it was just plain wrong for the students I was teaching to graduate and not know if there would be a job out there for them.
I began working on a pro-growth agenda. I know hard-working American families built this nation, so we should do what we can to put money back into their hands. And we should get government out of the way by reining in unnecessarily burdensome regulations.
Some in DC cautioned that this strategy wouldn’t work. I am pleased to report that the state of the American economy is EXCELLENT.
We are in a period of strong growth where businesses of all sizes are expanding and are reaching record-level optimism.
	•	Since January 2017, the economy has added 3.8 million jobs.
	•	The U.S. unemployment rate for September sank to 3.7% -- the lowest since 1969. The African-American unemployment rate hit its all-time low of 5.9% in May, the Hispanic unemployment rate hit its all-time low of 4.5% in July, and the unemployment rate for women is at its lowest in 65 years at 3.6%. 
	•	In August, the number of job openings hit an all-time high at 7.14 million. In fact, there were more job openings than workers even looking for jobs.
	•	Wage growth is at its highest it’s been in 17 months.
	•	An average American family (married with two kids) will save $2,917 in taxes this year.
	•	A single taxpayer will save an average of $1,400 in taxes this year.
	•	Confidence in the government’s economic policies rose in October to its highest level in the past 15 years – surpassing very strong economies in Singapore, Germany, Japan and Switzerland.
	•	Q2 GDP growth was confirmed 4.2%, the fastest rise in 4 years.
	•	In FY 2018, this administration eliminated 12 regulations for every 1 new significant regulation passed.
	•	This administration’s regulatory reform efforts have led to $23 billion in cost savings.
	•	In September, NFIB’s Small Business optimism index was at its third highest reading in the survey’s 45 year history and the National Association of Manufacturers’ optimism survey is the highest ever.
	•	Consumer confidence hit 138.4 in September, very close to the all-time high of 144.7 achieved in 2000.
Gone are the days of gloomy reports of unemployment and an economy stuck in neutral. This is why Americans trust Republicans over Democrats with handling the economy by 15 points and more than half of Americans now rate the economy as good or excellent.
The last thing we need to do right now is to move our economy backwards.
	•	During the previous administration, there were at least 21 tax hikes enacted. 
	•	The Congressional Budget Office and Tax Policy Center both showed that average tax rates rose under President Obama. 
	•	Americans suffered more binding regulations and growing government, as well as increased borrowing and spending. During the Obama presidency, there were 20,642 new regulations added. 
	•	In the first 21 months alone, Obama’s administration imposed $245 billion in burdensome regulations. 
	•	The American people felt it, too. In 2015, NBC reported only 34% of Americans believed the American dream still holds true. 59% of Americans said the next generation would be worse off than the current one.
And a nonprofit think tank has reported that families in Virginia’s 7th District would lose $40,621 in take home pay over the next 10 years if Democrats are successful in their desire to roll back the tax cuts.
As an economist and representative of Virginia’s 7th District, I will continue to be an advocate for a pro-growth agenda that benefits Virginia families.

Thank you,

￼

Congressman Dave Brat

Subject: SIGNED INTO LAW: Bipartisan Opioid Bill
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | Contact
THE BIPARTISAN OPIOID BILL IS NOW LAW
￼
For too long, families and communities across the country have been devastated by the opioid epidemic. Today we are taking a big step toward ending this crisis.
The president just signed H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, into law. This bipartisan, comprehensive legislation will provide critical tools and resources to help those on the front lines of this fight. 
￼
It will also build on the legacy of Dr. Todd Graham with provisions named in the Hoosier doctor’s honor.
Before he was tragically killed last year over an opioid prescription, Dr. Graham was dedicated to treating patients not only for their pain but for the underlying causes. That is why I worked to include this measure to advance the model of care he championed.
￼
I’m hopeful this legislation will help end the opioid epidemic by improving access to non-opioid pain treatments and enabling doctors to better treat patients and prevent addiction.
￼
Additionally, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act includes provisions to:
	•	Expand access to addiction recovery services;
	•	Give Medicare beneficiaries access to more treatment options such as Medication-Assisted Treatment;
	•	Establish comprehensive opioid recovery centers;
	•	Improve efforts to help at-risk patients;
	•	Enhance prescription drug monitoring programs;
	•	Support law enforcement efforts to combat dangerous drugs;
	•	Prevent shipment of illicit opioids in international mail;
	•	Crack down on synthetic drugs; and
	•	Provide local communities additional resources to address the opioid epidemic.
The opioid epidemic is taking a terrible toll on our communities. It is my hope that this vital new law will help Hoosiers work together to prevent and treat addiction and assist in recovery. 
As always, it is a privilege to represent 2nd District Hoosiers in Congress.
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website and join me on social media:
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Sincerely,
￼
Jackie Walorski U.S. Congresswoman

Subject: We Must Lower Prescription Drug Prices
Message:
￼    ￼   ￼

￼
Prescription drug costs are too high for Montanans, period. 
￼
Too many seniors on a fixed income are forced to choose between keeping the heat on and purchasing their lifesaving prescription drugs, and too many Montana families are forced to break the bank just to afford the medicines their kids need to live healthy lives.  That is why I am holding pharmaceutical companies accountable to lower prescription drug prices for all Montanans.  My bill, the CREATES Act, gives generic drug makers access to samples of name brand drugs so they can get more affordable versions on the market. This bill will bring down the costs that you pay. This bill will also decrease the federal deficit by $3.9 billion over the next decade because of cost savings to Medicare.   Montanans are too often left in the dark while prescription drug companies set prices.   I’m also sponsoring the SPIKE Act to bring more transparency to prescription drug pricing. This bill will force pharmaceutical companies to disclose detailed information about why they are raising costs.   And I am also pushing to prevent pharmaceutical middlemen from charging unjustified fees that raise drug prices for the rest of us.  These are common sense proposals that all Montanans can get behind.   My bills will protect Montanans from another painful round of prescription drug price hikes because you should never have to lay awake at night worrying about how you’ll pay for the prescriptions you and your family need to stay healthy.


 ￼
TESTER.SENATE.GOV | UNSUBSCRIBE

Subject: Aloha from Senator Schatz's Office
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼ 

Home | About | Newsroom | At Your Service | Representing Hawai‘i’s Values | Contact


October 24, 2018 

Aloha, 
  
I am pleased that Hawai‘i will be receiving more than $200 million to improve the Ala Wai Canal and watershed, reduce flood risks in the area, and strengthen flood warning systems. This major investment will make sure the Army Corps has the funding it needs to strengthen the canal and protect residents against flooding.  
  
We need a comprehensive approach to dealing with our country's opioid epidemic.  The bipartisan legislation passed earlier this month includes several of my provisions that will expand the use of telehealth to treat opioid addiction and increase funding for non-opioid pain treatment.  As always, please contact my office in D.C. or Hawai‘i if there is anything we can do. We are here to help.  Mahalo, 
 


Brian Schatz 
United States Senator 



Addressing the Opioid Epidemic
The U.S. Senate passed sweeping legislation to address the nation’s opioid crisis, including measures authored by Senator Schatz. Senator Schatz’s provisions would fund new research on non-addictive, non-opioid alternatives to treat and prevent pain and expand the use of telehealth to treat opioid addiction. 
  
“Opioid addiction is a national epidemic, and we need a comprehensive approach to address it,” said Senator Schatz. “Our bill will use technology to help connect health care professionals with more patients and help providers access the continuing education they need to treat addiction. It also invests in more research to find alternative treatments for pain so that we can try to stop opioid addiction before it starts.”
  
The Schatz provisions will: 
	•	Increase access to substance use disorder treatment through telehealth technology under Medicare. The provision eliminates originating site geographic restrictions for telehealth services to treat substance use disorders;
	•	Fund training for health professionals to treat opioid addiction based on the Project Extension for Community Health Outcomes, also known as the ECHO model. The ECHO model has already successfully helped states like New Mexico increase the number of physicians qualified to dispense or prescribe medication-assisted treatment for opioid addiction; and
	•	Give the National Institutes of Health more authority to spur research on the understanding of pain and the discovery of non-addictive painkillers to help treat chronic pain.

Connecting with the Hawaiian Community
Senator Schatz was invited to address the Annual Native Hawaiian Convention.  He discussed some of the challenges indigenous groups face at the Supreme Court and new policies that will affect the Native Hawaiian community.  Senator Schatz, a member of the Appropriations Committee, also gave an update on increased funding for Native Hawaiian health and education programs. 
￼


Protecting Against Flooding
Legislation to improve water resources and infrastructure in Hawai‘i and across the country was passed by Congress and sent to the President for his signature. The sweeping bipartisan bill includes more than $212 million to improve the Ala Wai canal and watershed, reduce flood risks in the area, and strengthen flood warning systems. 
￼
According to a plan developed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the Ala Wai Canal and the watershed that flows into it requires significant upgrades to prevent catastrophic flooding in the event of a major storm. The federal funding in the legislation passed earlier this month would go towards implementing the Army Corps’ plan to reduce flood risks by improving the flood warning system, and constructing six in-stream debris and detention basins in the upper reaches of Makiki, Mānoa and Pālolo streams, one standalone debris catchment feature, three multi-purpose detention areas in open spaces through the developed watershed, and concrete floodwalls averaging 4 feet high along one or both sides of approximately 1.9 miles of the Ala Wai Canal.

Sharing Our Unique Stories
￼ 
Students from Mililani Middle School visiting the Capitol.
￼ 
UPW retirees ask questions and share some of their concerns with Senator Schatz. 
￼ 
Jerry Boster, board president of the Hawai'i Parkinson Association and recipient of the 2018 Department of Defense Disability Award. 

To respond to this message, please click here. This link will take you to a webpage where you can reply to messages that you receive from Senator Schatz's office. 


Honolulu Office p: (808) 523-2061 Washington Office p: (202) 224-3934 f: (202) 228-1153

Subject: President Trump signs new law combating Montana's meth crisis
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





New meaningful actions to reverse meth epidemic in Montana
￼
Senator Daines discussed meth’s negative impacts on the Fort Belknap Indian Community with leaders and representatives of those tribes. Art from a Fort Belknap tribal member depicts those negative impacts.
What's New:
This week President Trump signed into law bipartisan legislation to combat the meth and opioid crises in Montana and across our country. Methamphetamine in particular is destroying families and communities across our state, and it disproportionately impacts Native American tribes. This new law includes the resources and reforms needed to combat both epidemics.  I recently took to the Senate floor to highlight key provisions in this new law, including my Mitigating METH Act, which expands opioid crisis grants to include Indian tribes as eligible recipients. The new law also includes the STOP Act, a bill I championed to help stop opioids and drugs from crossing the border or being shipped through the Postal Service. And it reauthorizes the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area and Drug Courts programs that help fight against drug use in Montana.
Why It Matters:  In Montana opioid overdoses have claimed the lives of 700 people since 2000. In addition, we have seen a 415% increase in meth cases this decade and a 375% increase in meth-related deaths. And increased meth use has also resulted in a sharp increase in foster care cases, which is why I authored a separate new law making it easier for children in the system to remain with their parents in a safe, clinical setting while the parent receives substance abuse treatment.  Almost all meth in Montana is produced in Mexico and smuggled over the southern border, making it important that we work alongside Customs and Border Protection (CBP) to stem the flow of drugs entering our country. In a recent hearing with CBP, I urged them to prioritize securing the border to prevent meth from entering our communities.
What’s Next:  I applaud President Trump for signing this important legislation into law. It recognizes that the best way to combat this epidemic is encouraging coordinated efforts between federal, state, local, and tribal partners. I will continue to work with Montanans to help ensure this law is implemented as effectively as possible.   Share your story:   Has your family been impacted by the meth or opioid epidemic? Share your story with me HERE.
Best Wishes, 
￼
Steve Daines United States Senate

Subject: INVITE: We Believe Survivors - Domestic Violence Awareness Month
Message:
October 24, 2018

Dear Friends,

Violence against women is rampant. Seventy percent of women worldwide will experience physical or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in their lifetime. In the U.S., nearly 20 people per minute are physically abused by an intimate partner. One in five women and one in 71 men in the U.S. have been raped in their lifetime.
                                  



The impact of sexual trauma is severe and very difficult to overcome. In addition to being physically and psychologically scarred, victims are often re-victimized by being discredited and dismissed. This was on blatant display during the Justice Kavanaugh confirmation hearings. His testimony in response to Dr. Christine Blasey Ford’s reporting of sexual assault was a slap in the face to survivors across the country. This fall, Republicans in Congress failed to reauthorize VAWA, the Violence Against Women Act, beyond a three months extension until after the election.

Women deserve better. That’s why I am hosting a panel sending a clear message: We believe survivors. I hope you will join me for this important conversation that will focus on healing and recovering from trauma.

During the event, we will explore the transition from victim to survivor. I will moderate a panel with

Rosa Brenes, domestic violence survivor
Catharine A. MacKinnon, James Barr Ames Visiting Professor of Law, Harvard Law School
Colsaria Hederson, Executive Director CORA, Community Overcoming Relationship Abuse
Amanda LeBlanc Freeman, Program Director Rape Trauma Services
Al Serrato, Chief Deputy District Attorney, San Mateo County District Attorney’s Office
Ryan Monaghan, Lieutenant San Mateo Police Department
We Believe Survivors - Domestic Violence Awareness Month
Thursday, October 25, 2018
7:00 - 8:30 p.m.
San Mateo City Council Chambers
330 West 20th Avenue
San Mateo, CA 94403 

SIGN UP HERE! 

I look forward to having this important conversation with you on Thursday, October 25th!

All the best,

Message:

FOR IMMEDIATE DISTRIBUTION
Kwentoria A. Williams 
Wednesday, October 24, 2018
Cell Phone: 202-430-0125 
 
Email: algreenpress@mail.house.gov 
Congressman Al Green's Statement on Bomb Threats 
(Houston, TX) - On Wednesday, October 24, 2018, Congressman Al Green released the following statement regarding the suspicious packages discovered this week:
“Today, our country is in a state of alarming apprehension as we learn of the suspicious packages sent to Mr. George Soros, former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, former President and First Lady Obama, John Brennan at the CNN New York headquarters, former Attorney General Eric Holder, as well as Congresswoman Maxine Waters (CA-43). To say that these are collective coincidences defies logic. This is an assault on our democracy, an attack on our free press, and, most obviously, a threat to our safety. We have no way of knowing who may next receive one of these suspicious packages. We have no way of knowing whether these suspicious packages will be intercepted and properly handled before they reach the hands of the intended or if they will be detonated en route and cause harm to an innocent person regardless of their views. 
“Each of the recipients of these suspicious packages has been the brunt of President Trump’s incendiary rhetoric. While he may see his statements as mere words, they are capable of inciting injurious actions. As America’s Commander in Chief, his words may be internalized by many as a call to action. 
“Mr. President, you set the tone and tenor for our nation. If you continue to use dog whistle politics, someone will suffer more than apprehension.”

Subject: Legislative Updates from My Office
Message:
￼

 

Dear Friend, 
Progress on Opioid Package 
I’m pleased to share that, last month, the House of Representatives took action to address one of the most serious crises in our country: the opioid epidemic. We passed a package of bipartisan bills that included legislation I authored. The three bills -- H.R. 5722, H.R. 5790, and H.R. 4684 - focus on preventing addiction through access to mental health care, providing access to treatment alternatives that help individuals avoid opioids, and ensuring the best possible recovery for those who are working to overcome addiction. These three bills touch on the entire scope of the opioid crisis. They have bipartisan support and were crafted with the help of experts to target specific moments in the treatment process that can mean the difference between life and death. And with the President’s signature on October 24, I am proud that these bills are now law.  
Working with local students on gun violence 
Unfortunately, there is still much work left undone this Congress. One such example is addressing gun violence. This past year, we experienced some of the worst mass shootings in our history, but nothing has been done. Finally, after yet another tragic shooting, this time in Parkland, Florida, robbed us of 17 more lives, our country seems to have reached a turning point. Across the country, students who know they should not have to fear for their lives going to school have said enough is enough, and already, their actions have led to major retailers curbing their sales of guns, corporations cancelling support for the NRA, and more. I’ve been privileged to meet with many of these students from schools like Marjory Stoneman Douglas, and students from Pasadena and Alhambra, to talk about their experiences and their resolve to change our laws. 
I met with a remarkable class at Alhambra High School and I saw that resolve in action as they presented me with a gun violence resolution they had written themselves. The amount of research and work that the students, under the leadership of Mr. Sanchez, put into this resolution is truly impressive. They had vigorous debates on each provision, from banning assault weapons to implementing true universal background checks. They had a vote on each of those provisions.  They were thoughtful and impassioned as they presented their views to one another and to the public. And it worked. The resolution was adopted unanimously by the Alhambra Unified School District. I was so impressed by their work so last month, I introduced the students’ resolution as H.Res. 1076. 
A movement is growing, and these students are not afraid to stand up to the NRA if it means saving their lives. And I’m proud to stand with them. 
Funding the federal government 
On Friday, September 28, the House took our final votes before we return to Washington in November. We accomplished some things, but much remains for when we get back. 
First, we avoided a government shutdown by passing a “minibus” appropriations package that funds the Departments of Defense, Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education for Fiscal Year 2019. The bill also extended funding for the rest of the government until December 7, 2018. This spending package helps to take us away from the brink of another government shutdown, while avoiding many of the problematic poison pills – like a border wall or defunding Planned Parenthood – that Republicans have sought. In addition, it provides robust funding for programs like the Low-Income Heating Assistance Program (LIHEAP), Head Start, and the National Institutes of Health. It also walks back one of President Trump’s attacks on women by fully funding the Title X Family Planning Program. Other victories in this package include an increase in the maximum Pell Grant award and language directing the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services to submit a family reunification plan for those separated at the border to Congress. However, this bill is not perfect. Defense spending remains disproportionately high, while also preventing actions to close Guantanamo Bay. And while the September shutdown was avoided, the deadline was only pushed back a few months. That means passing a reasonable budget while avoiding the next government shutdown will be at the top of our agenda in November. 
Tax Scam 2.0 
But passing a fair budget has become much more difficult thanks to the Republican Tax Scam, which has ballooned our deficits to pay for tax cuts to the wealthiest few. That damage was made worse last month as Republicans followed up with another series of bills – H.R. 6756, the American Innovation Act of 2018, H.R. 6757, the Family Savings Act of 2018, and H.R. 6760, the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act of 2018 - to make the new tax law’s temporary provisions for individuals permanent. Provisions for businesses organized as pass-throughs, which pay taxes through the individual system, would also be made permanent. Other provisions include making permanent the doubled estate tax exemption to $22 million per couple, the $10,000 cap on the deduction for state and local taxes (SALT), the cap on mortgage interest deduction, and the limits on the casualty loss deduction. The Tax Policy Center estimate that these bills will add over $3 trillion to the debt in its first ten years of implementation. 
This is another handout to the wealthiest Americans while leaving the middle class to pick up the tab. Already, the first Tax Scam has failed to deliver on the promise of higher wages. In fact, while corporations and shareholders are getting richer, only 4.4% of Fortune 500 workers have seen a raise or bonus. This Tax Scam 2.0 will build on that failed record by giving the top 0.1% of Americans with average incomes over $4 million per year an average tax cut of $105,000 in its first year alone.  That $105,000 tax cut exclusively for the 120,000 wealthiest Americans would be larger than the entire annual income for more than 120 million individual American households – before taxes – in that same year. And in order to pay for this, Republicans want to slash vital programs like Medicare and Social Security. I will fight to make sure working families don’t have to pay for the rich to get richer. 
Sincerely, 
￼

Subject: October News from Congresswoman Susan Davis
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
About Susan  |   Contact  |   Services  |   News  |   Legislation  |   Issues  |   Resources 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
Dear Friend,

It's time for another update from Congress!  Last month saw a final push in Washington to fund to the federal government and pass legislation.  And this month, I had the opportunity to hold events in the San Diego area and meet with constituents around the 53rd District.  Please see below to read my E-newsletter.

Warm regards,

￼

￼

Congress Avoids Government Shutdown

Congress passed a number of spending bills to fund the federal government and avoid another shutdown.  The president signed the $854 billion spending package just before the September 30 deadline, despite earlier threats to veto any bill that did not include funding for his border wall.  I was glad to see members of Congress put aside differences to work on this issue together and pass a spending bill in time for the new fiscal year, which began on October 1. 

House Passes FAA Reauthorization Bill

The House of Representatives passed a reauthorization bill that would fund the Federal Aviation Administration for five years in a bipartisan vote of 398-23.  The bill includes a provision to allow regulators to set minimum standards for leg room and seat size on airplanes due to safety concerns.  

The 2,000-page funding bill also requires a government study on whether shrinking or reducing bathrooms in favor of more seats on board airplanes creates problems for passengers accessing the restrooms.  I joined the majority of my colleagues in voting yes on the bill. 

Working to Create Opportunities for Students
￼
Discussing the importance of bipartisanship in Congress.

I joined the Bipartisan Policy Center in Washington, DC to discuss the importance of working across the aisle on behalf of our students. As a senior member of the Committee on Education and the Workforce, I spoke about my efforts to promote college affordability, equity in education, and quality apprenticeships.  Recently, I introduced the bipartisan APPRENTICE Act, a bill that would promote the expansion of apprenticeships across the country. 
 
Perfect Score for Supporting Equality

Human Rights Campaign released its legislative scorecard measuring support for equality in the 115th Congress.  I was honored to receive a perfect score of 100 for supporting several bills in Congress that promote equality.  Whether it's leading the fight to end Don't Ask Don't Tell or joining to secure marriage equality or working to overturn Trump's discriminatory transgender ban in the military, I remain dedicated to being on the frontlines in the struggle for full equality.

Cosponsored Legislation

H.R. 1147, Fair and Equal Housing Act, which would provide consistent and explicit non-discrimination protections for LGBTQ people in housing by adding “sexual orientation” and “gender identity” as protected characteristics under the Fair Housing Act.

H.R. 6649, 3D Printed Gun Safety Act of 2018, which amends chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, to prohibit the publication of 3D printer plans for the printing of firearms.  3D-printed guns pose a significant public safety risk because they could be made undetectable and untraceable.

H.R. 6885, Conserving Ecosystems by Ceasing the Importation of Large Animal Trophies (CECIL) Act, a bill that would prohibit import and export of any species listed or proposed to be listed as a threatened species or endangered species. 


￼

Global Speaker Series: Understanding US–China Relations
￼
Making opening remarks during the U.S.-China panel discussion.

I hosted another successful panel discussion as part of my ongoing Global Policy Speaker Series. Partnering with experts from the 21st Century China Center at UCSD, the event focused on U.S.-China relations.  The expert panel discussed topics ranging from economics and trade to military and security issues between the U.S. and China.  Click here to watch.

Service Academy Information Night
￼
Speaking to students and parents about our nation's service academies.  

I held a Service Academy Information Night for students interested in serving our country and attending our nation's prestigious military academies.  Each year, I bring together academic advisers from each of the academies, along with advisers from local ROTC programs, to answer questions and provide resources for high school students and their families.  It is a great privilege to be able to nominate worthy candidates to attend our nation's service academies.
 
Protecting Mail Delivery
￼
Meeting with local letter carriers in North Park.

I joined local letter carriers in denouncing Trump's plan to privatize the United States Postal Service. I am opposed to this proposal because if mail gets privatized, private companies may drive up prices on businesses and consumers and that would be bad news. Employees and customers would get the short end while the president's rich friends on Wall Street would reap the rewards.  Click here to read my statement.

Visiting Our Local Schools
￼
Speaking to a class of 12th grade students at Eastlake High School.

I had thoughtful discussions with two bright classes at Eastlake High School and the San Diego School of the Creative and Performing Arts. These visits always inspire me to ensure we are doing all we can to provide our children with a world class education.

National Commission on Service Roundtable
￼
Discussing the importance of service with members of the commission.

I participated in a roundtable with the National Commission on Military, National, and Public Service.  The commission was created by Congress to consider methods to increase participation in military, national, and public service and to review the military selective service process.

This event was a part of a series of public events the commission is hosting across the nation throughout 2018 and 2019.  During the roundtable, I spoke to the commissioners about ways that we can increase participation in national service programs.
