Subject: Medicare for All is a threat to your health care
Message:
￼ 
  

Medicare for All is a threat to your health care

Dear Lindsey,
Throughout my time in Congress, I have had a strong focus on protecting and improving a patient-centric health care system for Minnesotans and Americans across the country.
Unfortunately, some of my colleagues in Congress have thwarted reform efforts and have instead doubled down on a single-payer system-- the socialist Medicare for All plan.
Despite misleading promotions of Medicare for All, this plan threatens the quality and effectiveness of health care. According to the Council of Economic Advisors (CEA), "evidence on the effectiveness of single-payer systems suggests that a ‘Medicare for All’ plan would reduce the longevity and health of Americans, despite greater insurance coverage.”
Medicare for All would cripple the American health care market, markedly cutting payments to providers by more than 40 percent—diminishing quality and availability of care.
The CEA states, with a fiscal note of $32.6 trillion, “the high taxes needed to fund Medicare for All would lead to a decline in household incomes of $17,000 annually after taxes and health care expenditures—a 19% decline.” This would devastate the budgets of hard-working individuals and families across the country, with no way out.
Under a single-payer system, individual choice to purchase insurance plans would be completely stripped. All employer-offered and private health insurance benefits, as well as competition from the private sector would be illegal. Medicare for All would call for government-distributed health care “for free”, with no consumer input and all consumer payback responsibility.
A single-payer system would threaten the well-being of Minnesotans and Americans across the country. You and your neighbors deserve to have health care coverage that works for them and their unique needs, which is why we must focus on a doctor and patient-centric system and not move toward a government-centric Medicare for All system.
I will continue to work for the individual health care needs of members of the Second District. As I work on this and other issues, I always like to hear directly from you.  Please share any thoughts you may have through my website, and sign up for my e-mail newsletter for the latest updates from Washington, D.C. and around the district. You can also stay on top of my work by following my Facebook and Twitter pages. Please feel free to call my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2271 or my local Burnsville office at 651-846-2120 with any comments or for assistance with a federal agency.

Sincerely, 
￼
Jason Lewis
Member of Congress

Subject: Boozman Bulletin: New Tool to Fund Water Infrastructure Projects
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

 
Boozman Bulletin: New Tool to Fund Water Infrastructure Projects  
Yesterday, President Donald Trump signed America’s Water Infrastructure Act into law. I was honored to attend the signing ceremony at the White House because there are historic reforms included in this bill that change how we fund water infrastructure projects.
I’m particularly pleased that it includes my innovative solution to updating our water and wastewater infrastructure. With this new tool in the toolbox, we will be able to help state and local governments overcome the barriers that have stalled water infrastructure improvements for far too long. Fixing our crumbling infrastructure is a national priority and this new policy initiative I authored creates another option for any community, including those in rural America, to address overdue water infrastructure upgrades, 
The new program will combine the best aspects of two existing funding programs to make the process easier and more affordable for states to meet their underserved or unmet water infrastructure needs. It will increase access to previously unavailable funding sources for small and medium-size communities, while removing high application fees which often prevent rural communities from applying for funding.
￼ 
The signing ceremony for America's Water Infrastructure Act. (Official White House photo by Shealah Craighead)
This policy change is the result of months-long negotiations. It blends the best ideas available to ensure this common sense, bipartisan approach will work effectively and efficiently while providing millions, and potentially billions, in project dollars to communities that have traditionally not had access to these types of funds.
Making this change will allow a multitude of vetted water and wastewater projects to receive funding without the Environmental Protection Agency having to process thousands of additional applications. 
With support from a diverse group of senators, this new initiative to address overdue water infrastructure upgrades has the opportunity to yield dividends across the country. The fact that this new policy has support from lawmakers with vastly different political ideologies, underscores an important point.
Infrastructure investment is not a rural issue, or a big city issue. It is not a red state problem or a blue state problem. This is a national emergency, and we must put partisanship aside and work together to provide safe and reliable drinking and wastewater services to every part of our country.
This message is echoed by the diverse voices in the industry and advocacy community, on both a national and state level, who advocated for this idea.  
Dennis Sternberg, Executive Director of Arkansas Rural Water Association, applauded the policy update to extend these authorities to states. “We are very pleased a version of Senator Boozman’s bill was included in the package. Small and rural communities have more difficulty affording public wastewater service due to lack of population density and lack of economies of scale. Rural America is very appreciative for the help.”   
 

Quick Takes: 
	•	Improving Services for Air Travelers: Earlier this month President Trump signed into law the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018. I supported this five-year reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration because it provides protections for air travelers from being bumped after boarding and from shrinking seat sizes as well as modernizes airport infrastructure and enhances transportation safety and security.  
	•	Celebrating Arkansas Black Hall of Fame Inductees: Six individuals with Arkansas roots will be inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame on Saturday. I recognized the accomplishments and achievements of this distinguished group of men and women on the Senate floor. Watch the speech here. 
	•	Recognizing Arkansas Veterans: The ‘Salute to Veterans’ series honors the service and sacrifice of Arkansas veterans who served our nation in uniform. In the latest edition, I recognized Vietnam veteran Lt Col (retired) James Hudson. Hear his memories about his military service and his work to advance our air superiority. His entire interview is preserved in the Library of Congress Veterans History Project.   
	•	Removing Unnecessary Prescription Drugs: Research has found that the majority of opioid abusers get their drugs from friends and family, often lifting pills from a familiar medicine cabinet. Removing them from homes helps reduce experimentation and overdoses. Saturday is Arkansas Drug Take Back Day. Get rid of old and unused prescription drugs at a nearby drop-off site.  
	•	Connect on Social Media: Stay up to date with what I’m doing for Arkansans via social media. You can find me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

Subject: SPECIAL UPDATE: Barletta Bill to Combat Opioid Crisis Signed Into Law
Message:
Open in its own browser window   Open a plain text version
News from Representative Lou Barletta 
￼
 


 
 October 24, 2018  
Fighting to End the Opioid Epidemic in Pennsylvania 
￼
Nearly 10,000 Pennsylvanians have died due to drug
overdoses in the last two years alone. 
Since 2000, more than 300,000 Americans have died from overdoses involving opioids, and according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, nearly two million Americans will suffer from opioid addiction just this year.  That’s not to mention the 130,000 children over the last decade who were born having already been exposed to opioids and suffering from withdrawal by no fault of their own.
And while every community across the country has been impacted by the opioid crisis, it has disproportionally devastated the Appalachian Region, which includes more than 50 counties in Pennsylvania.  Just last year, over 5,000 Pennsylvanians died from drug-related overdoses – a 15 percent increase from 2016.  Many of those individuals were 25 to 44 years old and in their prime working years, creating a significant challenge to economic growth in communities hit hardest by this epidemic.  From employers who can’t find skilled workers to fill their jobs, to those suffering from addition that prevents them from receiving a steady paycheck, the total economic burden of prescription opioid misuse in the U.S. is estimated to be $78.5 billion a year.  We must address the issues that are creating these economic hardships. 
￼
To raise awareness about the opioid crisis, I told the story of
Brayden Schlier of Lehighton, who was accidentally suffocated by
his mother at just six weeks old when she fell asleep on top of him
after getting high on opioids. 
That’s why I wrote H.R. 5294, the Treating Barriers to Prosperity Act of 2018, which President Donald J. Trump signed into law today as part of H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act.  My bill addresses the negative impacts of opioid addiction on labor force participation and economic development by allowing Pennsylvania communities to use Appalachian Regional Commission (ARC) funding to fight this crisis.  Specifically, ARC funding can be used for everything from attracting doctors to putting in broadband for telemedicine, spurring economic growth and helping those struggling with addiction by breaking down barriers to employment.
With Pennsylvania being one of the states hardest hit by this epidemic, finding solutions to the opioid crisis has been one of my top priorities in Congress, and the Treating Barriers to Prosperity Act is just one example of the bipartisan, real-world solutions I have brought to our state.  I applaud President Trump for signing this important legislation into law and giving communities across Pennsylvania the tools they need to combat the opioid crisis.





How You Can Help Combat the Opioid Crisis 
 
As part of my ongoing effort to combat the opioid crisis in Pennsylvania, I wanted to make sure you are aware of an opportunity to help by participating in National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day.  Every year, the Drug Enforcement Administration holds Prescription Drug Take-Back Days to provide citizens with the opportunity to safely get rid of excess drugs, helping prevent the possibility of any accidental overdoses by children or abuse by others.  This Saturday, October 27, you can drop off your old medication in a way that is safe, convenient, and responsible from 10 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. 
￼
National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day provides all of us with an opportunity to raise awareness about the opioid crisis, while also preventing excess drugs from falling into the wrong hands.  To find the collection site closest to you this Saturday, please visit https://takebackday.dea.gov/.   
Together, we can take another step toward defeating the opioid epidemic. 
 


 

How I Can Help You 



 
 
• Federal agencies 
• Federal grants 
• Military and veterans issues

• Service academy nominations 
• Tours and tickets in Washington, D.C.
• Internships
 


 

How You Can Help Me 




I remain convinced that some of the best solutions to America’s problems come from outside of Washington, D.C. I encourage you to voice any questions, concerns, or suggestions you may have by contacting one of my offices.

Subject: Working for You
Message:
October 24, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
I wanted to let you know about an important bill I sponsored to help reduce opioid addiction. The measure was signed today by President Trump.

In fact, it is my 16th legislative proposal to be signed into law since coming to Congress. Six of those measures were signed by former President Obama, six by Trump and four by George W Bush. 

My latest proposal creates a national database to give patients information about managing pain without using addictive opioids.

The list of 16 accomplishments cover issues important to our district, such as protecting Medicare and Social Security, helping veterans, fighting red tide, improving foster care for children and banning the slaughter of American horses.

Some of those proposals originated from the people I represent in Manatee, Sarasota and Hillsborough counties. And virtually all were achieved by working with colleagues from both parties on a bipartisan basis.

Nothing is impossible if we work together. If we had more civility and less partisanship in Washington, we would get more done for the people.

My work in Congress has earned high marks from independent groups that track effectiveness and bipartisanship. The Center for Effective Lawmaking, a respected non-partisan research group run by the University of Virginia, ranked me one of the most effective members of Congress from either party. (click here). 

Another study by the non-partisan Lugar Center and Georgetown University’s McCourt School of Public Policy called me one of the most bipartisan members of Congress. (click here). 

As the co-chair of Florida’s bipartisan 29-member congressional delegation, I have always believed that no single party has the market cornered on good ideas.

The new law signed today will help address the growing drug epidemic in Florida and across the country. 

Drug addiction is destroying too many families and claiming far too many lives. I hope my legislation gives doctors and patients the information they need to seek out safer alternatives to managing pain.

Please let me know if you need any more information on this bill or any of the others I mentioned. And keep your tremendous ideas and input coming. I work for YOU!

Vern

Subject: Keeping Wisconsin Strong
Message:

￼ 
Home 
About Ron 
Issues 
Wisconsin's 3rd District 
Constituent Services 
Newsroom 
Contact 
October 24, 2018 
Dear friend, 
I wanted to keep you updated on the work I'm doing on behalf of Wisconsinites:
Fighting for Wisconsin Communities  Last week, I toured through areas impacted by last month's flooding, including Wonewoc, Elroy, and Ontario.
As I’ve visted with communities and families across the state, I have seen our spirit of strength and resiliency in times of adversity. The President’s disaster declaration will be a welcome relief for many that have been flooded out of their homes and businesses. I look forward to continuing to work with FEMA to ensure the additional federal resources are well-utilized
My office has, and will continue to, work side-by-side with Wisconsinites and local officials that are rebuilding their homes and businesses. Anyone with questions regarding recovery efforts or services should call my office toll-free at 1-888-442-8040, or visit my website: kind.house.gov.
Wisconsin residents can apply for disaster assistance online at DisasterAssistance.gov or by calling 1-800-621-3362.
Don't Forget: Medicare Open Enrollment is here! From October 15 to December 7 of this year, all Wisconsinites with Medicare have the opportunity to enroll in a new plan, or make changes to their existing plans. You can also adjust your prescription drug coverage to better meet your needs.
The Medicare Open Enrollment period is the best time to get the health coverage you need. Be sure to keep an eye on your mail, where you may receive notices from your current plan, but be smart about sharing your identity and personal information. Plan providers aren’t allowed to call you or visit your home without an invitation from you first.
If you have questions about signing up or want to talk through your options with a trained professional, call 1-800-MEDICARE or visit Medicare.gov. 
Here to Help My office is available to help you work through issues with government agencies and departments. This includes getting copies of service records, receiving benefits, and cutting through government red tape. You can reach the office by calling 1-888-442-8040 or visiting kind.house.gov.
Sincerely,
￼

Subject: Best-Ever Job Market, Wages Rising, Yoder Highlights Type 1 Diabetes Awareness
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
ABOUT  |  CONTACT  |  SERVICES  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATION  |  RESOURCES
￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
October 24, 2018
Last Week in Congress
U.S. Regains Place as World's Most Competitive Economy
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from the Wall Street Journal
We came into the 115th Congress with a fully Republican government for the first time in over a decade. The centerpiece of our agenda was to grow the economy at a rate that the American people haven’t seen since the Great Recession. And that’s exactly what we’ve done. The U.S. has recently regained its status as the world’s most competitive economy for the first time since 2008 thanks to strong economic growth. The report on global competitiveness specifically cited America's "vibrant entrepreneurial culture," "competitive labor market," and "nimble financial system" as reasons for regaining the top spot in the world.
Today, unemployment lines across the U.S. are the shortest since 1969 – nearly 50 years ago. For the first time since 2000 there are more jobs available than there are unemployed Americans, and all indications point to sustained, long-term growth in the economy. The economic surge we’re seeing is a direct result of the pro-growth policies like reforming our 30 year-old, broken tax code. This is the Great American Comeback.
￼
U.S. Job Openings Hit Record Level
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from CNBC
Job openings in our country have passed 7 million for the first time, showing that the job market is stronger than ever. This number is far more than the number of unemployed workers in the country, which is currently around 6.2 million. Plus, in a sign of high confidence in the economy, the number of workers who quit their jobs in order to find better jobs is 12.7 percent higher than it was a year ago.
In addition to job availability, workers are also seeing their wages rise. According to the Wall Street Journal, blue collar wages are actually rising even faster than white-collar pay. In fact, wages for the bottom tenth of income earners rose faster than other income brackets, and high-profile companies like Amazon are announcing major pay increases. These number confirm that our economy is booming, and that this boom is providing new opportunities for all Americans. 
￼
Around the District
Yoder Highlights Work to Combat Type 1 Diabetes
￼ Kevin with Kerri Lindsay and her two sons, Melissa Cooper, Garrett Brown, and Jessica Brown
Families representing the JDRF Kansas City Chapter have been visiting with me for several years now, and it is so exciting to see these kids again to learn about the tremendous strides being made in the research and development of treatments and ultimately a cure for Type 1 Diabetes. During this visit, Garrett took the time to show me how his Artificial Pancreas works to monitor his blood sugar and adjust insulin doses as needed. This device was just a dream a few short years ago when we first met. As a leader in Congress on efforts to increase federal investment in medical research, I am again inspired by this group and their advocacy for the critical research necessary to beat this disease that affects over 30.3 million adults and children in the U.S. I recently supported legislation in Congress to renew the Special Diabetes Program, which has provided over $3 million to The University of Kansas Medical Center to support their efforts to advance therapies to cure, prevent, and treat Type 1 Diabetes.
￼
Friends In Service of Heroes
￼ Kevin with Jerry Ingram, Max Deweese, and Paul Chapa
It was wonderful visiting with some great Americans, including WWII veterans Jerry and Max, at FISH - Friends In Service of Heroes in Overland Park last week. Thank you to Paul Chapa for your leadership and commitment to our vets through this program. I was proud to report that we’re spending more on our vets than any time in history, improving the quality of service at the VA, and fulfilling our promises to those who serve our country.
￼
Step Up for Down Syndrome Walk
￼ Kevin with Sara from the NDSS and Step Up Walk participants
I was proud to join the Step Up for Down Syndrome Walk on Saturday, benefitting the Down Syndrome Guild of Greater Kansas City. Together, we have gotten the ABLE Act signed into law, increased opportunities for individuals with Down Syndrome to find good jobs, and improved methods for people with disabilities to save up for financial independence. I am excited to continue our partnership for all kids to fulfill their dreams!
￼
KCK Congressional Forum Celebrates 50 Years
￼ Kevin with Edwardsville Mayor "Tiny" McTaggart, Congressional Forum President Bill Epperheimer, and Loretta Colombel
I am glad to be a part of the 50-year tradition of the KCK Chamber of Commerce's Congressional Forum, which we celebrated on Friday at Sporting KC's Children's Mercy Park. The Congressional Forum has been here through decades of challenges and successes in both our community and our country, and I am proud to be part of a line of Representatives who have joined this group to discuss the issues of the day. Thanks to the members young and old for keeping the tradition going.
￼
Yoder Hosts Medicare Enrollment Assistance Event
￼ Kevin at last week's Medicare enrollment event
I was proud to be able to sponsor a Medicare Open Enrollment event in Johnson County last week, providing seniors the opportunity to meet with a Medicare counselor and talk about new options for coverage. Thank you to the local, state and federal counselors who took the time to meet with seniors, saving some Medicare enrollees well over $1,000.
￼
National Manufacturing Month at Hipower Systems
￼ Kevin speaking at the Hipower Systems ribbon cutting
October is National Manufacturing Month - the perfect time to visit Hipower Systems and celebrate with a ribbon cutting ceremony at their new headquarters in Olathe. Hipower Systems is a home grown manufacturer of power generation and power distribution equipment, with corporate partners around the globe. I was honored to visit Hipower Systems and learn about their operations, from design, engineering and manufacturing to sales and support here in the Third District. Hipower Systems has invested more than $40 million in the new plant, which will produce a new line of portable generators, creating new jobs and opportunities in Olathe. Special thanks to Samuel Silva for the invitation. The National Association of Manufacturers reports that optimism among manufacturing is at an all-time high right now, and this will mean expanding operations and more high-quality manufacturing jobs for American workers going forward.
￼
Kansas Hospital Association
￼ Kevin with representatives from Shawnee Mission Health, the University of Kansas Health System, and Children's Mercy 
We are fortunate to have access to some of the best hospitals in the country right here in the Third District. It was good to catch up with leaders at Shawnee Mission Health, the University of Kansas Health System, and Children's Mercy to talk about important policy issues facing hospitals today. It is clear that Congress must provide stable payment policies, continue to work to increase transparency and lower prices on prescription drugs, and provide tools to combat the opioid crisis as drug overdoses are now the leading cause of death for people under the age of 50. I also toured the Emergency Room at Shawnee Mission Health and heard from health care providers dealing with the opioid crisis here in Kansas City and how they are working to combat this epidemic.
I will work and continue to lead efforts in Congress to increase federal investment in medical research funding, which has huge impacts on the daily work done at these hospitals. Thank you to hospital leadership and staff who took the time to meet with me and who serve the patients and families in the Third District of Kansas every day.
￼
Giving the Basics
￼ Kevin helping pack boxes of supplies at Giving the Basics
Giving the Basics is a true Hygiene Hub in our community, providing personal care products to schools, police departments, shelters and pantries across the metro area. I enjoyed a tour of the warehouses, both old and new, and even got to pack boxes of items that will be distributed to one of many shelters that partner with the organization. It’s such an inspiration to see the commitment and dedication of the staff and volunteers who are working to ensure everyone, from students to seniors, has the basic needs that so many of us take for granted. Thank you to Teresa and Kelley for all you do.
￼
Cub Scout Pack #3395
￼ Kevin with Cub Scout Pack #3395
It was a treat to visit with Tiger and Cub Scouts from Pack #3395 last Monday in Leawood. We read parts of the U.S. Constitution, discussed the three branches of government, and I enjoyed taking their creative questions. It was an honor to be able to pass out pocket Constitutions to the scouts, so that they continue their growth in service and civic duty with our nation's founding documents in hand.
￼
Tallgrass Creek Retirement Community
￼ Kevin speaking to residents at Tallgrass Creek
I enjoyed visiting Tallgrass Creek Retirement Community in Overland Park, to talk with seniors about important issues facing our nation like the economy, prescription drug prices, and my work to preserve and protect Medicare and Social Security for this generation and the next. In the House, I have supported efforts to close the Medicare Part D Donut Hole, help make drug prices more transparent, and replace the old Medicare cards with new, safer cards that do not show Social Security numbers. 
￼
Yoder Receives Defender of Housing Award
￼ Kevin with the Defender of Housing award
I was honored to receive the Defender of Housing award from the Home Builders Association of Greater Kansas City last week. The award is given to members of Congress who support policies that help make the American dream of homeownership possible for more people. I also toured a new home building site in the area to see firsthand the impact that a strong housing market is having on our district.
￼

Fact of the Week
According to the National Association of Manufacturers, for every $1.00 spent in manufacturing, another $1.89 is added to the economy. This is the highest multiplier effect of any economic sector.
In addition, for every one worker in manufacturing, there are another four employees hired elsewhere.
Third District Trivia 
The national unemployment rate is currently 3.7%. How low is the unemployment rate in Kansas right now?
Send your answers to haley.brady@mail.house.gov and the first correct response will receive a shout out in next week's newsletter.
Congratulations to last week's winner David Viebrock!
Last week's answer:  According to the Farm Bureau, the average U.S. farm feeds 165 people each year.
National Prescription Drug Take Back Day
￼
Drug overdose is the leading cause of death for Americans under the age of 50. One way we can help slow this crisis is by turning in unused prescriptions. Click here to find a collection site near you.
Lenexa Chili Challenge
￼
The Lenexa Chili Challenge was a huge success on Friday, with so much good chili and so many great people!
NASCAR at the Kansas Speedway
￼
KCK was proud to welcome back the NASCAR Cup Series for the Hollywood Casino 400, and I was glad to be on hand for the opening ceremonies. 
Legislative Look Ahead
Members of the House of Representatives will work from their respective home districts this week.
Legislative Wrap Up
Members of the House of Representatives worked from their respective home districts last week.
￼
Agency Help
￼

Subject: Early voting, drug pricing, and district meetings
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Website | About Me | Constituent Services | News | Contact Me
Dear Lindsey,
            I hope you’re doing well! This October, I’ve spent a great deal of time meeting with constituents, visiting local organizations and businesses, and working with my staff to help 9th District residents with a wide range of issues. I wanted to share some of that with you and highlight the work that I’ve been doing on behalf of the 9th district recently.
            I also wanted to take this opportunity to remind you to vote! With so much going on in our country, make sure you don’t miss your chance to cast a ballot and make your voice heard. Early voting has already begun in Illinois. For more information on how and where to vote, visit the following website:
https://www.elections.il.gov/infoforvoters.aspx
Legislative Priorities
            One of my greatest priorities in Congress has always been to protect, strengthen, and expand earned benefits like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. Recently, Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell was on Bloomberg discussing his intentions to go after these treasured programs that Americans have earned by paying into them every single month. This has been the Republican plan all along. First they exploded the deficit with multi-trillion-dollar tax cuts for billionaires and wealthy corporations. Now, they’re using the deficit as an excuse to come after Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid to pay for it. These attacks are nothing new. Earlier this year, the Seniors Task Force, which I co-chair, released a report detailing the constant and never-ending Republican attacks. You can read it here.
            I won’t stop fighting for our earned benefits. I am a founding member of the Expand Social Security Caucus, which my colleagues and I recently launched. Watch the video below to learn more:
￼
            Another one of my priorities is to lower health care costs, especially the skyrocketing prices of prescription drugs. A life-saving drug is 100% ineffective when it is unaffordable. Drug companies are making record profits and receiving government benefits left and right while everyday Americans have to decide between paying rent and buying the medicines their family members need to survive. That’s why last week 15 of my colleagues and I sent letters to the CEOs of 5 pharmaceutical corporations that benefit from corporate tax breaks and publicly-funded research, demanding answers to the problem of soaring prescription drug prices. It is unconscionable that these corporations are using their multi-billion-dollar tax savings to benefit wealthy stockholders instead of to make their drugs affordable. We need answers about why the taxpayer dollars they receive don’t benefit taxpayers – and we need them now. This week, Americans for Tax Fairness announced that the total amount of stock buybacks authorized by corporations since the Republican tax bill passed in December 2017 now exceeds $750 billion.
            October is National Disability Employment Awareness Month and October 15th marked the end of Hispanic Heritage Month. Click the links in this sentence to read my statements on both of these important commemorations. You can read my statement on Hispanic Heritage Month en español here.
Recent District Meetings
￼ ￼
            Recently, I met with community leaders, faith leaders, hospital representatives, and immigration advocates to discuss the ravaging effects that President Trump’s proposed changes to the Public Charge rule could have on health care access for legal immigrants in our community. The President’s proposed rule is cruel and discriminatory. It will cause children to go hungry, women to lose health care, and families to lose housing. You can read more about the rule and let the Administration know what you think of it by following this link.
￼
            Earlier this month I stood with Senator Dick Durbin and my friends at the Syrian Community Network to protest President Trump's inhumane decision to close America's doors by reducing our refugee admissions level to a mere 30,000. I believe this number must be raised significantly – to at least 75,000 if not higher. As our community knows well, diversity is strength. The United States can and should be doing more to help the global refugee crisis. On a related note, I have been outspoken about the need to be compassionate and supportive of the caravan of refugees heading towards our country from Honduras.
￼   ￼
￼
            I love seeing my constituents at work. In early October, I had the privilege of touring two wonderful businesses on the same day. First, I toured the ThermalCare manufacturing plant, where more than 120 union strong workers are employed making industrial water cooling equipment. Next I visited the Evanston ReBuilding Warehouse, a non-profit that promotes the reduction of waste in landfills through sustainable building practices. They sell low-cost materials and use the proceeds for job-training & development. I also sat down with members of the West Ridge Chamber of Commerce, where I discussed taxes, health care, immigration and many more issues with local small business owners. What an honor to have these great places of work in my district!
Firefighter Assistance Grant
            All of us depend on firefighters and first responders for safety. That’s why I was so happy to see that a $1.4 million grant was recently awarded to 16 fire departments in the 9th and 10th Congressional Districts of Illinois. The grant will allow the fire departments to significantly upgrade their communications capacity, leading to more responsive and effective emergency services for thousands of people. Sen. Tammy Duckworth, Rep. Brad Schneider and I all sent letters of support for this grant. I am proud to have played a part in ensuring that federal dollars meaningfully benefit communities here in Illinois.
            I hope you have found this information helpful. If you have any further questions, please feel free to contact my office. As always, I welcome your input, comments and questions about policies, legislation and issues. Please call, write or email me to let me know your opinions and thoughts.
Sincerely, ￼ Congresswoman Jan Schakowsky Member of Congress  Share this on:  ￼  ￼

Subject: E-Newsletter: Women's Veteran's Event & Opportunity Zones
Message:
October 24, 2018
 
￼
  
￼

About Tim
Services
Media Center
Legislative Work
South Carolina
Resources



Dear fellow South Carolinians,  Thank you for subscribing to my weekly e-newsletter, and please remember to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.   Women Veteran’s Event With Veterans Day approaching, I hope you will join me on November 10th in Columbia for a special event honoring South Carolina’s women veterans. All South Carolinians, whether you are a veteran or just a proud American, are encouraged to RSVP and come!  In addition, I recently was happy to announce a special keynote speaker: my friend and colleague, Sen. Joni Ernst. As a combat veteran herself, I am so excited to welcome her back to the Palmetto State and look forward to having her join us at the event. I have no doubt that her passion, story, and mission will resonate with South Carolina’s 43,000 women veterans.  You can learn more about the event here, and RSVP at www. scott.senate.gov/veteransrsvp  ￼ 
Opportunity Zones Late last week, the Treasury Dept. released its first set of rules regarding the Opportunity Zones legislation. Opportunity Zones will not be another bureaucratic process burdened by red tape, but rather a streamlined, efficient process that allows for investments to truly help communities in need. America’s governors, mayors and other local leaders can begin to bring development, hope, and prosperity to some of the most challenged places in our country.  You can hear me talk about the new regulations here, and read my full statement here. 
 Sincerely, ￼  Tim

Subject: Restoring Clean Drinking Water for Our Children and Holding Polluters Accountable
Message:
￼
 
Restoring Clean Drinking Water 
for Our Children 
and Holding Polluters Accountable
￼

I was proud to stand hand-in-hand with local officials, the Sierra Club, Clean Water Action, and the League of Conservation Voters at the Well Field Superfund site in Fair Lawn to announce North Jersey’s clawing back of $19.5 million from polluting companies to expand and upgrade the Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) groundwater clean-up efforts at the site, a victory for clean drinking water for our children, our seniors, and our families.

Keeping North Jersey’s water and air free of pollution is a not a Democrat or Republican issue, it’s just good for New Jersey. This critical investment by the EPA in our community will hold polluters accountable for their damage to our neighborhoods and benefit all who call Fair Lawn home – in jobs created by the clean-up efforts, in improved property values surrounding the Well Field site, and in local families' access to clean water.

The full video of our event can be found HERE.


Breaking the Partisan Gridlock in Congress  for All Americans 

The Problem Solvers Caucus has had enough of the gridlock and we're prepared to buck the status quo and pass common sense legislation on everything from infrastructure to health care. As Co-Chair of the Caucus, I led nineteen Members in committing to only vote for a Speaker of the House who will support House Rules reforms to “Break the Gridlock.” In Washington, I'm proud of every Member standing for Break the Gridlock reforms so we can vote on bipartisan ideas for the good of the American people."

The full list of goals in the ‘Break the Gridlock’ proposal can be found HERE.


￼

Clawing Back Dollars to Keep Jersey Communities Safe on ‘Coffee with a Cop’ Day

In honor of national “Coffee with a Cop Day,” I visited the brave men and women of the Washington Township Police Department to tour the new equipment they have clawed back through federal excess equipment programs. Since last September, Washington Township's first responders have secured $110,000 worth of equipment, including a cargo trailer, forklift, and a utility truck for use in water rescue and flooding emergencies. 

This new equipment is another great example of North Jersey towns boosting the return on investment from our federal tax dollars through programs that protect our children, families, and seniors with the money we already send to Washington. This year, we announced that the Fifth District has clawed back $290 per household from Washington – 16% higher than in previous years – to support our local schools, boost storm preparedness and response, and fight crime and terror.

More information about federal grants available in your town can be found HERE.

￼

Thousands Secured for 
Sussex Social Security Recipient

In June of 2016, Corrie Besaw of Sussex got a notice from the Social Security Administration saying her disability insurance benefits had been terminated. Because she was still qualified to receive them under the Department of Disability Services’ guidelines, Corrie filed to have them reinstated and was approved. But after 11 months and multiple visits to the Social Security offices in Newton, the benefits never restarted because of a bureaucratic glitch.

Corrie contacted my office this summer, and we reached out to the Social Security Administration on her behalf. We got her benefits restarted, and she received $15,000 after not receiving a payment for nearly a year. One of my proudest roles as your representative is to be an advocate for you within the federal government – whether it’s assisting you with Social Security or Medicare benefits, navigating claims with the V.A., or with nominations to one of our military service academies.

If you are having trouble with a federal agency, contact my office HERE.

￼

‘Josh on the Job’ Helping Seniors with  Habitat for Humanity
￼

For decades, our seniors in North Jersey took care of us, and now it is our responsibility to take care of them. That’s why I was honored to join a crew of longtime volunteers with Habitat for Humanity of Bergen County – the self-styled “Greyheads” – to lend a hand assisting Irene Ade, a 90 year-old Washington Township senior, with keeping up her house and property.

Keeping North Jersey affordable for Irene and her fellow seniors is key to helping them save their hard-earned money and stay in New Jersey. That’s why I helped pass the HOME Act, bipartisan legislation that makes it more affordable for Habitat for Humanity to help seniors like Irene.

Last May, I also announced my Three-Part Senior Security Strategy to cut Social Security taxes on seniors, eliminate double taxation, stop the government from withholding seniors’ Social Security benefits if they are behind on debt payments, and to do all we can to combat the latest Medicare scams. 

More information about my Senior Security Strategy can be found HERE.


￼
Above: I visited with Irene in her Washington Township home after helping Habitat for Humanity with landscaping and exterior repairs at her house.

You can keep in touch with me and my office by ‘liking’ my Facebook page and following me on YouTube, Twitter, and Instagram.

Know someone else who should get these updates? Forward this email to them and encourage them to click HERE to sign up.

Got something on your mind? You can always send me an email HERE or request a meeting HERE.

Yours,

Josh

Subject: Through Tragedy Comes Change
Message:
News from Congressman Tom MacArthur

￼ 

Home
Contact
Services
Media


  
“Congressman MacArthur hasn't forgotten Parkland and it is refreshing to see a politician cut through the noise and focus on fixing what's broken." –Andrew Pollack 
  
Friend, 
I announced three bills I have been working on for months that will enhance our schools and community safety efforts. Following the horrific events in Parkland, I met with local advocates, law enforcement officials, and students to hear their concerns and ways they’d like the federal government to address safety improvements in schools. I’ve also been grateful to have the opportunity to work alongside Andrew Pollack, a school safety advocate who lost his daughter, Meadow, at Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland. Through Andrew’s leadership, he’s created a comprehensive and effective agenda to make schools safer and honor the life of his daughter. I am thankful for his partnership and his willingness to take this unfathomable pain and turn it into action to save others. 
I have not forgotten Parkland and we must continue to do all we can for kids, parents, and teachers. 
  
Fostering Relationships Between Law Enforcement and Mental Health Professionals 
I introduced the bipartisan Mental Health and Public Safety Partnership Act. In many towns across the country, there is a gap between mental health and law enforcement services that needs to be filled. Fostering relationships between law enforcement officials and social workers will better serve our communities and enhance safety throughout our communities. Ocean County has already taken steps to address this need. The On P.O.I.N.T. program, which creates a partnership between Ocean Mental Health Services and the Stafford Township Police Department, has been successful in connecting local law enforcement officials with mental health professionals. 
  
Establishing Innovative Tools to Report Threats at Schools and in the Community 
The Modern School Threat Reporting Act is a new and modern approach to make schools safer. My bill creates federal grants that will be available to states to create mobile applications (apps) that alert law enforcement officials if students, teachers, or parents believe there is a threat to the community. Andrew Pollack, a school safety advocate who lost his daughter, Meadow, on that tragic day in Parkland, championed the similar Florida state law. Andrew has turned unimaginable tragedy into a desire to effectuate change and I am grateful for his support and work on the issue. 
  
Raising Awareness of Criminal Activities in Communities 
Another bill I am working on with Andrew will expand the Clery Act to high schools receiving federal funds. Under current law, colleges and universities are required to maintain records of criminal activity on and around campuses and make that information available to the community. This is an additional way to keep the community informed, instill accountability, and protect our kids. 
  
I won’t ever be blinded by partisanship and I refuse to take part in the partisan dysfunction that prevents progress. The nonpartisan Lugar Center at Georgetown University recently named me again among the most bipartisan members of Congress, because I work against Washington dysfunction and stand up for Burlington and Ocean Counties. If I can ever be of any assistance, please visit my website or contact my office: http://macarthur.house.gov. 
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Tom MacArthur

506 Cannon House Office Building
Washington, DC 20515
Ocean County Office
Township of Toms River Hall
33 Washington St
Toms River, NJ 08753
Burlington County Office
535 East Main Street
Marlton, NJ 08053

Subject: A Letter from Congressman Bill Pascrell, Jr.
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A Message From Rep. Pascrell
Subscribe 
￼
About Bill
Media Center
Bill's Views
Services
Student Center
October 24, 2018
Dear Friend, 
As your Representative in Congress for New Jersey’s Ninth Congressional District, I always want to keep you informed about my work in Washington and in New Jersey. 
Ribbon Cutting at Overlook Park in the Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park 
Work has continued to progress at the Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park. The completed work at Overlook Park marks another milestone in the continued success to implement our vision for this landmark. This $3.2 million improvement project was made possible by both corporate contributions and funding from federal, state, county and local officials. 
The improvements at the Great Falls included landscape redesign, which now offers visitors the opportunity to view the Great Falls from an amphitheater at the most picturesque vantage points. This view is reminiscent of the one Alexander Hamilton had when he conceived and implemented his plan to harness the force of water at the Great Falls to power new industries to secure our economic independence. 
 ￼
 Representative Bill Pascrell Jr. speaking about the newly renovated Overlook Park
 
This critical moment in our nation’s historic quest for freedom and prosperity is foundational to American industry and the story of our State. It is why I sought to preserve and protect the Great Falls by bringing it into the National Park system. I hope you will take time to visit and enjoy the newly renovated space at Overlook Park.
You can read more about the new renovations at Overlook Park here. 
Cleanup in the Hackensack River and Berry’s Creek
After several decades of study, work will finally begin on a $332 million plan to clean-up Berry’s Creek in the Hackensack River. Earlier this month, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) selected a path forward to address the highest levels of mercury ever recorded in a freshwater ecosystem in the United States. We have known for years about this issue and I have urged EPA to act on the elevated pollution levels in the Hackensack River. 
 ￼
From left, Representative Bill Pascrell, Jr., EPA Region 2 Administrator Peter Lopez, NJDEP Acting Associate Commissioner for Policy Katrina Angarone, Captain Bill Sheehan announce support for EPAs cleanup efforts at Berry’s Creek
Thankfully, the EPA heard my call and added Berry’s Creek Study Area to their Emphasis List of Superfund sites. EPA published the interim plan to address the contamination after an in-depth investigation of the extent of the contamination which took water and fish sampling data and assessed how the tidal action in the creek moves sediment through the watershed. This would not have been possible without support and extensive input from the public, all levels of government, and more than 100 potentially responsible parties. 
Making progress at the heavily-contaminated Berry’s Creek Study Area can allow us to start addressing the broader problems throughout the Meadowlands and Hackensack River. Cleaning up Superfund sites to protect natural resources and public health must be a top priority. And we know that it is only right polluters, not the taxpayers, should be expected to bear the financial responsibility for cleaning up the mess they created. Thankfully, the responsible parties in this case look to be cooperating with EPA. But that is not always the case. That is why I have long supported legislation, like the Superfund Polluter Pays Act, to reinstate the excise tax on polluting industries to pay for the cleanup of Superfund sites to relieve taxpayers of the expense. We can and must act on this to ensure taxpayers should not get stuck with the tab for reckless corporate polluters. 
You can learn more about the cleanup efforts at Berry’s Creek here. 
House Republican Tax Scam 2.0 
As New Jersey’s only member on the House Ways and Means Committee, I strongly opposed the Republican’s latest tax scam that will pummel New Jerseyans and millions of other middle-class Americans to give more money to millionaires and big corporations. 
Among the most egregious offenses, this new bill would make permanent the harmful caps on the federal State and Local Tax (SALT) deduction. According to 2016 Internal Revenue Service data, middle-class New Jerseyans enjoyed SALT deductions on average of at least $10,000 in 20 of 21 counties in our state. In our region, the average SALT deduction in Hudson County was $14,491, $14,714 in Passaic County, and $24,783 in Bergen County. For decades, our neighbors have used this deduction for medical bills, school tuition, home repairs, and other life necessities. This misguided cap may lead to communities cutting local funds for schools, roads and public safety. In their tax scam, Republicans voted to steal it and then convert it into tax cuts for corporations.
I have offered amendments to restore the full SALT deduction to give relief to taxpayers in my district. Republicans voted these amendments down on strictly party lines. 
Despite the overwhelming unpopularity of the Republican’s first tax scam, they are ‘full steam ahead’ to another tax bill that would further hurt New Jersey. I will continue to oppose Republican’s shortsighted effort to raise taxes on New Jersey families. 
You can read more about my efforts to oppose the latest Republican tax scam here. 
Be assured that I will continue working to assist you with any federal issues. My first priority in Congress is representing the people of Northern New Jersey, so please continue to contact me to express your views and ideas. I encourage you to stay updated on my work in Congress by visiting my website, and Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, and Instagram pages.
Sincerely, ￼  Bill Pascrell Jr. Member of Congress

Subject: Poll: Saudi Arabia
Message:
￼ 

Poll: Saudi Arabia
Hoosiers,

On Tuesday, October 2nd, Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist for the Washington Post, disappeared after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul. During the subsequent investigation, lawmakers across the world called for answers and action over his disappearance, including President Trump, who sent Secretary of State Pompeo to Saudi Arabia to further understand their role in these events. 

On October 22, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister called the death of Jamal Khashoggi "a tremendous mistake" while Turkey described the killing as a "violently planned, very complicated murder, which was being covered up."

President Trump called for "severe punishment" if, after investigation, it is confirmed that Saudi Arabia extrajudicially and maliciously assassinated a journalist. Yesterday, the president called it the "worst cover-up ever."

Question of the Week: Do you support enforcing sanctions against Saudi Arabia after a full investigation into the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi?

[_] Yes.

Subject: Loudoun County Library Joins GPO Program That Keeps America Informed On The Federal Government
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
The Comstock Connection
News From The Office Of Congresswoman Barbara Comstock
￼ 
Our District
Biography
Media Center
Services
Contact Me

Loudoun County Library Joins GPO Program That Keeps America Informed On The Federal Government 
Washington, D.C. - The U.S. Government Publishing Office (GPO) welcomes Loudoun County Public Library (LCPL) in Northern Virginia to the Federal Depository Library Program (FDLP). Congresswoman Barbara Comstock designated the library as a Federal depository. As a member of the FDLP, LCPL will provide its customers with free digital access to Federal Government information. LCPL has been named one of America’s best public libraries by Library Journal two years in a row. It is made up of nine branches and is the only library in Virginia’s 10th Congressional district to have joined the FDLP. 
“I was honored to designate Loudoun County Library as a Federal Depository Library,” said Congresswoman Barbara Comstock (R-VA). “Through this designation, the Loudoun County Library will now be able to distribute materials from the federal government, the largest publisher in the world. As a part of this program, Loudoun County Library will better serve the Northern Virginia community, and it will be a tremendous asset to researchers in the region.”
You may read the Government Publishing Office’s full press release here.

Subject: Hurricane Michael Recovery Continues
Message:
News from Martha Roby
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
Friends, 
As Hurricane Michael recovery efforts continue, we are gradually learning the full scale of damages portions of our district are facing. The setback for the agriculture industry is severe, to say the least. In the immediate aftermath of the storm, I traveled to the Wiregrass to see firsthand what some of our farmers are experiencing. The devastation is heartbreaking.
Agricultural damage from Hurricane Michael across Alabama, Florida, and Georgia is projected to top $1.3 billion in total losses, with cotton, pecans, and poultry commodities hit the hardest. An expert with the Alabama Cooperative Extension System estimates the loss to our state’s cotton crop alone could eclipse $100 million. That sum does not include the impact the storm had on livestock, peanuts, and timber. When I was on the ground in the Wiregrass, I even saw 1,500 acres of cucumbers that might not make it to harvest. Our farmers are in the midst of a very real crisis.
In the wake of this disaster, Governor Kay Ivey requested that Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue declare our hurricane-damaged counties in Alabama as agriculture disaster areas. She also requested the maximum assistance be made available to our state through existing Department of Agriculture (USDA) and Farm Service Agency (FSA) programs.
￼
I, too, have been actively engaged with Secretary Perdue, and recently penned a letter to him voicing my support for the Governor’s request. It is imperative that our farmers receive the most fitting and best available assistance from USDA during this time, and I am confident Secretary Perdue understands the severity of the devastation that occurred to agriculture in our state. I will remain in close contact with USDA to address any further needs the Department may require in getting our farmers the help they need in the weeks and months to come.
Read more about our Hurricane Michael recovery efforts in my weekly column here. 
FEMA DAMAGE ASSESSMENTS BEGIN IN THE WIREGRASS 
FEMA teams have begun damage assessment to determine whether the Wiregrass will qualify for a major disaster declaration. Local officials have urged homeowners to document damage with photographs and email the information to ema@houstoncounty.org as soon as possible. You can read more about the process through the Dothan Eagle here.  
COFFEE COUNTY RANKED A PAYCHECK FRIENDLY COUNTY 
￼ 
Coffee County was recently ranked the 2nd most paycheck friendly county in Alabama! The study found that Coffee County had an income growth rate of 2.6% over the last five years. Covington County was ranked 5th with an income growth rate of 2.2%. Read more about the study here. 
THE WEEK AHEAD 
Congress is out of session for an October district work period, and this week I will be traveling throughout Alabama's Second District visiting with constituents, local leaders, and businesses. Yesterday, I spent time in the Wiregrass to continue damage assessments with some local farmers. I am looking forward to a week full of valuable time with the people I represent. Stay up-to-date via Facebook and Twitter. 
It is an honor to serve you in Congress. Please never hesitate to let me know if there is a way my office can be of assistance.   Sincerely, 
￼  Martha Roby 
Member of Congress

Subject: profits over patients
Message:
￼ 
For almost two years now, I've been digging into the role opioid manufacturers and distributors have played in the opioid epidemic. We've published a series of investigative reports, and last week released the latest one -- and what it shows is shocking.
As NBC News has reported, one physician's assistant prescribed a patient Subsys -- a powerful fentanyl drug -- for her chronic back pain and called it a miracle drug, upping her dosage to SIX TIMES the original amount over only 8 months.   Later, she found out he had received more than $41,000 from the drug's distributor, Insys Therapeutics, to push high doses of Subsys to his patients.   And the report I released suggests that patient wasn't the only one. My staff reviewed 1.6 million pages of internal documents from Insys Therapeutics. And those pages show a jarring pattern -- a corporate strategy -- to boost prescriptions of Subsys in the midst of a massive opioid addiction crisis.   The company took an anything-goes approach to push sales of Subsys higher, funneling money to doctors for speaking events and distorting the doctor-patient relationship by paying sales representatives more for getting physicians to prescribe the highest dose possible (one executive emailed sales reps: "the bigger the script, the more money you make"). 
I talked to NBC Nightly News about this, and I wanted to make sure you saw the clip: 
￼ 
Insys paid doctors to talk about the company's drug with their colleagues in an effort to increase prescribing.   They gave bonuses to sales reps who pushed the highest strengths of Subsys, and penalized those who failed to generate enough prescriptions.   They leveraged personal relationships between doctors and sales reps.  What united these strategies? As one Insys national sales director wrote in October 2013, "What drives us all? COMPENSATION."   This company put profits above all else to line the pockets of their executives -- and that could have cost people their lives. It's disgusting, unethical, and immoral, and it should be illegal. 
Here's the report:
￼ 
The conclusion of my latest report? "As long as both sales representatives and prescribers have strong financial incentives to boost prescriptions, greed will continue to distort the patient-physician relationship." 
I won't stop fighting to fix this, Claire
￼ 
Visit my website:  www.mccaskill.senate.gov  Unsubscribe 
￼

Subject: You’re Invited – Townhall on Disrupting Barriers in Our Community
Message:
￼ 
  

Dear Lindsey, 
The East Bay has always been home to an incredibly diverse, vibrant community. 
But inequality is on the rise in our own backyard. A recent UC Berkeley study showed that barriers in our community are making it harder for our Black, Latino, and AAPI neighbors to get by -- to pay rent, access quality, affordable health care services, and stay in their communities. 
And we’re not alone. Across our country, communities are grappling with systemic barriers that hold back communities of color. 
We must work together and face these issues head on. 
I hope you’ll join me this Thursday for a town hall on disrupting barriers within our community. I’ll be hosting a discussion with Alameda County Supervisor Keith Carson on how to tackle these pressing issues in the East Bay. 
Our conversation will start at 5:30 pm on Thursday, October 25th at Oakland Technical High School, and we welcome your thoughtful participation. 
I hope to see you there, and as always, my office is happy to assist you and your family. If you need help with a federal issue, please call my Oakland office at (510) 763-0370. You can also connect with me via email, facebook, twitter, and instagram. 
In Solidarity, 
￼ 
  
P.S. Space for the town hall is limited. Please follow this link to register for the event.

Subject: United States Senator Joe Manchin Newsletter - October 23, 2018
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
 
￼

October 23, 2018 

 
Manchin's Mountain Message
Service Academy Nomination Selection Board Announced 
  
Earlier this week, a four-member panel interviewed prospective candidates who are vying for a nomination to the four military service academies:  the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, the U.S. Naval Academy, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy and the U.S. Air Force Academy.
  
It is an honor to nominate our hardworking and dedicated West Virginia Students to the U.S. Service Academies each year and to highlight the many ways West Virginia students can enter the military while also getting a college education. Every member of the panel brings something to the table and I look forward to reviewing the results of the interviews when I make my nominations. I commend all of the students who interviewed with the board, and who are willing to step forward to serve our country. Their sense of patriotism shows the true spirit of West Virginia and the strength of the next generation.
  
The interview panel includes: 
  
CSM (Retired) Kevin Harry, former West Virginia National Guard State Enlisted Leader
  
Major Jason Lambert – Headquarters, Marine Corps, Legislative Liaison 
  
Rebecca Tucker– Professor of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math, West Virginia University Parkersburg 
  
Zahava Urecki—Legislative Correspondent, US Senator Joe Manchin 
  
￼ 
  
The interview process was conducted this week. The Senator's nominations will be announced in November. 
  
  
How May We Help You?
I truly appreciate the opportunity to hear from my fellow West Virginians. As your U.S. Senator, I am proud to be your voice with government agencies during your time of need. My goal is to provide top-notch customer service for every West Virginian who contacts me, or who may need help.  I have a team of caseworkers in each of my four offices to help you with matters of concern. While I have no direct jurisdiction in the administrative matters of any federal, state, or local agency, I welcome the opportunity to assist you with whatever problem you may be experiencing and ask that full consideration is given to your case.
Recently, Angie Walsh a caseworker in my Martinsburg office, assisted Mr. Thomas Holcomb, owner of Mumsey's Iron Skillet in Fenwick, West Virginia.  After Mr. Holcomb’s business was severely damaged in the 2016 flood, he had secured a loan from the SBA to rebuild.  Unfortunately, the rebuild ran into unforeseen expenses and Mr. Holcomb was having difficulty navigating the loan process with the Small Business Administration, Disaster Loan program.  Angie assisted Mr. Holcomb in communicating with the SBA about his property, the damages and the amount of the assistance needed, and was successful in obtaining the full amount to reopen the restaurant.  Mumsey's Iron Skillet is scheduled to reopen in 2019! 
￼ 
  
 
On the Road
Small Communities Big Solutions Conference 
This week, I attended the Small Communities Big Solutions Conference to discuss the opioid epidemic with our community, business, and healthcare leaders. No single agency can resolve this tragic issue and we must continue to work together on prevention and treatment for those affected by this epidemic. 
￼ 
￼ 
Senator Manchin speaks about the opioid crisis at the Small Communities Big Solutions Conference hosted by Alliance for the Economic Development of Southern West Virginia, Coalfield Development Corporation and The Community Development Hub of WV.  
  
Mountain State Apple Harvest Festival Parade 
I always enjoy the Apple Harvest Festival. Thank you to everyone who brought their friends and families out for a day at the festival and who joined in to walk in the annual parade. 
 ￼ 
Senator Manchin attends the Mountain State Apple Harvest Festival Parade. 
  
Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center Ribbon Cutting 
The newly renovated Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center is a welcomed addition to the Charleston area. I was honored to participate in the ribbon cutting ceremony and am excited about the new opportunities it will bring to the Mountain State.
 ￼ 
Senator Manchin attends the Charleston Coliseum and Convention Center Ribbon Cutting. 
  
Appalachian Next Generation Aerospace Conference 
I was proud to attend the Appalachian Next Generation Aerospace Conference to celebrate all that has been achieved in our state through aviation and all that is certain to be accomplished in the days and years ahead.
 ￼ 
Senator Manchin attends the RCBI Aerospace Conference. 
  
Education Alliance Summit 
Empowering our leaders in education with the tools they need to provide the highest quality education to our students is an important investment in the future of our home state. I was honored to participate in the Education Alliance Summit and take part in these conversations.
 ￼ 
Senator Manchin attends the Education Alliance Summit. 
  
135th Year of the Salvation Army in Wheeling 
One of my Regional Coordinators, Mary Jo Guidi, celebrated 135 years of the Salvation Army in Wheeling.  Thank you to all who support this remarkable institution.
 ￼ 
Regional Coordinator, Mary Jo Guidi, joins Captain Carringer, Major Hoggs, and Jackye and Billy Skelton to celebrate 135 years of the Salvation Army in Wheeling. 
  
  
To learn more, call my office Toll Free at (855) 275-5737, email me,or find me on social media: 
 ￼      ￼     ￼

Subject: President Trump Signs Bill Authorizing New Lock in Sault Ste. Marie
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  October 23, 2018
CONTACT:
James Hogge, 231-640-9158


President Trump Signs Bill Authorizing New Lock in Sault Ste. Marie

Petoskey – Congressman Jack Bergman released the following statement after President Donald J. Trump signed America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018 (S.3021) into law.
“Building a new Poe-sized lock in Sault Ste. Marie has been a main priority for me in my first term in Congress. In just one short car ride with President Trump, I expressed how important this project is for Michigan’s First District and the entire Great Lakes region. And today, the President officially authorized funding for a new lock. This is a great day for northern Michigan and the Upper Peninsula.”
In a major win for the First District of Michigan, the America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018: 
	•	Authorizes the building of a new Soo Lock;
	•	Advances research on eradicating invasive species such as Asian Carp and Zebra Muscles;
	•	Takes aim at resolving toxic algal blooms in the Great Lakes; and
	•	Requires EPA to help public water systems monitor for unregulated contaminates, such as PFAS.
. 

bergman.house.gov  
###

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Tuesday, October 23, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week I attended various meetings and events with different individuals and organizations, including the McMullen Community Health Center grand opening, the Atascosa Health Center Hurricane response grant announcement and the grand opening of the Webb County Gene Simeon Walker Los Botines Fire Station where I presented a U.S. flag and announced federal funding for the station.  

In the district, my staff attended several meetings and events including the Border Patrol Youth of the Month Ceremony and the ALFA Outstanding Commitment Awards in Laredo. 
Lastly, I have included a video from The Texas Department of Public Safety regarding their new Impact Texas Teen Driver (ITTD) program in honor of Teen Driving Safety Awareness Week.
As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Rep. Cuellar Speaks at McMullen Community Health's Center Grand Opening Ceremony

￼

As a long-standing supporter of community health centers, I spoke at McMullen Community Health Center’s grand opening ceremony on for their new behavioral health services clinic on Monday, October 15. This facility is the first of its kind for the county. The addition of this new behavioral health facility will be an invaluable resource to all of McMullen County. Pictured from left are Congressman Henry Cuellar, PA-C Angela R. Karsky, McMullen Community Health Center Practice Manager Brenda Salazar, Atascosa Health Center, Inc. CEO Monty Small, Camino Real Community Services Executive Director Emma Garcia, Camino Real Integrated Health Program Manager John Koenig, Camino Real LPC Mary Rivera, Camino Real QMHP-CS Nancy Moreno, and McMullen County Judge James Teal. 


Rep. Cuellar Announces $600,000 Grant for Atascosa Health Center Hurricane Response Service 

￼

On Monday, October 15, I announced the awarding of more than $600,000 in federal funding directed to support the quality and scope of primary healthcare services at the Atascosa Health Center. These funds will also be directed to assist in current hurricane recovery efforts and prepare AHC to effectively respond to future natural disasters that affect our district. Pictured from left are Atascosa Health Center, Inc. CEO Monty Small, Mayor of Pleasanton Travis Hall, Director of Behavior Health LCSW Dr. Noel Laurel, Board Member Virginia Herring, Mayor of Karnes City Leroy Skloss, Medical Director Dr. Rayford Mitchell, Board Member Dwayne Villanueva, Board Member Lillian Cashmer, CFO Maria Garcia, Board Member Luana Newman-Leus, and Congressman Henry Cuellar.


Rep. Cuellar Announces $566,000 for Converse Fire & EMS Department 
￼

On Monday, October 15, I visited the City of Converse where I announced $566,000 in funding for Converse’s Fire & EMS Department through the DHS Staffing for Adequate Fire & Emergency Response (SAFER) Program. This funding will go directly to the hiring of six additional “front line” firefighters, keeping the station fully staffed so that the department can more efficiently respond to emergency situations in the community. Pictured front row from left are Fire Chief Luis Valdez, Councilman Jeff Beehler, Stella Calvillo, Mayor Al Suarez, City Manager Le Ann Piatt, Congressman Henry Cuellar. Back row, from left are Assistant Chief Ray Christian, Councilwoman Nancy Droneburg, Councilwoman Shawn Russell, and behind is Councilman Marc Gilbert. 


Rep. Cuellar Presents Webb County Volunteer Fire Department with $1,281,601 FEMA Funds 
￼

On Tuesday, October 16, I announced that the Webb County Volunteer Fire Department will receive $1,281,601 from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). This award comes through the DHS Federal Emergency Management Agency’s (FEMA) Staffing for Adequate Fire & Emergency Response (SAFER) Program and will provide the Webb County Fire Department with the funding to hire nine additional front line firefighters. Pictured from left are Webb County Economic Development Director James Flores, Webb County Executive Administrator Lalo Uribe, Congressman Henry Cuellar, Webb County Judge Tano Tijerina, Webb County Commissioner Pct. 2 Wawi Tijerina, Webb County Volunteer Fire Department Chief Ricardo Rangel, Webb County Commissioner Pct. 3 John Galo, and Webb County Commissioner’s Court Executive Director Leroy Medford. 


Texas Department of Public Safety’s Groundbreaking in La Joya
￼

On Tuesday, October 16, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr counties Nichole Hernandez attended the Texas Department of Public Safety’s La Joya Area Office Groundbreaking Ceremony. The DPS La Joya Office project will be able to accommodate 40 Troopers in the squad room with 4 sergeant areas; an HP Lieutenant office, Ranger’s office, two interview rooms with rear entry, a 12 person conference room, an 800 square foot gym, a 1,780 square foot Training Classroom/ Emergency Operation room and supporting elements. 


Laredo Sector Border Patrol October Youth of the Month Ceremony 
￼

On Wednesday, October 17, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties Francis Atwell attended the Laredo Sector Border Patrol October Youth of the Month Ceremony at United South High School in Laredo. At the event, he presented the students with Certificates of Academic Recognition for their academic achievements, community service, and dedication to extra-curricular activities. Pictured is Francis with the honorees and Agents of Laredo Sector Border Patrol. 


Association of Logistics and Forwarding Agents Outstanding Commitment Awards 
￼

On Tuesday, October 16, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties Francis Atwell attended the Association of Logistics and Forwarding Agents (ALFA) Outstanding Commitment Awards for 2018. Pictured from left are Francis Atwell, Adminstrator de la Aduana de Nuevo Laredo Gerardo Omar Celis Lizarraga, Deputy Field Director of Customs and Border Protection Laredo Field Office Bradd Skinner, GAAREM President Ricardo Zaragoza Ambrosi. 


Staff Spotlight: Constituent Service Representative Sylvia Segovia 
￼

Meet our Constituent Services Representative Sylvia Segovia. Sylvia is based in our Laredo office and she enjoys interacting with constituents and providing support to help them address their concerns or questions about federal agencies. Although born in Detroit, Laredo has been her home for her entire life. 


Intern Spotlight: Yusuf Besli
￼

Yusuf Besli is a junior at the Harmony School of Innovation in Sugarland, Texas. He was born in Cleveland, Ohio, but currently resides in Houston. Yusuf is interested in pursuing a career in foreign affairs or government relations, which is what initially led him to apply for an internship with Congressman Cuellar’s office. Yusuf considers working directly with constituents (i.e. giving tours and taking calls) to be among his most rewarding experiences throughout his internship since he feels this type of work really made an impact. To learn more about Yusuf and other interns click here.


Texas Department of Public Safety: Impact Texas Teen Driver ITTD
￼

This video from the Texas Department of Public Safety explains their new safe driving program, Impact Texas Teen Driver (ITTD).Teenagers can watch to ensure they are better prepared for driving safely. 




 
 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: BREAKING: Southern Storage Reservoir Signed Into Law
Message:
News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼ 
EAA SOUTHERN STORAGE RESERVOIR SIGNED INTO LAW
Lindsey - 
With the President's signature, our southern storage reservoir legislation is officially law! 
Today he signed the Water Resources Development Act. In total, our bill contains 9 provisions that I wrote, including a section authorizing the reservoir co-written with Senators Marco Rubio and Bill Nelson, as well as a provision forcing the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to re-do the Lake Okeechobee Regulation Schedule (LORS) that determines when the Army Corps is authorized to discharge water from Lake Okeechobee. 
Together, the provisions are expected to substantially reduce discharges to the east and west coasts. 
This is a video from just a few days after I was sworn in as a Member of Congress where I made a promise on the Floor of the United States House of Representatives: that fixing our water quality would be my top priority.... 
￼ 
Since then, we've secured hundreds of millions of dollars toward that goal and fully funded the rehabilitation of the Herbert Hoover Dike, but authorizing the EAA Southern Storage Reservoir and forcing a redo of the Lake Okeechobee Regulation Schedule are the biggest accomplishments yet in our fight. 
This was a community effort, and together, I am confident we will keep up the momentum to ensure the funding we need for this infrastructure and make health and human safety the top priority once and for all. 
READ MORE 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media: 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman
