Subject: We're On Top!
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼


 ￼
￼ 
￼



The Webster Wire
Listening to Floridians
Dear Friends: 
Great news! The United States is back on top as the most competitive country in the world, according to the World Economic Forum! This is the first time since 2008 that the U.S. has been number 1. 
￼  source: Wall Street Journal 
_______________
More good news came from the Office of Management and Budget last week as they announced that in the last year, President Trump’s regulatory reform efforts have saved taxpayers $23 billion.  President Obama weaponized the federal government, using rules and regulations to impose his political philosophy, empower government to pick the winners and losers and circumvent Congress.  This stifled job growth and greatly expanded the federal government, beyond its constitutional boundaries. In contrast, under President Trump, the American economy has been revived by getting rid of unnecessary, outdated, and duplicative regulatory burdens. 
￼ 
_______________ 
Recovery continues for our fellow Floridians in the panhandle who were devastated by Hurricane Michael. The State Emergency Operations Center continues to function at level-one activation, which is full scale 24-hours-per-day activation. Many churches, nonprofit organizations and government entities such as Volunteer Florida are coordinating and organizing volunteer relief efforts to provide aid and assistance.  For more information on ways to get involved or donate, visit www.VolunteerFlorida.org. If you have friends and loved ones in the declared disaster areas in need of aid such as transitional sheltering assistance, have them visit https://www.disasterassistance.gov/ for more information and to apply for aid. 
￼ 
_______________ 
It was a pleasure to recognize Groveland City Councilman John Griffin for his 17 years of service to our county and community. I stopped by his home recently and presented him with a flag I flew over the Capitol in his honor. Thank you John, we are grateful for your service! 
￼ 
_______________ 
Thank you to the Home Circle of Hernando County for allowing me to join your homeschool group meeting last week. We know that a quality education is the key that opens the door to achieving the American Dream.  I believe every parent should be able to pick the educational opportunity that best fits their child.  I have fought against a bureaucratic approach to education and for more local and parental control, I will continue to work supporting and empowering parents with educational choice. 
_______________ 
Wednesday, I attended the Tavares Monthly Healthcare Professionals marketing meeting. I shared actions the House has taken this year to improve Healthcare policy, answered questions from attendees and listened to their feedback and ideas. 
￼
_______________ 
Saturday, I joined the Alzheimer’s Family Organization and others from across my district at the annual Walk Aware for Alzheimer’s in Floral City. The walk commemorates the lives of those who live on in our hearts and memories, and raises awareness for Alzheimer’s care, support, and research. 
I am dedicated to ensuring critical Alzheimer’s research funding is protected.  While in Congress, I have requested full funding and to prioritize NIH funding for medical research and innovation.  This year, Congress authorized funding for NIH at $37 billion, a $3 billion increase from Fiscal Year 2017. 
 ￼ 
_______________ 
Last week, I also attended a small business listening session at the Commercial Contractors Association of Lake-Sumter’s monthly meeting.  It was great to hear from small business owners across these counties on how actions we’ve taken to date cutting taxes and reducing red-tape are empowering them to keep more of their hard-earned dollars and expand their businesses.  These individuals are on the front lines creating jobs in our community.   
­­_______________ 
Meeting and talking with students is one of my favorite – and most encouraging - things to do.  Thursday, I joined the Clermont Middle School Student Body for a Q&A time with the entire school and their teachers. 
￼ ￼ 
_______________ 
Thanks to all who came out for the Citrus County Chamber of Commerce Business Appreciation BBQ and to M&B Dairy for hosting the event. It was a great time together as a community, discuss shared interests and important community issues while enjoying delicious BBQ and ice cream! 
￼ 
Your servant, 
￼ 
￼  Daniel Webster Member of Congress
Constituent Corner
My office recently announced that as a result of working diligently with VA county services and liaison offices, nearly $4.5 million has been returned to veterans in my district in compensation, pension or retroactive payments since January 2017.  One of those veterans we were able to help is from Inverness and contacted our office regarding his form 9 appeal with the VA. We provided him with the current dates that video conferences were being scheduled, which gave him an idea of a possible timeline. Several months later, his hearing was held. A call was also made to the Board of Veterans Appeals office to confirm that the transcript of the hearing had been attached to his file. Shortly after, we learned his request to reopen his claim for service connection was granted and awarded, allowing for a larger monthly benefit and his nearly $200,000 retroactive benefits payment had been received.  
Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you.  
District Update
Making reading a priority and ensuring students are gaining this critical skill has been one of my focuses throughout my time in public service.  My Community Relations Representative, Cindy, attended the Early Learning Coalition of Marion County Fall in Love with Reading event. 
￼ 
Legislative Update 
Hurricane Michael has reminded us once again of the importance of disaster preparedness.  It is critical for protecting lives and being a good steward of disaster relief dollars.  Before recess, Congress passed my bipartisan bill to strengthen ‘Worst-Case Scenario’ preparedness for hospitals, and long-term care facilities. My bill, sponsored with Rep. Debbie Dingell (D-Michigan), requires the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, with the National Academy of Medicine, to conduct a comprehensive study into the future natural disaster threats impacting emergency preparedness procedures for hospitals, long term care facilities, and other health care facilities. 
The study will provide Congress with new recommendations and expert analysis on: current emergency preparedness policies and regulations. It will also identify new policies that better address all future threats, provide updated guidelines for alternative power systems and access to clean water and recommendations to improve Federal grant programs to assist health care facilities.

Subject: Fallen Heroes
Message:
￼
Fallen Heroes
Dear Friends,

This weekend was difficult for many of us following the news that Gwinnett County Police Officer Antwan Toney was shot and killed on Saturday afternoon, while responding to a call. This terrible crime clearly demonstrates the danger our law enforcement officers face daily in our own backyards, and I hope you will join me in remembering Officer Toney’s service and sacrifice and keep his family in your prayers. 

To all those who are working around the clock – and risking your lives – to keep Georgians and our Nation as a whole safe: thank you. I encourage you to read the message below from the Gwinnett County Sheriff's Office.
￼

”This is Gwinnett County Police Officer Antwan Toney. 

If you don't already know him, you'll never have the chance to meet him because he gave his life in service of our community today.

He's a hero, but that may not mean much to his grieving family right now. They're likely still in shock.

This man died today because he was committed to making our community a safer place. For us. He died for us. We owe him a debt that we can never repay.

Never forget the sacrifice that law enforcement officers are willing to make for you. Never forget the tears of their families when they do. The streets of America are stained with the blood of countless officers across this great nation. Be thankful for them.”

My Time on the Ground
With recovery efforts from Hurricane Michael in full swing, I started last week by joining men, women, and children from across the country in offering my time, support, and resources to help storm-battered communities rebuild and recuperate. While crisscrossing the district, I visited cotton and poultry farms to assess the damage and spoke with local farmers to discuss next steps to ensure a quick and full recovery.

 
I was proud of the resilience and kindness of neighbors helping friends and strangers. In the days and weeks ahead, people in our communities will need all the resources they can get. I will continue to work with FEMA to ensure folks have the aid they need for disaster relief. Thank you to the hundreds of first responders, law enforcement officers, and volunteers who provided shelter for evacuees, a meal, and a friendly face. 
￼

On Tuesday morning, I popped into a series of classrooms at Brentwood School in Sandersville to talk with students and administrators. Incorporated in 1969 as part of the Washington County Independent Schools, Brentwood has focused its mission on providing students from Washington County and the surrounding area with an independent, well-rounded educational experience in a nurturing and safe environment. Thank you to Headmaster Anne Brantley for an awesome tour. Y’all have a bright future ahead of you! 
￼
Congressman Hice joins students at Brentwood School in Sandersville
￼
Representative Hice with Brentwood School administration during a tour of the school

At lunch, I joined folks from the Tenille Rotary and the Lions Club to provide a legislative update and hear about what’s happening in the community. I appreciated all of your questions and thoughts and look forward to seeing many of you again soon. 
￼
Representative Hice answers questions from the crowd in Tennille
￼ 
Congressman Hice joins local Rotarians for a legislative update
￼
Representative Hice thanks attendees

Next, I stopped by Verescence’s Sparta plant for a tour of the facility alongside some local leaders from Hancock County. Established in 1996, this site produces goods for one of the world’s leaders in glass bottle manufacturing for the perfume and cosmetics industries. Thanks for having me. 
￼
Operations Manager Andy Krzemien gives Congressman Hice a tour of the Verescence Sparta plant
￼
Representative Hice with Andy Krzemien, Operations Manager of Verescence Sparta, and Allen Haywood, Executive Director of Sparta-Hancock County Development Authority
￼
Congressman Hice with LaTunya Goodwin, President of the Sparta-Hancock County Chamber of Commerce, and Ed Garcia, Director of Quality Assurance

Continuing my day in Hancock County, I visited Sparta Mushrooms to get a firsthand look at its greenhouses, which recently won an award for historic preservation. As an old furniture factory with a new purpose, Sparta Mushrooms currently produces shiitake, lion's mane, and oyster mushrooms. What a unique trip! 
￼
Congressman Hice makes a pit stop to Sparta Mushrooms in Hancock County
￼
Congressman Hice with Allen Haywood, Executive Director of Sparta-Hancock County Development Authority

Thursday was another full day in the District. First, I started in Greene County for another unveiling ceremony of the Foundations of American Law and Government display in the county courthouse. This collection – which incorporates nine historic documents – is designed to educate the public about the history and background of American law. These important documents are now prominently exhibited in almost 50 Georgia county courthouses, including many in the 10th Congressional District, like Baldwin, Gwinnett, Walton, Barrow, Newton, Henry, McDuffie, Lincoln, Taliaferro, Warren, and Columbia counties.
￼
Congressman Hice speaks with a community member in Greensboro
￼
Representative Hice at the dedication ceremony with local leaders

That afternoon, I sat down and heard directly from farmers in Oglethorpe County about the policies affecting our agriculture community. Thanks for having me. I appreciate all of your thoughts and feedback!
￼
Representative Hice thanks Farm Bureau board members
￼
Congressman Hice listens to local farmers in Oglethorpe County

After the roundtable, I walked through the fields with some local farmers to take a look at the harvest of soybeans and cotton. As Georgia’s top industry, the hard work of our farmers, ranchers, and producers significantly contributes to the safest, most abundant, and most affordable food supply in the world.
￼
Congressman Hice joins Melanie Sanders for a tour of the soybean farm
￼
Representative Hice gets a firsthand look at Oglethorpe County farmland
￼
Congressman Hice thanks a local farmer
Next, I spoke with Amy Stone, the Oglethorpe Development Authority Director, to discuss local economic development projects, the need for greater access to rural broadband, and improving resources for early childhood education in low-income areas. 
￼
Congressman Hice meets with Amy Stone, Oglethorpe Development Authority Director

I closed out the day by speaking with a group of young people at Oglethorpe County Middle School. As Future Farmers of America (FFA), these students – even at their age – are already understanding the importance of our ag community and the many ways it affects nearly every part of our lives. Thanks so much for letting me be a part of your engagement and learning process. 
￼
Congressman Hice addresses the group at Oglethorpe Middle School
￼
Representative Hice takes questions from FAA members after the discussion
￼
Oglethorpe FAA members with Congressman Hice

On Friday, I was honored to join Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas in Covington for a dedication ceremony for the new addition to the Newton County Judicial Center. It was a pleasure being with you, sir, and thank you for keeping Georgia on your mind!
￼

Historic Sites Here At Home
The United States is filled with stunning landscapes, iconic battlefields, and cultural treasures. As a member of the House Natural Resources Committee, I am proud to support and safeguard the preservation of hallowed lands like Kettle Creek Battlefield – right here in Wilkes County – before they are lost to time. Last week, I introduced H.R. 7077, the Kettle Creek Battlefield Study Act, to direct the Secretary of the Interior to evaluate the Kettle Creek battlefield site and determine its suitability as a designated unit of the National Park System.

Considered to be one of the most significant Patriot victories in all of Georgia during the Revolutionary War, the Battle of Kettle Creek is a keystone of not only our state’s history, but our Nation’s. Thanks to the incredible support of the Civil War Trust and community members, earlier this year, nearly 180 acres of this crucial battlefield park were preserved. Protecting sites important to our shared national heritage is fundamental to maintaining our history for years to come, and I am glad to offer whatever support I can for the protection of significant sites like this one.

Serving You
Committed to providing superior constituent services, my staff regularly comes to you to host Mobile Office Hours across our district. Team Hice will be on-site this week in Oglethorpe and Wilkes counties to help hardworking folks learn more about the federal resources available to them, cut through red tape, and get the timely replies they deserve.
￼

Considering a Career in Public Safety?
As we build on the success of the 2018 Regional Job Fair from a few weeks ago, I wanted to announce another outstanding event for folks who are looking for work. On Monday, November 5th from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., the Georgia Piedmont Technical College will be holding a Public Safety Opportunities Career Fair. If you or someone you know is interested in a rewarding career as a police officer, firefighter, EMT, or another job in the public safety sphere, I encourage you to stop by and learn more! A commitment to public safety is a high honor and responsibility, and I’ve been incredibly proud and impressed by GPTC’s commitment to these honorable professions, in addition to broadcasting the many, many other job opportunities across our community.
￼


Helping Our Heroes
I hope veterans in the area will join Team Hice this Saturday, October 27th from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. for my second annual Helping Our Heroes event. In appreciation of all our local veterans, I invite 10th District heroes to come by the Jefferson County Leisure Center, where you will enjoy a complimentary continental breakfast and learn more about the benefits available to you. At the event, guests will be entered into a drawing for a free turkey.  Working in coordination with the Forces United (formerly the Augusta Warrior Project), the Augusta Vet Center, the Charlie Norwood VA Medical Center, the Georgia Department of Veterans Service, and the Jefferson County Vets in Action, we are bringing help and resources to you. If you or someone you know is a veteran and interested in attending, I encourage you to click here or call (478) 457-0007 for further details on this exciting event. 
￼

The Week Ahead
With more time in the District, I look forward to spending time in Athens, talking with folks in Eatonton and Covington, and helping our heroes in Jefferson County. 

As always, I’m here to serve you. Please contact my office with any questions, comments, or concerns. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to keep track of upcoming legislation and events!

Sincerely, 
￼



FOLLOW US
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 

￼ 

￼ 

TOP NEWS
Officials react to death of Officer Antwan Toney Gwinnett Daily Post – 10/21 “Deeply saddened by the passing of @GwinnettPd Officer Antwan Toney, who paid the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. Dee Dee and I thank you for your service and are lifting Officer Toney’s family and friends up in prayer during this incredibly difficult time. #BackTheBlue” — U.S. Rep. Jody Hice, R-Ga.
Hice’s Mobile Office Hours to offer assistance on Wed. News-Reporter – 10/18 The office of Congressman Jody Hice will host Mobile Office Hours with two opportunities for 10th District residents to meet with his staff this month. In Wilkes County, representatives will visit on Wednesday, October 24, and a staff member from U.S. Senator David Perdue’s office will also attend.
U.S. Congressmen Rick W. Allen and Jody Hice to Honor World War II Veterans Rick W. Allen – 10/18 U.S. Congressmen Rick W. Allen (GA-12) and Jody Hice (GA-10) will host a veterans’ appreciation event featuring a documentary about the Honor Flight program, a non-profit organization that transports our World War II heroes to Washington, D.C. to visit and reflect on their service at their respective memorials. The event will be held at 9:30 a.m. on Thursday, November 1st at Grovetown High School, where the Congressmen will present certificates of special recognition to local veterans for their bravery during World War II.
Hice to host Helping Our Heroes veterans’ event Augusta Chronicle – 10/18 U.S. Congressman Jody Hice (GA-10), in partnership with Jefferson County, will host the 2nd Annual Helping Our Heroes veterans’ appreciation event on Saturday, Oct. 27 at the Jefferson County Leisure Center. Veterans are invited to enjoy a continental breakfast and turkey giveaway, while receiving information on filing claims, veteran housing, benefits, suicide prevention, employment, and more.
Early voting for Georgia November election opens Monday 13 WMAZ – 10/12 But Georgians will also settle races for Lieutenant Governor, Secretary of State, Attorney General, Agriculture Commissioner, Insurance Commissioner, Labor Commissioner and state School Superintendent. Two seats on the state Public Service Commission, which regulations Georgia utilities, are also on the ballot Three congressional seats that cover parts of Central Georgia are also up for grabs. Democrat Sanford Bishop, whose district includes part of Macon; and Republicans Jody Hice, whose district includes Milledgeville, and Rick Allen, who represents Dublin, all face challengers.

Subject: Knight Vision: October 22, 2018
Message:
￼ 
  

Around the District
Chatsworth Porter Ranch Chamber of Commerce
Last week I attended the Chatsworth Porter Ranch Chamber of Commerce's 17th Annual State of the Community Breakfast. I enjoyed hearing from our constituents and seeing old friends. Check out some photos HERE.
￼

Seniors Expo
Lily and I had the opportunity to meet with many of you at the High Desert Medical Group “Senior Expo”. Congratulations to Joan Osborne for being named this year’s Senior of the Year. I had the honor to present the Veteran’s Community Service Award to “Coffee for Vets”. Thank you to Crazy Otto’s Restaurant on Avenue I in Lancaster and the Blanco Family for their hard work every week to welcome veterans for coffee and fellowship.
￼

Addressing the Opioid Epidemic
On Friday I hosted House Energy & Commerce Committee Chairman Greg Walden in Simi Valley to meet with local care providers and discuss federal, local, and private sector efforts to fight the opioid epidemic. Read more HERE.
￼

Veterans Portal
Did you know my website has a one-stop-shop Veterans Benefits Portal? From here, you can easily find where to get medical benefits, education assistance, and other earned benefits! Check it out HERE and tell a veteran you may know!
￼

Pinetree Community Elementary School 30 year anniversary
Pinetree Community Elementary School in Canyon Country celebrated 30 years of excellence on Friday. Congratulations and thank you for three decades of service to educate our young students.
￼

Palm Tree Elementary Ribbon Cutting
Congratulations to Palm Tree Elementary on your new upgrades! The Palmdale School District has been making improvements on many of their campuses throughout the district. Palm Tree received a fresh coat of paint.
￼

Mesquite Elementary Ribbon Cutting
Mesquite Elementary School held a ribbon cutting ceremony to celebrate the improvements that the Palmdale School District made to the school. The cafeteria has been remodeled and the exterior of the buildings have been covered with fresh paint. Principal Ken Young expressed his gratitude for the efforts of all involved.
￼

Oaks Club Driving Range Grand Opening
Congratulations to The Oaks Clubs at Valencia on the grand opening of your new driving range!
￼

UCLA Health Open House
We had a member of our staff at the ribbon cutting for the UCLA Health open house on Tourney Road in Valencia. Some of the services being offered are primary care, imaging and specialty services. We really appreciate the new facilities and the care being offered by UCLA.
￼

Kaiser 50th Anniversary
We had staff in attendance at the 50th Anniversary Celebration of Kaiser Permanente providing quality medical care in the Antelope Valley. Kaiser also held a Grant reception for the organizations they have been able to assist. I want to thank Linda Lawson, the Chief Administration Officer and her team for their work to keep our community healthy.
￼
Palmdale Chamber of Commerce Luncheon
It was an honor to speak and be recognized at the Palmdale Chamber of Commerce Luncheon. Thank you for all you do for the economy of the AV!
￼

Earned Medals for an American hero
Last week we honored a true American Hero. Steve Griffing received his Bronze Star and Purple Heart. Thank you to Brigadier General David Smith, California State Military Reserve, Installation Support EAFB for attending and pinning the Bronze Star. Steve also received the Purple Heart. The Young Marines did a great job presenting the Colors. I enjoyed meeting so many of Steve’s family and friends that came out to honor him.
￼

Coffee for Vets
I joined my fellow veterans at the Tuesday “Coffee for Vets” gathering at Crazy Otto’s in Lancaster. The room was packed and the coffee was flowing. We had staff on hand from our office available for those who had questions about VA benefits and more. Thanks to all of the men and women who were in attendance for serving our country.
￼

Simi Valley Networking Luncheon
We had a representative from the staff in attendance at the Simi Valley Chamber of Commerce Network Luncheon. Attorney Mike Khalilpour was the guest speaker and he covered the topic of taxes and business.
￼

Interviewing a local hero
I had the honor of interviewing U.S. Marine Corps Sergeant Wyatt Waldron about his experience in Iraq and a 2005 encounter in which he earned the Silver Star for his heroic actions and bravery. Thank you Sgt. Waldron for your steadfast defense of our nation. Watch the interview HERE.
￼

Speaking at Desert Christian School
It was great to talk with the students at Desert Christian School. Thank you to Mr. Fox for inviting me to meet with his government classes. We had great discussions about government from the local level to the federal level.
￼

Around the Capitol
Honoring 9/11 Heroes
The 9/11 Victim Compensation Fund is set to expire in 2020. This program provides assistance to the heroic police officers, firefighters, and other responders who answered the call of duty to save lives on and after that tragic day. Last week I cosponsored a bill to permanently reauthorize this vital program.
￼

USA back on top!
The United States is back on top of being the most competitive economy in the world! Read more HERE.
￼

Earthquake Preparedness
Last week, FEMA hosted a nation-wide earthquake drill to reinforce the importance of earthquake preparedness. Make sure you and your family are always ready! To learn more, click HERE.
￼

Santa Clarita Christian School visits the Capitol
My staff had a great time meeting 8th Graders from Santa Clarita Christian School and talking about what we do in Congress and some of the history of the Capitol. Thanks for stopping by!

Subject: Working to Support You
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Kuster
￼
 
ABOUT
CONTACT
SERVICES
MEDIA
LEGISLATION
ISSUES
 
October 22, 2018
Connect with us 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼

Dear Lindsey,   
Expanding Access to Substance Misuse Treatment  
Last week, I joined Senators Shaheen and Hassan, local elected officials, healthcare professionals and area residents to give remarks at the Ribbon Cutting Ceremony and Open House for the recently completed Friendship House treatment facility in Bethlehem. I was proud to write in support of funding through the Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC) for the construction of the new 32-bed facility to help expand services at Friendship House, the North Country’s only short-term residential and outpatient treatment program. I will continue my work to help ensure everyone struggling with addiction can get the care they need. 
￼
At the Friendship House Ribbon Cutting 
Investing in Our Rural Communities  
I also heard from staff, board members, and officials from White Mountain Science Institute, Littleton Industrial Development Corporation, and White Mountain Community College about their respective work and their plans to utilize the NBRC funds they received this year, which I fought to secure. Since it was enacted in 2008, the NBRC has promoted economic development, created jobs, and supported rural communities in New Hampshire and across the Northern Border region. Granite Staters deserve to know NBRC will be around in the years to come, and that’s why I am committed to fighting for and securing the funds this critical partnership needs to continue helping North Country communities grow and thrive.  
￼
At the White Mountain Science Institute 
Keeping Students Safe   
I joined Congresswomen Lois Frankel, Brenda Lawrence, and Jackie Speier in calling on Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos to swiftly arrange meetings and fully engage with survivors of campus sexual violence before formally proposing new regulations governing Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972. I’ve heard firsthand from survivors about the devastation and isolation they felt after experiencing campus sexual violence, and I am deeply concerned by the fact that many survivors have yet to be consulted about new regulations that will directly impact survivors’ ability to pursue an education free from sexual violence. Everyone deserves to feel safe at school, and it is imperative that the Department of Education actively seek feedback from those who know what it is like to feel unsafe. 
Protecting Loan Forgiveness for Public Servants  
Senators Shaheen and Hassan, along with Congresswoman Shea-Porter and I, wrote to Secretary DeVos, urging her to turn over more information and swiftly act to fix the Department of Education’s flawed handling of the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) program. In addition to ignoring the mounting warning signs about the Department’s handling of PSLF, the Trump administration has also actively reduced oversight of student loan servicers, thereby contributing to the current problems in student loan servicing. It is imperative that the Department act quickly to correct these implementation issues so that millions of dedicated public servants can obtain the loan forgiveness they deserve.
Looking Out for the Health of Granite State Kids  
I also joined the New Hampshire Congressional Delegation in sending a letter to the National Institute of Environmental Health Services (NIEHS), calling on the agency to focus research efforts on the potential connection between per-and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) exposure and pediatric cancer. New Hampshire parents are extremely concerned about what exposure to PFAS chemicals means for the health and safety of their children, and NIEHS must work to determine whether environmental contamination from this family of chemicals is a contributing factor to incidences of pediatric cancer found in the Granite State and across the nation.
I Want to Hear From You  
As always, please do not hesitate to reach out to my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-5206 or my Concord office at 603-226-1002 with any questions, concerns or ideas you have—I love hearing from you! Thank you for everything you do to make our state such a wonderful place to live. Enjoy your week!
Sincerely,                                       ￼

Subject: The Enzi Update - October 2018 Newsletter
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
-->
￼





 
The president signed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act 10 months ago. The full benefits haven't been fully realized yet, but the initial results are promising. The economy is expanding at its second-fastest pace in 13 years, and 1.7 million jobs have been added since Congress passed the historic tax reform legislation. Workers saw their disposable incomes grow 3.5 percent over the last year, helping families keep more of their hard-earned money. And, importantly, it has helped to provide certainty for the small business community and lowered employers’ tax burden so they can expand their businesses, create jobs and keep money in their pockets. I am happy to see these positive effects, and I will continue to work hard for the folks in Wyoming and around the country. 
￼

What's new?
President signs Enzi, Barrasso bill to reauthorize Congressional Awards program
￼
President Trump signed a bill into law to reauthorize the Congressional Awards program, which is the U.S. Congress’s award for young Americans. The bill was introduced by U.S. Senators Mike Enzi and John Barrasso, both R-Wyo. The reauthorization extends the program until 2023.
Learn more
 

Senate Budget Committee Republicans press CBO on new health insurance model
￼
Enzi led a letter with Republican members of the Senate Budget Committee encouraging the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to release details of its new health insurance simulation model, which generates estimates of health insurance coverage and premiums for the population under age 65. 
"Cost estimates are one of the first things people talk about when it comes to health care reform proposals," Enzi said. "It's important we get the best estimates possible." 
Learn more

Enzi statement on Justice Kavanaugh's confirmation
￼
In early October, the Senate voted to confirm the nomination of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to be an associated justices of the U.S. Supreme Court. 
"I have read the FBI’s supplemental background investigation on Justice Kavanaugh," Enzi said. "I found no new facts were revealed and no corroboration of the accusations were presented. Sexual assault allegations deserve to be taken seriously and career agents at the FBI compiled this background information independent of political considerations. Throughout this process I have believed that it is important to fairly examine the evidence presented without prejudice. I continue to believe Judge Brett Kavanaugh is well qualified and I voted for him to be an associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court."

Around the state
 
Enzi hosted the 15th Inventors Conference this month in Casper. "This conference is near and dear to my heart and has grown to be one of my favorite events of the year," Enzi said. "I am continually amazed by the ideas and the ingenuity from those living in Wyoming." See more
 
￼
 

 
Enzi is accepting applications for high school juniors to serve as a U.S. Senate page in Washington, D.C. this spring. "This is a great opportunity for young people and provides experiences that participants will carry with them for the rest of their lives," he said. "Not many people can say they’ve worked on the Senate floor. The page program gives students a front row seat to see history in the making while gaining real work experience." If you or someone you know is interested, be sure to apply by Nov. 7. Learn more
 
￼

 
Enzi attended the grand opening for Area 59, the new Gillette College center for innovation and fabrication. Area 59 is Wyoming’s largest collaborative workspace supporting students and the community at large. With 3D printers, laser cutters, a woodworking shop and even two robotic arms, Enzi said this is truly an exciting facility for the community. See more
 
￼

Subject: Running Water
Message:
￼
PHOTO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich joins the International Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Foundation in Thoreau for the Community Plumbing Challenge to install water and sanitation services in homes on the Navajo Nation, October 22, 2018.
October 22, 2018
Dear Friend,
I was in Thoreau this morning with plumbers and pipefitters from New Mexico and all around the world who have gathered this week to help install plumbing and water sanitation services in homes on the Navajo Nation. It continues to be the stark truth that too many New Mexicans lack access to basic infrastructure that many of us take for granted. 
It's estimated that 40 percent of households on the Navajo Nation lack running water. Which is why I was pleased to join with Navajo Nation leaders, the International Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Foundation, labor groups, plumbing manufacturers and other government officials today who are working hard to find solutions on this critical issue and make a real difference in people's lives. 
I am a strong supporter of the Navajo-Gallup Water Supply Project, which will build 280 miles of new pipeline, new pumping plants, and water treatment plants to deliver water from the San Juan River to communities on the Navajo Nation, the Jicarilla Apache Nation, and Gallup. I helped secure more than $20 million for the Navajo-Gallup Water Supply Project in the latest government funding bill, and I am committed to seeing this project through to completion.
I will continue to defend and protect tribal sovereignty, and stand up for New Mexico's tribal communities on issues such as education, water access, housing, infrastructure, public safety, and cultural preservation. I will keep doing everything I can to uphold our commitments to all of our tribes and fight for the funding, resources, and policies they need to thrive.
This is not only the right thing to do. It is our moral obligation and our treaty obligation to meet the federal government's trust relationship with our tribes. 
Sincerely,
￼
MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator
Follow Martin Heinrich on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram:
￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: A Secure Retirement
Message:
A message from US Senator Todd Young
￼ 


Panel Discussion in Indy to Mark ‘National Retirement Security Week’ 
As I travel throughout Indiana, I see Hoosiers benefiting from our growing economy. Still, many people I meet are concerned they are not financially prepared for retirement. In addition to working on legislation to help people save more, I cosponsored a resolution to designate this week as National Retirement Security Week.
Today I joined the National Federation of Independent Business to host a panel discussion in Indianapolis on the importance of retirement security. We hope to continue raising awareness about retirement security issues, financial literacy, and the important role employers play in helping their employees plan for their retirement. 
Statistics show that just under half of all private-sector workers aren’t participating in a retirement savings plan through their employer. Twenty-eight percent of all non-retired adults lack any retirement savings, while nearly half of those aged 18-to-29 report no retirement savings at all. That’s why I introduced the Retirement Security Flexibility Act and the Federal Retirement Commission Act to help strengthen private retirement programs and ensure Americans have the tools necessary to plan for retirement.
￼ 
In the photo: NFIB Indiana state director Barbara Quandt Underwood, Senator Todd Young, Indiana Secretary of State Connie Lawson, financial advisor Peter Dunn, known as “Pete the Planner” 
Indy’s Brookside Neighborhood 
As part of my Fair Shot Agenda, I visited the Brookside neighborhood in Indianapolis last week to get a firsthand look at the community’s Five Pillars of a Healthy Community initiative and efforts to transform the neighborhood.
From providing ministry and education to our young people at Oaks Academy Brookside, to offering job opportunities for people who have struggled with substance abuse at Purposeful Design – Brookside should serve as a model for neighborhoods across the country to replicate. I commend Pastor Dale Shaw, Oaks Academy Brookside Head of School Kelly Altman, Cindy Palmer with Heart Change Ministries, Purposeful Design Founder and Director David Palmer, and all of the Brookside community heroes who are working together to strengthen their community.
The goal of my Fair Shot Agenda is to ensure all Hoosiers, from all neighborhoods, have an opportunity to succeed. To achieve this we must foster an environment where people are engaging in their communities and caring for one another. That is exactly what we are seeing here in Brookside.
Media recap: 
The Statehouse File: “Jobs initiative transforming Indianapolis neighborhood” 
WISH-TV: “Sen. Todd Young visits Indianapolis neighborhood” 
WTHR: “Sen. Young visits Brookside community” 
￼
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month 
During Breast Cancer Awareness Month, I visited Indiana University’s Melvin and Bren Simon Cancer Center to tour one of their breast cancer research laboratories and see the outstanding world-class research being done there. I met with IU Simon Cancer Center Director Dr. Patrick J. Loehrer Sr. and other IU School of Medicine and Simon Cancer Center researchers to learn more about the importance of National Institutes of Health research investments, and their positive health and economic outcomes. It’s important that we ensure this center has the requisite resources to continue its good work and perhaps even expand into other areas that can help save lives and ensure Hoosiers have access to outstanding medical care. 
See what Dr. Patrick J. Loehrer Sr. said about the visit by clicking here.
 ￼ 
Saudi Arabia and the Humanitarian Crisis in Yemen 
Last Monday night, I discussed the murder of Jamal Khashoggi and the humanitarian crisis in Yemen with CNN's Jake Tapper. The murder of Khashoggi is absolutely outrageous. The American people will not stand by idly as journalists are murdered. 
We have seen a pattern of reckless behavior by the Saudi Crown Prince, including in Yemen where Saudi Arabia has engaged in gross violations of human rights and helped cause the world’s worst humanitarian crisis. America’s basic and fundamental values demand a suspension of arms sales to Saudi Arabia. Watch my interview with CNN below.
￼ 
Innovation in Higher Education 
I joined a bipartisan group of Senators last week to introduce legislation that would replace the experimental sites initiative within the Higher Education Act to promote effective, evidence-based innovation in higher education. With this needed reform we can better understand the lessons learned from experiments and use them to ensure students are prepared for the jobs of today and tomorrow. Click here to learn more on how this bill will result in greater access to opportunity for our students. 
Social Media Recap 
 ￼ 
 ￼ 
￼ 
One more thing before you go... Mobile Office Hours 
This Thursday in Gibson County a member of my staff will be holding mobile office hours at the Oakland City Library from 1:00 – 2:00 p.m. to help constituents in need of assistance from a federal agency.
Thursday, October 25, 2018 
1:00 – 2:00 p.m. 
Oakland City Library
210 S. Main St. 
Oakland City, IN 47660 
Thank you for the continued privilege to serve you in the U.S. Senate. My mission is to fight on behalf of Hoosiers and the interests that are unique to our state. I look forward to working with you, and sharing our progress, in the days ahead.  
In Service, 
￼ 


Contact Todd 
You can follow us on social media to receive constant updates on Senator Young's work on behalf of you:
Facebook 
Twitter

Subject: Rutherford Roundup - Salute the Troops Edition
Message:
News from Representative Rutherford  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
 

Contact Me | Subscribe
￼
RUTHERFORD ROUNDUP 
Salute the Troops Edition 

Welcome to a special edition of the Rutherford Roundup dedicated to our men and women in uniform. The First Coast is one of the most military-friendly communities in the country, and we are incredibly proud to be home to so many outstanding servicemembers, veterans and mission-critical installations. From reinvesting in our forces to funding the DoD on time, this Congress has taken seriously its responsibility to make sure our troops are ready for the fight. This newsletter recaps recent actions we in Congress have taken to fulfill our obligation to provide for the common defense.

￼ 

￼ 
Each year, thousands of brave men and women selflessly volunteer to serve our nation. They are the embodiment of our nation’s fundamental shared belief that freedom is worth defending, and we owe our military members and their families our unwavering support. 
Yet, for several years, our military was underfunded and unable to properly train, support, and equip our troops. Congress let DoD funding fall into uncertain, short-term funding cycles, failing to complete the agency’s budget on time for ten straight years. I have heard from so many military leaders about the ways these cuts have harmed readiness and directly endangered our troops. Consider the following:
	•	Less than half of the Navy’s aircraft are mission capable. Ships are staying in port due to lack of maintenance rather than sailing to perform missions.
	•	Eighty servicemembers died last year from training exercises.
	•	The average age of Air Force aircraft is over 27 years old.
	•	Half of Marine Corps aviation units lack the minimum number of ready basic aircraft.
	•	Only one third of the Army’s 58 total brigade combat teams is “ready to fight tonight."
	•	The number of military facilities deemed by the Pentagon as “failing” have doubled in recent years due to deferred maintenance.
	•	Barracks are crumbling, hangars are being condemned, and air traffic control facilities and runways are in disrepair.
This is simply unacceptable and must end for good. We cannot continue to allow ships to be stuck in port, planes to fall from the sky, and troops to live and serve in unsafe facilities and housing.  
￼
  
￼ 
My colleagues and I in this Congress recognize that the most important job of the government is to provide for the national defense. We have worked tirelessly to find ways to responsibly invest taxpayer funds to protect our troops and fight our adversaries. Congress recently passed, with my proud support, a $674 billion DoD funding bill for Fiscal Year (FY) 2019 that builds on our progress to rebuild our military and turns the tide on the current challenges DoD is facing. As General Dunford, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said, “What the troops have seen is a commitment from the executive and legislative branches of government to give them the wherewithal to do their jobs.”   
The FY 2019 funding bill provides the resources needed to rebuild infrastructure, repair equipment, upgrade vehicles, and scale up recruiting and training. We also gave our servicemembers a 2.6% pay increase - the largest in nine years - which is incredibly well-deserved. 
Important for Northeast Florida’s installations, the legislation also provides funds to procure three Littoral Combat Ships and three MQ-4C Triton unmanned aerial vehicles supporting missions at NS Mayport, plus ten P-8A Poseidon aircraft supporting missions at NAS Jax. It also supports the sustainment of the F-15C aircraft used by the 125th Fighter Wing. And the bill funds maintenance, repair, and upgrade work on the ships, planes, vehicles, and facilities at our installations, making them more efficient and effective.  
￼ 
￼ 
Supporting the DoD also means supporting the industries they rely on, and the First Coast is home to many of the defense industrial base manufacturers, suppliers, and service contractors that provide our warfighters with the tools they need to succeed. This bill provides for six E-2D Advanced Hawkeyes, manufactured by hundreds of employees in St. Augustine, and advances the procurement of our Light Attack Aircraft program, which is key for the potential procurement of the A-29 Super Tucano aircraft manufactured in Jacksonville. 
The effort to build our military to meet the current global threat will take a sustained commitment in the coming years, and as the proud representative of this district, I will continue to fight for our servicemembers, our installations, our veterans, and our nation. 

￼ 

￼
￼

Subject: How are you celebrating National Down Syndrome Month?
Message:
￼

￼ 
Hello,
For those of you who don't know our family's story, my oldest, Cole, is 11 years old. Like many boys his age, he plays basketball and other sports. He's also in the Cub Scouts. Cole finds joy in learning, loves school, and is great at math. He is a wonderful big brother to his two younger sisters, Grace and Brynn. 
Cole has Down syndrome, and like everyone else, he has dreams and aspirations. I love how excited he gets when we talk about his passions and the future. He wants to go to college and find a career. He often says he wants to be "...just like Dad and go into the Navy."
Because of Cole, I've connected with a whole new purpose in my life, and today I am a proud ability advocate. I say ability advocate because I believe it is so important to focus on what every person has to offer--not their limitations.  For me, ensuring those who are part of the disability community have every possible opportunity to live happy, healthy, and productive lives is not just good policy, it's personal. 
This month I've been celebrating Down Syndrome Awareness Month and National Disability Employment Awareness Month, to honor the many people, like Cole, who bring so much joy and happiness to the world. 
I'm marking this important month by reflecting on all the big wins for the disabilities community this past year. For example, I led the effort to include provisions important to those with disabilities in tax reform, and today I'm proud to say we're knocking down barriers that often trap people with disabilities in poverty. Thanks to months of hard work, I'm pleased to report that the employment rate for people with disabilities has jumped sharply over the last two months. 
Tax reform is also building on the success of my Achieving a Better Life Experience (ABLE) Act that created tax-free savings accounts for job training, education, and disability-related expenses. By increasing annual contribution limits and allowing rollovers from 529 savings accounts, ABLE accounts are now more flexible and accessible to those who need them. 
My ABLE to Work Act, which was signed into law in tax reform, makes it easier for people with disabilities to explore the workforce and save more of what they earn. More specifically, thanks to my legislation, an ABLE beneficiary who works and receives an income can save up to the Federal Poverty Level in addition to their annual contribution limit of $14,000. As a result, ABLE accounts are helping people with disabilities find an internship, start a new job, or even run their own businesses!  The inclusion of my ABLE to Work Act in tax reform marks an exciting new chapter for the disabilities community.
A job means so much more than a paycheck, it's a foundation for a better life. That's why it's so important to keep working to unleash the full potential of people living with disabilities and continue building on the progress we have already made. That's why I made sure tax reform was written with people with disabilities in mind.
That's not all. My ABLE Financial Planning Act was also signed into law last year and allows rollovers from a 529 account. This means that individuals who may have been saving for their child's college tuition can now roll over up to the maximum contribution each year until the 529 account has been depleted. This adjustment empowers people with disabilities at every stage of their life, and it helps them invest in their futures, pay for medical expenses, and look for a job. It can even help them cover the cost of getting to work when they find a job, which is a game changer for so many.
This month also marks the first anniversary of the bipartisan Disability Employment Working Group I started with a number of my Democrat and Republican colleagues. Our goal is to find real solutions that help individuals with disabilities find meaningful work in our community and escape the cycle of poverty. We meet on a regular basis to identify regulations that act as barriers to entry for those with disabilities, and identify legislative changes that can encourage them to enter the workforce and unleash their full potential.
These are just a few of the many ways I'm celebrating Down Syndrome Awareness Month and National Disability Employment Month. I know there's much work to be done in the future.  However, when we provide opportunities for people--no matter their walk of life--and unleash their full potential, there's no telling what we can accomplish together. 
Thanks, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress

Subject: ALERT: Executive Action Will Bring More Water to Central Valley
Message:
Enews Sign Up | View Online
￼
HOME   |    ABOUT   |    SERVICES   |    ISSUES   |    NEWSROOM   |    CONTACT 
October 22, 2018
Executive Action Will Bring More Water to Central Valley
Over recent years, California has experienced its worst drought in recorded history. Since coming to Congress, I have dedicated myself to fighting for water for the Central Valley. However, our California Senators have refused to help - putting the needs of a tiny fish over the needs of Central Valley families. 

After years of fighting, at our request, the President signed an Executive Action promoting the reliable supply and delivery of water in California and the entire western United States. 

I am proud our efforts have effectuated such substantial progress. With a reliable water supply, we can restore fallowed fields into fertile farmland, put Californian’s back to work, and give all Central Valley families the opportunity they deserve.

This Executive Action puts in place a strict timetable for rewriting the biological opinions that lie at the root of the water crisis. The Executive Action also prioritizes building critical projects to expand water storage in our state so that we can store more water during wet years for use in dry years.

As a life-long Central Valley resident and farmer, I know firsthand the challenges faced by Valley families and farmers when water becomes scarce. Access to safe, clean, and reliable water is the lifeblood of the Central Valley’s booming agricultural economy, and ensuring access to water is imperative to the everyday lives of all Valley families. 

Now, California families can rest assured that help is on the way.

Sincerely, ￼ David G. Valadao Member of Congress

Subject: A Message From Ann
Message:
A message from Congresswoman Ann Wagner 
￼ 

About
Contact
Services
Media Center
Issues


Dear Lindsey, 
As members of the greater St. Louis community, we must always be watchful and aware of our surroundings. This week we were reminded that trafficking can happen anywhere, including right here in St. Louis. That is why fighting human trafficking remains one of my top priorities in Congress and why I was so honored to receive the 2018 Wilberforce Award from Rescue:Freedom International for writing and passing the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (FOSTA). There is still much more work to be done. Recently, I introduced the Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act to promote information sharing between non-profit organizations and financial institutions. With this legislation, we can put a stop to the money laundering that allows traffickers to keep their illicit networks afloat. 
￼
￼

I’m also honored to work alongside the St. Louis Business Travel Association (STLBTA) in fighting human trafficking in our region. As a transportation crossroads, St. Louis is unfortunately one of the country’s leading hotspots of trafficking. Travel pros are on the front lines of this fight and deal directly with victims, buyers, and pimps. I am grateful the STLBTA was one of the first travel organizations to sign ECPAT’s Code of Conduct, signaling their commitment to end the commercial sexual exploitation of children. We have made tremendous strides in the fight against trafficking, and that’s a testament to our travel industry, community organizations, academic institutions, law enforcement, prosecutors, and service providers. It was wonderful to see so many attend the STLBTA’s presentation on how best to make St. Louis safer for everyone.
 
￼
￼
￼

Throughout this Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we remember all the strong survivors and their families, as well as those we have lost. So many of us have loved ones affected by cancer. Together, we can fight against this disease with research, education, and awareness. In Congress, I will continue cutting red tape to promote innovation for new life-saving cures.
 
￼

The nomination application deadline for the United States Service Academies’ Class of 2023 was last week. We received 41 applications from across Missouri’s 2nd Congressional District. My dedicated Nominations Panel is preparing to review each candidate’s file and conduct interviews later this year. It’s an honor to nominate talented students to the U.S. Air Force Academy, U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, U.S. Military Academy, and the U.S. Naval Academy each year!
 
Sincerely,
￼  Ann Wagner Member of Congress 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Subject: News from the 10th
Message:
News from Congressman Brad Schneider 
￼

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Dear Friends, 
Before talking about last week, I want to flag some important dates looking forward. 
First, early voting begins today, October 22, for the November 6 general election. Some key facts to know about early voting: 
	•	You can vote at any early voting location in the county where you live,
	•	You do not need to provide an excuse or reason why you cannot vote on Election Day, 
	•	Government-issued photo ID is not required, and
	•	Grace Registration is available for unregistered voters at any early voting site.
You can find an early voting site near you on the websites for Cook County and Lake County. Voting is among our most important rights as citizens in a democracy, and early voting is an excellent and convenient way to make your voice heard.
Second, on November 9, I am excited to host our second annual Veteran’s Breakfast to kick off the Veteran’s Day weekend.  This is another opportunity to honor those in our communities who served, and share some of the ways my office and local veteran organizations can be of assistance. The breakfast is at Crist’s Rey St. Martin College Prep in Waukegan, and is free and open to all veterans in Illinois’s Tenth Congressional District. More details are listed below. 
As for the week that was, it was another very busy week throughout the district, including visits to Round Lake Beach, Mundelein, Waukegan, Glenview, Gurnee, Wadsworth, North Chicago, Grayslake and Northbrook.  One of the highlights was running into students I met during school visits earlier this month at various event around the district.  It’s inspiring to see these young people engaged in our community and I really enjoy the opportunity to hear from them, and their parents, every chance I get.
Please read on for updates from my week working at home in our district. Additionally, we’re still accepting RSVPs for our Medicare Part D Help Sessions this November– sign-up today! 
  
CONSTITUENT SERVICE SPOTLIGHT: HELP RECOVERING MEDALS 
￼                                                                       
Our office worked with John Wensch of Winthrop Harbor to acquire medals that his late father, a World War II veteran, earned in the Pacific Theater. I'm grateful for the service of John's father, and glad we could help honor his memory in this way. 
If you need help with a federal agency – from Medicare and Social Security to immigration and the VA – please contact our office in Lincolnshire at (847) 383-4870.
  
100 PERCENT SCORE ON LGBTQ EQUALITY ISSUES 
￼ 
  
Last week, I was proud to announce that my legislative record on LGBTQ equality issues has earned a 100 percent score from Human Rights Campaign. The Fair and Equal Housing Act, bipartisan legislation that I helped introduce to prevent housing discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, was one of the bills featured in the scorecard. I will continue to stand up to efforts to undermine these hard fought rights or to discriminate against our fellow Americans because of who they are or who they love. 
Learn more on HRC’s website. 
  
HELP WITH MEDICARE OPEN ENROLLMENT FOR SENIORS 
￼ 
  
The Medicare annual enrollment period starts TODAY and lasts until December 7. This is the yearly time when seniors can make changes to their Medicare coverage for the following year. 
I’m excited to announce four upcoming events for constituents to meet with counselors to discuss their coverage options and compare and select the best plan for them. These events are by appointment only, and attendees should RSVP for a one-hour timeslot using the instructions below. You can also reach us at our office at (847) 383-4870 with questions.
Wednesday, November 14 | 9:30am – 2:30pm Indian Trails Library 355 Schoenbeck Rd, Wheeling, IL 60090 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
Thursday, November 15 | 10:00am – 2:00pm  Zion-Benton Public Library 2400 Gabriel Ave, Zion, IL 60099 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
Tuesday, November 20 | 9:30am – 3:30pm Glenview Senior Center 2400 Chestnut Ave., Glenview IL, 60026 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 784-6040
Tuesday, November 27 | 9:30am – 2:30pm  Vernon Area Public Library 300 Olde Half Day Road, Lincolnshire, IL 60069 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
  
RSVP FOR VETERANS BREAKFAST 
￼ 
  
This Veterans Day weekend, I’m hosting a breakfast to honor those in our communities who served, and share some of the ways my office and local veteran organizations can be of assistance.  
The breakfast is free and open to all veterans in Illinois’s Tenth Congressional District. If you, or someone you know, is a veteran, I hope to see you there. 
Cristo Rey St. Martin College Prep 3106 Belvidere Road Waukegan, IL 60085 RSVP 
  
NEIGHBORHOOD OFFICE HOURS 
This week, our constituent service representatives will be in Wheeling and Libertyville. If you need assistance with a federal issue, please come see us!
View the full schedule on our website. 
  
WEEKLY WRAP-UP  
￼ 
During our most recent #BradAtYourBusiness, I appreciated hearing the perspective of Rick Larsen and the team at American Outfitters LTD on the opportunities and challenges facing local businesses. They’ve been producing t-shirts, banners, and other promotion material in the Waukegan area since 1975.
  
  
￼ 
Thank you Washington Early Learning Center for inviting me to visit during your parent-teacher conference day and meet with community members.
  
￼ 
  
I had a wonderful visit to Heart of the City in Waukegan. Their program increases access to soccer for Lake County students to inspire kids to be competitive on the field, successful in the classroom, and productive in the community. A great organization!
  
￼ 
  
It was great to see young people in the Glenbrook South High School Interact Club getting ready to serve a meal to community members in need.
  
  
￼ 
I was glad to be in Round Lake for the annual chili supper to support Round Lake Area BEST and Round Lake Area Exchange Club.
  
￼ 
I joined volunteers at Growing Healthy Veterans constructing a "Hoop House" greenhouse in Gurnee this weekend The organization works to engage veterans in agricultural projects to enhance their physical health, overall wellness, and that of their families and communities.
  
￼ 
There were great costumes over the weekend at the North Suburban YMCA - Northbrook Halloween Spooktacular! 
  
￼ 
  
I was glad to join the Exchange Club of Grayslake for their annual pancake breakfast and support their service in the community. Also caught up with WRLR 98.3FM.
  
Thanks for reading!          
 Sincerely, ￼  Bradley S. Schneider Member of Congress

Subject: Wishful thinking can't fix this.
Message:
Monday Report from Representative Rick Nolan
￼
 
￼
￼
￼
￼
Climate Change is Altering Our National Parks - Not the President's Resolve to Ignore Facts and Science
￼  If climate change continues unabated, studies predict indicated that many native trees like these along Echo Bay Trail in Voyageurs National Park will eventually be replaced by less desirable species that can better live in hot weather. 
Dear Friend, 
Ignoring the overwhelming evidence of man-made climate change based on facts and science, the President told CBS News correspondent Leslie Stahl last week he thinks the Earth’s rapid warming “will change back again.” Too bad the President’s wishful thinking won’t save our 417 national parks.    According to a new study by the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Wisconsin, failure to address global warming by radically reducing fossil fuel-based carbon emissions is already altering these national treasurers forever.   Over time, for example, scrub trees that can live more easily in hotter weather could replace the tall pines covering much of the land in Northern Minnesota’s Voyageurs National Park - which I was proud to support when it was established in 1975 during my first term of Congressional service. Some species of fish and wildlife will disappear – including our iconic Minnesota loons, which are likely to move north into the colder regions of Canada.   Out West, the study predicts that California’s Joshua Tree National Park will eventually lose its Joshua trees, while wildfires transform the forests of Yellowstone National Park into grasslands. And if current trends continue, Glacier National Park will lose its glaciers as they melt into rivers.    Dire predictions like these still fail to move the President and GOP leaders to take even modest steps to address climate change. Their concern, as the President indicated in the CBS interview, is to keep the fossil fuel industry fabulously profitable and wealthy– regardless of the cost and permanent loss to future generations.  
We will keep you posted as events proceed. Meanwhile, I want to hear your thoughts. Feel free to contact any of our offices listed below or send me an email. 
Sincerely,  ￼ 

Real Immigration Reform is the Only Solution to the Chaos and Tragedy on our Southern Border
￼  The President’s new plan would reportedly give parents two heartbreaking choices: stay behind bars with their children for months or years until their cases are decided – or allow their children to be placed in separate federal detention centers in hopes of being picked up by a relative or guardian.
Last summer, political pressure from a shocked and angry public forced the President to abandon his policy of forcibly separating immigrant children from their parents at our southern border. But last week, the Washington Post reported that he’s actively considering reinstituting this terrible practice, hoping to intimidate more families from seeking asylum in the United States. And he may, in fact, shut down the government in December if Congress doesn’t approve funds for his wall.  
Let’s be clear. We must have strong border protection. A nation without borders is not a nation. But it is simply preposterous to suggest that it be done with an $18 billion dollar wall, or by deporting some 11 million people. 
Real immigration reform would include a path to citizenship for immigrants who have been living in the U.S. for some time, and who do not have a criminal record. And real reform would include respect for international accords that protect those who come here legally seeking asylum. 
It’s been more than five years since the Senate sent a bipartisan immigration reform bill to the House. Since then, Republican leaders have refused to allow consideration of the plan, which might have avoided much of the terrible chaos and cruelty on our southern border. 
Republican leaders need to get serious about passing real, comprehensive immigration reform – and stop trying to fix the immigration mess with bad legislation concocted from behind closed doors, with every Democrat and a good share of their own caucus left out of consideration. There is plenty of rank and file support on both sides of the aisle to find commonsense, bipartisan solutions to put a stop to the needless human tragedies that continue to occur on our southern border.  

Under Pressure, Administration Agrees to Implement Year-Round Sale of E-15 Ethanol
￼  According to the Congressional Budget Office, biofuel is responsible for a 35% increase in every bushel of corn used to make it.   
Under strong pressure from farm state Democrats and Republicans alike, the Administration has finally agreed to direct the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to get moving on rules and regulations allowing year-round sales of E-15 fuel that is 15 percent ethanol by July 2019.   This is good news for Minnesota corn and soybean farmers – and for the 47 Democrats and Republicans, including me, cosponsoring the Consumer & Fuel Retail Choice Act (H.R. 1311) to allow for year-round sale of E-15 fuels. Passing the bill would go beyond EPA regulations to put the force of law behind year-round E-15 sales.  As I have pointed out before, ethanol adds 63 cents in value to every bushel of soybeans used to make it - and adds about 35% to the value of every bushel of corn used in production. With farm income at a 12-year low, that’s a real boost to our farmers and rural communities. According to the Minnesota Bio-Fuels Association, Minnesota ranks fourth among states in ethanol production. By the end of May 2018, Minnesotans had already used a record 29.9 million gallons of ethanol – a 57 percent increase in sales over the 19 million gallons sold during all of 2017. 

GOP Tax Cuts for Millionaires, Billionaires and Wealthy Corporations Drive the 2018 Federal Deficit to Record Heights 
Republicans promised their tax cuts for the rich would "pay for themselves." That hasn't happened, so they're targeting cuts to Social Security and Medicare instead. 
￼  We cannot and will not allow the President and GOP leaders to carry through with their plans to cut Social Security and Medicare in order to make up for record high deficits brought on by their $1.5 trillion tax cut for millionaires, billionaires and wealthy corporations. 
The simple fact is that the massive, $1.5 trillion tax cut - 80% of which the President and Republican leaders handed to millionaires, billionaires and wealthy corporations last year - is not “paying for itself” as they promised it would. Last week, the Treasury Department admitted that the federal deficit ballooned to $779 billion in fiscal year 2018 – a 17% increase over 2017, due directly to the fact that big corporations and the richest one percent of Americans are paying far less in taxes.   Now guess how the President and GOP leaders plan to deal with this ballooning deficit, now predicted to reach$1 trillion a year by 2020? That’s right. They’re targeting big cuts in Social Security and Medicare – the hard earned benefits Americans begin paying for from their very first day on the job. GOP Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell admitted as much last week when he called Social Security and Medicare “the real drivers” of the federal deficit.   What nonsense! The real truth is that neither Social Security nor Medicare is in debt. Quite the opposite – the Social Security Trust Fund is carrying a surplus of roughly $2.8 trillion according to the official actuary audit. And Medicare will remain solvent well into the 2030’s. So there is plenty of time to fix whatever needs fixing in both programs – without cuts to benefits and without risky Republican privatization schemes to turn Social Security over to Wall Street and Medicare over to the for-profit health care industry.   Meanwhile, as I have said many times before, it’s time for real tax reform that targets the middle class and requires the rich to pay their fair share for a change. That must be our goal going forward.

Our Week in Duluth 
￼  It is important for Congressional offices and federal agencies to have good communication to better serve our constituents. This week, the U.S. Forest Service invited Congressional staff members to Duluth to speak with leadership teams from the Superior, Chippewa, and Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forests. Jeff Anderson, my District Director, joined representatives from Senator Tina Smith and Senator Tammy Baldwin’s offices, and staff from the House Committee on Agriculture to discuss congressional relations between the Forest Service and congressional offices.  
￼  USS Duluth Crewmembers Association representatives (left to right) Don Rowe (Mentor, Ohio), James Shepard (Burleson, Texas), and Dan Streu (Duluth, MN) stopped by my Duluth office for a visit and an update on our efforts to request that the Secretary of the Navy name a new LPD amphibious U.S. Navy ship for the city of Duluth and in honor of the USS Duluth LPD-6, commissioned in 1966 and later decommissioned in 2005. I have worked with the association on a number of projects over the past 6 years including our successful efforts to bring an anchor from the decommissioned USS Duluth to its new home on the Lakewalk on the shores of Lake Superior.  
￼  My District Director Jeff Anderson joined area housing stakeholders in a housing issue roundtable hosted by my colleague, U.S. Senator Tina Smith. The roundtable was hosted by Ecolibrium 3 in Duluth’s Lincoln Park neighborhood. Representatives from the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, City of Duluth, Duluth Housing & Redevelopment Authority, Center City Housing, CHUM, Lifehouse, and area realtors shared housing needs in the Twin Ports. Senator Smith and I are committed to making sure the federal government is a partner in building quality, affordable housing here in Minnesota. 
Our Week in Two Harbors
￼  The Two Harbors Area Chamber of Commerce held their annual membership meeting at the Castle Danger Brewery in Two Harbors. Members heard from MNDOT officials about North Shore road construction projects. Attendees also received an update from a panel of local leaders including Mayor Chris Swanson, Lake County Administrator Matt Huddleston, Lake View Hospital’s Greg Ruberg, the DNR’s Kevin Johnson and Jay Belcastro from Lake Superior School District. My District Director Jeff Anderson attended this meeting on my behalf.
Our Week in Pine City 
￼  Locals gathered at the Pine City Senior Center where they received an update from Nolan Congressional Field Representative Rick Olseen about the announcement from Social Security Administration last week that benefits for more than 67 million Americans will increase 2.8 percent in 2019. 
Our Week in Eveleth 
￼  The Alcohol and Mental Health Community Solutions public forum was hosted by the Opioid Abuse Response Strategies North Workgroup (OARS) in Eveleth last week. Presenters discussed how alcohol and methamphetamines top the list as the major substance abuse issues in northern Minnesota, even in light of the national opioid crisis. Nolan Congressional Field Representative Tom Whiteside attended the event.

Finally...
On This Day in History - October 22, 1962  President John F. Kennedy Announces Blockade of Cuba as Missile Crisis Threatens to Ignite Nuclear War with the Soviet Union
￼  Like virtually every other major newspaper around the world, the New York Times front page announced the U.S. blockade of Cuba with bold headlines. 
Fifty-six years ago today, President Kennedy spoke to the world from the Oval Office, announcing that the U.S. had imposed a quarantine on Cuba in an effort to force the Soviet Union to withdraw offensive nuclear missiles they had secretly installed on the island. In the end, the Soviets removed the missiles, moving the world away from the brink of nuclear war.   Some 15 years later, as a young Congressman, I met in Havana with then Cuban President Fidel Castro in what became a successful effort to free the last U.S. prisoners from the ill-fated 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion. Castro predicted it would be many decades before diplomatic relations between the U.S. and Cuba would be normalized. At the time, I thought him overly pessimistic, but in the end, his assessment proved to me true.

Subject: We All Know Someone with a Preexisting Condition
Message:
￼    ￼   ￼

￼
We all have loved ones who live with high blood pressure, asthma, diabetes, and even cancer.
These illnesses are just a few of the "pre-existing conditions" that over 150,000 Montanans fight through on a daily basis. 10 years ago, our health care system allowed insurance companies to deny coverage to folks with these pre-existing conditions.
￼
That is one of the many reasons why I fought hard to change our health care system and pass laws that ensure all Montanans who have pre-existing health conditions can access health insurance and seek the treatment they need.
 
￼
But today that progress is under attack. There are politicians in Helena and Washington, D.C. who are fighting to roll back these protections and give insurance companies the power once again to deny you coverage if you have a pre-existing health care condition.
Their actions not only harm thousands of Montana families, including your own, but they are also driving up health care costs for everyone. Their attacks on our health care are unacceptable, and that is why I will continue to defend all Montanans with pre-existing conditions.
 
I am fighting to stop the expansion of "junk" insurance plans that don't cover pre-existing conditions. I'm holding the U.S. Justice Department accountable so it defends our strong health care laws in court, and I'll keep passing bills that will lower health care costs for Montana families.
￼
You can learn more about my efforts to lower health care costs HERE.

As always, it is an honor to serve you in the Senate, especially those of you with pre-existing conditions.
 
￼

Subject: BREAKING: Medicare Open Season Underway!
Message:
October 22, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
If you or a family member are on Medicare, I wanted to remind you that open enrollment is now underway.   This is the 7-week window when seniors can change their prescription drug plan or switch from original Medicare to Medicare Advantage or vice versa.     This once-a-year window gives Medicare recipients the opportunity to select a new plan for 2019 based on annual changes in cost, coverage options and available providers or pharmacies. 
The enrollment period ends on Dec. 7.    Everyone with Medicare is eligible for prescription drug coverage, regardless of income and resources, health status or current drug expenses. Seniors who are happy with their current coverage do not need to do anything.   Seniors may sign up or update their plans in two ways:   1) Phone: Call 1-800-MEDICARE. Seniors should have their Medicare card, a list of drugs they use and the name of their pharmacy on hand to get immediate help in choosing a plan.   2) Online: Go to Medicare.gov to review prescription drug coverage options.   The Medicare program can often be confusing, so please do not hesitate to call my Sarasota office at 941-951-6643 or my Bradenton office at 941-747-9081 for assistance with open enrollment.   More details on Medicare Open Enrollment are available online in the U.S. Government Medicare handbook.     Vern
