Subject: McCollum News: Protecting Our Care From Republican's Deficit-Exploding Tax Cuts
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Betty McCollum 
￼
 

￼
￼
￼


SUBSCRIBE
|
WEBSITE
|
CONTACT ME

 

 
Dear Neighbor, 
In late 2017 when Republicans passed a massive $1.5 trillion tax cut for millionaires, billionaires, and big corporations, their bill went to President Trump’s desk without the vote of a single Democrat. This was profoundly irresponsible legislation that I could not support. 
At the time, Republicans promised that economic growth would replace the lost government revenue and even reduce the budget deficit. Now we know the truth, or at least the price tag for the snake oil they were selling to the American people. 
On September 30th, 2018 the federal budget year ended with a $779 billion deficit – a 17% increase over fiscal year 2017. Government revenue in 2018 from corporations alone was down more than 30%, a direct result of the permanent tax cut they received. Even more revealing, $164 billion of the 2018 budget deficit is directly attributable to lost revenues as a result of the Republican tax cut.    That’s right, the Republicans are now borrowing $164 billion from China and other countries to give tax breaks that benefit the wealthiest Americans.  
And it gets worse. Next year’s deficit is projected to be $981 billion and then over $1 trillion in 2020. 
This week, the Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blamed the deficit on Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. The Republican plan is clear: explode the deficit, drive up the national debt, and then achieve their longtime goal of cutting Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid to pay for their fiscally irresponsible tax cuts. 
It is impossible to operate the much needed day to day functions of the federal government when Congress refuses to collect sufficient revenues. 
I want to reassure my constituents, especially seniors, people with disabilities, children receiving survivor benefits, families with loved ones in nursing homes, and low-income families – I will fight to protect your earned benefit programs! We need to strengthen these programs and I support lifting the caps on payroll deduction so every dollar of earned income by every millionaire is being paid into the system.  
Our nation faces an inevitable fiscal crisis and the Republicans in Congress don’t care. President Trump’s own record of multiple business bankruptcies should be considered a foreshadowing of the mess he will leave the American people, especially our children. 
To keep America moving forward we need to make smart investments, help provide the tools the American people need to keep them productive, and make everyone pay their fair share for the freedom, blessings, and opportunity this country provides us all. 
The choice is clear – we can pay taxes to our government and support the services necessary to keep America strong, or we can continue to borrow money from China to give tax cuts to the rich. 
Middle class families are already paying their fair share of taxes, it’s long past time that big corporations and the wealthiest among us pay their fair share too. 
  
Sincerely,  ￼  Betty McCollum Member of Congress

Subject: Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 10.22.18
Message:
October 22, 2018
Share this email:
￼
￼
￼

￼
Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 10.22.18
Monday, October 22, 2018 –                                 
Prescription Drug Costs
Previously, I reported in this column that two bills meant to combat high drug prices had passed both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I am happy to say that President Trump has since signed them into law.
The Know the Lowest Price Act of 2018 and the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act ban “gag clauses,” which are sometimes imposed by pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) on pharmacists and can lead to customers paying higher prices for prescription drugs.
These bills easily passed the House and the Senate, and President Trump voiced strong support for them as he signed them into law. These were the Senate versions of legislation I worked on in the Energy and Commerce Committee with a bipartisan group of lawmakers, including Buddy Carter (R-GA), Debbie Dingell (D-MI), Michael Burgess (R-TX), Peter Welch (D-VT), Gene Green (D-TX), and Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-WA). They are bipartisan wins for transparency in drug pricing.
Good News for Manufacturing
America’s economic strength is often associated with manufacturing, and manufacturing jobs are often associated with well-paid, steady work.
Right now, manufacturing is enjoying a resurgence nationally and in the Ninth District.
At the national level, U.S. manufacturing capacity increased for the sixteenth straight month in September. Crucial policy changes, such as the rollback of excessive regulations both by Congress and by the Trump Administration and enactment of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, are fueling this boom.
Prudent regulation and the cutting of excessive red tape allow those companies to devote more attention and resources to their businesses rather than complying with overly-prescriptive governmental dictates.
By making America’s tax code more competitive with the rest of the developed world, companies have more reasons to open or expand manufacturing operations in the United States.
Further, we changed the tax code to make it easier for American companies who profit overseas to bring those profits back to the United States for investment, wage increases, etc.
Wages are up. The American people are confident about their economy, and they are buying more goods, manufactured goods.
Better policies at the federal level encourage this manufacturing boom. We can share in this national manufacturing renaissance. Good economic news from the past months shows that we are in fact sharing in the growth.
The Roanoke Times highlighted that the Volvo plant in Dublin has added 300 new workers since the beginning of September and 900 new workers overall since the beginning of the year. As manufacturing swings upward, more trucks are needed to move goods, therefore increasing sales of big rigs like the ones produced in Dublin.
Other companies with established operations in the Ninth District are expanding, too. I have participated in these announcements. The paper and packaging company WestRock announced in September that it will be investing $248 million to upgrade its manufacturing operations in Covington and Alleghany County. WestRock’s choice to invest millions indicates a long-term commitment to its manufacturing operations in our area.
In Henry County, Monogram Foods also announced in September a $30 million expansion, which will lead to the creation of 300 new jobs. This is Monogram’s latest expansion in Henry County.
Not only are manufacturers with an existing presence here investing in and expanding their operations; companies have found our area ideal for establishing new operations. This happened in Henry County, where Press Glass, a flat glass manufacturer headquartered in Poland, will invest $43.55 million and create 212 jobs.
Press Glass saw what the other companies knew from their operations here. We have the workforce and the infrastructure a manufacturer needs to succeed.
As I visit businesses across the district, investments are being made and jobs are being created.
We also are working together at the local, state, and federal level to build on these assets for further growth. One example where this is occurring is Project Intersection in the City of Norton, a site being developed for future manufacturing operations. It is a product of regional cooperation through Norton and the Counties of Lee, Scott, Wise, and Dickenson. Federal contributions have included a $3.5 million grant through funding I secured in the Abandoned Mine Land reclamation program and $917,315 from the Appalachian Regional Commission.
Thanks to the individuals who took risks to start manufacturing goods in the United States, manufacturing helped build this country into a great economic power, and it provided many families with stable, well-paying jobs. Recent months show that by implementing better policies and leveraging the right assets, manufacturing can thrive once again, in Virginia and across the nation.
If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office.  You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405 or my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671. To reach my office via email, please visit my website at www.morgangriffith.house.gov.
###

Subject: Baldwin Announces Over $14 Million for HIV/AIDS Care and Support Services
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email


￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
As a strong supporter of increased funding for domestic HIV/AIDS programs, Senator Baldwin is pleased to announce that more than $14 million in federal grant funds have been awarded from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to improve the quality of health care and support services for Wisconsinites living with HIV/AIDS.  
These federal grants, which are part of the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program, will support Wisconsin organizations and clinics including the AIDS Resource Center of Wisconsin, the Medical College of Wisconsin, Milwaukee Health Services, Inc., Sixteenth Street Community Health Centers in Milwaukee, and the University of Wisconsin-Madison. 
“HIV/AIDS remains a public health crisis in our country and despite medical advances, people living with HIV still face significant physical, emotional, and financial burdens to quality health care,” said Senator Baldwin. “I am proud to have helped secure this funding for HIV/AIDS prevention programs and other efforts aimed at building healthier families and saving lives throughout Wisconsin.”
The Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program provides support for people living with HIV/AIDS who do not have adequate health coverage or resources to cope with the disease. Grants were awarded by Parts B, C and D of the Ryan White Program and funding will be directed to the following areas:  
	•	Part B provides funding to states to improve the quality and availability of HIV health care and for the AIDS Drug Assistance Program (ADAP)
	•	Part C directly funds community clinics and health centers that deliver quality, comprehensive HIV care to over 275,000 Americans per year
	•	Part D funds local organizations’ efforts to provide family-centered comprehensive HIV care and treatment for women, infants, children and youth
Senator Baldwin has long supported increased funding for domestic HIV/AIDS programs to improve prevention and education efforts and to help save lives. In addition to helping secure over $14 million in federal grant funds for the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program this year, Senator Baldwin introduced the HIV Clinical Services Improvement Act to ensure that our community providers have the capacity and support to deliver high-quality care to those living with HIV/AIDS. Senators Baldwin and Kirstin Gillibrand have also repeatedly lead calls for strengthening federal investments in our domestic programs to address the serious public health threat of HIV/AIDS in America.   
Read more about Senator Baldwin’s commitment to improving the quality of health care and support services for Wisconsinites living with HIV/AIDS here.

Subject: Wicker Praises the Return of Pastor Brunson to the United States
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
October 22, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | About Roger | How Can I Help You? | Newsroom | Issues | Mississippi | Visiting DC | Contact
Wicker Praises the Return of Pastor Brunson to the United States
American Had Been Unjustly Detained in Turkey for Two Years
Prayers were answered on October 12 when American pastor Andrew Brunson was released by the Turkish government.  For two years, the Christian missionary had either been jailed in a maximum security prison or placed under house arrest.  Detained on false charges, he was denied due process or legal counsel.  Like thousands of Americans, I was thrilled to see President Trump welcome him to the White House merely a day after he could return home.
Unfortunately, Pastor Brunson’s story is just one example of the rampant persecution that followed a failed military attempt to overthrow Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan two years ago.  In the aftermath, the government conducted a widespread purge of military leaders, civil servants, and others – both Turkish citizens and foreign nationals – thought to be supportive of the coup.  NASA scientist Serkan Gölge, a dual Turkish-U.S. citizen, is still imprisoned in Turkey on charges similar to those levied against Pastor Brunson, and two Turkish employees of our State Department remain jailed simply for doing their jobs to assist U.S. diplomats.
Wicker Resolution Condemns Turkey’s Religious Freedom Violations
I have followed all of these cases closely, urging President Trump to use his meetings with President Erdogan to demand justice.  My role as chairman of the U.S. Helsinki Commission involves working at an international level to promote the rule of law and human rights.  Turkey has rejected those principles with the unfounded detention of Pastor Brunson, other innocent Americans, and Turkish nationals who worked for our diplomatic mission. 
Congress, the Trump Administration, and the international community should continue to put pressure on Turkey.  It is unacceptable for Americans or other foreign nationals to be used as political hostages.
In June of this year, I introduced a bipartisan Senate resolution to support the efforts taken by the Trump Administration to protect religious liberty in Europe and Central Asia.  The resolution names Turkey as a “Special Watch List” country because of its serious violations of religious freedom.  The resolution also specifically mentions the treatment of Pastor Brunson, calling on those who are responsible for his imprisonment to be denied entry into the United States.
‘Global Magnitsky Act’ Holds Human Rights Offenders Accountable
Banning the travel of human rights violators to the United States is one of the ways the “Global Magnitsky Act” has sought to curb the abuse of human rights around the world.  The law began as an effort to hold Russian officials accountable for the imprisonment and ultimate death of Sergei Magnitsky.  The lawyer had uncovered a major tax corruption scheme involving Russian government officials.  In 2016, the “Magnitsky Act” was expanded, allowing travel bans and economic sanctions to be placed on officials in any country for human rights offenses.
I am proud to be one of the principal authors of this landmark law, and I believe in the enduring message it sends: The United States will always stand up to injustice and attacks on human dignity.  Pastor Brunson’s case illustrates the persecution that has been felt by religious minorities around the world.  His release is an encouraging development, but our work is not done.

Subject: Georgians Coming Together
Message:

Here are a few things I thought you'd like to see: 
  
1. Hurricane Michael 
  
￼ 
  
President Trump and Vice President Pence visited Middle and South Georgia this week to tour Hurricane Michael devastation and meet with farmers and producers whose crops were impacted. I joined Vice President Pence on Tuesday, and we appreciate the Trump Administration's support as we work to get our communities up and running again. 
  
Read more in The Covington News. 
  
2. Georgians Coming Together 
  
￼ 
  
Many of our communities have a long road ahead after Hurricane Michael, but it's so encouraging to see Georgians coming together during this challenging time. Georgians from across the state have donated supplies, served meals to those in need, and assisted first responders with recovery efforts. 
  
Read more here. 
  
3. World's Most Competitive Economy
  
￼ 
  
For the first time in a decade, the United States has been named the world's most competitive economy. Without a doubt, our agenda is working and delivering results. 
  
Read more at Fox Business.

October 21, 2018 
Each week, I receive thousands of letters, emails, tweets, Facebook posts, and phone calls from constituents voicing their opinions. Through my Correspondence Corner video series, I regularly respond to constituent communication on a variety of topics.
 
In today's Correspondence Corner, I answer a few questions from constituents regarding a new proposal that may limit seniors' access to needed Medicare services, and the recent murder of a journalist, apparently at Saudi hands.
 
If you have a question or comment for me, you can send an email on my website or reach out through my Facebook or Twitter. You can also follow me on Instagram here.

Subject: Schweikert Review October 21st
Message:
District Update |October 21, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
This Week In Review
 The United States economy hit a record breaking high. As reported, the U.S. is now the world's most competitive economy. This is great news for businesses and workers!  
 ￼  As the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act soon marks it's first year as law, we can reflect on each month since it was passed, and the positive climb our economy has taken. This news shows our economy is at an all time high. Most recently the House passed a Tax Reform 2.0 package that will continue to put our economy ahead of others as it will lock in the middle-class and small business tax cuts.   Let's take a moment to celebrate the good news!   
Pima Medical Institute Site Visit
￼  My team and I spent time touring Pima Medical Institute (PMI) in Phoenix. During the visit we discussed students’ medical education and training in the allied health field, along with discussing the benefits of being an employee-owned company.
Thank you to Pima’s staff for giving us a tour of the Phoenix campus. We thoroughly enjoyed visiting and learning more about the training and skills you are teaching to students.   
Constituent Spotlight
 
 ￼  My team had a very special visit with Mr. Elson and his wife. Mr. Elson is a Navy SEAL Veteran who came to us after a long process of asking the VA to provide his disability benefits, and my team aided him across the finish line! It was an honor to meet Mr. Elson and his wife and thank him for his service to our country.  If you have a Federal Agency issue that our office can help with, reach out to us!    
￼  Legislation Highlight:    The JOBS for Success Act, H.R. 5861, helps to support a partnership between the local workforce and the families who are eager to move from welfare into jobs. This bill will focus on four key changes:   - Renames the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program to Jobs and Opportunity with Benefits and Services (JOBS).   - Ensures no one gets ignored or is left on the sidelines, there are no "lost causes" or families that are "too difficult".   - Focuses on real outcomes - getting and keeping a job.  - Helps poor families, those that need these funds the most.   - Uses funds to help individuals find work by requiring at least 25% of funds go towards core activities to support individuals and families.

Subject: Check out this hometown hero
Message:
News from Congressman
￼ 

Home
About
About District
Conact
Media 


  
Newtown Resident Saves Man from Drowning
￼ 
Kristian F. Falkenstein of Newtown prevented a 32-year-old man from drowning last year in Belmar, New Jersey. After seeing a man being swept out to sea, Kristian immediately swam out to save him. When Kristian reached him, he was barely above water. 
Despite the waves and strong rip current, Kristian was able to keep him afloat for several minutes until two lifeguards and a responding police officer were able to swim out to them with flotation devices to assist until the Coast Guard arrived on the scene. Falkenstein and the victim were taken to a hospital. The man was not injured, but Falkenstein was treated for effects of near-drowning; he recovered. 
Kristian Falkenstein is nothing short of a hero. His valiant actions saved a life that day. I proudly presented him with the Carnegie Medal for his bravery. I applaud Kristian for his heroism and willingness to take on significant risk in assistance of a fellow citizen. 
Learn more about Kristian’s actions HERE. 
  
Puerto Rico Congresswoman González-Colón Visits Bucks County
￼ 
This week, I hosted my friend and colleague Rep. Jenniffer González-Colón, Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico, to discuss the federal response to Hurricane Maria with the Bucks County Puerto Rican Cultural Association in Bristol Borough. 
One year after hurricanes Irma and María devastated Puerto Rico, FEMA, its federal partners and the Government of Puerto Rico are undertaking one of the largest post-disaster reconstruction and humanitarian efforts in U.S. history. Major infrastructure projects are being undertaken as federal agencies support Puerto Rican officials to restore the island’s lifeline systems and enable Puerto Rico to withstand future weather events. 
Watch the discussion HERE. 
  

Statement on Jamal Khashoggi
As mounting evidence appears to indicate that the Government of Saudi Arabia directed the murder and dismemberment of Jamal Khashoggi, I am requesting that the Trump Administration conduct an immediate and thorough investigation to determine those responsible for this extrajudicial killing, torture, and violation of internationally recognized human rights.
Read my full statement HERE. 
  
High School Football
￼  
I was proud to attend Conwell-Egan Catholic High School's homecoming football game against Bonner-Prendergast. As an Egan grad, I'm excited to watch CEC Football continue their successful year!

Subject: Dunn Dispatch
Message:
News from Representative Dunn

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email     Click here to forward this email
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Services
About
 
NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend,  Over a week ago, the western part of the Second District was ravaged by Hurricane Michael. As we work to pick up the pieces and rebuild, I am continually amazed by the kind and giving spirit that defines Northwest Florida communities.  ￼    Since Hurricane Michael left a path of destruction, I have traveled to the counties and people who were hit the hardest. I’ve met with local leaders, law enforcement, first responders, and members of the military in counties across the district and surveyed much of the damage.  As we work to rebuild our communities, we must work together. Thank you to all who are dedicating their time to helping the Panhandle, including our law enforcement, first responders, military members, National Guard, utility workers, and volunteers.   ￼ ￼  President Trump came down to survey damage from Hurricane Michael and promote our relief efforts. He has assured me that he has our back. The Panhandle will rebuild and with the help of President Trump we will come back better than ever.  ￼  Thank you to Governor Rick Scott for working with us to advocate for Northwest Florida. Governor Scott has been on the ground with me in the affected areas and has met with hundreds of survivors in the Second District. He has worked tirelessly to ensure state resources are ready and available to the counties devastated by the hurricane.   ￼  My good friend Majority Whip Steve Scalise came down to Port St. Joe to hear from local leaders and survey damage. We helped serve hot meals to hardworking folks in the area courtesy of Drago’s Seafood. Drago’s is a Louisiana-based restaurant that traveled down to Gulf County to provide 1,000 meals to victims of Hurricane Michael. Thank you to all who have donated time and efforts to helping out those who need it most.   ￼  Another area that was hit hard by Hurricane Michael was Tyndall Air Force Base. I have spoken to President Trump, Air Force Secretary Heather Wilson, and leadership in Congress about the importance of rebuilding Tyndall Air Force Base. Tyndall is an important part of the economy in NW Florida and our national security. I am working with the Air Force and my colleagues in Congress to ensure that Tyndall is rebuilt.   It will take some time, but we will come back from this. We are hurting, but we will rebuild. My office is here to help. If you are having issues with disaster assistance or have a question about resources that are available please do not hesitate to reach out. Please call 202-225-5235 or email me through our website www.dunn.house.gov.   Below are Hurricane Michael resources available to many in the Panhandle. It is extremely important you start by applying for assistance through FEMA:   To apply for federal assistance through FEMA, visit DisasterAssistance.gov or call 1-800-621-3362.  If you’ve been displaced from your job through Hurricane Michael, there is help. The Florida Department of Economic Opportunity has created jobs that help rebuild our communities. Click here to learn more.  FEMA will also provide Disaster Unemployment Insurance to help with lost wages due to Hurricane Michael. To apply, call 1-800-621-3362 or visit www.fema.gov/disaster/4399   Operation Blue Roof is a program offered by FEMA that makes temporary repairs to homes affected by the hurricane. It is available in all counties approved for FEMA Individual Assistance. To learn more call 1-888-ROOF-BLU or visit www.usace.army.mil/BlueRoof/    Beware of fraud and scams.  ￼    Sincerely, ￼  Neal Dunn Member of Congress

￼

Home

Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you. 
Sincerely, ￼ 
Warren Davidson Member of Congress 


￼ 
Ohio Work Week
Congressman Warren Davidson is working from Ohio this week as Congress is not in Session.  
On Monday, Congressman Davidson was invited to Hamilton by a group of pastors and ministers to speak at luncheon on behalf of Clergy Appreciation Month. He then toured Safe Haven Farms in Middletown, a non-profit that provides vocational services for adults with autism. Later in the day Congressman Davidson was invited to speak to the Tristate Tooling and Manufacturing Association.
On Tuesday, Congressman Davidson was invited to attend the Ohio Defense Forum, a discussion with military and defense experts and community leaders about the integral part Ohio has in defending our country. Read Congressman Davidson's Facebook post about the Ohio Defense Forum here. He later toured the Transportation Research Center.  
On Friday, Congressman Davidson cheered the Treasury Department's proposed regulations on Opportunity Zones, a provision of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. The goal of Opportunity Zones is to attract investment for new businesses and jobs in underserved areas. Read Congressman Davidson's statement here. 
The following picture is of Congressman Davidson at the Ohio Defense Forum.  
￼ 
  
￼
Correcting an Out-of-Date Treaty
On Thursday, Congressman Davidson released a statement in support of President Trump's move to withdraw from an outdated postal treaty that gives countries like China and Singapore an unfair advantage, and floods U.S. markets with cheaper e-commerce packages. Read the statement here.

About
In the News

Friends -  
     I am honored to have received a 100% voting score from the National Right to Life, America's oldest and largest pro-life organization. 
  
￼ 
   
     As children of God, we are called to protect the most innocent, the unborn. Over the last 22 months, my office has supported and fought for pro-life legislation that includes: 
	•	H.R. 7, the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act
	•	H.R. 36, the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act
	•	H.R. 490, the Heartbeat Protection Act
	•	H.R. 4712, the Born-Alive Abortion Survivors Protection Act
     No American should ever worry that their tax dollars are being used to fund organizations that perform abortions, which is why I have also supported every effort to defund Planned Parenthood and advance pro-life protections. I will continue to support legislative efforts like this in the U.S. House of Representatives.
     As your Congressman, I am committed to transparency and open communications. Please visit my website, clayhiggins.house.gov, for all recent news from my office. It is an honor to serve you, and by extension, the Nation we all love. If there is anything that I can do to assist you, please contact my office.
 
Sincerely,

Subject: Working for PA-10
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
ABOUT
CONTACT
ISSUES
MEDIA CENTER
SERVICES
￼
October 21, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
It was a pleasure to meet with the Juniata Farm Bureau this morning and I had the honor to receive the Friend of Farm Bureau Award.
￼
A Friend of Our Farmers
The Friend of Farm Bureau Award is presented to members of Congress who have a strong record of support for a variety of key issues facing the agriculture industry. In the 115th Congress, I have fought to bring back whole milk into public schools, adequately insure our farmers, and incentivize companies to invest in broadband infrastructure on a larger scale. I appreciated hearing from the Juniata Farm Bureau about the issues that are important in our region. Pennsylvania farmers contribute so much to the Commonwealth and I am proud to stand with them. Thank you for having me!
Labor Market Sees Record Growth
The U.S. has 7.1 million job openings, a record high and another sign that the labor market is booming. Available jobs have surpassed the number of unemployed workers, making it clear that pro-growth economic policies are putting American workers first.These bold policy initiatives are not just rhetoric; their benefits are spreading throughout the country and are creating significant opportunities for Pennsylvanians.
Hearing From Our Rural Mail Carriers
I had the opportunity to sit down with our mail carriers about the future of the USPS, an iconic institution that has long been a valuable part of American life.
￼
As the son of a part-time seasonal postal worker, I know how important the USPS is for rural communities who rely on these services. That is why I proudly co-sponsored House Resolution 993, to ensure the USPS is not subject to privatization. Congress must do everything possible to ensure that the USPS can continue to provide quality service to rural areas that cannot be served by private commercial mail.
Supporting Vocational Education
On Thursday, it was great to visit the Mifflin County Academy of Science and Technology to learn more about the programs that are preparing students who are interested in pursuing a trade. Having a skilled workforce in areas such as auto repair, woodworking, welding, machining, and mechatronics is vital for running Pennsylvania’s economy. Spending decades in small business, I worked alongside many skilled workers who I believe to be the backbone of America’s producing and manufacturing power. PA-10 is defined by its hardworking families and it’s important to have institutions like Mifflin Academy to offer alternative job training to a four-year degree. Thank you for allowing me to tour your facility!
Putting Patient Care First 
I had the pleasure of attending Geisinger Health System’s open forum where members of the community exchanged views and learned what is being done to improve patient services in PA-10. Events like this highlight Geisinger’s commitment to patients and the communities they serve. As a three-time cancer survivor and the father of a daughter living with cystic fibrosis, I understand the importance of good, quality, and inexpensive health care. I will continue to support policies that increase medical development in the private industry and investments in new treatments, instruments, and procedures that can truly improve the wellbeing of patients.
New Medicare Card Mailing Update- Wave 7 Begins, Wave 5 Ends
The Center for Medicare and Medicaid has finished mailing Medicare cards to people who live in Wave 1 through 5. If you have Medicare and did not receive a new card, you can:
	•	Sign into MyMedicare.gov to see if we mailed their card. If so, they can print an official card. They will need to create an account if they do not already have one. 
	•	Call 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227) where we can verify their identity, check their address, and help them get their new card. 
You can also print out and give them a copy of Still Waiting for Your New Card?, or you can order copies to hand out. 
To ensure that people with Medicare continue to get care, you can use either the former Social Security number-based Health Insurance Claim Number (HICN) or the new alpha-numeric Medicare Beneficiary Identifier (MBI) for all Medicare transactions through December 31, 2019. 
People with Medicare should continue to protect their new number to prevent medical identity theft and health care fraud, especially during Medicare Open Enrollment. View and share our new Guard your Medicare card video, which reminds people with Medicare to beware of scams.
Investing in Pennsylvania’s Energy Economy
I’m pleased to hear that TransAlta Renewables and Microsoft have teamed up to invest in renewable energy in Pennsylvania.United States’ energy policy should strive assure a secure supply of energy, keep the costs low for consumers, and ensure the adequate protection of the environment.This partnership will bring direct investment to our state, promote job growth, and support efforts to develop a more diverse energy economy.
As Always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA
￼Share on Facebook
￼Share on Twitter
￼Share on LinkedIn
E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.*
￼ 
*By subscribing to my  e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e-mail account. 


 
 
Thank you for subscribing to my eNewsletter and please remember to forward this to your friends!  This is a great way for me to communicate directly with you about what's going on in Washington, as well as providing you with exciting news from Pennsylvania's 10th District.  My Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube accounts are also excellent tools for you to share your thoughts with me and get up-to-the-minute news about what's happening.
As always, my staff and I are ready and willing to assist you.  If you would like to schedule a meeting, request a tour or flag, voice an opinion, or make a suggestion please contact my Washington, D.C. office.
If you need assistance working with a federal agency or applying for a grant please contact one of my Constituent Service Centers, located throughout the district.
I am here to serve you and represent your views, as a resident of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District.

Subject: Rep. Lynn Jenkins Weekly Update: Visit to Benedictine College, Bilateral Trade Update, & More!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
HOME 
CONTACT US 
CONSTITUENT SERVICES 
ISSUES AND LEGISLATION 
October 21, 2018 
Visit to Benedictine College’s American Government Class:
Thank you to Benedictine College for inviting me to speak to Dr. Raymond’s American Government class! I enjoyed the chance to share my experiences in Congress with these aspiring leaders and answering their great questions. I have been blessed to have others pass on their knowledge to me, so I am grateful for the opportunity to pass on what I’ve learned to a new generation of leaders.
￼
 
Bilateral Trade Update:
On Tuesday, the United States Trade Representative officially notified Congress in letters to the House and Senate of the Administration’s intent to enter into three different trade negotiations with Japan, the European Union, and the United Kingdom. These announcements are welcomed developments that, following further consultation with Congress, can greatly expand new markets and unlock these massive economies in which to sell Kansas-grown and Kansas-made products.
Following an agreement last month with Canada and Mexico on a new NAFTA, I am pleased the Administration has progressed to this stage to deepen our international trading partnerships with these key allies across the Atlantic and the Pacific.
 
ICYMI: NAFTA Agreement:
The United States, Mexico, and Canada have recently announced that an agreement has been reached to update NAFTA. News of an agreement is welcomed as NAFTA has been an overwhelming success for Kansas agriculture. As Congress and the public analyze the full agreement text, I look forward to fully reviewing the details and hearing from farm, ranch, and working families across my district about their thoughts on the agreement.
 
Ways and Means Investigation on Maternal Mortality Rates in the U.S.:
Recent investigations have revealed that an alarming number of mothers in the United States are dying during and after childbirth. Every year in the United States more than 50,000 mothers are severely injured during or after childbirth. In fact, maternal mortality review committees from nine states found that approximately 63 percent of pregnancy-related deaths were preventable. Bringing a new baby into this world should be one of the most exciting and rewarding times in a woman’s life. It is absolutely unacceptable to sit idly by when we can prevent these tragic deaths.
As Chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Oversight, I sent letters to 15 major hospital systems around the country to explain why the mother mortality rate during childbirth is on the rise. The letters ask these hospital systems to detail the steps they are taking to identify risks and complications in pregnancies and to answer questions on their childbirth safety protocols. I hope we can find out why these deaths are happening and how Congress can act to stem this tragic loss of life.

Subject: BUILD THE WALL
Message:
News from Representative Bradley Byrne
  
￼
ABOUT BRADLEY | HOW CAN I HELP | CONTACT BRADLEY | WANT TO RECEIVE MY UPDATES?
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
If you had any doubt about why border security is important, just look at the caravan of illegal immigrants heading toward the United States. We must secure our borders! 
Border security is national security. Having a secure border is absolutely necessary if we want to cut down on crime and keep potential terrorists and bad actors out of our country. 
I’ve got a solution that would allow us to overcome Democrat obstruction in the Senate to secure funding for the border wall. We should use budget reconciliation, the same process we used to pass tax reform.  
That is why I am introducing the 50 Votes for the Wall Act. I explain the process in this op-ed for The Hill. Securing our border is securing the integrity of the United States for future generations, and I am committed to the fight.
ICYMI: Upcoming Town Hall Meetings 
￼ 
In case you missed it, I will be holding town hall meetings across Southwest Alabama over the next few weeks. I would love to see you out at the meetings in Lillian, Saraland, and Bayou La Batre. I look forward to hearing what issues matter most to you. Details on all the town hall meetings can be found by clicking here. 
An Update from Washington 
￼ 
October is a busy time here in Alabama. With college football, Homecomings, and visiting the citizens of Alabama to hear about the issues that matter most to you. On Tuesday, I traveled up to Montgomery to speak to the Montgomery Chamber of Commerce’s “Eggs and Issues” breakfast. I shared an update on the House agenda and our efforts to ensure all Americans are "Better Off Now." 
This past Friday, I had the opportunity to discuss how Alabamians are better off now with members of the Fairhope Kiwanis Club. I’m always happy to provide an update on how the People’s House has been working for those of us right here along the Gulf Coast.
In such divisive times, it is important to be optimistic about the course of our country and of Alabama. Southwest Alabama is growing and thriving like never before, and our pro-growth policies are a big reason behind that. 
It is an honor to be at the helm of rebuilding our military, free-trade issues, tax reform, and an endless list of vitally important topics. And, it is an honor to serve Alabama in Washington.
Recovery Reminders 
Hurricane Michael was truly a devastating storm. Folks in the Wiregrass region and the Florida Panhandle have been impacted financially, physically, and emotionally.
I wanted to remind you of the recovery options and available to you through the federal and state governments.  
For general information on how to receive assistance, please visit MichaelRecoveryInfo.com. Click here to apply online for federal disaster assistance, here for information from the Alabama Emergency Management Agency, and here for disaster relief and recovery services from the American Red Cross including information on contacting missing loved ones.  
I send my deepest sympathies to all those impacted, and continue to pray for a speedy recovery for all those impacted by the storm. 
Republican Policies Work 
￼ 
Too often the media focuses on the negative side of politics in Washington and on the partisan fighting that dominates the news cycle. Rarely do they celebrate the major accomplishments or acts of bipartisan cooperation that goes on every day in our nation’s capital. 
In the past two years, the House of Representatives has passed over 1,000 bills, roughly 80% of them through bipartisan cooperation. We have strengthened our military, worked to prepare our workforce for the future, and provided funding for vital infrastructure projects.  
Our unemployment rate is at the lowest levels in nearly fifty years, job openings are at an all-time high, and our nation’s economy is once again the most competitive in the world. There is still work to be done, though. We must find a way to overcome obstruction and advance solutions that work best for all Americans. The American people want results, not resistance.
Thanks to conservative policies, our nation truly is better off now and stronger for the future.  
In Case You Missed It!   
Here are a few articles from this past week that are worth a read:  
“Another great sign for the economy: Job openings hit an all-time high in August.” –  CNBC 
“U.S. Is World’s Most Competitive Economy for First Time in a Decade.” – Wall Street Journal  
“Budget reconciliation is the key to building the border wall.” – The Hill   
“Water infrastructure is vital for state.” - Atmore Advance 
“Bradley Byrne strikes optimistic tone in Montgomery Chamber of Commerce speech. - Yellowhammer News 
"Mobile couple rescues people from burning building while on vacation" - WKRG 
“Bradley Byrne: Water infrastructure vital to Alabama’s economy.” - Alabama Today 
Photo of the Week 
￼ 
 It was an honor to serve as an honorary captain and toss the coin at Friday night's Robertsdale vs.  Baldwin County High School football game. 
What’s Ahead  
As we continue to move through the month of October, I always enjoy getting out to catch up with folks in Southwest Alabama and update them on what we are doing in Washington. Again, I will be holding several town halls throughout the rest of this month, starting with Lillian on Monday, October 22nd, at 11:30 AM.
I will also be hosting my annual Ag Matters tour this week. This tour allows me to visit farms and family forests in all six counties that make up the First Congressional District. I look forward to making stops this year in Jackson, Chatom, Grand Bay, Fairhope,  Monroeville, and Atmore.
As always, if you need help with a federal agency or have questions about anything under debate in Washington, please contact my office. You can call my Mobile office at 251-690-2811 or you can click here to send me an email directly. I also invite you to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to get up-to-the-minute updates on my travel in Southwest Alabama. At the end of the day, my staff and I are here to serve you! 
Stay in touch, 
￼
Congressman Bradley Byrne

Subject: Yearly Roundup
Message:
District Update | October 21, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friends, 
These past ten months have been filled with productive visits with Arkansas families, farmers, teachers, students, veterans, community leaders, and so much more. I'm grateful to represent you in Congress and to be your voice. Here are some of this year's highlights so far. 
January 
￼
It was National School Choice Week, January 20-26, 2018, when I toured Maumelle's Academics Plus Charter School. I had recently returned from Egypt and was glad to share my experiences there with the sixth graders who were studying Ancient Egypt. We discussed strategies for concurrent credit and how to best prepare students for college. I was impressed by the students and their eagerness to learn. 

February
￼
In February, I held the third meeting of the 2017-18 Class of my Future Leaders Council. They were an inspiring group of young Arkansas leaders. I enjoyed talking with them about how a bill is formed and how it goes through the committee process. Our future is in good hands! 

March
￼
In March, Senator John Boozman and I showed U.S. Air Force (USAF) Secretary Heather Wilson around Little Rock Air Force Base (LRAFB). We met with the airwomen and airmen serving our nation and several sites around the airbase, including the Sensitive Compartmentalized Information Facility (SCIF) building. There, we discussed their current training mission and how we can assist the National Guard and the USAF in obtaining more missions. We are grateful for Secretary Wilson’s sustained interest in LRAFB.

April
￼
In April, I visited Del Rio, Texas, where I met with border patrol agents, and state and local officials, including the Val Verde County judge and sheriff, Joe Martinez (pictured above). This was my fourth visit to our southern border with Mexico, and I continue to build my understanding of the strategic challenges we face and what the House can do to deliver on our promise to better secure our borders and protect our families. 

May
￼
A young Syrian girl in a refugee camp holding a note that I wrote in the Holocaust Museum, encouraging the Syrian people to remain resilient.
 
In May, I had the privilege of visiting the Syria exhibit at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C. This exhibit is dedicated to highlighting the vicious attacks against the people of Syria by its leader, Bashar al-Assad. By regaining control of the land occupied by real or perceived threats to the tyranny perpetrated by the Syrian government and sowing seeds of discord amongst the rebels to encourage more violence and bloodshed, he has become the embodiment of everything in opposition to democracy. I want to thank a Syrian-American and Arkansan, Mouaz Moustafa, for personally showing me this exhibit and for his leadership at the Syrian Emergency Task Force.

June
￼
In June. I hosted Dr. Carla Hayden, the Librarian of Congress and America’s Librarian, to central Arkansas. Dr. Hayden was joined by her mother, Colleen, who was born in Helena. We kicked off her time in Arkansas by visiting with Governor Asa Hutchinson. We visited educational and historic sites together, such as our stops at the William F. Laman Public Library in Little Rock and the Historic Arkansas Museum. We also hosted more than 100 librarians and educators from across the state for lunch at the Clinton Library. National and local libraries play such an important role in our communities, helping to educate the next generation of leaders, and I am glad that Dr. Hayden got to see Arkansas’s terrific work in action.  

July 
￼
On the Fourth of July, it was an honor to read the Declaration of Independence at the Historic Arkansas Museum. It's always a pleasure to visit with old friends and to make new ones.

August
￼
In August, I had the opportunity to serve our homeless community breakfast in Little Rock at the Salvation Army of central Arkansas and Jericho Way. So far this year, my team has conducted 35 visits to six centers to hear directly from central Arkansans on how we can better assist and best provide services to the homeless. 

September
￼
Pictured: Top picture (left to right): Lambert Marshall (Bearskin Farm), Congressman Hill, Lauren Ward (Arkansas Rice Federation), and Lynn Marshall (owner, Bearskin Farm). Bottom picture (left to right): Josh Hankins (Arkansas Rice Federation), Congressman Hill, Lauren Ward, and Mark Isbell (owner, Isbell Farms).  

Harvest season is a special time in our state, and I appreciated Bearskin Farm and Isbell Farms for the ring-side view of their rice harvests, which is crucial to our economy. I'm thankful to the Arkansas Rice Federation for coordinating these visits. Our Arkansas farmers continue to utilize innovative technologies and produce the best rice in the world as they maintain a competitive advantage as the nation's largest rice producing state. 

October
￼
With my good friend, UK Member of Parliament Rehman Chishti visiting, I held the 20th meeting of my Veterans Advisory Council in Beebe earlier this month. It was an honor to visit with the men and women of White County who have served our country and talk with them about their needs and how my office can help them access the benefits they've rightfully earned. I value the experiences our Arkansas veterans share with me as I continue fighting for them in Congress. 

Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I'm doing on your behalf. If I can be any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at (501) 324-5941 or Hill.House.Gov. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Representative French Hill

Subject: Putting the pieces back together after Hurricane Michael
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
This past week was a big week for Georgia as President Trump, Vice President Pence, Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue, and countless other local, state, and federal officials were in Middle and South Georgia to show their support and reaffirm their commitment to those in our rural communities impacted by Hurricane Michael.
I must say, it was very disappointing how the press treated the President’s visit this past Monday. Farmers have lost orchards that families have owned for generations, cotton growers are not sure what tomorrow brings, and all the press asks about is a U.S. Senator's DNA and global warming. I want to thank President Trump for rising above and keeping the focus of the day on what matters: those impacted by this catastrophic storm.
￼ 
President Trump meets workers at the American Red Cross in Macon. 
On Wednesday this past week, Vice President Pence stopped in Moultrie to speak to farmers to affirm the Administration's support of our rural communities. Click here to watch Vice President Mike Pence’s remarks at the Sunbelt Ag Expo in Moultrie. 
￼ 
Vice President Pence speaks at the Sunbelt Ag Expo. 
As we assess damages, I am continuing to meet with farmers, families, and business owners throughout the Eighth District to see how we on the federal level can better provide resources to help recover and rebuild. In the meantime, I wanted to share some additional resources that may be helpful for those impacted: 
	•	For information on USDA disaster assistance programs, CLICK HERE.
	•	Residents and business owners in designated counties can begin applying for federal assistance online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov or by calling 1-800-621-FEMA.
	•	For information on each county’s specific State of Emergency County Contacts, and other helpful state resources, please visit the Georgia Emergency Management & Homeland Security Agency (GEMA/HS) website here: http://www.gema.ga.gov/. 
 ￼ 
Congressman Sanford Bishop (GA-02) and I receive a briefing at the American Red Cross in Macon. 
￼ 
Meeting with farmers to discuss ways we can better help recover from the impacts of Hurricane Michael. 
 
ASSISTANCE FOR MEDICARE PART D ENROLLEES 
Staff in our Tifton and Warner Robins district offices are currently accepting appointment requests to answer questions and to speak with constituents to discuss their Medicare Part D options during open enrollment, which runs through December 7, 2018.
We encourage anyone already enrolled for Medicare Part D to call either our Tifton office at 229-396-5175 or Warner Robins office at 478-971-1776 for assistance or to schedule an appointment with a member of our staff.  We are happy to work with you individually to find the prescription drug plan that is best for your needs.
To find out more about Medicare Part D, you may also contact the Medicare offices at 1-800-MEDICARE or visit http://www.MEDICARE.gov or contact GeorgiaCares at 1-866-552-4464 to find a plan that best suits your needs.
￼ 
The only time to make changes to your plan is during open enrollment. 
  
MONROE COUNTY CATTLEMAN NAMED 2018 GEORGIA FARMER OF THE YEAR 
On Tuesday, October 16th, James Vaughn of Forsyth, was honored as the 2018 Georgia Farmer of the Year at the Sunbelt Ag Expo in Moultrie, Georgia. Mr.Vaughn is an innovative farmer and a great advocate for the agriculture industry and Middle Georgia. Using best practices tools and diversification, he took 500 acres and grew it tenfold using the greatest practices available across all of his farm operation. 
Not only is he producing high-quality commodities, but Mr. Vaughn is a beacon of hope for family farming operations for generations to come. 
Click here for more information on the Sunbelt Ag Expo and Mr. James Vaughn.  
  
HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
October 21, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


Welcome Home Pastor Brunson



On Saturday, I was honored to join President Trump in the Oval Office of the White House to welcome Pastor Andrew Brunson home. Pastor Brunson, who is originally from Black Mountain, North Carolina, was imprisoned in Turkey on October 7, 2016. On Friday, over two years later, Pastor Brunson was released and finally reunited with his family here in the United States.

￼
Official White House Photo By Jodie Steck.

￼
Official White House Photo By Jodie Steck.

￼
Official White House Photo by Shealah Craighead.

In May, a bipartisan group of 154 Representatives joined Congressman David Price and me in sending a letter denouncing the wrongful imprisonment of Pastor Brunson. You can read the letter by clicking here. I also called for the release of Pastor Brunson in a June speech on the House Floor, which you can click here to watch. You can also read my full statement on the release of Pastor Brunson here.






Cutting Bureaucratic Red Tape



Since President Trump took office, his Administration’s regulatory reform efforts have helped save our country $23 billion. I am proud to have supported President Trump’s efforts so we can fulfill our promise to reduce bureaucratic red tape that wastes taxpayer dollars and negatively impacts the lives of hardworking Americans. You can learn more about these efforts in the graphic below courtesy of the White House. 

     ￼





Hurricane Florence



It has been one month since Hurricane Florence caused so much damage and suffering to our neighbors in eastern North Carolina. I am thankful for all of our emergency responders and their tireless effort to save lives last month and those working hard to help rebuild and support those impacted by this deadly storm. Check out this graphic for a great by-the-numbers look at the federal response in NC thus far courtesy of FEMA. I’m proud to have played a part in ensuring this federal aid is provided through my votes to provide the Carolinas with over $10 billion in aid. You can learn more about those efforts here. 

￼





What I Have Been Reading



Funeral plans announced for NC trooper who was fatally shot during traffic stop

Charlotte Observer 

My prayers are with Trooper Kevin Conner's family and his fellow North Carolina State Highway Patrol troopers as they mourn his passing. This is a tragic reminder of the sacrifices our law enforcement officers make to keep our communities safe. I am thankful each day for everything they do.


US regains title of world's most competitive economy

Fox Business 

We've heard nothing but good news about our economy this month. This week, the World Economic Forum announced that, for the first time in ten years, the United States has regained the title of the world's most competitive economy. Earlier this month, the Department of Labor announced U.S. unemployment had hit its lowest level in almost fifty years. The Department of Labor also announced that job openings hit an all time high in August so it is no surprise consumers and small businesses are more and more optimistic about the future of our country. 

￼

Subject: The Great Commission
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends, 
 
As part of the Great Commission in the Bible, Jesus tells us in Matthew 28:19-20, “Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you. And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age.”
 
These powerful verses remind me of Pastor Andrew Brunson, a North Carolina native who was wrongfully arrested and imprisoned in Turkey. Pastor Brunson was living in Turkey with his family for more than two decades and led a small congregation with his wife, Norine. They made it their mission to share the gospel of Jesus Christ.
 
Unfortunately in 2016, Pastor Brunson was falsely accused of terror-related crimes and arrested, where he faced up to 35 years in prison. After two years of imprisonment and a stressful trial, Pastor Brunson was convicted and sentenced to time served. The world watched as Pastor Brunson languished in a Turkish prison for two years.
 
As I prayed for the safety and release of Pastor Brunson, time and again I came back to the verse, “And surely I am with you always, to the very end of the age.” Pastor Brunson said he was always sure God had a plan to end his suffering, and his recent release was truly an answer to so many prayers. 
 
It was also the result of a lot of people, including myself and Senator Thom Tillis, other North Carolina members of Congress, and President Donald Trump, who were working hard to get his release.
 
As your Congressman and someone who always tries to stand up for religious liberty, I made sure I did everything in my power to ensure Pastor Brunson’s safe release back to the United States. In July at an international summit of leaders from 57 nations, I represented the United States and put forward a human rights resolution urging the release of Pastor Brunson. I was proud to see my amendment adopted and to send a strong message to Turkey: the world will not tolerate these human rights violations – especially by a NATO ally and partner – and Pastor Brunson must be set free.
 
This was significant progress, but I know Pastor Brunson would not have been released without the hard work of President Trump. He went above and beyond to put economic and political pressure on Turkey in an effort to secure Pastor Brunson’s release.
 
With that said, I still have concerns about the troubling pattern of human rights abuses and ongoing religious persecution by Turkish authorities. The current regime led by President Erdogan is continuing to consolidate power at the cost of human rights. While President Trump has done an outstanding job projecting American leadership on the world stage, we must continue to demand better from our NATO partners.
 
One of the most inspiring moments of this ordeal was seeing Pastor Brunson kneel in prayer with President Trump in the Oval Office. There you had a humble preacher from North Carolina praying with the leader of the free world – it was a remarkable moment and one I will never forget. 
 
 
Until next week,
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress (NC-08)

Subject: All Around SC-07
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
Law Enforcement Appreciation
 
 
It was an honor to attend the Marion County and Dillon County law enforcement appreciation dinner. We had a moment of silence in memory of Sergeant Carraway and prayed for the entire Florence Police Department together. I also thanked them for their life saving work during Hurricane Florence- it was a testament to what they wake up ready to do for us every single day. This was just a small way to say thank you and show our support for our brave men and women in uniform. 
 

￼
 
 
Creating Opportunity Through Infrastructure Investment 
 
 
Improving and expanding infrastructure in South Carolina is one of my top priorities, which is why I helped create the National Advisory Committee on Travel and Tourism Infrastructure (NACTTI). The purpose of this committee is to provide information and recommendations to the Secretary of Transportation on critical infrastructure projects that will facilitate expedient travel, increase tourism, and create opportunity and economic development. We held a NACTII meeting this week to discuss how I-73 will meet all three of these requirements! I showed them the awful traffic congestion on Highway 501 and explained how I-73 will create unprecedented opportunity in the Pee Dee. I look forward to continued work with NACTII to create opportunity through infrastructure investment in South Carolina and throughout the country. 
 

￼
 
 
Beach Renourishment Progress
 
 
Ensuring the prosperity of our beaches is critical to growing our tourism economy and I am proud that my office was able to secure over $80 million dollars for this vital project. This week, I met with members of the Army Corps of Engineers to check on the progress of beachfront renourishment and learn more about the process. 
 

￼
 
 
Preparing our Workforce 
 
 
I had a productive meeting with Florence Darlington Technical College President Ed Bethea this week. FDTC offers specialized training that enables people to get high-paying, skills-based jobs upon graduating. Getting people off of the sidelines of the economy and into the workforce is one of my top priorities and I look forward to working with President Bethea to bridge the skills gap and prepare the Seventh District workforce for new opportunity!
 

￼
 
 
FEMA Updates and Resources
 
 
As our community continues to recover from Hurricane Florence, below are some updates and resources that might be useful to you and your family. 

Mobile Disaster Recovery Center in Horry: Mobile Disaster Recovery Centers will be around Horry County over the next three weeks. The unit will offer in-person support to homeowners, renters and business owners who sustained loss or damage from Hurricane Florence, including recovery specialists from FEMA and the U.S. Small Business Administration. Click here for MRDC times and locations. 

Help with Home Repairs: FEMA mitigation specialists will visit six home improvement stores in Horry and Marlboro counties over the next two weeks to offer advice on how to repair and rebuild structures to be safer and stronger. The mitigation specialists will be on hand to answer questions and provide home improvement tips and information on building structures that are more hazard-resistant, with proven methods that can prevent or reduce damage from future disasters. Click here for times and locations. 
Preserving Family Heirlooms: The Smithsonian will be at the below Disaster Recovery Centers to help families preserve any precious heirlooms that were damaged in Hurricane Florence.
	•	Team 1: Tues., Oct. 23 – Thurs., 25: DRC 1 (Conway, Horry County) Hours: 11:00 am - 6:00 pm
	•	Team 2: Tues., Oct. 23 – Wed., Oct. 24: DRC 2 (Dillon, Dillon County) Hours: 1000 to 1700 Thurs., Oct. 25; DRC 4 (Marion, Marion County) Hours: 10 a.m. - 5 p.m.
	•	Team 3: Tues., Oct. 30 – Wed., Oct. 31: DRC 3 (Cheraw, Chesterfield County); Hours: 1000 thru 1700 Thurs., Nov. 1 - DRC 5 (Bennettsville, Marlboro County) DRC 5: Hours: 10:00 am to 5:00 pm
 

Have a great week,
￼
 Tom Rice

Subject: Big News for Chambers County and More
Message:
Babin Bulletin | October 21, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Rep. Babin and Judge Sylvia Announce De-obligation of Chambers County Hurricane Ike Cleanup Debt

WASHINGTON — U.S. Rep. Brian Babin (TX-36) and the Honorable Judge Jimmy Sylvia, Chambers County Judge, released the following joint statement announcing millions of dollars of Hurricane Ike cleanup debt erroneously charged to Chambers County will be de-obligated. An amendment introduced and passed by Babin to this year’s Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) reauthorization bill, now signed into law by President Trump, holds FEMA responsible for assurances offered and later rescinded to county governments after expenditures had taken place. The debt Chambers County acquired during Ike cleanup efforts based on faulty information by FEMA falls under the definition stipulated by the Babin amendment, and therefore essentially will be canceled out.

￼
“This is a great day for residents of Chambers County,” said Rep. Babin. “The process initiated by today’s letter is the culmination of years of hard work that will ensure FEMA takes responsibility for their assurances made to county officials in the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Ike and the federally-declared disaster left in its wake. With this debt de-obligated, Chambers County can once again operate in service of its citizens without the fear of imminent financial calamity. Thank you to my colleagues Senators Cruz and Cornyn, Judge Sylvia, and so many others whose efforts have ensured the county can put this behind them and continue focusing on prosperity for the county.”

“I'm extremely happy to announce that the $9 million in de-obligated FEMA funds looming over Chambers County since Hurricane Ike have been eliminated,” said Judge Sylvia. “Thanks to the diligence of Congressman Babin and assistance from Senators Cornyn and Cruz, H.R. 302 (specifically section 1237 pertaining to de-obligated funds by FEMA) was signed by President Trump on October 5, 2018. 

To read my full press release, click here.
Visiting Cleveland's SkillsUSA Class
 A couple of months ago, a group of students from Cleveland ISD visited Washington, D.C. with SkillsUSA. Unfortunately, we did not get the opportunity to visit while they were on Capitol Hill due to scheduling conflicts. At the end of the week, my wife and I were boarding a plane back to Texas, when a woman sitting with a group of high school-aged teens recognized me. It was Ms. Andi Pope and her SkillsUSA class from Cleveland. We were all on the same flight! 

After we landed in Houston, I had the opportunity to speak with all of the students about what they had been learning, plus give them an update on what being a Member of Congress encompasses. At that time, they invited me to have lunch at Tonkawa Bistro, the on-campus student-run restaurant by their Culinary Arts Department. If you are unaware about SkillsUSA, it is an organization that partners with students, teachers, and industry to ensure that each student has the skills to go into the American workforce. They offer different career and technical educational programs, events, and competitions in high schools across the country. (Pictured below from L to R: Tarik Barnes, Andi Pope (teacher), Jose Arguelles (student General Manager of Tonkawa Bistro), and Makina Walden).
￼
On Monday, I was able to visit Tonkawa Bistro and enjoy a delicious lunch prepared by some of the most ambitious and intelligent students.
￼
Babin: Trump Correct to Use American Leverage to Halt Migrant Caravans
President Trump is absolutely correct to call for Central American governments to cooperate in halting migrant caravans or else risk losing their generous financial aid from the United States. These nations must secure their own borders and stop allowing – and even encouraging – their citizens to illegally cross our sovereign borders. I applaud President Trump for his boldness in acting to protect the interests of American citizens by using our extensive leverage on the international stage.

To read my full press release, click here.

County Judges' Lunch
￼

It was a very informative lunch as I had the opportunity to meet with many of the county judges' across TX-36. It's important for me to know the issues each of our counties are facing as well as figuring out what we can all work together on - federally and locally. 

￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Trinity Valley Exposition
￼
The fairgrounds in Liberty were busy this week as students unloaded their heifers, steers, pigs, goats, and lambs to show and sell at the Trinity Valley Exposition (TVE) Fair and Rodeo. It was great getting to see the hard work these students have put into their animals.
￼
 It seemed like the whole community of Liberty County gathered together to take part in such a fun time of the year. 
Appreciating Our Law Enforcement
 On Tuesday evening, I attended the annual Tyler County Law Enforcement Appreciation Banquet in Warren, where I was able to visit with many of our local law enforcement officers. It’s a privilege getting a chance to thank these brave men and women for always being the first on the scene of a crime or accident and keeping our communities safe and protected. We should never forget that they are members of our community too and thank them for their service.
￼
JSW Steel Breaks New Ground
 JSW Steel in Baytown has officially broken ground on the only melt and manufacture plate mill with a contiguous pipe mill in North America. It was a pleasure to be able to speak at such an awesome occasion. 
￼
JSW Steel USA is also working to hire 1,000 new employees while investing up to $1 billion to modernize and expand its U.S. operations. That's more jobs for Texans and the country as well as more money being invested into America's economy!
 Texas Emergency Hospital
 On Monday, I was given a tour of the newly opened and remodeled Texas Emergency Hospital in Cleveland. I am proud of this facility and the emergency care it gives to the community.
￼
The Barbers Hill Eagles Take On The Vidor Pirates
 Friday night unveiled another outstanding football game in East Texas. Both teams fought so hard, and it was an outstanding match-up of skill and perseverance. Congratulations to each team for an excellent game.
￼
La Porte Roundtable
I was able to meet with several of the local business owners in La Porte this week. Small businesses are one of the primary reasons why Texas is at the top of the list of the most economically sound states in the country. Making sure these businesses have the resources they need to grow and succeed is one of my top priorities. 
￼

Subject: Walker Weekly Report: October 21, 2018
Message:
￼
Walker Weekly Report
￼
This might be a boring chart, but it contains phenomenal news. We are dedicated to helping all of our people prosper and find opportunity. Thanks to our reforms, women, those with disabilities and all of our diverse communities have record low unemployment.
This week, we saw North Carolina announce the lowest state unemployment rate in 18 years, a new national record for job openings with more than 7 million, and the announcement of 380 new jobs and a $35 million investment in Person County. We also met with hundreds of constituents, visiting with North Carolinians in all eight counties of our district.
Keep reading for the full update. Have a blessed week.
Sincerely, ￼ Mark Walker
￼
HIGHLIGHTS
￼
Outdoor Furniture Maker Polywood Investing $35 Million in Person County and Creating 380 New Jobs
On the same day we learned that our economy has hit a record 7.136 million job openings, even more opportunities were being created in our community. I was pleased to be in Timberlake celebrating the creation of 380 new jobs and $35 million being invested in Person County. Polywood knows what so many other companies have learned, our economy and our manufacturing sector is roaring back, and North Carolina is leading the way.
The news from Pollywood follows Tuesday's report that "job openings hit an all time high in August."
Learn More
￼
Listening to Hundreds of Constituents: Visiting All 8 Counties in the 6th District in One Week
In seven days, we have visited with hundreds of North Carolinians across all eight of our counties in the 6th congressional district – Alamance, Caswell, Chatham, Guilford, Lee, Person, Randolph and Rockingham. 
From meeting with JDRF Triad to discuss Type 1 diabetes and how we can give patients more options, lower costs, and find a cure, to celebrating the new facilities for the North Eastern Alamance Fire Department, we are always blessed to have so many opportunities to build and strengthen our relationships in the community. 
Learn More
￼
Early Voting Continues in North Carolina Tomorrow
As the November 6th Election Day approaches, please be aware that early voting in North Carolina begins on October 17th and continues through November 3rd.
Early voting is an easy and convenient way to avoid long lines on Election Day. Find the early voting locations in your county at the North Carolina State Board of Elections website here.
Find Your Voting Location

Friend: 
It's been another very productive work session in Southern Illinois this week. This week I want to focus on Tuesday night, where I continued my long-standing tradition of greeting Honor Flight veterans either in Washington or right here in Southern Illinois. Americans owe a debt of gratitude to our nation's bravest individuals, those who have served in defense of freedom and liberty. My wife Tracy and I welcomed these fine men and women home and had the opportunity to chat with them about their brave journey's and what we can do to help ensure their needs are being met in Washington. We were joined by over 3,000 family and friends of our Southern Illinois veterans. If you know a veteran in Southern Illinois who would be interested in the Honor Flight program, please share this info: https://www.veteranshonorflight.org/

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
Friends,
In case you missed it, according to the World Economic Forum's Competitiveness Report, the U.S. is the most competitive economy in the world for the first time since 2008. We all know our economy is continuing to get stronger and stronger, thanks in part to the pro-growth policies my colleagues and I have passed in Congress. 
￼
Type 1 Diabetes Research 
It was great to see my friend Tyler from Mayfield Heights, a young advocate for JDRF, the leading global funder of type 1 diabetes research. As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I have strongly supported funding for the National Institutes of Health's Special Diabetes Program to award grants for research into the prevention and cure for type 1 diabetes. 
In support of people with type 1 diabetes, I also recently signed a letter calling on the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to continue to find pathways for type 1 diabetes patients to access new diabetes technologies. These technologies would help people with type 1 diabetes better manage their disease and avoid costly complications. 
￼
Brecksville-Broadview Heights Middle School 
Congratulations to Brecksville-Broadview Heights Middle School for being recognized as a National Blue Ribbon School for 2018! I'm proud to have such an example of academic excellence in Northeast Ohio. The students, teachers, and staff are doing a fantastic job!
This week, I presented a congressional proclamation and a flag that was flown over the U.S. Capitol celebrating this achievement to the Brecksville-Broadview Heights school board. 
Feel free to check out my remarks in the Congressional Record. 
￼
Akron-Canton Airport 
I was happy to meet Ren Camacho, the new President of Akron-Canton Airport (CAK). He's got some big shoes to fill with Rick McQueen's departure after more than 36 years at CAK. However, after serving as the chief of planning and engineering for Cleveland's Department of Port Control, and overseeing the Cleveland Hopkins-International Airport, Burke Lakefront Airport and the Lakefront Harbors, I'm certain Ren is the man for the job.
My colleagues and I recently passed legislation to reform and reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). The FAA employs about 46,000 people and is responsible for the safety and efficiency of our nation's aerospace system, including air traffic control operations. This 5-year reauthorization of FAA programs invests in airport infrastructure, promotes safety and American leadership in aviation, and strengthens consumer service. I was happy to share this great news with both Ren and Rick at CAK. 
￼
Brecksville Chamber Networking Lunch
On Tuesday, I was honored to attend the Brecksville Chamber of Commerce's October Networking Lunch with community leaders from the area. I spoke about the recently passed opioid package, the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative, and how I work with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle. Thank you to the Brecksville Chamber for all the hard work you do for our district. I hope to see you all again soon!
￼
Convenience Store Visit
I had a great time Monday morning at the Sheetz in Mentor. I was happy to discuss menu labeling, data security, the Renewable Fuel Standard and other issues impacting the hard-working folks at this family owned and operated company that's been serving Northeast Ohio for decades. Thank you to Adam Sheetz for the invitation!
￼
￼
Bryant & Stratton College 
Also on Monday, I enjoyed spending time with the Solon Chamber of Commerce, Solon Mayor Ed Kraus, Solon City Council members and others at the Bryant & Stratton College campus in Solon. 
￼
It was a wonderful and busy week in Northeast Ohio. I enjoyed spending time with talented educators, officials, and business men and women who work hard for our communities every day. 
Dave
