News from Congresswoman Claudia Tenney
￼

Home
About District
News
Contact

Tenney Receives Friend of Farm Bureau Award Recognized as Advocate for Family Farmers
Farms are the lifeblood of our local economy and a vital part of our upstate heritage. In New York, our dairy farmers have experienced severe hardships. Since my first day as a member of Congress, it’s been my top priority to fix this serious problem jeopardizing the survival of the great tradition of family farming. I’ve fought and helped enact real solutions to ensure our agricultural community can grow and prosper once again. I’ve listened to the problems facing our farmers and been their voice in Washington, fighting for real change and delivering on our promises. It is a distinct honor to be recognized by the Farm Bureau for our office’s work and strong advocacy for upstate farmers in Congress.
In Congress, our office has delivered on promises made to our farmers in the 22nd District. 
I led the charge against the negative impact of the Canadian Class 7 milk pricing scheme which was eliminated as part of the new United States, Mexico, Canada Agreement (USMCA). I also was a co-sponsor of the School Milk Nutrition Act which allows schools to offer low-fat (1%) milk to students rather than just fat-free and the WHOLE MILK Act which would allow schools to offer whole milk as an option to students. 
In addition, I have held round tables with local farmers in five counties through the district and brought the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue to NY-22 to listen to the needs of local farmers.   
For more information about the American Farm Bureau Federation (AFBF), please visit: https://www.fb.org/. 
Assistance With Grants and Letters of Support 
Whether you’re a fire department in need of new equipment or a community organization looking to grow, our office can assist you in navigating the federal grant process. By working with the Congressional Research Service, we can help find grants that may be appropriate for your needs. In many cases, we may even be able to furnish you with a letter of support. To find out how we can assist you in the grant process, contact our New Hartford District Office at 315-732-0713. 
￼ 
 
  
In the District & D.C.
 
 ￼ 
Congratulations to AmeriCU Credit Union in Yorkville, NY on the new beautiful renovation! Community financial institutions such as AmeriCU are the lifeblood of rural economies throughout our nation. It was a privilege to join them during their ribbon cutting ceremony this past week. 

￼ 
It was great to stop by New Hartford Senior Center to celebrate the 32nd anniversary of the center’s incredible service to our senior citizens. Our senior‘s experience many unique challenges, and I will continue my work in Congress to ensure their voices are heard and Medicare and Social Security are protected. 
 ￼ 
On Thursday, I visited Utica National Insurance Group. We toured the facility and spoke with employees about the future of federal insurance, workforce development and tariffs. The work Utica National does for people throughout NY-22 and our country is outstanding, and I look forward to continue advocating for them in Congress.
￼ 
It was a privilege to attend the annual Boy Scouts Leadership Dinner. For more than 100 years, the Boy Scouts of America have molded young boys into men of character, compassion, and commitment. It is because of these young men that I am confident in our nation’s bright future.
 ￼ 
On Friday, I took a tour of CMP-Advanced Mechanical Solutions facility in Binghamton, New York. We spoke with management and employees to learn more about the manufacturing work they do for our community.
￼ 
During my time in Congress, I have been a strong advocate for our local dairy farmers.This week, I attended the Oneida County Farm Bureau's annual meeting to speak with farmers and learn directly from them how I can continue to bring their voice to Washington. 
￼ 
I attended the 60th anniversary for the Rome Teachers Federal Credit Union, and presented them with a certificate honoring their dedication to our communities. As a member of the House Financial Services Committee, I will continue to fight for small credit unions like this that work for our local communities. 
  
  
In the News
TALK! With Claudia Tenney WUTQ 
 

Constituent Services
I would like to thank all who have taken the time to contact our office to provide vital feedback on legislation and our work on behalf of the 22nd District. In my time serving the 22nd District, our office has had the opportunity to respond to 124, 679 individual constituent messages and taken 27,108 phone calls.  
If you would like to schedule a meeting with either myself or my staff, please send us a message on our website. 
As always, our office is here to serve you. Please do not hesitate to contact our office if you need assistance with any of the following: 
	•	Assistance with a Federal Agency 
	•	Grant Application
	•	Tours of the Capitol and the White House
	•	Military Academy Nominations 
	•	Flag Requests                                     
Sincerely, ￼  Claudia Tenney Member of Congress

Subject: Unifying Trade & Environmental Policy
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
Unifying Trade & Environmental Policy... 
Dear Friend:
I appreciate you taking the time to read this week’s brief update—it is an honor to represent you in the U.S. House of Representatives!  This week, I introduced H.R. 7064, the ‘Fair Environmental Trade Agreements Act.’ This act seeks to integrate environmental and labor policies in with U.S. trade policy.   While the United States has consistently raised its environmental regulations and labor standards, other countries have been exporting products, once made in America, to us while we have been exporting our manufacturing jobs to them because of their competitive advantage in not bearing the mitigation cost of industrial pollution and employing forced and child labor at little cost.  Under current law, the office of Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) can negotiate ‘fast-track’ trade agreements through 2021. Although TPA calls for the inclusion of environmental or labor standard in such agreements, they are not required provisions. My bill, if enacted, will require the U.S. Trade Representative to certify to the U.S. House Ways & Means Committee and to the Senate Finance committee, that any trade agreement with the United States enters into will require that other nations meet minimum environmental and labor stands.   Our trade with China, for example, is subject to both these issues. Its outdated and inefficient factory technology only focuses on increased output. The result is that Beijing is reported to have some of the worst air quality and factories have been known to use child labor to keep production costs low. China also is said to use forced prison labor. When a country only focuses on reducing manufacturing costs at the expense of its workers and the environment, it can easily drive down the production costs below having the same goods made in the U.S.  Following up on another concern of mine, I want to let you know that after my September op-ed titled, “The U.S. Air Force Needs a Light Attack Aircraft”, received a response from Dr. Heather Wilson, Secretary of the Air Force. In her response, the Secretary stated that she “fully agrees with your [coffman] view that it [light attack platform] should be an affordable and lethal alternative for the U.S. and its allies and partners to use in permissive environments.” The Secretary went on to say that “our focus is on delivering a high quality, exportable, and affordable combat aircraft…and to provide this capability quickly and a reasonable cost.” As a Member of the House Armed Services Committee, a Marine Corps combat veteran who has personally relied on close air support in combat, and I consider the prompt procurement of the light attack aircraft essential to our national security. I will continue to update you as the procurement process progresses.   As always, I invite you to stay in contact with me via my website, facebook or twitter account. See you around the district! 
Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative 
￼

Subject: My Bill is Heading to the President's Desk
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Sunday, October 21, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
My Bill is Heading to the President's Desk
 

Last week, the Senate passed the Gulf Islands National Seashore Land Exchange Act, which means my bill is now on its way to President Trump's desk to be signed into law.   I've worked closely with leadership at the Mark Seymour VFW post and the Gulf Islands National Seashore who have supported our efforts in getting this bill to the finish line.   This legislation would make permanent a 30-year easement that has provided an access road and driveway for The Mark Seymour Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 5699, which is located within the National Park Service’s (NPS) Gulf Islands National Seashore in Ocean Springs. In exchange for the easement, the VFW will transfer a portion of its acreage to the park, which includes valuable wetlands.  The National Seashore is a staple of the Mississippi Gulf Coast that holds historic sites, wildlife sanctuaries, and natural beaches. I am pleased to see my bill advance its way to President Trump's desk for the final sign off. This is a huge victory for the Gulf Islands National Seashore that draws in millions of visitors every year. 
￼
80 years of Shipbuiling October of 2018 marks 80 years of Ingalls Shipbuilding producing world-class military ships from Pascagoula. Shipbuilding is an important piece in south Mississippi's economy and provides thousands of jobs for hardworking Mississippians.   Ingalls Shipbuildling has constructed nearly 70 percent of the Navy's warship fleet and also exclusively builds the United States Coast Guard's National Security Cutters that are used for drug interdiction in U.S. waters. Since 1938, Ingalls continues strengthening our national defense by ensuring our military personnel has the most lethal arsenal to keep our country safe.    I am grateful to represent the world's greatest shipbuilders in D.C. and look forward to 80 more years of continued success from Ingalls Shipbuilding!
￼
Salute to the Military Tuesday night I had the pleasure of attending the 40th Annual Salute to the Military on Tuesday evening. The annual Salute to the Military celebration has become engraved as a Mississippi Gulf Coast tradition to honor our Armed Forces.   This year we were privileged to welcome the Vice Commandant of the United States Coast Guard, Admiral Charles Ray as the keynote speaker. I was also honored to have Purple Heart recipient Ken Duncan and his grandson join me for the evening as my special guest.   It's no secret that Mississippi has a continued history of supporting our men and women in uniform every step of the way.  My position in Congress allows me a unique opportunity to provide support for our military and ensure our men and women in uniform have the tools and resources they need to do their job. Just this year, we voted to give our troops their largest pay raise in nine years and have fully funded our military on time for the second year in a row. I am so thankful that south Mississippi takes the time to honor the world's greatest military force. 
￼

￼

￼


In your service,
￼
Steven

Subject: Rep. Lowenthal eNewsletter - October 19 - Saudi Arabia, Gerrymandering, LGBTQ Rights
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Lowenthal
￼
 
HOW CAN ALAN HELP?
LEGISLATION
47TH DISTRICT
ABOUT ALAN
CONTACT ALAN
 

In This Edition 
This week I, along with over 40 other Members of Congress, sent a letter to President Trump urging him to impose sanctions on Saudi Arabia over the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. 
It was a pleasure to participate in the 2018 USC George Washington Leadership Lecture on political gerrymandering this week in Mount Vernon, Virginia. 
I am honored to have received a 100% rating on the Human Right's Campaign's Congressional Scorecard for my voting record on LGBTQ issues. 
This week I joined with House Natural Resources Committee Ranking Member Raul Grijalva in submitting comments to the US Forest Service. The agency has proposed two rules which I believe would place the interests of the mining and oil and gas drilling industries over environmental protection. 
In this edition of Alan’s Inbox, see my response to constituents who have contacted me to express their opinions on the 2018 Farm Bill, which authorizes a number of federal programs related to agriculture and food policy. 
Be sure to check out Congress U, where I talk about Jeanette Rankin, who was the first woman to be elected to Congress. 
Lastly, don’t forget to take this week’s poll in the right-hand column.  
  
￼ 
￼ 
CONNECT WITH ME
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
  
Do you believe that marijuana should be legalized for recreational use throughout the United States? 
 

Yes, it should be legal nationwide

Yes, but it should be on a state-by-state basis

No, it should not be legal

Don't know/unsure
 

If you have a problem, click here to open survey in a new window
  
  





￼
Finding an End to Partisan Gerrymandering 
It was a pleasure to participate in the 2018 USC George Washington Leadership Lecture on political gerrymandering this week at Mount Vernon in Virginia. I had an interesting and engaging conversation with Professor David Sloane of the USC Price School of Public Policy, which was followed by a discussion with a panel of experts on gerrymandering issues and solutions.   
Throughout my time in public office, I have been working to find solutions to the problem of extreme partisan gerrymandering. As a California State Senator, I was proud to play a significant role in the establishment of the California Citizens Redistricting commission, which gave responsibility for the drawing of districts to the residents of the state, rather than politicians. In Congress, I authored the “Let the People Draw the Lines Act,” which, like the independent redistricting commission I helped to establish in California, would ensure that congressional districts accurately represent local communities instead of favoring the interests of incumbents and political parties. Most recently, I led a bipartisan amicus brief of House members in the Gil v. Whitford case to establish barriers to extreme partisan gerrymandering. 
Click here for more information on this event and to watch a recording of the discussion. 
￼
Congressman Lowenthal at Thursday’s lecture on solutions to partisan gerrymandering
Calling for Sanctions Against Saudi Arabia 
This week I, along with over 40 other Members of Congress, sent a letter to President Trump urging him to impose sanctions on Saudi Arabia over the death of activist and journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The letter calls for sanctions under the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act, which requires presidents to decide within 120 days whether to impose sanctions requested by Congress. The letter also requests an end to U.S. support for Saudi Arabia’s military action in Yemen.  
More than two weeks after Khashoggi disappeared while visiting the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Trump has remained unwilling to call out the Saudi government. It took the president until Thursday to say he believes Khashoggi is dead, even as Turkish officials say they have recordings of his torture and murder. President Trump’s reluctance to take a strong stand on this issue is unacceptable, and I hope that he will recognize the gravity of this situation and heed Congress’ requests. 
A 100% Rating from the Human Rights Campaign 
I am honored to have received a 100% rating on the Human Rights Campaign’s Congressional Scorecard for my fight on Capitol Hill for LGBTQ equality. As the first Congress Member to permanently fly the Pride flag outside their Congressional office and a Vice Chair of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I am a proud ally of the LGBTQ community both here at home and abroad. We have come so far in such a short amount of time, but we still have so far to go. I will continue to fight for the equality of all American, because no one should be discriminated against because of who they are, or who they love.
￼ 
Opposing the US Forest Services’ Proposal to Weaken Environmental Standards 
This week I joined with House Natural Resources Committee Ranking Member Raul Grijalva in submitting formal comments to the US Forest Service regarding two of the agency’s proposed rules, which I believe would place the interests of the mining and oil and gas drilling industries over environmental protection. The proposals are consistent with many previous Trump Administration policies, claiming that environmental standards are a “burden” to these extractive industries. In the letter we point out that our national forests have been managed for nearly 60 years under the principle of “multiple use and sustained yield,” a philosophy that allows for a mixture of sustainable activities within our forests. That philosophy is threatened by the Trump Administration’s constant push for more drilling and mining on America’s public lands. 
To read the full letter, click here.  
  
￼

Each week hundreds of constituents contact my office to share their views on a variety of topics. I have recently received many messages from constituents expressing their opinions on the 2018 Farm Bill. Below is a portion of my response to those messages: 
  
“The Farm Bill authorizes a number of federal programs related to agriculture and food policy.  The programs affected by the Farm Bill are widespread, reaching beyond American farms, impacting land conservation, rural economic development, and nutrition programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). 
I am committed to making these programs work better for all Americans.  However, I am troubled by proposals in the House Farm Bill that would cut more than $24.6 billion from SNAP over the next ten years.  SNAP has proven to help struggling families overcome food insecurity and poverty, and 85% of food-insecure families with children have working parents.  According to the Center for Budget and Policies, 740,000 households with children would lose SNAP benefits under the new Farm Bill. 
The Farm Bill proposal also includes a work requirement for SNAP recipients that could threaten essential benefits for millions of people, especially older Americans or those with chronic conditions.  These proposals could also lead to some children becoming ineligible for free and reduced-price school meals. 
In California, the SNAP program is also known as CalFresh.  In the 47th Congressional District, 1 in 3 CalFresh households include seniors (60+) and 67% include children.  Further, these cuts would also hurt 490 retailers in our district, including supermarkets, grocery stores, and farmers markets.  
Beyond SNAP cuts, the bill strips away important conservation programs, such as a requirement that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) review agricultural pesticides to ensure they do not harm endangered species, as well as local and regional agriculture grants that support struggling farmers. 
For these reasons, among others, I voted against the Farm Bill in June 2018.  The legislation is currently held in conference to resolve the difference between the House and Senate versions.”  
  
If you have written in to me, please continue to do so. If you have not, I encourage you to share your views and concerns with me, as it is the best way for me to find out which issues you care most about.   You can find out how to contact me on my website by clicking here. 
  
￼ 
Representative Jeannette Rankin  Over the past several weeks Congress U has been looking at some notable legislation to come out of Congress in the recent past. I thought we might change gears over the next few weeks and look at a few notable, but perhaps less known, Members of both the House and Senate. 
I feel I have to start with Jeannette Rankin. She was an amazing and courageous American, who was not only the first woman to be elected and serve in Congress, but also the first woman to hold federal office in any capacity. 
Born in Montana Territory in 1880, Rankin graduated from the University of Montana in 1902 and then headed to the West Coast where during graduate studies she became involved in the woman's suffrage movement. By 1914, she had successfully led a movement which saw Montana grant equal and unrestricted voting rights to women. She later turned this movement's infrastructure into her Congressional campaign, and in 1916 became the first woman elected to the House of Representatives. 
Just three months into her tenure, she was called on to vote for the U.S. entering WWI. She famously said, "I wish to stand by my country, but I cannot vote for war." She was one of only 49 Representatives and two Senators who voted against going to war. 
Dur to redistricting in Montana, she wound up losing her race in 1918, and returned to her activist roots, this time focused on pacifism and non-participation in war. 
She was again elected to the House in 1940, and less than a year into her second tenure in Congress, she was asked again to vote on American entry into war--this time against Japan following the Pearl Harbor attack. Rankin, as she did in 1917, again voted no. This time, she was the only Member of Congress to do so. Days later, she abstained during the vote to declare war on Germany and Italy. Later in life, when asked if she regretted her votes, she said, "Never. If you're against war, you're against war regardless of what happens. It's a wrong method of trying to settle a dispute." 
 The outcry against Rankin’s votes -- from her colleagues, the press, and her constituents -- was overwhelming. She chose not to run for reelection, and in 1942 retired from public service.   She continued her peace and pacifist activism throughout the rest of her life, becoming an icon in the peace movement of the 1960s and until her death in 1973.   In 1985, a statue of Rankin was placed in the U.S. Capitol's Statuary Hall. It is inscribed, "I Cannot Vote For War." A copy of the statue also stands in the Montana capitol building in Helena.  
  
￼ 
  
United States Supreme Court Justices receive lifetime appointments. Would you support the establishment of term limits for Supreme Court Justices? 
  
52% Yes 
33% No 
15% Undecided 
  
  
Thank you, ￼  Alan Lowenthal Member of Congress

Subject: financial success, bullying and new healthcare resources for uninsured
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
October 21, 2018
Dear Friend,  
I enjoyed the opportunity to spend time with many constituents as I traveled around the district and attended events in our community last week.  My constituents are my best source of information, and I like hearing directly from you about the issues that matter most. Your input guides my decision-making and legislative agenda. 
Continue reading for a brief recap of my work on your behalf and a summary of some of the legislation I’ve recently supported! 
Facilitating Economic Success 
Our economy is now booming, and everyday Americans are feeling the positive effects of:
✔Higher wages 
✔Lower taxes 
✔Increased bonuses and benefits  
CNBC reported last week that job openings have reached an all-time high.  This is further proof that the economy is doing very well.  This doesn’t happen by accident.  Tax reform and deregulation have been vital to our nation’s economic success. Last week, a report by the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs stated that we’ve issued 176 deregulatory actions since January of 2017.  That is 12 regulations eliminated for every new regulation adopted.  The same report estimates that this action has saved American families and businesses over $23 billion.   Additionally, there’s a mountain of evidence that proves wages and income are strong in this booming economy. Get the facts.    
When the economy is working, small businesses grow.  Last week, I was able to visit a local small business in Central Pasco, Tru Simulation, which has recently invested more than $40 million dollars in expansion since 2015.  It is also helping boost local tourism, with over 1,000 clients visiting the facility each year.  During my visit we discussed regulatory improvements that could be helpful in aiding the company as it seeks to expand even further.  
￼ 
We want to ensure all Americans have the skills they need to prosper in this booming economy.  That is why we just provided $12.1 billion in federal funding for critical Department of Labor programs designed to develop a 21st century workforce in the most recent budget we’ve adopted.  We also want to invest in the future by ensuring that all children have the chance to achieve their highest potential, which is why I was pleased to support $10.1 billion in the Head Start program, $250 million for early childhood education, $5.3 billion for the Child Care and Development Block Grant, $250 million for Preschool Development Grants and $12.4 billion for education programs to help students with special needs in the FY 2019 budget, which we just recently passed. 
￼ 
Fighting for Our Nation’s Heroes 
The most recently adopted budget also honors those who have bravely answered the call to serve while protecting our national security.  I’m proud of the work we’ve done to ensure our military remains the strongest in the world.  
￼ 
Improving the level of support our nation’s heroes receive as they integrate back into civilian life has been a priority for me.  That is why I was excited to support over $300 million in federal funding in the most recent budget to help Veterans transition back into the workforce.  
￼ 
Supporting the Fight Against Opioids and other Healthcare Priorities 
Did you know that the budget bill we just passed for FY 2019 contains an additional $6.6 billion to fight opioids? As these funds are distributed to states and local governments through federal agencies, I will fight to make sure our community receives its fair share.  
Community health centers offer the uninsured and underinsured the opportunity to receive quality primary care, dental treatment, mental health services and substance abuse treatment on a sliding fee basis.  I am pleased to announce that the Community Health Center of Pinellas County has just been awarded more than $1.29 million dollars.  I was proud to help ensure these federal dollars were able to be returned to our community.  Community Health Centers have a proven track record of providing high quality, cost-efficient health care to approximately 25 million Americans, including over 7 million children and 300,000 Veterans. Community Health Centers have long enjoyed bi-partisan support because they are a prime example of what is working in our health care system, and I am proud to have helped secure funding to expand their work in our community.   
￼ 
In honor of Breast Cancer Awareness month, I was honored to participate in last week’s Breast Cancer Survivor luncheon in Tarpon Springs.  The bravery and persistence that these women display is inspiring.  We have to continue the fight to find a cure.  
￼ 
Supporting and Protecting our Future Leaders 
October is also National Bullying Prevention Month.  We have to make sure all children have a safe, harassment-free learning environment.  As adults, we must remain mindful of the importance of always treating one another with civility and respect.  Our children are watching and take cues from us about acceptable standards of conduct. 
￼ 
Did you know the most recent budget bill we passed for FY 2019 includes over $1.5 billion in funding to increase access to mental health providers and improve student safety in schools? 
￼ 
It was refreshing to visit Southerland Elementary School last week to speak with students about the importance of civic engagement and the role of Congress.  These bright young children had great questions and were enthusiastic about getting involved in public service.   
 ￼ 
Protecting our Infrastructure 
Protecting our water and infrastructure is essential to our state.  I recently voted to help pass the Water Resources Development Act, which has just been signed into law.  It authorizes locally driven infrastructure enhancements which are critical to our economy and to protecting our communities – improvements to harbors, ports, locks, dams, inland waterways, flood protection, and other water infrastructure.  It also addresses stormwater and wastewater infrastructure improvements and strengthens the Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (WIFIA) program. Click here to learn more about this important legislation.   
  
Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Gus Bilirakis

Subject: Build the Wall, Enforce the Law
Message:
￼ 
  

BUILD THE WALL, ENFORCE THE LAW

This week I signed onto the Build the Wall, Enforce the Law Act. 

This legislation fully funds President Trump's southern border wall. It also includes important provisions to make communities safer by stopping the flow of federal grant money to sanctuary cities, making alien gang membership grounds for deportation, and requiring that ICE directly addresses undocumented immigrants who are charged with a violent crime resulting in serious injury or death.

I have been to the Southwest border and I have seen the threats we face firsthand. There is much more than just illegal aliens coming across our borders. 

It is critical to our national security that we secure our border while addressing the threats already in our country like dangerous sanctuary cities and violent gangs. 

This legislation works to combat these threats and accomplish our most important duty to provide for the common defense. I will be working to bring this bill to a vote as soon as possible to support the safety of our communities.

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CLXXXIV

Monday, October 15, 2018:  This weekend, I did an interview with NBC Nightly News regarding my “gag clause” legislation that was recently signed into law by President Trump.  A link to the segment can be found here.  This morning I travel to Charleston, SC, to visit the Ralph H. Johnson VA Medical Center and meet with my good friend CEO Scott Isaacks.  As the CEO of this 152-bed Level 1A tertiary care medical center, Scott also oversees six outpatient clinics in South Carolina and Georgia including those in Savannah and Hinesville. 
￼
Rep. Carter visiting the Ralph H. Johnson VA Medical Center
After an overview presentation of the facility, I receive an opioid presentation to learn more of the work they are doing to address the opioid epidemic followed by presentations on telemedicine and mental health services offered at the center.  Next, I am treated to a tour of the center including visits to the community living center, GI clinic, Hall of Heroes and research building.  My final stop is a visit to the Fisher House located a few blocks from the hospital in beautiful downtown Charleston where families of veterans receiving care at the medical center are provided with temporary lodging.  To learn more about the Ralph H. Johnson VA Medical Center and the services they offer visit www.charleston.va.gov.  After making the 2 & ½ hour drive back to downtown Savannah, I meet with constituents before heading to Richmond Hill in Bryan County to meet with constituents.

Tuesday, October 16, 2018:  I graduated from Groves High School in Garden City in 1975.  Another member of that graduating class was Clyde Campbell, a star basketball player who I first met in the 8th grade at Mercer Junior High School and who I had lost touch with until a few years ago when he came to my Savannah district office to share with me the wonderful work he is doing with Clyde Campbell Ministries, Inc. in the Savannah area. 
￼
Rep. Carter at the “Development of a Man Tackling the Hard Issues” Graduation
This morning, I am honored that he has invited me to be the keynote speaker at the “Development of a Man Tackling the Hard Issues” graduation at the Chatham County Jail.  This jail ministry that Clyde started helps individuals look at life through a different lens and motivates them to focus on building a team of positive players to help them transition back into society with a positive mindset.  Afterwards, I head to Brunswick in Glynn County where I am the keynote speaker at the Brunswick Exchange Club’s weekly meeting.  After bringing this great group up to date on the happenings in Washington, DC, I head to Ocean Petroleum in downtown Brunswick and meet with Ashley Davis who runs this family owned and operated wholesale distributor of petroleum products.  Next, I head back up to Savannah and during the drive back I have a phone interview with The District, the student run news source for the Savannah College of Art and Design.  Once back in Savannah, I meet with the Savannah Board of Realtors.

Wednesday, October 17, 2018:  This morning I’m at the offices of Altrus Assisted Living Services in Savannah for an Alzheimer’s Coffee with Congress meeting hosted by the Alzheimer’s Association.  The purpose of these meetings is to give caregivers the opportunity to meet Members of Congress and share their stories as caregivers.  The stories that I hear today from these brave men and women are amazing and encouraging. 
￼
Rep. Carter visiting the Girls on the Run Program at South Effingham Elementary School
Afterwards, I head to the Savannah Police Training Center where I have the opportunity to address the Chatham Area Traffic Incident Management Team, and bring them up to date on infrastructure improvements in our area, including an update on the progress of the Savannah Harbor Expansion Project (SHEP).  A link to a news clip on this meeting can be found here.  Next, I head to the Savannah Treatment Center for a tour of this rehabilitation center that specializes in the treatment of opioid addiction.  As the only pharmacist currently serving in Congress as well as being a member of the Energy and Commerce (E&C) Committee that has passed legislation on this subject, I have a special interest in this area and am impressed with the fine work being done here with medication assisted treatment.  A link to a clip of my visit can be found here.  Next, I head to South Effingham Elementary School in Guyton for a visit with participants in the Girls on the Run program.  This great program helps to combat the unfortunate rise in unhealthy behaviors from the young people in our communities by positively influencing their social, physical, emotional and psychological development.  Along with community service and the Girls on the Run 5K, these girls are building both character and the confidence they will need to succeed.  My last stop of the day is to downtown Savannah where I meet with a group of young professionals.

Thursday, October 18, 2018:  I’m at St. Joseph’s/Candler Hospital on Reynolds Street in Savannah this morning meeting with hospital personnel to discuss maternal mortality and what we can do to address the issue in Georgia.  At a recent E&C Health Subcommittee meeting I learned that Georgia has the worst maternal mortality rate in the U.S. and that the pregnancy-related mortality ratio in the U.S. is one of the highest in the world.  The purpose of this meeting is to gain insight into the problem from health care professionals dealing directly with the situation. 
￼
Rep. Carter at the designation ceremony of Chatham County as an Official Coast Guard Community
A link to a news clip of the roundtable can be found here.  Next, I head to West Chatham County for a visit with Pond & Company, an engineering firm that has recently located here from Atlanta, to discuss infrastructure in our district.  Afterwards, I head to the Savannah International Trade Center where I am honored to participate in the designation ceremony of Chatham County as an Official Coast Guard Community.  Along with the Commandant of the U.S. Coast Guard, Admiral Karl L. Schultz, and elected officials from Chatham County, the City of Savannah and Tybee Island, I help to celebrate this well-deserved rare honor that our community is so proud of.  Afterwards, I head to Park Place in Savannah and meet with directors and representatives from the fine congregate care/group homes for teens and older youth in the First District to learn of the great work they do and discuss concerns they have.  My final visit of the day is to Blue Force Gear in Pooler as I tour their new facility and learn about the great work they do in making equipment that will lighten the load of the U.S. and allied warfighter by using advanced materials and proprietary manufacturing methods.

Friday, October 20, 2018:  I’m at Savannah State University early this morning as I have the honor of participating in the Step Up Savannah, Bridge the Gap to Prosperity meeting where the Creating Opportunity Awards are presented.  These awards are a distinction conferred by Step Up Savannah to community champions that have worked to help realize Step Up’s vision.  Afterwards, I head to Ellis Square in downtown Savannah for the “Red, White & Blues BBQ” sponsored by the 200 Club of the Coastal Empire. 
￼
Rep. Carter visiting McAllister Elementary School in Richmond Hill
The 200 Club is another example of what makes our community so great as their mission is to provide financial assistance to the surviving spouse and children of local law enforcement officers and firefighters who lose their lives in the line-of-duty while protecting our community.  Next, I head to McAllister Elementary School in Richmond Hill where I have the great joy of reading Pete the Cat to a kindergarten class and participating in the pep rally as members of the Richmond Hill High School football team and band march through the halls.  Afterwards, I head to my Savannah district office to meet with a veteran before heading to the federal courthouse in Savannah for the Southern District of Georgia’s Investiture Ceremony for Judge Stan Baker.  Judge Willie Moore will be moving to senior status and replaced by Judge Baker, who is an outstanding choice and I’m sure will do an exceptional job of serving this court for many years to come.  My final stop of a very busy week is in Richmond Hill in Bryan County as I have the honor of giving welcoming remarks at the Great Ogeechee Seafood Festival, an event started in 1985 that has grown to be one of the most anticipated in the State.

How important is it to you that political discourse in America be toned down in favor of greater civility and recognition of opposing viewpoints?


VERY important - The partisan tone has become too hateful and inflamed to the point where serious issues cannot be addressed.

SOMEWHAT important - I don't always like the coarseness and disrespect, but that's a part of democracy.

NOT important - There is a lot to be outraged about and that anger needs to be expressed even if some people get offended.

Subject: Cruz News: October 20, 2018
Message:
￼
 
 
October 20, 2018
Greetings,
This week is Texas Chambers of Commerce Week. Chambers across the Lone Star State play a crucial role as advocates for small businesses, job creators, and the hardworking men and women in their communities. I have been proud to meet with and work alongside these men and women to roll back job-killing federal regulations, lower taxes, and create more economic opportunity and good paying jobs for Texans.
Small businesses are the backbone of our economy. Throughout my time in the Senate, my top priority has been and continues to be jobs and economic growth. This week, I was honored to receive the National Federation of Independent Business’ Guardian of Small Business award. America’s economy is booming. In Texas, people are investing new capital, opening new facilities, hiring new workers, and raising wages. We’re seeing record low unemployment. That’s the power of getting the government off the backs of job creators, and allowing folks to prosper.
Central Texas is hurting as floodwaters ravaged communities all across the area this week. On Wednesday, I surveyed the storm damage in Burnet and Llano County and received a briefing from local officials in the area. In the last year, Texas has faced a number of powerful storms that have left entire communities devastated. However, I have every confidence that Texans will stand united, and rebuild stronger than ever. One of the great strengths of our state is the number of churches, charities, organizations, and people who have helped in the recovery, relief, and rebuilding process. This weekend, Texans should heed warnings from local officials, know their evacuation route, and avoid high water areas.
Our prayers continue to be with those Americans recovering in Central Texas, and from Hurricanes Matthew and Florence. These devastating natural disasters are a stark reminder of the importance of taking all steps necessary to prepare our homes and families for any future weather event. For those seeking preparedness information and resources, please refer to the federal and state resources listed here.
Please read below for an update from this last week.
Keep Texas Strong,
￼ Ted Cruz
￼

Subject: Medicare Enrollment Is Open Now
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: October 20, 2018   ￼  I was honored to be inducted as an honorary member of Alpha Gamma Rho agricultural fraternity at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln on Friday evening.    
Medicare Enrollment Is Open Now  During Medicare open enrollment, current and prospective beneficiaries are able to update or initiate Part D coverage as needed. This year’s open enrollment will take place from October 15th to December 7th, allowing seniors to make decisions regarding their 2019 Medicare coverage.  While no action is required if current beneficiaries are happy with their coverage, formularies can change from year to year and it is highly recommended every beneficiary review their coverage annually. In order to guide Nebraska’s seniors through this sometimes difficult process, my office will conduct our annual Senior Services Fairs in Scottsbluff and Grand Island.  The Scottsbluff Senior Services Fair will take place at the Lied Scottsbluff Public Library located at 1809 3rd Avenue from 9:30 a.m. to noon (MT) on November 14th. The Grand Island Senior Services Fair will be held on November 15th from 9:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. (CT) at the Grand Generation Center located at 304 E 3rd Street.  Representatives from Social Security, the VA, the Nebraska Senior Health Insurance Information Program (SHIIP,) and my office will be on-site to answer any questions or concerns regarding these agencies and programs. We recommend Nebraskans seeking assistance with Medicare Part D at the Grand Island event make appointments by calling Nebraska SHIIP at 1-800-234-7119.  In addition, if you plan to seek assistance with choosing a Part D plan at either of these events, please be sure to bring a full list of your prescriptions and dosages to ensure representatives can help you choose the best plan to cover your recurring prescriptions.  For those who may not be able to travel to one of these events, I also hold an annual Medicare teleconference through which a representative from Medicare can answer your questions about open enrollment. Residents of the Third District who would like to be included in this annual teleconference are encouraged to call my Grand Island office at 308-384-3900 prior to November 13th.  For additional information, seniors may visit Medicare.gov to learn more about available options, check current enrollment, and apply for new coverage. Nebraskans can also speak with experts by calling Nebraska SHIIP at 1-800-234-7119 or Medicare at 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227.)  I sincerely hope seniors needing advice or assistance will utilize one or more of these resources to receive coverage through this vital program. Medicare Part D was designed to improve coverage and keep costs down by requiring insurers to compete. Taking an active role in reviewing your coverage improves your ability to benefit from this competition.  As a member of the House Ways and Means Committee which has jurisdiction over Medicare, I will continue to ensure its benefits remain available for future generations of Americans.   Meet with Me This Week 
I'll be holding mobile offices in South Sioux City and Bloomfield this week to meet with constituents and discuss important issues such as the Farm Bill, trade, and tax reform. I hope you'll join me.

Thursday, October 25

Dakota County Mobile Office Hours
South Sioux City Hall
1615 1st Ave, South Sioux City
10:00 to 11:00 AM CDT

Knox County Mobile Office Hours
Bloomfield City Library
121 S Broadway St, Bloomfield
1:00 to 2:00 PM CDT

If you have any questions about these events, please contact my Grand Island office at (308) 384-3900 or my Scottsbluff office at (308) 633-6333.

As always, feel free to forward my e-newsletter to family and friends, or let them know they can sign up to receive updates from my office on my website at AdrianSmith.house.gov.

Dear Friend,
Missourians work hard day in and day out for their money, and they should have a government that watches over their dollars as carefully and responsibly as they do at home. We don’t mind paying our fair share to live in a safe nation, to have a judicial system that maintains law and order, or for public infrastructure improvements. But in Missouri we don’t have the appetite for a massive government that wants to use our hard-earned tax dollars on inefficient government programs and handouts. Your money belongs in your pocket, not in Washington’s coffers...KEEP READING HERE 


WHAT'S GREAT IN THE 8TH

Subject: Hultgren Huddle - Weekend Update
Message:
News from Representative Randy Hultgren
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

HOME
ABOUT RANDY
SERVING YOU
NEWSROOM
OUR DISTRICT
CONTACT
￼
￼
￼


In this Issue:

	•	Hultgren Hunger Forum a Hit
	•	Wrapping Up the Year
	•	U.S. Economy Doing Extremely Well
	•	Turkey Releases Pastor Brunson
	•	Randy on the Issues - Advancing Science & Technology
	•	Congress On Your Corner

Hultgren Hunger Forum a Hit
I had the honor and privilege of hosting a public forum in St. Charles on Wednesday called “Confronting the Scourge of Hunger”. The forum highlighted global hunger and ways to address hunger needs locally in our northern Illinois communities ahead of the holidays.
For many in our community, region, and world, getting enough to eat is a daily struggle. It’s not just a matter of sufficient access to food, but also getting enough calories and essential nutrients on a daily basis. Like many of you, I remain grateful for the blessings of basic necessities of food, clothing, and shelter. However, nearly 600,000 people in northern Illinois rely on food pantries to feed themselves and their families.
Distinguished special guests from international and regional food relief and assistance organizations joined us Wednesday, including Ambassador Tony Hall of the Alliance to End Hunger, Zach Schmidt of Bread for the World, Teresa Schryver of the Northern Illinois Food Bank, Jodie Clow of Faith Acres Foundation in Island Lake, Erin Wise of the Shepherd’s Heart Benevolence Ministry at Chapelstreet Church in Geneva, and Abby Deatherage of Local Compassion and Justice at Willow Creek Community Church.
Together they described what is happening with hunger globally and in our own region, as well as the substantial progress being made and the successes achieved in helping our “neighbors” get enough to eat and overcome the obstacles associated with hunger.  
As we head into the holidays, I will remain mindful of those in our local communities and around the world who confront hunger on a daily basis. I will be thinking of ways I can be of help to those in need, whether its volunteering at a local food bank or cosponsoring legislation such as the Global Food Security Act in Congress 
￼ 
￼ 
Wrapping Up the Year
With the President recently signing the Department of Energy Research and Innovation Act into law, the work we have done at the Science Committee will continue to spur discovery and economic growth in Illinois. I was humbled to have large parts of H.R. 5120, my bipartisan legislation the House passed back in 2014, included in this package. A primary focus of mine with the labs has been getting unnecessary bureaucracy out of the way so researchers can develop business ideas out of their research and get it to the market more quickly.  
As Congress continues our work for the rest of the year, I was thrilled to see the Department of Energy Office of Science funded for the second year at its highest level. The Office of Science is the United States largest funder of research in the physical science and the primary funding source for Fermilab and Argonne.
As Congress finished out our appropriations process, there are still key programs I will continue advocating for in a long-term Commerce, Justice, Science (CJS) Appropriations Bill. I have long supported robust funding at the National Science Foundation and expect to see this in any final package.
I have also co-led the bipartisan letters of support for the Regional Innovation Program, funded in this bill, which make it easier for businesses in Illinois to share best practices, advocate on their behalf, and get new ideas to market quicker. Perhaps most important is keeping these jobs in Illinois! 

U.S. Economy Doing Extremely Well
Following Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's description of the U.S. economic outlook as "remarkably positive", Chicago Fed President Charles Evans says "U.S. economy is doing extremely well. Fundamentals are strong, the labor market is doing terrific." 
Read more here about the future of our roaring economy! 

Turkey Releases Pastor Brunson
I am so very thankful for Pastor Brunson’s long-awaited release, which will mark the end of an avoidable and distressing episode in U.S.-Turkish relations.
My hope is that with Andrew Brunson’s release we can begin the process of healing between our two nations and ultimately strengthening relationships with a crucial regional ally. 
For now, we can take a moment to reflect on the successful efforts that resulted in his freedom and rejoice with his family, while bearing in mind that there are still others in similar circumstances who remain incarcerated.

Randy On The Issues - Advancing Science & Technology
As a senior member of the Science Committee, I believe maintaining America’s leadership role in scientific research and development is critical for our future. We need a renewed focus on STEM education. The House passed my Accelerating American Leadership in Science Act that provides important funding for Fermi Lab, as well as the DOE Labs Modernization and Technology Transfer Act that helps educational institutions in the 14th District innovate. 
In Your Service,  ￼  Randy Hultgren Member of Congress 14th District, Illinois 
Congress on Your Corner
￼ 
￼
The AP Government Class at Prairie Ridge High School welcomed Congressman Hultgren to their class where they had a discussion of democracy and the American electoral process.
￼ 
￼
Snap-On Tools runs a state of the art operation right here in the 14th District. They were kind enough to invite the Congressman to check out their facility and to chat with some local employees. 
￼
Thanks to the American Hospital Association for hosting the Congressman for a great roundtable discussion in Woodstock
￼ 
￼
Congressman Hultgren visited Experian where he had the opportunity to learn more about their operation as well as the credit score reporting and monitoring services they offer.

Subject: Jackie's Reads for October 20, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

October 20, 2018 
Dear Friends,  Given these turbulent political times, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.   
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world. When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change. 
Happy reading and all the best,    ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼ 

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
The Trump Tax Scam, Phase II
Deficits are up? Cut Medicare and Social Security!
By Paul Krugman, The New York Times Opinion
                                    
￼
When the Trump tax cut was on the verge of being enacted, I called it “the biggest tax scam in history,” and made a prediction: deficits would soar, and when they did, Republicans would once again pretend to care about debt and demand cuts in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security.

Sure enough, the deficit is soaring. And this week Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, after declaring the surge in red ink “very disturbing,” called for, you guessed it, cuts in “Medicare, Social Security and Medicaid.” He also suggested that Republicans might repeal the Affordable Care Act — taking away health care from tens of millions — if they do well in the midterm elections.
Any political analyst who didn’t see this coming should find a different profession. After all, “starve the beast” — cut taxes on the rich, then use the resulting deficits as an excuse to hack away at the safety net — has been G.O.P. strategy for decades.
To read the complete New York Times op-ed, please click here. 
The Rigging of American Politics
￼
Political systems depend on legitimacy. In America, that legitimacy is failing.
By Ezra Klein, Vox
Brett Kavanaugh was nominated to the Supreme Court by an unpopular president who won 3 million fewer votes than the runner-up. He was confirmed by a Senate majority that represents a minority of the country. He was confirmed despite most Americans telling pollster after pollster they did not want him seated on the Supreme Court. 
Nothing about Kavanaugh’s ascension breaks the rules of American government. Donald Trump is the duly elected president of the United States. Republicans hold a majority in the US Senate. Elected officials bear no responsibility to follow public opinion. Yet the left sees Kavanaugh’s confirmation as illegitimate, and they’re turning their ire on the composition of the US Senate and their focus to the possibilities for future court-packing and judicial impeachment. 
American politics is edging into an era of crisis. A constitutional system built to calm the tensions of America’s founding era is distorting the political competition between parties, making the country both less democratic and less Democratic. 
To read the complete Vox article, please click here. 
I Fell For Facebook Fake News. Here’s Why Millions of You Did, Too.
By Geoffrey A. Fowler, Technology Columnist, The Washington Post
The Facebook video is nuts, but I can’t tear my eyes away. A plane, struggling in a huge storm, does a 360-degree flip before safely landing and letting out terrified passengers. 
It turns out the video is totally bunk, spliced together from a computer-generated clip and unrelated real news footage. But that didn’t stop the Facebook post from arriving in my News Feed via a friend last month. I watched it. Maybe you did, too: It has nearly 14 million views. 
Everyone now knows the Web is filled with lies. So then how do fake Facebook posts, YouTube videos and tweets keep making suckers of us? 
To find out, I conducted a forensic investigation of the fake that fooled my social network. I found the original creator of that CG plane clip. I spoke to the Facebook executive charged with curbing misinformation. And I confronted my friend who shared it. 
To read the complete Washington Post column, please click here.

Subject: Weekly Update: I'm Here to Serve You
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS

Weekly Update: I'm Here to Serve You By Congressman Wittman October 20, 2018  Without question, the most important part of my job as a member of Congress is to serve you, my constituents. It is my passion to serve that drives me to wake up each morning and fight for you in Washington. Every day votes are held, I commute from my hometown of Montross, and I drive past the homes of friends I’ve known all my life; that keeps me grounded as I start each day.  From cutting through the bureaucracy to arranging Capitol Tours, I want to do everything I can to provide the best service possible to my constituents. As your member of Congress, I serve as a liaison between you and federal agencies. My staff and I frequently help people navigate issues they're having with federal agencies. Although I cannot override the decisions made by a federal agency, I can often advocate on a person's behalf to get answers to questions, find solutions, or just cut through the red tape. Just this Congress, my amazing district staff completed over 1,500 cases.  Last week, I had the great pleasure of meeting with some folks to hear their casework success stories.  Cheryl reached out to my office for assistance in securing the necessary paperwork for her VA home loan. We assisted her in navigating the Navy bureaucracy and Cheryl was able to purchase her home. 
￼

Saeed requested assistance in securing visas for his young children, who faced the prospect of being left behind in Pakistan and separated from their parents while their visas were being processed. My office was able to cut thru the red-tape at USCIS and the State Department and obtain visas for Hassan and Hania.

￼
If you ever have a problem with a federal agency or need assistance, please check out my website or call one of my local offices in Stafford, Tappahannock, or Hanover. In order to provide assistance to residents who do not live near my district offices, I want to invite you to visit one of my satellite offices. Click here to view the locations and schedule.  I always put the First District First. My top priority will always be serving you and it is an honor to serve you and Virginia's First District in the People's House.
￼

October 20, 2018


 
SENIOR CITIZENS INFORMATION FAIR I’m hosting a Senior Citizens Information Fair next week in McAlester to allow constituents who have questions or issues with the Social Security Administration to visit with me and members of my staff and get assistance.  Additional resource organizations will also be in attendance to offer assistance, such as KI BOIS, and others. Hope you’ll join us!
 
Senior Citizens Information Fair Friday, October 26
10:00 – 11:30am CT J.I. Stipe Center
801 N. 9th St.
McAlester, OK  74501 
LIVE ON FOX AND FRIENDS On Tuesday, I joined Fox and Friends to discuss Elizabeth Warren’s DNA test results. As a member of the Cherokee Nation, I am disappointed by Senator Warren’s attempt to prove any kind of Native American heritage in order to advance her political career. What she did is get a liberal university to provide information to convey that her lie is not a lie.  The lie has gone far enough and it’s time for her to apologize to the American people and the Cherokee Nation. Watch the interview at this link.  
￼
MEETING WITH OKLAHOMANS One of my favorite things I get to do as a member of Congress is visit with students of all ages. I stopped by Whittier Elementary this week to talk with students about Congress and how a bill becomes a law.  
￼

I also spoke to a history class at Warner High School about current issues in the news.
￼

It was great to be with students at Connors State College, where we discussed how best to reach elected officials on issues of importance. 
￼

Thanks to representatives from the National Multiple Sclerosis Society for stopping by our Claremore office to meet about their legislative priorities.
￼
Enjoyed visiting with Barbara Chance!  
￼
I had the chance to attend the monthly farm auction at the Brinkley Auction in Idabel and meet with Larry Brinkley. This auction is one of the largest in the nation, and brings in people from all over the United States.  
￼
I toured the new Fred’s Pharmacy location in Idabel. It was great to speak with Wes Maddox and learn more about this new establishment and the opportunities it will bring to the community.  
￼
 MOBILE OFFICE STOPS FOR VETERANS  
￼
In the Second District, I have offices located in Claremore, Muskogee, and McAlester. However, I understand that many constituents don’t live near one of my offices, or don’t have the time to travel to one. Our veterans deserve first-class service no matter where they live. That’s why I’m sending my veterans caseworker to you so that a member of my team can assist you in your own town.
Members of my staff will stop in five southeastern counties in OK-2 this month. The stop below is coming up next week. Visit my website to see the full list of dates and locations. Stop by if my team can help you! 
Choctaw County Mobile Office Stop
Thursday, October 25, 2018
1:00PM – 4:00PM CT

See more from my week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way.
Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin

Subject: An Update from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez to Constituents of the 15th District of Texas
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
The past couple of weeks have proven to be very busy, but I wanted to take the time to update you on our recent work in Washington, D.C. and the 15th District of Texas. 
It is an honor to serve as your congressman. 
The District Office in Seguin, Texas is officially open! It is an honor to open an office for residents in the northernmost region of the 15th District of Texas. I am humbled to bring on veteran, Robert 'Bobby' Herrera, to better assist Central Texans. This new location will offer educators, senior citizens, veterans, and any constituent facing issues with federal agencies the ability for us to engage on their behalf on any federal issue — whether it be the U.S. Department of State, U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, or the Social Security Administration. Mr. Herrera is ready to offer direct assistance with these agencies on my behalf. To the people of Seguin, Texas, and surrounding areas – we are here, able, and ready to help.
The new District Office is located at 1243 Cardinal Ln., Seguin, Texas 78155. 
￼
￼
On Monday, I joined community leaders from Brooks County to discuss solutions for water and drainage issues in Jim Hogg, Duval, and Brooks Counties. It is my hope that this conversation is the first of many as we develop short term and long term solutions to these pressing issues. I will continue to work with local, state, and federal officials to ensure South Texas is safe, open for business, and not hindered by future severe storms and flooding. Find out more by clicking the picture below.
￼ 
On Tuesday, I met with Texas Farm Bureau members from across the 15th District in George West, Texas to hear about what matters most to our producers. From U.S. foreign policy to trade, immigration, bipartisanship and everything in between, what we do in Washington and around the world affects our farmers and ranchers.
￼ 
On Wednesday, I met with City of Seguin Mayor Don Keil; City Manager, Doug Faseler; Grants Coordinator, Dana Losey; and Assistant General Manager of Schertz-Seguin Local Government Corporation, Amber Beard to discuss strategies that improve the overall well-being of Seguin, Texas and surrounding communities. 
￼ 
Recently, I visited the Karnes County Courthouse to discuss methods to strengthen energy development and strategies to promote investments for local infrastructure improvements. I pledge to continue working to build economies and communities in Karnes County and keeping an open dialogue with county officials.
￼ 
I thank my friend, Homer Lott Jr., Mayor of Runge, Texas, for taking the time to chat about ways we can work together to help the residents of the 15th District of Texas.
￼ 
Recently, I visited with Seguin ISD Superintendent, Dr. Matthew Gutierrez, and the fantastic people serving the youth of Seguin, Texas. I extend my gratitude to all of you for ensuring that the children of Seguin have full, adequate resources that strengthen their educational fortitude.
￼ 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.    
  
Sincerely,
￼  Vicente Gonzalez Member of Congress

Subject: Helping After Hurricane Michael, American Spirit Award, & More
Message:
Having trouble viewing this email? View it as a Web page.
￼ 
Website                          Media Center                        Contact Me
Dear Friend,   Thank you for the opportunity to update you on the work of the 115th Congress. I trust this finds you and your family well, as we work together to bring Hoosier common sense to Washington.

In This Week's Rokita Report
	•	Town Hall in Frankfort on Sunday
	•	Helping After Hurricane Michael
	•	American Spirit Award for Aviation Support
	•	Lowest Unemployment Since 1969
Photos and Videos
￼
Bruce Buchanan, a 4th District corn farmer, is grateful to President Trump for his recent decision to allow E15 fuel cells.
￼
Thank you to Mark and Abhi and my entire district staff for their help.  They gathered supplies that were needed by those impacted by Hurricane Michael in Florida.
￼
Israel is a crucial ally of the United States.  I recently spoke on the House Floor in support of President Trump's efforts to strengthen our friendship.

Town Hall in Frankfort on Sunday
Public meetings are a chance for me to get my marching orders to discuss issues directly with my fellow Hoosiers.  To provide an opportunity to do so, I will be holding a Town Hall on October 21st.  I look forward to hearing from you at the Frankfort Neighborhood Center.
￼
When: Sunday, October 21st starting at 2 PM ET
Where: Frankfort Neighborhood Center
259 South 3rd Street, Frankfort
Helping After Hurricane Michael
On Monday, Team Rokita was honored to participate in Hoosier Hospitality by donating supplies for those affected by Hurricane Michael.  My staff collected needed supplies, such as diapers, food, water, tarp, and bleach, to help those in need.  I personally flew the supplies to Florida where they could be put to immediate use.  I would like to thank my staff and everyone who has been helping Floridians recover from this storm.
￼
The plane was loaded with supplies and ready to go to Florida.
American Spirit Award for Aviation Support
This week, I was honored to receive the American Spirit Award by the National Business Aviation Association (NBAA) for my work with general aviation.  The NBAA American Spirit Award is presented in recognition of an individual within business aviation who exemplifies courage, and is in the pursuit of excellence and service to others that characterize the men and women who created and nurtured the American aviation community.  Some past recipients include Captain ‘Sully’ Sullenberger, the passengers and crew of United flight 93, and former president of the NBAA, Jack Olcott.  You can find a list of past recipients here.
America has the largest, safest, and most effective aviation system in the world, and general aviation plays a key role in that.  In Indiana alone, general aviation has an economic impact of $5.8 billion.  My team and I have been able to protect and grow general aviation in Indiana and across the nation by rolling back red-tape and introducing bills like my Securing and Revitalizing Aviation (SARA) Act, that adds protections for the aviation community.  I will continue to push for system modernization and to protect general aviation.
In the 114th Congress, I introduced H.R. 1086, the General Aviation Pilot Protection Act, a bipartisan effort to reform third-class medical certification.  Third-class medical reforms were signed into law and went into effect on May, 1 2017.  This Congress, Congressman Rokita introduced H.R. 6957, the Securing and Revitalizing Aviation (SARA) Act, which would improve protections for the aviation community.
Lowest Unemployment Since 1969
The U.S. unemployment rate reached its lowest levels since 1969 after the economy added 134,000 jobs in September.  This is the latest sign that the pro-growth policies promoted by House Republicans and President Donald Trump are working.  We have been committed to removing the roadblocks put in place by the previous administration.
The American economy excels when Americans take charge.  High taxes and excess regulations were crippling the economy.  Thanks to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the American tax code is competitive.  Our businesses are no longer burdened by one of the world's highest tax rates and Americans are saving money.  According to the Tax Foundation, the average Hoosier in the Fourth District saves $1,425 in taxes.  Hoosiers, not Washington, know how to spend their own money.
Under President Trump, for every new regulation enacted a record twenty-two have been repealed.  Proposed regulations have been withdrawn.  One of the regulations was overturned by a bill that I wrote and which was signed into law by President Trump.  My bill repealed onerous proposed requirements that would have grown the Department of Education's role in determining local education accountability standards.  As Chairman of the Subcommittee on Early Childhood, Elementary, and Secondary Education, I believe that parents, states, and our communities should be deciding the education of children, not Washington bureaucrats.
The results of these efforts are clear, the American economy is booming.





In Case you Missed it
	•	Rokita Receives American Spirit Award
	•	Rokita to Hold Town Hall Meeting at Neighborhood Center
	•	Rokita Issues Statement on Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation
	•	Rokita Calls for Support of Israel
	•	China's Economy is More Like a Paper Dragon than a Ferocious Tiger

Thank you for your continued interest in Congress and for supporting my efforts to bring Hoosier common sense to Washington. Take care.
Sincerely,

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

October 20, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review
 



October 16

Rising Annual Deficits: I know that at times I sound like a broken record on the debt and deficit, but it will prove to be the issue of our times. Accordingly, I give you a brief update based on the fact that yesterday, the Treasury Department reported that the deficit for fiscal year 2018 was $779 billion. This is a 17 percent and 113 billion dollar increase over last year.
More significantly, this was the largest deficit that our country’s seen since 2012 when it was over $1 trillion and tapering down from the deficits that exploded with the Great Recession of 2008 and 2009. In fact, the annual deficit peaked in 2009 at $1.4 trillion. It gradually dropped to $439 billion by 2015, and since then, it has risen steadily. It was $585 billion in 2016 and $666 billion in 2017.
The whole 666 thing in 2017 freaks me out…but that’s another story for another day on God’s warning signs for us on the debt and deficit…. Click here to read more.
￼

October 17

Government Waste - MOX Closure: You know the two things that drive me crazy about government?
One, that the left hand never seems to know what the right arm is doing. A whole host of governmental promises are either not remembered or soon forgotten by the complexity of government and its commitments or simply by the passage of time.
Two, it doesn’t mind burning money. You think about how hard each of us work to earn a dollar’s pay…and then government goes out and literally burns money that we spent days, weeks, months, or even years to accumulate and send off (by law and edict) for their care and stewardship.
So the bottom line is that we have a giant entity that we all pump money into that oftentimes doesn’t live up to its commitments and burns money as it does so.
There’s not a more relevant example out there than what just happened last week with the MOX facility up at the Savannah River site in Aiken. Click here to read more.
￼

October 18

￼
 Click above to learn more.

￼

Updates on the Two New Trade Agreements: George Will said it perfectly when he recently observed, “protectionism - laws and administrative rulings by which government determines the prices and quantities of imported goods and services - is government regulation.”
What the administration can’t do, and what we can’t do as Republicans, is to say that we’re for less regulation and then stand quietly as massive amounts of new regulation are put on us in the form of tariffs. On this point, it’s interesting that observers have noted that the deregulatory efforts by the administration to date have saved about $1.3 billion this year. That’s good. What’s not so good is that this is a fraction of the amount of money that is now going to go to farmers from the taxpayers, as the administration tries to protect farmers from the effects of the NEW tariffs.
In this light, let me offer a few thoughts on the two recent trade agreements by the administration….
As I’m sure you know, one was with Korea (KORUS), and there was a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) - and it will now be called the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Click here to read more.
￼


October 19

Foreign Military Sales: Time out of session in preparation for the midterm elections is dangerous on my part, given I don’t have a campaign to run but instead have time to look at different wastes in government that should drive all of us crazy.
In this regard, I thought you might find interesting a recent report by the Government Accountability Office that found in the last 6 years the Department of Defense has given foreign countries discounts on the purchase of military weapons and equipment to the tune of $16 billion.
Here’s the kicker: over half of that was to oil-wealthy countries in the Middle East (Qatar, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia) who rank as some of the richest in the world - and are fully capable of paying full-price.
This is particularly true, given the fact that these countries run massive trade surpluses given their oil sales. Saudi Arabia has created a $697 billion sovereign wealth fund, Kuwait a $524 billion fund, and Qatar has a $320 billion fund. Click here to read more. 
￼
 Click above to read the GAO report.
