Subject: Remembering One of Washington's Greatest
Message:
Share on: 
￼￼ 
 
￼
￼


Dear Friend,  This week our nation lost a truly great leader, philanthropist, and visionary.  As co-founder of Microsoft; owner of the Seahawks and Trailblazers; co-owner of the Sounders; and founder of Vulcan Inc., the Allen Institute for Brain Science, and the Museum of Pop Culture, Paul Allen was an institution here in Washington State. He will be dearly missed, but his legacy lives on in the lives he touched through his work redefining modern technology and his kind heart and extensive philanthropy in our community and around the world.  Welcoming Home Our Nation’s Heroes  This week, I was honored to welcome home World War II veterans who traveled to Washington, DC with the Puget Sound Honor Flight. The Honor Flight Network is a non-profit organization dedicated to honoring America’s veterans for all their sacrifices. They transport our heroes to Washington, DC to visit and reflect at our nation’s memorials built in their honor, with the top priority given to the senior veterans of World War II.  
￼
Encouraging News for Washington’s Economy  Earlier this week, United States Trade Representative (USTR) Robert Lighthizer, pursuant to the Bipartisan Congressional Trade Priorities and Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) Act, sent letters to Congress expressing the Administration’s intent to enter into three different trade negotiations with the European Union, Japan, and the United Kingdom.  I welcomed this announcement demonstrating a formal intent to begin negotiations with some of our greatest trading partners. It is my hope the Administration will consult extensively with Congress as the scope and objectives for these negotiations are set.  With 40 percent of jobs tied to trade in Washington State, strong and ambitious trade agreements with these allies would be beneficial for our workers, businesses, and farmers.  Addressing Flood Risk in the Puyallup River Basin  This week, I sent a bipartisan, bicameral letter with Sens. Murray, Cantwell, Reps Heck, and Kilmer to the Army Corps of Engineers to ask them to complete the Puyallup River General Investigation study to identify flood protections that are needed for the Puyallup River Basin. It is my hope that the Army Corps will complete this study so we can find ways to reduce flood risk in the Puyallup River Basin.  Pierce County Zero Emissions Buses  On October 17, Pierce County for the first time ever will be running all-electric, zero-emissions buses in the South Sound. Recently, the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) awarded Pierce Transit a $2.55 million “Low or No Emissions” grant to purchase the agency’s first-ever, all-electric, zero-emission buses and related infrastructure. The “Low-No” grant program aims to put a new generation of advanced, non-polluting transit buses on roadways across the nation. Earlier this year, I sent a bipartisan, bicameral letter with Sens. Murray, Cantwell, Reps Heck, and Kilmer to the FTA in support of federal funding for these electric, zero-emissions buses for Pierce County. This will help improve our public transportation in the South Sound while reducing pollution to help keep our air clean.   District Happenings   Saturday: Issaquah Goes Apples & Farm Fresh Market  Hosted in Downtown Issquah, Issaquah Goes Apples celebrates harvest season with a pop-up market, walking tours, art experiences and more!  Highlights include a cider press, live music, pumpkin patch, and scarecrow-making contest. Participants of all ages are welcome!  EVENT DETAILS:  When: Saturday, October 20, 9:00am-2:00pm Where: Historic Shell Station, 232 Front St. N, Issaquah, WA 98027  Saturday: Junk-tiquen in the Burg  Hunt for unique upcycled, repurposed, and vintage goods at the 5th Annual Junk-tiquen in the Burg Fall Show. There will be vendors from across the Pacific Northwest  EVENT DETAILS:  When: Saturday, October 20, 9:00am – 4:00pm Where: Kittitas County Event Center, 901 E. 7th Avenue, Ellensburg, WA  Wishing you all a wonderful weekend!  Sincerely,
Dave

Subject: October Visits
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
GET CONNECTED: 
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼   
Dear Friend,

October is a busy month for all of us. Friday Night Lights are back; the weather can’t decide what to do; and classes are in full gear. For me, this month is filled with events and road trips across our GREAT district.

Earlier this month, I spoke at the AIPAC Southwest Region Veterans Dinner. The brave men and women we honored sacrificed much for our country. My deepest thanks to them for their service. 

Without a doubt, Israel is our closest ally in the Middle East. Two of her greatest strengths are that she stands up for herself and she stands up for her friends. Israel’s strength proves that all 8,019 square miles of her is mighty.

Our two nations work closely together to keep each other safe and secure. Our scientists and our military value the input of each other. Together, we’ve achieved many great things. I look forward to our continued alliance.

￼
"T-Bone by Brooke Langston is on display in the Capitol.

Each year, our office hosts the Congressional Art Competition. I had the pleasure of speaking to the audience at the Brazoria County Fair, and my…I must tell you, we have some talented young artists in our district. Congrats to Chisom Akunne for taking home the top prize at the fair. Her piece, “The Sheriff,” is remarkable! To all our young artists out there: Looking forward to seeing y’all participate in next year’s art competition! Contact Janet Brown in our Beaumont Office (409-835-0108) for more details. I’ll be sure to post details on my Facebook in the spring, too!

￼
Lecturing students and taking questions at LIT.

I also visited the Lamar Institute of Technology. They graciously invited me to teach a class. For about 50 minutes, the students and I talked trade, reducing regulations on business and industry, Harvey recovery, and the day-to-day life of a Congressman. Let me tell you, there are some bright, young minds at LIT. Many thanks to Dr. Lonnie L. Howard, LIT, and the students!

￼
At the Beaumont Rotary Club.

Right after class, I met with the Beaumont Rotary Club. Southeast Texas is rich with energy, trade, and ports. We will not soon forget that, and we are doing everything possible to continue advancing the gains these industries bring to families, the community, and our economy. 

At the end of the day, all we can do is work hard and do our best to help others. “Service Above Self” isn’t simply a motto for Rotary Club, it’s a way of life. Southeast Texas leads by example, and the example you set is a gift to our community, our state, and our nation.

Read more about our visit in The News: www.panews.com/2018/10/17/weber-energy-trade-huge-us-rep-touts-current-economic-strength/

￼
A great morning with Olin employees.

Across our great district, we are concerned with safety – the safety of our families, neighbors, coworkers, and community. Olin recently received the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program Star Site award. This distinct award is given to the few who shine in their prevention and control of occupation health and safety hazards. The care employees put into making sure their workplace is a safe environment is outstanding. Olin is no exception. It was a pleasure to stop by, say hello, and walk through their gallery showcasing products and projects that will lead Olin into the future. Chemical manufacturing is an important industry that plays a role in our daily lives.

￼
Touring our ports by sea...

Our Coast Guard works around the clock to protect our nation and be prepared for whatever may come our way. We will never forget the Coast Guard's heroism and lifesaving rescue missions during Hurricane Harvey. My deepest thanks and gratitude to them. 

One of my priorities in Congress is reauthorizing Coast Guard programs. Our Coast Guard is tasked with search and rescue missions, illegal drug and migrant interdiction, oil spill prevention and response, and more. While visiting with Rear Admiral Thomas, we discussed these missions, the state of equipment, and Harvey, while touring the facility and port. 

￼
and by air!

We need people who understand liberty and freedom, our Declaration of Independence and Constitution are clear on these matters. We need people – no, make that Patriots – who understand freedom is not for sale and should never be taken for granted. Texas 14 , y'all get it. I am BLESSED to represent you.


Sincerely,
￼
Randy K. Weber

Subject: Fighting for Main Street
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | CONTACT
FIGHTING FOR MAIN STREET
￼
Small businesses are not only the lifeblood of our economy, but they create good jobs for Hoosiers and make our communities stronger.
This week, I visited one of these family-owned small businesses – Stephenson’s of Elkhart – to see up close how they help make northern Indiana a great place to live.
￼
It was an honor to receive the National Retail Federation’s “Hero of Main Street” award, which was presented by Stephenson’s owner Danny Reynolds and Indiana Retail Council president Grant Monahan.
I am committed to making sure our Main Street job creators have every opportunity to succeed.
Building on our economic momentum driven by tax cuts and regulatory reforms will allow small businesses and local retailers like Stephenson’s to continue investing in our communities, and it will help more Hoosiers achieve the American Dream.
PROTECTING HOOSIER JOBS
￼
We need to hold China accountable for unfair trade practices, but we need to do it in a way that doesn’t harm American manufacturers, farmers, workers, and consumers. 
I am committed to fighting for Hoosier businesses and workers, so this week I led a bipartisan group of 169 members of Congress in calling for a process that allows U.S. companies to request an exclusion from the recent tariffs imposed on $200 billion of Chinese imports. You can read our letter here.
This process would help U.S. companies retain global competitiveness, and it would help target the effects of the tariffs on China, rather than on U.S. companies and consumers. 
The administration should heed our bipartisan call to establish a strong exclusion process and ensure we stay focused on the real target, which is China’s unfair trade practices.
UPDATING LOCAL SERVICE CLUBS
￼
Our local service clubs play a vital role in making our communities stronger and making a real difference in Hoosiers’ lives.
This week, I had the honor of speaking with members of the Elkhart Rotary and the Kiwanis Club of South Bend about how we can work together to build a brighter future.
￼
I’m grateful for all these local leaders do to make northern Indiana a better place for Hoosiers to live, work, and thrive.
As always, it is a privilege to represent 2nd District Hoosiers in Congress.
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website and join me on social media:
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Sincerely,
￼
Jackie Walorski U.S. Congresswoman

Subject: Taking Action Against the Opioid Crisis
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Taking Action Against the Opioid Crisis
One of the great tragedies our nation is experiencing right now, particularly in East Tennessee, is the ongoing crisis involving opioid abuse. Opioids include legal prescription painkillers, such as OxyContin; illegal drugs, like heroin; and synthetic drugs, such as fentanyl. It is still shocking to me that just last year more Tennesseans died from a drug overdose than in car accidents. Chances are you know someone – a friend, a family member, a coworker – who has been affected by this crisis. This epidemic is decades in the making and affects everyone – Republicans and Democrats, young and old, urban and rural, and all classes of society. There is no single cause for how we got here, and there is no silver bullet for how we solve it either. What is most clear is that we cannot sit idly by and let this epidemic continue to ravage our country and our region.  
The good news is Republicans and Democrats in Congress are working together to make significant reforms and to provide the necessary resources to address this crisis. Two years ago, I voted to support the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act to expand education and improve treatment for individuals with substance abuse disorders. Earlier this year, I supported legislation that provided $4 billion to programs designed to prevent and treat opioid abuse, and I was grateful to see $1.2 million of this funding go to East Tennessee facilities to improve treatment and education on opioid abuse. At the end of September, I was also proud to vote for an additional $6.7 billion in funding to boost our substance abuse programs and expand access to mental health services.  
While a lot of attention was being paid last month to the Supreme Court nomination, I was proud to support a significant piece of legislation that flew under the radar, but will further impact our fight against this epidemic. H.R. 6, the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act, promotes treatment and recovery; improves prevention practices; gives law enforcement the resources they need to protect our communities; and boosts our efforts to crack down on synthetic drugs like fentanyl. This bill also ensures access to mental health and substance use disorder services for children and pregnant women under the Children’s Health Insurance Program; modifies the a previous exclusion so that women in institutions for mental disease can receive other treatments they need covered under Medicaid, such as prenatal services; and requires our country to develop best practices and guidance in an effort to improve care for infants with neonatal abstinence syndrome. I was extremely pleased to see this vital bill pass the both the House and the Senate with substantial bipartisan support, and I look forward to President Trump signing it into law.  
As a physician, I know doctors are one of the most important pieces of the solution. As we’ve learned a great deal about these drugs’ potency and their potential for addiction, prescribing guidelines must now change to help ensure fewer people get addicted in the first place. That’s why I introduced legislation to limit the number of days for an initial opioid prescription fill. Opioid addiction can start in as few as three days, and to address this issue I introduced H.R. 3964, the Opioid Addiction Prevention Act of 2017, which would create a 10-day limit on initial opioid prescriptions, with chronic pain, cancer, hospice and end-of-life and palliative care patients exempted.  
Additionally, illicit drugs like fentanyl are still coming into the United States from China and causing overdose deaths across the country. These synthetic opioids are dangerous, and I believe we need to make it easier for our law enforcement agencies to target suppliers of these dangerous narcotics. For this reason, I introduced H.R. 5298, the Modernizing Drug Enforcement Act, which will give the Drug Enforcement Administration the tools they need to combat any synthetic opioid compound, like fentanyl.  
I am proud Congress has come together on a bipartisan basis to address this serious issue. There is no question more work needs to be done, but I’m hopeful the steps we’ve taken will begin to reverse this devastating crisis that has impacted so many across the First District.  

My door is always open to East Tennesseans. Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

Subject: Great news!
Message:
District Update | October 20, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Lowest Unemployment Rate Since 1969
The economy is growing at historic rates. The unemployment rate is 3.7%, which is the lowest in my lifetime. There are 7.1 million open jobs in our country and 90% of workers are seeing bigger paychecks. The U.S. also has the world's most competitive economy for the first time in a decade.
Tax reform and our pro-growth agenda are working. More than 4 million workers have seen the benefits of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and over $4 billion has been paid in bonuses. Click here for a list of companies who have given bonuses, increased wages, and/or expanded benefits as a result of tax reform.  We have kept our promises to the American people. These are results, not rhetoric.  Get the facts here. 
Making the Tax Cuts Permanent
     ￼

Budget rules required Congress to sunset in 2025 the improvements to our tax code enacted in the tax reform package last December.   That's why I introduced H.R. 6760, the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act of 2018. This bill would make the tax benefits for individuals and small businesses enacted last year permanent so that families can continue to reap the benefits of tax reform for years to come.  
 
    ￼
Click here to watch the video of Davis speaking on his bill to make the tax cuts permanent. 
I am proud to say that the House of Representatives passed my bill to make the tax cuts permanent. This legislation represents my continued commitment to the millions of hardworking middle-class Americans.   
Growing the Middle Class
Tax reform is helping the middle class get ahead. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is putting more money in the pockets of the families I serve. In fact, the average family in the 13th district will save almost $2,000 in taxes this year.   We doubled the standard deduction, so it is now valued at $12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for married couples. We also improved the tax brackets which have lowered rates for all taxpayers. This helps nearly every middle class family in my district.   Taxpayers with children under the age of 17 can claim the Child Tax Credit to decrease the amount they owe the government each year in taxes. Under H.R. 1 Congress doubled the value of the credit from $1,000 to $2,000 for each qualified child. Additionally, even if a taxpayer has no tax liability for the year, up to $1,400 of the credit is refundable, meaning the government will send a check to the taxpayer up to that amount.   Make no mistake, tax reform is good for the middle class and I will continue to stand up for middle class families across my district.

Subject: HS Students in PA-02: Join me at Temple University!
Message:
News from Representative Evans
￼

Home
Contact
Services
Media
 
STUDENTS IN PA-02: JOIN ME!
￼ 
  
Join me next week at Temple University for my 2nd Annual National Services Opportunity Fair -- an event designated for middle, high school, and college freshman students who are interested in national service careers! 
For more information on this exciting event, please call (215) 254-3140.  
VOTING
In recent weeks, millions of Americans will actively engage in a sacred tradition that is rooted in democracy -- voting on November 6th!
I urge each and every one of you to tell your family and friends about the importance of voting and why we can't sleep on this year's midterms. Whether you are frustrated or content about the policies my colleagues and I propose, it's crucial for every American to vote in a mere 17 DAYS. 
November 6th is a chance for ALL Americans to make their voices heard and participate in an importance political process that will affect ones everyday life. 
Don't be that person who simply forgot to vote and looks back days, weeks, and years from now contemplating 'what-if' scenarios.  
Small Business Innovation Act
I'm proud to announce that my Small Business Innovation Act was signed into law! 
 
The Small Business Innovation Act will help out small businesses safeguard their intellectual property by expanding education on obtaining and protecting patents.
  
If we want to move our city forward and create a stronger Philadelphia block by block, it's imperative we enact policies that will protect our small businesses and foster their growth!
  
You can read more about this new law by clicking here. 
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Dwight Evans

Subject: Social Security announces 2.8% increase
Message:
￼ 


Saturday, October 20, 2018


Social Security announces 2.8% increase



Dear Friend: 
Welcome to your weekly update. As always, you can learn more about these and other legislative issue at my website: upton.house.gov. 
Social Security announces 2.8% increase
I am pleased to announce a 2.8% Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) increase for more than 67 million Americans in 2019. 
The COLA is one of the Social Security’s most important protections, which ensures benefits keep up with inflation. 
Social Security also recently expanded their Compassionate Allowance List, which has enables them to identify and fast-track cases where individuals have diseases that are most likely to be approved for disability benefits. 
Social Security is an earned benefit that Americans have paid into throughout their entire lives and I am committed to preserving and strengthening this vital program for today’s and tomorrow’s seniors. 
Federal Aviation Administration Reauthorization signed into law
The President recently signed the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act into law. 
This five-year reauthorization provides long-term stability for the Nation’s aviation community, continues investment in airports across the country, improves America’s competitiveness in the global aviation sector, strengthens passenger protections, and ensures the safety of the system for the traveling public.  
Also tucked in the FAA reauthorization is a PFAS provision which removes federal requirements that airports use firefighting foam containing the chemicals.
Back in Southwest Michigan
With no votes in the House this week, I am hard at work in Southwest Michigan. 
Just this morning, I celebrated National Breast Cancer Awareness Month at the Making Strides against Breast Cancer Walk in Portage. 
I spoke with students at Portage Northern Middle School about government and civility in politics, presented the Parchment football team with flags for their part in helping those affected by the water crisis, and shared my love of reading with students at Brown Elementary in St. Joseph – just to name a few!
To stay up to date on my work here at home, follow my Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages.
Have a great weekend and God bless,
￼
Fred Upton
Member of Congress

Subject: CVS Merger
Message:
News from Representative Crawford 
￼ 
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   
￼
 CVS Merger
What happens when major corporations that participate huge facets of our healthcare industry merge into one entity? The Department of Justice’s (DOJ) October 10 approval of the merger between CVS Health Corporation (CVS) and Aetna Inc. (Aetna) ensures we will find out. As you likely know, CVS is comprised of two sides – retail pharmacy and pharmacy benefit manager (PBM). PBMs manage the price negotiations between pharmacies and insurance companies. Aetna is one of the country’s largest health insurers, covering 22 million people. Both companies say the merger will allow them to better coordinate care and keep costs down for consumers. While this is a worthy goal, Arkansas’ history with CVS’s PBM does not instill much confidence in me that this merger will benefit Arkansans. 
In March, I sent a letter to the DOJ expressing my strong opposition to this merger, specifically asking them to consider how CVS has continued undercutting reimbursements to independent pharmacies, while reimbursing its own pharmacies at a higher rate. I am still concerned that this type of vertical integration could destroy competition, hitting our community pharmacists and leaving them the option to either constantly lose money or close business in rural, underserved areas, like the First District of Arkansas. CVS even had the gall to send letters to our pharmacists offering to buy them out during the times they were receiving poor reimbursements.
To me, not much good can come from this consolidation. I truly fear that consumer choice will be endangered and costs will increase for prescription medications. Community pharmacists are critical healthcare providers to folks in rural areas. They know their customers by name, ask about their families, and come in on weekends. Rural America stands to lose the most when monopolistic consolidation occurs and I will continue engaging with our pharmacists and other healthcare providers to inform and advocate for policies that facilitate fair competition resulting in access to quality, affordable healthcare. 
FAQ (What folks have been calling/texting my office about this week)
Q: I keep hearing that there is a caravan of 3,000 migrants headed for the US border, what is being done to stop them?  A: I have long been a supporter of funding a wall along our southern border. True immigration reform can not begin until we have secured our borders, if we don't we will continue to face these problems down the line. Last week, Rep. McCarthy introduced a border funding bill that I plan on supporting when it comes to the Floor for a vote. 
You can text me legislative concerns or questions at 870-292-6747
￼ 
Pine Bluff Commercial
DRA announces multi-million investment in Delta
“Infrastructure is a key ingredient in creating economic growth, and is a consistent struggle for many small towns in Arkansas’ First District,” said U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford. “I welcome these recent investments from the DRA which will help bridge the gap faced by many communities in rural Arkansas.”
￼

Subject: McKinley Talks Workforce Needs, Tax Reform, Diversifying WV's Economy
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online. 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT  |   SERVICES  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   OUR DISTRICT  |   CONTACT 
October 20, 2018 
McKinley Talks Workforce Needs, Tax Reform, Diversifying WV's Economy 
This past week, we traveled across the district to discuss workforce needs, tax reform, and diversifying West Virginia's economy. We had a busy week visiting Wood, Hancock, Doddridge, and Monongalia County.  We were pleased to host a roundtable with veterans from the American Legion Post 15 in Parkersburg, and to discuss WV's economic resurgence at the monthly legislative breakfast in Wood County. As always, we had lively discussions, and it was nice to catch up with old friends. Although there is more work to be done, there is a lot of optimism about things turning around for our state.   Click on the following to read more about our meetings:   McKinley Tours Former Johns-Manville Plant McKinley Hosts Roundtable with Local Manufacturers   
￼

WV Economy Benefits From Vital Federal Facilities 
It is vital that our local economy supports and expands the federal presence in NCWV. Federal agencies such as the National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) in Morgantown and the Criminal Just Information Services (CJIS) in Clarksburg employ thousands of people each year, attract private investment, and help diversify our economy. 
Click here to read more
￼

Job Openings Hit An All Time High 
Job openings have hit an all-time high throughout the United States and West Virginia. There are almost one million more openings than job seekers in the country. With unemployment at historic lows and investment in West Virginia on the rise, I am energized to keep the economic momentum going while continuing to tackle issues like health care and opiate addiction This is extremely good news for America, but also a reminder that we need to do a better job with matching workforce skills to demands.   Click here to read more
 
Pleasants Power Station Remains Operational 
The FirstEnergy Pleasants Power Plant will remain operational until June 2022. This announcement is positive news for the 160 workers and residents of Pleasants Co. who rely on the tax revenue from the plant. We still need action to prevent premature retirement of coal plants vital to our economic and national security.   Click here to read more

Subject: Rep. Smucker's E-Update
Message:
News from Representative Smucker  Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version 
￼
 
HOME
ABOUT
CONTACT
MEDIA
SERVICES
 
Thank you for subscribing to my E-Newsletter! This week I want to update you on my work on behalf of our veterans and their families, share some stellar economic news, and make sure you know where I am visiting in the district.  
I enjoy hearing from you and responding to your questions via email, phone calls, and letters. If you'd like to share your concerns or opinions with me, or if you have questions about legislation or specific votes, you can send me an email here. To stay up-to-date on my work in Pennsylvania and Washington, be sure to follow me on Facebook and Twitter. You can also check out my YouTube page here where there are 100+ videos, many of which are direct responses to your questions. 
I'm also extraordinarily proud of the casework my office has been able to complete for constituents. More than 1,800 cases have been completed, and more than $650,000 has been returned to constituents. The top four federal agencies with which you've requested help are the Social Security Administration, Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of State, and Department of Treasury.
If you need help with a federal agency, my office can often help cut through some of Washington's red tape. I'd encourage you to contact my district office at (717) 393-0667 if I can help in any way. 
 
￼ 
Our veterans, servicemembers, and their families have endured tremendous hardships and made significant sacrifices in their fight to preserve the freedom of the United States. We owe each of them a debt of gratitude we'll never be able to fully repay. But we can, and should, do everything we can to ensure their well-being.
You can read about all my efforts on behalf of our veterans, servicemembers, and their families here, and see some highlights below. 
Warrior Wellness Act 
I introduced the bipartisan Warrior Wellness Act in September to improve the mental health services provided to servicemembers by the Department of Defense. Some of the greatest wounds inflicted upon our brave service men and women are unseen. We should be treating these wounds as we would any other. Ensuring our troops have access to high-quality mental health services and are properly treated is critical to their safety, the safety of their fellow soldiers, and the effectiveness of our national defense.
Learn more about this legislation here. 
Home for the Brave Act 
I introduced the bipartisan Home for the Brave act to assist in the fight against veteran homelessness. Our veterans have put their lives at great risk to keep all of us safe back home. Our district has made great strides to eliminate veteran homelessness, and I am proud to stand with my constituents in this noble effort. 
Specifically, this legislation would exempt disability benefits from counting as income when determining eligibility for federal housing assistance program. To return home and be priced out of housing assistance simply because a veteran receives service-related disability benefits is just plain wrong, and my legislation would correct this problem.
Learn more about this legislation here. 
Expanding Military Apprenticeship Opportunities 
America's military is made up of hardworking men and women who wake up every day to serve others. We should be making it easier for them to transition to civilian life with a steady job, and infuse our workforce with leadership skills only the military can provide.
That's why I introduced, and President Trump signed into law, an amendment that expands opportunities for active-duty servicemembers to learn career skills and occupational training. Previously, less than half of our nation's military personnel had access to apprenticeship opportunities, but my legislation ensures every single member of our armed services has access. 
Learn more about this legislation here. 
If you are a veteran, or if you know a veteran, and you need help with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, I may be able to help. Please contact my district office at (717) 393-0667 if I can help you or someone you know. 
 
American Regains Rank as World's Most Competitive Economy 
￼ 
I recently visited Pennsy Supply Inc. in Manheim (pictured above) where I was shown around their facility and held a town hall with employees. Among many other topics, we discussed America's booming economy and how it is helping lift American businesses to new heights. 
A recent article in the Wall Street Journal reported that the United States has regained the top spot in World Economic Forum rankings "thanks to strong economic growth."
Here's a short excerpt from the article: 
"The report scores countries on how closely they match up to the competitive ideal. The U.S. scored 85.6 out of a possible 100. America's vibrant entrepreneurial culture and its dominance in producing a competitive labor market and nimble financial system 'are among the several factors that contribute to making the U.S. innovation ecosystem one of the best in the world,' the report said." 
This stellar economic news would not possible without the determination and optimistic spirit of American workers. You can read the full article here. 
Additionally, you can invite me to visit your business, volunteer organization, or simply set up a meeting with me in one of my offices by emailing me here. 
 
Here's Lloyd! 
￼ 
You can use the interactive map above to see the many different schools, volunteer organizations, manufacturers, and small businesses I've visited since taking office. If you'd like to invite me to visit you or an organization, you can invite me here. You can also schedule a meeting with me in one of my offices here. 
You can use the map here or by clicking on the image above. 
Since taking office, my staff and I have traveled more than 18,000 miles to meet with constituents. Between all my offices, I've hosted more than 500 meetings with constituents to hear about what's on their mind, and I've participated in more than 160 events with local businesses, schools, civic organizations, forums with constituents, or community resource centers. You can see all of these events using the map. In fact, I've supported more than 65 bills in the House of Representatives directly because of these important meetings -- that's about 1/3 of all the legislation I've cosponsored since taking office. 















Thank you for subscribing to my newsletter! You can stay up-to-date on what I'm doing in Washington and Pennsylvania by following me on Twitter and Facebook.

Sincerely, 
￼ 
Lloyd Smucker

Subject: The Scoop: Veterans History Project, Rx Prices, Year-round E15
Message:
￼ 

About Grassley
Constituent Services
News Center
Contact Grassley


Grassley Direct
On my weekly "Capitol Hill Report," I spoke with Brian Fancher of KLMJ Radio in Kampton and Paige Godden of the Guthrie County Times about Justice Kavanaugh, Iowa elections and Google.  
Q&A: Veterans History Project
Q: What is the Veterans History Project? 
Q: How can Iowans contribute to the Veterans History Project? 
Q: Is your office conducting interviews for the Veterans History Project? 

Quick Links
I'm inviting Iowa's veterans to attend a Library of Congress “Veterans History Project” event in honor of Veterans Day. The event will take place on November 9, 2018, from 8 a.m. – 4 p.m. at the Iowa Gold Star Military Museum in Johnston. The Veterans History Project collects and makes accessible firsthand interviews and narratives of United States military veterans from World War I through the present. Iowa's veterans are invited to contribute by participating in a 30-minute to an hour-long taped interview about their service in the military. If you are a veteran, or know a veteran, who is interested in participating, you can find more information here.  
  
President Trump’s decision to allow the year-round sale of E15 is a promise made and kept to farmers throughout rural America. Biofuels are a part of everyday life in Iowa, the top corn- and ethanol-producing state in the United States. In an op-ed I wrote with Senator Joni Ernst, we discuss the importance of ethanol and the Renewable Fuel Standard not only to Iowa and rural America, but also the nation’s economy and national security. 
  
No one buys a gallon of milk without knowing the price. Why should prescription drugs be any different? I applaud Health and Human Services Secretary Azar’s announcement to provide patients and their doctors with more information on prescription drug prices. This announcement follows my bipartisan work with Senator Durbin to support the Administration in advancing such a policy in recent legislation. Pharmaceutical companies must do more to provide transparency about prescription drug prices.
  
Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia and I led a bipartisan group of senators in sending a letter to Assistant Secretary for Family Support Lynn Johnson, urging her to implement recommendations from a recent Health and Human Services report that would help foster children who have been prescribed psychotropic medications. It is critical that the Administration for Children and Families immediately take steps to ensure that states are providing treatment planning and monitoring to ensure that children are being prescribed psychotropic medications safely and appropriately.
Post of the Week
￼ 
Wk 22 #cornwatch break in corn harvesting to start soybeans # 1 concern of farmers are the beans when moisture level is right. Can’t artificially dry beans so we will keep going until beans are done. Then back to corn

Early Voting Has Begun 
Dear Friend- 
One-stop early voting is underway in North Carolina, and will continue through Saturday, November 3, 2018.  If you are not already registered to vote, you may register and cast a ballot on the same day during the one-stop early voting period. 
Each county in the First Congressional District has at least one early voting site.  If your county has multiple early voting sites, you can cast your ballot at any site in the county in which you reside.  For more information on one-stop early voting locations, visit: https://www.ncsbe.gov/Voting-Options/One-Stop-Early-Voting. 
Election Day is Tuesday, November 6, 2018.  In order to vote on Election Day, you must be registered to vote and may only vote in your specific precinct.  To check your voter registration status, visit: https://vt.ncsbe.gov/RegLkup/ . 
Please visit https://www.ncsbe.gov/index.html for any questions you may have about voter registration, early voting, or casting a ballot. 
Below is a list of early voting sites in the First Congressional District and their hours of operation.  Remember, for one-stop early voting, you must cast your ballot at any site in the county in which you reside, but on Election Day you must vote at your specific precinct. 
Sincerely, 
               ￼           G. K. Butterfield             Member of Congress

Subject: POTUS brings water to Valley
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Jeff Denham
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼



￼
 
DENHAM.HOUSE.GOV
ABOUT
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
ISSUES & LEGISLATION
NEWSROOM
CONTACT


October 19, 2018 
Dear friend,  This afternoon I was honored to join President Donald Trump, where he signed a Presidential Memorandum to improve storage and delivery of water in the Central Valley. My number one priority has always been to deliver more water to the Central Valley. This order will reduce regulatory burden to and promote more efficient environmental reviews of California water storage projects, ensuring that Valley farmers and residents have a supply of water for generations to come. I truly believe that bringing White House officials to the Valley to see firsthand the challenges we face was the catalyst for today’s announcement. This is the first time the administration has ever gotten personally involved in the California water crisis.  Last month I sent a letter to the White House asking the president to take immediate action to stop Sacramento’s radical water grab and address the future of Don Pedro Reservoir. This order directly addresses hydroelectric relicensing like what is currently happening at Don Pedro and requires agencies to consider local plans like the Tuolumne River Management Plan developed by Modesto and Turlock Irrigation Districts. This process has been held up by Sacramento Bureaucrats who are using the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to shut down hydropower generation and drastically increase flows on the Tuolumne River by essentially holding the Department of Energy, Department of Interior and Department of Agriculture hostage through the hydropower relicensing process as they try to flush large amounts of our usable water into the ocean. Earlier this year, I released an animated video on NMFS Sacramento’s dangerous power grab, which can be viewed here.   The president’s order also establishes timeliness for environmental reviews of infrastructure projects by creating a single federal authority to approve new water projects in support of the Central Valley Project. This will supplement my New WATER Act (H.R. 434), which will be signed into law as early as next week as part of  America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018 and supports innovative financing opportunities for water projects throughout the western United States. Eligible projects include new reservoirs, below ground storage projects, recycling and desalination projects. This legislation supports large projects like enlargement of Shasta Dam, construction of Sites Reservoir and Temperance Flat Dam, and expanding Los Vaqueros Reservoir.  For more information about what I’m doing to fight for Valley water, visit Denham.house.gov/water.  Top Army Corps official visit addresses flood protection, Sacramento water grab Before I joined the president this morning, I met with Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works Rickey “R.D.” James, who came out at my invitation to tour our federal levees and to discuss impacts of Sacramento’s water grab, the Waters of the United States definition, the recently passed Water Resources Development Act, regulations and permitting. The last time I visited this levee was in February 2017, when it breached. Now, federal funding has been secured and dirt is being moved to harden this life safety infrastructure.
￼ 
Stanislaus County pilot program looks to improve healthcare access Following 18 months of coordination with the California Medical Association (CMA) and the Stanislaus Medical Society, I’ve developed a pilot program through the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation to significantly improve access to healthcare for Medi-Cal patients in Stanislaus County. CMA’s executive board recently voted to proceed with the project. Nearly 45 percent of Stanislaus County residents are currently enrolled in Medi-Cal but face major barriers to timely care; low reimbursement rates in the state of California have made it difficult for Valley physicians to see more Medi-Cal patients. My pilot program will field-test the best Medicaid reimbursement strategies to incentivize more physicians to operate in areas with a high population of Medicaid enrollees, like California’s Central Valley. This is the only model of its kind and is structured to be scalable for other communities with similar challenges across the Valley and the nation. Access is the biggest healthcare problem we have in the Central Valley. This project will improve physician reimbursement rates and bring more doctors and better care to our community.  To read my full press release on this announcement, click here, and to review the full proposal, click here.   Human trafficking roundtable seeks to end Yesterday I hosted a roundtable on human trafficking prevention in Modesto. Attendees included Rescue:Freedom, the CA Travel Association and Hilton Hotels. In addition, an official from the Department of Homeland Security briefed the group on the department’s anti-trafficking campaigns (the Blue Campaign) and what federal resources are available to local organizations.  This event was a follow-up to my August roundtable, from which attendees left with better knowledge about how they can help combat human trafficking. One example of resulting action came from the ride-share company Uber, which, as a result of discussions with other attendees, implemented new best practices with their 1,400 active driver partners in the 10th congressional district. Drivers now have a more prominent feature within the help section of their driver app to access resources such as the National Human Trafficking Hotline, and victims can now get out of a dangerous situation and to a safe place nearby by connecting with local organizations to arrange and dispatch rides, in real time, regardless of whether the rider has a smartphone.  More human traffickers are caught in California than any other state. We must turn this tide. I’m proud to be able to bring together leaders from across our community to find solutions and deliver results. 
￼
Local vets honored by Library of Congress, 21 new Veterans History Project videos submitted On Tuesday, I hosted a reception at the Manteca VFW Hall to honor the 32 veterans who shared their stories of service as part of the Library of Congress Veterans History Project. Karen Lloyd, director of the Veterans History Project for the Library of Congress, was present to accept the most recent installment of 21 videos and meet the Central Valley veterans featured in them. As a veteran myself, it’s been an honor sitting down to hear these stories from local men and women who have worn the cloth of this nation. This event was about saying “thank you.” To view all of my #TVT tributes, click here. For photos from the event, click here. 
CLICK HERE TO WATCH THE EVENT HIGHLIGHT VIDEO  ￼ 
Check out my new veterans e-newsletter and subscribe Each quarter, I distribute a special edition newsletter with the latest veterans news out of Washington. This newsletter can be found in local VFW Halls and on my website, or you can subscribe to receive it directly in your inbox by visiting www.Denham.house.gov/vets and filling out the form at the top of the page. The last edition included information about my VA COST SAVINGS Enhancement Act, my Vet-to-Farm amendment in the NDAA, and my work to ensure homeless veterans have equal access to housing assistance through the Department of Veterans Affairs. Click here to view the most recent edition online.   Upcoming Mobile District Office Hours I have two Mobile District Office Hours (MDO) in the next week where constituents can meet with representatives from my district staff for assistance with variety of services and issues, including Medicare, Veterans Affairs, Social Security and the Internal Revenue Services (to name a few). For a full list of scheduled MDOs, visit the Upcoming Events section of my website. Casework assistance is always available through my Modesto office as well by calling 209-579-5458.  Tuesday, October 23 – Ripon 1-2 p.m. Ripon Chamber of Commerce 104 South Stockton Ave, Ripon, CA 95366  Thursday, October 25 – Denair 10:30-11:30 a.m. Denair Community Services District 3850 North Gratton Road, Denair, CA 95316  In the News October 19, 2018 Trump to jump into Western water wars ahead of midterms  Annie Snider, Politico  October 17, 2018 MID says it’s close to having more water storage in Merced County dam  Thaddeus Miller, The Merced Sun-Star  October 17, 2018 Congress Approves Bill Supporting Study of Lake McClure Storage Project (Raising the Spillway) in Mariposa County, MID Says  The Sierra Sun Times  October 17, 2018 EPA Acting Administrator Visits Central Valley  The Oakdale Leader  October 13, 2018 Denham gets EPA’s ear on state’s Delta water plan  The Manteca Bulletin  Sincerely,

Subject: Think Pink, #FamiliesBelongTogether, USC, and Upcoming Events!
Message:
View this email in your browser 
￼ 
Fighting to Find A Cure
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Dear Lindsey, 

October is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month and last week I had the honor ‪to join fighters and survivors of breast cancer at the 7th Annual Compton Walk for a Cure. Many thanks to Compton City Councilwoman Janna Zurita and Compton Unified School District Vice President Satra D. Zurita for uniting our community and ensuring that those with this disease, never have to walk alone.

Together, we can defeat breast cancer. 

In Community,
￼
Nanette Diaz Barragán
Congresswoman, California's 44th District 

#FamiliesBelongTogether
￼ 
It was truly a labor of love at last Saturday's Long Beach Immigrant Rights Coalition’s Evening of the Giving Spirits Dinner. Thank you for recognizing me with the Immigrant Justice Award. This honor only drives me to work harder for our immigrant community against this Administration’s anti-immigrant policies.

Inspiring the Next Generation of Lawyers
￼ 
I enjoyed visiting my alma mater, USC Gould School of Law, to speak to students from Dean Guzman’s class about my law school experience, career as a lawyer, and public service as Congresswoman of California's 44th Congressional District. Delighted to inspire the future generation of lawyers to break barriers and Fight On!

Veterans Welcome Home Event
￼ 
Join me next Friday, October 26th as I host a Welcome Home Event for Veterans from 10:00AM - 2:00PM at the VFW Post 5394 (303 E Palmer St. Compton, CA 90221). 

The goal of this event is to connect veterans with other veterans in our Congressional District and to inform them of the many services and resources available to them once they return home from service.

To RSVP, please call (310) 831-1799 or email rsvp.barragan@mail.house.gov. For more information on the event, click here.

If you are a vendor or exhibitor who is interested in attending the event to provide information on the services your organization offers to veterans, please contact our office.

Join Congresswoman Barragán at CalEITC4Me's 2018 Women’s Economic Empowerment Summit on October 25th!
￼ 
How can we reverse these trends and break down the barriers that keep women off the path to stability, upward mobility, and long-term prosperity in our Golden State? CalEITC4Me, a statewide campaign initiated by Golden State Opportunity Foundation, began as a leader in the effort to bring awareness to the California Earned Income Tax Credit (Cal EITC) and other benefits that put more money in the pockets of working families throughout California.
 
I'm honored to be a featured speaker at CalEITC4Me's 2018 Women's Economic Empowerment Summit on Thursday, October 25th from 8:30AM - 2:30PM at the South Gate Municipal Auditorium (4900 Southern Ave, South Gate, CA 90280). I'll be joining more than 150 leaders in the fight against poverty to discuss smart policy solutions like my legislation to expand the earned income tax credit that can lift women out of poverty and break open the doors of opportunity.

The event is free and open to the public. To register for the event, click here.

                                                  Dear Friends,  President Trump today signed a presidential memorandum that will significantly improve California's water supply, particularly in the San Joaquin Valley. The president's action will remove bureaucratic obstacles to improving the water supply and speed up the completion of new biological opinions that will enable more water to be directed toward Valley farmers, families, and communities. Having watched the Valley's water crisis deepen for many years, I can say this is the most meaningful presidential action on the issue in decades.   Along with other Republican congressmen, I joined President Trump for the signing ceremony. Message:

A message from Georgia's 6th Congressional District
￼

Home
About District 6
How Can I Help?
Issues
Newsroom
Contact


 
October 19, 2018
This Week in GA-6  
This week was spent meeting with constituents across the district, getting feedback about how Washington can work better for you, and how the revved up economy is impacting hard-working families. 
Second Lady Karen Pence also visited the 6th District, and we stopped by Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta. We met several remarkable children and learned how art and music therapies are making a difference for these courageous young fighters. Check out a few pictures from our visit and from other events across the district this week.
￼ 
Visiting Children's Healthcare of Atlanta with Second Lady Karen Pence  
￼ 
With great performers at St. Elias Antiochian Orthodox Church's Mid-East Festival  
￼ 
Speaking with constituents that belong to the Association of Mature American Citizens (AMAC)  
￼ 
Having a great time with the Roswell High School Congressional Youth Council  
Additionally, The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6) is now on President Trump’s desk and ready to be signed. The opioid crisis is wreaking havoc on families and communities across America, and our community is among the hardest hit. Hundreds of thousands of American lives have been cut short by prescription drug abuse. With this critical legislation, we are taking a big step towards tackling this crisis.
Thank you for taking the time to read this note. To stay current on what's going on in Congress, please follow me on Facebook by clicking here or visiting Facebook.com/RepKarenHandel. If you find this update helpful, please take a second to forward it along to a few of your friends and neighbors.  
In addition, because of rules from the House of Representatives, I will not be able to conduct live tele-town halls after August 8th through Election Day. As always, feel free to call (202) 225-4501 or (770) 998-0049 if you need assistance from me or anyone in my office.
As always, thank you for the opportunity to serve you. 

Sincerely, ￼  Karen C. Handel Member of Congress

Subject: Central American Caravan Headed towards the US
Message:
￼
October 19, 2018
Visit My Website | Share on:
￼￼

Central American Caravan Headed towards the US
Several thousand potential illegal immigrants have traveled through Central America hoping to cross into Mexico and eventually into the United States. While the Administration has taken swift action to thwart this event, we can't rely on help from other countries to protect our borders. I’m encouraged by the actions of our Administration in coordination with Mexico. We must keep the immigrants from illegally entering our country and abusing resources that are meant for our citizens and those here legally. 

￼
 

Packages Overseas Subsidy Termination Act

This week the Administration announced it is withdrawing the United States from the Universal Postal Union, ending postal subsidies that cost Americans millions of dollars and lost jobs. Currently, it's cheaper to ship a package from China to Dallas, than from Dallas to Ft. Worth. Under the new system, Americans will no longer pay higher shipping rates to subsidize inbound international packages. Americans should never have shouldered this expensive burden so foreign suppliers can inexpensively ship their goods, hurting American businesses. Additionally, the United States Postal Service (USPS) is a major gateway for the import of fentanyl and other synthetic opioids from China. Eliminating these subsidies will restore fair pricing for foreign suppliers, decreasing the number of packages and providing less opportunity for importing narcotics. This announcement achieves the same goals as my bill, H.R. 5524, the POST Act, and I look forward to working with the administration to implement this new system. 

￼

Coppell High School named Best Student Newscast in the Country

Coppell High School was named the best student run newscast in the nation yesterday by the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences (NATAS).  As part of a country wide student awards production, Coppell High School's newscast bested 200 other students from 19 regional chapters that advanced to the national competition. Coppell was representing the Lone Star Emmy Chapter, which includes the entire state of Texas. I'm honored to represent Coppell High School in Congress and commend the hard work by our exemplary students. 

￼

National Breast Cancer Awareness Month
October is National Breast Cancer Awareness month. Providing an opportunity to raise awareness and bring attention to the most common cancer among women worldwide. Breast cancer has been steadily declining since 1990, with early detection and improved treatment options playing a major role, but more can be done. On average, every 2 minutes a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer and over 3.3 million breast cancer survivors are living in the United States today. I'm encouraged to see institutions in our community providing potential life saving cost free services, click the link below to read more:  Local hospital provides no cost health education events and mammograms  
￼

Deregulation Drives Growth and Cuts Costs
In fiscal year 2018 alone, the Administration saved American businesses and families $23 billion by cutting costly and unnecessary bureaucratic red tape. Eliminating 12 regulations for every one created, deregulation has cut costs for small businesses, freeing up resources to create more jobs and raise wages and benefits. Investing in our workforce and stifling big government intervention has allowed companies to provide better products and services, giving new life to all aspects of business operations. We need to continue cutting expensive and draconian regulations that stifle growth and expansion for our small businesses. 
￼

￼
Click to Connect with Kenny
With Weekly Updates from Washington & the 24th District. 
It is an honor to represent you in Washington and I value your input. Please don't hesitate to contact one of my offices or e-mail me at marchant.house.gov/contact.

Subject: Latest News from Congressman Steve Cohen
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Congressman Steve Cohen 
￼ ￼ 
Website
|
Serving You
|
Legislative Work
|
Our District
|
Resources
￼
October 19, 2018 
 
Dear Friend, 
This week, I attended the Freedom Awards at the National Civil Rights Museum, wrote to five pharmaceutical companies about high drug prices and their tax windfall, expressed my concern about unprocessed voter applications, noted the local impact of DNA evidence in solving crimes, attended the swearing in of Juvenile Court Magistrate Alycia Carter Chism, visited students at Crosstown High School, talked to students at the Memphis Business Academy, read about my recent visit to constituents at the U.S. Naval Academy, planned next Friday’s “Congress On Your Corner,” invited veterans to my annualVeterans Day event,offered some U.S. Capitol Society calendars and provided a health tip involving earthquake preparedness. Keep reading to learn more about my week and follow me on Twitter and Facebook to see more updates as they happen.  
Honoring National Civil Rights Museum Freedom Award Winners  Demanding Answers from Big PHARMA on Drug Prices  Pressing Shelby County Elections Officials for Answers  Noting the Local Impact of DNA Evidence in Solving Crime  Attending Swearing In of Juvenile Court Magistrate Alycia Carter Chism  Visiting Crosstown High School Students  Talking with Students at Memphis Business Academy  Reading about Visit to 9th Congressional District Midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy  Holding “Congress On Your Corner” next Friday  Inviting Vets to MyAnnualVeterans Day Gathering  Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars  Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter  Weekly Health Tip  Quote of the Week  


Honoring National Civil Rights Museum Freedom Award Winners 
￼ 
On Wednesday, I attended the National Civil Rights Museum’s Freedom Award Student Forum and helped honor “Keeper of the Dream” student winners Sarah Rosenthal of Germantown Middle School, Timmy Becton Jr. of Douglass High School, Xinya (Cindy) Tan of White Station High School and Cameron Jones of Marion High School in Arkansas as well as the Bridge Builders cohort of Caitlin Robinson from the Hutchison School, Lakia Coakley from Middle College High School, Aaliyah James from Overton High School, Elena Matadefrom Bellevue Middle School and Aniya Mull from Soulsville Charter School. They are keeping the dream alive. 
That night, I attended the NCRM’s Freedom Awards and saw former Vice President Joe Biden, civil rights leader Jesse Jackson and Memphis entrepreneur and philanthropist J.R. “Pitt” Hyde honored for their lives of public service. Biden told the crowd at The Orpheum Theater that we are living through “a battle for the soul of this nation.” The 27th awards ceremony was infused with the music of the late, great Memphis native Aretha Franklin, who passed awayin August, and whose grandchildren were in the audience. Fifty years after the assassinations of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and of Senator Robert Kennedy, on whose staff Biden was working in 1968, it was an especially moving and memorable evening.  
Demanding Answers from Big PHARMA on Drug Prices 
On Monday, I joined 15 colleagues in sending letters to the CEOs of five large pharmaceutical companies that benefit from corporate tax breaks and publicly funded research, demanding answers to the problem of soaring prescription drug prices. The five corporations to which we wrote – Amgen, AbbVie, Eli Lilly, Merck and Pfizer – each benefitted from last year’s GOP tax bill with windfall tax cuts. We want to know why, despite receiving massive amounts of U.S. taxpayer support, the companies are charging prices that place life-saving medications out of the reach of many Americans. We also asked if they had discontinued any drugs in development and, for those companies scaling back employment in their research divisions, what business factors affected those decisions. We concluded the letters by asking how much their top executives are getting paid. I will continue to press this issue and get answers on these important public policy issues. 
Pressing Shelby County Elections Officials for Answers 
Today, when I went to vote I was disturbed to learn that the voting booth large screen format that I chose does not follow the law in terms of how the candidates’ names are placed on the ballot.  Tennessee law requires that the names of the major parties’ candidates be listed first and second and then independent (non-party affiliated) candidates listed after. When I chose the large screen format, I discovered that the second major party candidate’s name doesn’t even appear on the first page of the large format.  I have contacted the Shelby County Election Commission as well as Secretary of State Tre Hargett to express my concern.   It is the duty of election officials to ensure that ballots are in order as required by law before the first voter steps into the booth, and that federal voting rights are protected.   
Earlier in the week,  Iwas disappointedwhen it became clear that 24,000 pending voter registration applications in Shelby County still had not been processed even as Early Voting for the Midterms got under way. That, combined with the Shelby County Election Commission’s assertion last week that 55 percent of the voter applications it had received were invalid, raise critical questions. As a senior member of the House Judiciary Committee, whose jurisdiction includes oversight compliance with theVoting Rights Act, I believe this matter is serious. We have an ugly history in this country of voter suppression, especially against prospective African American voters. We need to ensure that all who have the right to vote have that right upheld in this election. I havewritten to the commission and am continuing to press for answers.  
Noting the Local Impact of DNA Evidence in Solving Crime 
This week, welearned about the recent use of DNA evidence to win a conviction against the perpetrator of an 18-year-old rape that occurred in southwest Memphis. That evidence was finally tested 12 years after the crime occurred. DNA analysis is a powerful tool to bring about justice, but that doesn’t happen when rape kit evidence sits on shelves untested. I have amended multiple House bills to increase funding to for rape kit analysis to address a shameful nationwide backlog. Since 2014, my amendments have increased funding for the Department of Justice’s Sexual Assault Kit Initiative (SAKI) by 36 percent. Congress must continue to provide funding to ensure that all rape kits get tested and all perpetrators are brought to justice. I commend the prosecutors in Memphis for their persistence. 
Attending Swearing In of Juvenile Court Magistrate Alycia Carter Chism 
￼ 
On Wednesday, I attended the swearing in of Alycia Carter Chism as a Magistrate for the Memphis and Shelby County Juvenile Court. Alycia Carter was my first associate district director and counselin my Congressional office and I was proud to recommend her to Judge Dan Michael. The Magistrate said her black robe is not just black garment but a symbol of responsibility, and she pledged to handle every child who appears before her with care, dignity and respect. She will do us proud. 
Visiting Crosstown High School Students 
￼  
On Monday, I visited with the 9th grade students of Crosstown High School and came away impressed with their zeal for learning and their knowledgeable questions.These bright young people are our future, and I look forward to watchingtheir progress. 
Talking with Students at Memphis Business Academy 
￼ 
Also Monday, I visited teacher Justin Cole’s class in the auditorium of the Memphis Business Academy and talked with students about the importance of their roles as U.S. citizens, the need for criminal justice reform, public investment in college education and immigration reform. The students asked smart questions. They are a dedicated group and should go far. 
Reading about Visit with 9th Congressional District Midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy  
My visit with 9th Congressional District midshipmen at the U.S. Naval Academy, which I mentioned in last week’s newsletter, was the subject of a story last Saturday in The Daily Memphian. See it here.  
Holding “Congress On Your Corner” Next Friday 
As your representative in Congress, part of my job is making sure your concerns and issues with federal agencies and federal benefits are dealt with fairly and expeditiously. My office will be on hand Friday to help you with Social Security, Medicare, veterans benefits and military service issues, Small Business Administration (SBA) loans and services, Federal Housing Administration (FHA) home loans, federal grant applications, visa and passports, Internal Revenue Service (IRS) issues and more. When: Friday, October 26, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m.. Where: The Parkway Village Branch Library, 4655 Knight Arnold Roadin Memphis.    
Inviting Vets to My Annual Veterans Day Event 

￼ 
Words cannot adequately express the gratitude a grateful nation owes its military veterans for their dedication to our country and the sacrifices they have made. My annual Veterans Day gatheringis a time to thank them and their families and enjoy some barbecue while we discuss veterans issues. My 10th Annual Veterans Day Meeting and BarbecueLuncheon will be held on Monday, November 12, from noon to 2 p.m. at the Kroc Center of Memphis – Hardin Hall, 800 East Parkway South. Vets please RSVP by Thursday, November 8 at (901) 544-4131.  
Offering U.S. Capitol Historical Society Calendars 
￼ 
My office will soon have a limited number of 2019 U.S. Capitol Historical Society calendars available. If you would like to receive a calendar, please complete this formon my website. Due to the rules of the House, I can mail calendars only to residents of Tennessee’s 9th Congressional District. Please feel free to share this email with other residents of the 9thCongressional District who may be interested in receiving one but who do not receive my e-Newsletter. 
Signing Up for “Congress On Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter 
￼ 
I enjoy meeting regularly with constituents in the district and helping get answers for them to questions about dealing with federal agencies. If you are interested in attending one of my “Congress on Your Corner” events, you can sign up here to receive notification as soon as the next event is scheduled. 
For those who haven’t participated in a telephone town hall, it’s easy to sign up for them by using this form.   
If you would like to receive this weekly e-Newsletter, or share it with others, you can do that with this form. 
Weekly Health Tip 
￼ 
District staffer Patti Marsh participates in earthquake drill 
Each week, I share a health tip in the hope of promoting a healthy lifestyle for residents of the 9th Congressional District. As always, it is best to check with your doctor before making any changes to your diet, exercise routine or lifestyle. 
More than 3 million people across the Central U.S., including the staff in my Memphis office, participated in Thursday’s “Great Central U.S. Shakeout” earthquake disaster drill. Our region is particularly susceptible to serious earthquakes like the ones that shook the New Madrid Fault Line running from Marked Tree, Arkansas, to Cairo, Illinois, in 1811 and 1812, and created Reelfoot Lake when the Mississippi River ran backwards for a while. Those quakes rang church bells in Boston and collapsed chimneys for hundreds of miles in all directions. There are very useful resources from the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s “Earthquake Safety Checklist” (tips: update emergency contacts and learn how to shut off gas lines and purify water) and from the web page of the drill this week to help you prepare for an earthquake and plan ahead to make sure your shelter will be resilient. It’s always time to prepare  for “the Big One.” 
Quotes of the Week  
￼ 
“America’s ability to lead the world depends not just on the example of our power, but on the power of our example.” – Former Vice President Joe Biden, “Reclaiming America’s Values,” The New York Times, September 14, 2017. 
“Forces we thought we had buried, fights we thought we had won -- they're lashing back once again, testing our humanity, our decency, with the same old tactics that represent one of the oldest most insidious forces in America.” – Former Vice President Joe Biden after receiving this year’s National Civil Rights Museum Freedom Award Wednesday.  
Two Tigers teams meet in Memphis-Missouri game Saturday. Go Memphis!  
As always,  
I remain, 
Most sincerely, 
￼ 
Steve Cohen Member of Congress  
  
￼ 
￼ 

￼ 

￼
Memphis 
167 North Main Street,
Suite 369
Memphis, TN 38103
Phone: (901) 544-4131
Fax: (901) 544-4329
Washington, D.C. 
2404 Rayburn
House Office Building
Washington, DC 20515
Phone: (202) 225-3265
Fax: (202) 225-5663
