Subject: Work Week with Congressman Faso
Message:
￼ 
  

Share on: 
￼ ￼
Work Week with Congressman Faso
Table of contents
	•	Tomorrow: Dutchess County Veterans Resource Fair
	•	Discussing the Importance of NY Waterways 
	•	Celebrating CRMC's New Generator
	•	Benefiting the Arkell Museum through Farm-Fresh Food
	•	Joining Seniors at Columbia Co. Golden Gathering
	•	Antiquated Scaffold Law Continues to Drive Up Costs
	•	Honoring Eagle Scout Christopher
	•	Touring Cricket Valley Energy Center
	•	Supporting Increased Mental Health Funding
	•	Helping our Seniors
	•	Taking Action to Stop International Drug Trafficking through the U.S. Postal Service

Tomorrow: Dutchess County Veterans Resource Fair 
Join me TOMORROW, Saturday, October 20th, at the Pleasant Valley Town Hall located at 1554 Main St. in Pleasant Valley for my Dutchess County Veterans Resource Fair. From 10:30 AM to 12:30 PM, local veterans will have the chance to meet and speak with representatives from community outreach programs as well as from county, state, and federal agencies.
If you have any questions, feel free to contact my Kingston District Office at (845) 514-2322. Additional information on the event can also be found here: https://bit.ly/2PHG3wL

￼

Discussing the Importance of NY Waterways 
We are fortunate to have many dedicated community members who work tirelessly to preserve our waterways for communities upstream and the millions of downstream residents, small businesses, and habitats impacted by our actions on a daily basis. I had the ability to participate in the Choose Clean Water Coalition Upper Susquehanna Forum at SUNY Oneonta yesterday and speak to many local advocates about the importance of a healthy watershed to our local economies and to our environment.
In Congress, I have made protecting our outdoor spaces and local waterways a top priority. I recently supported an appropriations bill that provided over $70 million for the Chesapeake Bay Program. This program seeks to protect the bay and its watershed, which extends all the way up to our district in Upstate New York. As I reaffirmed yesterday, I will continue to reach across the aisle to coordinate on bipartisan initiatives and policies that safeguard our environment.
￼

￼


Celebrating CRMC's New Generator
I visited Catskill Regional Medical Center earlier this week to celebrate the installation of their new, state-of-the-art, fuel efficient generator. Through my efforts working with hospital officials and FEMA, I was able to help CRMC secure a grant to cover 75% of the generator’s purchase and installation costs. CRMC had been seeking this funding since Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012. The generator will allow the hospital to continue to provide life-saving care to the community through flooding and other emergencies.
￼


Benefiting the Arkell Museum through Farm-Fresh Food
I attended the Harvest Feast to benefit the Arkell Museum in Canajoharie, which featured some great locally grown, farm-fresh food. The museum is dedicated to preserving the rich history, culture, and art of the Mohawk Valley. Given their unwavering commitment to the community, I have formally nominated the Arkell Museum for the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Medal for Museum and Library Service.  Thank you to the museum's Executive Director Suzan Friedlander and Library Director Hannah Stahl for showing pieces from the Portraits and Landscapes Collection – they were magnificent. 
You can learn more about the Arkell Museum here: http://www.arkellmuseum.org/
￼


Joining Seniors at Columbia Co. Golden Gathering
I joined area seniors at New York State Senator Kathy Marchione’s Golden Gathering in Columbia County. This event was open to local seniors and allowed them to connect with programs, organizations, and benefits that are available to them. I had the privilege of co-hosting a table for attendees to sign Christmas cards for our troops.
Our Upstate seniors have spent years building and contributing to our communities – it was great meeting and speaking with many of them. If you, or a senior you know, is experiencing difficulties with a federal agency, such as the Department of Veterans Affairs or the Social Security Administration, my office may be able to help. Feel free to call my Kinderhook District Office at (518) 610-8133 to speak with a caseworker.

￼

￼

￼

Antiquated Scaffold Law Continues to Drive Up Costs
New York's outdated Scaffold Law added between $200 and $400 million to the cost of the new Gov. Mario Cuomo Bridge. It is estimated that each year we spend an extra $785 million to cover increased insurance premiums on construction projects in our state. This money that could be going toward building roads or bridges is instead going to artificially high insurance costs. Reform is needed now, and that is why I have introduced legislation that requires projects that use federal taxpayer dollars to have the exact same liability standards used by 49 other states.
You can read more about the impact this wasteful law has on the costs associated with construction in New York State here: https://bit.ly/2NT7dz2

More information on my bill to change the federal liability standard, H.R. 3808, can be found here: https://bit.ly/2xN4DXB

Honoring Eagle Scout Christopher
Attaining the rank of Eagle Scout is no easy feat – it takes time, dedication, and a commitment to one’s community. I had the privilege of joining Christopher at his Eagle Scout Court of Honor on Sunday. His Eagle Scout project consisted of making a sign for the Town of Kingston and the Sawkill Fire Department as well as constructing a stone wall and flower beds. Congratulations, Christopher!  
￼

Touring Cricket Valley Energy Center
Thank you to the team at Cricket Valley Energy Center (CVEC) in Dover for showing me around. It was great talking with many of the workers and being able to witness the significant construction progress of the facility. CVEC is a 1,100 MW natural gas power plant on a 193-acre site. 
CVEC will provide countless economic benefits to our region, from offering low-cost electricity to creating good-paying jobs and generating valuable tax revenue for the Town of Dover and the surrounding areas. 
￼

￼

￼

￼

Supporting Increased Mental Health Funding 
Mental health has been a top priority for me during my time in Congress. I have supported over $1.5 billion in funding for various programs to help support the mental health of our veterans and children and to assist communities more effectively identify and treat mental illness.  The $120,000 grant awarded to HealthAlliance Hospital to increase awareness of mental health in the Kingston area is only one of many steps the government has taken to put more emphasis on treating mental illness and to better equip our local schools, hospitals, and local officials to support the overall mental health of our communities.   Read more about the funding HealthAlliance recently received from the federal government here: https://bit.ly/2J3Bo5w

Helping our Seniors
Last year, I met with Greene County Senior Corps RSVP volunteers and participated in their Meals on Wheels program. Meals on Wheels is an invaluable program that helps our senior neighbors. I assisted on a bipartisan effort this year to increase funding for the Older Americans Act to Provide Access to In-Home and Nutrition Services, including Meals on Wheels. As a result of our advocacy we were able to obtain an increase to the program that funds Meals on Wheels in the appropriations bill my colleagues and I recently voted on in the House.  In 2017, Meals on Wheels served over 22 million meals to New York seniors alone. Balanced and healthy eating keeps seniors secure in their own homes and in their communities. I will continue to support this great program, and thank you to all the dedicated volunteers who help deliver nutritious meals throughout our Upstate communities.  Read the bipartisan letter my colleagues and I sent advocating for robust funding for the Older Americans Act, including the Meals on Wheels program: https://bit.ly/2J6BKsh
  
￼

Taking Action to Stop International Drug Trafficking through the U.S. Postal Service
According to the Postal Service Office of Inspector General, “Online drug traffickers typically send packages via a shipping provider, including the Postal Service, and have become familiar enough with the postal network to exploit it.”
The Postal Service Office of Inspector General recently released a report on illicit drug distribution through the postal network. This report underscores the serious loopholes in the U.S. Postal Service that are being used by nefarious drug traffickers to push deadly drugs through our borders and into our communities.   The STOP Act, a bill I advocated for in the House that is soon to become law, would thwart this practice by requiring advanced electronic tracking data on international packages being relayed through the U.S. Postal Service. This way, law enforcement will know where packages are coming from, where they are going, and what their contents are. The STOP Act will have a real impact in stemming the ongoing opioid crisis in communities throughout New York and across the country.
More on drug traffickers exploiting the U.S. Postal Service found here: https://wapo.st/2J6mWK4
You can read the full report here: https://bit.ly/2pZmNiR

Subject: Here to help!
Message:
News from Representative Bustos 
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
Grants Resource Fair 
￼
Congresswoman Bustos greeting attendees at her Grants Resource Fair 
Yesterday, I held my second Grants Resource Fair with special guest State Representative Mike Halpin. It was great to meet all of the local non-profits and government agencies who came out to learn more about the application process for state and federal grants. I’m pleased so many folks joined us and took advantage of the tools and resources our state and federal agencies have to offer. If you are interested in learning more or would like to apply for a grant, please do not hesitate to contact my office for support along the way. Click here to see more. 
Protecting Social Security, Medicare & Medicaid 
￼
Congresswoman Bustos visiting with residents of Langman Apartments this morning 
Today, I visited Langman Apartments in Milan to meet with residents and listen to their concerns regarding Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. It was a pleasure to meet so many folks and listen to all the experiences and stories they had to share. It’s clear just how important these programs are to so many people, which is why I’ll continue to fight to protect them. Especially after Washington Republicans once again expressed their desire to cut them this week to offset budget deficits created by the GOP Tax Scam. Instead, I’ve helped Democrats develop a plan that would lower healthcare costs and tackle the rising price of prescription drugs. See more from my visit here. 
To keep up on the work that I am doing to fight for the hardworking families of Illinois, make sure to stay connected with me @RepCheri!            
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
Have a great weekend, 
Cheri

Subject: Opening Close Up Summit
Message:
Email not displaying correctly? Click here.
￼ ‌ ￼ ‌ 
￼

This Week in Congress
October 19, 2018

• Opening Close Up Summit
• GDP: a worthwhile investment
• Let's Read! Rota
• Emergency food aid for Rota
• National Principal Shadowing Week
• Unforgiven: righting student loans
• If you served, register!
• $131k for outdoor recreation plan
• NMC visits Washington
• Opportunities
• Legislative Highlights
￼
￼

Opening Close Up Summit. About 80 students took part in the three-day Close Up Youth Summit this week, identifying issues of concern to our community and brainstorming policy responses. In Congress we budgeted $900,000 for Close Up this year, to pay for the summit and for students to spend two weeks on the mainland learning about their power and responsibility as citizens. I opened the summit on Tuesday thanking the students for recognizing their new, adult role in determining how to make life better for all of us. 
￼
￼

GDP up 25.1 percent. Gross Domestic Product in the Northern Marianas increased 25.1 percent in 2017, the sixth straight year of growth.  
￼
￼
￼

GDP: a worthwhile investment

Gross Domestic Product in the Northern Marianas increased 25.1 percent in 2017, the sixth straight year of growth. The Director of the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, Dr. Brian C. Moyer (pictured above), briefed me shortly before the public release on Thursday. Congress provides $750,000 to pay for production of the annual economic data. The funding covers American Samoa, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and the Marianas. GDP is the sum of goods and services produced in a territory, state, or nation over a given period of time and is a primary means of gauging economic health. GDP is also invaluable in policy decision-making. To pass the Northern Mariana Islands U.S. Workforce Act, for instance, one of my key talking points was the conclusion by the Government Accountability Office that ending the CW program would cut GDP by 26 to 62 percent. That was language that everyone understood. Director Moyer and I also discussed where to take the program next. Quarterly reports may be a development to consider in future.
￼
￼

Let’s Read! Rota. As part of my on-going “Let’s Read!” initiative, I delivered a total of 50 boxes of books to Sinapalo Elementary School, Dr. Rita H. Inos Junior-Senior High School, Eskuelan San Francisco de Borja, and Antonio Camacho Atalig Memorial Library. Your congressional office has hand-selected over 50,000 books and I will continue to deliver them to eager readers. Thanks to the students, teachers, librarians, and principals for their warm welcome. 
￼

Emergency food aid for Rota

Up to 643 Rota households may be eligible for emergency food assistance and up to 103 existing food stamp recipients may get supplemental aid under the federal Disaster Nutrition Assistance Program. In a letter dated October 16, the U.S. Department of Agriculture Food and Nutrition Service informed Governor Torres that the agency has approved D-NAP for Rota families affected by Typhoon Mangkhut. Only people who lived or worked in Rota on September 9 are eligible. Benefits will be based on household size. The CNMI Department of Community and Cultural Affairs will accept applications from October 22 to 26, between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m. at the Rota Youth Center in Sinapalo. Rota residents who were displaced by the typhoon can apply during the same five-day window at the CNMI NAP office in Saipan or at the DCCA office at the San Jose Public Gymnasium in Tinian.
￼

￼

National Principal Shadowing Week. Principal Leila Staffler led me on a “power walk-through” of Kagman High School on Thursday, visiting classrooms, observing teachers, talking to students, and generally assessing the quality of learning taking place in her school -- all while taking notes with an app on her smartphone. I am impressed! Principals across the nation hosted elected officials in their schools this week to give us a firsthand look at the challenges and opportunities school leaders face, and the impact of education policy on students. For instance, I got to see how students are using laptops purchased with funding I included for Marianas schools in Section 1014 of the Every Student Succeeds Act, P.L. 114-95. Thank you, Ms. Staffler, for the warm welcome and the eye-opening visit. 
￼

Unforgiven: righting student loans

Along with 116 Democratic colleagues in the House and 36 in the Senate, I demanded answers from Education Secretary Betsy DeVos this week and a quick resolution to her Department’s mishandling of the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program. For graduates, who work full-time for a government or not-for-profit organization, the PSLF program is supposed to write off the balance of their federal direct student loans after 120 qualifying monthly payments. Public servants with student debt first became eligible for the loan forgiveness in September 2017, and over 28,000 individuals have applied. But Department data released in September 2018 show that only 96 borrowers were approved—a denial rate of 99.6 percent. And a report by the Government Accountability Office sharply criticized the department for mismanagement. The Trump administration must act quickly to ensure that all qualified teachers, first responders, and other public servants, who have worked for ten years expecting loan forgiveness, get what the law requires.
￼
￼

If you served, register! Our Veterans Registration Drive continues this weekend and next at Joeten Superstore in Susupe. The more veterans we get registered, the better our chances that the feasibility study I included in the VA MISSION Act will recommend a VA-staffed Community-Based Outpatient Clinic, or CBOC, for Marianas veterans. Your congressional staff and the CNMI Office of Military and Veterans Affairs office will be there at the registration table from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. to answer any questions you may have about benefits. 
￼

$131k for outdoor recreation plan

The Commonwealth Department of Land and Natural Resources has been awarded a $131,162 Land and Water Conservation Fund grant to update the State Comprehensive Outdoor Recreation Plan, the National Park Service announced on Tuesday. DLNR will use the grant to pay for technical assistance refresh the plan for the Northern Marianas from 2019 to 2024. Established by Congress in 1965 and funded through oil and gas royalties from federal lands, the Land and Water Conservation Fund enables local governments to improve existing parks and other recreation areas in their communities. Congratulations to DLNR.
￼
￼

Northern Marianas College in DC. Associated Students of NMC President Ken Gabrido, NMC Student Leadership Coordinator Alexis Cabrera, and ASNMC Vice President Shanthia Espinosa visited their congressional office on Thursday. They were in Washington to attend the 2018 National Student Government Summit. With more than 100 training workshops and roundtables, the summit provides over 700 student leaders nationwide with networking, research, and information resources designed to improve student government. Thank you for visiting. 
￼

OPPORTUNITIES

Grants:
	•	Enhanced Hunter Education and Safety
	•	Cooperative Watershed Management

Jobs:
	•	Support Services Assistant
	•	School Support Assistant
	•	Store Manager
￼

LEGISLATIVE HIGHLIGHTS

THIS WEEK AND NEXT WEEK

The House is in recess for the District Work Period.

Subject: A major development for homeowners with crumbling foundations
Message:
News from Representative Courtney  Having trouble viewing this email? Click here!     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
  
Dear  , 
I would like to provide you with the following updates from this past week.   
￼
Congressman Courtney touring CNC Software INC with CEO Meghan West
Visiting Submarine Suppliers in Northcentral Connecticut  
This week I had a chance to visit two great Eastern Connecticut companies that supply the Virginia-class program at Electric Boat. They are just two of the more than 400 Connecticut companies that participate in the supply chain, fueling work at the shipyard in Groton.   
First, I visited Willington Nampleate is a family owned business in Stafford Springs, and their plating products provide a non-corrosive method of identification for submarine systems that ensure safe operation. Thanks to the CEO at Willington Nameplate Mike Goepfert for showing me around. Next, I headed over to CNC Software INC in Tolland, a company with nearly 200 employees, that sells software programs to hundreds of customers including defense firms such as General Dynamics Electric Boat and Lockheed Martin. I took a tour of their enormous facility with CEO Meghan West. Their products are essential of the Virginia-class program. They serve a necessary function for our national security by securing the onboard computer systems of one of the most complex platforms in the U.S. Navy.   
These companies are just two examples of the hundreds of exciting and innovative companies in our district and across the state that are growing alongside the increase in submarine production at Electric Boat. As Ranking Member of the Seapower subcommittee, I will continue to continue to fight for shipbuilding right here in Eastern Connecticut.  
￼
Courtney and Larson Announce Major Development for Crumbling Foundations  
On Tuesday, Congressman John Larson and I announced a brand-new tax clarification from the IRS which will provide relief for middle-class homeowners with crumbling foundations. The IRS clarification will allow homeowners to “carry forward” or “carry back” a net operating loss should their casualty loss exceed their income. This clarification means that even if the net loss suffered by a homeowner exceeds their annual federal tax liability, they can carry forward that loss for up to 20 years and can carry back for two years. This development is going to have significant implications for middle-class homeowners whose repair costs exceed their annual income.  
This clarification builds on the critical development that Congressman Larson and I announced last year that the IRS would allow homeowners to claim a casualty loss on their 2017 tax returns to recoup the costs of repairing a home foundation. This announcement is the result of more than two years of work we have done with the IRS to secure this critical tax deduction for homeowners in our state. We are grateful for the continued attention of the IRS and Treasury Department to this crisis in Connecticut, and the support they have provided today to homeowners struggling with the damage caused by crumbling foundations. Also, we are grateful to have had the support of the Connecticut Society of Certified Public Accountants and their Executive Director, Bonnie Stewart, in this effort. 
Our work is not done, and we will continue to work with officials at every level of government to solve the crisis of crumbling foundations in our state. 
￼  
Gemma E. Moran United Way Food Center Celebrates 30 Years of Service 
I joined the 30-year anniversary celebration of the Gemma E. Moran United Way Food Center in New London last week. During that time, the food center has helped prevent thousands of people from going hungry. The festivities included honoring Gemma Moran who has dedicated her life to helping those in need and ending hunger in our community. We were also joined by dozens of volunteers including a group of new hires, from Electric Boat who came out to do their part to contribute to the community. These women represent a new wave of skilled labor joining our local companies big and small as shipbuilding and submarine production continues to expand. All in all, it was a truly magnificent event, and I would like to thank United Way, Gemma Moran, and all the community partners and volunteers who made it possible. 
I hope you enjoyed this snapshot of my work, and as always thank you for taking a moment to read my weekly update. If you have any questions or concerns about the information in this newsletter, you can contact me through my website or by calling my Norwich district office at 860-886-0139.   
Have a great weekend,                                  
￼  Joe Courtney Member of Congress 
  
 ￼ ￼

Subject: Newsletter From Congresswoman Shea-Porter
Message:
Open this e-mail in its own browser window  
News from Congresswoman Shea-Porter
￼
NEWS FROM THE FIRST DISTRICT
Dear Friends,                                  
I visited Gilford High School to see all the innovative work teachers and the principal are doing to educate our students. I also enjoyed talking to the students! 
I sent a letter to Secretary of Homeland Security Kirsten Nielsen asking her to resign. Her department’s treatment of children has been unconscionable and one of the darkest moments in our history. 
Visiting Gilford High School 
It was a pleasure to visit Gilford High School this morning, and to see all the innovative work being done to enhance the educational experience for Gilford students. School principals and teachers across our state are working hard to help our students succeed and to ensure that they have access to high quality education. Today’s visit was an opportunity to highlight the good work that our principals and teachers are doing, and to recognize Gilford High School for its efforts to innovate in the classroom. Schools in New Hampshire and across the country need more resources to improve school infrastructure and the classroom environment, and it’s important that both the state and federal governments provide more funding for our public schools.
￼ 
Calling for new sanctions on Saudi Arabia and asking what the US knew before the Saudi operation to murder Jamal Khashoggi 
This week, I sent a letter to Office of National Intelligence Director Dan Coats asking him what the US knew about potential Saudi plans to silence Jamal Khashoggi. I am deeply concerned that the Trump Administration has yet to address this egregious violation of human rights by the Saudi Crown Prince with the seriousness that it demands. We must sanction Saudi Arabia in response to this brazen attack, and I support ending arms sales to the Kingdom. 
Calling on DHS Secretary Nielsen to resign 
I signed a letter this week to Secretary Nielsen once again urging her to resign. In our letter, several Members of Congress wrote, “We formally request that you resign as Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). You are responsible for the unimaginable trauma of thousands of children across the United States. From the children torn from their parents at the border, to Dreamers facing exile from their home, and to the U.S. citizen children who face losing a parent to deportation; your actions continue to wreak havoc on communities across this nation. In order to restore our values and the public’s trust in the DHS, we demand your resignation and urge the reversal of the policies implemented at DHS and DOJ designed to destroy families.”
Announcing $800K in funding for trauma support services to help children exposed to substance misuse 
On Thursday, the Congressional Delegation announced that the US Department of Justice has awarded the City of Manchester with nearly $800,000 to improve a project that provides services to children exposed to trauma, including substance misuse, domestic violence, and sexual assault. 
Children who are dealing with traumatic experiences deserve all the help we can provide. Our communities need more funding to help vulnerable children when the opioid epidemic or violence at home disrupts their lives. The Manchester Police Department’s Adverse Childhood Experiences Response Team (ACERT) Enhancement Project plays an important role in this effort by offering services that support young victims who have experienced trauma, and I am pleased that it will be getting this significant federal funding. Congress must keep working to ensure our communities have all the tools they need to protect children in the midst of this devastating epidemic.
New funding headed to UNH for Aquaculture Programs 
This week, I announced that UNH has received $747,673 from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) through the NOAA Sea Grant 2018 Aquaculture Initiative. The funding will support a UNH project that seeks to boost U.S. seafood production. The project will specifically include workshops on farming steelhead trout and blue mussels. In August, I had a great time visiting Virgin Oyster Company, which has been working with Sea Grant to sustainably farm oysters in Little Bay. 
From supporting oyster farmers to helping fishermen sustainably harvest their products, New Hampshire’s Sea Grant program continues to bring tremendous benefit to our Seacoast economy. Congratulations to my alma mater UNH, to Dr. Chapman, and to the entire Sea Grant partnership on receiving this funding. It has been a privilege to support the Sea Grant program in Congress, and I look forward to seeing it continue to thrive and help our state’s fishermen and businesses. 
Calling on Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to address her department’s failure to faithfully implement the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program 
A new Government Accountability Office (GAO) report has revealed that an alarming number of public service loan forgiveness (PSLF) borrowers have been denied the loan forgiveness they are entitled to. Under this program, student loan borrowers can have their loans forgiven over many years if they pursue work in public service. 
This week, I joined Democratic Members of Congress in writing to Secretary DeVos. “Consumer advocates, state regulators, Members of Congress, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and GAO have all repeatedly raised alarms about the Department’s handling of the PSLF program,” we wrote in our letter. “Not only has this Administration ignored the mounting warning signs…but it has actively reduced oversight of student loan servicers—thereby contributing to the current problems in student loan servicing.”
“We are deeply troubled that millions of dedicated public servants may not obtain the loan forgiveness that they deserve if the Department does not act quickly to correct program implementation issues.”  
Visiting the New Hampshire Farm Museum 
I had a great time at the New Hampshire Farm Museum in Milton! Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, the museum showcases the historic Jones farmhouse and Plummer Homestead. 
Closing thoughts 
I am proud that I just received a perfect score on the Human Rights Campaign’s Congressional Scorecard! I will never stop fighting for LGBTQ communities. One of my proudest moments was helping to repeal Don’t Ask Don’t Tell, and it’s been wonderful to see LGBTQ rights move forward the last decade. Now we need to protect the progress made.
Best Wishes, ￼  Carol Shea-Porter Member of Congress ￼￼ 
Recent Press Releases 
	•	New Hampshire Delegation Joins Democratic Colleagues to Call on Secretary DeVos to Release More Information about the Department’s Failure to Faithfully Implement the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program
	•	NH Delegation Announces $800K in Trauma Support Services to Help Children Exposed to Substance Misuse
	•	Shaheen, Hassan & Shea-Porter Announce More Than $700,000 for UNH Aquaculture Training Program
	•	NH Delegation Honors Recipients of 2018 Congressional Law Enforcement Awards

Subject: Crucial reminder:
Message:
￼ 
Hi Lindsey – I wanted to send a quick and crucial reminder. Have you had your flu shot yet?

As a doctor and the former Chief Medical Officer of Sacramento County, I can’t emphasize enough how important it is to get your flu shot. It’s the single best way to protect yourself and the ones you love from the flu. The Centers for Disease Control recommend that anyone who is six months old and older should receive a flu shot once a year. 

If you haven’t gotten your flu shot yet, there’s still time. Sacramento County’s Department of Health and Human Services is hosting free, public flu clinics.

Please click here to learn more about upcoming flu clinics near you.

￼
I got my flu shot today. Have you had yours?

You can also call (916) 875-SHOT (7468) to learn more or to ask a question.

According to the Centers for Disease Control, flu symptoms can occur suddenly and may include fever, muscle and body aches, cough, and sore throat. Though most people generally recover in a couple weeks, the flu is a serious disease that leads to thousands of American deaths every year.

If you haven't already gotten your flu shot, please don't delay. And remember - you can help stop the spread of germs by washing your hands and staying home if you're sick.

Be well,
￼
Ami Bera, M.D.
Member of Congress

P.S. Your thoughtful suggestions always help my office do a better job of serving you. 

What did you think about this email update? 
￼ I liked it. Thank you! 
 ￼Sorry, I thought it could have been better.
 
Other: Not sure / I have a suggestion.

Listening to you is my most important job. Thank you for taking a moment to share your thoughts.

Subject: Shameful
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative David Cicilline 
￼
SERVING YOU  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATIVE WORK  |  OUR DISTRICT
 
October 19, 2018
 
 
 Dear Friend,   Earlier this week Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blamed our country’s growing deficit on Social Security and Medicare. He refused to acknowledge that the massive tax cut he and fellow Republicans passed for the richest Americans contributed to the financial predicament we now face.  Social Security and Medicare are programs that hard-working Americans earned, and just days after making false claims about these programs, Senator McConnell doubled down by saying Republicans will keep trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act. If they succeed, they will take away protections for 130 million people with pre-existing conditions, raise health care costs, impose an age tax on older Americans, and eliminate access to coverage for millions of working people.  Democrats remain committed to fighting for the people by working to protect access to affordable health care, lower prescription drug prices, and ensure retirement security. We will pass a tax cut for the middle class rather than working on behalf of special interests that fund Republican campaigns.  COASTAL STATES  This week I participated in the Annual Fall Coastal States Organization membership meeting. It was great to join leaders and advocates from other states to discuss the importance of working together to protect our coastal communities, resources, and economies.  While coastal counties in the United States make up less than 10% of the total U.S. land area, they are home to a significant portion of our country’s population - 40% or 125 million people.  And coastal counties make up an important part of our economy. In Rhode Island, the coastal economy supports more than 240,000 jobs and generates more than $17 billion annually.   Recognizing the significance of coastal communities, their economic impact, and how important their existence is to such a large portion of our population is incredibly important.   That’s why in Congress I’ve been proud to work on preserving natural resources and waterways, and remain committed to combating the effects of climate change and reducing our dependence on fossil fuels.   This year, I lead the New England Delegation in the House in signing on to the New England Coastal Protection Act, which would prohibit the expansion of oil and gas drilling off the coast from Maine to Connecticut.   And I will continue to advocate for strong funding for the Southern New England Estuaries Program.  We have a responsibility to ourselves and future generations to be responsible stewards of the environment.   Too many Republicans in Congress along with the Trump administration are beholden to fossil fuel companies and working in the interest of big corporations and not the American people they represent.   In Congress, I will continue fighting for the values we share as champions of the environment.  RHODE ISLAND SEA GRANT   This week I was proud to announce along with the rest of our state’s congressional delegation an award of $745,815 through the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to the Rhode Island Sea Grant program at the University of Rhode Island. This award will support a training curriculum for entry-level aquaculture workers in our state. Federal work-training investments like this help create good-paying jobs and allow potential employees to gain critical skills needed for this industry.  Aquaculture is an important industry in the Ocean State and has grown drastically over the past several years. This federal investment will help close a skills gap and allow more people to get good jobs in this expanding industry.  INVESTING IN OUR CHILDREN  I was glad I got to join so many Rhode Islanders at Children’s Friend’s annual Investing in Our Children luncheon today. Children’s Friend is our state’s oldest child welfare agency and provides extremely caring and effective services to some of the most vulnerable members of our society.   Each year this organization provides services to more than 30,000 Rhode Island children and families.   It is the responsibility for all government officials – federal, state, and local – to work together with our partners in the private and non-profit sectors to support these efforts and ensure that no child falls through the cracks. In Congress, I’m proud to continually fight to strengthen programs that benefit children and families including:  • Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) which ensures 9 million children are provided with low-cost health insurance.  • Child Care Development Block Grant which helps families access quality, affordable child care.  • Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), which supports low-income mothers and young children who have or are at risk of developing nutrition-related diseases and disorders.  • Head Start, which offers education, health, and nutrition services to economically disadvantaged children, as well as parenting and employment support to parents.  I promise to continue to advocate for robust funding for these programs to ensure that every child has their basic needs met and the chance to get ahead.   
￼ 
 REFOCUS GALA   On Thursday, I attended ReFocus' 12th Annual Auction and Gala in Providence to raise awareness for members of our community with different physical and developmental needs.   ReFocus is a non-profit human service agency that is dedicated to offering opportunities of growth to adults with developmental disabilities so that they are able to thrive in a loving, trusting, and challenging environment. The organization does incredible work to serve our community.   I was proud to help them raise awareness and recognize their Executive Director, Christine Kavanagh, RSM, for 45 years of dedicated service.   As always, if you or someone you know has any questions or concerns, please call my office at 729-5600 or send me an email at David.Cicilline@mail.house.gov.  You can also click here to follow my work on Twitter.   Warm Regards, ￼  David Cicilline Member of Congress

Subject: From the Front...
Message:
News from Representative Steve Womack
￼

HOME 
| 
ABOUT STEVE 
| 
SERVICES 
|  
3RD DISTRICT 
|  
ISSUES & LEGISLATION 
|  
NEWSROOM 


October 19, 2018 
WEEK IN REVIEW
￼
To start off this week's From the Front... I would like to thank all of the Arkansans who stopped by my Washington office during their visits to our nation’s capital, including Lani and Grayson Guilmette from Centerton, the Hale family from Fayetteville, the Hecht family from Bentonville, Chris Peterson from Fayetteville, Lindsey Huntsman from Fayetteville, the Farris family from Bentonville, Zachary and Leesha Smith from Bentonville, Mika and Connor McFadden from Fayetteville, the Perry family from Rogers, the Garrett family from Bentonville, the Arnwine family from Bentonville, Jerry and Melissa Chatham from Rogers, the Robinson family from Hartford, Rosemary Fusaro from Eureka Springs, Amalee and Matthew Schwartz from Eureka Springs, and the Swindle family from Bentonville. Safe travels back to the Natural State!
￼
It was another busy week in the Third Congressional District! With October being National Manufacturing Month, I thought it would be the perfect time to visit manufacturing facilities across AR-3. My team headed out to the Pernod Ricard facility in Fort Smith, where I spoke to employees about the importance of career and technical education (CTE) programs. With job opportunities – for a range of industries – booming across the nation, it’s important that workers are trained and have the skills needed to access high-demand, well-paying jobs for the 21st century. 
￼
I then met with local leaders from ABB, Trane, Mars, and the Fort Smith Chamber to discuss projects and workforce development in our community. Workforce training was again a leading topic of discussion, and I gave them an update on the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act. This bipartisan bill strengthens the U.S. career and technical education system. It gives states and schools increased flexibility and resources for job training and technical skills programs. These companies discussed how the booming economy has led to an increased demand for skilled employees, but that there aren’t always enough qualified applicants to fill vacant positions. We need to ensure workers are equipped to compete in a 21st century economy. Legislation like this is critical to closing the skills gap and ensuring hardworking Americans have the tools needed to pursue their American dream. I was pleased to let them know that the bill was recently signed into law by President Trump.
￼
My next stop was to the Glatfelter facility, where we watched materials get turned into wet wipes and other household products. It's always interesting to see how things are made! I’m proud of our district’s strong manufacturing sector. My goal is to always keep this opportunity growing.
On Wednesday, I started my day with the Bentonville Rotary Club. I provided them with an update on recent things happening in Washington and policy priorities. We also talked about the importance of uniting our divided country and being engaged and informed citizens. I appreciated their time and look forward to visiting again soon!
￼
Our veterans represent the very best of America. It was a privilege to be with NorthWest Arkansas Community College (NWACC) as its Veteran Resources Center announced the creation of its own challenge coin to honor students who’ve served our country. The coins will be presented to veteran graduates, and I couldn’t be prouder of these hardworking students.  It’s inspiring to see these brave men and women further their education – and I am forever grateful for their service. While at the ceremony, I challenged NWACC President Dr. Evelyn Jorgenson to present her challenge coin. She was caught without it! You know what that meant: push-ups! Thank you to NWACC for allowing me to be with you for such a special event – and as always, thank you to our veterans! 
￼
I ended the day at Childcare Aware of Northwest Arkansas, where I met with employees and learned more about their initiatives to support local families. The organization’s mission is to improve child care and advocate for the safety and development of all children. One aspect they focus on is protecting kids during natural disasters and other emergency situations. It’s crucial to know the steps one should take before, during, and after a disaster strikes – and they are providing the resources to ensure families know how to do just that.  Their work is creating a stronger and more resilient community! 
￼
One of the best parts of my job is seeing the range of companies that operate in Northwest Arkansas. I stopped in Berryville to get a behind the scenes look at the work being done at Ducommun. Their innovative manufacturing supports quality jobs in our district. Importantly, their work also ensures that our military is equipped with the tools and technology they need in the field.
￼
I finished up the week at PAM Transport. I had the opportunity to meet their hardworking employees and learn more about the company. I also took a ride in one of their new tractor-trailers to see the advanced technology they are equipped with. American truckers keep our economy strong!  Products in our homes and stores have all been transported in trucks between cities, states, and across the country. Safe travels to all these dedicated drivers. They keep the U.S. moving!
Just in case you missed it, it was reported that the U.S. was named the world’s most competitive economy for the first time in a decade! America is leading again thanks to strong economic growth and opportunity!
Wishing everyone a great weekend! Remember to keep an eye on my website or check out my Twitter and Instagram pages to stay up-to-date with the latest news from the Third District and Washington. 

From the front...
￼  Congressman Steve Womack Arkansas Third District 
￼
￼

Subject: Congressman Sessions Hill Report: Week of October 15-19, 2018
Message:
News from Congressman Sessions      
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
The Hill Report   A Weekly Newsletter from Congressman Pete Sessions Week of October 15 - October 19, 2018
This month, I ask you to join me in recognizing National Disability Employment Awareness Month. Often times, capable individuals with disabilities who want to work still face many obstacles when looking to join or re-join the workforce. For example, while about 40 percent of Social Security Disability Insurance beneficiaries say that they are interested in working, studies show that the share who succeed in returning to work is much lower. 
I have seen firsthand the difficulties a disabled person may face when looking for a job. My son, Alex, is a hardworking and fun-loving young man who also has Down Syndrome. As a father, I was worried that Alex may not find an employer and work place interested in taking advantage of the many wonderful qualities and skills he has to offer. I am proud to say that Alex now works as a greeter at The Home Depot and is thriving. He offers a personal and friendly greeting to every customer he comes in contact with and some folks even come in specifically to see him. It is important for businesses and corporations to see the value of hiring those with special needs and I am proud to say that many of our Dallas area companies have already taken great strides to show that people with disabilities can be productive employees.  
￼ 
Congressman Sessions with his son, Alex Sessions. 
I am also very proud to offer internship opportunities to bright young students with special needs. Morgan is a student at George Mason University, Class of 2019. Every week, Morgan interns in my Washington, D.C. office and is a tremendous help to my staff. She assists with typical intern tasks like folding constituent letters and delivering Dr. Pepper products to our hardworking Capitol Police Officers. I have no doubt that Morgan will go on to do many amazing things professionally. All she needs, and what all disabled people need, is to be given the same opportunity as everyone else. 
￼ 
Congressman Sessions with one of his Washington, D.C. interns, Morgan. 
I encourage all employers and workers to include a person who may have a disability in their workplace. I am sure you will see, just as I have, that their abilities far outnumber their disability.
  
Events in the District  National Physicians’ Council for Healthcare Policy (NPCHP)  Since I was first elected in 1996, I have engaged with physicians from across the country to better understand the issues impacting their patients, and I have met with individuals who cannot afford to pay the costs of soaring healthcare premiums or do not have access to healthcare choices that meet their needs.  
I have also hosted bi-annual meetings for the National Physicians’ Council for Healthcare Policy (NPCHP) in both Washington, D.C. and in Dallas. Established in 2014, the Council aims to provide a national voice for physicians engaged in private practice so that America can restore physician autonomy and create a framework where physicians can do their job better in a competitive, transparent market place. During our fall meeting this week in Dallas, we discussed several issues ranging from drug shortages and drug pricing to new discoveries in Alzheimer’s and Neurodegenerative diseases. It is always a great pleasure to host this event and I look forward to fostering discussion on the many issues concerning healthcare today. For more information on the NPCHP, I encourage you to visit: http://npchcp.org/ 
￼  Congressman Sessions speaking at the NPCHP Fall Meeting in Dallas, Texas. 
Dallas Regional Chamber 2018 Congressional Forum This week, I was honored to participate in the Dallas Regional Chamber 2018 Congressional Forum alongside my colleague Congressman Marc Veasey (D-TX) of District 33 to share my views on the issues affecting North Texans. We discussed a wide range of issues including my efforts to promote long-term economic growth and the need to maintain a robust partnership and a strong trade agreement among our neighboring countries. While we may disagree from time to time, I am proud to serve Texas alongside my colleagues in Washington, D.C. and look forward to continuing to work on behalf of the people of North Texas. 
￼  Congressman Sessions visiting the Dallas Regional Chamber of Commerce. 
Have a great weekend,  
￼
Pete Sessions U.S. Congressman

Subject: Rep. Grothman Newsletter - The World's Most Competitive Economy
Message:
￼ 
  

Economic News
This week, the U.S. economy regained the title for the most competitive economy on the global stage. It has been a decade since the United States held this title, and thanks to our commitment to pro-growth economic policies, including tax reform, the U.S. economy is back on top. The report, published by the World Economic Forum, cited that the process of bringing company operations back to the United States and the repatriation of manufacturing facilities has drastically helped the economy over the past several months.

While our economy is currently booming, some of the greatest news about this rapid recovery is that it shows few signs of slowing down. JP Morgan CEO, Jamie Dimon, has expressed his belief that the economy will only continue to get stronger in the foreseeable future, and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell described the U.S. economic outlook as remarkably positive.

Evidence to back up those statements includes that wages are finally catching up with the economy. In September, overall hourly wages were up 2.8% from a year earlier and low income earners are seeing more money in their paychecks. With job openings at record highs, it is important that we find constructive solutions to filling job positions across the board so that our economy continues at this pace. 

Impact of Tax Reform 
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act has provided immense support to many residents throughout Wisconsin and within the 6th district. This year alone, tax reform has helped create nearly 23,000 jobs in Wisconsin, many of which have included employment opportunities in important economic sectors such as manufacturing.

Tax reform has not only helped create new job opportunities, but also is putting more money in the pockets of hard working Wisconsinites. Recently, the Heritage Foundation published a report detailing the impact it would have on districts and communities throughout the county if this important piece of legislation were to be repealed. 

The graphic below indicates that people in the district would be at risk of losing anywhere between $18,000 to $19,999 in take-home pay over the 2020-2029 period if tax reform was repealed. Tax reform is helping people in Wisconsin and its important to know how and why. For more information click here. 

￼
  

Fulbright Awards
I am proud to announce that three individuals from the 6th district received this years Fulbright award. The Fulbright Program, established by Congress in 1946, awards individuals for their outstanding academic work and distinction. 

The program was created in order to foster and strengthen relationships between individuals in the United States and other countries across the globe through international educational exchange. The U.S. participates in this program with approximately 100 foreign partner governments to promote educational diversity and excellence.

Kyle Armstrong of Neenah, Lindsay Jagla of Mequon, and Dr. Marianne Johnson of Oshkosh are all recipients of this years award. Kyle and Lindsay participated in English Teaching Assistantship student programs in Taiwan and Colombia respectively, while Dr. Johnson participated in an Economics scholars program in Albania. An incredible accomplishment, congratulations!    

Weekly Roundup
Continued economic success has manufacturers feeling good about their businesses again. The industry represents the backbone of our economy and its so great to see it thriving once again!

￼

This week, my Washington D.C. office received this flyer, courtesy of Lakeshore Technical College. I'm so proud to have such a prestigious institution in the 6th district. Keep up the great work!

￼

Contact Me
As your congressman, I’m here to serve you. If you have any questions please don’t hesitate to reach out to my offices in Fond du Lac and Washington. If you enjoyed this newsletter be sure to forward it to your family and friends so they can stay informed on what I’m doing in Washington and the 6th District.

Sincerely,
￼
Member of Congress

Subject: This Week: Meeting with Granite Staters across New Hampshire
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email

￼   
Follow us:   
￼ 
￼
￼ 
￼

Senator Maggie Hassan  
See below for highlights of my week fighting for the priorities of Granite Staters.
Visit my website for more updates at Hassan.Senate.Gov. 

This Week: Meeting with Granite Staters across New Hampshire

This week, I was home in New Hampshire and got to visit many parts of our beautiful state during the state work period. 
On Monday, I visited Hampton Fire/Rescue to present a federal grant from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to support fire fighters by purchasing new communications equipment. I also commended our brave public safety officials for their selfless service, particularly their leadership on the front lines of the deadly opioid crisis. 
￼  
On Wednesday, I toured Milpower Source in Belmont. This innovative New Hampshire company is helping to develop products that bolster our national security. It was great to hear about the work they do to create jobs and keep our country safe. Job-creating businesses like Milpower Source are struggling to fill positions that require highly skilled workers, so I spoke with them about my efforts to close the skills gap and help more hard-working Granite Staters get the support they need to enter – and remain – in the workforce. 
￼ 
Yesterday, I was in Ossipee, exploring the new accessible trail at the Ossipee Pine Barrens preserve during its grand opening. New Hampshire has both beautiful natural resources and a strong tradition of inclusion, and this new trail is helping to ensure that all people – including those who experience disabilities – can access and explore the beauty of our state. 
￼ 
￼ 
I stopped by the Stafford County Head Start in Rochester. All of New Hampshire’s children deserve the opportunity to learn, to grow, and to lead, which starts with investing in – and expanding access to – early childhood education. 
￼ 
I commend all of the staff at Strafford County Head Start and those across the Granite State for the important work they do to not only shape our children’s futures, but to support families who have been impacted by the devastating opioid epidemic. 
I capped off the week with a visit to the North Country for Friendship House’s ribbon cutting ceremony of its new residential facility. 
Friendship House provides life-saving treatment and recovery services to Granite Staters living with addiction, and I congratulate them on this new facility. 
￼ 
I am also happy to announce the Innovate NH Entrepreneurship Forum on November 13th at Manchester Community College. The Forum will provide an opportunity for entrepreneurs across New Hampshire to hone the skills and knowledge necessary to turn an innovative idea into a thriving business. 
The Forum will provide a day of interactive workshops for entrepreneurs covering critical “how-to” topics to get small businesses off the ground and make them successful. Workshops will focus on learning to fund an idea; seeking out resources and support; creating a business plan; rural entrepreneurship; managing social media as a startup; women business ownership; and more. 
You can RSVP here and learn more here. 
To stay up-to-date about my efforts fighting for the priorities of Granite Staters, you can follow me on Twitter here, Facebook here, and Instagram here. 
To find out more about what services my staff can help you with, visit my website here. 

If you would like to unsubscribe from my e-newsletter click here.

Subject: Delivering Fiscal Relief to Minnesotans!
Message:
￼ 
  

Delivering Fiscal Relief to Minnesotans!

￼
Rep. Lewis discusses the benefits of tax reform.

Dear Lindsey,

I wanted to reach out to let you know about the recent Tax Roundtable I hosted at Schadegg Mechanical in South Saint Paul, where I came together with local business members and stakeholders to discuss the many ways our historic tax reform is benefiting their employees and businesses. 
Click here to watch my tax reform video, explaining the ways tax reform is helping families and businesses!
After hosting the Roundtable, it was clear the benefits Tax Cuts and Jobs Act are being seen throughout Minnesota and the Second District. With lowered individual rates, a doubled standard deduction and doubled child tax credit, individuals and families are seeing more money in their paychecks and increased savings.
Small businesses in the Second District are thriving because of the lowered corporate and small businesses tax rate as well as the incentives to reinvest and expand. And as we’ve seen, when businesses thrive, their employees thrive. Wages have been increasing for employees across the country, and companies have given bonuses and provided expanded retirement benefits for their hardworking employees.
Listening to stories of success from business members in the Second District really showed that the benefits are hitting close to home, and local taxpayers are actively noticing the ways in which tax reform has helped them and their families. Working to deliver fiscal relief to Minnesotans has been a top priority of mine, and passing the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was the first step in achieving this end.
Moving forward, I’m excited to work on getting Tax Reform 2.0, over the finish line. Under this new legislation, the individual rate cuts become permanent, giving families more fiscal stability. Additionally, with expanded education and other life-planning savings accounts, you can build reliable savings for the future. 
It was great to come together with Minnesota businesses and stakeholders to discuss current benefits and other steps we can take to help our small businesses and their employees. I will continue to work for economic growth and personal prosperity for members of the Second District. 
As I work on this and other issues, I always like to hear directly from you.  Please share any thoughts you may have through my website, and sign up for my e-mail newsletter for the latest updates from Washington, D.C. and around the district. You can also stay on top of my work by following my Facebook and Twitter pages. Please feel free to call my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2271 or my local Burnsville office at 651-846-2120 with any comments or for assistance with a federal agency

Sincerely, 
￼
Jason Lewis
Member of Congress

Subject: Senator Hoeven October 19 eNewsletter
Message:
￼

Official Site | Contact Me | Services | News 
￼￼￼   ￼ 

October 19, 2018
SBA Administrator Linda McMahon to Keynote 2018 State Of Technology Conference
Senator Hoeven announced that the head of the Small Business Administration (SBA), Linda McMahon, will keynote his State of Technology Conference this year. The conference, which the senator hosts with the Fargo Moorhead West Fargo Chamber of Commerce each year, will be held on the morning of Friday, November 30, at the Delta Hotel in Fargo. Click here for more. 
￼ 

Hoeven Outlines His Recently-Passed Measures to Resolve Easement Issues, Support P3s & Provide Flexible Funding For Construction of Fargo-Moorhead Region Flood Protection Project
In a meeting with MG Scott Spellmon, Deputy Commanding General for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, and leaders from the Fargo-Moorhead region, Senator Hoeven outlined provisions he secured in the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) and the Fiscal Year 2019 Energy and Water funding bill to help resolve the easement issue and provide funding to move forward construction of comprehensive flood protection in the Red River Valley. Both the WRDA and Energy and Water funding bill were recently approved by Congress and sent to the president to be signed into law. Click here for more. 
￼ 

Greater Fargo-Moorhead EDC, Local Consortium Submit Bid to Host New NIFA & ERS Locations
Senator Hoeven, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Appropriations Committee and a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, announced that the Greater Fargo-Moorhead Economic Development Corporation (GFMEDC) has submitted its proposal to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) for North Dakota to host the new locations for the Economic Research Service (ERS) and the National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA). The proposal comes as the result of a working group Hoeven organized, which consists of the GFMEDC, North Dakota Department of Commerce, Bank of North Dakota, North Dakota State University (NDSU), the City of Fargo, the Fargo Moorhead West Fargo Chamber of Commerce and the congressional delegation. Click here for more.

Subject: Rep. Peterson's Newsletter 10/19/2018
Message:
￼
NEWSLETTER-MN07: Updates

￼
Appleton – Swift County
Dear Friends,
 
This week, I met with Minnesotans from Bemidji to Lamberton. I visited Red Rock Central Secondary School in Lamberton to recognize the school’s distinction as a 2018 National Blue Ribbon School. Red Rock Central Secondary is one of four schools in the 7th to receive this honor for outstanding academic performance and their work closing achievement gaps between students. On Monday, I met with ProAg in Mahnomen and Noah Insurance in Callaway to chat about crop insurance and the proposed changes that could come from a new Farm Bill. I met with officials from the city of Tracy on Wednesday to discuss flood mitigation. The city saw damage from flooding in July and is currently working with state and federal officials to find ways to prevent a similar situation from occurring in the future.
 
Sincerely,
￼ Congressman Collin C. Peterson
Minnesota 7th District
 
Blue Ribbon Schools
￼
Class President Noah Pankonin, Principal Phil Goetstouwers, and State Senator Bill Weber
 
This week, I visited Red Rock Central Secondary School in Lamberton to celebrate its selection as a 2018 National Blue Ribbon School. This prestigious distinction recognizes public and private elementary, middle, and high schools for their overall academic performance and progress in closing achievement gaps among students. Red Rock Central Secondary School is one of 349 schools selected by the National Blue Ribbon Schools Program this year, including 8 from Minnesota. Buffalo Lake‐Hector‐Stewart Elementary School, Canby Elementary School, and Fertile-Beltrami Elementary School are the other winners from the 7th District.
 
Flood Mitigation Meeting with Tracy Officials
￼
 
I met with Tracy city officials this week to discuss how they are recovering from the flooding that hit their community in July. The City of Tracy is working with Homeland Security and Emergency Management (HSEM) and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to develop a proactive mitigation plan to prevent wide spread flooding damage in the future. We discussed the different options that the city could pursue and the federal funding sources that could be used to finance the plan.
 
Local Parents Share Their Experience Raising Diabetic Children
￼
 
I had the opportunity to sit down with Gina Stanford and her son Noah, Priscilla Bowman, and Stacy Zimmy with her daughter Addie on Thursday morning. We visited in my Detroit Lakes office where they told me about their experience as parents of children with diabetes. One challenge they mentioned is the lack of food labels in restaurants and not knowing whether to take medication before enjoying a meal. Although many restaurants do offer nutrition labels upon request, many do not have that information. There are laws in effect that require food vendors to display the nutritional content of their products, however they do not apply in some cases. I will continue to work in Congress on this issue that impacts so many families.
 
Highwater Ethanol
￼
 
I had the opportunity to visit Highwater Ethanol in Lamberton this week. As the Co-Chair of the Biofuels Caucus, I have been a constant advocate for year-round sale of E15. While I support the Administration’s attempt to expand access to E15 through rule makings, I am concerned that without a legislative solution this issue will get tied up in the courts. I will support legislation to allow this change to be implemented effectively. Increased E15 sales will provide a needed boost to the ethanol industry and give corn growers access to a broader segment of the domestic fuels market.
 
Local and County Officials in Bemidji
￼
Bemidji City Manager Nate Matthews and Beltrami County Administrator Kay Mack (Photo courtesy of Matthew Liedke and the Bemidji Pioneer)
 
On Tuesday, I met with local and county officials in Bemidji to discuss issues that are important to the area. We spoke at length about the new veterans home that is planned for the city and the importance of involving federal lawmakers as the project moves forward. The State of Minnesota will provide a significant portion of the funding, but there is a good deal of money that still needs to be found. I asked that the community to provide me with regular financial updates so that I can work to find additional funding at the federal level.
 
Click here to read a story from the Bemidji Pioneer about this visit.
 
Talking Crop Insurance with ProAg and Noah Insurance
￼
(Left) Aaron Vipond, Pam Vipond, Mike Vipond and Dave Vipond (Right) Larry Noah
 
I visited ProAg in Mahnomen and Noah Insurance in Callaway on Monday to talk about crop insurance. I have long been a supporter of the crop insurance program as it is a vital risk management tool that farmers use as a backstop against bad weather and market volatility. I am pleased that new federal insurance products are being developed for dairy and livestock producers.
 
New Flyer Bus Company
￼
 
LeRoy Stumpf of my staff visited the New Flyer Bus Company on Wednesday. The tour was hosted by Transportation for America Chairman John Robert Smith. Chairman Smith gave a presentation about the importance of transit systems in communities both large and small. A good transit system allows those who do not drive to be mobile while also reducing the number of vehicles on our roads. New Flyer sells models of their buses to cities across the United States and Canada and can tailor them to fit the needs of nearly any customer. They have designed models to be fueled by diesel, natural gas, electricity, hydrogen and hybrid.
 
AgriTalk with Chip Flory
￼
 
I got the chance to talk on Tuesday with Chip Flory on AgriTalk about a handful of things, including the ongoing negotiations on the farm bill and other issues impacting farmers like the Administration’s announced expansion of E15 ethanol sales year-round. I told Chip that the E15 decision is a promising one for the ethanol industry, but it’s something that farmers won’t see the full benefit of until there is legislation passed that makes progress on renewable fuels more permanent if the rulemaking gets caught up in the courts. I also gave an update on where we are with the farm bill, and the ongoing meetings with Chairman Conaway and our counterparts in the Senate, Chairman Roberts and Ranking Member Stabenow. We have a handful of outstanding disagreements, but we’re close and if we can all stay at the table productively, we can get a bill done and signed before the end of the year.
 
Northwest Minnesota Council of Collaboratives Meeting
￼
 
The Northwest Minnesota Council of Collaboratives (NWMNCC) is comprised of organizations and individuals from Kittson, Marshall, Mahnomen, Norman, Pennington, Polk and Red Lake counties. The primary goal of the NWMNCC is to improve the lives of children and families. This is accomplished by coordinating human and financial resources to address the needs of over 75,000 people. I am glad one of my staff could attend your meeting and learn about the problems our youth face in our schools, at home and in our communities.
 
Groundbreaking for Apex Townhomes in Detroit Lakes
￼
 
On Wednesday, my staff attended the official groundbreaking ceremony for Apex Townhomes in Detroit Lakes. The project is a 30-unit affordable housing project funded by the federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credit which encourages the investment of private equity in the development of affordable rental housing for low-income households. Detroit Lakes, along with many other communities throughout my district, are in serious need of affordable housing. With a strong job market and many local businesses expanding, it's critical to have enough housing to sustain a growing workforce. I strongly support our rural housing infrastructure and will continue to champion affordable housing in communities throughout my district.
 
Head Start Facility Opens in Thief River Falls
￼
 
The Inter-County Community Council Executive Director Catherine Johnson gave my staff aide a tour of the new Head Start facility in Thief River Falls this week. Catherine told us how the Council partnered with Northland Community and Technical College in Thief River Falls to open the new child care center. The new building has several rooms for learning, exercising, sleeping and eating inside, and a quality playground outside. The Head Start program will start with 40 children at the Northland site and will see 50 others at their homes.
 
Bemidji Area Forestry Affairs Council
￼
 
Jerry Richards, the new Chair of the Bemidji Area Forestry Affairs Council, hosted a meeting with the U.S. Forestry Service on Saturday. The Forestry Service representative explained the Sand Plains Pine Project in the Chippewa National Forest. The U.S. Forestry Service wants local foresters to collaborate with the Nature Conservancy to better manage the forest through a science-based repopulation of certain species of trees. They described the area of the Chippewa National Forest where the project would focus as vital to local tribal communities and businesses reliant on timber.
 
Capitol Police Officer from Alexandria
￼
 
Gretchen Revering serves as a Capitol Police Officer in the United States Capitol Building. The Alexandria native started her position in March and has been doing important work to ensure the security of America’s lawmakers and the Capitol’s many guests. Officer Revering was on her evening patrol Monday when she stopped to check in on the office of her hometown’s congressman. Thank you for your service, Gretchen.
 
World Food Day
￼
 
World Food Day is October 16th. Today, there are more than 815 million hungry people in the world, and for the first time in 15 years that number is on the rise. We are fortunate in the United States to have a strong domestic food supply. Some nations are not so lucky. Feed the Future is an organization that aims to strengthen the agriculture industries of nations around the world through agricultural education initiatives
 
You can read more about Feed the Future’s work to address world hunger by clicking here.
 
American Pharmacists Month
￼
 
October is American Pharmacists Month, during which time we recognize the contributions of pharmacies to our communities. Pharmacists are among the most accessible providers in rural healthcare systems and offer a range of critical services including daily prescriptions, guidance on over-the-counter medications, care management, and medical counseling. I am proud to support pharmacies as a co-sponsor of several measures to increase the transparency of drug pricing and secure reimbursement for pharmacies in underserved and often rural areas. 
 
￼Legislative Update
 
Ensuring Lasting Smiles Act
Last August, I introduced the bipartisan Ensuring Lasting Smiles Act with Representative David Young (R-IA-3) to require all group and individual health plans to cover medically necessary services related to congenital anomalies and birth defects. I’m happy to announce that Representatives Anthony Brown (D-MD), Glenn Thompson (R-PA), and Paul Tonko (D-NY) have agreed to co-sponsor the legislation, bringing the total number of co-sponsors from both sides of the aisle to 13. I will continue to work toward ensuring that customers can afford costly reconstructive treatments, particularly when the healthy development of a child is at stake.  
This Week in American History
￼
 
On October 15, 1800, Spain transferred the Louisiana Territory, part of which would eventually become western Minnesota, to France. France sold the 530,000,000-acre territory to the United States three years later for $15 million. Napoleon Bonaparte, France’s First Consul at the time, authorized the sale.
 
What’s the Story?
￼
 
The State of Minnesota adopted its first official seal in 1858. Lawmakers chose to update the seal in 1971. After their first ideas failed to be approved by the state’s lawmakers, the current design was adopted in 1983. The seal features a farmer plowing the land to represent the importance of agriculture to the state’s economy. To represent the Native heritage of the state, a Native Minnesotan is shown on horseback galloping south toward the farmer. Also depicted are the state tree, the Norway pine, and the Falls of St. Anthony to symbolize Minnesota’s northern forests. I display this enlarged version of the Great Seal of the State of Minnesota in my Washington, D.C. office.
 
￼
Dr. Joel, Emily and Harry Dunn toured the U.S. Capitol Building with our intern, Kaelib TeeGarden, this week

Subject: Investing in Our Community’s Health
Message:
￼
October 19, 2018 
Investing in Our Community's Health 
 


Dear Neighbor,
I believe that every American needs and deserves to know if they’re getting the best prices on their prescription drugs. Many of our neighbors in the Seventh District have struggled to afford their lifesaving medications because of needlessly high drug prices. Until recently, pharmacy gag clauses have prevented pharmacists from telling patients when they could pay less for prescription drugs, on both Medicare and private insurance plans. 
The good news is that Congress passed and the president signed the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act and the Know the Lowest Price Act to end these pharmacy gag clauses. I was proud to support this legislation to ensure our neighbors have better control of their health care decisions. I support allowing American consumers to buy their medication overseas by mail to save money.  
￼
Investing in cancer research is one of my top priorities. Recently, I voted to fund the National Institutes of Health $4.1 billion above the president’s request, and I increased funding for the National Cancer Institute by $509 million above the president’s budget request. Unfortunately, breast cancer is the top cancer among women worldwide. This year, more than 17,000 Texas women and over 150 men are expected to be diagnosed with breast cancer, according to the Texas Health and Human Services Commission. Prevention is the best way to combat this disease. Regular mammograms are vital to early detection. I encourage all women to consult with their healthcare providers so they can take the necessary steps to catch this disease in its early stages. Let’s fight this disease together. You can learn more about symptoms, diagnosis and treatment here.    

￼
Pierce Bush, CEO of Big Brothers Big Sisters of Greater Houston and Congressman John Culberson (TX-07) 
This week I also had the opportunity to visit Big Brothers Big Sisters of Greater Houston. This organization has been a bright spot in our community for the last 68 years, and it reminds me that one of the greatest joys in life is to help someone else.   As the Appropriator for Southeast Texas and chair of the Subcommittee on Commerce, Justice, and Science on Appropriations, I support significant investments in peer-to-peer mentoring programs. In fact, I have raised funding for youth mentoring programs to $100 million, well above the president’s budget request. It’s a privilege to help support the work they do, and I’m excited to see the impact this program will have on future generations here in Houston.
To let me know your thoughts on these or any other issues, you can email me here. 
It is an honor and privilege to represent you and Texas in the United States House. 
 Sincerely,   ￼  John Culberson

Subject: This Week in the Office of Senator Marco Rubio
Message:
￼
This Week in the Office of Senator Marco Rubio 
On Monday, I visited Marianna, Florida to survey the damage and meet with local officials to discuss recovery efforts following Hurricane Michael. Read more here. 
￼ 
On Tuesday, I surveyed the damage caused by Hurricane Michael in Apalachicola, Port St. Joe, Wewahitchka and Blounttown. I also discussed ongoing recovery efforts with local officials. Read more here. 
￼ 
This week, my office assisted constituents affected by Hurricane Michael in Blountstown and in Panacea. We will continue our efforts to reach those who were impacted and help communities affected by this tragic storm. See how my office can assist you here.
￼ 
On Monday, I joined Fox News @ Night to discuss the ongoing Hurricane Michael efforts and the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi. Watch my interview here.
￼ 
On Tuesday, I joined CNN’s New Day to discuss Jamal Khashoggi and Hurricane Michael recovery. Watch my interview here.
￼ 
On Sunday, I joined CNN’s New Day, CBS’s Face the Nation, and NBC’s Meet the Press to discuss ongoing Hurricane Michael recovery efforts and the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi. Watch my interviews here. 
￼ 
Earlier this week, I urged Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos to assist Florida schools affected by Hurricane Michael, by quickly approving Project SERV applications, which are critical to recovery efforts. Read more here. 
￼ 
Senator Nelson and I were joined by Congressman Dunn in requesting President Trump affirm his commitment to rebuilding Tyndall Air Force Base, which was critically impacted as a result of major Hurricane Michael. Read more here. 
￼ 
Monday, Senator Nelson and I were joined by several of our Florida colleagues in sending a letter urging FEMA Administrator Brock Long to approve Florida Governor Rick Scott’s request to initiate the Transitional Sheltering Assistance (TSA) program for the remaining 13 counties impacted by Major Hurricane Michael: Calhoun, Franklin, Gadsden, Gulf, Hamilton, Jackson, Jefferson, Leon, Liberty, Madison, Suwannee, Taylor and Wakulla. Read more here. 
￼ 
Tuesday, I urged Secretary Carson, Secretary Mnuchin, and Director Mulvaney to provide federal relief for Floridians impacted by Hurricane Michael. Read more here. 
￼ 
I urged the Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works, R.D. James, to fairly consider Florida’s critical water infrastructure projects in its Fiscal Year (FY) 2019 Work Plan. Read more here.
