Dear Friend, 
It's been a great week seeing firsthand once again how South and West Texans of all trades are working hard and making a real impact across our state and nation. A few highlights:  
Energy security is national security. My thanks to UTSA for hosting today's South Texas Energy Cybersecurity Forum, and Secretary Perry for your continued efforts to ensure the security of our state's energy infrastructure for years to come.  
￼ 
Through rain or shine, cold and heat, the men and women of our agriculture industry work hard each day to produce goods we rely on for survival, and I'm proud to fight for TX-23's 9,000 working farms and ranches in Congress. My thanks to the Pecos-Reeves Counties Farm Bureau for having me.  
￼ 
The Supercritical Transformational Electric Power (STEP) program allows us to generate more power, spend less money, leave a smaller environmental footprint and create 100+ new jobs over the next 6 years in San Antonio. Proud to have helped get funding for this important project.  
￼ 
Everyone has a role to play in preventing bullying at all levels, and as a community, we must do better. I was glad to get a group of local leaders together to start a continued dialogue about how we can stop bullying. Here's what we discussed.  
￼ 
When someone says the word hygiene, you likely think of brushing your teeth, washing your face or hopping in the shower. But what's just as important in today's digital world is your cyber hygiene. In case you missed it: here are three easy tips you should implement into your daily cyber hygiene routine to make sure you protect yourself online.  
￼ 
Thanks for the shoutout, John! I appreciate your kind words and will continue to do all that I can to help folks across South and West Texas. You can listen here. 
￼ 
As always, please don't hesitate to reach out to my office with any questions or concerns. For further updates on my work for you, follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube at @HurdontheHill.  
Have a great weekend!
 
Sincerely,
Will

Subject: Fort Report: Election Security
Message:
News from Representative Fortenberry
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
 
Home
About Jeff
Legislation
Services
News
Contact Me
 
Dear Friend,  I know it is a bit old-fashioned, but I like stepping into the voting booth and using a pencil to fill in an oval on paper.  There is no Russian hacking or fancy Facebook algorithm interfering with my vote.  It’s my conscience, my pencil, on paper.
Still, many Americans wonder if our election counts are to be trusted.  Sowing seeds of doubt in our democratic processes is the intention of those who intend to do us harm.  Despite ongoing nation-state meddling that long predates the 2016 election, please know that great measures are being undertaken to ensure the integrity of our election systems, from registration to voting to post-election vote certification, this November and beyond.
According to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Russian hackers targeted election infrastructure in at least 21 states during the 2016 campaign.  Nebraska was not targeted by outside interference.  Our state has, nevertheless, taken several steps to ensure pre-and-post-election security.  Importantly, our continued use of paper ballots creates a non-digital firewall impervious to hacking.
The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is, by Congressional mandate, charged with protecting America’s “critical infrastructure.”  In January, 2017, DHS designated our country’s election systems a “critical infrastructure subsector,” placing a far higher priority on protecting election resources than was previously the case.  I recently received an update from the DHS Secretary outlining latest election security measures.  DHS has implemented sophisticated sensors that provide granular real-time monitoring of voter registration databases to detect malicious activity and malware.  Through its Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center, DHS can now receive, collate, and communicate attempted interference discovered at any of the more than 10,000 election jurisdictions in the country.  As part of its whole-of-government approach, DHS has also stepped up election day and post-election day monitoring and incident response, and instituted robust counter-measures against foreign manipulation of public discourse.  I invite you to review the correspondence I received from the DHS Secretary here. 
Earlier this year, via the Help America Vote Act, Congress provided $380 million in grants to help the country’s 55 states and territories enhance election security.  According to the United States Election Assistance Commission (EAC)—the federal body created by Congress in 2002 to serve as the liaison to state election officials—Nebraska received about $3.5 million dollars.  This funding has been used to replace and upgrade voting equipment, and enhance ballot authentication, voter list maintenance, and accurate election night reporting.
Even with the ongoing threat of cyber-attacks, it is extremely difficult for foreign actors to hack the vote itself.  There is yet no evidence that they have previously done so.  
Still, five states—Louisiana, Georgia, South Carolina, New Jersey, and Delaware—rely exclusively on electronic voting, leaving no permanent paper trail.  These areas of vulnerability were addressed in a proposed bipartisan bill that I support, the Secure Elections Act (SEA).  It mandates that all states perform manual audits on a percentage of digital votes in all precincts in every election.  Without checking paper results against electronic results, there is no guarantee that interference has not occurred.  
Taken together, these actions at the state, executive branch, and legislative branch levels should reassure you that your vote is secure.  The sine qua non of a republic is free and fair elections.  If the voting process and vote tallies cannot be trusted, election results cannot be trusted.  
Earlier in the tech revolution, I recall a TV report done at a trade show about the latest computer gadgetry.  In addition to many high-tech vendors, the reporter interviewed a gentleman who just had a paper and pencil at his simple low-tech booth.  Technology has helped us exceedingly well in data movement and productivity.  But in that solemn space of the voting booth, maybe a paper and pencil works just fine.   Sincerely, ￼  Congressman Jeff Fortenberry 

P.S. If you would like to send my office an email reply, please visit my website, Fortenberry.house.gov, or communicate with me on my Facebook and Twitter pages.

PRESS RELEASE

October 19, 2018
Press Contact
Richard Motta
340-201-9439

Congresswoman Plaskett to Host Seminars on Military Service Academies


ST. CROIX– Virgin Islands Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett invites the public to a Military Service Academy Seminar in each island district.
 St. Thomas Friday, November 9, 2018 6:00 - 8:00 pm UVI ACC, 1st Floor Conference Room  St. Croix Saturday, November 10, 2018 2:00 - 4:00 pm UVI Great Hall   
Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett's Service Academy Seminars are aimed at providing information on the application and nomination process to students interested in attending a military service academy. The seminars are open to all high school students. The military service academies include the U.S. Military Academy (West Point), the U.S. Naval Academy, Air Force Academy, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, and U.S. Coast Guard Academy. Admissions experts, graduates, and local service members will be present to answer questions and assist students with the admissions process. 

For more information, please contact Cletis Clendenin at 340-774-4408.

#ProtectOurCare 
Republicans keep blurting out the truth: if they control Congress next year, they will return to their monstrous campaign to steal health insurance from tens of millions of families, raise health costs, impose an age tax on older Americans, and destroy protections for the 130 million people with pre-existing condition by trying to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
￼ 
Congresswoman Pelosi sat down with the Harvard Institute of Politics to discuss House Democrat’s agenda, #ForThePeople: lowering health & prescription drug costs, raising wages by rebuilding America, & cleaning up corruption in D.C. 
They have used their control of Washington to wage a bitter war on the health care of families and seniors. At the same time, like clockwork, Republicans in Congress are setting in motion their plan to destroy the Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security that seniors and families rely on, just months after they exploded the deficit by $2 trillion with their Tax Scam for the rich.  
In budget after budget, they have exposed their cynical agenda: give massive, unpaid-for handouts to further enrich big corporations shipping jobs overseas and the wealthiest 1 percent, and stick seniors, children and families with the bill. Under their twisted agenda, we can afford tax cuts for billionaires, but not the benefits our seniors have earned. 
The American people deserve a government that fights for them. Democrats are For The People: lowering health costs and the price of prescription drugs, increasing pay and driving strong growth by rebuilding America, and cleaning up corruption to make Washington work for the people.

Subject: Blackburn Report
Message:
￼ 
 
Talking Rural Broadband In Hickman County 
I had the pleasure of spending some time with our rural broadband providers at a meeting in Hickman County this week. I so appreciated the opportunity to join State Representative Curcio, County Mayor Bentley, representatives from the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development, and many local stakeholders who are directly engaged in deploying more rural broadband in Tennessee. We discussed the barriers they’re facing and what more we can do at the federal level to support their efforts. While we have made a great deal of progress on the legislative front in Congress, particularly during my tenure as the Chairman of the Subcommittee on Communications & Technology on the House Energy & Commerce Committee, there is still more work to do. Tennessee has made great strides in closing the digital divide, and its thanks to the hard work of these individuals and their small companies that we are getting closer every day. Thank you for all you do! I look forward to continuing to work across the state to make sure every Tennessean has 21st century internet for a 21st century economy. 
￼

Creating Jobs in Henderson County 
On Tuesday, I had the wonderful opportunity to visit the newly-expanded Nidec Leroy-Somer facility in Lexington, Tennessee. Nidec is one of the world’s largest motor manufacturers, and recently bought Leroy-Somer from Emerson Electric, which included the Lexington manufacturing plant. At the time of this purchase, employment numbers were rapidly declining at the plant, but with Nidec’s investment of $18 million to upgrade the facility, they are able to hire an additional 300 Tennesseans over the next five years! It was such a pleasure to learn about the company and discuss crucial issues they are facing at the federal level such as workforce development and defense funding. Nidec’s substantial investment in Henderson County and the neighboring communities serves as even more proof that Tennessee is the best place to do business and create new jobs. 
￼

Delta Regional Authority Invests in West Tennessee 
On Wednesday, the Delta Regional Authority (DRA) announced that it will invest nearly $2.8 million in West Tennessee communities to make infrastructure improvements that will attract new industry and support expansion of existing businesses, enabling the creation and retention of about 3,400 jobs. Two communities in the seventh district will receive grants. The city of Savannah’s Industrial Development Corporation will use DRA funding to build new parking and truck transportation areas to support a manufacturing facility in Hardin County, which will create 75 new jobs and help retain 160 workers. The Lexington Industrial Development Board will also use DRA funding to upgrade the Nidec Leroy-Somer facility with new electrical equipment enhancements to the shipping bay, enabling the company to create 300 new jobs. Thank you to the DRA for your dedication to unlocking the economic potential of our rural Tennessee communities. With a top-notch workforce, business-friendly environment, and outstanding local leadership, these communities provide ideal settings for investments in high quality infrastructure and jobs.
 
Championing Reliable, Affordable Energy 
I was delighted to be named an “American Energy Champion” this week by the American Energy Alliance for demonstrating my commitment to pro-growth policies that will lead to more affordable energy for Tennessee families. As a longtime leader and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, I have stood up for free-market energy policies and fought against overreaching, burdensome government mandates such as the EPA’s Waters of the United States (“WOTUS”) rule. As your representative, I will continue to advocate for affordable, reliable energy and less government intrusion into your energy choices.
￼

New Medicare Card Wave 7 Begins 
Medicare has begun sending new Medicare cards to beneficiaries in Tennessee.  The new cards feature a new Medicare Number, instead of your Social Security Number.

Cards will be sent automatically to current beneficiaries, and you should begin using your new card right away. Remember that Medicare will never call you uninvited and ask you for personal or private information to get your new Medicare Number and card.

You can learn more by visiting medicare.gov/newcard or calling 1-800-MEDICARE with any questions regarding the new Medicare card.

The Most Competitive Economy for First Time in Decade
America is open for business! Thanks to President Trump’s leadership, and the newly passed Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, our economy and our country are stronger than ever. For the first time since 2008, the United States is the most competitive country in the world, according to the World Economic Forum, and I am committed to keeping it that way! 

Yours in Service,

Subject: EPA Public Comment Period on Fuel Standards
Message:
￼
Home       About Mark       Our District       How Can Mark Help You?       Legislation       Newsroom       Contact Mark        
Dear Lindsey:
Earlier this month the United Nations' panel on climate change released a landmark report finding that severe consequences of climate change will hit earlier than we thought. The report, authored by 91 scientists from 40 countries, found that "absent aggressive action" the impacts of climate change—like worsening food shortages and intensifying wildfires—will take effect as early as 2040.  Despite this warning, the Trump Administration is continuing to push its agenda of rolling back fuel economy and greenhouse gas emissions standards for motor vehicles and eliminating California's authority to set its own, higher standards, opening the door to more pollution and turning its back on the clear, scientific warnings about climate change.   Before this announcement, the current fuel standards were expected to reduce our oil dependence by over 2 million barrels a day by 2025, save Americans $1.7 trillion in fuel costs, and cut greenhouse gas emissions by 6 billion metric tons—effectively eliminating the impact of 59 million vehicles from the road by 2030.
Simply put, this rollback is a blatant attack on public health, the environment, and America's economic competitiveness. Since the Trump Administration announced this shortsighted decision, I have been fighting back in Congress by:
	•	Calling for a national boycott of any company that does not commit to maintaining current fuel standards;
	•	Urging California's public retirement funds to divest from companies that participate in the rollback, and leading a group of Democratic Members to join this effort;
	•	Calling on automobile manufactures to clarify how they will respond to a rollback;
	•	Sending a letter to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) urging the Administration to maintain and strengthen current standards; and
	•	Leading a group of Democratic Members of Congress in introducing a resolution (H.Con.Res.130) in support of the existing standards and the ability of States to adopt standards that are higher than the federal standards.
Now, I am issuing a public comment calling for an immediate halt to the Trump Administration's rollback, and there is still time left for you to make your voice heard, too.  The EPA is in the process of receiving feedback from the public on this rollback. To share your thoughts with them on the importance of maintaining strong fuel efficiency standards for our environment and economic competitiveness, you can submit your comment to them at https://www.regulations.gov/comment?D=EPA-HQ-OAR-2018-0283-0756 through Tuesday, October 26, 2018.  To stay up-to-date on these and other topics before Congress, please follow our Facebook and Twitter pages. As always, please do not hesitate to contact our office with any questions you may have or if we can be of assistance.

Sincerely, ￼  Mark DeSaulnier Member of Congress

Message:

October 19, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | Meet Rodney | 11th District
￼
Services | Newsroom | Contact Rodney
Saudi Arabia Worth a Read from the Washington Post: Jamal Khashoggi’s final column Appropriations Highlight: Preparing for the Health Emergency NJ 11 Students Preparing for College Help Salute our State’s Role as America Celebrates its 250th Birthday Salute: The VanOrden’s 76 years of Service to the Lincoln Park First Aid Squad
Saudi Arabia 
This past week we continued to see troubling reports detailing the moments that lead to the horrible killing of Saudi journalist and Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. The United States, the people of Saudi Arabia, and the entire world deserve to know who was responsible for these crimes so they may be brought to justice.
I applaud Secretary of the Treasury Steve Mnuchin’s Thursday decision to withdraw from the Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh next week. You can read more about this decision in the New York Times report here.
Further, utilizing the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act, Congress has already initiated the process to investigate the disappearance of Mr. Khashoggi.  Under the legislation, the President, upon receipt of a letter from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is authorized to impose sanctions on those responsible for extrajudicial killings, torture, or other human rights violations against individuals who seek to obtain, exercise, defend, or promote human rights and freedoms, including freedom of expression. You can read more about Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Bob Corkers’s (TN) actions here.
The U.S. – Saudi relationship has lasted for over seven decades tracing back to President Franklin D. Roosevelt meeting King Abdul Aziz ibn Saud aboard the USS Quincy in 1945. Despite differences between our two countries and setbacks that have strained our relationship, each president since Roosevelt has worked to strengthen our alliance with Saudi Arabia. Today, the Saudi’s are a key national security ally in the Middle East, assisting our fight against terrorism and checking Iranian extremism. In addition, they are a critical economic and trading partner.
It is imperative we deliver justice to Mr. Khashoggi while doing our best to rebuild and restore our historic relationship.
 
Worth a Read from the Washington Post: Jamal Khashoggi’s final column, an appeal for free expression in the Arab world, which ran in Thursday’s Washington Post. You can read it here.
Appropriations Highlight: Preparing for the Next Health Emergency
The Fiscal Year (FY) 2019 Labor-Health and Human Services (LHHS) Appropriations bill was approved by Congress and signed into law last month – marking the first time in twenty years this legislation was enacted prior to the end of the fiscal year.
The LHHS bill, which was drafted by my House Committee on Appropriations, funds a variety of human service programs and provides robust support for key investments that will save lives in the event of health emergencies.
Contained in the legislation is $50 million to establish an Infectious Disease Rapid Response Reserve Fund. This will allow the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), and other health agencies to respond to the next infectious disease outbreak. As we have seen with previous outbreaks, it is imperative our health officials have the resources on hand to respond quickly and effectively. I am pleased Congress was able to have the foresight to approve these new resources so we are better prepared to save lives.
The LHHS bill also includes $171 million for Preparedness and Response activities at the CDC, an increase of $10 million from FY 2018, to support programs that strengthen national readiness to both naturally occurring and intentional public health emergencies. Further, this legislation continues robust funding of $610 million for the Strategic National Stockpile, a national repository of antibiotics, vaccines, antidotes, and other critical medical equipment and supplies available in the event of an emergency.
You can read more about the LHHS bill here and to learn more about the legislation’s impact on New Jersey visit here. 
 
NJ-11 Students Preparing for College 
This time of year many students and families across New Jersey’s 11th Congressional District are busy planning for their collegiate and postsecondary education.  As we have seen over the years, the cost for students attending college has become a heavy burden for many undergraduates and their families. 
It is important to note, there are a number of resources available to students and their families for planning and acquiring funds for postsecondary education.  I would encourage you to review this comprehensive guide of the various resources that may be of assistance to students and their families compiled by the Congressional Research Service.  
 
Help Salute our State’s Role as America Celebrates its 250th Birthday 
Plans are already underway to mark our nation’s 250th Anniversary in 2026. In 2016, Congress unanimously approved the United States Semiquincentennial Commission Act establishing USA250, United States Semiquincentennial Commission to organize, advocate, and promote this critical milestone anniversary of the founding of America and the signing of the Declaration of Independence.
This week, I wrote USA250 requesting an update on their plans to recognize New Jersey’s contributions to the Revolution. New Jersey was at the crossroads of America's Revolutionary War, with nearly 300 sites in our State with direct ties to the American Revolution, it is imperative the Commission honors New Jersey!
To learn more and to share your ideas with the Commission you can visit their website here.
You can read more about “Revolutionary New Jersey” by visiting the Crossroads of the American Revolution website here.
 
Salute: The VanOrden’s 76 years of Service to the Lincoln Park First Aid Squad 
This week I was pleased to pay tribute to Richard and Susan VanOrden who have dedicated over 76 years of service to the Lincoln Park First Aid Squad.  Richard began on the squad in 1978.  Sue began in 1982.  That's 40 and 36 years respectively. They have held many positions between the two of them as well as Sue holding the position of President of the entire New Jersey State First Aid Council. Every year, they have made their required hours, often giving above and beyond.   Thank you Richard and Sue for your dedicated service to Lincoln Park and the surrounding communities!

Subject: Civility and Respect
Message:
News from Congressman Dan Newhouse
￼  
Civility and Respect 
￼
This week, I welcomed my friend and colleague, Rep. Derek Kilmer, to Central Washington where we kicked off our Civility and Respect Tour around the state. Rep. Kilmer is a Democrat who represents Washington's 6th District, and while we disagree on many policy issues, we have fostered and maintained a friendship and positive working relationship.  
We are both members of the House Appropriations Committee and participate in a monthly meeting of a Bipartisan Working Group. We have introduced legislation together, such as the VA Management Alignment Act, and we have worked together on several important issues, such as combating the opioid crisis and putting an end to school violence. 
In the wake of horrific events like the shooting of Rep. Steve Scalise at the congressional baseball practice and the tragic rally in Charlottesville, civility is more important now than ever. Together, Rep. Kilmer and I joined the bipartisan Civility and Respect Caucus, which aims to spread the message of "disagreeing without being disagreeable."  
￼ 
The first stop on the tour was to the Hanford Site. I wanted to show Rep. Kilmer the importance of the federal government's obligation to the people in the Mid-Columbia, and there is no better way to understand the work being done at Hanford than to see it first-hand. We saw the progress being made at the Vit Plant, and Rep. Kilmer was able to better understand how important the clean up effort is for Central Washington.  
Click here to watch KEPR's coverage of our visit. 
￼ 
The second stop on the Civility and Respect Tour brought Rep. Kilmer and I to speak with members of the Tri-City Regional Chamber and Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. We discussed the importance of being able to engage with our colleagues - not only in politics but also in business. According to the Harvard Business Review, 48% of workers on the receiving end of uncivil behavior unintentionally decreased their efforts on the job. I am very proud to represent such a robust, diverse, and growing business sector in the Tri-Cities, and I am pleased Rep. Kilmer got to meet and speak with local business owners.  
￼ 
The Central Washington leg of the tour ended at an event hosted by WSU Tri-Cities, where we participated in a discussion with students and staff about how they can be more civil to each other at school and on social media. Civil discourse requires confidence and knowing that standing up for your beliefs isn't always the easy thing to do. The students at WSU Tri-Cities had excellent questions for Rep. Kilmer and I about how we collaborate on important national issues when we disagree with one another. Click here to watch a stream of the student discussion.  
The Civility and Respect Tour continues today in Western Washington, as I join Rep. Kilmer in his district to visit Tool Gauge for a forum with Pierce County business leaders, participate in a student discussion at the University of Washington Tacoma, and tour the Naval Base Kitsap-Bangor and Puget Sound Naval Shipyard.  
See more photos from the Central Washington leg of the Civility and Respect Tour here. 
Walk to End Alzheimer's 
￼ 
Together, we walked last Sunday in the Tri-Cities to end Alzheimer's. Many people in our community have been personally affected by this terrible disease. The Alzheimer's community has long supported research and resources and has come together with one common goal: to end Alzheimer's. Not only is this disease the 6th leading cause of death in the United States, but it is expensive and requires dedication, persistence, and specialized care. As a Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I supported $2.34 billion of funding for Alzheimer's research - a $425 million increase over last year. Research is absolutely critical in finding ways to prevent and - eventually - cure Alzheimer's. I am proud to have delivered the largest amount of research funding ever appropriated, which was recently signed into law by President Trump. In addition to research, we must ensure that patients, families, and caregivers have a strong public health infrastructure to specifically address this disease. I am proud to be a friend of the Alzheimer's community, and I will continue to work alongside you to beat this devastating disease.  
Sharing Resources for Seniors 
￼ 
I stopped by the Senior Times Expo in Kennewick to speak with seniors and learn about some of the local services and resources available. This is the 6th Tri-Cities Senior Times Expo that my staff has participated in, and it is encouraging to see our community come together to provide social, health, retirement, and fitness information in a one-stop shop. Did you know that my office can assist with claims and benefits from Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Affairs, and other federal agencies? Learn more here. 
Right Here at Home 
￼
I visited the Framatome Richland facility to learn how their fuel engineers produce clean, no-waste nuclear fuel. The Richland facility has been in production for over 40 years, and the fuel produced here accounts for 5% of the electricity generated in the United States. Their "dry conversion" process generates essentially no liquid waste, and their three conversion lines produce the energy equivalent of 30,000 tons of coal per hour. We should be exploring and promoting alternative, reliable energy resources, and it is great to learn about these energy resources being produced right here in Central Washington.   
Aviation Maintenance and Workforce Education 
￼ 
Aviation plays a key role in the economy in Moses Lake and Grant County, and fostering aviation is important for the future of students at Big Bend Community College. I was able to visit Big Bend and see the workforce education center and aviation maintenance technician program firsthand. I was also pleased to have the opportunity to present Rich Mueller and Richard Hanover from the Port of Moses Lake a signed copy of the legislation I worked to get signed into law that preserves critical FAA facilities at the Grant County International Airport. The airport acts as an important resource for Big Bend, as the school works to provide internships and apprenticeships to students, so they can earn a paycheck as they learn. The FAA Reauthorization also included language to promote these collaborative relationships between education programs and private companies, and Big Bend serves an excellent and successful example of this.  
Positive Effects for Car Dealerships 
￼ 
Thank you to the staff and General Manager, Jose, at Bud Clary Toyota of Moses Lake for welcoming me to their car dealership and giving me a tour of the sales and service departments. While I was on site, I met with several of the Bud Clary employees. I updated them on my work in Congress and heard from them first-hand about how the country's steadily improving economy is positively affecting the Moses Lake Region.  
Friend of Farm Bureau 
￼ 
I was honored to receive the "Friend of Farm Bureau" award at the Washington Farm Bureau's Policy Forum in Moses Lake. Agriculture is absolutely vital to the economic well-being of Central Washington and our state, and I will continue to work to ensure the agriculture community's voice is heard by the federal government.  
Hero of Main Street 
￼
The Department of Labor recently announced that there are 7.1 million open jobs in the U.S. Main street businesses are the pillars of our communities because they provide employment and opportunity to our neighbors. I was honored to be named a "Hero of Main Street" and presented with the award by local business owners Pat, Linda, and Matthew Gilmore, who own Dunbar Jewelers in Yakima. I will continue to support policies that encourage small businesses to hire more workers. The award is for recipients who have supported policies that recognize the contributions of the retail industries and have worked to encourage a vibrant, sustained, and healthy retail sector.  
Thank you for reading this e-news update. It is an honor and privilege to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Dan Newhouse Member of Congress

Subject: I'll Work with Anyone and Everyone for Montana's Veterans
Message:
￼    ￼   ￼

￼
 
 
As Ranking Member of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I’ve made it clear that I’ll work with anyone and everyone to make sure that the VA does right by Montana's veterans.

It doesn’t matter if that person is a Republican, Democrat, or Independent. If they share my goal of making sure the VA is delivering the very best health care and benefits to veterans in a timely manner, I’ll listen to their ideas and see if we can work together to improve the VA’s ability to deliver for our veterans.

I’ve found a great partner in the Chairman of our Committee, a Republican named Johnny Isakson from Georgia. Johnny is a fierce advocate for veterans and has been a pleasure to work with.

The Veterans' Affairs Committee has had a historic two years. Together, we’ve written major bipartisan VA reforms and with the support of veterans, Republicans, Democrats, the VA, and the White House, we’ve gotten them signed into law.

Now our laws are helping the VA live up to the promises our nation made to those who served.

The VA MISSION Act

Despite its best intentions, the Choice Program hasn’t worked for too many Montana veterans. So we got to work and crafted a bill that scraps the Choice Program, strengthens the VA and uses the private sector to fill in the gaps where the VA falls short. President Trump signed our bill into law June 6, 2018. 

￼

Forever G.I. Bill

On August 16, 2017, President Trump signed my fifth bill of the year into law. Our #ForeverGIBill ensures veterans can use their education benefits when it makes the most sense for them because they no longer expire after an arbitrary deadline and strengthens G.I. Bill benefits for generations of veterans to come.

Veterans Appeals Modernization Act

Before our bill to streamline the disability appeals system was signed into law on August 23, 2017, the system hadn’t been reformed since 1933. Now the VA can tackle the appeals backlog while helping to prevent future delays for veterans.

Our Veterans’ Affairs Committee has passed a historic amount of legislation in the past two years. But I’m not satisfied until all veterans have access to the health care and benefits they've earned. And now, I’ll be holding the VA accountable to use the tools we’ve given them to get the job done right.

If you have any ideas, suggestions, or questions about how the VA can better serve Montanans, please don’t hesitate to contact my office. As always, it’s an honor to serve you in the United States Senate.
 ￼

Last week, President Trump signed into law the  Music Modernization Act , a bill I introduced that will improve the lives of songwriters, recording artists, producers, sound engineers, and just about everyone who works in the music industry. It helps ensure that songwriters are paid a fair market rate when their songs are played, and that recording artists and producers are fairly compensated for their work.
￼ 
Click here to watch the bill signing, which included remarks from Sam Moore of Sam & Dave, Kid Rock, Michael Love of the Beach Boys, John Rich of Big & Rich, President Trump, and myself.

I also had the privilege of honoring a wonderful group of Utah veterans this morning at the WWII Memorial this morning. Click here for the video and click here to get to know the veterans.

Subject: SAVE THE DATE: We Believe Survivors - Domestic Violence Awareness Month
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼



￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
 

October 19, 2018 
Dear Friends, 
Violence against women is rampant. Seventy percent of women worldwide will experience physical or sexual abuse by an intimate partner in their lifetime. In the U.S., nearly 20 people per minute are physically abused by an intimate partner. One in five women and one in 71 men in the U.S. have been raped in their lifetime. 
￼ 
  
The impact of sexual trauma is severe and very difficult to overcome. In addition to being physically and psychologically scarred, victims are often re-victimized by being discredited and dismissed. This was on blatant display during the Justice Kavanaugh confirmation hearings. His testimony in response to Dr. Christine Blasey Ford’s reporting of sexual assault was a slap in the face to survivors across the country. This fall, Republicans in Congress failed to reauthorize VAWA, the Violence Against Women Act, beyond a three months extension until after the election. 
Women deserve better. That’s why I am hosting a panel sending a clear message: We believe survivors. I hope you will join me for this important conversation that will focus on healing and recovering from trauma. 
During the event, we will explore the transition from victim to survivor. I will moderate a panel of survivors, service providers, academics, and law enforcement. Look for a list of the panelist soon in this space. 
We Believe Survivors - Domestic Violence Awareness Month Thursday, October 25, 2018 7:00 - 8:30 p.m. San Mateo City Council Chambers 330 West 20th Avenue San Mateo, CA 94403 
SIGN UP HERE! 
Please save October 25th in your calendar. I look forward to having this important conversation with you. 
All the best, ￼

Subject: Fighting the Opioid Epidemic
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼ 
WEBSITE  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   CONTACT ME  |   ABOUT TOM  |   
￼
 
Red Cross opens new Corning facility- Corning Leader

2018 Walk to End Alzheimer's Disease Brings Community Out- WENY TV


Alzheimer's Walk raises more than $60000 for care and research- Corning Leader

￼
Tom meets with CAER in Mayville, Chautauqua County


Dear Neighbor,
We recently sat down with Countywide Alliance for Enforcement and Rehabilitation (CAER) in Mayville to discuss the opioid and heroin epidemic ravaging our neighborhood and how we are working to help.
Thousands of New Yorker’s lives have been cut short by prescription drug abuse and heroin. This is why we have made combating this crisis a top priority.
With my support, we recently passed more than 50 bills addressing the opioid crisis and President Trump signed those bills into law.
To help conquer this epidemic, we introduced the Help Ensure Lives are Protected (HELP) Act to allow federal prosecutors access to more severe penalties, including life in prison or the death penalty, when prosecuting certain criminal drug cases.
We are also adamantly opposed to bringing legalized open injection sites as some government officials in our community have proposed.  These sites will bring an influx of violence, crime and homelessness into our backyards as dangerous drug dealers will naturally follow the increased heroin users into our communities.
Our plan provides for safe and effective ways to combat the opioid and heroin epidemic through:
1. Treatment and Recovery
	•	Improve and expand access to treatment and recovery services
	•	Provide incentives for enhanced care, coordination, and innovation
	•	Establish comprehensive opioid recovery centers
2.  Prevention
	•	Encourage non-addictive opioid alternatives to treat pain
	•	Improve data to identify and help at-risk patients and families
	•	Address high prescribing rates while enhancing prescription drug monitoring programs
3.  Protecting Communities
	•	Give law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of our communities
	•	Better intercept illicit opioids at international mail facilities
	•	Improve access to federal resources for local communities
4.  Fighting Fentanyl
	•	Better tackle ever-changing synthetic drugs
	•	Crack down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs
	•	Provide grants for local communities to combat fentanyl
As always, please reach out to any of our offices if you have questions or need assistance.
Until next time,
Tom

Subject: A common sense solution to lower drug prices at the counter
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼


Share On:
￼￼￼


￼



Biography | How May I Help You? | Policy Issues | News | Our District | Contact




Long’s Short Report – A common sense solution to lower drug prices at the counter
By Rep. Billy Long
Earlier this year, President Trump rolled out his American Patients First blueprint to lower drug prices, which have steadily increased over the years. One of his priorities within the plan was to prohibit “gag clauses” within health insurance contracts that prevent pharmacists from letting their patients know that it would be cheaper for them to pay cash for their prescription rather than using their insurance.
In the U.S., nearly 60 percent of Americans take prescriptions drugs. From 2006 to 2015, prescription drug spending increased on average nearly five percent a year, with the highest increase in spending occurring in 2014 at 12.4 percent. In 2016 alone, Americans spent over $325 billion on retail prescription drugs, which was nearly 10 percent of all health care costs.
These alarming numbers got our attention in Congress, and we quickly began working on ways to fix this problem. In September, the Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee, which I sit on, held a hearing that addressed eliminating “gag clauses.” The legislation discussed would prevent group health care plans, individual health care plans and Medicare Part D plans from barring pharmacists from informing their customers about lower-cost prescription drug options.
Soon after our hearing, similar legislation, S. 2553, Know the Lowest Price Act, and S. 2554, the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act, were passed in both the House of Representatives and Senate with overwhelming bipartisan support. On October 10, President Trump signed both bills into law, finally allowing pharmacists to relay common sense information to their customers about prescription drug prices. Now, when a consumer goes to purchase their prescription drugs, they will be given all of their options.
President Trump and Congress will continue to focus on solutions to lower drug prices. Breaking down communication barriers that can prevent lower drug prices is a common-sense approach. The American people deserve a health care system that works for them and not against them. I applaud my colleagues in both chambers for their hard work and I thank the president for his strong leadership on this issue.
For more information on my activities in our district and in Washington I encourage you to follow my Facebook page athttps://www.facebook.com/Rep.Billy.Longand my Twitter page at https://twitter.com/USRepLong. You can also subscribe to my weekly newsletter, "Long's Short Report,” by visiting https://longforms.house.gov/newsletter-and-email-updates-form.

Subject: News from Nita: 📢 Important Announcement on Medicare
Message:
￼
ABOUT NITA           CONSTITUENT SERVICES           NEWSROOM           LEGISLATIVE ISSUES           17th DISTRICT           CONTACT ME 
Dear Friend:
Here are some of the ways in which I'm fighting hard this week to keep Lower Hudson Valley communities safe, healthy, and secure: 
	•	Fighting to Protect Medicare & Social Security 
	•	Securing Investments in Critical Cultural and Arts Programs 
	•	Helping a Constituent Secure Overdue Retirement Pay 
Fighting to Protect Medicare & Social Security 
￼ 
Every senior deserves access to a healthy and secure retirement, which is why I am working in Congress to prevent any cuts to Medicare and to strengthen the program for future generations. That's also why I want to make sure you are aware of two important announcements:  
	•	Medicare open enrollment for 2019 is underway. During the enrollment period, which runs from October 15, 2018 to December 7, 2018, beneficiaries can explore their coverage options and make changes to their health and prescription drug plans. Visit www.medicare.gov to learn more.   
	•	The Social Security Administration (SSA) recently announced a 2.8 percent cost-of-living-adjustment (COLA) for 2019, the largest increase in seven years. While I am concerned that the COLA increase may not fully cover the rising costs of basic necessities like housing, health care, and transportation, it does provide additional security for Social Security beneficiaries. As costs of living continue to rise, I will continue working to ensure Social Security benefits are protected for current and future generations.
Securing Investments in Critical Cultural and Arts Programs 
￼ 
Rep. Lowey participates in a conversation on the humanities in Pocantico Hills. From left: Waddell Stillman, President of Historic Hudson Valley; Congresswoman Nita Lowey; Jon Parrish Peede, National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) chairman; and Sara Ogger, Executive Director, Humanities New York. 
I participated in a conversation at Historic Hudson Valley in Pocantico Hills with National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) Chairman Jon Parrish Peede regarding the importance of the humanities in cultivating local community and broad recognition of the region's historical heritage, and of robust federal investment in the NEH. 
	•	Preserving our shared histories and culture is crucial for future generations.  
	•	As Ranking Member on the House Appropriations Committee, I secured nearly $153 million for the NEH in the Fiscal Year 2018 omnibus spending bill, an increase of $3 million over the previous year's funding level, despite the President's efforts to end the Endowment.   
	•	I will continue working to protect federal investments in critical cultural and arts programs that benefit residents of the Lower Hudson Valley. 
Helping a Constituent Secure Overdue Retirement Pay 
A constituent contacted me after he tried for two years to have the Defense Finance Accounting Service (DFAS) assign his late father's retirement pay to his sister with disabilities, as his father requested. In response to my inquiry, the DFAS apologized for the hardship caused by the delay, sent the retroactive payment of $40,720, and began monthly payments of $1,426. 
Having trouble of your own? My office is here to help. We offer a number of services to constituents in New York's 17th Congressional District, including assistance with federal agencies and consumer protection problems. Contact us at the numbers below for help.  
Staying in Touch  It is an honor to represent the Lower Hudson Valley in the United States Congress. To stay in touch and get the latest updates, please connect with me on Facebook and on Twitter.  If you have questions or need assistance, please contact my office in Westchester County at (914) 428-1707, Rockland County at (845) 639-3485, or Washington, D.C., at (202) 225-6506, and we will do all we can to help.  
    Sincerely,  ￼      Nita M. Lowey     Member of Congress

Subject: Legislative update: Two bills signed into law
Message:
October 19, 2018
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
https://guthrie.house.gov
￼ 

Dear Friends, 

I wanted to take a moment to update you about two of my bills that were recently signed into law. The first is the Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act, which was signed into law by President Trump on October 5th. 

I introduced the Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act to provide legal protection for sports medicine professionals who cross state lines with their high school, college, or professional teams. These sports medicine professionals - such as physical therapists, physicians, or athletic trainers - are licensed in their home state but previously had to obtain a license in each of the other states in which their teams participate. After passage of the Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act, they now only need to carry their home state license in order to provide care for athletes competing across state lines.

If you have a child who plays on a youth or college sports team that travels, the Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act could help them receive better care during their games. This bill received broad bipartisan support in the House and Senate, and I was proud to see President Trump sign it into law earlier this month. 

￼
The Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act will help physical therapists like those at KORT in Bardstown. I visited them earlier this month to tell them about my bill. 

President Trump also recently signed my bill to reauthorize the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) into law. Sadly, last year NCMEC received more than 27,000 reports of missing children. This legislation updates programming at NCMEC to reflect the latest research and technology, and it ensures continued federal support of efforts by state and local entities to recover missing and exploited children. You can read more about my bill, which President Trump signed into law on October 11th, here. 

Some of you may be interested to learn that I recently cosponsored the Equal Treatment of Public Servants Act. This bill will help certain public servants who also pay into Social Security in addition to a state pension. You can read more about this bill from Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady and Texas Senator Ted Cruz here. 

Over the past two weeks, I have enjoyed the chance to meet with Second District residents to get their feedback on a number of issues facing the Commonwealth and our nation. As chairman of the Workforce Development Subcommittee, I have appreciated hearing from both employers and employees about how to best help Kentuckians find jobs. My bill, the APPRENTICE Act, will expand apprenticeship opportunities - one way to help people learn skills for available jobs.  

￼
I visited Ken-Tron Manufacturing in Owensboro on October 5th, National Manufacturing Day. Manufacturing employs over 250,000 Kentuckians, and as chairman of the Workforce Development Subcommittee, I think it is important to help people learn new skills to get these great jobs. 

One of my top priorities as a member of the Communications and Technology Subcommittee is expanding cellular and internet service in rural parts of the Second District. Expanding service will help attract businesses and residents to the Second District. I was grateful that Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Commissioner Mike O'Rielly took the time to visit the Second District with me to hear directly from stakeholders about what more can be done to expand service. 

￼
Commissioner O'Rielly and I had the opportunity to visit Bluegrass Cellular in Elizabethtown. 

As we approach the holiday travel season, know that my office can help sort out any issues you may have with your passport. If you ever need help with a federal agency, please contact my Bowling Green district office at (270) 842-9896 or at guthrie.house.gov. 

Sincerely,
 
￼
BRETT GUTHRIE
Member of Congress

Subject: Blaine’s Bulletin: Blatant Intimidation and Bias Have No Place in American Government
Message:
￼ 
October 19, 2018

BLAINE'S BULLETIN

As a former community banker, I had the amazing opportunity to work with many members of our community on their journey to the American dream. Whether it’s the first loan to open a small business or credit to hire more workers, financial institutions are critical partners for individuals and businesses as they strive to achieve success through hard work and dedication. 
For the last five years, I have fought to end the Obama Administration’s ideologically driven initiative to kill legitimate businesses, aptly named “Operation Choke Point.” In this unprecedented initiative, unelected bureaucrats at the Department of Justice, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), and other agencies set out to kill legal businesses by starving them of access to financial institutions.
Last week, our worst fears were realized, despite the previous administration’s attempts to defend its actions. Newly-unsealed court documents revealed additional compelling evidence exposing the vindictive bureaucrats who crusaded against legitimate businesses such as gun stores and certain lenders.
In one example of blatant intimidation, a bank terminated their relationship with a legal business after threats from the FDIC. The bank eventually surrendered to the pressure, and when the bank notified the FDIC of the decision, they admitted that a risk assessment “pose[d] no significant risk to the financial institution, including financial, reputation, and legal risk,” yet they still terminated the banking relationship.
The evidence is astounding. As a former examiner, I find it appalling that senior government officials would not only allow but encourage this type of irresponsible behavior. The intimidation tactics and implicit bias employed by these unelected bureaucrats stands in direct opposition to the important missions of the agencies. It is also unfathomable that some of the bureaucrats named in these newly-released documents still have their jobs.
Early this week I sent letters to FDIC Chairman Jelena McWilliams and Comptroller of the Currency Joseph Otting urging them to investigate this matter and take immediate and firm action against any member of their staff who has abused their power. I hope Chairman McWilliams and Comptroller Otting will restore the integrity of their agencies by removing those who weaponized their authority to attack businesses that have done nothing wrong.
This is not a partisan issue. The House passed my legislation to end Operation Choke Point once and for all by a strongly bipartisan vote of 395-2, and I am hopeful the Senate will act as well.
I am appalled by the blatant intimidation, coercion, and bias employed by unelected government officials to play politics with the livelihood of Americans. No matter your ideological leanings, the government should not be able to destroy all that you have worked for in pursuit of the American dream. We have a duty to ensure American businesses are never again subject to despicable abuses of power like Operation Choke Point.
###

Subject: Did you hear about what Mitch McConnell said?
Message:
￼ 
  

Dear Lindsey, 
Did you see what Senator Mitch McConnell said this week? 
After passing the biggest tax scam in history -- taking from the poor and lining the pockets of the rich -- Republicans want to pay for it out of YOUR Social Security and Medicare. 
And that’s not all. They’re trying to push 4 million children and seniors off of nutrition assistance. They want to kick 22 million people off Medicaid. 
If you’re poor or elderly in the GOP's America, you’re out of luck. 
We can’t let them get away with this. 
There are tens of millions of Americans who are barely making ends meet. 
Teachers are working second and third jobs. 4 in 5 Americans don’t have enough in their retirement accounts to get by for more than a year. Everyday families are struggling to afford their prescriptions, groceries, and rent. 
But, at the same time, the rich are just getting richer. Wall Street is hauling in record profits. And billionaires are rigging the system even further in their favor. 
It doesn’t have to be this way. Everyone should all be able to live, work, and retire with security and dignity. 
We can and must do better for the people.  
As always, I am here for you. You can reach my East Bay office at (510) 763-0370 or connect with me via email, facebook, twitter, and Instagram. 
In solidarity, 
￼

Subject: Bergman Sends Bipartisan Letter requesting $74 Million for New Soo Lock in FY2019 Work Plan
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Oct 19, 2018
CONTACT: James Hogge 231-640-9158


Bergman Sends Bipartisan Letter Requesting $74 Million to Begin Construction on Soo Locks

Washington - Following House and Senate authorization to fund a new Poe-sized Lock in Sault Ste. Marie, Congressman Jack Bergman, joined by Congressman John Moolenaar, Congressman Paul Mitchell, and Congresswoman Marcy Kaptur of Ohio, sent a letter to Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney and the Army Corps of Engineers, requesting $74 Million be included in the FY2019 work plan to begin construction of a new Lock. Rep. Bergman issued the following release:

"While we've made great strides since taking office, there is much work ahead to ensure construction of a new Lock in Sault Ste. Marie. Last week I led a bipartisan letter requesting $74 Million be budgeted for the FY2019 work plan, to begin construction on a new Lock. By beginning one shipping season earlier, this measure would save taxpayers nearly $30 Million  in costs. " said Rep. Bergman. 

The letter in its entirety can be found below:
We write to you regarding the Army Corps of Engineers fiscal year 2019 (FY2019) work plan and urge you to include funding for the construction of a new lock in Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan. Ensuring the Soo Locks are safe, reliable and efficient, now and into the future, is vital to our economy and national security of the United States. 
As confirmed by the New Soo Lock Economic Validation Study Report released in June 2018, the Soo Locks are the linchpin of the Great Lakes Navigation System. Critical supply chains that support billions of dollars in economic activity and millions of jobs in the agricultural, automotive, manufacturing, and mining sectors rely on a single engineering marvel – the Poe Lock. On average, 80 million tons of cargo transit the Soo Locks annually and last year alone the Poe Lock handled 89-percent of the total tonnage. The need for a second Poe-sized lock was first identified and authorized in 1986. To this day, that need remains – as identified by President Trump in April 2018. 
Construction of a second Poe-sized lock is necessary and prudent to ensure the resiliency and long-term reliability of the Soo Locks thus reducing the risk of a catastrophic failure, which would reverberate throughout the supply chain and affect every state. While we commend the men and women who keep the nearly 50-year old Poe Lock operating, it is critical we reduce the risk associated with a single point of failure. Specifically, we urge you to include $74 million in the FY2019 work plan for the construction of a second Poe-sized lock. According to the Corps, this will allow design efforts to resume and construction to begin one shipping season earlier with a cost savings of approximately $30 million.
The Soo Locks are Nationally Critical Infrastructure due to their economic importance and impact on national security. We urge you to include $74 million in the FY2019 work plan to resume design efforts and begin construction of a second Poe-sized lock. We believe you will understand the critical importance of the Soo Locks. We appreciate your consideration and commitment to this project.                                                                   
bergman.house.gov  
###

Subject: Addressing the Opioid Crisis
Message:
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT SUZAN  |   HOW CAN I HELP?  |   NEWSROOM  |   ISSUES  |   CONTACT 
ADDRESSING THE OPIOID CRISIS 
Dear Friend,
The opioid crisis has impacted communities across the country, including here in Washington. In the United States, more than 115 people die every day from opioid misuse. But Washington state has lowered opioid overdoses since last year, due in part to expanded treatment and increasing access to life-saving medicine. This is promising news for Washingtonians. 
Recently, Congress took a major step in addressing the opioid crisis by passing meaningful legislation that expands treatment options and combats illicit drug importation. Included in this legislation were two bills that I introduced, the  Expanding Oversight of Opioid Prescribing and Payment Act and the Combatting Opioid Abuse for Care in Hospitals Act. The Expanding Oversight of Opioid Prescribing and Payment Act (H.R. 5723) requires the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission (MedPAC) to evaluate and report on adverse payment incentives that lead to the over prescription of opioids and underutilization of non-opioid alternatives in the hospital setting. The Combatting Opioid Abuse for Care in Hospitals Act (H.R.5774) requires the Department of Health and Human Services to provide hospitals with guidance on strategies for pain management and preventing opioid-use disorder for Medicare patients who receive treatment at the hospital. It also requires the establishment of two technical expert panels to review medical care quality measures and make recommendations on best practices for pain management and reducing opioid use in surgical settings. 
Too many people are suffering from addiction that started from an opioid prescription when an alternative might have been available, including a gentleman I met who became addicted at age 17 simply because he was prescribed opioids when he had his wisdom teeth removed. We know that 80 percent of patients who undergo minor surgery are prescribed opioids at discharge which is an independent risk factor for chronic opioid use. This is problematic because ten percent of patients prescribed opioids for long term use develop an opioid use disorder. I am hopeful that my bills will provide the answers we need to reformulate our payment policies so that hospitals are given the right incentives and alternative strategies for pain management are more available. 
Opioid addiction is a national crisis that requires a comprehensive approach. There is no one fix, but it requires collaboration between law enforcement, public health leaders, and medical professionals. These bills are a step in the right direction, by helping families and strengthening communities.
As always, my office is here to serve you. If you have questions or comments about the topics that matter most to you, I encourage you to contact me through my website. You may also keep up-to-date on what I’m doing by following me on social media or signing up for my eNewsletter. If you need assistance dealing with a federal agency, such as the VA, IRS or Department of Education, please do not hesitate to contact my Bothell office at (425) 485-0085.
Sincerely,
Suzan

ABOUT JIM

October 19, 2018

￼ 



￼
￼
It’s time to vote  Nashville Business Journal Decision time is here in Tennessee. Among other races, Tennessee voters are in the process of electing the state’s next governor and U.S. senator. 
Tennessee early voting turnout massive as midterm interest approaches presidential level  The Tennessean Voting numbers shattered the state's past two midterm numbers and were not far behind Tennessee's pace set during the 2016 presidential election. 
Early voting turnout high in early days  Nashville Post Early voting continues through Nov. 1 at sites around the county.  The 15 most interesting House races of 2018  Vox  There’s a dizzying number of contested House races. Here are the 15 you need to know.  ACLU: 245 separated migrant children still in U.S. custody  The Washington Post Nearly four months after a federal judge ordered the Trump administration to reunite families separated at the border, 245 children remain in government custody, according to a new analysis of government data by the American Civil Liberties Union.  In Shift on Khashoggi Killing, Trump Edges Closer to Acknowledging a Saudi Role  The New York Times But the president stopped short of saying the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, was responsible for Mr. Khashoggi’s death.  Trump praises Montana congressman who body-slammed reporter  The Associated Press His remarks praising Gianforte come amid an international furor over the apparent assassination of a Washington Post columnist. 
China’s Growth Slowest Since 2009  The Wall Street Journal BEIJING—China’s economic expansion slowed to its weakest pace since the financial crisis, as top financial regulators launched an extraordinary coordinated effort to calm jittery investors.  Scientists Learn To Hear The 'Songs' Of Ice Shelves  NPR The "whistling" of the Ross Ice Shelf, Antarctica's largest, is beautifully eerie. It's also potentially a divining rod for changes to shelves' composition that can be monitored in real time.  A Meme Tricks People Into Registering to Vote  The Atlantic The meme has seemingly resulted in at least some people registering to vote or updating their information. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Jim Cooper

Dave 
 


Dear Friend, 

It has been another great week in the 7th District and I wanted to give you all a brief update on what has been happening.  

Addressing the Opioid Epidemic
On Wednesdsay it was my privilege to take part in a forum with Chesterfield Sheriff Karl Leonard and some of the people he is helping battle opiod addiction. Sheriff Leonard has become one of the leading voices in the district for his efforts combating the opioid epidemic and for the work he has done to help addicts find recovery. As a Member of Congress, one of the best parts of my job is that I get to hear from people who have gone through the worst of the human experience, have come out the other side with hope, and are rebuilding their lives. I was grateful for the opportunity to have a thoughtful and open dialogue with these individuals on overcoming difficult circumstances and how to best find a support system as they continue to get better..
I am doing my part in the fight and have put forward legislation addressing this crisis. I am proud my bill was included in the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act which passed the House and Senate and was sent to the President’s desk to be signed into law. I have also introduced legislation to get more money to recovery programs that are working to help fight this epidemic. Opiod abuse is affecting our loved ones and the communities we live in, but we are even tougher and must continue to fight back.           
             ￼    ￼
    
Other Events Around the District 
Thursday I had the privilege of attending Mission Tomorrow, a career exploration event held for over 12,000 middle schoolers in the 7th district. Mission Tomorrow offers information on various CTE programs, jobs and careers – piquing interest in fields of study early so kids know more about their options.

                         ￼      ￼

                                                   ￼

I enjoyed a luncheon with a group of people who support the Fellowship of Christian Athletes. They hosted Harlem Globetrotter Melvin Adams and discussed how to best unite two passions, faith and athletics.

                          ￼     ￼

I had the privilege of speaking at Powhatan High School and was able to answer questions from the students. After nearly two decades as a professor, I know how important it is that our students are given the space to ask questions and take an active role in our government and society. I am particularly pleased to share with our kids that the economy is booming and producing jobs for them when they graduate. 

    ￼

On Wednesday I attended the Chesterfield Chamber of Commerce ribbon cutting ceremony. Thank you for supporting the business community in the 7th District. I am proud of the work we have done to cut through bureaucratic red tape and help grow our local businesses.

￼

Stay in Touch  
I am always interested in hearing your thoughts. If you have any comments, questions, or concerns, you can contact me directly by clicking here or by calling my office at (202) 225-2815.

You can also follow me on Twitter, Facebook, or YouTube for updates on my work in Congress. 

Thank you,

￼

Subject: My op-ed in the Asbury Park Press
Message:
￼

Dear Neighbors, 
The following op-ed appeared in the Asbury Park Press this week. I thought you'd be interested in my thoughts on the future of our health care system.   Sincerely,  
Congressman Frank Pallone, Jr. 
President Trump’s Disgraceful Health Care Lies
By Rep. Frank Pallone, Jr. 
President Trump has no problem telling a lie. But last week the President wrote a brazen opinion piece for USA Today on health care that took his lies to a new level.  The piece so thoroughly distorted the facts that one has to wonder if there is anyone left in the White House who values the truth.  
For two years, President Trump and Congressional Republicans have worked together to undermine our nation’s health care system. Congressional Republicans have repeatedly attacked Medicare and Medicaid. They tried, unsuccessfully, to strip away health care coverage from more than 24 million Americans, including 500,000 here in New Jersey. 
And now President Trump wants to eliminate protections for 130 million Americans with pre-existing conditions. 
Understandably, this is not a record that President Trump wants to promote. But rather than changing his ways, he’s once again trying to distort reality.     
President Trump is not being honest when he writes that Democrats want to gut Medicare for America’s seniors.  That could not further from the truth. We want to protect and strengthen Medicare and Medicaid.
If Democrats take back the House, we’ve already committed to strengthening Medicare and making prescription drugs cheaper for seniors.  We would do this by giving the federal government the ability to negotiate drug prices with the pharmaceutical companies on behalf of seniors on Medicare. This is already being done by the Department of Veterans Affairs and through Tricare, the Military’s health care plan. It’s a commonsense proposal that Congressional Republicans have unfortunately repeatedly opposed. We’re committed to finally getting it done for seniors.   
Congressional Democrats will also continue to fight House Republicans ongoing attacks to slash funding for Medicare and Medicaid. Over the last two years, House Republicans have proposed budgets that would have cut almost $500 billion from Medicare and more than $1 trillion from Medicaid. Today, seniors who need long-term care rely on Medicaid for support, and these Republican proposed cuts would seriously risk that ongoing support.  We should be looking at ways to strengthen long-term care support for seniors not undermine it through these draconian cuts.   
And Republicans are now considering additional cuts to Medicare and Medicaid in order to pay for their $1.5 trillion tax scam that disproportionally benefits the wealthy and corporate interests.  The tax law also dramatically hurts New Jersey families by limiting state and local tax deductions. But now Congressional Republicans and members of the Administration are using the tax law as another reason to target future cuts to Medicare and Medicaid. Congressional Democrats are simply not going to let that happen. 
The President is also lying when he claims he’s protecting people with pre-existing conditions.  In June, his own Administration asked a federal court to strike down key patient protections included in the Affordable Care Act (ACA).  If successful, the Trump Administration’s action would eliminate protections that ensure more than 130 million Americans with pre-existing conditions cannot be denied coverage.
One of the key points of the ACA was that insurance companies could no longer discriminate against anyone who had a pre-existing condition. Before the law, insurers could outright deny or limit insurance coverage to people with pre-existing conditions like cancer, Multiple sclerosis, bipolar disorder or sleep apnea. They could also charge outrageously high premiums that made insurance virtually unaffordable.
Last year, Republicans failed to strip these protections away when they were unsuccessful in repealing and replacing the ACA.  But now, the Trump Administration is trying it again. This time through the courts. 
If Democrats are fortunate to take back the House next month, we will protect coverage for the 130 million Americans with pre-existing conditions. We will strengthen and improve the ACA by reversing the most egregious efforts by the Trump Administration and Congressional Republicans to sabotage our nation’s health care system. We will also take bold action to reduce the costs of health care and prescription drugs, while also protecting and strengthening Medicare and Medicaid.  
It’s time for Washington to work again for the people, and that will happen in a Democratic House.

Subject: rebuilding our military and caring for our veterans
Message:
￼

Hello, 
Yesterday, I was with military families at Fairchild Air Force Base for my 9th annual Military Family Summit.
In case you missed it in the Spokesman-Review:
"With more than 100 years of family members serving in the military, [Secretary of the VA] Wilkie appeared at Fairchild at the invitation of U.S Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, who has been organizing the Family Military Summits since 2009.
"I've said before, in order for America to be a diplomatic power, it needs to be a military power," McMorris Rodgers said. "In order to be a military power, it needs to be an economic power. It's all connected. And the military families are the basis behind every part." 
CLICK HERE to read the full story in the Spokesman.
When someone joins the military, it's not just a job--it's a family commitment to our country. That's why our focus at the Summit yesterday was on families serving at Fairchild and some of the most important issues they face.
More Job Opportunities for Military Spouses: Did you know that the unemployment rate among military spouses is historically higher when compared to the general population? With more than 7 million jobs available in America, more work needs to be done to help military spouses find a good-paying job, especially when they relocate.
Last year, I worked on a provision that is now law for spouses to be reimbursed for new licenses due to a move. For instance, if a military family is reassigned to Fairchild, and a husband or wife of a service member needs a nursing license in Washington state, they can be reimbursed for that cost up to $500. It's just one way I've worked to knock down a barrier to employment that is unique to military families.
Building a Stronger Military: Families deserve every assurance that their loved ones serving in the military are safe and that they have the training and equipment they need to do their jobs. Unfortunately, our armed forces had been overstretched, undertrained and depleted. Our military was forced to do more with less. It created a readiness crisis that has jeopardized our troops' lives and threatened our national security. That's why, in addition to increasing troop pay with the largest increase in nearly a decade, we've kept our promise to rebuild the military. 
	•	I supported legislation to fund the Pentagon for a full year -- on time. 
	•	I supported the largest year-to-year increase in military funding in 15 years, including $34 billion to support military families. 
	•	I also helped secure 12 more tankers for Fairchild and worked to expedite their delivery. This squadron of tankers will make Fairchild the largest tanker base in the country will make our Air Force base a center of excellence. 
Restoring Trust at the VA: In addition to providing our active-duty service members with the tools for success, I am also committed to making sure our nation's heroes are cared for when they return home. That means restoring trust and accountability at the VA. In an effort to accomplish this goal:
	•	I supported legislation funding the VA with its largest dollar amount in history. 
	•	I helped pass the VA MISSION Act, which consolidates the multiple community care programs we have in Eastern Washington, and extends the Choice Program. 
	•	I led in advocating for the reopening of our 24-hour urgent care in Spokane. 
	•	I am leading to make the Spokane VA a teaching hospital so doctors can go to medical school here in Spokane, train at the Spokane VA, and continue to serve our veterans in Eastern Washington.  
Because of these efforts, I am proud to say our military and their families are Better Off Now. If you missed 
the summit and would like to learn more, please visit my Facebook page.
Thanks, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress

Subject: a new record in America
Message:
￼ 
 

October 18, 2018
 
Dear Friends,  I hope you're all having a wonderful week. Let's hope the Brewers can have a great weekend and make it to the World Series!  There are a few things I'd like to update you on, so let's dive right in!
 Never Been A Better Time To Find A Job 
I'm not sure if you heard the news, but now there are more than seven million job openings across America- a new record. Thanks to our pro-growth policies that make it easier for businesses to hire workers and grow, there are a heck of a lot more "help wanted" signs around than even just a few years ago.  And interestingly enough, there are more than one million more job openings than there are unemployed Americans. Our economy can't afford anyone to sit on the sidelines because now is such a great opportunity to get that new job!  Click HERE or the image below to "like" and SHARE the good news on Facebook! 
￼   
Let's Get Our Fiscal House In Order 
I recently chatted with Fox News' Harris Faulkner about the need to reduce government spending. Like my dad always says, "it's not how much you make, it's how much you spend." Wisconsin families have to watch what they're spending, and so should the federal government.  Click HERE or the image below to watch part of the interview. 
￼ 
 Great Opportunity For College Students Or Recent Grads 
Attention college students or recent grads: my Washington DC office is now accepting applications for Spring internships. It's a great way to serve your community and learn new skills.   For more information on the internship, click HERE or the photo below. Also be sure to share these opportunities with any interested students!
￼ 
 Stay Connected On Social Media      
Snapchat is a fun way to stay connected with what’s going on in Wisconsin and Washington (and of course, find me on Facebook and Twitter- @RepSeanDuffy). Find my snapchat profile either by searching @RepSeanDuffy or use the Snapcode below!    
￼  
 
Until next week!   God bless, 
  
￼ 
  
Sean Duffy
