Subject: President to sign Greg Walden’s Bill to Combat Opioid Crisis into Law
Message:
News from Representative Walden

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
 
ABOUT GREG
ISSUES
CONTACT
NEWS
LEGISLATION
 
Dear Friend: 
President to sign Greg Walden’s Bill to Combat Opioid Crisis into Law 
After months of bipartisan work, more than 60 pieces of legislation, and dozens of hearings in the House and Senate, my comprehensive legislation to combat the opioid crisis will be signed into law in the coming days. The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act incorporates the feedback I’ve heard from those on the front lines of the opioid crisis in meeting after meeting across our district.   
At more than 10 roundtables in Oregon, I’ve heard from victims, families, medical providers, treatment advocates, and law enforcement officials about what is working -- and what more needs to be done -- to get our communities on the path to recovery. That input has been crucial as we’ve worked to craft the largest Congressional effort to address a single drug crisis in history. 
￼ 
Hearing from local medical providers, community leaders, and law enforcement officials in Pendleton last week about what more can be done to combat the opioid crisis. 
Over the last week, I held four meetings, from Medford to Bend to Baker City to Pendleton, to talk with medical providers, community leaders, and law enforcement officials about how we can better work together to combat the opioid crisis in Oregon. In each meeting, I heard a similar refrain about the need for more effective treatment options, better preventative measures for our youth, and the ability to stop dangerous synthetic drugs like fentanyl from flowing into our communities. My legislation will help us make important progress on each of these fronts, but there is much more to be done. 
That’s why I’ve supported bringing additional resources into our communities to help combat this crisis. Recently, Oregon received $17 million to combat the opioid crisis. That funding includes key resources for community health centers across our district to help them stem the tide of addiction and save lives. I helped lead the effort in Congress to boost and extend funding for community health centers in Oregon so they can continue to serve our communities, and these resources will provide them with additional tools in this fight. 
￼
Oregon to receive $17 million in federal funds to fight opioid crisis 
Oregon Rep. Greg Walden’s bill to help fight the opioid crisis could become law as soon as next week. 
The Republican from Hood River swung though Eastern Oregon to talk up the bill and hear from folks on the front lines of the drug addiction crisis. Friday morning at the Umatilla County Courthouse, Pendleton, he said the bill would provide about $17 million split between the Oregon Health Plan and local clinics to help treatment, recovery and prevention efforts and fight fentanyl and other illegal drugs. The Columbia River Community Health Services in Boardman is one of the clinics and received $295,000.
Click here to read more from the East Oregonian. 
Walden Leads Congressional Effort to Bring Greater Transparency to Prescription Drug Costs
￼ 
Michele Belcher, owner of Grants Pass Pharmacy in Grants Pass, first told me about how “gag clauses” prevent pharmacists from disclosing important pricing information to patients. I recently helped pass into law legislation that will ban this troublesome practice by insurance companies.
American consumers should have the right to know how they can save money when they go to pay for their medicines. Unfortunately, so-called “gag clauses” restrict a pharmacist’s ability to inform a patient that their drug would be cheaper if they paid out of pocket than if they paid through their insurance. That is unacceptable, and I recently helped pass into law the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act and the Know the Lowest Price Act that will ban the use of gag clauses and bring patients greater transparency when it comes to their drug costs. 
I first heard about the gag clause issue from Michele Belcher, an independent pharmacist from Grants Pass, who I met with recently to discuss how the new laws will help improve how she communicates with her patients. 
Michele told me that as a pharmacist she was precluded -- under certain insurance contracts -- from telling a patient that their cash price would be cheaper than going through their insurance. Michele told me that she once even received a cease and desist letter for trying to help the parents of a child with a terminal disease access his medication. 
Gag clauses have no place in an open market and I applaud President Trump for signing these common-sense bills into law. I will continue to work alongside my colleagues in Congress and people on the ground in Oregon to increase affordability and patient choice in our health care system. 
￼ 
Walden pushes bill to rid pharmacies of 'gag clauses' 
Apparently there was a dirty little secret between the drug companies and the insurance companies about prescription costs for years. 
Pharmacists could not inform customers, other than Medicare D patients, if their drug was cheaper if they paid out of pocket versus through their insurance, because of so-called "gag clauses." 
Pharmacist Michele Belcher, who owns the Grants Pass Pharmacy, brought this to Oregon Rep. Greg Walden's attention.
Click here to read more from the Grants Pass Daily Courier. 
Walden Hears from Onion Growers About Challenges Facing Oregon’s Ag Industry 
￼ 
Oregon onion growers put food on our tables and play a key role in our eastern Oregon economy. Last week, I met with the Oregon/Idaho Fruit and Vegetable Association to discuss the issues impacting their industry and tour the new Snake River Produce facility in Nyssa. I’ve worked closely over the years with this group to make sure public policy is working for them so they can continue to feed America and the world. 
That includes working with local growers to bring common sense to the Food and Drug Administration’s water quality standard in the Food Safety Modernization Act that ignores the science surrounding onion growing and unnecessarily drives up costs for growers with no benefit to consumers.  I’ve also worked to repeal the troublesome Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule. In meetings across rural Oregon, farmers, ranchers, and property owners have repeatedly expressed their concerns about the impact of this heavy-handed rule that threatened jobs and livelihoods across the West.
I also heard their concerns about the need for trade policies that work for them and about imports from Mexico and Peru that flood our markets.  The growers are deeply concerned about foreign growers who don’t adhere to the same food safety standards, labor standards and regulations that American growers do.  We will continue to work together to help find solutions to the regulatory issues and get better trade agreements with other countries.  
￼ 
Staying competitive 
Onion growers in Oregon, Idaho and Washington are for free trade but they want a “level playing field or fair trade.” 
That was the message given to U.S. Congressman Greg Walden, R-Oregon, during a meeting with Malheur County, Idaho and Washington onion industry leaders at Snake River Produce in Nyssa Thursday morning. 
Click here to read more from the Ontario Argus Observer. 
Walden Secures Klamath Drought Relief in Water Package Sent to President’s Desk 
Farmers, ranchers, and water users in the Klamath Basin have faced another challenging water year. That’s why I helped secure needed drought relief for Klamath Basin irrigators in a landmark water package that was sent to the President’s desk last week.
I included a provision in the America’s Water Infrastructure Act that authorizes $10 million annually for four years to the Bureau of Reclamation to implement groundwater pumping and other priorities for basin farmers. This will help our farmers get help for their added costs and losses this water year and will help ensure we are prepared if our farmers are hit again with similar conditions in the years ahead. 
Importantly, the underlying legislation also also included provisions to boost hydropower development in Oregon and modernize our drinking water infrastructure to ensure we have safe water to drink when we turn on the faucet. These issues have been priorities for me in Congress, and all these measures will be signed into law through the America’s Water Infrastructure Act.
To read more about this bill, please click here. 
￼
Walden Applauds Senate Passage of Klamath Drought Relief in Water Package 
Representative Greg Walden (R-Hood River) today applauded the Senate passage of a landmark water package that includes funding he helped secure for drought relief for Klamath Basin irrigators. Walden included a provision in the Water Resources Development Act that authorizes $10 million annually for four years to the Bureau of Reclamation to implement needed drought relief measures for the $181 million dollar agriculture economy in the Klamath Basin. That measure passed the House of Representatives in September with Walden’s support. 
Click here to read more from the Klamath Falls News. 
Greg Walden Listens to Oregon Veterans in Malheur County
￼ 
Malheur County veterans discuss what’s working and what’s not when it comes to veterans benefits and healthcare.   
The Veteran Advocates of ORE-IDA in Malheur County serves as a resource for veterans in the area for housing, health care, and assistance at the VA. Getting Oregon veterans the care they deserve at the VA continues to be a top priority of mine in Congress, and I appreciated the opportunity to share an update on these efforts in Ontario last week. 
With my support, Congress has passed into law historic funding for the VA to clean up the backlog of claims and ensure the VA has the needed resources to give veterans the care and support they deserve. In addition, we’ve also passed into law the VA Mission Act to bolster the VA, fully fund the VA Choice Program, and give veterans timelier access to quality care through my legislation -- the VA Medical Scribe Pilot Act. 
Thank you to the Veteran Advocates of ORE-IDA for your work to help those who have worn our nation’s uniform, and thank you most of all to the veterans at last week’s meeting for your service to our country. 
￼
In local visit, Walden outlines support for veterans 
U.S. Congressman Greg Walden, R-Oregon, said he and other lawmakers are trying to make the Veterans Administration work for veterans.
Walden was speaking to local veterans and others who packed the Veteran Advocates of Ore-Ida office in Ontario Thursday morning before Walden made stops in Nyssa, Baker and La Grande. 
Click here to read more from the Ontario Argus Observer. 
In 2018 alone, I’ve already helped more than 450 Oregon veterans and their families with health care, benefits, and claims at the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). If you or a loved one needs help with the VA or any other federal agency, you can reach out to my office from Oregon at 800-533-3303. I will do everything I can to get results for you. 
But veterans should not have to come to their Congressman to receive the care they deserve. That’s why I’ll continue to support efforts in Congress to make sure the VA is working for our veterans, and make sure veterans have access to the best mental health care, opioid addiction treatment, and suicide prevention programs. 
That’s all for this update. Remember, you can always keep in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 
It is an honor to represent you in the U.S. Congress. 
Best regards, 
Greg Walden U.S. Representative Oregon's Second District 

Please feel free to sign up for my E-Newsletter, like me on Facebook, and follow me on Twitter and Instagram if you have not already done so.  If you would like to contact me with a follow-up question or comment, you can do so by clicking here. Click here if you would like to Unsubscribe.

Subject: Remembering Officers Vega and Zerebny
Message:
If you are using an iPad or iPhone, click here to view this email in your Web browser. 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

Dear Friends, 

On the second anniversary of the deaths of Officers Gil Vega and Lesley Zerebny, our community came together to honor the lives of two local heroes who made the ultimate sacrifice to keep us safe. 

The anniversary was a sober reminder of the importance of supporting our law enforcement officers and their families. That’s why in the wake of the deaths of Officers Vega and Zerebny, our community came together to draft and introduce bipartisan legislation to honor our local heroes: the Heroes Lesley Zerebny and Gilbert Vega First Responders Survivors Support Act. 

H.R. 5060, the Heroes Lesley Zerebny and Gilbert Vega First Responders Survivors Support Act, would update the Public Safety Officers’ Benefit (PSOB) Program so that grieving families of fallen heroes will have the support they need to pay off their debts, pursue their education, and get back on their feet. The bill continues to gain momentum with recent key endorsement from the California Police Chiefs Association, California Peace Officers’ Association, and the California Reserve Peace Officers Association. 

You can read the quotes below to learn what law enforcement advocates and organizations are saying about this legislation to provide first responders and their families with the benefits they have earned and deserve. I’d also like to share an op-ed I wrote reflecting on the service and sacrifices made by our law enforcement officers. 

I firmly believe that together, we can get this bill across the finish line and signed into law. 

Best,
￼
Raul Ruiz, M.D.
Member of Congress


“Under the current program, officers and their loved ones are deprived of their full benefits due to structural flaws in the program. H.R. 5060 would address these shortcomings, and would, among other things, double the death and disability benefits and increase the education benefit. With this legislation, our officers will be comforted to know their families will have better financial stability.” 

-David Swing, President, California Police Chiefs Association 

“The California Peace Officers’ Association commends Congressman Ruiz for introducing H.R. 5060, The Heroes Lesley Zerebny and Gilbert Vega First Responders Survivors Support Act, and we are pleased to support it. Not only does the measure serve as a reminder of the sacrifices made by public safety heroes like Officers Zerebny and Vega, but also ensures that the families that the fallen leave behind are not forgotten. CPOA urges Congress to pass this important measure on behalf of the law enforcement family in California.” 

-Sheriff Jay Varney, President, California Peace Officers Association 

“The families of public safety officers who experience the tragedy of a line of duty death or disability rely on the benefits promised to them by the PSOB Program to continue with their lives. Unfortunately, the current PSOB Program death, disability and education benefit amounts are not adequate to meet the financial needs of these families, which is why the Heroes Lesley Zerebny and Gil Vega First Responder Survivors Support Act is so important. We thank Congressman Ruiz for his leadership and commitment to this important issue and hope to see the Heroes Lesley Zerebny and Gil Vega First Responder Survivors Support Act enacted in the 116th Congress.” 

-Bill Johnson, Executive Director, National Association of Police Organizations 

“We strongly support the efforts by Congressman Ruiz to update to the Public Safety Officers’ Benefit Program, which will provide needed resources and support services of police officers and fire fighters killed in the line of duty. The bill, introduced after the line of duty deaths of Palm Springs Police Officers Leslie Zerebny and Gilbert Vega, should be a priority for passage by the next Congress. Officer Zerebny was married to a deputy from the Riverside County Sheriff's Department, and the impact of her death and that of Officer Vega continues to be felt by law enforcement and the community throughout Riverside County. Passage of this bill is an important step in honoring their memories and helping their families to heal.” 

-Bill Young, President, Riverside Sheriffs’ Association 

“I want to thank the Congressman for everything that he has done for me and my family these past two years. He has really been involved since the beginning and he didn't have to be. To push this bill is one of the best things that he can do not only for our family, but all the families across the nation who have gone through what we have been through. As it is there are so many things we are going through and thinking about and having to worry about how certain bills are going to be paid should not be one of them. Especially to those families that were living off the one income and no longer have that coming in. Thank you so much Dr. Ruiz for all that you have done for our family, the Zerebny family and the community. It does not go unnoticed and is very much appreciated.” 

-Gloria Vega, daughter of Officer Gil Vega

Message:

￼ 
ABOUT ED  |   HOW CAN WE HELP  |   ISSUES & LEGISLATION  |   NEWSROOM  |   CONTACT 
GET CONNECTED: 
￼ ￼ ￼  
HAPPY BIRTHDAY, CU LASP
 Congratulations and Happy Birthday to Colorado’s very own Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics! 
What started as the Upper Air Laboratory in 1948 launching payloads on V-2 rockets has grown to become the world’s only research institute to have sent space science instruments to all 8 planets and Pluto. 
￼
Cheers to another 70 years of exploring the Earth, and every planet in the solar system…and beyond!  

ICYMI - RECENT NEWS ON SOCIAL SECURITY & FINANCIAL AID FOR STUDENTS
                                
YOUR SOCIAL SECURITY CHECK IN 2019

Last week, the Social Security Administration announced a 2.8% cost-of-living increase for Social Security benefits in 2019. All beneficiaries will be able to find out what this means for them in December through their online account or a paper statement in the mail. Click here to learn more. 

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT THE 2019-2020 FAFSA

Earlier this month, the Free Application for Federal Student Aid opened for the 2019-2020 school year. The program can provide helpful financial aid through Pell Grants for Colorado students, and is available to complete now until next fall. Find out how to take advantage today.


CLEAN WATER IS A CIVIL RIGHT
 Today marks the anniversary of the passage of the Clean Water Act, landmark legislation designed to prevent pollution into water, improve sanitation of wastewater, and conserve our nation’s wetlands.
Clean water is crucial for our health, and for sustaining farming and ranching communities. Water scarcity is projected to rise in coming years--particularly for our neighbors in southern Colorado and the western slope--which makes protections for water even more important.    Despite these concerns, the Clean Water Act is under threat. House Republicans recently passed a bill allowing for pesticides to be sprayed directly into rivers, lakes, or wetlands, and the Trump Administration has revoked rules that prevent coal companies from dumping mining debris into local streams. I believe clean water is a civil right and continue to support efforts to ensure clean water in our food and ecosystem, protect wetlands and improve water conservation.  

STANDING UP FOR WHAT IS RIGHT

This week the Human Rights Campaign, the nation’s largest LGBTQ civil rights organization, released their annual congressional scorecard. I’m proud to stand on the right side of history when it comes to protecting and advancing the rights of the LGBTQ community. No one should be discriminated against because of who they are, or who they love. Learn more at www.hrc.org/scorecard.

￼

Subject: A message from Senator Cory Gardner
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

Home
Contact Me
Press Releases
Videos

Dear Friend,  
Making Flying Unauthorized Drones Over Wildfires a Felony 
This month, I voted in favor of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act of 2018. This legislation included my provision to make the use of flying unauthorized drones over wildfires a felony. I heard directly from the brave men and women combating the wildfires across Colorado this year and after meeting with them I worked on this provision to deter the idiotic behavior of unauthorized drones being used over wildfires.  
￼
Click here or on the photo above to view my remarks. 
Downloadable video is available here.  
Advancing Legislation Important to Colorado's Public Lands
Recently, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, on which I serve, advanced multiple pieces of legislation important to Colorado out of committee. The Land and Water Conservation Authorization and Funding Act aims to fully fund and permanently reauthorize the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF) was one of these bills. Also passed out of committee was the Restore our Parks Act. This legislation focuses on the $12 billion park maintenance backlog that prevents new investment and improvements in infrastructure to parks in Colorado and nationwide. 
Other legislation I have backed that also advanced out of committee are the Amache Study Act, that assesses the historical significance of Amache, and the Wildfire Management Technology Advancement Act of 2017, that increases firefighter safety. It also included the Pike National Historic Trail Study Act, legislation that could designate Zebulon Pike's famous route of exploration through the American Southwest, as well as the Endangered Fish Recovery Programs Extension Act of 2017, which maintains annual funding for the Upper Colorado and San Juan Fish recovery programs through 2023.  
View my remarks from the hearing here. 
To download the video click here. 
ARIA Policy Moves Forward
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has recently advanced the Asia Reassurance Initiative Act of 2018 (ARIA) out of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously. ARIA serves as a generational policy framework that enhances U.S leadership in the Indo-Pacific region. This legislation demonstrates a commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific and rules-based international order while projecting American values of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Unites States has been, and will remain, a Pacific Power.   
2018 Colorado Principal of the Year
It was great having the opportunity to meet with Joe Simo on his trip to Washington. Joe is from Centennial Middle School in Montrose and is the 2018 Colorado Principal of the Year. I always appreciate meeting with educators from our great state and hearing new ideas on how to improve education in Colorado.
￼
 Improving Artificial Intelligence
I've introduced the bipartisan Artificial Intelligence (AI) Government Act that would improve the utilization of AI throughout the federal government by providing resources and direction to agencies. Better understanding of the opportunities and challenges these technologies present is crucial in bringing agencies and industry to the table to discuss government adoption of AI. 
  Meeting with Coloradans in Washington
I met with many Coloradans to discuss a variety of important, bipartisan issues recently. These discussions revolved around education, school safety, sports in academia, and issues farmers in CO are currently facing. I also was able to meet with the Colorado Bankers Association, Malachi, the Boys and Girls Club of America Youth of the Year, as well as Thomas Walsh, a member of the U.S. Paralympic Ski Team. 
Below are a few pictures from my meetings.  
￼ 
￼
￼ 
￼ 
￼
￼
 
Need Help with a Federal Agency? 
My staff is available to assist you with finding out the status of a case and requesting additional information from a federal agency. I have offices in Denver, Durango, Pueblo, Grand Junction, Fort Collins, Greeley, Yuma, and Colorado Springs. Learn more about how we can help here.  
Thank you for taking the time to read my weekly update. If I can be of any assistance to you, please contact my Washington, D.C. office at (202) 224-5941. 
  
Sincerely, 
￼
Cory Gardner 
United States Senator

Subject: Capitol Hill Update from Congressman Castro
Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
Last week, I released a Diplomatic Cable episode featuring former U.S. State Department Under Secretary for Political Affairs, former U.S. Ambassador to NATO, and 27 year civil servant Ambassador Nick Burns on immigration, refugee quotas, trade deals, and the overall effects of the budget cuts to U.S. diplomacy and development. You can listen to the episode on iTunes, Spotify, and Google Play. 
￼ 
￼ 
Indefinite Family Detention 
We recently learned that the Administration is shuttling hundreds of migrant children overnight to a tent city in Tornillo, Texas. In response, I wrote Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary Alex Azar requesting more information on these midnight runs, and whether HHS plans to open other temporary shelters for migrant children.  
While we have not heard back on this congressional inquiry yet, I toured the Tornillo shelter this week to see the conditions in which these children were being held. You can read about my visit here.  
We must continue to shed light on the issue of minors held in detention, and reuniting all those children who were separated from their parents as part of the Trump Administration’s zero-tolerance immigration policy. You can read my statement here on press reports that the Administration is mulling over its second iteration of the family separation policy. 
Honoring our Nation's Veterans 
Team Castro attended the Unaccompanied Burial of U.S. Army Veteran, Mr. John Ezba. On behalf of the San Antonio community, we thank Mr. Ezba and all Veterans for their service to our great nation. 
￼ ￼ 
District Updates 
Team Castro attended the SAStands Meeting for an update on the cite and release efforts and a Know Your Rights workshop; the centennial celebration of Woodlawn Lake Park; the Artpace Chalk It Up Festival where local artists came together to showcase their works while encouraging arts education and creativity in the SA community; and the 2018 LGBTQ Film Festival and San Antonio Coming Out Day.
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
Team Castro also joined the San Antonio Charter Amendment Election panel discussion along with other citizens; the Restored by Light: Reinspired art show at Mission San Juan Capistrano; and the San Antonio Opportunity Zone Conference, on potential investment & development in 20 census tracts in San Antonio. 
￼ ￼ 
Bipartisan Avenues 
It was great to speak to the Southwestern Association of Criminal Justice conference in San Antonio about finding areas of bipartisan cooperation on criminal justice reform including body cameras and police brutality. 
￼ ￼ 
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress

Dear Friend, 
Fall is a busy time for many, so I wanted to take this opportunity to remind you of Medicare’s Open Enrollment period, which started this week and ends December 7.    First and foremost, if you are satisfied with the Medicare coverage you have, you don’t need to do anything at all. If you are currently a Medicare beneficiary, you remain eligible and will continue to receive Medicare benefits.  
Below are some helpful resources courtesy of Medicare.gov that will guide anyone interested in participating. 
·         Medicare Plan Finder -- Here you can review, compare, and join a 2019 plan using your zip code or through a more personalized search. 
·         Enroll in a Medicare Plan -- Visit this page if you already know the name of the plan you want to join. 
·         Check Your Enrollment -- Use this tool to check your current and future enrollment. 
Remember, this is the only time you can change your plan this year, so take this opportunity to find something that works for you or your eligible family member. Please don’t hesitate to contact me on this or any other federal issue of importance to you.

￼
 
￼ 
ABOUT LINDA
SERVICES
LEGISLATION
ISSUES
MEDIA CENTER
CONTACT
 
Dear Friend,  Exercising the right to vote is one of the most fundamental rights in our democracy. It is also one of the most hard-won, as women and people of color fought tirelessly and sacrificed greatly to access this right. 
Throughout our country's history, some have tried to limit access to the polls by conditioning the right to vote on various discriminatory requirements. Despite the progress that has been made to give more Americans a voice in our democracy, states and localities across the country have recently passed sweeping laws that disproportionately suppress the voting rights of minorities. This has been a direct result of the Supreme Court's 2013 decision in Shelby County v. Holder, which gutted core protections from the Voting Rights Act of 1965 (VRA). 

Every eligible voter should be able to participate in our democracy without having to face unnecessary barriers. That is why I am fighting to protect every American’s access to the polls and standing against arbitrary laws that make it more difficult for citizens to exercise this right. In Congress, I continue to support the Voting Rights Advancement Act, which restores critical measures in the VRA and strengthens voter protections for minorities. 
Without restoring many of these protections, our democracy and our country cannot continue to grow and progress. I am a firm believer that when more people participate in the civic process, our elected officials better reflect the diversity of our country.
Please know that I will never stop fighting to ensure equal access to the polls, and full participation in our American democracy.  
Sincerely, ￼  Linda T. Sánchez Member of Congress 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Washington Update
Strengthening and Expanding Social Security 
Many retired Americans rely almost exclusively on Social Security for their retirement income, and this earned benefit does not adequately keep up with the rising costs they face. Although the cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) of 2.8 percent for 2019 represents the largest increase since 2012, there is still more that should be done to improve on Social Security's promise. That is why I recently introduced the Strengthening Social Security Act, which would change the formula used to calculate COLA adjustments to the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly (CPI-E). Using this more accurate reflection of the inflation affecting today's seniors will enhance the lives of millions of Americans. I also joined the recently formed Expand Social Security Caucus because I recognize that our seniors deserve a raise and I am committed to working with my colleagues to preserve this program for years to come.

Highlights from the District
￼  
Recently, I held an Understanding Medicare event with the Center for Health Care Rights to provide some useful information as we begin the period for Medicare open enrollment. Thank you to everyone who took time our their busy day to learn more about the different enrollment options and to discuss how policies at the federal level are impacting our community. Remember that Medicare open enrollment runs from October 15 to December 7. If you or a loved one has Medicare, now is the time to compare the quality of available health and drug plan options and decide if you want to select a new plan for the coming year.

Flu Season is Here 
The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health offers flu vaccines at no charge to people who do not have health insurance or whose healthcare provider does not offer flu vaccines. The following clinics are taking place in our community, so bring a friend with you and do your part to help prevent the spread of the flu.

That is why I hope you will encourage your children to come learn more about some of the exciting and unique career opportunities that require more than a high school diploma, but less than a four-year degree.
Working professionals as well as representatives from our local community colleges, trade unions, and apprenticeship programs will be available to answer questions about careers in fields such as: aviation, construction, health sciences, and automobile technology. For more information, please visit my website.

Congresswoman Encourages More Central Ohioans to Vote 
With less than three weeks (19 days) until the 2018 General Election, U.S. Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03) is urging Central Ohioans and all Americans to go to the polls, vote, and have their voice heard.
On the first day of early voting in Ohio, Beatty implored a crowd gathered in front of the Franklin County Board of Elections to show up, speak out, and cast their ballot on or before November 6th. “Your voice is your vote, and your vote is your voice,” Beatty said. “To paraphrase former President Obama, ‘if you want to see real change and new leadership, don’t boo, vote!’”

Subject: Commentary: Veterans Deserve Better Than the VA’s 45,000 Job Vacancies
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Commentary: Veterans Deserve Better Than the VA’s 45,000 Job Vacancies
By Congressman Vicente Gonzalez (TX-15)
￼ 
Since its creation in 1930, the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has provided medical care and services to over nine million military veterans - making the VA the largest integrated health care system in the U.S. However, limited staff and resources have restricted veterans’ access to healthcare. In 2014, it was reported that 40 veterans died in Phoenix, Arizona because of unusually long wait times. This is unacceptable.
Currently, there are over 34,000 veterans who reside in the 15th District of Texas; a large number, but small in comparison to the VA’s 45,000 vacant jobs. These 45,000 vacancies represent about ten percent of the VA’s workforce and are emblematic of a larger problem that we have the power to change. Our veterans deserve a VA that works and works for them.
It has been my goal to support members of the U.S. Armed Forces – past, present, and future. My father was a Korean War Veteran and a U.S. Merchant Marine and it has been my mission to craft legislation and enact policies that protect those who have protected this great nation.
This Congress, I have introduced and supported legislation that would allow us to chip away at inefficiencies and outdated practices, build capacity at the VA, and better serve our servicemembers. I proudly supported the VA Mission Act, which overhauls the community care program, and introduced H.R. 6281, the Veterans FAIR Act of 2018, which seeks to provide veterans with sufficient time to transition back to civilian life before committing to binding benefits plans.
If you are a veteran having an issue with the VA, or know of one in need of assistance, please – reach out to my offices at (888) 217-0261. You can also contact Wounded Warrior Fellow and Caseworker, Patrick Roberts, at Patrick.Roberts@mail.house.gov. 
To every veteran that needs assistance, there is assistance available, and I will fight to make sure you receive it. 
____________________________________________

Subject: Medicare is under threat
Message:
News from Representative Brat 
￼ 
Website 
Subscribe
To Newsletter 
Constituent
Services 
Legislative
Resources 
Press
Shop 
About 
Dave 
Contact
Dave 



Dear Friend, 
Since I came to Congress, I have been critical of Obamacare. As I continue to travel throughout the Seventh District, it is the number one issue I hear about. People are concerned about how they will be able to afford the skyrocketing premiums and deductibles they face under this failed policy.  President Obama promised families that Obamacare would cut premiums, but average individual market premiums more than doubled from 2013 to 2017. We were told if "you like your plan, you can keep it," but 4.7 million Americans saw their plans canceled in Obamacare's first year.  Rather than admit wrong and vote to move away from Obamacare, Democrats are suggesting we add even more government to fix the mess they created. In vogue in the Democratic party is a single-payer government run plan they call "Medicare for All." It would be more accurate to name it "Medicare for None." In short, this plan is a total government takeover of your healthcare and would destroy Medicare as a program for seniors for all 1.5 million plus Virginians who count on it. It would also eliminate nearly 5 million private health insurance plans Virginians currently have. Much like the DMV, you will see long lines, poor quality care, and a decline in innovation if Democrats have their way.  What does a total government takeover of the healthcare industry cost? The Richmond Times-Dispatch reports it will cost $32 trillion and would require Washington to double your taxes to pay for it.  
￼
￼
We need to start over on health care and get it right for Virginia families. The policies from Washington should result in more insurance options at lower costs, not a total government takeover that moves us further down the road to socialism.

Thank you,

￼

Congressman Dave Brat

Subject: Making the Economy Great Again
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Graves
￼
 
Website
Meet Sam 
Legislation
News 
Services
6th District
Contact Sam
 
October 17, 2018
￼ 

E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.* 
 ￼ 
 *By subscribing to my e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e- mail account.

Dear Friend, 
President Obama famously said in 2016 that President Trump would need a “magic wand” to get the economy to do what he was promising. It turns out he didn’t need a wand; just sensible economic policies that needed to be put in place. 
I was proud to support common-sense economic policies like the tax cuts which greatly benefitted the middle class and our small businesses. On top of that, we’ve gotten rid of numerous regulations that were crushing our economy with help from the President whose administration is doing the same at the agency level. 
Can you guess what happened as a result of those “magic” economic policies? 
On the national level, we’ve seen over 4 million new jobs created, more Americans than ever are employed, unemployment is incredibly low, poverty rates have fallen and we’re seeing the highest GDP growth rate in 14 years. 
In Missouri alone, it’s estimated that the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will lead to the average household receiving a 7.1% increase in their income! Missourians have also seen a utility rate cut for 1.4 million customers and the lowest unemployment level since the year 2000. 
The optimism and confidence ratings are through the roof for small businesses. The bottom line is that things are going very, very well and across the country, the positive effects of a booming economy are being felt on a daily basis. 
So where do we go from here? 
America needs to keep moving forward. The numbers cannot be ignored and the people I talk to in North Missouri back up the statistics every single day. 
Last month, I voted to keep the tax cuts in place permanently. Along with that, all of the important deductions and credits would be permanent as well. And new investment options for families would allow them to save and grow the additional money they are seeing as a result of the tax cuts. Making sure the middle class and our small businesses continue to thrive will only lead to more economic growth. 
I’ve been saying this is what the economy needed for a long time but getting lower taxes and less regulation in place wasn’t easy. Yet, it works. And it turns out it wasn’t magic. Just common sense. It’s that kind of common sense I hope we see more of in the years to come. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Sam Graves

Subject: Tickets for tours in Washington, D.C. and an upcoming event featuring Congresswoman Barragán!
Message:
View this email in your browser 
￼ 
Tickets for Tours in Washington, D.C. 
￼ 
Dear Lindsey, 

Washington, D.C. is a beautiful city full of history and culture, and it is my honor to help you make the most out of your visit. Touring our nation’s Capital is a remarkable experience that will certainly leave you inspired and amazed. There is no doubt you will always find something to do in D.C.  Whether walking the halls of the Capitol or paying a visit to the White House, my office can assist you in requesting tours and tickets to some of Washington D.C.’s most popular destinations.

My office is giving away four tickets to go on a White House Garden Tour only for this weekend. If any constituents from California's 44th Congressional District are in D.C. and are looking to do something this weekend, stop by our office or call us at 202-225-8220. 

For future visits to our nation’s Capital, please visit my website for more information on how to book a tour for D.C.'s most popular attractions. I hope to see you in D.C. soon! 

In Community,
￼
Nanette Diaz Barragán
Congresswoman, California's 44th District 

Popular Destinations
	•	The White House
	•	The Supreme Court
	•	The U.S. Capitol Building
	•	The Library of Congress
	•	The Bureau of Engraving and Printing
	•	The Pentagon 
	•	The FBI
	•	The Department of State 
	•	The Kennedy Center
	•	The National Archives Museum 
	•	The Treasury Department
Before making a tour request, please note:
Once the request is submitted, the number and names of people allowed on the tour cannot be changed.
Please make travel plans first, then contact my office when you have a specific date in mind. It is not advisable to wait for a confirmed tour before making travel arrangements, as the White House confirms tours with very little notice (usually as little as 14 days advance notice).
For the best chances of having a tour request be accommodated, please give at least three months advance notice (this is the earliest the White House will accept a request from our office). Tour requests cannot be submitted less than three weeks before the requested tour date.
If you have any questions or concerns, please call our office at 202-225-8220.

Join Congresswoman Barragán at CalEITC4Me's 2018 Women’s Economic Empowerment Summit on October 25th!
￼ 
Join me on Thursday, October 25th, at CalEITC4Me's 2018 Women’s Economic Empowerment Summit from 8:30AM - 2:30PM at the South Gate Municipal Auditorium (4900 Southern Ave, South Gate, CA 90280).

The goal for this event is to gather nonprofit and philanthropic leaders to share information and resources beneficial to achieving security for low income women and their families. Panelists will discuss the challenges as well as the programs, strategies, and solutions that are building financial well-being in local communities. Topics highlighted will include participant centered coaching and other best practices that have proven successful in helping women achieve economic security.

The event is free and open to the public. To register for the event, click here.

The key to ending poverty is investing in women. I look forward to sharing ideas on what each one of us can do to empower women and bring them on the path to stability, upward mobility, and long-term prosperity.

Subject: September Jobs Report - Record low unemployment!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





                                 Jobs & Economy Report – September  Top Story
The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics recently reported that the unemployment rate in September fell to 3.7%, the lowest level since 1969. BLS also found that, on average, 190,000 new jobs have been created in each of the past three months. This report is the latest sign that our nation’s economy is booming. Over 4 million jobs have been created nationwide since November 2016.
Montanans benefiting from surging economy
￼
http://www.tcmemt.com/
Matt and Kris Lane are owners of Tri-County Mechanical whose offices are in Helena, Butte and Great Falls. They employ over 100 people in Montana. Matt recently shared that in 25 years he has never seen their business do so well. He also said they have seen a large profit as a result of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, and that 100% of the tax savings has been put into new equipment, vehicles, and bonuses to their employees!
Historic Trade Deal reached
I’m also pleased that President Trump recently reached a new and improved trade agreement with Canada and Mexico. This agreement is a positive step and will help provide certainty for Montana farmers, ranchers, and businesses. Moving forward, I will continue to review the deal and work with the President to ensure Montanans have the right opportunities to succeed.
Further, President Trump has begun negotiating a much-needed trade agreement with Japan. I have long championed the need to level the playing field in Japan and other Asia-Pacific countries so that Montana farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers have greater access to these important markets.
￼
 
Tax Cuts and Jobs Act - Did You Know?
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act reduced rates across the board, doubled the standard deduction, doubled the child tax credit, and made American entrepreneurs and businesses more competitive. And contrary to the claims of opponents, it actually increased the share of federal taxes paid by millionaires, according to the nonpartisan Joint Committee on Taxation. In short, the tax cuts law was both sweeping and fair.

Subject: 11,000 constituents helped in Sacramento County!
Message:
￼ 
Lindsey – I wanted to send you some great news.

As of today, my office has officially helped more than 11,000 constituents in Sacramento County, including returning nearly $5.5 million to local taxpayers.

Making Government Work for Sacramento County is about serving our community – it’s about helping veterans cut through red tape, making sure seniors receive their Social Security, and ensuring families get the tax refunds they were promised.

To me, this milestone is more than just a number. These are friends and loved ones right here in Sacramento County.

And we’d be honored to serve you too. Please call my office at (916) 635-0505 or visit bera.house.gov/gethelp to learn more.

￼

We’ve helped constituents like Aaron – an Iraq War veteran – finally receive his GI Bill benefits, so he could pay for school and become a paramedic. 

We helped Jon, a local small business owner, finally receive his green card after waiting for ten years so he could stay focused on his company and employees.

We helped Courtney get her passport approved, so she could attend her grandmother’s funeral.

Congress should be a place for service. And I’m committed to continuing to serve you however we can. That’s why my office can help with everything from stalled passports to veterans’ health care issues. We’re also happy to connect people with whatever resources they may need.

If you need help with the federal government, please feel free to call us at (916) 635-0505 or visit bera.house.gov/gethelp to learn more.

Be well,
￼
Ami Bera, M.D.
Member of Congress

P.S. Your thoughtful suggestions always help my office do a better job of serving you.

Subject: Bipartisan step forward to combat opioid abuse epidemic
Message:
Click here to open this message in your browser    
￼ 

Dear Hoosier, 
The opioid abuse epidemic has taken the lives of too many Hoosiers, harming families and communities across our state and around the country. I’m proud to have helped the Senate take more bipartisan actions to combat this public health crisis with the passage of the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, which includes several provisions I introduced. President Trump is expected to sign the SUPPORT Act into law soon. To see my speech on the Senate floor about the bill click here or below. 
This bipartisan bill is an example of what we can accomplish when we work together. This bill provides important new tools to combat the epidemic, and works to ensure that those providing prevention, treatment, and recovery services in our communities have the resources necessary to help those in need of assistance. 
￼ 
To watch my recent floor speech on the SUPPORT Act, click the image above or click here.  
Some of the provisions I led that were included in the bill include: 
Substance Use Disorder Workforce Loan Repayment Act 
This provision, based on legislation I introduced with Senators Lisa Murkowski and Maggie Hassan in March, will address the ongoing shortage of professionals needed to provide treatment and recovery services. It incentivizes substance use disorder providers to work in areas that have high overdose rates or a shortage of treatment providers by providing up to $250,000 in student loan relief in exchange for up to six years of service. Investing in these providers could help save the lives of parents, siblings, friends, and neighbors that are struggling with addiction. 
Dr. Todd Graham Pain Management, Treatment and Recovery Act 
This provision, named in honor of Todd A. Graham, M.D. – a doctor in South Bend, Indiana with over three decades of service – who was senselessly murdered in 2017 after refusing to prescribe an opioid to a patient, will expand Medicare beneficiaries’ access to non-opioid alternatives for treating pain. It is based on bipartisan legislation I introduced with Senator Todd Young. 
Provisions to encourage the development of non-addictive pain treatments
As the opioid crisis continues to wreak havoc on families in Indiana, it’s clear there’s a need for new, alternative treatments for those battling chronic or acute pain. Earlier this year, Senator Young and I introduced two bipartisan bills aimed at bringing non-addictive pain medications and treatments to patients more quickly and helping clarify how the FDA approves treatments that reduce the need for opioids. I am proud that both of these important provisions were included in the SUPPORT Act. 
This bill is an important step, but we are not finished. We know it will take all of us, working together, to make more progress combating this epidemic. I am proud to represent all Hoosiers in the Senate and will continue working on bipartisan, commonsense policies to reduce the overdose rate in our state. I’m the hired help for Indiana, so if there is anything I can do, please do not hesitate to contact my office at 317-226-5555 or email me here. 
 
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Senator Joe Donnelly 
 

  
  
￼  ￼ ￼ ￼

￼

￼￼

Subject: VIDEO UPDATE: no more pharmacy gag clauses
Message:
￼
Okay -- this is really exciting. The President signed my bipartisan legislation to prevent pharmacist "gag clauses" into law!




Here's the story: Earlier this year at a healthcare roundtable, I heard from a woman who was shocked to find her mother's prescriptions would actually cost less without her insurance -- and she was even more shocked that her pharmacist couldn't tell her that basic information.
Well, that didn't sound right to me -- so I set out to fix it. And this past week... we did!  WATCH THE VIDEO: ￼  What does this mean for Missourians? Well, now when you're at the pharmacy counter, you'll know the lowest price you can pay for your prescriptions.
I'm committed to making healthcare more affordable for Missourians, from eliminating these pharmacist gag clauses to pushing back on "junk" health insurance plans that could raise costs for seniors and bring back discrimination against folks with pre-existing conditions. 
I will always do what's right for Missouri - whether it's pushing for more affordable prescription drugs or protecting health insurance for Missourians with pre-existing conditions. 
Thanks for being with me in this fight.

￼
Senator Claire McCaskill
Visit my website: 
www.mccaskill.senate.gov

Subject: Standing Up for Wisconsinites
Message:

￼ 
Home 
About Ron 
Issues 
Wisconsin's 3rd District 
Constituent Services 
Newsroom 
Contact 
October 17, 2018 
Dear friend, 
As someone born-and-raised in western Wisconsin, I am proud to work every day on solutions for the issues that matter most to our communities.
Helping Wisconsinites Impacted by Flooding and Severe Storms My staff and I have been on the ground, touring flooded communities in our state and helping Wisconsinites begin the process of rebuilding their homes and businesses. Wisconsinites are strong, but there is no doubt that federal assistance will be needed to help everyone get back on their feet.
I have called on the President to fully support the state of Wisconsin, our communities, and our farmers, and will continue to help those in need navigate federal agencies as they seek disaster relief.  More information about how my office can help flood victims is available by visiting my website: kind.house.gov, or by calling toll-free: 1-888-442-8040. Wisconsinites are also encouraged to report home damage by calling 211, or their county emergency management offices.
Fighting for You This week I sent a letter to Alex Azar and Seema Verma, Secretary of Health and Human Services and Administrator of CMS, demanding that they provide additional Navigator funding in order to assist Wisconsin residents enroll in health insurance coverage for 2019. Only one Wisconsin organization was awarded federal funding for enrollment services this year, and the grant was cut by over 80% from prior years.
Choosing a healthcare plan can be complicated, and I want to ensure we have sufficient resources available to find coverage that works for every Wisconsinite and their family. Nobody should go without the care they need.
It’s Time for Medicare Open Enrollment  From October 15 to December 7, all Wisconsinites with Medicare can change their Medicare health plans and prescription drug coverage for the following year to better meet their needs.  If you have questions about signing up or want to talk through your options with a trained professional, call 1-800-MEDICARE or visit Medicare.gov. My office can also help connect you with the right person to find more information about plans.
Here to Help My office is available to help you work through issues with government agencies and departments. This includes getting copies of service records, receiving benefits, and cutting through government red tape. You can reach the office by calling 1-888-442-8040 or visiting kind.house.gov.
Sincerely,
￼

Subject: Happening Today! Know Mental Health, No Suicide: A Suicide and Mental Health Awareness Resource Fair and Panel Discussion
Message:
RESOURCE FAIR TODAY AT 5P PANEL DISCUSSION TODAY AT 6P  
 
￼
 
 
 
 Happening Today!  Dear Friend,
My office will host the Suicide and Mental Health Awareness Resource Fair and Panel Discussion TODAY, October 17th from 5 pm to 8 pm at the International House at 1817 Central Ave #215 Charlotte, NC 28205.
The Resource Fair starts at 5:00 pm and the panel discussion starts at 6:00 pm. Attendees will have an additional opportunity to speak with the resource providers following the panel. 
Panelists include Dr. Elise Herman, Psychiatry Specialist at Novant Health; Dr. Adrianne Pinkney, Integrative Wellness Coach and Founder of B. WELL: Live Consciously; Victor Armstrong, Vice President of Behavioral Health at Atrium Health; and Kathy Rogers, Executive Director at Mental Health America of the Central Carolinas.
The event will provide constituents with resources to identify and manage a variety of crisis situations ranging from anxiety to suicidal thought. Constituents will walk away confident that they have the resources necessary to manage their mental health and assist others around them who are struggling to manage, including students.
I hope you will be there to take advantage of this opportunity to learn more about the resources available to identify the signs, symptoms, and treatment of mental health challenges. Resources and panelists will also have information on domestic violence and challenges resulting from sexual assault/harassment. Please see the list of confirmed resource information providers below:
	•	Mental Health America of the Central Carolinas
	•	American Foundation for Suicide Prevention
	•	Veterans Bridge Home

	•	Monarch

I hope you can attend. Please share this invitation with your friends, family, and neighbors.
 
Best Regards,

Subject: Tune in TODAY at 1:00 p.m. to watch Oxnard's Sgt. Major Canley receive Medal of Honor
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼





Friend,  
Today at 1:00 p.m. PT, Ventura County’s own Sergeant Major (Ret.) John Canley will receive the prestigious Medal of Honor – the highest military honor awarded by the U.S. government – for his heroism during the Vietnam War. You can watch a live stream of the ceremony here. Tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. PT, you can also watch a live stream of his induction into the Hall of Heroes at the Pentagon.  
I have had the great privilege to get to know Sergeant Major Canley and his family, and his dedication to his fellow servicemembers and to our country is unparalleled. He is also truly one of the most humble and gracious people I have ever met. It was my great honor to have him attend the State of the Union with me this year, which fell on the 50-year anniversary of the start of the Tet Offensive, where his extraordinary actions saved so many lives.  
In 1968, during the Battle of Hue, Sergeant Major Canley’s commanding officer was gravely wounded, so he took immediate command of his company, directing several counter attacks, saving lives, and advancing the war strategically. For his extraordinary heroism, Sergeant Major Canley received the Navy Cross, as well as two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart.  
In 2014, one of Sergeant Major Canley’s fellow servicemembers contacted me to request that I recommend that his medal be upgraded to the Medal of Honor. My office requested a review of Sergeant Major Canley’s records, and in December 2017, Secretary of Defense Mattis sent a letter stating that he agreed that Sergeant Major Canley’s actions merit award of the Medal of Honor. However, Secretary Mattis noted that Congress would need to pass legislation to waive the five-year time limit on awarding the Medal of Honor. I authored legislation to make Sergeant Major Canley eligible to receive the medal, and it was signed into law in January. Today – at long last – he will receive the Medal of Honor. You can read more about Sergeant Major Canley’s story in the VC Star.  
We have a sacred duty to all our men and women who have served our country. That is why I will continue to make sure that Sergeant Major Canley, as well as all of Ventura County’s veterans, receive the benefits, recognition, and care that they have earned and deserve.  
If you or someone you know needs help with a federal agency, please call my office at (805) 379-1779. I am here to help.  
Sincerely,
￼
JULIA BROWNLEY Member of Congress  P.S. Your suggestions help me do a better job of serving you. Did you find this email informative? [Yes] [No] [Other]

Subject: Poll: Term Limits for Congress
Message:
￼ 

Poll: Term Limits
Hoosiers,

The first bill I introduced after I was sworn into office in 2017 was H.J.Res 23, which would impose term limits on Members of Congress. Specifically, this legislation would limit the number of terms that a Member of Congress may serve to four in the House of Representatives and two in the Senate.

Our government is here to serve you - not the other way around. Establishing term limits for Members of Congress would ensure a change in culture that will get us back to a Washington that serves the great people of this country instead of serving career politicians.

Question of the Week: Do you support establishing term limits for Members of Congress?

[_] Yes.
[_] No.
[_] I don't know.
[_] Other (share your thoughts).

Take the poll here.

Subject: Feeding the Future
Message:
News from Representative Noem

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
During the 2017-18 school year, 142,000 South Dakota students ate meals at school. I am glad to see President Trump recognize this week of October as National School Lunch Week. It’s incredibly important we provide healthy, desirable food to fuel our kids as they learn. 
￼ 
A few years ago, the Obama administration created a failing one-size-fits-all meal program that severely restricted meats, grains, sodium, and more without a good scientific basis for doing so. As written, meat was limited to 3-4 chicken nuggets a day and products like milk and cheese would have been difficult to serve, as they have naturally occurring sodium. I introduced legislation to push back on these guidelines, giving schools more flexibility. I'm thankful my urging resulted in added freedom from rigid nutrition standards, but it’s an issue we continue to work on.  
That’s why I’ve introduced legislation that once and for all transforms the school meal requirements into voluntary guidelines, giving local schools much-needed breathing room and allowing those closest to our kids to make decisions about our kids. 
Have a great day! 
-Kristi

Subject: The VA's MISSION Act To Do List
Message:
￼    ￼   ￼

￼
 
 
￼
 
When Montana veterans came to me with issues with the Choice Program, I listened. And I got to work with a Republican Senator out of Georgia named Johnny Isakson to write a bipartisan bill—the VA MISSION Act—that President Trump signed into law this year to deliver a better health care experience for Montana’s veterans. 

Veterans should be able to rely on their local doctors when the VA can’t deliver. That’s why we wrote the VA MISSION Act. This bipartisan law puts veterans in the driver’s seat about where to get their health care services, and it also cuts government red tape that has caused so many difficulties for Montana veterans. 

We worked with veterans, advocates and the VA to craft a bold, bipartisan compromise that scraps the Choice Program, streamlines community care, and puts medical decisions in the hands of doctors and veterans – where they should be.

And on June 6, 2018, the President signed the bill into law, calling it a “historic moment.”  

￼

From that day, the VA has a year to implement our VA MISSION Act. And every step of the way, I’ll be holding the VA accountable to use the tools we’ve given them to get the job done right. 

Now we need Montana veterans and community providers to help make sure that the VA knows what works, and more importantly, what doesn’t work, for Montanans as they craft the Veterans Community Care Program. When the VA wants veterans and community providers to weigh in, I’ll make sure that you know when and where you can tell the VA about your experience with community care.

If you have any questions about the new Veterans Community Care Program, please don’t hesitate to contact my office for answers. As always, it’s an honor to serve you in the United States Senate.
 ￼

Subject: Faces of the crisis
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

October 17, 2018 
Dear Friend,  
It continues to be a great honor to serve and represent you in the U.S. Senate. Here is a brief update on just some of the issues I’ve been working on.  
￼ 
Working Across the Aisle to Combat the Opioid Crisis 
￼ 
Joining NH leaders confronting the opioid epidemic at Farnum Center in Manchester 
Earlier this month, I joined a bipartisan majority in the Senate to pass opioid response legislation that will provide treatment providers, recovery centers, researchers, first responders, and other stakeholders with access to new tools to help save lives. This legislation is the product of months of hearings and negotiations, and builds on the bipartisan progress Congress has already made to address this crisis. It also includes key provisions that I sponsored to take on the fentanyl crisis in particular, which continues to be the main contributor of overdose deaths in New Hampshire. We still have a long way to go until we provide all those with substance use disorders the treatment and care they need, and I will continue to work across the aisle until we turn the tide of this crisis.  
In the Capitol, Putting Faces on the Opioid Crisis 
￼ 
Too often the conversation in Washington surrounding the opioid epidemic is focused on statistics. The scale of this crisis is staggering but numbers don’t tell the whole story. Anne Marie and Jim Zanfagna lost their daughter, Jacqueline, at 25 years old to an accidental overdose in October 2014. Shortly after Jacqueline’s death, Anne Marie painted a portrait of her and after showing it to a local support group began receiving requests to paint portraits of other loved ones who were lost to an overdose. These Angels of Addictions portraits facilitate grief healing through art, raise awareness of the opioid epidemic and honor those who have been lost. 
￼ 
I was honored to host the Zanfagnas and over 120 Angels of Addictions portraits in the U.S. Capitol last week. Each portrait is a deeply personal reminder of what this country has lost to the opioid crisis. The Angels of Addictions portraits reminds us who we are fighting for, and I appreciate that members on both sides of the aisle, as well as staff and visitors to the Capitol, took the time to come see the Angels of Addictions exhibit. 
￼ 
Welcoming Pastor Andrew Brunson Back to the U.S.  
I have been working across the aisle over the last year to secure the freedom of Pastor Andrew Brunson, an American held hostage in Turkey. In June I visited and met with Pastor Brunson as well as Turkish President Erdogan, whom I pressed for Pastor Brunson's release. On Friday, it was a tremendous relief to see Turkish authorities finally release him and allow him to return to the United States. His detention was an injustice but, ultimately, Turkish authorities did the right thing in releasing him. The effort to secure his release was an excellent example of bipartisan cooperation and coordination across the U.S. government. I hope that, going forward, Turkey will also release the others we have been advocating for who are wrongfully detained, so that we can further repair the relationship between our nations.
Protecting Consumers from Junk Insurance & Exorbitant Health Care Bills 
Last week I voted to reverse the Trump Administration’s new policy on short-term health insurance plans, which are also known as “junk plans.” These junk plans often deny coverage for pre-existing conditions and fail to cover maternity care and substance use treatment. They also drive up health care costs for others and threaten the stability of health insurance markets. I opposed these junk plans because they will further sabotage health care in this country. Republican leadership and the administration should be working to make health care more affordable and accessible rather than continuing to sabotage the health care marketplace for consumers. 
In addition, earlier this month I introduced legislation to combat rising out-of-pocket health costs. Families in New Hampshire and throughout the nation continue to struggle to pay their medical bills and that’s unacceptable. My bill would help fix chronic problems in our health care system by lowering costs for patients and increasing access to health services. This includes putting a cap on what hospitals and physicians can charge uninsured patients and out-of-network patients who have individual market coverage. It’s imperative that Congress take action to reduce these costs and help ensure every American has access to quality, affordable health care. 
Honoring NH Law Enforcement 
￼ 
Every year we honor members of New Hampshire’s law enforcement community for exemplary service at the New Hampshire Congressional Law Enforcement Awards (NH-CLEA) ceremony in Concord. The men and women serving in New Hampshire’s law enforcement are heroes, and it was a privilege to recognize them. I want to extend my sincere appreciation to all of these honorees, as well as their families who support them and also make sacrifices every day. I'm especially grateful for the leadership of our police officers in battling the opioid epidemic. Every day, law enforcement are saving lives and getting lethal drugs off our streets. These law enforcement awards are an opportunity to recognize and honor those lost in the line of duty -- I am eternally grateful for their sacrifice, and they will never be forgotten. 
###

Subject: Expanding Iowa’s Small Business Opportunities Via Tax Reform
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
  
￼ 

 Home | Newsroom | Helping Iowans | Contact 

Good morning– 
Small businesses are the backbone of Iowa’s economy, making up 99% of our businesses. As a member of the Senate Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee, I have made it a priority to pursue pro-growth policies and help small businesses across our great state succeed.
One such effort is my support of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which has provided much needed tax relief in the form of lower tax rates for every income bracket, a new 20 percent deduction for pass-through businesses and increased opportunities for businesses to immediately write off the cost of their investments.  
Included in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is a piece of legislation that I cosponsored: the Investing in Opportunity Act. This encourages private investment in distressed communities, or Opportunity Zones, by allowing investors to temporarily defer taxes on their capital gains and put these dollars to work in these communities.  
It is critical that we make these tax cuts permanent, and I have cosponsored legislation that would do just that. Recently, in my Small Business Committee hearing, I had the opportunity to question our witnesses about the importance of making the small business tax cuts permanent, as well as the promise of Opportunity Zones for rural communities in Iowa.  
￼ 

Positive Impacts of Tax Reform and Opportunity Zones 
 ￼ 
Sens. Tim Scott and Joni Ernst: Why we believe so strongly in the power of 'opportunity zones' 
 ￼ 
Ernst Highlights Positive Impacts of Tax Reform on Iowa's Farmers 
￼ 
Ernst Applauds Designation of 62 Opportunity Zones in Iowa 
 

For more updates on what's happening in Washington, D.C. and Iowa, be sure to 'Like' my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter @SenJoniErnst, and subscribe to my YouTube channel. 
Thank you! 
 ￼
