Subject: Combating Chinese Espionage
Message:
News from Representative Michael McCaul

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward

￼
 
WEBSITE
BIOGRAPHY
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
ISSUES
NEWSROOM
DISTRICT
 
Dear Friends, 
October is Domestic Violence Awareness Month.  In recognition of this, the House - with my support - unanimously approved the reauthorization of the Family Violence Prevention and Services Act.  This is the primary source of federal funding to support emergency shelters and assistance for victims of domestic violence and their families.  
In addition to supporting this funding, I visited the Focusing Families Crisis Center in Hempstead, Texas to learn more about local efforts to combat domestic violence. This local organization is committed to strengthening communities through education, prevention, and intervention to eliminate family violence, sexual assault, and other crisis issues. Thank you for all of the incredible work you do in our local communities to help keep them safe.
￼ 
Below are some highlights from last week: 
Combating Chinese Espionage and Theft 
It was reported that a Chinese intelligence official was arrested in Belgium and extradited to the United States to face espionage charges. The Chinese government steals as much as $600 billion of the United States’ intellectual property annually. FBI Director Christopher Wray said last week that the Chinese government "represents our broadest threat" and are "fighting tomorrow’s fight." I have long advocated for a tougher approach to China and am glad that is finally happening. 
Earlier this year, I questioned State and Treasury Department officials about whether they were looking into placing tougher restrictions on the blatant aggression by China. As Assistant Attorney General Demers said: "We will not tolerate a nation that reaps what it does not sow." 
You can click here or on the image below to watch my questioning of Assistant Secretary Singh and Assistant Secretary Billingslea.  
￼ 
Tomball Chamber of Commerce Lunch 
The Greater Tomball Area Chamber of Commerce provides resources and fosters relationships that empower businesses to prosper. It was great to attend their Friday lunch to talk about the exciting news surrounding our economy. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act has spurred American innovation and unleashed unprecedented optimism across this country. I look forward to working with our local business leaders to continue providing the best environment for hardworking Texans to thrive.  
￼ 
TX-10 Fulbright Recipients 
Since its inception in 1946, the Fulbright Program has provided more than 380,000 participants — chosen for their academic merit and leadership potential — with the opportunity to exchange ideas and contribute to finding solutions to shared international concerns. As a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, I am delighted that six students from TX-10 have been accepted this year. These students will follow in the storied history of the program that has molded renowned world leaders, intellectual titans, and even fellow Members of Congress. Congratulations and best of luck!
You can click here or on the image below to learn more about the Fulbright Program. 
￼ 
 
National Farmers Day 
October 12th was National Farmers Day. Thank you to all of the patriotic, hardworking farmers across our beautiful country. Your important work provides American families with healthy and abundant food that allows them to grow and thrive. I look forward to continuing my long support of our great American farmers.
￼ 
U.S. Navy Turns 243 
This past weekend, the United States Navy celebrated their 243rd birthday. Generations of proud sailors, comprised of brave men and women, have served their nation nobly in a sailors uniform. We honor their 243 years of selfless service at home and on the high seas abroad to ensure we remain what President Lincoln called, "the last best hope for Earth."
￼ 
Legislative Update 
Last week, Members were in their districts for a District Work Period. No votes were held. 
This week, Members will continue to be in their districts for the District Work Period. For this reason, there are no votes currently scheduled in the U.S. House of Representatives. 
As always, I encourage you to visit my website, mccaul.house.gov, for more information on constituent services and legislative updates. Also, follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and YouTube to get the latest updates on my work in Washington and the 10th District of Texas. It continues to be a great honor to represent you in the United States House of Representatives.
  
With Best Regards, 
￼ 
Michael T. McCaul
Member of Congress

Visit my website for more info about the recall: http://bit.ly/2CfQ7Jc   RepPeteOlson  October is #DomesticViolenceAwarenessMonth. We must work together to end this devastating crime b/c homes should be full of love, not fear. If you or someone you know is a victim, please visit http://bit.ly/2QEUt0u  to find resources available near you or call 1-800-799-7233. ￼   RepPeteOlson  A huge thank you to @PasadenaISD_TX for having me out to present the ceremonial coin toss for the @DobieHS Longhorns game against the Kingwood Mustangs last night! #DobiePride  ￼ 
Dear Friend,  Thank you for taking time from your busy schedule to read about some of last week’s highlights here in Texas.    Hearing From Rosenberg Manufacturers  On a recent tour of the Frito Lay facility in Rosenberg, I learned more about their commitment to safety and efforts to develop healthier snack options. We also discussed how aluminum tariffs will impact their business and others like it. Hearing directly from the businesses in our district gives me firsthand knowledge of how federal policies affect them. With over 12.7 million Americans working in manufacturing, including many of our friends and neighbors, it’s crucial that we implement pro-growth, pro-business policies to ensure the American manufacturing industry can grow and thrive. ￼  Rep. Olson tours Frito Lay in Rosenberg with staff from the facility   CYAC Students Learn from Memorial Hermann  We had a great second meeting of our 2018-2019 Congressional Youth Advisory Council (CYAC) ON Saturday. We visited Memorial Hermann to learn about their Life Flight program. We also heard from guest speakers Ashlea Quinonez, Rachel Kemp, Leslie Norman, Dr. Melissa Kwan and Jason Glover, who shared how they started working in the medical field. The CYAC gives students an opportunity to meet with industry leaders, like folks at Memorial Herman. It’s also an opportunity for me to learn their priorities to better represent our youth in Congress.   ￼  Rep. Olson and CYAC students visited Memorial Hermann and learned about their Life Flight program   Supporting Local Veterans  I joined local veterans at VFW Post 3903 in Rosenberg to provide an update on my support of veterans in Congress. Last month, President Trump signed a spending bill that I supported, which included $86.5 billion for VA funding, the largest amount ever, to improve care for our veterans. We also discussed issues that directly impact their lives, like care at the VA. As a Navy veteran, I remain committed to care for our veterans after battle.  ￼  Rep. Olson and local veterans at the Rosenberg VFW Post 3903   Talking Public Service With Pearland Students   I was honored to join Dawson High School Youth and Government and the Pearland Chamber of Commerce last week to discuss the federal legislative process and my work as a Representative in Congress. These bright students are our next generation of leaders and I was impressed by their questions and interest in government and civics. ￼  Rep. Olson addresses Dawson High School Youth and Government students  I’m honored to represent you in Congress. For more information on constituent services, current legislation or to sign up for my E-newsletter, please visit my website, www.olson.house.gov.   Very respectfully, Pete Olson

Subject: Filling you in
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Kuster
￼
 
ABOUT
CONTACT
SERVICES
MEDIA
LEGISLATION
ISSUES
 
October 16, 2018
Connect with us 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
Honoring Those Who Keep Us Safe 
On Friday, I joined Senator Shaheen to take part in the 20th annual Congressional Law Enforcement Awards Ceremony in Concord. Our law enforcement officers put themselves in harm’s way every day to keep us safe and play a critical role in combating the opioid crisis facing New Hampshire. It was wonderful to honor their unyielding courage, compassion, and dedication to our communities and state and I remain committed to fighting for the support and resources they need to do their jobs and protect Granite Staters. 
￼
With Senator Shaheen at the Congressional Law Enforcement Awards 
Investing in Granite State Communities 
I applaud the Senate for unanimously confirming Harold Parker as the next Federal Co-Chair of the Northern Border Regional Commission (NBRC). Since its inception in 2008, the NBRC has invested critical federal resources to rural communities throughout New Hampshire. From increasing affordable housing opportunities for veterans, to expanding treatment facilities for Granite Staters battling substance misuse, the NBRC has made a real difference in our state. I have introduced bipartisan legislation that was included in the House and Senate farm bills to ensure the NBRC is reauthorized, and I look forward to working closely with Harold Parker in his new position.  
On Tuesday, Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan and Congresswoman Carol Shea-Porter and I announced that the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has provided more than $1 million in grants for urban community development and affordable housing in Nashua. Investing in the well-being and success of people who are vulnerable and struggling financially is beneficial to everyone. These funds will help Nashua increase the number of its residents who have the stability that comes with a safe and affordable place to live. In addition, the funds will expand opportunities for people with low and more modest incomes to make a decent living and contribute to our state’s economy. I was proud to join my colleagues for this announcement, and I look forward to our continued efforts to help ensure all Granite Staters can get ahead and thrive.
Championing Higher Education  
I was deeply humbled to receive the New Hampshire College and University Council’s Granite Stater of the Year Award on Thursday evening. The New Hampshire College and University Council (NHCUC) understands the critical intersection of education in meeting the needs of our workforce challenges and acts tirelessly to strengthen collaboration with the business community, improve recruitment of students to New Hampshire colleges and universities, and champion higher education in the state. It was an honor to be recognized, and I look forward to continuing to work with NHCUC to improve skills training and access to quality, affordable higher education.
￼
Receiving the NHCUC Granite Stater of the Year Award 
Conserving New Hampshire’s Natural Treasures 
I joined Senators Shaheen and Hassan and Congresswoman Shea-Porter on Wednesday to announce that the U.S. Department of Interior has awarded New Hampshire more than $500,000 through the State Wildlife Grant (SWG) Program to boost Granite State conservation efforts. For generations, Granite Staters and tourists have enjoyed observing New Hampshire’s amazing wildlife, and these funds will help Granite State species with dwindling populations recover. I’m pleased about this collective investment in our environment, and I will continue to push for policies and programs that protect the animals that call New Hampshire home. 
Here to Serve You  
My biggest responsibility in Congress is to serve you, the people of New Hampshire’s Second Congressional District. If you have questions, concerns, or ideas, please do not hesitate to reach out to my Washington, DC office at 202-225-5206 or my Concord office at 603-226-1002. Thank you, as always, for everything you do to help make New Hampshire such a wonderful place to call home. Have a great rest of the week!
Sincerely,                                       ￼

Subject: Fed Chair Projects Continued Economic Growth, Seniors Get Social Security Increase, Yoder Holds Veterans Roundtable
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
ABOUT  |  CONTACT  |  SERVICES  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATION  |  RESOURCES
￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
October 15, 2018
Last Week in Congress
Fed Chair: U.S. Economy is "Remarkably Positive"
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from the Washington Post
Our last two years of economic growth have been incredible, and experts like Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell say that this success will continue for the foreseeable future. Recently, Chairman Powell described this growth as unprecedented, and predicted that unemployment will remain below 4% through 2020. He also noted that wages are rising but inflation is under control - great news for American workers and consumers. These results are being driven by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, as well as our work to reduce excessive government regulations on businesses. 
￼
Major Cost of Living Increase for Social Security Beneficiaries
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from MarketWatch
The Social Security Administration announced last week that Social Security recipients will receive at 2.8% cost of living increase next year - the largest increase in seven years. This is outstanding news for seniors who count on these retirement benefits. Over 60 million Americans receive Social Security, and this adjustment will help many of them cover their expenses in the coming year.
￼
Tracking a Productive 115th Congress
￼
I'm proud to be working hard to make the House productive for the people it represents. We've had a busy 115th Congress, passing over 1,000 bills through the House. This is almost 40% more productive than past Congresses, and it's part of our commitment to making the government work hard for the people of America. These bills have included landmark opioid legislation, major improvements at the VA, and historic increases in funding for medical research at NIH. You can visit better.gop to learn more about the many accomplishments of the 115th Congress.
￼
Around the District
Military and Veterans Advisory Committee
￼ Kevin with the Veterans Advisory Committee members
On Thursday, I was honored to sit down with my Military and Veterans Affairs Advisory Committee to discuss the opioid crisis and treatment among vets, improvements to the VA Choice program, Tricare benefits, and suicide prevention measures for veterans. Congress recently passed the largest Veterans Affairs funding bill in our nation’s history, which will help keep vital programs available to those who put their lives on the lines for all of us. I was also proud to report that Congress passed the VA MISSION Act, which will expand the VA Caregiver Program to veterans from all eras to support veterans battling disabilities and ailments from their service who rely on family members as in-home caregivers. Thank you to Mike Cooper, Commander of American Legion Post #153 in Olathe for hosting the meeting. I’m so thankful for the service and sacrifice of our nation’s veterans, and I greatly appreciate their insight and advice about issues facing our military and veterans today.
￼
Shawnee Mission Education Foundation Breakfast
￼ Kevin with SMSD Superintendent Dr. Michael Fulton
I’ve enjoyed attending the Shawnee Mission Education Foundation (SMEF) breakfast for several years, and last week's breakfast was exceptionally inspirational. Students and teachers shared their success stories in the fields of medicine, robotics, energy/sustainability, welding, firefighting, and theater/fine arts. These students are being prepared for their futures here at Shawnee Mission School District as they work to ensure that every student impacts our world for good while in school and upon graduation. Thank you to Kim Hinkle, Executive Director of the SMEF for your leadership, and thank you to Dr. Michael Fulton, SMSD superintendent. Welcome to the SMSD team.
￼
Travanse Senior Living in Olathe
￼ Kevin with Mike Fraser and Tom Inderhees
Thank you to Mike Fraser for the invitation and tour of Travanse Senior Living in Olathe last week. I appreciated visiting with residents, seeing the veterans service wall, and learning about your care of the 55 residents, including home health and hospice. I'm working hard in Congress to keep prescription drug prices low for seniors, and recently we passed and the president signed the Know the Lowest Price Act. This important legislation eliminates “gag clauses” that prevent pharmacists from being able to tell Medicare consumers if there’s a cheaper way to pay for a prescription medicine at the drugstore, such as when the cash price is cheaper than an insurance co-pay. 90% of seniors take prescription drugs, and I am proud to be working to make those prescriptions more affordable.
￼
Heart to Heart International
￼ Kevin touring the new Heart to Heart warehouse
I’m proud of Heart to Heart International (HHI), headquartered here in Lenexa, and their work on the frontlines to provide disaster relief for victims of floods, tornadoes, and hurricanes here in the United States and all over the world. Last week, I toured the new warehouse and office space in Lenexa to see their operations and to hear about their partnership with FEMA and the CDC to provide medical teams, medical supplies, equipment, and hygiene health products during humanitarian crises. I was inspired by the work HHI accomplished after Hurricane Maria, visiting the hardest-hit and remote areas of Puerto Rico bringing medical relief to people cut-off from the outside world. They are still working in Puerto Rico to build solar powered water systems and rebuild homes. Thank you to Jim Mitchum and Kim Carroll for the great tour of the new facility, and especially your leadership of this amazing work.
￼
Kansas City Kansas Community College
￼ Kevin with new KCKCC President Dr. Greg Mosier
I had an awesome visit to the KCKCC campus last week, meeting the official Blue Devil mascot, touring the new Veterans Center and visiting with veteran students, observing a nursing simulation class, and talking with students and exhibitors at the transfer fair. I was most proud to learn from new President Dr. Greg Mosier that due to the work that I supported in the House to expand Pell Grants to year-round, 160 students were able to attend KCKCC this summer. If not for our work to make Pell Grants available in summer too, these students would not have been able to take classes and move closer to graduation and entering the workforce. Thanks Dr. Mosier and your energetic team!
￼
St. Joseph Catholic Church 150th Anniversary
￼ Kevin with Father Scott Wallisch, Mary Raymond, and students from St. Joseph
This year marks the 150th anniversary of the founding of St. Joseph Catholic Church in Shawnee, Kansas. The small frontier town of Shawnee was founded in 1857, and one year later St. Joseph’s Catholic Church opened its doors to minister to the growing and diverse community. Today, 150 years later, St. Joseph’s continues to play an important role in the health and spiritual lives of people in Johnson County. This is a parish dedicated to the education of our youth and the well-being of our community, and I can only imagine the accomplishments the church will amass in the next 150 years. I was honored to present a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol to Father Scott, Mary Raymond, students and families in recognition of its anniversary, and tour the new renovations of the church.
￼
American Israel Public Affairs Committee
￼ Kevin speaking at AIPAC in Overland Park
On Monday, I spoke to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) in Overland Park about our strong and critical relationship with Israel. Over the past few years I have supported our ongoing military cooperation with Israel, and I have been a witness to the resilience, ingenuity and steadfastness of the Israeli people in the face of constant threats and intimidation from their neighbors in the region. I believe that it is incumbent upon the U.S. government to continue our support for the only democracy, and one of the last vestiges of stability and freedom, in the Middle East. I look forward to continuing to lead the charge on this important work in Congress and appreciate AIPAC’s ongoing support of the unique bond between our two great countries.
￼
Sarah Cannon Cancer Network
￼ Kevin with Matt Sogard, Yvonne Ward, Dr. Anne Kobbermann, and Ryan Hallenbeck
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and last Thursday I toured the Sarah Cannon Cancer Network in Overland Park to see firsthand the amazing advancements in breast cancer prevention and treatments. It was great to visit with patients and health care providers about their care here including the importance of clinical trials. We also discussed the Oral Drug Parity Act, of which I am a proud cosponsor, that would allow for equal treatment of oral and infusible cancer therapies. As treatments become more advanced, many cancer drugs can be administered by mouth, like normal medication. Thank you to Yvonne Ward, RN, MSN, OCN, CBCN, ONN-CG, for the invitation, and Matt Sogard and his team from Overland Park Regional Medical Center for the tour.
￼
Claridge Court in Prairie Village
￼ Kevin speaking at the Claridge Court breakfast group
It was a pleasure visiting with the breakfast group at Claridge Court in Prairie Village about the economy and senior issues before Congress. I'm working in Congress to strengthen important senior programs like Medicare. I support the closure of the Medicare Part D donut hole, which is a gap in coverage for seniors with high prescription costs that ends up costing large amounts of out-of-pocket payments. Earlier this year, Congress moved to close the donut hole and lift this burden from seniors. Thanks to Richard for the invitation to stop by and speak with the group.
￼
National Desert Storm and Desert Shield Memorial Fundraiser
￼ Kevin with Sonia Tolbert, Scott Nusz, John Lawrence, and Vesna Lawrence
It was an honor to stop by the VFW Post #846 in Overland Park to support their National Desert Storm and Desert Shield Memorial fundraiser event. I had a great time visiting with many veterans, patriots, and their families. The proceeds from this fundraiser will go toward the new memorial that will be built on the National Mall in Washington, DC in 2021. I was proud to support the legislation that Congress passed to authorize the new memorial in 2017. Click here to learn more about the memorial and view designs for the final site.
￼
Reminder: Medicare Open Enrollment Assistance Events Coming Up
￼ Kevin with seniors at a previous Medicare enrollment event
Attention seniors and caregivers of seniors: Medicare Open Enrollment Period begins next week October 15 and extends through December 7. I will be hosting two Medicare Open Enrollment Assistance Events to provide help to seniors during this time. These events will be held Wednesday, October 17 from 9:00 AM to 12:30 PM at Johnson County Central Resource Library and Tuesday, October 23 from 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM at Kansas City, KS West Wyandotte Library. For more information, click here or call my office at (913) 621-0832.
￼

Fact of the Week
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Thanks to improvements in awareness and early detection, the breast cancer fatality rate declined by 39% from 1989 to 2015.
Third District Trivia 
Friday was National Farmer's Day. How many people does the average U.S. farm feed each year?
Send your answers to haley.brady@mail.house.gov and the first correct response will receive a shout out in next week's newsletter.
Congratulations to last week's winner Jerry Shapiro!
Last week's answer:  Larry Winn was the U.S. Representative for the Third District in 1969. 
National Farmer's Day
￼
Happy National Farmers Day to the 3.2 million men and women in Kansas and across the country who work tirelessly to provide the world with food, fiber, and fuel. Growing up on a farm, I saw firsthand the early mornings, long nights, and uncertain times folks like my dad worked through to put food on the table for our family and so many others. Don't forget to Thank A Farmer!
Gerry and Jerry Ray
￼
Two of my mentors and the reason I first ran for the Kansas Statehouse are Gerry and Jerry Ray. Gerry was my predecessor in the Kansas House, and Brooke and I value the Rays' friendship greatly.
Aunt Jean's in Shawnee
￼
While in Downtown Shawnee, I stopped in local small business: Aunt Jean’s gelato and coffee shop. I tried a favorite, the Nehi Peach soda.
VFW Steak Night
￼
Last weekend I stopped by VFW Veterans of Foreign Wars of Lenexa, Post #7397 for their monthly steak night. It was great to see Jerry Ingram, a Marine Corps veteran who fought at Iwo Jima in WWII.
Legislative Look Ahead
Members of the House of Representatives will work from their respective home districts this week.
Legislative Wrap Up
Members of the House of Representatives worked from their respective home districts last week.

Subject: Rebuilding Together After Hurricane Michael
Message:
News from Martha Roby
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
Friends, 
As you well know, Hurricane Michael, the third most powerful hurricane to ever make landfall on the United States mainland, ravaged areas of Alabama, Florida, and Georgia last week. While only early estimates are available at this point in time, it has been reported that more than 650,000 homes and businesses across the Southeast lost power, and 60,000 of those are in Alabama. Hundreds of families lost everything, and it has been confirmed that at least 18 people were killed. 
￼  
While Hurricane Michael appears to have done its worst in Panama City, Florida, and the nearby areas, Barbour, Dale, Henry, Geneva and Houston Counties in our district were also impacted. It could potentially take days, or even weeks, before we know the full scale of the damage, but we do know that Hurricane Michael is the most powerful storm to ever hit Houston County according to recorded history.   
I encourage everyone to help out with relief efforts in whatever way you can. We should all be deeply thankful for the first responders and all those working to repair the damage. This is a very, very trying and difficult time for so many people across the Southeast, and we will get through it together. 
ASSESING DAMAGE IN THE WIREGRASS 
￼ 
I was on the ground in the Wiregrass last week assessing the Hurricane Michael damage to local agriculture with some of our farmers. I was able to see firsthand the devastation this storm brought to several farms both in Henry and Houston Counties.   While we don’t yet know the full scale of the damages, it’s safe to say our cotton farmers face significant economic setback. My office stands ready to assist in whatever ways we can. The AL-02 economy depends on our farmers and their important work. 
USDA DISASTER ASSITANCE TOOL 
As we begin our Hurricane Michael recovery efforts, many farmers and producers in AL-02 may be in need of disaster assistance. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has a great tool to help you identify which disaster programs meet your needs. I encourage you to share this information with anyone you know who might need it.  TATE'S SUPERMARKET FEEDS THE COMMUNITY 
￼   It has been encouraging to see neighbors are helping neighbors during this tough time. Last week, Tate's Supermarket in Hartford emptied its freezers, cooked all the food, and gave it away to those in need. There are great people in this world.   During what is a very, very difficult time for so many, I encourage everyone to share examples of people helping other people. We will get through this together.   You can stay up to date on recovery efforts and my work in Congress via Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.         
It is an honor to serve you in Congress. Please never hesitate to let me know if there is a way my office can be of assistance.   Sincerely,  
￼  Martha Roby 
Member of Congress

Subject: This Week In Washington
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Bad Deal for Pennsylvania's Refineries
The Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) is a federal program mandating oil refiners to blend a certain amount of renewable fuels, such as corn ethanol, into the nation's fuel supply every year.
This is one of the most egregious examples of the government picking winners and losers. Washington has deemed the workers at Pennsylvania's oil refineries the losers.
While sales of gasoline with up to 10% ethanol (E10) are available year-round, there is a ban on sales of fuel with 15% ethanol (E15) in the summer months, due to the smog it produces. Recently, the Trump administration directed the Environmental Protection Agency to craft a rule allowing for the year-round sale of E15 gasoline.
Authorizing the expanded sale of E15 gasoline without meaningful reforms for the U.S. refining sector is a missed opportunity that only benefits ethanol producers and their allies. This legally-dubious proposal does not address the high compliance costs associated with the government's Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS), which threatens thousands of jobs at Philadelphia Energy Solutions and Monroe Energy.
I continue to believe that changes to the RFS should improve conditions for both agriculture and the refining industry. This week's action is not only imbalanced, it risks worsening air quality and hurting consumers.
￼
￼
Promoting Civic Engagement
Promoting opportunities for youth civic engagement paves the way for students to become active participants in our republic.
In an effort to help high school students understand the roles of the legislative, executive, and judicial branches of the government, staff in my Allentown office, in conjunction with Lebanon Valley College, hosted the Youth Civic Engagement Symposium.
More than 100 Lebanon County students from six schools heard from speakers from all levels of government, including former Pennsylvania Governor, Tom Corbett.
I have no doubt that this year's Youth Civic Engagement Symposium provided students with an appreciation of our civic institutions. I thank all those who helped organize the event.
Read more about this terrific event in the Lebanon Daily News.
￼
￼
Tariffs Hurt Pennsylvania's Employers
On July 6, the administration began imposing a 25 percent tariff on $50 billion worth of goods from China. As a result, Pennsylvania manufacturers are shouldering a new 25 percent tax burden on certain component parts.
Companies may seek an exclusion from these taxes if demand for a necessary item cannot be met by a domestic firm.
In an effort to assist Pennsylvania businesses affected by these tariffs, I sent a series of letters to U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) Robert Lighthizer urging a full and fair review of all exclusion petitions by Pennsylvania companies.
Section 301 tariffs are direct taxes on American consumers and producers. They reduce American purchasing power, curtail freedom, impede job creation, and limit production. Approving these exemptions will help Pennsylvania employers remain competitive globally.
I hope these exclusion petitions are expeditiously reviewed.
￼
￼
Statement on U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley's Resignation
Ambassador Nikki Haley has done an exemplary job serving our country at the United Nations. She demonstrated strong American leadership on the global stage and reaffirmed our commitment to our top allies like Israel. Ambassador Haley also diligently worked to hold belligerent nations like Syria, Iran, Russia, and North Korea accountable for violating U.N. rules, human rights, and international norms. I am grateful for Ambassador Haley's service and look forward to President Trump nominating someone who shares her approach to representing American interests at the U.N.

Subject: proud to be ranked #15 in bipartisanship
Message:
District Update | October 15, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Celebrating Vancouver's Waterfront Park, and new jobs
￼
It was exciting to be a part of Vancouver Waterfront Park's celebration on September 29 along with thousands of others. My hat is off to the City of Vancouver, the developers, builders, and investors who had the vision for highlighting the Columbia River with this incredible design.
￼
The new waterfront park will be a huge economic expansion in an area that has been through some highs and lows – this development will help even more families thrive in Southwest Washington. I was pleased to support federal grant funding that helped make this dream a reality.
 
Improving lives for recovering moms and their children
￼
Lifeline Connections’ new facility in Vancouver for pregnant and parenting women in substance use recovery will be life-changing for those families. 
￼
It was great to tour the gorgeous facility several weeks ago and see how the federal funding we helped secure for this program will improve lives for moms and children.
 
 

TOP NEWS
COLUMBIAN: Waterways association names Herrera Beutler Legislator of the Year
READ MORE HERE

CLARK COUNTY TODAY: Vancouver Waterfront Park grand opening a smashing success

BIPARTISAN WORK: Ranked #15 out of 438 in working on bipartisan solutions
The Lugar Center and Georgetown University McCourt School of Public Policy released its Bipartisan Index. Out of 438 U.S. House members it scored, I was honored to be ranked as the 15th most bipartisan.

I’ve been laser-focused on creating better economic opportunities and solving problems for folks from Vancouver to Chehalis to Goldendale to Seaview, and whether that’s standing up for real health care solutions, protecting our native salmon runs, increasing survival rates for expectant moms or preserving manufacturing jobs, I’m proud to work with both parties on solutions.

You can read more about the ranking here.

ASSISTING SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON RESIDENTS
HELPING ARMY VETERAN WITH MEDICAL BILLS

Mr. Josh Bradley of Toledo, a veteran of the U.S. Army, contacted our office because he was involved in a vehicular accident for which he was not at fault. He was faced with massive medical expenses, and because the responsible party had limited insurance coverage, the VA was supposed to step in and pay the medical bills. 

However, Mr. Bradley was unable to get the VA to pay the medical expenses, even after hiring a lawyer. Our office reached out to the VA on September 4, and by September 7, the decision was made to cover his medical bills, amounting to $59,580.33.

Are you having trouble with a federal agency?
 
If you or someone you know needs assistance with a federal agency, please contact my Vancouver office at 360-695-6292, or through my website jhb.house.gov. While we can't guarantee an outcome, we will try our best to assist in any way we can.


HONORED TO BE A FRIEND OF FARMERS

I'm proud to receive the "Friend of Farm Bureau" award for my support of policy issues affecting Southwest Washington's farmers and ranchers.

I’ve worked to ensure that pest and disease research programs are available for cranberry farmers in Pacific County, fought to help berry and tree fruit farmers market and protect their crops, and pushed to repeal the ’Waters of the U.S.’ rule that would give the federal government control over ditches and puddles on private property. 

It’s an honor to have this work recognized, and I’ll always be a friend of farmers as long as I’m representing them in Congress.

News from Congressman Arrington

￼

￼
￼
NEWS FROM WASHINGTON AND ACROSS WEST TEXAS
Dear Friend,  
As the Autumn weather starts to fill the air and harvest is on the horizon, our priority remains building on pro-growth policies that expand our economy, creating a freer, safer, and prouder nation.  
Our Farmers 
Last week, we celebrated National Farmers Day, and I thought about the hardworking farmers and ranchers throughout District 19. A farming culture is ingrained in our region’s heritage, and we wouldn’t be the country we are today if it weren’t for our producers that have worked the fields throughout the years. From the sweat of their brow, they work day in and day out to produce our food, allowing our nation to remain independent and secure. 
￼ 
Did you know that one U.S. farm feeds 165 people annually in the U.S. and abroad? It is expected that by 2050, our global population will top 9.7 billion – farmers and rancher will have to grow 70% more food than what is now produced to keep up with the growth. That is why it is essential we pass a Farm Bill that gives our farmers and ranchers the certainty and stability they deserve as they enter into the harvest season. Even more so for our state, because ag is our #1 industry. In 2014, the industry contributed to 8.5 percent, or $135.5 billion, of Texas’ GPD. It keeps our people fed and clothed and keeps our economy thriving. 
￼ 
Farm Bill Status 
House and Senate Republicans on the Farm Bill conference committee have been faced with resistance and obstruction from our Democrat counterparts. It is unacceptable that at a time when our farmers and ranchers are already hurting due to low commodity prices and unfair foreign trade practices that we in Congress not provide them with the critical certainty and security they need. Unfortunately, the Farm Bill’s progress is being held up by Democrats on most of the titles of the Farm Bill, including common-sense, dignity-restoring work requirements for able-bodied adults – they are simply obstructing in hopes of winning the midterms in November. 
While I had hoped we could have delivered a Farm Bill to the President’s desk by the September 30th deadline, my colleagues and I on the Farm Bill Conference Committee will continue to work to pass a Farm Bill that gives our ag producers the long-term certainty they need and deserve before crucial safety net programs expire in December.
￼ 
Steaming Economy 
Our economy continues to steam ahead. With another positive, historic jobs report, consumer and business optimism is getting higher and higher. Unemployment continued to drop in the month of September – now at a 50-year low. Over the past few months we’ve seen a steady drop in unemployment: June – 4.0%, July – 3.9%, September – 3.7%. Businesses are expanding, and more people are contributing in the workforce. Pro-growth policies are boosting our economy, ensuring West Texans and ALL Americans are better off now. Read here for an article on the September jobs report.  
October marks Manufacturing Month, and this year our manufacturers have much to celebrate. Buoyed by tax reform and regulatory relief, 77% of manufacturers say they plan to increase hiring, 72% plan to increase wages or benefits, and 86% plan to increase company investments. That translates into a better quality of life and more jobs – in fact, 160,000 more manufacturing jobs since tax reform was put into effect. I send a special thank you to all our manufacturers in West Texas – your hard work plays a vital role in building a better country for our children and grandchildren.  
￼
Please know, it is an honor to be your representative. Feel free to reach out to my office and let me know how I can best serve you.  
Your friend and fellow West Texan, ￼  Jodey C. Arrington Member of Congress

Kansas Common Sense  October 15, 2018
Hello,
 
Welcome to “Kansas Common Sense.” Thanks for your continued interest in receiving my weekly newsletter. Please feel free to forward it on to your family and friends if it would interest them.
 
Reforming and Modernizing our Nation’s Water Infrastructure
On Wednesday, the Senate voted 99-1 to reform and modernize our nation’s water infrastructure with passage of the America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018. From flood protection to modernizing our drinking water systems, this legislation will address critical components of Kansas’ infrastructure that are far too often taken for granted. Our farmers, ranchers and manufacturers rely on our ports and waterways for access to markets around the world.
 
With more than 60 percent of our grain exports moving through America’s inland waterways, along with a multitude of other commodities and products, this legislation will benefit Kansas agriculture and stakeholders across a number of industries. In addition, by increasing local involvement and providing more feasible cost-sharing arrangements with Kansans, this legislation delivers much needed progress for more efficient and innovative solutions to address our infrastructure needs. To read more on this important legislation, click here.
 
Meeting with AUSA Officials Representing Fort Riley
On Tuesday, I welcomed Chief of Staff of the Army General Mark Milley and Undersecretary of the Army Ryan McCarthy to the Association of the United States Army (AUSA) Fort Riley-Central Kansas Chapter event during the AUSA’s annual meetings in Washington, D.C. I was pleased to spend an evening alongside Kansans representing our Army communities and the Army’s most senior leaders who have an appreciation for the tremendous support our state provides soldiers and their families. I’m thankful General Milley and Undersecretary McCarthy shared how invaluable Fort Leavenworth and Fort Riley are to the future of the Army, and General Milley noted that Fort Riley will experience an increase in soldiers over the next few years as the Army continues to grow in end-strength. A strong national defense requires a ready and robust Army and I will continue to work to make certain the Army is fully funded, equipped and ready to protect our country.
￼ 
Questioning Witnesses on Data Privacy Regulations On Wednesday, I participated in a Senate Commerce Committee hearing to discuss how new data privacy rules like the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation and the recently adopted California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018 have impacted consumers and what they believe is needed in order to have effective data privacy standards. There are many opinions on how these standards ought to look, which is why I have been working with my colleagues to collect the thoughts of all interested parties, including consumer advocates, industry representatives and academics to identify responsible federal privacy standards.  
As chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection, Product Safety, Insurance, and Data Security, I am committed to ensuring that consumers’ personal data is protected from data misuse, while also establishing certainty for businesses to create jobs, innovate and compete domestically and internationally. To view my questioning, click here. 
￼ 
Requesting Information from Google on Data Vulnerability On Thursday, I joined other Senate Commerce Committee leaders in requesting a copy of an internal memo and answers about a security vulnerability from Google CEO Sundar Pichai, which placed private user information at risk. The memo, according to press reports, advocated against public disclosure of the vulnerability on grounds that it would attract the potential attention of regulators and Congress. As chairman of the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection, Product Safety, Insurance, and Data Security, I will remain vigilant in identifying data practices that harm consumers, while aiming to provide long-term regulatory solutions that bolster consumer protections without unduly harming innovation in the internet ecosystem. To read the letter, click here.   
Participating in KSU Office Park Ribbon Cutting Ceremony  Friday evening, I joined the KSU Foundation to cut a ribbon for the new building, Phase II, of the K-State Office Park. Phase II is the second of four buildings planned for the K-State Office Park, and the multi-phase office park project enables the KSU Foundation to lease space to industry partners and leaders while creating a pipeline for student talent. Upon completion of the fourth phase, the office park will total 240,000 square feet and 1,000 new jobs as part of the combined 56-acre world-class ecosystem of innovative research and academic growth adjacent to the university in the office and research parks. During my remarks at the event, I discussed the importance of the relationship between private industry and our unviersities, and how we can all work together to create an innovative and educated workforce that meets the demands of our state’s ever-changing economy. A special thanks to Greg Lohrentz and Kate Ryan for inviting me to join this special occasion.
 ￼ 
Touring Rooks County Health Center  On Friday, I was in my hometown of Plainville to tour the Rooks County Health Center. During our tour, I was able to learn more about the facility’s new MRI suite. Having an in-house MRI suite is rare among critical access hospitals like Rooks County Health Center, and folks were eager to share the positive impact of the new equipment. Additionally, we saw and discussed the hospital’s swing bed program and the physical, occupational, speech and respiratory therapy programs. I was happy to visit with a number of employees who were interested in hearing more about veterans’ healthcare, the ability to streamline services, reimbursement and patient satisfaction. Thank you to Rooks County CEO AJ Thomas for arranging my visit and to MRI Technologist Randy Richmeier for leading our tour. Thanks also to Michele Hinger, Justin Thummel and Dr. Daniel Sanchez for joining our tour and discussion.
￼ 
Highlighting the FAA Reauthorization and Visiting with Kansas City FAA Officials  On Thursday, I spoke on the Senate floor to highlight the recently-passed FAA reauthorization. This five-year, bipartisan landmark legislation will enhance air travel for many Americans and provide stability for all those working in the aviation sector. During this speech, I highlighted my work and significant provisions for Kansas that were included in the legislation. To view more on these provisions, click here. To watch my floor speech, click here. 
￼ 
On Monday, I was in Kansas City where I joined FAA officials during their executive meeting. During the meeting, we discussed a number of topics including the FAA reauthorization bill and the significant impact it will have on the FAA’s responsibilities, our success in the fight against air traffic control privatization, protecting general aviation and supporting small and rural airports. Thank you to FAA Regional Administrator Joe Miniace and Deputy Regional Administrator John Speckin for arranging my visit and for the productive conversation. 

￼
Touring the University of Kansas Health Systems Emergency Department
Following my meeting with FAA officials on Monday, I was at the University of Kansas Health System Kansas City campus to tour their emergency department and meet with transplantation officials. I was pleased to hear from many hospital employees on things being done in the emergency department to protect vulnerable populations and improve outcomes for the many Kansans who utilize this world-class facility. During my tour of the emergency department, I heard many concerns about the growing impact of the opioid epidemic on the hospital, as well as the constant need for quality mental health services. Additionally, I met with transplantation officials to hear an update on the system’s diverse transplant program and current challenges they are facing, and we also discussed ways that we can work together to increase organ donations across the state and country. Kansas City and the whole state are grateful for the talented individuals who work at the University of Kansas Health System and their dedicated work to care for Kansans. Thank you to Health System Kansas City Division COO Chris Ruder for leading my tour and to Vice President of Operative Services Dr. Sean Kumer for discussing the transplantation program. 
Now Accepting Spring Internship Applications My own interest in public service was sparked by an internship for Kansas First District Congressman Keith Sebelius in 1974. As an intern, I had the chance to learn firsthand how a Congressional office operates and how the legislative process works. I am proud to be able to offer this same opportunity in my Senate office today, where I have interns year-round working closely with my staff on behalf of Kansans.  Applications for internships in my Washington, D.C. and Kansas offices for Spring 2018 are due October 27. Congressional internships are open to qualified undergraduate and graduate students who have an interest in public service and have achieved academic excellence. Click here for more information. 
Honored to Serve You in Washington
It is an honor to serve you in Washington, D.C. Thank you to the many Kansans who have been calling and writing in to share their thoughts and opinions on the issues our state and country face. I appreciate the words of Kansans, whether in the form of a form of letter, a Facebook comment or a phone call, who wish to make their voice heard. 
Please let me know how I can be of assistance. You can contact me by email by clicking here. You can also click here to contact me through one of my Kansas offices or my Washington, D.C., office.
Very truly yours, Jerry

The Webster Wire
Listening to Floridians
Dear Friends: 
Hurricane Michael was a devastating storm, one of the most powerful hurricanes in decades. Recovery and rebuilding operations have commenced in the aftermath of this storm and I am confident in the resilience of Floridians.  As you work to clean up your homes and property, please be careful to avoid scammers. Do not accept restoration or tree trimming assistance from someone who is asking for payment on the spot and is not a utility employee or contractor.
If you sustained damage and need assistance, please call my office at 352-241-9220. 
_______________ 
I was honored to visit The Villages Honor Flight Monthly meeting where we celebrated the 100th Birthday of one of their members. During the meeting, I presented them a check displaying the $4.5 million dollars that my office has assisted constituent veterans in receiving in various retro checks from the VA since January 2017. 
￼ 
_______________ 
On National Mental Health Day, I visited Vincent Academy Adventure Coast, a program that serves those with mental illness in Hernando and the surrounding counties by promoting recovery from mental illness through work training. 
￼ 
_______________ 
I was honored to speak at Lake Technical College’s grand opening and ribbon cutting for the Center for Advanced Manufacturing. 
￼ 
￼  
_______________ 
It was great to speak to the Mid-Florida Community Services, Inc. (MFCS) board members and staff at their monthly board meeting. MFCS serves the majority of my district, including Hernando, Citrus, Lake, and Sumter Counties. MFCS is a great community action partnership that meets the many needs of individuals throughout our communities, including senior services, Head Start programs, community assistance, and transportation services. 
_______________ 
While in Inverness, I visited the new Veterans Memorial and 9/11 Memorial with Mayor Bob Plaisted. I also stopped by the Valerie Theater and learned about its history and current influence on the City of Inverness. 
￼  ￼ 
_______________ 
I visited the Citrus County Education Foundation’s new store, Supplies 4 Success. They are ready to help Citrus County teachers this school year with school supplies. 
￼ 
_______________ 
Withlacoochee Technical College is celebrating 50 years. I stopped by to tour the school and learn more about the programs they offer. 
￼ 
 _______________ 
The Mission in Citrus is dedicated to helping veterans, men, women, and children get off the streets. It was great to stop by their homeless shelter and meet with some of the veterans who live there. 
Your servant, 
￼ 
￼  Daniel Webster Member of Congress 
 

Constituent Corner
A constituent from Brooksville contacted my office because his tax return was being audited without any update from the IRS.  My office submitted an inquiry and learned that his return was pulled for final review before approval. The constituent later emailed my office and said “I wanted to update you and thank you for all of your assistance with our IRS tax return audit. We have received our return.”
Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you. 
Legislative Update 
Last week, I published an op-ed in the Citrus Chronicle about a commonsense healthcare solution bill I recently sponsored. Most of our nation’s healthcare spending is spent on a small percentage of very sick people. These individuals account for a large portion of insurance companies’ expenses. In response, insurance companies recoup those costs by raising premiums, copays and deductibles for the rest of their customers - those who do not need much healthcare. 
The ACA exacerbated this problem by imposing an onerous list of mandated health benefits and unprecedented price controls on insurance companies in typical Washington top-down mandate. This toxic brew resulted in skyrocketing premiums on the young and healthy, with insurance companies still losing money because these individuals couldn’t afford to buy insurance.
Click here to read about the bill I’ve introduced to address this issue.  
District Update
My Community Relations Representative, Pam, attended the 6th Annual Breast Cancer Awareness Luncheon with Ladies in Philanthropy (LIP) in partnership with Leesburg Regional Medical Center. 
￼   ￼ 
My Community Relations Representative, Cindy, attended the Sumter County Chamber Fall Festival. 
￼

Subject: Finally signed into law
Message:
News from Congressman
￼ 

Home
About
About District
Conact
Media 


Saracini Aviation Safety Act Signed into Law
 ￼ 
Last week, the President signed a bipartisan FAA reauthorization measure that protects passengers, pilots, and flight attendants by mandating the installation of secondary barriers on all new commercial aircraft. Due to the tireless work of Ellen Saracini, Congressman Josh Gottheimer, and Senator Pat Toomey, The Saracini Safety Aviation Act is finally law. 
This critical measure seeks to prevent our aircraft from being hijacked again. I am deeply appreciative of the dedication of Ellen, Josh, and my bipartisan colleagues who worked fervently to enact this measure. American citizens are undoubtedly safer.  We will continue to fight until all current passenger aircraft contain secondary barriers. 
Learn more HERE. 
Social Security Announces 2.8 Percent Increase
 ￼ 
I’m pleased to announce that 2019 Cost of Living Adjustment for Social Security will be 2.8%. The COLA is one of social security’s most important protections, which ensures benefits keep up with inflation. While the announcement of a 2.8% COLA is good news, we can and must do better for our seniors. Social Security is a promise and earned benefit that Americans have paid into throughout their entire lives. Whether it is ensuring seniors get the benefits they worked for or expanding access to Medicare for those in need, I am committed to standing up for Bucks and Montgomery county residents. 
  
Bensalem Business Visit
￼ 
As part of my small business tour, I visited the Jean Madeline Aveda Institute in Bensalem. The institution trains and educates beauty industry professionals in our community. Effective workforce development programs are key to preparing students for careers and furthering the education of professionals to remain competitive in the modern workplace. 
  
Oldest VFW in Bucks County
￼  
I was proud to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the Joseph A. Schumacher VFW Post 1597 in Croydon. This post along with their Auxilary is the oldest Veterans of Foreign Wars Post in Bucks County. Thank you for your dedication to our veterans, their families and our community.

￼
Home       About Mark       Our District       How Can Mark Help You?       Legislation       Newsroom       Contact Mark        
Dear Lindsey:
I hope you will consider joining us for our upcoming town hall in Richmond. During the town hall I will provide an update on what is happening in Washington, DC, answer your questions, and share information on the services my office can provide. Details for the town hall are below.
Richmond Town Hall Tuesday, October 23, 2018 6:30 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. Lovonya DeJean Middle School Multipurpose Room 3400 Macdonald Avenue Richmond, CA 94805 Doors Open at 6:00 p.m.
Please RSVP by visiting https://desaulnier.house.gov/town-hall-rsvp, or contact my offices in Walnut Creek or Richmond for more information about the event.

MARK IN THE NEWS
ABC7 News: Could air traffic controller shortage have impact on safety?
We cannot wait for a tragedy to prompt us to take action to address gaps in aviation safety and ensure that staffing shortages are addressed. Mark spoke with ABC7 News about the shortage of air traffic controllers in the Bay Area and around the country.
￼


MARK'S LEGISLATIVE ACCOMPLISHMENTS
Bringing Innovative Solutions to Housing Crisis America is on the verge of a major housing crisis, especially in high-cost regions like the Bay Area. Working families in communities across the country have few affordable housing options within a reasonable distance to their workplace. The tradeoff becomes traveling great lengths to their jobs and spending hours stuck in traffic rather than with their families. This week I introduced a bill that will help incentivize innovative solutions to America's housing crisis. While there is no one-size-fits-all solution to these challenges, our bill will help communities explore much-needed innovative housing solutions like expanding common amenities for a younger workforce, building accessory dwelling units—like basement apartments or converting garages into housing—and adapting one or several buildings into multiple housing units. To learn more about our bill, click here.   Fighting for Women and Working Families I am proud to annouce that I received a 100% from the American Association of University Women (AAUW) Action Fund for the 115th Congress for our work fighting for women's economic security, equal access to education, and civil rights. I look forward to building on these efforts and working to make America more just, fair, and equal. Learn more about the organization here.  

MARK AROUND TOWN
Providing a Congressional Update to Pleasant Hill Rotary Club
Mark joined the Pleasant Hill Rotary Club for their weekly meeting to provide an update on the work he is doing in Congress to make our aviation system safer, bring innovative new housing to regions like the Bay Area, fight the rollback of environmental protections, and much more.
￼
Honoring Disability Employment Awareness Month
During National Disability Employment Awareness Month, Mark toured the Military Ocean Terminal Concord site with North Bay Industries to discuss how the site is helping empower people with disabilities through employment opportunities.
￼

OPINIONS FROM THE DISTRICT  
Hearing directly from you not only informs my work in Congress, but also is my favorite part of being your Representative. To share your opinions with me you can either email me or take our survey.
Below are some of the top issues you shared with me over the last week:
	•	160 constituents wrote in opposing the Advancing the Quality and Understanding of American Aquaculture (AQUAA) Act (S. 3138), which would allow for permits to be issued for marine finfish aquaculture activities and cause harm to fish.  
	•	36 constituents wrote in to oppose offshore drilling along the coast of California, which could cause serious damage to wildlife migration routes and habitats along the coastline.  
	•	24 constituents continued to express opposition to the House version of the Farm Bill reauthorization, which would cut essential programs like SNAP and agricultural subsidies.

LETTERS MARK RECENTLY SENT
Letter to the Acting Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency opposing the use of WIFIA loan funds to finance the WaterFix/twin tunnels project in California.
Letter to Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue to oppose the Administration's moves to roll back rules that protect conservation areas from environmentally harmful roads and logging infrastructure
Letter to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services urging them to rethink changes to the outpatient service payment rates that may reduce the ability of hospitals to deliver care to vulnerable patient

Sincerely, ￼  Mark DeSaulnier Member of Congress
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

Subject: Knight Vision: October 15, 2018
Message:
￼ 
  

Around the District
Gathering of Eagles Dinner
Saturday night Lily and I joined The Flight Test Historical Foundation at their annual Gathering of Eagles Dinner. This year the Foundation honored six women who dared to dream and made that dream come true. Congratulations to Cynthia "CJ" Bixby, Eleen A. Bjorkman, Laurie Grindle, Kelly J. Latimer, and Sandra Miarecki, Ph.D. I'd also like to congratulate Britney Jaworski for receiving the 2018 William J. "Pete" Knight Memorial Scholarship.
￼

Kaleidoscope Festival
It was great seeing so many people at the Palmdale Amphitheater for the Kaleidoscope music and art festival. The afternoon was filled with dancing, music, and fun for the whole family.
￼

Learning about government
Local Scouts gathered at Saint Rose of Lima Catholic Church in Simi Valley to learn about the role of government in our society. My staff had a great time meeting the Scouts and answering their questions about how Congress operates.
￼

Community Health and Fitness Expo
The Simi Valley Free Clinic hosted The Community Health & Fitness Expo at The Town Center Mall. The Expo included a number of health related booths and 5k and 10k runs dedicated to The Frederick Michael Gibson Run for Depression Awareness.
￼

Five Below Grand Opening
Congratulations to Five Below for your grand opening! Welcome to Simi Valley!
￼

Studios at Bella West Grand Opening
Congratulations to Valerie Orcutt on the Grand Opening Celebration of her new Studios at Bella West. For 15 years Bella West, and now the Studios at Bella West, will continue to be an oasis of warmth and style for women and men in the Antelope Valley.
￼

Simi Valley Networking Breakfast
I visited the Simi Valley Chamber of Commerce Networking Breakfast to provide an update on what's happening in Washington and the many services our offices are able to provide constituents and businesses.
￼

Hart High School Grad inspires the nation
This story is truly inspirational. Congratulations to William S. Hart High School graduate Justin Gallegos on being the first athlete with Cerebral Palsy to sign a sponsorship contract with Nike! Read more HERE.
￼

15 years of Henry Mayo's service in Newhall
The Henry Mayo Newhall Hospital Foundation celebrated the 15th anniversary of the Sheila R. Veloz Breast Center. Members of our staff were in attendance Wednesday night to help honor this fine facility that serves our community. Congratulations and thank you to the physicians and staff who work hard to deliver quality care.
￼

Teacher of the Month
Congratulations to Ms. Adamski of Big Springs Elementary School for being honored as Simi Valley Education Foundation's Teacher of the Month!
￼

Salute to Youth
I had a great time at the AV Unified High School District’s “Salute to Youth” event. Thank you to everyone who made this such a great success for our students!
￼

AV Board of Trade Aerocomm Committee
I met with the AV Board of Trade’s Aerocomm Committee. We talked about Department of Defense appropriations, the Space Force and the FAA reauthorization. Thank you to Al and Don and the committee for all they do to advocate for Aerospace Valley.
￼

Walk to School
I joined the students of White Oak Elementary School in Simi Valley for their annual "Walk to School" day. The kids and their parents learned from police, firefighters, and local officials about proper safety and precaution practices. Thank you to Principal Nicole Perryman for hosting this great event!
￼

Homes for Veterans
Our staff attended the ribbon cutting for the new Veteran Preferred Apartments in Palmdale. Thank to to the Estes Family and the City of Palmdale for your commitment to providing our veterans with affordable housing. Check out some photos HERE.
￼

Simi Valley Restaurant of the Week
Congratulations to the Junkyard Café in Simi Valley for being named the “Restaurant of the Week”. Owners Evelyn and Toni received the honor from the Simi Valley Chamber of Commerce. Nice job!
￼

Around the Capitol
FAM Act signed into law
The Friendly Airports for Mothers Act has been signed into law! This bipartisan bill will provide support to new mothers on the move. Read more HERE.
￼

FLIGHT R&D Act signed into law
The FLIGHT R&D Act has been signed into law! When American aerospace succeeds, the entire world benefits and our economy booms. Read more HERE.
￼

National Law Enforcement Museum
DC’s newest museum opened up this Saturday! The National Law Enforcement Museum will serve as a great lesson about the important role police have played in our country’s history and in our communities. As an 18 year veteran of the LAPD, I am proud to represent the interests of men and women in blue in Congress and I look forward to making my own visit to this museum! Read more HERE.
￼

Happy Birthday United States Navy
Happy 243rd Birthday to the United States Navy! Be sure to wish a sailor you know a happy birthday and thank them for their service.
￼

Ambassador Haley's Leadership at the United Nations
Throughout her tenure at the U.N., Ambassador Haley has served the United States with exemplary leadership, strength, and compassion. She has fought for American ideals on the world stage and protected our interests in a tumultuous international climate. I’d like to thank her for her service to the nation and wish her continued success for the future. Read more HERE.
￼

Subject: A Message From Ann
Message:
A message from Congresswoman Ann Wagner 
￼ 

About
Contact
Services
Media Center
Issues


Dear Lindsey, 
Paying for childcare is just plain hard for the working families I’ve spoken with across Missouri’s 2nd Congressional District. As a mother of three and a new grandmother, I know it’s challenging to raise young children, and we must find ways to help make the lives of working families a little bit easier. I also know that too many families across the state struggle to care for aging parents, and giving them new financial flexibility to pay for that care is important. The Child and Dependent Care Modernization Act of 2018 will do both by modernizing the maximum amount a family can contribute to Dependent Care Flexible Spending Accounts to track with the real costs of dependent care today. 
￼
At the White House, I met with President Trump and the Interagency Task Force to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons to discuss the administration’s progress to end human trafficking with cabinet-level officials. President Trump shared that the “administration is committed to leveraging every resource we have to confront this threat, to support the victims and survivors, and to hold traffickers accountable for their heinous crimes.” He praised my legislation, the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (FOSTA), that has led the fight against sex trafficking on the internet. I look forward to continued cooperation with the President to fight trafficking and support survivors. 
￼
￼
￼
As a member of the Financial Services Committee, rolling back regulations that burden small businesses and Main Street Americans is one of my top priorities. Regions Bank is expanding into St. Louis with several branches, and I attended the ribbon cutting for their newest branch in O’Fallon. The reform of several Dodd-Frank provisions has given neighborhood banks like Regions the opportunity to expand and give back to the community. In Congress, it’s my privilege to continue cutting red tape and providing ways for our economy and job market to grow. 
￼
￼
St. Charles County recently opened their new Emergency Management Operations Center. Together with St. Charles County Executive Steve Ehlmann, I visited the 30,000 square foot facility where the planning and coordination of disaster preparedness, response, and recovery takes place. The project finished over half a million under budget and enables St. Charles County to more efficiently respond to emergencies.   Next door, we met the St. Charles County Police Cyber Crimes Unit, which focuses on crimes against children and exploitation, including human trafficking. The unit is home to the Midwest’s only Electronic Storage Detection K9, Corporal Bonnie! We became fast friends, and besides being adorable, Bonnie can search, locate, and recover hidden electronics containing evidence to assist police in criminal investigations. I was fascinated to hear about their work and look forward to visiting again in the future!
￼
￼
￼

 Last Friday, Seaman 1st Class Natale I. Torti, who made the ultimate sacrifice at Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, was welcomed home to his final resting place at Jefferson Barracks. As Americans, we honor the memories of all those who served by remembering that freedom is not free. Our peace and protection have been bought and paid for with the blood of generations in uniform who have gone before us. My thoughts are with the Torti family, and I pray our country will be ever mindful of our heroes’ service and sacrifice.

One of my favorite stops last week was a visit to Mr. Brueckmann’s government class at Pattonville High School. I delivered 200 U.S. Constitution booklets and quizzed the students about the amendments and articles. Our nation’s Constitution is over 231 years old and still the standard bearer for freedom and democracy around the world. It was my pleasure to share our founding document with them--these Pattonville students have a bright future! 

￼
￼
￼

Sincerely,
￼  Ann Wagner Member of Congress 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Subject: News from the 10th: Medicare Part D Open Enrollment Help for Seniors
Message:
News from Congressman Brad Schneider 
￼

￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼

Dear Friends, 
Today is the first day of Medicare Open Enrollment season for seniors to make changes to their Medicare coverage. I know the enrollment process can be daunting, and it’s OK to have questions. That’s why we’re pleased to be hosting four informational events in Wheeling, Zion, Glenview and Lincolnshire to help connect seniors with help. If you would like assistance, make sure to call and sign-up for an appointment! 
HELP WITH MEDICARE OPEN ENROLLMENT FOR SENIORS 
￼ 
  
The Medicare annual enrollment period starts TODAY and lasts until December 7. This is the yearly time when seniors can make changes to their Medicare coverage for the following year. 
I’m excited to announce four upcoming events for constituents to meet with counselors to discuss their coverage options and compare and select the best plan for them. These events are by appointment only, and attendees should RSVP for a one-hour timeslot using the instructions below. You can also reach us at our office at (847) 383-4870 with questions.
Tuesday, November 13 | 9:30am – 2:30pm Indian Trails Library 355 Schoenbeck Rd, Wheeling, IL 60090 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
Thursday, November 15 | 10:00am – 2:00pm  Zion-Benton Public Library 2400 Gabriel Ave, Zion, IL 60099 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
Tuesday, November 20 | 9:30am – 3:30pm Glenview Senior Center 2400 Chestnut Ave., Glenview IL, 60026 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 784-6040
Tuesday, November 27 | 9:30am – 2:30pm  Vernon Area Public Library 300 Olde Half Day Road, Lincolnshire, IL 60069 To RSVP and schedule personal consultation: call (847) 383-4870 *Spanish speakers available 
  
ADVOCATING FOR S.A.L.T. RELIEF 
The tax bill President Trump signed into law last year effectively eliminated the federal deduction for  state and local tax (SALT) paid by many Illinois residents, and punishes many Illinois families. Our state already pays more in federal taxes than we receive back in benefits, making the elimination of the SALT deduction even more egregious. Last week, I joined a letter urging Governor Rauner to address the damage of this new law on Illinois taxpayers and explore options for relief as other states have done, including New Jersey, New York, and California.
Read the letter on our website. 
  
NEIGHBORHOOD OFFICE HOURS 
This week, our constituent service representatives will be in Mt. Prospect, and  Glenview. If you need assistance with a federal issue, please come see us! 
View the full schedule on our website. 
  
RSVP FOR VETERANS BREAKFAST 
￼ 
  
This Veterans Day weekend, I’m hosting a breakfast to honor those in our communities who served, and share some of the ways my office and local veteran organizations can be of assistance.
The breakfast is free and open to all veterans in Illinois’s Tenth Congressional District. I hope to see you there. 
Cristo Rey St. Martin College Prep 3106 Belvidere Road Waukegan, IL 60085 RSVP 
  
WEEKLY WRAP-UP  
￼ 
 
I toured work to repair a collapsed culvert under Washington Street in Waukegan with Sam Cunningham, State Sen. Terry Link and State Rep. Rita Mayfield. Across our country, our infrastructure needs investment. I’m committed to working across the aisle to make bipartisan progress on this issue.
￼ 
  
I was glad to join local business leaders and Mayor Nancy Rotering at the Business Summit in Highland Park.  
￼ 
I was glad to visit Tech Campus last week and learn more about the career and technical education training opportunities available to students. They young people here are gaining the STEM skills and hands-on experiences to succeed in a 21st century economy. 
￼ 
With some of the constituents who visited our #NeighborhoodOfficeHours at the Deerfield Public Library this afternoon. 
Thanks for reading!         
Sincerely, ￼  Bradley S. Schneider Member of Congress

Suite 200
Lincolnshire, IL 60069

Subject: Newsletter: Women Veteran's Event & Recovering from Hurricane Florence
Message:
October 15, 2018
 
￼
  
￼

About Tim
Services
Media Center
Legislative Work
South Carolina
Resources



Dear fellow South Carolinians,  Thank you for subscribing to my weekly e-newsletter, and please remember to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.  
Women Veteran’s Event Last week, I was happy to announce the keynote speaker at my upcoming South Carolina Women Veteran’s event: my friend and colleague, Sen. Joni Ernst.   Senator Ernst is a force to be reckoned with. Not only does she hold the title of United States Senator, but she also holds the rank of Lieutenant Colonel in the Iowa Army National Guard. As a combat veteran herself, I am so excited to welcome her back to the Palmetto State. I have no doubt that her passion, story, and mission will resonate with South Carolina’s 43,000 women veterans.  You can learn more about the event here, and RSVP at www. scott.senate.gov/veteransrsvp. 
￼   
Recovering from Hurricane Florence Although it has been over a month since Hurricane Florence battered the Carolinas, many are still recovering from its destruction and devastation. To view information about disaster recovery center locations, FEMA assistance, IRS relief, SBA loans, unemployment and more, visit my Hurricane Florence Recovery help page here. 
 Sincerely, ￼  Tim
