Dear Friend, 
As your Representative in Congress, it is my privilege to deliver this newsletter with opportunities for federal grants in District 10. 
Grants are available to individuals, non-profit organizations, and state or local government entities. 
As you may know, federal funding is extremely competitive and limited in availability. It is my hope that this newsletter will be a helpful resource for you in the grants process. 
For more information about getting started and the application process, please visit www.grants.gov, or contact Erin Waldron, my Director of Economic and Community Development, at 321-388-9808. 
Are you eligible for a federal grant?  What are your next steps?  Learn how to write grant applications 
My office is here to assist you with any of your needs. 
 
Recently Awarded in District 10
Hurricane Education Recovery Assistance for Homeless Children and Youth Program – Department of Education 
	•	Recipient: Florida Department of Education
	•	Award: $3,687,195
	•	Description: The Department of Education awarded more than $3.6 million in new federal assistance for Florida under the Hurricane Education Recovery Assistance for Homeless Children and Youth Program. Congress appropriated a total of $25 million for this new program, and amounts awarded were based on specific data received from eligible applicants. The Department is authorized to award funds to eligible state educational agencies (SEAs) to provide assistance to eligible local educational agencies (LEAs) serving homeless children and youth displaced by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria, or the 2017 California wildfires. The funds will be used to address the educational and related needs of these students, consistent with the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act and the Hurricane Education Recovery Act. These awards were based on:
	1.	the total number of children and youth enrolled in public schools in the state during the 2017-2018 school year who were both displaced and homeless as a result of a covered disaster; and
	2.	additional “demonstrated need” for assistance as reflected by the total number of children and youth enrolled in public schools in the state during this period who were homeless as a result of a covered disaster but were not displaced.
Aspire ACT Team Expansion & Enhancement Project – Department of Health and Human Services 
	•	Recipient: Aspire Health Project, Inc.
	•	Award: $678,000
	•	Description: Aspire Health Partners' Florida Assertive Community Treatment (FACT) Team is made up of a multidisciplinary, mobile group of treatment providers including a psychiatrist, psychiatric nurses, counselors, case managers, a vocational specialist, a substance abuse specialist and a peer counselor. Maintaining a small caseload, this group functions interchangeably to provide treatment, rehabilitation and support services that the 100 people with mental illness served by the team needs to live successfully in the community.
2018 Citizenship and Assimilation Grant Program – Department of Homeland Security 
	•	Recipient: Hope Community Center
	•	Award: $225,000
	•	Description: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced the award of $9.425 million in grants to 40 organizations that prepare lawful permanent residents (LPRs) for naturalization. The grants also aim to promote prospective citizens’ assimilation into American civic life by funding educational programs designed to increase their knowledge of English, U.S. history, and civics. Located in 19 states, these organizations will receive federal funding to support citizenship preparation services for LPRs through September 2020.
FY 18 Positive Train Control (PTC) Grants under the Consolidated Rail Infrastructure and Safety Improvements Grant Program – Department of Transportation 
	•	Recipient: State of Florida
	•	Award: $14,914,238
	•	Description: This project will complete the installation of Interoperable Electronic Train Management System (I-ETMS) with testing and documentation to support certification on the 61.3-mile Central Florida Rail Corridor (CFRC) from DeLand to Poinciana, FL. PTC will also facilitate the future use of Motor Vehicle Presence Detection Systems, which will detect motor vehicles that have stopped on the railroad crossing. As a result, implementing I-ETMS will ensure the safety of SunRail and Amtrak passengers on trains traversing the CFRC each year, as well as roadway workers in work zones and automobile drivers traversing the CFRC’s grade crossings.
2018 Hazardous Materials Instructor Training Grants Disc. Grant – Department of Transportation 
	•	Recipient: Sustainable Workplace Alliance
	•	Award: $843,440
	•	Description: Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration is awarding $3,622,052 in Hazardous Materials Instructor Training (HMIT) grants.  PHMSA’s Hazardous Materials Instructor Training grant and its Supplemental Public Sector Training grant collectively fund prevention and response activities. HMIT is a competitive program whereby grantees use funds to train instructors who then train private-sector hazardous materials (hazmat) employees. The Office of Hazardous Materials Safety awards funds through a competitive process to nonprofit organizations that demonstrate: 
	1.	expertise in conducting training programs for hazmat employees and
	2.	the ability to reach and involve in a training program a target population of hazmat employees.
FY 18 Community Safety Grant Disc. Grant – Department of Transportation
	•	Recipient: State of Florida
	•	Award: $250,000
	•	Description: The Sustainable Workplace Alliance proposes to conduct a “Whole Community” plan for hazmat transportation emergency preparation and response. This proposed project will focus on conducting national outreach and training programs to assist communities in preparing for and responding to accidents and incidents involving the transportation of hazardous materials, including Class 3 flammable liquids by rail. Specific focus will be given to rural communities. Additionally, CVSA will collect, publish and widely distribute best practice guidance on ways to connect with and increase awareness of state and local emergency responders, appropriate Federal, state, local and tribal government organizations, and the general public of hazardous materials being transported through communities. Elected to focus on smaller, rural communities where emergency response training is often lacking. This is especially an issue in remote communities where volunteer based first responders are the norm. It is estimated that 645 students will be trained.
2018 Hazardous Materials Emergency Preparedness (HMEP) Grants – Department of Transportation 
	•	Recipient: Florida Division of Emergency Management
	•	Award: $647,594
	•	Description: Congress created the HMEP Grant Program in 1990 which allows recipients to design and implement planning and training programs based on their individual needs. The program uses a discretionary formula for States and Territories and a competitive application process for Tribes. The formula is based on census data, the number of hazmat incidents, the severity of hazmat incidents, and the estimated costs of incidents. HMEP State and Territory grant recipients are currently completing Year 1 of a 3 year grant cycle. This next release of funds allows for continued operations of existing planning and training projects outlined in the Fiscal Year 2016-2018 grant applications. HMEP applicants allocate grant funds towards activities such as:  Developing or revising emergency plans and training activities to account for bulk transportation of energy products by rail and over the road; Conducting commodity flow studies to determine the frequency and quantity of hazmat shipments being transported through local communities; Training emergency responders to respond appropriately to incidents involving bulk shipments of energy products as well as other hazmat. 
2018 Technical Assistance Grant – Department of Transportation 
	•	Recipient: State of Florida
	•	Award: $78,000
	•	Description: The East Central Florida Planning Council plans to engage with subject matter experts in the pipeline industry to inform and train first responders using best practices on how to mitigate and resolve pipeline failures safely. The Council will provide hands-on training to first responders using the grant to purchase training props and equipment and will provide extensive emergency response planning and public education. Funding will also be used to support the Florida Pipeline Emergency Responders Initiative.
2018 State Base Pipeline Safety Grants (Natural Gas) – Department of Transportation 
	•	Recipient: State of Florida
	•	Award: $530,727
	•	Description: The East Central Florida Planning Council plans to engage with subject matter experts in the pipeline industry to inform and train first responders using best practices on how to mitigate and resolve pipeline failures safely. The Council will provide hands-on training to first responders using the grant to purchase training props and equipment and will provide extensive emergency response planning and public education. Funding will also be used to support the Florida Pipeline Emergency Responders Initiative.
FY18 Paul Coverdell Forensic Science Improvement Grants Program – Department of Justice 
	•	Recipient: Orange County Sheriff’s Office
	•	Award: $250,000
	•	Description: Orange County Sheriff's Office (OCSO) faces several challenges to analyzing firearms and fired cartridge casings in a timely manner, including a limited number of qualified analysts, no available acquisition and correlation equipment onsite, and current policies for testing and analyzing firearms evidence by Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE). At present, the time to conduct firearms analysis and get a report back from FDLE takes from one to six months. OCSO will purchase an Integrated Ballistic Identification System (IBIS) that gives the Forensic Unit the ability to analyze, correlate, and upload data to the National Integrated Ballistic Information Network (NIBIN). This data will become part of the national database for firearms-related evidence. Also, OCSO will engage local and regional partners to process firearms-related evidence for multiple law enforcement agencies, train additional forensic staff members to use the Brasstrax platform, build a secured workstation, utilize overtime hours to reduce the backlog of evidence, and pursue accreditation for the forensic lab. The Brasstrax/Matchpoint system will reduce the report time for firearms related evidence to as little as 48 hours, if needed for expedited cases. 
Federally-Facilitated Exchange Navigator Program Grant – Department of Health and Human Services 
	•	Recipient: State of Florida
	•	Award: $1,250,000
	•	Description: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) awarded $10 million in Navigator grant awards to 39 organizations who will serve as Navigators in Federally-facilitated Exchange states. These awards will support the work of organizations that offer assistance to consumers navigating, shopping for, and enrolling in health insurance coverage for 2019. Navigators are one of many ways individuals can get help shopping for, and enrolling in, health insurance coverage; CMS continues to expand options for individuals to enroll in coverage through partnerships with the private sector, including agents and brokers and health insurance issuers. Applicants to the 2018 Navigator Funding Opportunity Announcement (FOA) were encouraged to leverage volunteers and enter strategic partnerships with public and private organizations in their work targeting “left behind” consumers who could benefit from individual market coverage. Applicants were also directed to use more cost-effective strategies to meet their enrollment goals. The grants awarded today will have a period of performance of one year from the award date, September 12, 2018, to September 11, 2019. Entities and individuals cannot serve as Navigators in the Federally-facilitated Exchanges without receiving federal grant funding from CMS to perform Navigator duties.
Upcoming Grant Opportunities
Assistance to Firefighters Grants – Department of Homeland Security
	•	Award Ceiling: $9,000,000
	•	Application Deadline: October 26, 2018
	•	Description: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Grants Programs Directorate is responsible for the implementation and administrations of the Assistance to Firefighters Grant (AFG) Program. The purpose of the AFG Program is to enhance the safety of the public and firefighters with respect to fire and fire-related hazards. The program guidance document provides potential applicants with the details of the requirements, processing, and evaluation of an application for financial assistance for eligible activities.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=309032  
Museum Grants for African American History & Culture – Institute of Museum and Library Services
	•	Award Ceiling: $250,000
	•	Application Deadline: November 1, 2018
	•	Description: The goals of the Museum Grants for African American History and Culture program (AAHC program) are to build the capacity of African American museums and support the growth and development of museum professionals at African American museums. The AAHC program supports projects that nurture museum professionals, build institutional capacity, and increase access to museum and archival collections at African American museums and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). IMLS welcomes applications from museums of all sizes and geographic areas whose primary purpose, as reflected in their mission, is African American art, life, history, and culture. Projects may be structured at any of several stages of maturity: exploratory, piloting, scaling, or mainstreaming. A proposed project’s activities may be brand new to the institution, or they may implement learnings, perspectives, or competencies acquired during a previous project. A project may be an effort to intensify the impact of an approach that has been tested and found to be effective, or it may be structured as an opportunity to expand a function or activity that has been deemed successful.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=308276  
Historic Preservation Fund Grants to Underrepresented Communities – Department of the Interior
	•	Award Ceiling: $50,000
	•	Application Deadline: November 1, 2018
	•	Description: Grants support the survey, inventory, and designation of historic properties that are associated with communities currently underrepresented in the National Register of Historic Places and among National Historic Landmarks. Within one year of the completion of the grant, all projects must result in: the submission of a new nomination to the National Register of Historic Places or National Historic Landmark program OR an amendment to an existing National Register or National Historic Landmark nomination to include underrepresented communities.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=308402
Preschool Development Grant Birth through Five – Department of Health and Human Services
	•	Award Ceiling: $15,000,000
	•	Application Deadline: November 6, 2018
	•	Description: The Administration for Children and Families (ACF) at the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), in consultation with the Department of Education (ED), will be soliciting applications from eligible States and Territories—"State entity" can either be a State government agency or a non-profit, nongovernmental entity—to carry out the activities of the Preschool Development Grant Birth through Five (PDG B-5). The new PDG B-5 grant seeks to empower state governments to develop, update, or implement a strategic plan to facilitate collaboration and coordination among early childhood care and education programs in a mixed delivery system to prepare low-income and disadvantaged children to transition into the local educational agency or elementary school. States may pursue a range of activities as outlined in this announcement to align and strengthen existing funding streams, coordinate delivery models, improve the use of existing resources, encourage partnerships among providers and stakeholders, and maximize parental choice in a mixed delivery system.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=308843
Self-Help Homeownership Opportunity Program (SHOP) – Department of Housing and Urban Development
	•	Award Ceiling: $10,000,000
	•	Application Deadline: November 12, 2018
	•	Description: This SHOP NOFA announces the availability of $10,000,000 in FY2018 SHOP Grant funds to be awarded to national and regional non-profit organizations and consortia to facilitate and encourage innovative homeownership opportunities on a national, geographically diverse basis through the provision of self-help homeownership housing programs. Applicants must propose to use a significant amount of SHOP Grant funds in at least two states. Individuals are not eligible to apply for SHOP Grant funds. SHOP Grant funds must be used for land acquisition, infrastructure improvements, and for reasonable and necessary planning, administration and management costs (not to exceed 20 percent). The construction or rehabilitation costs of each SHOP unit must be funded with other leveraged public and private funds. The average SHOP Grant expenditure for the combined costs of land acquisition and infrastructure improvements must not exceed $15,000 per SHOP unit. SHOP units must be decent, safe, and sanitary non-luxury dwellings that comply with state and local codes, ordinances, and zoning requirements, and with all other SHOP requirements, including but not limited to, the requirements for energy-efficiency, water conservation and accessibility). The SHOP units must be sold to homebuyers at prices below the prevailing market price. Homebuyers must be low-income and must contribute a significant amount of sweat equity towards the development of the SHOP units. A homebuyer’s sweat equity contribution must not be mortgaged or otherwise restricted upon future sale of the SHOP unit. Volunteer labor is also required SHOP Grantees may award SHOP Grant funds to local non-profit affiliate organizations to carry out the Grantee’s SHOP program. These affiliate organizations must be located within the Grantee’s service area.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=308897
Access and Mobility Partnership Grants; Human Services Coordination Research (HSCR) – Department of Transportation
	•	Award Ceiling: $2,434,767
	•	Application Deadline: November 13, 2018
	•	Description: FTA makes available $2,434,767 in funding for a Human Services Coordination Research (HSCR) Program with funds available under the Public Transportation Innovation Program. Research activities awarded under this competitive program will support the implementation of innovative strategies in the coordination of human services transportation to provide more effective and efficient public transportation services to seniors, individuals with disabilities, and low-income individuals. Proposed research projects should address gaps identified in the locally developed Coordinated Public Transit-Human Services Transportation Plan. The HSCR funds will finance operating and capital project expenditures to develop and deploy projects that improve transportation services for targeted populations as noted above through methods that effectively and efficiently coordinate human services transportation.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=308944
2019 Senior Corps RSVP Competition – Corporation for National and Community Service
	•	Award Ceiling: $729,000
	•	Application Deadline: November 7, 2018
	•	Description: Senior Corps RSVP grants allow organizations to establish Senior Corps RSVP programs that engage volunteers in service to a specific geographic area (click here for the full list of available opportunities). Successful applicants will receive funding to recruit, train, and manage volunteers, placing them at organizations addressing critical community needs. Established in 1971 and now one of the largest senior volunteer programs in the nation, Senior Corps RSVP engages older Americans ages 55 and over in a diverse range of volunteer activities. RSVP volunteers mentor and tutor disadvantaged children and youth, renovate homes, feed the homeless, assist victims of natural disasters, provide free income tax assistance, and much more.
	•	More Information: https://www.grants.gov/web/grants/view-opportunity.html?oppId=309121
My office is here to assist you with any of your needs.
 Sincerely, 
￼
Val Demings U.S. Representative, Florida's 10th Congressional District 


Washington, DC
238 Cannon House Office Building
Washington, DC 20515
Phone: (202) 225-2176

Subject: RELEASE: Rep. Blum Cosponsors Bill to Protect Social Security and Medicare
Message:
￼


October 15, 2018



Rep. Blum Cosponsors Bill to Protect Social Security & Medicare
WASHINGTON-- Congressman Blum recently cosponsored H.Res.1026 to express the sense of the House that Medicare and Social Security must be protected for current enrollees and preserved for future generations.

Rep. Blum commented, "Growing up, my mother was dependent on Social Security survivor benefits to put food on the table after my father passed— I personally understand the importance and necessity of these benefits. Iowans have worked hard and paid into the Social Security system with the expectation that these funds will be available upon retirement. Both parties in Congress must work together to enact responsible long-term reforms that will protect both current and future retirees- and this bill confirms my commitment to do so."

￼

Subject: Wicker Highlights Wins for America's Airports, Water Infrastructure
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
October 15, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | About Roger | How Can I Help You? | Newsroom | Issues | Mississippi | Visiting DC | Contact
Wicker Highlights Wins for America’s Airports, Water Infrastructure
Confirmation of New Supreme Court Justice Coincides With Major Legislative Accomplishments
The confirmation of a Supreme Court justice deserves national attention.  These lifetime appointments to the court are some of the most influential decisions a president can make.
The consideration of Judge Brett Kavanaugh was no exception, arguably drawing the most intense attention a Supreme Court nominee has ever received.  On October 6, I voted with the majority of my Senate colleagues to confirm Judge Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.
Judicial nominations have been a priority for the Trump Administration, and the Senate has now confirmed two of the President’s Supreme Court nominees, a record 29 circuit court judges, and 53 district court judges.  However, these nominations have not stood in the way of other legislative victories.  In recent weeks, the Senate’s accomplishments have continued to grow, with bills impacting our infrastructure and public safety earning wide bipartisan support.  
Long-Term Reauthorization for FAA
One of those accomplishments is the recent reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), which oversees all activities related to commercial air travel.  For years, the agency has operated under stopgap reauthorizations.  The new law’s five-year reauthorization is welcome news for airports, industries, and passengers that depend on FAA programs.   
More specifically, the FAA law will support the grant program that many of our state’s airports have utilized to improve and expand their facilities.  It will continue the work being done at Mississippi State University’s Center for Excellence for Unmanned Aircraft Systems, which is critical to the safe integration of drones into the national airspace.  The reauthorization will also institute measures to benefit consumers, such as minimum seat size requirements on commercial flights and protections against exorbitant costs imposed by air ambulance providers.  
Wicker Provision to Help Rural Communities
Another accomplishment I am particularly pleased to see reach the finish line is passage of the “America’s Water Infrastructure Act.”  Like the FAA bill, this legislation prioritizes the safety and well-being of Americans through needed upgrades and maintenance.  Without reliable ports and inland waterways, the commerce that fuels our economy would be severely hampered, hurting the communities along our coasts and rivers.  Without effective dams and levees, American lives and property are put at risk in the event of extreme flooding. 
The water infrastructure bill also includes a provision I authored to help small communities with their wastewater treatment systems.  Small communities often struggle with the costs and technical expertise required to operate these systems in compliance with federal rules.  My provision would create opportunities for these communities to receive technical assistance for wastewater treatment.  It follows the success of a similar provision I enacted into law in 2015 for drinking water systems.  Not only is clean drinking water and wastewater important to public safety, it can encourage critical economic investment.
Passage of these bills was accompanied by other bipartisan wins, including legislation to address our nation’s opioid epidemic and appropriations bills to keep the government funded.  President Trump has set forth an ambitious agenda for his Administration, and Congress continues to work to make good on its end of the deal – cutting taxes, rebuilding America’s infrastructure, and ensuring that our military remains the strongest fighting force in the world.
Other news this week:

	•	Wicker Underscores Need for Unified Approach to Privacy Legislation
	•	Wicker Votes for Bipartisan Water Infrastructure Act
	•	Wicker Shares Success of MIssissippi Wildlife Conservation Efforts

Subject: You're Invited: Service Academy Day this Saturday
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼

HOME
ABOUT G.K.B.
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
 
The Washington Rundown 
Last week, Hurricane Michael caused devastation to the Florida Panhandle and throughout the Southeast, including North Carolina.  As of Friday, eleven deaths have been confirmed, and more than a million homes and businesses were without electricity, including 529,000 households in North Carolina.  If you are in need of help after Hurricanes Florence or Michael, dial 2-1-1 or 888-892-1162 to reach the statewide information line that is available 24/7 to answer your shelter, housing, and other storm-related questions. Residents in the 28 counties included in the major disaster declaration following Hurricane Florence, including Wilson County and Pitt County, have until TODAY at 5pm to register to vote.  The voter registration deadline was extended due to Hurricane Florence. 
Butterfield Accepting Military Academy Applications 
Are you or someone you know interested in attending one of the nation’s military academies? Did you know all service academies, other than the United States Coast Guard Academy, require a nomination from a qualified nominating source? 
Each year, Congressman Butterfield has the honor of nominating a limited number of young people from North Carolina’s First District for appointment to four of the five U.S. Military Service Academies: the U.S. Air Force Academy, U.S. Naval Academy, U.S. Military Academy (West Point), and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy.  
Interested students who meet the eligibility requirements should send their completed application packet to Congressman Butterfield’s Durham office no later than November 15, 2018.  
Click here to read the eligibility requirements and start your application. 
￼  Rep. Butterfield with students from NC-01 who were appointed to a U.S. military academy for the 2018 academic year after receiving a nomination from Congressman Butterfield.  Photo taken on June 18, 2018. Read more about the 2018 military academy appointees here. 
Join Us this Saturday for Service Academy Day! 
Join Congressman Butterfield's office for our annual Service Academy Day this Saturday, October 20! 
Students, parents, guidance counselors, and other school officials are invited to attend Service Academy Day to learn more about each military academy and our office's nomination process.  Students will have an opportunity to meet representatives and cadets from the service academies, as well as ROTC programs at the local colleges and universities.
￼  
RSVP here to attend Service Academy Day on Saturday, October 20. 
￼  Photos from the 2017 Service Academy Day in Wilson, North Carolina.  Photos taken on Oct. 21, 2017. 
In The News 
 
Rocky Mount Telegram: Free concert to launch event center 
Here comes the funk. 
Grammy award-winner George Clinton and Parliament-Funkadelic are set to “tear the roof off” the Rocky Mount Event Center when they perform a free show at 7 p.m. Oct. 25 to celebrate the grand opening of the center. […] 
WTVD ABC 11 Chief Meteorologist Chris Hohmann will serve as the master of ceremonies. U.S. Rep. G.K. Butterfield, D-1st District, will give remarks. 

WUNC: Duke University Mourns The Death Of Dr. Brenda Armstrong 
One of the most revered doctors at Duke University died Sunday. Dr. Brenda Armstrong will be remembered for the impact she made in her community and at Duke University School of Medicine, where she spent more than 20 years. […] 
Armstrong said in interviews, she was raised to give back and help her community in segregated Rocky Mount. One of her childhood family friends was Congressman G.K. Butterfield. "America has lost a giant," Butterfield said in a statement. 

The Wilson Times: Butterfield questions Kavanaugh's 'past conduct, judicial temperament' 
Wilson's congressman says he's "extremely disappointed" in the Senate's confirmation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh as the United States' 114th Supreme Court justice. 
U.S. Rep. G.K. Butterfield, a Wilson Democrat representing North Carolina's 1st Congressional District, expressed concern over the allegations of sexual misconduct Kavanaugh faces and predicted the appellate judge and former White House counsel for President George W. Bush will bring partisan politics to the high court bench.
"Now more than ever, our country needs a Supreme Court justice who will rise above ideology, protect the rights of all Americans and preserve our system of checks and balances by stopping presidential abuse of executive power," Butterfield said. "Unfortunately, nothing in Judge Kavanaugh's record or past have shown he will be such a justice."

Subject: Schweikert Review October 14th
Message:
District Update |October 14, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Arizona Health Care Update
￼ This week the Arizona Department of Insurance published county-specific rate information before open enrollment. With these new rates come a window of optimism in the Arizona health insurance market that has suffered from the constraints of the Affordable Care Act.   In 2017, most counties only had one insurer offering plans on the ACA exchange. Beginning in 2019, Arizona will have five insurers participating in the ACA exchange across the state. Four of these insurers will be offering plans in Maricopa County and three will be offering plans in Pima County - both counties that had only one insurer in 2017.   For those in the individual market, you can view the 2019 expected rates through this link.   
Read My Joint Op-Ed
As the Arizona Department of Insurance publishes 2019 health insurance rates, I also wanted to share a joint op-ed I released with my colleague Representative Webster.   The Op-Ed introduces a plan for a Federal Invisible Risk Sharing Program, and gives a reminder of the less then desirable outcome that the ACA imposed on insurers and patients.  The legislative proposal explains how Congress can address the issue of unaffordable health care and gives insurers the ability to recoup the extraordinary costs of their highest cost patients. This will help to ensure individuals have access to affordable health insurance at the lowest possible rates, whether they have a pre-existing condition or not.    For more information, read the full op-ed here. 

JOIN THE CONVERSATION
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼

SPRING INTERNSHIPS 
￼

My Washington, D.C. and Scottsdale offices are now accepting full-time and part-time Spring 2019 interns to join our staff. For any motivated, detail-oriented, and service-oriented college students or recent graduates interested in gaining experience in Washington or Arizona in a government office, please e-mail your resume, a cover letter, and three references to Sam.Sabol@Mail.House.Gov for a Washington, D.C. internship, or Ernestina.Borquez-Smith@Mail.House.Gov for an Arizona based internship. We look forward to hearing from you! 

SEND ME A MESSAGE! 
As your representative, I am here to help answer your questions. Please always feel free to reach out to either my Washington, D.C. or Scottsdale offices with any questions.

Subject: Paulsen Post - October 14, 2018
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
HOME 
CONTACT ME 
ABOUT 
SERVICES 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
October 14, 2018 
Dear Friend,

 
Big milestone this past week as I marked my 250th classroom visit in our schools. I joined some sharp students in Mr. Bell's A.P. Government and Politics class at Minnetonka High School -- more below. 
A couple of important updates to two topics I've mentioned recently. First, legislation prohibiting so-called pharmacist "gag clauses" was signed into law last week after it earned bipartisan support in the Senate. I authored legislation in the House prohibiting these clauses, which prohibit pharmacists from telling patients when their are cheaper ways to pay for their medications and prescriptions. Learn more here. 
And, landmark opioid legislation which had already passed in the House was approved by the Senate, and is expected to be signed into law in the coming days. This is a big bipartisan win in the fight against the opioid crisis, and it's great news for the first responders, doctors and patients on the front lines of this epidemic. Learn more here.
 
Have a great week and please let me know whenever I can be of assistance to you or your family. Join the conversation online by visiting my website, Facebook page, Twitter, and Instagram. And as always, be sure to watch the latest Erik's Correspondence Corner below.
 
￼

 
Sincerely,
 
￼ Erik Paulsen Member of Congress
A Big Milestone
I'm fortunate to represent some incredible schools and it's why I take the time to meet regularly with teachers and students. Every classroom is different and gives me an opportunity to learn a new perspective. This past week I marked my 250th classroom visit!  
It was great to join Mr. Bell's juniors and seniors in his A.P. U.S. Government and Politics class at Minnetonka High School. We discussed a wide variety of issues, how the media can play a positive and negative role surrounding public policy, as well as ways to become engaged in public service. Thank you to Minnetonka High School and Mr. Bell for hosting me! 
 
￼
 
Protecting Medicare for Seniors
Millions of Minnesota seniors rely on Medicare for their everyday medical needs, and none more so than those with complex, chronic conditions like arthritis, multiple sclerosis or cancer. But I fear a new Medicare proposal by the President's administration, designed to reduce costs, threatens access to critical care seniors need.
It's called Step Therapy, and in short, it would require doctors to treat seniors with an escalating series of treatments, starting first with the cheapest medication. This means patients will have to "fail first" on a low-cost treatment before their doctors can prescribe the care they think is best-suited to their needs.
I've heard growing concerns about this plan, so I convened a roundtable in my District Office with care providers, doctors and patients, to hear directly from them about their experiences with Step Therapy. Their message was unanimous: Step Therapy can be a nightmare, causing delayed treatment, creating massive loads of paperwork, and leave patients desperately waiting for the care their doctors know they need.
After what I heard, I'm calling on the Health and Human Services Secretary to reevaluate this proposal, because we should ensure seniors are able to get the treatments they need, when they need them. The doctor-patient relationship is critical and cutting costs should not come at the expensive of quality care for Minnesota seniors. 
 
 
A Tax Reform Success Story in Brooklyn Park
So many small businesses I've visited have shared their stories on how tax reform has helped them hire more people, invest more in capital equipment and give their employees a raise and better benefits. I heard the latest success story during my visit to Diversified Plastics in Brooklyn Park. Their business is strong, they've hired 7 additional employees, and they're boosting starting wages to keep up with the demand for their products. Learn more about my visit here.
 
￼
Erik with a patient at a DaVita dialysis center in Edina
 
￼
Erik with the folks at Meyer Contracting in Maple Grove, another tax reform success story
 
￼
Rep. Paulsen at the SAGE Academy Charter School in Brooklyn Park
  
￼
Rep. Paulsen with Paul Douglas and Jordana Green in-studio at WCCO Radio
 
￼
An Annual Tradition: The Maple Plain Fire Company's Steak Fry

Subject: UPDATES from Your Congressman
Message:
News from Representative Bradley Byrne
  
￼
ABOUT BRADLEY | HOW CAN I HELP | CONTACT BRADLEY | WANT TO RECEIVE MY UPDATES?
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
I extend my deepest sympathies to all those affected by Hurricane Michael and will continue to pray for a speedy recovery and return to normalcy for those affected. The Wiregrass region of Alabama was hit hard, but nothing compares to the heartbreaking devastation we are seeing for our neighbors in the Florida panhandle.
I also wanted to make you aware of the recovery resources available to you and those you know who may have been impacted by the storm. Click here to apply online for federal disaster assistance, here for information from the Alabama Emergency Management Agency, and here for disaster relief and recovery services from the American Red Cross including information on contacting missing loved ones.  
It is in times like these that we must come together as a community to assist each other, and I applaud the work of our first responders, electric linemen, area shelters, and all those helping those affected by this historic storm.  
A Day in Semmes 
￼ 
On Wednesday, I had the opportunity to discuss how Alabamians are "better off now" with members of the Semmes Chamber of Commerce. From lower taxes to less red tape, I and other commonsense legislators in Washington are helping to pave the way for a booming economy. A special thank you to the local ROTC for providing the colors for the luncheon. After visiting with the Chamber, I went with Mayor David Baker to see some of the recent developments around town; from road projects to new retail, Semmes continues to grow. I also appreciated visiting with some of the first responders at the fire department. These folks do a great job of keeping Semmes and the surrounding areas safe, and I am very grateful for their service to our community.
Building a Stronger Alabama 
In a major bipartisan effort, this week the Senate passed a piece of legislation that will help to unlock the full economic potential of our region and state. Having passed the House last month, America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018 (S. 3021) passed the Senate on Wednesday and will now go to the President’s desk to be signed into law.  
This bill authorizes funding for waterway projects, port improvement projects, and other important water infrastructure projects in all 50 states. Not only will this allow for much-needed infrastructure improvements, but the bill reinstates a “Buy America” provision for federally funded projects, meaning a boost for American steel producers.
There are very few places in the United States that can boast the sort of infrastructure we have here in Alabama. It is clear, though, that our infrastructure throughout the country is in need of updates, repairs, and overhauls to ensure that we are at the cutting edge of transportation and connection. Keep an eye out this week for my column with more information on this landmark legislation! 
Securing our Elections 
￼ 
Few things are as sacred to Americans as the ability to vote in free and fair elections. When the integrity of such a system is undermined by the actions of a group of outsiders, namely illegal immigrants voting in our elections, we must act.  
I joined Congressman Brooks, Congressman Aderholt, and 20 of my Congressional colleagues in sending a letter to Attorney General Jeff Sessions urging him to dedicate more resources to protect our elections from illegal voting. Too often, people focus on Russian interference in our elections while the issue of illegal immigrants voting falls by the wayside.  
We cannot allow this threat to our national integrity to continue, and we need to do everything in our power to uphold these deepest American values. There is still work to be done in securing our border, enforcing our laws, and keeping our elections safe, and I am dedicated to seeing those tasks through to the end.
In Case You Missed It!  
Here are a few articles from this past week that are worth a read:  
“Alabama reactions pour in after Senate votes to confirm Brett Kavanaugh.” –  Yellowhammer News 
“Bradley Byrne: SUPPORT in times of crisis.” - Alabama Today 
“Alabama officials celebrate strong national September jobs report.” - Yellowhammer News 
"Alabama Congressmen to Jeff Sessions: protect American election integrity.” - Alabama Today 
“Local veteran attends Honor Flight.” - Brewton Standard 
“Sen. Shelby celebrates confirmation of Kavanaugh.” - al.com 
"Burke confirmed to federal bench" - Alabama Daily News 
Photo of the Week 
￼ 
Rebecca and I were honored to be a part of the retirement celebration last Saturday night for newscaster Bob Grip. Bob has such a proud tradition on FOX10 News but an equally impressive role as a leader in our community. We wish you all the best in your retirement, Bob! 
What’s Ahead  
As we continue to move through the month of October, I always enjoy getting out to catch up with folks in Southwest Alabama and update them on what we are doing in Washington. I will be holding several town halls throughout the rest of this month. Here are the ones we have scheduled so far: 
	•	Saraland - Thursday, October 25th at 3:00 pm (Saraland City Hall; 937 Highway 43 South)  
	•	Bayou La Batre - Monday, October 29th at 11:00 am (Bayou La Batre City Hall; 13785 South Wintzell Avenue)  
Be sure to follow me on Facebook and Twitter to stay up to date with the latest news and information on where I will be in the upcoming weeks! I would love to have you join us and hear what issues matter most to you. 
As always, if you need help with a federal agency or have questions about anything under debate in Washington, please contact my office. You can call my Mobile office at 251-690-2811 or you can click here to send me an email directly. I also invite you to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to get up-to-the-minute updates on my travel in Southwest Alabama. At the end of the day, my staff and I are here to serve you! 
Stay in touch, 
￼
Congressman Bradley Byrne
 
PS: Do you enjoy my email updates? If so, please forward these updates to your friends and family. They can also sign up to get my updates by clicking here.

Subject: Rep. Lynn Jenkins Weekly Update: Investigation on Maternal Mortality Rates, Trade Update, & More!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
HOME 
CONTACT US 
CONSTITUENT SERVICES 
ISSUES AND LEGISLATION 
October 14, 2018 
Ways and Means Investigation on Maternal Mortality Rates in the U.S.:
Recent investigations have revealed that an alarming number of mothers in the United States are dying during and after childbirth while the maternal mortality rate is on the rise. Every year in the United States, more than 50,000 mothers are severely injured during or after childbirth and 700 die. In fact, maternal mortality review committees from nine states found that approximately 63 percent of pregnancy-related deaths were preventable. Bringing a new baby into this world should be one of the most exciting and rewarding times in a woman’s life. It is absolutely unacceptable that preventable failures are the cause of avoidable, unnecessary, and absolutely tragic deaths.
As Chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Oversight, I sent letters to 15 major hospital systems around the country in a search for answers on why there is a growing rate of mothers dying from childbirth. The letters ask these hospital systems to detail the steps they are taking to identify risks and complications in pregnancies and to answer questions on their childbirth safety protocols. I hope we can find out why these deaths are happening and how Congress can act to prevent this tragic loss of life.
 
World Mental Health Day:
While this year’s World Mental Health Day fell on October 10th, the importance of treating and reaching out to those suffering with mental health illness must be a focus that lasts all year long. Mental health has many faces and millions of Americans are struggling not only with the illness, but also with the stigma surrounding the issue.
Both before and during my time in Congress, I have been an advocate for improving the mental health system in our country. I was proud to introduce H.R. 1877, the Mental Health First Aid Act, which was signed into law with bipartisan support in 2016 as part of the 21st Century Cures Act. The legislation drove innovation and prioritized the fight against the ongoing mental health crisis by creating an evidence-based education program that provides first aid training to community leaders such as teachers, police officers, and first responders. The training teaches communities how to identify symptoms of common mental illnesses, de-escalate crises, and help those showing early signs of mental disorders gain access to relevant mental health resources.
This program is not only making a difference to our communities, but also changing the stigma surrounding mental health illnesses. So many suffer in silence for fear of prejudices and discrimination; however, with better education on the causes, effects, and treatments comes increased understanding to ensure no one has to bear the burden alone. We have made essential steps in the right direction over the past several years, but more must be done.
￼
 
ICYMI: United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement:
Last week, the United States, Mexico, and Canada announced that an agreement has been reached to update the North American Free Trade Agreement. News of an agreement is welcomed as NAFTA has been an overwhelming success for Kansas’s economy and especially for Kansas agriculture. As Congress and the public analyze the full agreement text, I look forward to fully reviewing the details and hearing from farm, ranch, and working families across my district about their thoughts on the agreement.
 
Celebrating Our Navy’s 243rd Birthday:
Happy Birthday to the United States Navy! October 13th marks the birth of our country’s Navy 243 years ago. Our deepest gratitude to all the brave individuals serving, their families, and all who have served since the earliest days of the Navy’s existence.
￼

Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you. 
Sincerely, ￼ 
Warren Davidson Member of Congress 


￼ 
Butler, Clark, and More
Congressman Warren Davidson has been working in Ohio as congress is not in session. 
On Monday, Davidson visited the Niederman Family Farm in Butler County. As an agribusiness, the farm has benefited greatly from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. 
On Tuesday, Davidson visited Brian Harbage on his farm in Clark County. Davidson said on his Facebook page the two spoke about several issues including trade and tariffs. They also discussed healthcare challenges for small businesses, and the various benefits small businesses are reaping from tax reform.
On Thursday, Davidson met with NFL Hall of Fame Inductee Anthony Munoz at Eaton’s annual Harvest Festival. He then stopped at The Almond Sisters Bakery in Hamilton before traveling to the Butler County Township Association’s Annual Banquet. 
On Friday, Davidson toured the new Ohio Eagle Distributing facility in West Chester. The company said the new facility is to become the center of their business in the area. Later in the day Davidson was invited to speak at a destination ceremony for a new housing facility in Hamilton.
￼ 
￼
National Farmers Day
As National Farmers Day was Friday, Davidson thanked farmers on his Facebook page and remarked that everyone benefits from the hard work farmers do. There are several provisions in Tax Reform that directly benefit farmers. You can learn more about these benefits here.

Subject: Working for PA-10
Message:

￼
￼
ABOUT
CONTACT
ISSUES
MEDIA CENTER
SERVICES
￼
October 14, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
This week, The U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Risk Management Agency (RMA) announced a new insurance plan that protects dairy producers from unexpected declines in quarterly milk sales.
￼
Expanding Resources for American Dairy Producers
Dairy Revenue Protection provides insurance for the difference between the final revenue guarantee and actual milk revenue if prices fall. This plan offers coverage levels from 70%-95% of revenue. Dairy Revenue Protection is another tool available to dairy producers to mitigate risks associated with a changing market and strengthen the rural economy. DRP is offered in all counties nationwide. Sign-up for Dairy Revenue Protection today; first available coverage will start in the first quarter of 2019.
For more information about Dairy Revenue Protection, click here.
Disaster Assistance Available to PA Residents 
Residents of Susquehanna and Wayne Counties who were affected by severe storms and flooding on August 13-14, 2018 are eligible to apply for low-interest disaster loans from the U.S. Small Business Administration. Loans up to $200,000 for homeowners and $2 million for businesses are available to repair or replace damaged real estate. These loans are a step in the right direction to ensure Pennsylvanians recovering from recent flooding can get back on track.
Applicants may apply online using the Electronic Loan Application at DisasterLoan.sba.gov or call 1-800-659-2955. The Filing deadline to return applications for physical property damage is December 10, 2018. The deadline to return economic injury applications is July 9, 2019.
Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River Awarded Grant 
I’m pleased to announce that Upper Delaware Scenic and Recreational River was awarded an Open Outdoors for Kids grant from the National Park Foundation.
￼
These funds will connect 1,330 students with the parks Delaware and Hudson Canal Days, which teaches participants about life on the canal in the 1800s through living history programs. Thanks to these efforts, more young people will have the opportunity to learn in our national parks this school year.
Celebrating National Farmers Day 
Every year on October 12th, we have an opportunity to thank those that work in acres, not hours.
￼
Agriculture and agribusiness have a profound impact on the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and particularly on the 10th congressional district in Pennsylvania. Total economic impacts from agriculture gross over 135.7 billion and employ 579,000 Pennsylvanians. With 63,000 family farms currently in operation across the Commonwealth, any agricultural legislation is of the utmost importance to me. Thank you, Pennsylvania farmers, for everything you do.
Social Security Announces 2.8% Benefit Increase for 2019
More than 67 million Americans will benefit from a 2.8% increase in Social Security and Supplemental Security Income benefits in 2019. The 2.8% cost-of-living-adjustment (COLA) will begin January 2019. Additional adjustments, based on the increase in average wages, will increase the maximum amount of earnings subject to the Social Security tax to $132,900 from $128,400. Social Security and SSI beneficiaries can expect to be notified in early December regarding their new benefit amount.
Pennsylvania State Flaming Foliage Festival 
Each year in early fall, Pennsylvanians attend the Flaming Foliage Festival to celebrate nature’s beautiful colors and views. On Saturday, I stopped by to see the festival’s renowned parade, recognized as the largest parade in central Pennsylvania, and the crowning of the Flaming Foliage Queen. The festival featured an impressive food and craft show, featuring more than 100 vendors. What an opportunity to take in the fall beauty of PA. Thank you for having me!
As Always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA
￼Share on Facebook
￼Share on Twitter
￼Share on LinkedIn
E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.*
￼ 
*By subscribing to my  e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e-mail account. 


 
 
Thank you for subscribing to my eNewsletter and please remember to forward this to your friends!  This is a great way for me to communicate directly with you about what's going on in Washington, as well as providing you with exciting news from Pennsylvania's 10th District.  My Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube accounts are also excellent tools for you to share your thoughts with me and get up-to-the-minute news about what's happening.
As always, my staff and I are ready and willing to assist you.  If you would like to schedule a meeting, request a tour or flag, voice an opinion, or make a suggestion please contact my Washington, D.C. office.
If you need assistance working with a federal agency or applying for a grant please contact one of my Constituent Service Centers, located throughout the district.
I am here to serve you and represent your views, as a resident of Pennsylvania's 10th Congressional District.

NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend,  This week, the Second District was devastated by Hurricane Michael. Many of our friends and family in the counties that were hit by the hurricane have lost everything. We continue to pray for all those who lost loved ones and those who haven't yet made contact with their loved ones.   If you are still attempting to contact a loved one, please consider filling out this online form created by the Florida Department of Heath.   If you would like to volunteer your efforts the Red Cross and Volunteer Florida have an abundance of resources to help our neighbors. At this time, I urge you to heed the warnings of local emergency workers and law enforcement as rescue and recovery efforts continue. The Florida Department of Emergency Management is working around the clock with local first responders, law enforcement, the Florida National Guard, and various military entities to keep us safe.   On October 10, 2018, President Trump issued a major disaster declaration for the State of Florida, ordering federal aid to supplement state and local recovery efforts to areas affected by Hurricane Michael. This Major Disaster Declaration triggers the release of federal funds to help people and communities in the wake of Hurricane Michael.  All individuals and businesses who were impacted by Hurricane Michael should apply for FEMA assistance. Please call 1-800-621-3362 or visit http://www.DisasterAssistance.gov to apply. Individual assistance does not have an income limitation.  Over the coming days, weeks, and months more information about aid for storm recovery will become available. If you have any questions about applying for aid please contact my office at 202-225-5235. We are here to help.  If my office can be of any assistance as we begin recovery efforts please do not hesitate to contact us at 202-225-5235 or at www.dunn.house.gov.   Sincerely, ￼  Neal Dunn Member of Congress

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
October 14, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


Celebrating Pastor Brunson's Release



For over two years we have called for the release of Pastor Andrew Brunson. Today, our prayers were answered and Pastor Brunson can finally be reunited with his family. Pastor Brunson, who is originally from Black Mountain, North Carolina, was imprisoned in Turkey on October 7, 2016. On March 13, 2018, Pastor Brunson was issued an indictment filled with bogus charges relating to terrorism and espionage. Click here or on the image below for my full statement on Pastor Brunson’s release. 

￼

In May, a bipartisan group of my colleagues in the House and I sent a letter denouncing the wrongful imprisonment of Pastor Brunson. You can read the letter by clicking here. I also called for the release of Pastor Brunson in a June speech on the House Floor, which you can click here. On Saturday, I was honored by President Trump's invitation to join him and Pastor Brunson in the Oval Office to celebrate his return home. You can watch Saturday's meeting by clicking here or on the image below.

￼





Firefighters Grant Workshop



On Wednesday, my office held it's annual FEMA Assistance to Firefighters Grant Program workshop for Tenth District fire and rescue departments on the campus of Gaston College in Dallas. It was a great turnout and special thanks to Cherryville Fire Chief Jeff Cash and Assistant Chief Jason Wofford for serving as instructors for the class. 

￼

In the Tenth District, fire and rescue departments use these grants to help them better serve their communities. A great is example is the Linconlton Fire Department, a recent recipient of a grant, which is planning on using the funding awarded to hire additional full-time firefighters. Click here to learn more about the Lincolnton Fire Department courtesy of the Lincoln Times News.





Did You Know?



The House of Representatives has been very productive. While you may have heard about historic legislation like the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the important steps the House has taken to combat the opioid epidemic, and the well-deserved pay raise we voted on for our troops, the House of Representatives has done much more. Since January of 2017, the House has been working hard on the issues that matter in the Tenth District and all across the country. Click here to learn more about some of the 245 bills that are now law.

￼





What I Have Been Reading



'I don't have anything left': Hurricane Michael survivors scramble for food, water as death toll rises

USA Today 

This week our nation was once again hit by a deadly storm that left devastation in its wake.We are thankful for all of the emergency responders and their tireless work to save lives. Giulia and I are praying for all of those impacted by Hurricane Michael and Hurricane Florence as communities all across the southeast begin to rebuild.  


The Navy turns 243 today- check out these incredible photos of the Navy in action
 
Business Insider 

On October 13, 1775 the Continental Congress established what became today’s United States Navy. Please join me in honoring the service of the brave men and women of the U.S. Navy who have defended our freedoms for the last 243 years. 


Gastonia police go pink for breast cancer awareness

Gaston Gazette 

The month of October is breast cancer awareness month. This month we honor and remember all of the mothers, daughters, sisters, and friends who have suffered from this terrible disease. The Gastonia Police Department is doing its part to raise awareness by wearing pink badges on their uniforms. It is inspiring to see our law enforcement officers, who keep our communities safe every day, go above and beyond for their neighbors in Gaston County.

￼

Subject: Resources following Hurricane Michael
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend,  
This past week, the strongest storm to ever hit the Florida panhandle also ripped its way through Georgia, with damaging winds, rainfall, and flooding. As we assess the damage of the storm, my offices will continue to remain in close communication with federal, state, and local officials to ensure Georgia has what it needs to recover.
I am very glad to report that on Thursday President Trump declared a federal state of emergency in Georgia for counties impacted by the storm. The designation authorizes the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to coordinate disaster relief efforts and provide equipment and resources to impacted counties.
President Trump’s declaration came after the entire Georgia Congressional Delegation sent a bipartisan, bicameral letter to the White House requesting federal expedited assistance to impacted counties. I was proud to lead this effort among my colleagues, and I will continue working to ensure Georgians have the tools they need to get back on their feet following this catastrophic storm. Click here to read more on our letter to President Trump. 
For information on each county’s specific State of Emergency County Contacts, and other helpful state resources, please visit the Georgia Emergency Management & Homeland Security Agency website here: http://www.gema.ga.gov/.  
There is certainly a long way to go in clean-up and rebuilding, but I am confident that we have the right leadership in Georgia to get the job done.
  
BREAST CANCER AWARENESS MONTH 
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, a time to increase awareness of the disease which impacts 1 in 8 women in the United States. 
The most commonly diagnosed cancer in women and the second-leading cause of cancer death among women, breast cancer affects all of us – not just women – which is why it is so important we continue to fund cancer research and support those women in our lives who are impacted by this disease.
￼ 
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month 
  
HAPPY 243RD BIRTHDAY TO THE UNITED STATES NAVY 
On October 13, 1775, a resolution of the Continental Congress established what is now the United States Navy. Today, the U.S. Navy remains the world’s most elite naval force.  
I want to wish a happy 243rd to the U.S. Navy and thank all our U.S. Navy Veterans for their service to our great country. 
￼
Happy Birthday, U.S. Navy. 
  
HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Have they forgotten?
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends,
 
As a father, one of the most important things I can teach my son is to treat others the way he wants to be treated. That’s the Golden Rule. We should all work to set this example for America’s children.
 
That’s one reason why I am so encouraged when I hear of a politician, celebrity or professional athlete using their platform for the greater good. Take our new Carolina Panthers owner, David Tepper. After Hurricane Florence, he, Luke Kuechly, Cam Newton and nearly 80 staff members and players spent their time packing relief boxes for families.
 
In stark contrast, it’s why I am so disappointed every time I hear of someone using their platform to provoke violence or incivility. Just last week, former Attorney General Eric Holder said of Republicans, “When they go low, we kick ‘em. That’s what this new Democratic Party is about.” That’s the exact opposite of loving thy neighbor. And in a televised interview, Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said you “cannot be civil” with members of the Republican Party.
 
What has happened to political discourse in our country? The hatred and anger – sometimes expressed behind a keyboard – and the inability to listen to and respect someone with a different opinion has sadly become the new normal. Have they forgotten last year’s terrible attack at a baseball field in Virginia by a deranged shooter who was targeting Republicans? 
 
Inciting violence and stoking anger is irresponsible. Period.
 
As people of different political parties, we can disagree without being disagreeable. It’s no secret that I don’t see eye-to-eye with my Democrat colleagues on every issue from time to time. But that doesn’t mean I can’t work with them to get things done.
 
Since my first days in office, I’ve worked hard to build relationships and navigate disagreements to find common ground. I will always stick to my conservative principles, but I am willing to work across the aisle and fight for you and your priorities.That’s exactly how I began my first term when I had several pieces of bipartisan legislation signed by President Barack Obama and what I continue to do today.
 
I’m the 12th most conservative member of the House, but I’ve had tremendous success in bringing people together around bipartisan solutions to improve job-training programs, to combat the opioid epidemic, to improve care for our veterans, and to support our military. And I’m proud to have several Democrats support my Concealed Carry Reciprocity bill. I was able to get their support because I’m upfront and strive to have open and thoughtful discussions. And I listen. 
 
It’s like my grandfather always told me, “You have two ears and one mouth for a reason.”
 
As your Congressman, I continue to work with President Trump – a Republican – and Governor Cooper – a Democrat – on Hurricane Florence recovery. And just last week, my bipartisan energy bill with Congresswoman Diana DeGette – a Democrat from Colorado – passed the Senate and is now on the way to becoming law. I believe there is plenty of room for common sense, bipartisan solutions like this.
 
￼
I joined Governor Cooper in Hoke County last week to discuss Hurricane Florence recovery efforts. 
 
At the end of the day, I understand people are frustrated with Washington. That’s exactly why I first ran for Congress. I was fed up because our government wasn’t listening to us and progress was jammed because of partisanship. I continue to hear your concerns and I will not stop fighting until you have a federal government that works for you.
 
 
Until next week,
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress (NC-08)

Subject: Here For You
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
Remembering Sergeant Carraway
 
 
Wrenzie and I attended Sergeant Terrence Carraway's funeral this week. He touched the lives of everyone he met and our community is truly a better place because of his service- both in and out of uniform. Our community is shaken from this loss, but we’ve shown incredible strength and unity in the face of this tragedy. The entire Florence Police Department and their families remain in our prayers. 

Read More »
 

 
Neighbor Helping Neighbor
 
 
Last week, Wrenzie and I met some amazing folks at Sweet Home Baptist Church in Longs. They have been collecting and donating supplies, serving hot meals, and housing people in need. Our team went back to the church this week to donate supplies and see how they were doing. Despite some of the volunteers having lost everything in the storm themselves, they are dedicated to making sure their neighbors are fed, have a place to sleep that night, and have the resources to recover. We were so glad to be able to contribute! 

Read More » 
 

￼

￼
 
 
On the Ground 
 
 
Senator Lindsey Graham and HUD Deputy Secretary Pam Patenaude were on the ground this week to survey damage from Hurricane Florence. We visited homes in Socastee and Marion to hear directly from residents about issues they are dealing with throughout the recovery process. We also met with local leaders to discuss the best path forward, specifically how we can apply the lessons we have learned from Hurricane Matthew to ensure we can help as many people as possible, as efficiently as possible. The support from President Trump and coordination between the Administration, Congress, and local officials will guarantee a strong recovery for South Carolina. 

Read More »
 

￼

￼
 
 
Thank a Farmer
 
 
Thursday was National Farmers Day, and South Carolina has the best farmers around. Many Seventh District farmers were impacted by Hurricane Florence, but we are working together to ensure our agricultural community has the necessary resources to fully recover from this storm. I am so grateful for their hard work, which allows us to put food on our tables and clothes on our back. In the Seventh District we thank our farmers everyday!
 

Have a great week,
￼
 Tom Rice

Subject: Border Walls and a Busy Week in TX-36
Message:
Babin Bulletin | October 14, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Babin Applauds Kavanaugh Confirmation, Condemns 'Win-At-All-Costs Tactics'

With Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation secured, this embarrassing chapter in the history of the Senate can finally conclude. The shameful political theater Americans witnessed in disgust was never about determining the truth but designed to block this nomination by any means necessary – no matter how salacious or unprecedented. The longstanding process for vetting a nominee openly and in good faith was so flagrantly violated that the public's faith in our government institutions may be forever damaged.

I applaud my Texas colleagues Senator Ted Cruz and Senator John Cornyn for their leadership in fairly evaluating and ultimately voting in favor of this supremely qualified nominee. Unfortunately, this process previewed the new playbook of win-at-all-costs tactics by radical elements whose desire for absolute political power over their countrymen would lead them to willfully destroy the foundational principles so many Americans cherish. The events of recent weeks make clear that the stakes remain high in the ongoing fight to preserve our liberties.

I wish Justice Kavanaugh a long career on the Supreme Court. I have complete confidence he will conduct himself with the integrity, sense of fairness, and respect for our Republic's sacred heritage of law and order that was so glaringly and unconscionably abandoned during his confirmation process.

To read my full press release, click here.
Update at the Wall
￼
I spent Thursday morning with agents of the U.S. Customs and Border Patrol in San Diego, CA as we looked at the different prototypes of President Trump's proposed wall. Securing our borders is perhaps the most important necessity facing our nation today. We have to protect our citizens and control our borders in order to maintain national sovereignty. It was great to be able to see the progress and hear stories from the brave men and women guarding our border. 

If you would like to see more, please visit my Facebook page where I posted a live video.
Small Business Roundtables
Small businesses are pillars of communities throughout our nation, so I was happy to meet this week with several small business owners in Warren and Hardin to discuss issues concerning them, including the need to reduce and eliminate overburdensome government regulations as well as how tax reform legislation passed this year benefits small businesses and their employees. Thank you to Brandy and Cory Winkler for hosting us at the Bar-B-Q Pit in Warren. Other participants included Cory Owens, owner of East Tex Paint & Body, Judy Lewis with Triple D Ranch, Valerie Middleton with Flowershop, and Shawn Ryals with R Texas Star Grooming & Boarding.
￼
Also, a huge thank you to the Hardin County Volunteer Fire Department for hosting as well as all of our participants which included Anthony Dagle with Southeast Texas Farm & Ranch in Raywood, Randy Brazil with Southeast Texas Olive in Devers, Connie Campbell with Maci Feed & Supply in Hardin, Patti Atkins with Oilfield Welding and Fabrication in Hull, Keisha Robinson with First Liberty National Bank in Hardin, Klint Bush with Bayview Home Health and Commissioner of Liberty County ESD 7 (fire station), and Grant Stoesser with G.S. Farm Company in Liberty. 
￼

Hull-Daisetta Site Visit
After Hurricane Harvey, Hull-Daisetta (H-D) Elementary School was completely flooded and all of its contents were declared a total loss. 

H-D Elementary has not had classes on this campus since August of 2017, but thankfully the reconstructed building is expected to be ready in December. Thanks to Superintendent Mary Huckabay and Principal Quinn Godwin (pictured below) for showing me around their soon-to-be new school!
￼

￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
Breitbart Interview
I joined Matthew Boyle on Breitbart Radio to discuss my disgust for the radical tactics we saw employed during the Kavanaugh confirmation process. 
￼
To read and listen click here.
Welcome Home SSG Phillip Blackmon
 Every year since September 11, 2001, RE/MAX Realty partners with the Texas Sentinels Foundation to build a house for a veteran who was severely injured in the line of duty. This year, U. S. Army SSG Phillip Blackmon has been named the recipient of a new home. 

SSG Blackmon was an Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Specialist who holds the record for successfully diffusing more than 150,000 tons of unexploded ordnance during combat missions in Iraq over a four year span. In 2006, an improvised explosive device (IED) detonated three feet away from SSG Blackmon's vehicle causing him and others multiple injuries.
￼
I am proud that Lanie Brown, Regional Director of Community Relations on my staff, was able to present SSG Blackmon with a flag flown over the U.S. Capitol and thank him for his willingness to answer the call and defend our nation's freedom.
Visiting with Chambers County Rice Farmers
I had the privilege of meeting with our local rice farmers in Winnie on Saturday where we discussed many important provisions in the Farm Bill. America thrives off of family farms, and it is crucial that we pursue policies to help them succeed. I will continue working hard to fight for our Texas farmers.
￼


Touring the RoyOMartin OSB Manufacturing Plant 
 The RoyOMartin Oriented Strand Board (OSB) manufacturing plant located in Corrigan provides many great jobs and opportunities to the region. I was able to tour the site on Tuesday with the plant’s Vice President, Terry Secrest, and was very impressed with the production by their hard-working employees. I’m looking forward to seeing the impact the plant's operation has for the community and Texas.
￼
 Friday Night Football Coin-Toss
 There is nothing like Texas football! The Woodville Eagles earned a tough win over the Warren Warriors last Friday night. Both teams played hard, and I was honored to flip the coin at the beginning of the game.
￼
Calling All Interns
I am looking for new interns to work in my Washington, D.C. office in the Spring of 2019. Students must be enrolled in an accredited college and have at least one semester under their belt. 

Washington will be a busy and exciting time in the Spring! My staff and I are excited to show a new group of students the fast-paced world of Capitol Hill. 

If you or someone you know are interested, review our application here.

Subject: Fighting Opioids
Message:
￼ 

Home
About Ken
About Our District
News
Contact

                                        
Weekly Newsletter  
Dear Friend, 
A quick housekeeping note. The Congressional App Challenge registration deadline is October 15th. Any student in the 4th Congressional District can design their own software application and compete in this challenge. Please register soon if you're planning to participate! 
I wanted to take this chance during district work period to offer a recap of our recent efforts to combat the opioid crisis in this country.  
One American dies from opioid overdose every 12.5 minutes. In 2015, Colorado experienced 159 heroin overdose deaths. This epidemic is ravaging our nation.  
House Republicans have passed dozens of bills to address this issue. For a good sense of what we've been working on, you can visit this link: https://www.opioidcrisis.gop/. 
Last month, I introduced legislation to enhance data sharing between wholesalers of opioids, as well as between wholesalers and law enforcement. Those companies that sell opioids to pharmacies have a responsibility to watch out for suspicious orders. My legislation works to centralize order information so that wholesalers can better track problematic orders.  
I'm thankful that this legislation was included in the bipartisan, bicameral opioid package that passed Congress and was signed by the President.  
I also worked this year to expose the way that sanctuary cities are harboring illegal immigrants who traffic heroin. Nick Rogers, the President of the Denver Police Protective Association and a long-time detective on the streets of Denver, testified before the Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Immigration and Border Security to explain how these policies prevent federal law enforcement from working with Denver police officers to apprehend certain illegal immigrants who assist in heroin trafficking. Denver is already a hub for heroin trafficking, and these policies only make the matter worse.  
In the following video, I question Robert Patterson, acting administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, about the connection between sanctuary city policies and the opioid crisis: 
￼
￼
If we want to win this battle against opioid and heroin addiction, we must attack it from all angles. The legislation passed over the past year will hopefully be a strong counter-offensive against this evil substance, saving lives and families across our nation.  
Keep an eye on my website for more upcoming events. And as always, for more frequent updates on legislation and events, please follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. I look forward to hearing from you; please do not hesitate to contact my Greeley, Castle Rock, or Washington office should you need any assistance. If you'd like to send me a message, you can do so on my website. 
Sincerely, 
￼
Member of Congress
