Subject: Walker Weekly Report: October 14, 2018
Message:
￼
Walker Weekly Report
Kelly and I are praying for all of those still being impacted by the Hurricane Michael storm that came through our community on Thursday. Many of you, like me, are probably one of the around 200,000 North Carolinians who still remain without power. We have been in contact with Duke Energy and I know their brave lineman and utility workers are laboring around the clock to get everyone’s power back up.
Our thoughts are also with the many school children across our state who have been out of school and will likely remain out for the first part of next week.
The destruction in the Florida Panhandle is devastating. As North Carolinians, we understand what it means to rebuild and overcome. The combining of federal, state and nonprofits working together brings hope to suffering communities. Please join me in keeping these dear people in our thoughts and prayers.
Even in the darkness, there is light. We are elated that North Carolina pastor Andrew Brunson has returned home from two years in captivity in Turkey. This week, President Trump also signed an important healthcare bill into law, and we remembered the fantastic life and legacy of one of our district’s oldest and greatest heroes.
Keep reading for the full update. Have a blessed week.  Sincerely, ￼ Mark Walker
￼
HIGHLIGHTS
￼
We're Bringing North Carolina Pastor Andrew Brunson Home
Every American should be proud that we are finally bringing North Carolina pastor Andrew Brunson home. His release on Friday, after a two-year unjust imprisonment, was only possible through millions of prayers and the concerted efforts of President Trump, Vice President Pence, Secretary Pompeo and members of Congress. This needs to be the end point for the many acts of aggression and human rights violations for Turkey and President Erdogan.
I am also grateful for the recognition President Trump gave to our efforts in getting Pastor Brunson home.   In July, we introduced the Turkey International Financial Institutions Act, legislation that would direct U.S. representatives at international financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank to oppose loans to Turkey, pending the release of Brunson and all U.S. citizens and consular staff. We were also part of a bi-partisan effort sending a letter to President Erdogan demanding Brunson's release.
Brunson, the pastor of Izmir Diriliş (Resurrection) Church in Izmir, Turkey, was detained on October 7, 2016 on charges of "support of a terrorist organization" and "political or military espionage." Brunson was transferred on July 25, 2018 from jail to house arrest while awaiting the next hearing on his case.
According to the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF), "Pastor Brunson initially was held in a cell with 21 other inmates that was built to hold only eight prisoners. He spends 24 hours a day in his cell, leaving for one hour weekly for visits."
Learn More
￼
Remembering Dr. Victory Tynes – A True Hero of Our Community and Our Nation
This week, I was deeply saddened by the loss of one of my oldest and greatest constituents and friends. I will never forget having the honor to present Dr. Victor Tynes with an American Flag flown in honor of his 102nd birthday. During the visit, we talked about his amazing life and his love of music, when we broke out singing Christmas Carols. He was an extraordinary man who lived an extraordinary life.
Dr. Tynes was a talented musician, an accomplished dentist, a devoted public servant, a WWII veteran and alumnus emeritus at North Carolina A&T State University. He was even chosen by the Pentagon to assist with the integration of Fort Bragg, serving as one of the first African-American officers. Thank you for your steadfast service to our community and our nation, Dr. Tynes. You will be missed.
Please keep his family in your prayers – from his children all they way down to his great great grandchildren.
Learn More
￼
President Trump Signs the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act into Law, Prohibiting Pharmacy Gag Clauses
This week, President Trump signed another important piece of legislation into law. The Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act will help keep North Carolina seniors and families from unnecessarily paying more for medications and offer more choice and transparency, ending gag clauses that prevent pharmacists from telling patients about less expensive prescription options.
“Our great citizens deserve to know the lowest prices available at our pharmacies and now that is what they are getting,” Trump said at the White House.
This legislation is part of our commitment to reduce prescription drug costs for North Carolinians and provide more transparency and choice.
Learn More
 
￼
FEATURED VIDEO
￼
Joining Fox News to Discuss the Release of North Carolina Pastor Andrew Brunson
 
￼
MORE GOOD NEWS ABOUT TAX REFORM
￼
CNBC: "Most Economists 'Never Thought the Economy Could Grow This Fast'"
President Donald Trump's corporate tax cut and his business deregulation efforts are not just an economic "sugar high," former Federal Reserve governor Kevin Warsh argued on CNBC Thursday.
Most economists "never thought the economy could grow this fast," said Warsh, who had been on the president's short-list for Fed chairman before Jerome Powell was chosen.
The government's final reading of second-quarter gross domestic product showed an advance of 4.2 percent on an annualized basis. The Atlanta Fed's GDPNow real-time indicator put the third quarter gain at 4.1 percent, as of Monday.
Taken all together with the first quarter's 2.2 percent increase, the economy stands to grow at an average of 3.5 percent for the first nine months of 2018.
That would be above Trump's goal of economic growth 3 percent-plus. The president has used GDP numbers and the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which closed at another record high Wednesday, as yardsticks of success for his policies.
"Today the economy is the strongest it's been since it's been in the U.S. since 2004" when growth was 3.8 percent, Warsh said on "Squawk Box." "At the end of this year, we may be saying the economy is the strongest since 1999," when growth hit 4.7 percent, he added.

Subject: Dave's Weekly Wrap
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT DAVE | ISSUES | TOURS & FLAGS | STUDENT CENTER | SERVICES | CONTACT
Friends,
I hope you all had a great week. I certainly enjoyed traveling around the district meeting with you all! 
Health Care Update
Our country is stronger when we work together to address the issues we face. These bipartisan health care victories are vital to countless folks in Northeast Ohio and across the nation. 
￼
I believe health insurance coverage should not discriminate against those with pre-existing conditions, which can affect any individual, regardless of race, gender, age, social class, or creed. I support protections in the law for individuals with pre-existing conditions. 
I also believe people should have all the cost information when purchasing prescription drugs, which is why I am glad to share the President signed S. 2554 and S. 2553 into law this week. These measures eliminate the use of "gag" clauses that prevent pharmacies from alerting customers if the retail cost of the drug is less than the co-payment they would be paying for buying the medication with insurance. Before my colleagues and I took action, many pharmacists couldn't legally tell their customers whether drugs were cheaper when paying out-of-pocket. This common sense action will help rein in drug costs for families in Northeast Ohio. 
Forged by the Sea
￼
Yesterday, the United States Navy celebrated its 243rd birthday! On October 13, 1775, the Continental Congress authorized the purchase of two vessels to be armed and used against British merchant ships, thereby creating the Continental Navy. This is considered to be the first establishment of the U.S. Navy. 
In honor of the U.S. Navy's birthday, I am pleased to share that my colleagues and I recently passed the bill to fund the Department of Defense. I strongly supported this legislation, which gives our service members a much deserved 2.6% pay raise, the largest increase in 9 years. This measure also includes provisions to rebuild our military by increasing funding for our military readiness programs to ensure our troops are prepared for their missions. 
I'd like to take the time to thank all of our brave servicemen and women for serving our country in all five of our armed services branches. We are forever thankful for your service to our great nation. 
Maplewood Elementary - 2018 National Blue Ribbon School 
Congrats to Maplewood Elementary School for being recognized as a National Blue Ribbon School for the 3rd time! This is a true testament to the hard work and dedication of the students, teachers, and staff. 
￼
I was honored to address the school assembly to present a congressional proclamation and an American flag that was flown in their honor over the U.S. Capitol. Keep up the great work!
￼
￼
Chagrin Documentary Film Festival 
I was honored to attend the 9th Annual Chagrin Documentary Film Festival to present the award for Best International Documentary to Director Leon Lee for "Letter from Masanjia."
It was a weekend full of inspiration with talented filmmakers from all over the world showcasing their work and I was glad to be a part of it. Thank you for inviting me!
￼
￼
Business Appreciation Mixer 
Thanks to Lyndhurst Mayor Patrick Ward and Heights-Hillcrest Regional Chamber of Commerce for inviting me to your Business Appreciation Mixer. It was a great opportunity to meet with and hear from community leaders, city officials, and business owners in the district. 
￼
Akron Cleveland Association of Realtors 
I had a great discussion with the Akron Cleveland Association of Realtors about common sense legislation my colleagues and I recently passed, including tax reform and a comprehensive package to combat the opioid epidemic. Thank you for all the hard work you do to keep Northeast Ohio a great place to live and raise a family!
￼
￼
Emergency Nurses Week
This week was Emergency Nurses Week. As the husband of a nurse and the co-chair of the Congressional Nursing Caucus, I want to recognize and thank emergency nurses for your tireless work to save lives. Your dedication does not go unnoticed. Thank you!
￼
Dave

Subject: Prosecute Predators
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window
 Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative John Ratcliffe 
￼ 

WEBSITE
SERVICES
CONTACT
FACEBOOK
INSTAGRAM



￼ 
Hi Friends,  
  
I’m happy to report that dozens of child predators have been prosecuted on the state and federal level in Northeast Texas since my Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act was signed into law by President Trump last year. 
  
My law enables law enforcement officers in our home communities to receive training at the National Computer Forensics Institute (NCFI). This ensures they know what digital evidence to look for and how to find it, so we can prosecute those who commit sickening crimes against the most vulnerable in our society.
  
￼ 
  
Ratcliffe tours the National Computer Forensics Institute in Hoover, Ala. 
  
In a recent meeting with my staff, Chief Investigator Corley Weatherford of Hopkins County Sheriff’s Office discussed how his NCFI training has helped him solve child exploitation crimes in coordination with the North Texas Internet Crimes Against Children (ICAC) Task Force. 
  
Thanks to his NCFI education on computer forensics and mobile device examination, Chief Investigator Weatherford has successfully worked on dozens of child exploitation cases that may have otherwise gone unsolved. This included the conviction of a Cumby school teacher with 100 child victims, and a conviction in a Sulphur Springs case involving a local pastor for child pornography.  
  
As a former U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Texas, the horrific child exploitation crimes I prosecuted still haunt me. They’re what spurred me to prioritize legislative efforts in Congress that focus on protecting children, and I won’t give up on this important fight.
  
Sincerely, 
￼  John Ratcliffe U.S. Representative for Texas’ Fourth District

News from Congresswoman Claudia Tenney
￼

Home
About District
News

Tenney Commends Madison County’s Action Against Non-Dairy Products Labeled as Milk
Dairy farmers are the backbone of our rural communities and economy.On Wednesday, I commended the actions of the Madison County Board of Supervisors in response to the resolution passed to address the mislabeling of non-dairy “milk.” Currently, Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations define dairy products as being from dairy animals. However, the FDA has not enforced this regulation and the liquid extracted from grains, seeds, beans or leaves of various plants are being processed and marketed as milk.
Traveling across the district, I’ve listened to the problems facing our farmers and I’ve taken their concerns with me to Washington. Mislabeled imitation dairy including soy and almond milk greatly hurt our dairy farmers, and I am glad Madison County has worked to address this issue. In Congress, I cosponsored the DAIRY PRIDE Act and helped pass into law legislation that directs the FDA to take action against mislabeled imitation dairy foods. I was pleased to see that FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb announced plans to begin this process soon. 
In Congress, I have been a fierce advocate for our dairy farmers. I led the charge against the negative impact of the Canadian Class 7 milk pricing scheme which was eliminated as part of the new United States, Mexico, Canada Agreement (USMCA). I co-sponsored the School Milk Nutrition Act which allows schools to offer low-fat (1%) milk to students rather than just fat-free as well as the WHOLE MILK Act, which would allow schools to offer whole milk as an option to students.  
Tenney Announces Grant Funding for Cybersecurity Projects 
FuzeHub and Stony Brook Univeristy (AIM's partner Manufacturing Extension Partnership center) set aside $200,000 in funding to help NYS manufacturers reduce their cybersecurity risks. NYS manufacturers now have access to these funds through AIM. Each eligible manufacturer may receive up to a maximum of $3,000 for cybersecurity-related projects. 
Funds are offered on a first-come, first-serve basis, and are extremely limited.  
Please contact AIM as soon as possible to avoid missing out on this funding opportunity. For more information, or to apply, call AIM Cybersecurity Coordinator Paul LaPorte today at (315) 624-9800, or email him at plaporte@mvcc.edu. 
Assistance With Grants and Letters of Support 
Whether you’re a fire department in need of new equipment or a community organization looking to grow, our office can assist you in navigating the federal grant process. By working with the Congressional Research Service, we can help find grants that may be appropriate for your needs. In many cases, we may even be able to furnish you with a letter of support. To find out how we can assist you in the grant process, contact our New Hartford District Office at 315-732-0713. 
￼ 
  
 
In the District & D.C.
  
￼ 
￼
  
Firefighters from across our community traveled to Albany to honor the life and legacy of Merle Nell, a Fire Police Captain and former Chief of the Vernon Fire Department.
Family, friends and fellow firefighters watched as Merle’s name was inscribed on the New York State Fallen Firefighters Memorial. 
Merle passed away in November, 2016 while on the scene of a fire in Vernon Center. His name is now etched on a wall with 2,551 other fallen firefighters from our great state who gave their lives in the line of duty. 
Affectionally known as “Skippy” to his family and friends, Merle’s legacy of service lives on through his sons and grandsons. Merle’s sons, Scott and Mark, serve as fire chiefs in Vernon and Verona, and his grandsons Adam and Matthew are active firefighters in Vernon and Zachary is a junior firefighter in Verona. 
A marine, father, postal worker and firefighter, Merle’s life of service was a true inspiration. His memory will live on in the hearts of our grateful community.

The Bost Bulletin  
Friend: 
It's been a very productive constituent work session in Southern Illinois this week, highlighted by meetings with constituents to hear firsthand their comments and concerns. My travels included visits with the Mascoutah Fire Department and Federally Employed Women, as well as a tour of the Continental Tire plant in Mount Vernon. Here's some of what we've been up to.

City Hall Board Meeting 
￼ 
I had the pleasure of meeting with Marissa mayor Chad Easton and other board members to discuss local issues facing Marissa. As a former local official myself, I understand the vital role local leaders play in shaping their communities. It is truly where the rubber meets the road.

Touring Continental Tire 
￼ 
And speaking of rubber meeting the road, I enjoyed a return trip to the Continental Tire facility in Mount Vernon. This local job creator plays an important role in strengthening Southern Illinois' economy.

Hearing From Mascoutah Firefighters 
￼ 
As a former Southern Illinois firefighter, I always welcome the opportunity to reconnect with my first responder brothers and sisters. I had the pleasure of dropping in on the Mascoutah Fire Department at their weekly meeting to thank them for what they do. I know how tough it is as I used to be in their shoes, and we owe our gratitude to these fine men and women risking their lives to keep us safe.

Visiting With Federally Employed Women (FEW) 
￼ 
I had the opportunity to hear from members of Federally Employed Women (FEW), an advocacy group working to improve the status of women employed by the federal government. 

Awarding Our Heroes 
￼ 
I had the honor of meeting with and awarding John Matheny's WWII medals to his son, Charles. John made the greatest sacrifice for his country and I know this recognition means a lot to his family. 

That's just some of the work I've been up to as I crisscross our 12 counties during the early weeks of October. I hope you have a great week ahead! 
Mike

Subject: Updates from the U.S. Senate
Message:
￼  


Friends,  Confirming Justice Kavanaugh and passing comprehensive legislation to address our nation’s infrastructure needs are two of the Republican-led Senate’s latest efforts to help the American people, and I look forward to continuing to deliver even more wins for West Virginians.   Click here or the image below for more details on this week’s accomplishments, and keep scrolling for additional updates from this week.
  
￼ 
  
Investing in West Virginia’s Economy 
I’ve always said that economic growth starts at the local level, which is why it’s important we continue working to revitalize and support our small communities in West Virginia. That’s why, for years, I’ve worked directly with the Department of Commerce to encourage a renewed focus and drive investment in West Virginia: to help spur economic development and boost our economy.   Earlier this week, I joined Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross in announcing that the department’s Economic Development Administration (EDA) has decided to—once again—invest in our state. $6.7 million in grants to be exact. These grants will support local business development and job growth efforts all across West Virginia. Not only are they expected to lead to more than a thousand new jobs for West Virginians looking for work now, but they will also lead to significant private investment that will benefit the region’s economy over the long term. Learn more about the individual awards here. 
Improving West Virginia’s Water Infrastructure 
Strengthening and improving America’s infrastructure is something we can all agree on, especially because of the enormous benefits that safe and reliable infrastructure provides. On Wednesday, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to pass a comprehensive water infrastructure bill that will cut red tape, grow the economy, and encourage fiscal responsibility. Better yet, as a member of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, I was able to ensure my provisions to benefit West Virginia communities were included in the bill. These provisions include measures that will grow and improve our water workforce and provide our communities better access to reliable wastewater systems. Combined with the many other legislative solutions in this bill, they will benefit Americans living in every single state, and I look forward to President Trump signing it into law. Click here for more details. 
Visiting the Eastern Panhandle 
On Friday, I hit the road and made a few stops in the Eastern Panhandle where I met with community leaders, students, educators, and small business owners. I spent the day discussing how Congress is working to help our veterans, combat the opioid epidemic, and improve our infrastructure. I also helped rally students at Martinsburg High School ahead of the school’s homecoming game, which was an exciting experience! Here are a few photo highlights from the day:
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
Calling All Students! 
Last month, I held a series of Academy Day events throughout the state, where my staff and I had the chance to meet with many impressive young West Virginians interested in attending a U.S. service academy. As your senator, one of my most important responsibilities is nominating young men and women for admission to these academies. The deadline to apply for a nomination is coming up tomorrow. 
More details about the process and the application for applying for a nomination from my office can be found on my website here. Check it out today, share with your friends, and be sure to apply before the deadline this Monday, October 15. 
  
￼ 
Senator Capito visits with academy nominees for the class of 2021 during a reception in May 2017. 
  
How Can We Help? 
Whether you need help with a casework issue or have a question about scheduling a meeting at one of my offices, my staff and I are ready to assist you. Learn more about the services we offer at www.capito.senate.gov.  
You can also submit your feedback and share your stories with me by visiting my “Share Your Stories” webpage here: www.capito.senate.gov/ShareYourStories. 
Some Good Reads 
The past couple of weeks have been busy and filled with a lot of exciting things for West Virginia. Check out a few local and national articles highlighting the good work we are doing in Congress, as well as some other fun reads that shine a positive light on our great state:
	•	Charleston Gazette-Mail: “National Park Status for New River Could Begin with Simple Name Change”
	•	The Herald-Dispatch: “Bipartisan Opioid Legislation Heads to President’s Desk” 
	•	WV News: “Senate Advances Kavanaugh Nomination With 51-49 Vote” 
	•	Bluefield Daily Telegraph: “Protecting Children” (Editorial) 
	•	The New York Times: “West Virginia’s Small-Town Revival”  
  
Social Media Recap 
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
￼ 
  
Join me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram for regular updates and photos. 
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Shelley Moore Capito United States Senator

Subject: Latest from Lamar: President Trump signed into law the most important legislation in a generation to help Tennessee songwriters
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
President Trump signed into law the most important legislation in a generation to help Tennessee songwriters
￼
Watch the above video of my remarks at the signing ceremony here. 
This week, I joined President Trump at the White House as he signed the Music Modernization Act -- a bill I led through Congress that will be the most important legislation in a generation to help songwriters. This is really big news for Tennesseans -- from Beale Street in Memphis, through Music City, all the way to the birthplace of country music in Bristol. We have thousands of songwriters -- taxi drivers, music teachers -- struggling to make a living, and in the Internet age, sometimes they aren’t paid for their songs, and when they are paid, they're not paid a fair market value. The Music Modernization Act is the most important law in a generation to help make sure that our songwriters in Tennessee -- and songwriters all over America -- can keep working and make a decent living by making sure they're paid when their songs are played, and making sure that they're paid a fair market value for their work. Our success is the result of most parts of the music industry -- songwriters, publishers, digital music companies and broadcasters -- working together on what they agree on instead of fighting over what they disagree about. It has taken us several years to get to this point, and I’m glad this very important legislation is now law.
I published an op-ed on this in the Tennessean this week. Give it a read here! 
 
￼
It was an honor standing next to President Trump to watch him sign this historic legislation for songwriters in our state.
 
Republican Congress Getting Results for Tennesseans:
	•	Senate Republicans blocked a Democrat effort this week that would take away from millions of Americans the option to buy more affordable health insurance.
	•	President Trump has nominated and Senate Republicans have confirmed a historic number of federal judges since the president’s inauguration. These include Justice Gorsuch, Justice Kavanaugh, 29 Circuit Court Judges, and 53 District Court Judges -- including Tennesseans Mark Norris and Eli Richardson who were confirmed this week.
Congress Extends the Freedom to Fish Act which Stops the Federal Government from Restricting Fishing Below Dams 
	•	The U.S. Senate passed a bill that is a big victory for Tennessee’s fishermen -- it extended the Freedom to Fish Act for five more years. Generations of fishermen have been fishing below the dams on the Cumberland River ever since they have been built, and this legislation ensures Tennesseans continue to have the freedom to decide for themselves when it is safe to fish rather than wasting taxpayer dollars to unnecessarily close off important fishing areas. The bill now heads to President Trump’s desk to become law.
 
Bill to help keep Chickamauga Lock construction on schedule heads to president
This week, the Senate passed the America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018, which will ensure construction of Chickamauga Lock can stay on schedule in the coming years. This legislation is one way the federal government can help improve water infrastructure, which helps protect jobs and industry in Tennessee by keeping commerce flowing on our nation’s rivers. Separately, this year, the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee I chair also worked hard to provide record funding for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to ensure we could keep federal lock and dam projects funded for the fifth consecutive year -- including the construction of Chickamauga Lock. I look forward to President Trump signing this legislation into law.
 
Tennesseans Mark Norris and Eli Richardson confirmed to serve as U.S. District Court Judges
This week, the Senate confirmed Tennessee Senate Majority Leader Mark Norris to serve as a U.S. District Judge for the Western District of Tennessee, and Eli Richardson to serve as a U.S. District Judge for the Middle District of Tennessee. I strongly supported Senator Norris and Eli Richardson’s nominations. Senator Norris is respected by his peers around the country, having been elected chairman of the Council of State Governments, and he has been an advocate and a champion for federalism and for the separation of powers. He is a citizen, a lawyer and a legislator. I have known him for many years -- since I was the governor of Tennessee -- and I am glad the Senate voted to confirm him. 
Eli Richardson will also be a strong asset to the federal bench. His professional experience -- as a litigator, FBI special agent and federal prosecutor in the Middle District of Tennessee, where he was appointed the office’s Criminal Chief -- make him uniquely qualified for this position. Tennessee is fortunate to have such a well-qualified nominee who is willing to serve, and I’m glad the Senate confirmed his nomination because it will help bring relief to a crowded docket.
 
Joined Tusculum University to inaugurate their new president, and celebrate their 225th homecoming celebration
￼
I enjoyed my time at Tusculum University yesterday, where I got to participate the inauguration of their new president, Dr. James Hurley. Dr. Hurley has a lot to offer this university -- he knows the territory, has a passion for education and basketball, was the first in his family to graduate from college and became president of that college, and we already know he thinks big. Big dreams include new programs to help the region deal with the opioid epidemic, transitioning from a college to a university and announcing a new College of Optometry. I also got to celebrate Tusculum’s 225th homecoming. Let’s look at Tusculum’s roots. Tusculum was founded two years before Tennessee became a state. There were a lot of Presbyterian pioneers and fighters who came to the area, including Rankin relatives of mine -- William B. Rankin, who became president of Tusculum College in 1854, and Thomas Samuel Rankin, who was a professor at Tusculum from 1885 when he graduated until 1931. These pioneers created the first higher education institution in Tennessee. This homecoming was a good reminder that Tusculum has plenty that is unique to celebrate, and it now has the arrival of an experienced, big thinking, new president who dreams of building on the success Tusculum has already had.
 
￼
 
 
 
I enjoyed having lunch with my interns this week. I always appreciate getting to know more about the folks interning in the Washington office. 
 
 
 
Stopping Senate Democrats from blocking 1.7 million uninsured Americans from buying more affordable health insurance 
￼
I spoke about this on the Senate floor, you can watch here. 
This week, Senate Republicans voted down a Democrat attempt to strip millions of Americans of an option to buy more affordable health insurance. This form of insurance, called short-term limited duration health plans, gives consumers a chance to buy insurance that might be 70% cheaper than plans on the Obamacare exchange. If you lost your job and couldn't afford insurance during the Obama years or if Obamacare plans got too expensive during the Obama years, you could buy short-term insurance for up to a year if your state allowed it. This week’s action means Democrats are saying, “We're not going to do what President Obama would do. We're going to keep your insurance high today with a yes vote. We're going to say to 1.7 million people that you can't buy insurance because we know more than you do.” I hope that across this country, as Americans look at this today you would ask Democrats: “Why do you want to kill a rule that President Obama favored that existed all during Obamacare while he was there, that gave people who might lose their jobs or couldn't afford Obamacare a chance to buy insurance that might be 70% cheaper? Why would you want to keep 1.7 million Americans who won't have insurance in 2019, according to the Urban Institute, from being able to buy these short-term plans?”
 
New law will allow pharmacists to help patients pay less for prescriptions
￼
This week, I went to the White House to join President Trump as he signed the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act, legislation that was passed by the Senate health committee I chair. This bill will ban “gag” clauses that prevent pharmacists from helping patients pay less for their prescriptions. If you walk into a pharmacy and ask for the prescription your doctor has written for an antibiotic, you might have a copay of $40 under your insurance plan, but if you pay with cash, it could only be $5. I hear often from Tennesseans that they struggle to afford their prescriptions. This new law, led by Senator Collins of Maine, takes a simple step to allow a pharmacist to tell a patient about the option to potentially pay less for prescription drugs so they can keep more of their money in their own pockets. 
 
￼
 
I enjoyed meeting with Knoxville Mayor Madeleine Rogero and Mayor Steve Williams of Huntington, West Virginia. We discussed the opioid legislation that I helped pass out of the Senate last week, which will help their communities fight the opioid epidemic. 
 
 
 
Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:

Tennessean: Lamar Alexander: Brett Kavanaugh went through 'inquisition' arranged by Democrats
Newsmax: Lamar Alexander: Public Confidence Shaken by Kavanaugh 'Inquisition' 
Tennessean: Gov. Bill Haslam, U.S. Sen. Lamar Alexander hail opening of new Tennessee State Museum
 
Listen to the Farm Bureau.

Subject: Saving $$ on Rx – Lowering Prescription Drug Costs!
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     SERVICES    |     ISSUES    |     LEGISLATION    |     MEDIA    |     CONTACT 
Saving $$ on Rx - Lowering Prescription Drug Costs!
Dear Friend:
As always, I appreciate you letting me bring you this brief update. It is an honor representing you!  This past Wednesday, the President signed into law two important bipartisan consumer bills, which I supported. The two bills, S. 2553, ‘Know the Lowest Price Act of 2018’, and S. 2554, the ‘Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act’ will lift what many local pharmacists describe as a ‘gag clause’ that prevented them from informing their customers how to lower their out of pocket costs when getting their prescriptions filled.   S. 2553, “Know the Lowest Price Act of 2018” amends title XVIII of the Social Security Act to prohibit Medicare Part D plans from giving complete information regarding the prices of specific drugs to Medicare beneficiaries. S. 2554, the “Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act” will end that practice and make the information publicly available. In some instances, for example, it can actually cost less to pay out of pocket for a prescription than it would to have it run through their health insurance policy yet pharmacists, prior to the passage of this legislation, were not allowed to give that information to consumers.  Consumers deserve the right to make fully informed decisions and withholding information regarding the cost of their prescription drugs is simply wrong. Th bills passed the House of Representatives on a unanimous vote and the Senate on a 98-2 vote.  
￼
 Rep. Mike Coffman met with Selena, manager of Gem Pharmacy in
Littleton, CO, following the passage of S. 2553 and S.2554
Another example what we can do for the good of our country when we work together in Congress was the final passage of H.R. 6, the ‘SUPPORT for Patients of Communities Act.’ This landmark legislation is the latest effort to combat the opioid crisis and it follows up on the passage of the ‘Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act’ and the ‘21st Century Cures Act’ last Congress. H.R. 6 includes key language to set up the programs to spend the $4 billion appropriated in fiscal year 2018 to help combat the opioid crisis, as well as the $6 billion included in the recent Defense-Labor-HHS appropriations package to boost programs that fight, treat, and stop substance abuse and provide better access to mental health services. Taken together, this package represents the most significant congressional effort against a single drug crisis in history.   I am also very pleased that H.R. 6, the “SUPPORT for Patients of Communities Act” included legislation, H.R. 4635, the ‘Peer-2-Peer Counseling Act,’ that I introduced in the House Veterans Affairs Committee earlier this year. H.R. The ‘Peer-2-Peer Counseling Act,’ will ensure the Veterans’ Administration’s (VA) existing peer-to-peer counseling program will be expanded to increase the number of female peer counselors to better serve the increasing numbers of female veterans. As our female veteran population continues to increase because women are approaching 20% of the active duty force, the VA will have to adjust the way it operates to accommodate when they leave active duty and become eligible for VA services.  The VA’s 2016 suicide data report found that “the risk of suicide was 2.4 times higher among female veterans when compared with civilian adult females,” so we clearly need to improve the quality and availability of counseling services for them. As a Marine Corps combat veteran and a member of the House Veteran Affairs Committee, making sure that our veterans receive the services they need has always been a priority for me.   Finally, I wanted to remind you that if you need help with a federal agency, my office is here to help. If you have a question personal regarding social security, Medicare/Medicaid or immigration, please contact our Aurora office at 720-748-7514, and one of our casework managers will assist you. I also invite you to visit my website or follow me on Facebook or Twitter to get the most up-to-date news as they happen.
Sincerely, 
￼
Mike Coffman
U.S. Representative

Subject: Weekly Update: Long Deserved Recognition
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
CONTACT
Weekly Update: Long Deserved Recognition  By Congressman Rob Wittman  October 14, 2018  Let me set the scene: crystal clear sky, fresh cut green grass, the calm waters of the York River, and a sense of accomplishment.   Last week, I had the honor of joining Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke at Werowocomoco to celebrate the long overdue federal recognition of the Chickahominy, Eastern Chickahominy, Monacan, Nansemond, Rappahannock, and Upper Mattaponi tribes. Earlier this year, the president signed my bill granting federal recognition to these Virginia Indian tribes into law, and I was proud to stand with them to celebrate this achievement.  
￼

We started the ceremony with a blessing of the ground by Chief Anne Richardson of the Rappahannock Indian Tribe. As I stood there with these tribes, who hold so much of our nation’s heritage, I couldn’t help but think how blessed we are. We sometimes lamented and said, ‘Is this ever going to happen. Through faith, through dedication, through working together, we accomplished what seemed impossible.  

￼
The effort in Congress to gain federal recognition for these six tribes dates back nearly 20 years to when Congressman Jim Moran first introduced the Thomasina E. Jordan Indian Tribes of Virginia Federal Recognition Act in 2000. Though these tribes had received official recognition from the Commonwealth of Virginia, they faced barriers preventing them from receiving federal recognition.  
￼
The tribes lacked formal treaties with the U.S. Government because they made peace with England well before the establishment of the United States. Additionally, due to the Racial Integrity Act of 1924, much of the tribes’ birth records, marriage certificates, and land titles were destroyed. The lack of these documents prevented the tribes from providing the necessary evidence to gain recognition through the Bureau of Indian Affairs federal recognition process.  Despite these obstacles, the tribes pushed forward. Committing themselves to working with Congress to get federal recognition through the legislative process. After decades, we have taken the critical last step in correcting the failure to recognize the ‘first contact’ tribes of the Commonwealth of Virginia.  
￼
This all started with a strong woman, Thomasina E. Jordan, who this legislation is named after. Now, the work of generations has finally come to fruition. I am humbled to have played a role in securing this moment decades in the making for our Virginia tribes. I will forever consider this one of my major achievements as a legislator. 
￼

Subject: Tired of winning? Neither am I.
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Sunday, October 14, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
Tired of winning? Neither am I.
 
 
When President Trump was blazing the campaign trail he promised the American people that we would win. He won in 2016 and is still winning today. Under President Trump's leadership, we've continued winning by putting America first and enacting policies that help get Americans off the sidelines and into the game. 

Over the last year or two, we've seen what winning looks like - a change of pace from the Obama Administration. Our economy is booming and unemployment levels are dropping their lowest level in nearly 50 years. These numbers did not appear out of thin air. They are a result of pro-growth and pro-American policies supported by Republicans in Congress and President Trump, such as tax reform. When our economy is winning, Americans win. 

A winning economy
· Lowest unemployment rate since 1969 – 3.7%
· Since President Trump took office, we’ve added more than 3.8 million jobs 
· Averaging 208,000 added jobs per month in 2018
· Average hourly earnings rose by 2.8% over the last 12 months
Tired of winning? Neither am I.

Winning the Supreme Court
President Trump has had the opportunity to appoint two very qualified conservative Judges to our Supreme Court. A monumental decision that will impact our country for years to come. I firmly supported both of President Trump's nominees, Justice Brett Kavanaugh and Justice Neil Gorsuch. Not confirming these men would have been a huge loss for Americans and would paved the way for further obstruction and destruction of our country by Democrats. We must continue placing conservative leaders in positions that will use the Constitution as a guide instead of a suggested reading. It was a hard fought battle, but President Trump and Republicans once again came out victorious.

Our military is winning
Through sequestration and other defense spending reductions, our military was hurting. President Trump made a promise to rebuild and strengthen our military - and we've done just that. A few months ago, we worked together to pass the National Defense Authorization Act making it the earliest passed NDAA in 41 years. To follow on the heels of the FY19 NDAA, we successfully passed the defense funding bill that will provide the necessary funding for our Armed Forces to have the tools they need to do their jobs. 

We are committed to making life better for all Americans.

Academy Day 2018
We had a great turn out at last Saturday's Academy Day. Students were able to talk with leaders from the academies and also hear from Mississippians who are currently enrolled or have graduated from an academy. 

￼

Students were able to hear from midshipman Lauren Green of the Merchant Marine Academy who is a senior this year and a native of Ocean Springs.

￼

They also had the opportunity to hear from LTJG Shelby Henderson, USCG Commanding Officer located in Gulfport. 

￼

I'd like to thank all who attended this year's Academy Day as well as the leaders from the U.S. Service Academies who were there to share more about their schools. 

In your service,
￼
Steven

Subject: No Place for Violence in Politics
Message:
￼ 
Website  |   About  |   Contact Me  |   Serving You  |   Media Center  |   Legislative Work  |   Our District  |   Resources 
  

October 14, 2018
THE SCALISE CAPITOL REPORT
My prayers are with the people of Florida and other impacted states as they begin the recovery process from the devastation of Hurricane Michael. In South Louisiana, we are no strangers to storms like this, and my office is already helping my colleagues in Florida during their time of need so people can rebuild and get back in their homes as quickly as possible.   There is no place for violence in politics. There have been too many reports of threats, harassment, and violence taking place against others simply because of their political affiliation or views. Despite these reports, we have continued to see Democrat leaders in Washington work to keep this anger burning and incite even more harassment and violence. I refuse to stand by silently, and I will continue to call for an end to this new wave of political bullying and even criminal activity. A healthy, strong democracy is not possible if anyone lives in fear of expressing their views. That might be how tyrannical dictators do things in third world countries, but that is not who we are in America. If this is going to stop, it must start with Democrat leaders, who need to condemn, rather than promote these dangerous calls to violence.  I wrote a column about this on FoxNews.com, which you can read here. I also joined Fox & Friends to drive home how important it is that we return to civility for the sake of our democracy. Click here or below to watch. 
￼
Touring the National Finance Center with Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue Earlier this week, I was pleased to host U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue in Southeast Louisiana. During his visit, we toured the National Finance Center (NFC) in New Orleans, an accounting hub for the U.S. government that manages the payroll for over 700,000 federal employees. The NFC, which employs nearly 1,000 people in our area, is managed by USDA and overseen by Secretary Perdue. Unfortunately, the building was severely damaged by a tornado in early 2017, but thanks to the dedication and hard work of the Louisianans who work there, the National Finance Center has never failed to fulfill its role in keeping our government running properly. During our visit, Sec. Perdue and I discussed how we can do even more to improve the center's operations and rebuild after the devastating tornado that destroyed their building.
￼ Secretary Perdue and I meet and talk with the dedicated employees at NFC.  
￼
Louisiana Agriculture Commissioner Mike Strain, Drago's owner Tommy Cvitanovich and I watch as Sec. Perdue charbroils some Louisiana oysters for lunch. 
 It is an honor to represent you in Congress. For more information please visit my website, Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook pages.   God Bless,
￼

Steve Scalise
House Majority Whip

Subject: praying for our neighbors
Message:
News from Representative Gus Bilirakis
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼
￼ 
￼
￼

 
October 14, 2018
Dear Friend,  
My thoughts and prayers are with all of our neighbors in the panhandle and beyond who have been in the destructive path of Hurricane Michael.  Please be assured we will ensure those communities have all of the federal support needed to facilitate recovery.  This most recent natural disaster is an ever-present reminder of the urgent need for the Senate to take action on the reauthorization of the National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP). All Floridians need continued access to affordable flood insurance, and the House passed our bill a year ago. I urge my Senate colleagues to take this issue up immediately. 
Last week was quite busy.  I enjoyed the opportunity to meet with many constituents and to attend events throughout our community.  However, I was saddened to learn about the passing of Carl Orth, a long-time reporter with the Suncoast News. It was truly a pleasure to work with Carl. His reporting was always thorough and fair. He made such a unique impact on our community by ensuring that his readers stayed up-to-date on current events in West Pasco. May his memory be eternal!
Please continue reading for an update of my work on your behalf last week! 
Meeting with Community Leaders and Surveying Community Needs 
As I travelled throughout the district last week, I talked with business owners and residents being impacted by flooding. Down by the sponge docks, the flooding was once again pretty bad. Much like I did in Holiday and other parts of Pasco County, I am working to secure federal funding to help address this problem in Tarpon Springs.   
￼ 
It was also great to have the opportunity to participate in the Downtown Avalon Park West groundbreaking ceremony in Central Pasco last week. This will be a great addition to our community. 
￼ 
I really enjoyed visiting the Pasco Housing Authority to learn more about the Family Self Sufficiency Program. This amazing program is transforming lives by giving participants the opportunity to improve their vocational skills, financial literacy and credit. Many graduates of the program have been able to leave public housing and purchase their own homes. I also appreciated the chance to talk with the dedicated employees who are on the front lines working with families to help facilitate this change. 
￼ 
Additionally, I enjoyed meeting with the leaders of Habitat for Humanity of Pinellas to learn more about the great work they are doing in our community! 
￼ 
Protecting our Seniors 
I understand how important increases in the Cost of Living Adjustments (COLA) within the Social Security program are to seniors living on a fixed income. So I was pleased at last week’s announcement of a 2.8% COLA increase, which is substantially higher than recent years.  Additionally, I know that many of my constituents saw last year’s COLA absorbed by increases in Medicare premiums. Fortunately, this year’s Medicare Part B base premium only increased by $1.50 this year, so most seniors shouldn’t face the same issue again this year.  However, I am actively working on legislation to fix this problem for the future, because I know how many seniors rely on their COLA to cover rising costs. 
As part of my effort to provide greater transparency in healthcare and to reduce the cost of Prescription Drugs, I was pleased to vote in favor of S. 2554, The Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act, which ensures health insurers cannot prohibit pharmacists from informing a patient about the lowest available price for a drug. For example, pharmacists should be able to alert patients when it is cheaper to pay cash for a medication than it is to pay a copayment. Additionally, S. 2553, Know the Lowest Price Act, ensures this same access to information for Medicare and Medicare Advantage participants. Both bills were just signed into law last week. There is no one simple solution to lowering the price of prescription drugs, but we are taking an aggressive approach and passing multiple measures that are part of the solution, including my bill to create more competition when none exists and my efforts to streamline approval for combination products. We have already seen my work help to lower costs on medications like the EpiPen, and last week’s new laws will help even more. 
It was also great to speak with my constituents at Heritage Park Health and Rehabilitation Center in Dade City last week. We discussed Medicare, Social Security and my efforts to reduce the cost of prescription drugs. 
￼
Fighting for our Heroes 
With more than 54,000 Veterans calling Pasco home, our community has outgrown the current VA West Pasco Outpatient Clinic. Veterans in our community deserve access to the best possible care, which is why I have fought tirelessly for a larger, state-of-the-art facility which will better meet the needs of our local heroes. This article highlights my efforts. This new facility will bring added convenience for Veterans. I look forward to celebrating its grand opening. 
Thank you for reading this week’s update. Feel free to share this e-newsletter with friends and encourage them to sign up! Remember, you can always stay in touch with me via email, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Gus Bilirakis

Subject: "Gag Clause" Provisions Outlawed
Message:
￼ 
  

"GAG CLAUSE" PROVISIONS OUTLAWED

This week, I joined President Trump as he signed my proposal to ban "gag clause" provisions into law. 

￼
Rep. Carter joins President Trump at the White House for the signing ceremony of legislation to ban "gag clause" provisions

In case you missed it, Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs) were able to include requirements in contracts that prevented pharmacists from providing advice to their patients on the best and cheapest out-of-pocket alternatives to medications covered under insurance. This is commonly known as a "gag clause." As a result, you could be paying more for your prescription than you need to. 

Now, this is outlawed and pharmacists will be able to tell you about the best and cheapest options available. 

It was an honor to join President Trump as he signed this important legislation making it law. Click here to view the signing ceremony. 

Now, I am committed to continuing this work with my colleagues in Congress and President Trump to lower prescription drug prices and health care costs for all Americans. 

FROM OUR NATION'S CAPITOL CLXXXIII

Monday, October 8, 2018:  This past weekend was a busy one as on Saturday morning I joined in the 13th annual Buddy Walk at Forsyth Park in downtown Savannah.  This great event is sponsored by the Lowcountry Down Syndrome Society (LDSS), a family support group that benefits people with Down syndrome and their families in eight surrounding counties in the Savannah area.  This is a very special group to me as I grew up with an Aunt who had Down syndrome.  Along with my good friend Joe Marchese and his beautiful daughter Emma, I walked part of the route with the thousands of people supporting this great cause.  Later in the afternoon, I traveled down to Kingsland in Camden County where I met with constituents from the surrounding area.  Yesterday, I flew from Savannah to Atlanta where I was honored to speak at the American Academy of Otolaryngology - Head and Neck Surgery (AA0-HNSF) annual meeting.  After being introduced by my good friend, Dr. Michael Zoller from Savannah, I was able to bring the group up to date on the latest health care news in Washington and then enjoyed answering questions.  Afterwards, I flew back to Jacksonville and stopped in Brunswick on my way home to Pooler for a meeting with constituents.  This morning I’m honored to be at the 4th Annual Folds of Honor Stars and Stripes Golf Tournament held at the Savannah Country Club on Wilmington Island.  The mission of the Folds of Honor is to provide educational scholarships to spouses and children of America’s fallen and disabled service members.
￼
Rep. Carter playing in the Folds of Honor Stars & Stripes Golf Tournament
This year’s event is chaired by Col. David Simons of Savannah and the special guest is Ginger Ravella whose husband, an F16 pilot, was killed in a combat mission in 2006 leaving her with five children, all under the age of 8 at the time.  All of Ginger’s children are receiving scholarships for school provided by the Folds of Honor.  Later in the afternoon, I head to Skidaway Island for a meeting with constituents before heading to Tybee Island for another meeting with constituents about important issues to them.  
Tuesday, October 9, 2018:  For the fifth year in a row, I’m at Richmond Hill Montessori Preschool in Bryan County to read to students in celebration of Georgia Pre-K week.  This year I get to read the classic Click Clack Moo: Cows That Type to four classes and participate in an activity where we make cow masks out of paper plates. 
￼
Rep. Carter reading to Richmond Hill Montessori Preschool 
Afterwards, I head to downtown Savannah where I attend the inaugural State of the Airport address given by Savannah Airport Commission executive director Greg Kelly as he outlines the growth of the airport throughout the years as well as future expansion. 
￼
Rep. Carter at the State of the Airport Address 
I am very proud that our office was successful this year in helping the commission secure an $8 million grant to fund a terminal apron expansion.  Later in the day, I head back down to Richmond Hill to meet with a group of students from Richmond Hill High School.
Wednesday, October 10, 2018:  I’m on a plane to Washington bright and early this morning and, once back in my office on Capitol Hill, I have the opportunity to catch up on some paperwork as well as meet with my policy team to review their work over the past few weeks.  While I’m away from Washington my legislative staff takes meetings with different groups visiting the Capitol and keeps me informed of their work.  Early in the afternoon, I head to the White House where the President has invited me to a bill signing ceremony in the Roosevelt Room.  The two bills being signed are companion bills to my legislation, the Know the Cost Act, that eliminates the “gag clause” provisions in health plans that prevent pharmacists from providing advice to their patients on the best and cheapest out-of-pocket alternatives to medications covered under insurance.  
￼
Rep. Carter at the White House signing ceremony of legislation to ban "gag clause" provisions 
As the only pharmacist currently serving in Congress, I know firsthand how important it is for pharmacists to help patients access the lowest cost options and that is why I took the lead on this legislation.  A link to the C-SPAN coverage of the bill signing ceremony can be found here. Afterwards, I head back to the airport for my return flight home.  
Thursday, October 11, 2018:  Thankfully, most of our district was spared from the ravages of Hurricane Michael that hit the Florida panhandle yesterday.  While our thoughts and prayers go out to those who were impacted by this devastating storm, we are glad that we were spared and also glad that our emergency management leaders did such an outstanding job preparing us for the worst.  Because of the bad weather, most of our events in the district for today and tomorrow have been canceled but I start my morning with a radio interview with my good friends Bill Edwards and Laura Anderson with WTKS in Savannah as we discuss my trip to the White House yesterday when the President signed my “gag clause” legislation into law. Later in the day, I have television interviews with Savannah stations WJCL, WSAV and WTOC before having a phone interview with the Savannah Morning News to discuss my “gag clause” legislation. A link to the WSAV interview can be found here.

Subject: Reviving Air Travel in Nebraska
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: October 13, 2018 
￼  I recently had a great meeting with the Scottsbluff Gering Chamber of Commerce to learn more about the exciting prospects for growth in Nebraska's panhandle.  
   Reviving Air Travel in Nebraska 
On October 5th, President Trump signed into law the 2018 Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act to update and authorize its activities for another five years. This is important to Nebraska’s Third District because it contained a policy change whose specific aim is to support and revive commercial air service to our rural communities.   Air travel volume at smaller airports in rural areas such as the Third District declined in recent years due in part to increased government regulations. One major cause occurred in 2013 when the FAA changed its requirement for first officers, or co-pilots, to certify 1,500 hours of flight time instead of 250 hours, which was previously the norm.   Under the previous regulation, junior pilots were able to earn a wage while training on the job with experienced pilots. This change, while well-intentioned from a safety standpoint, created a shortage of co-pilots which was cited as the main reason behind the bankruptcy of two airlines which previously served Third District airports.   The domino effect continued as air traffic declined and in turn threatened these airports’ access to federal funding should they fall below 10,000 enplanements per year, which is the threshold for full funding under the Airport Improvement Program. This program provides funding for capital and safety improvements to buildings, runways, control towers, and fueling infrastructure.  A small decline in enplanements could snowball into a much larger issue affecting the competitiveness of our airports by allowing them to fall into disrepair if deprived of such a vital source of funding. In order to stop this chain reaction, I wrote and introduced the Small Airport Regulation Relief Act in 2014, which was enacted into law in 2016 and again in 2018 as part of the FAA reauthorization I mentioned above.   Its purpose is to provide relief to these airports by exempting them from the 10,000 enplanement minimum and allowing continued access to federal funding as the pilot labor market expands to fill the void created by increased regulation by the FAA. In meetings with pilots and airline representatives, I have been told that changes to the structure of pilot training programs will help to provide additional pilots moving forward.   Should this not materialize, I am ready and willing to consider additional regulatory relief to deliver a full recovery at Third District airports. Declining demand is not a fact of life at our rural airports as recently announced direct service to Las Vegas from Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island has shown us. Commercial air service is vital to maintaining a vibrant rural economy and it will remain among my highest priorities as I serve as your representative in Congress.    E15 Year-Round 
The year-round availability of higher ethanol blends such as E15 is a simple, common sense measure which I have long championed for its benefits to producers, refiners, and consumers across America. In addition to introducing legislation requiring the EPA to allow the sale of E15 throughout the year, I have sent multiple letters and consulted administration officials on numerous occasions to this end. President Trump has long stated his support for renewable fuels, and I appreciate him following through on his commitment this week.  
As always, feel free to forward my e-newsletter to family and friends, or let them know they can sign up to receive updates from my office on my website at AdrianSmith.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  ADRIAN SMITH Member of Congress 
  If you would like to respond to this email, please click here.   ￼  ￼

Subject: Cruz News: October 13, 2018
Message:
￼
 
 
October 13, 2018
Greetings,
For far too long, Social Security has been wrongly tied to Medicare Part A enrollment. On Tuesday, I introduced the Retirement Freedom Act with Rep. Gary Palmer (R-Ala.) to address this problem. This bill would empower America’s senior citizens by allowing them to utilize private health insurance without losing their Social Security benefits. Seniors should be able to choose a health insurance plan that fits their needs, without the fear of losing their Social Security benefits, and I am hopeful my colleagues in Congress will act swiftly to create more healthcare options for seniors.
Across the Lone Star State, Texans are thrilled with the historic tax cuts, the job-killing federal regulations we’ve rolled back, and the strong, constitutionalist judges we’ve confirmed to the federal bench. However, there is still more Congress can do to deliver on the promises we made to the American people. This week, I had the pleasure of meeting with job creators and city officials from Killeen, Conroe, and El Paso. We discussed the military’s expansion in Texas, making the tax cuts permanent, reducing the burden of federal regulations, and reforming healthcare, among other issues. On Wednesday, I penned a letter with Sen. John Cornyn and Rep. Louie Gohmert in support of the City of Lufkin’s request for a foreign trade zone (FTZ) which, if established, will incentivize further investment in the city and create more good paying jobs and opportunity for Texans. Jobs and economic growth continue to be my top priority in the Senate, because they are the top priority of Texans. Additionally, I sent a letter with Senator Cornyn and Rep. Jodey Arrington to the Secretary of the Air Force inviting her to visit Dyess Air Force Base.
On Thursday, I penned an op-ed with Rep. Kevin Brady in the Dallas Morning News. We highlighted our bipartisan Equal Treatment of Public Servants Act, which would repeal the current Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) and replace it with a fairer formula. For decades, our teachers, firefighters, police officers, and other public servants have been subjected to an unfair, one-size-fits-all approach to calculating their earned Social Security benefits. I am hopeful Congress will act swiftly to replace this formula, and ensure our public servants are treated fairly as the accomplished individuals they are, receiving Social Security in line with their work history.
Texas benefited from a number of policies aimed at strengthening our port infrastructure and mitigating against future hurricane damage this week. On Wednesday, I voted for the bipartisan America’s Water Infrastructure Act, which includes projects that will begin to help shield a number of our Gulf Coast cities from the impacts of hurricanes and storm surges, and increase economic growth in several of our port communities. I take seriously my responsibility to work with Texas port communities, Gulf Coast city officials, and job creators to ensure they have the resources needed to remain a strong economic engine for our state and our country. I was also pleased the Department of Commerce announced this week its intention to allocate $10 million in grants to the state of Texas to enhance critical port infrastructure to support business development and disaster resiliency. According to grantee estimates, the projects combined are expected to create and retain nearly 16,000 jobs and spur almost $46 million in private investment. The ports of Port Arthur and Beaumont are making strides down the road to recovery.
Our prayers are with those Americans in the path of Hurricane Michael, and we continue to lift up those Americans recovering from Hurricane Florence. Both of these recent hurricanes are a stark reminder of the importance of taking all steps necessary to prepare our homes and families for any future weather event. For those seeking preparedness information and resources, please refer to the federal and state resources listed here.
Please read below for an update from this last week.
Keep Texas Strong,
￼ Ted Cruz
￼
Sens. Cruz and John Cornyn (R-Texas) announced that they are accepting applications for a judicial vacancy in the Southern District of Texas, Houston Division. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz introduced the Retirement Freedom Act, which would empower senior citizens and create more healthcare options by allowing them to utilize private health insurance without losing their Social Security benefits. Read more...

Subject: News from Georgia's Sixth District
Message:

A message from Georgia's 6th Congressional District
￼

Home
About District 6
How Can I Help?
Issues
Newsroom
Contact


 
October 13, 2018
Gold in East Cobb 
A special congratulations to Seline Nie, who lives in Marietta, for being named one of ten honorees to receive the Girl Scouts' 2018 National Gold Award. Seline was selected for being an inspiring young leader who takes a plan and puts it in to action. Seline's project focused on engaging girls in STEM education. Seline hosted 17 workshops and seminars worldwide to help grow girls' interest in science and technology. Way to go, Seline!

Social security benefits increase
For the first time in seven years, seniors will see their social security benefits increase. Benefits will increase 2.8% increase in 2019 — which translates into an additional $40 per month. The tax cuts are fueling more federal revenues and fostering greater stability for Social Security.
Click here to read more from the Wall Street Journal. 

Tax cuts continue to help families
Five ways the tax cuts are helping families and small businesses in Georgia's 6th District: 
	1.	The standard deduction has doubled - more of what you earn is tax free
	2.	Wages are rising, the largest in over nine years
	3.	 About 90% of families of all income levels are seeing a greater increase in take-home pay
	4.	The Child Tax Credit has doubled
	5.	 Businesses are expanding sick leave benefits for families

Friends in our prayers 
We are thinking of our friends dealing with the destruction of Hurricane Michael. In Southwest Georgia, many were left without power, roads were blocked, and Georgia's crops and livestock were deeply affected. Sadly, we lost a young person to this hurricane’s wrath. Our prayers continue.

￼ 
Meeting with the Windward Association of Retired Men on Monday 

Thank you for taking the time to read this note. To stay current on what's going on in Congress, please follow me on Facebook by clicking here or visiting Facebook.com/RepKarenHandel. If you find this update helpful, please take a second to forward it along to a few of your friends and neighbors.  
In addition, because of rules from the House of Representatives, I will not be able to conduct live tele-town halls after August 8th through Election Day. As always, feel free to call (202) 225-4501 or (770) 998-0049 if you need assistance from me or anyone in my office.

Sincerely, ￼  Karen C. Handel Member of Congress

Subject: Delivering Results for Texans
Message:
THE LONESTAR WEEKLY
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
ABOUT
FOR TEXANS
ISSUES
NEWSROOM
CONTACT
 Delivering Results for Texans



Despite what you might see in the mainstream media, the Senate has been hard at work getting things done during the 115th Congress.
In the past week alone, we’ve passed water infrastructure legislation, provided funding to prosecute cold cases solved by DNA evidence, and confirmed Brett Kavanaugh to the United States Supreme Court.
On top of that, we have confirmed 84 judges under President Trump. That includes three Texas judges on the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals and five that preside over Texas district courts.
We’ve also been able to repeal burdensome regulations leftover from the Obama Administration, like Obamacare’s individual mandate, to give consumers more choices when it comes to picking health care plans that work for them.
One bill I’m particularly proud of, the Fix NICS Act, helps fix our broken background check system and ensures that convicted felons aren't able to purchase or possess firearms. I authored that bill as a response to the tragic shooting in Sutherland Springs.
And finally, we’ve restored America's defense with the greatest investment in the military in decades, reauthorized important intelligence-gathering tools that help track terrorists abroad, and passed the VA Mission Act, which strengthens health care and community care options for veterans.
We put money back in America's pocket. We rolled back regulations to make their lives a little bit easier. We strengthened our military, gave our veterans access to better health care, and protected our communities from harm.
But we’re not done yet.

Subject: Jackie's Reads for October 13, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

October 13, 2018 
Dear Friends,  Given these turbulent political times, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.   
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world. When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change. 
Happy reading and all the best,   ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼ 

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
My Private Oval Office Press Conference With Donald Trump, Mike Pence, John Kelly, and Mike Pompeo
By Olivia Nuzzi, New York Magazine Intelligencer
￼
Around 12:20 p.m. on Tuesday, I was on my way out of the White House after a series of meetings in the West Wing. I was reporting on a question that has hung over this administration for months: How has Chief of Staff John Kelly managed to keep his job in spite of convincing and persistent rumors and reports that the president is unhappy with him, and he is unhappy in his job? I stopped to talk to another reporter, and then I began to walk toward the North Gate. As I walked, I noticed I had a missed call from a Washington number I didn’t recognize. It was Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders. She sounded very serious. She asked me if I had left yet. When I said no, she asked me to come back inside, and when she greeted me, she looked very serious. She implied she wanted me to go with her behind a door. I didn’t understand, maybe didn’t quite hear her. Then, she told me Trump wanted to speak to me.
I walked to the Oval Office. I guessed that the president wanted to disabuse me of any notion that Kelly was about to be fired, or had almost been fired many times before. I was right, but my imagination was too limited. What ensued amounted to a private press conference — featuring a series of special guest stars from the highest echelon of the Trump administration — to try to get me to change my mind.
To read the complete New York Magazine article, please click here. 
Unprotected
￼
An acclaimed American charity said it was saving some of the world’s most vulnerable girls from sexual exploitation. But from the very beginning, girls were being raped.
Words by Finlay Young, Photography by Kathleen Flynn
Special to ProPublica
On Sept. 7, 2013, on a long, straight avenue that runs across the bustling downtown of Liberia’s capital, Monrovia, street hawkers peered at the spectacle. Guests sweltered on packed rows of plastic seats, while at the end of a red carpet, next to the U.S. ambassador, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf sat atop something like a throne. 
She was a dervish of hugs, laughter, even tears. Her name was Katie Meyler. It was her 31st birthday and, she would later say, the best day of her life. The More Than Me Academy was opening. 
The building had been a war-ruined shell people used as a toilet, festering so long a tree had grown through its walls. Now, with the Liberian president having given Meyler free use, it shone, improbably rebuilt into a school. A slogan ran step by step up a staircase: “I – promise – to – make – my – dream – come – true.” A sense of possibility infused the day, for Liberia and for the girls whose lives Meyler was transforming.

Subject: Pastor Andrew Brunson Returns Home
Message:
￼
October 13, 2018
Visit My Website | Share on:
￼￼

Pastor Andrew Brunson Returns Home

After two years of detainment, Pastor Andrew Brunson was released from house arrest and is returning home today. In October of 2016 Pastor Brunson, along with his wife, were imprisoned as part of a political crackdown in Turkey. While his wife was released after 13 days, he was not. Today we celebrate his release and a safe return back to the Unites States to be with his family. This welcome news is long overdue and our prayers were finally answered. We look forward to your return Pastor!

￼
 

Prescription Drug Pricing for You, Not the Pharmaceutical Industry

On Wednesday, the President signed two bills into law, the Know the Lowest Price Act and the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act. These laws will help seniors and all recipients of prescription drugs save money and receive the lowest possible price. Ending these so called "gag orders" will allow pharmacists to tell you when the cash price for a prescription is less than what you would pay using your insurance. For too long North Texans have been subjected to high prices that many struggle to pay while cheaper prices were available.

￼


Happy Birthday US Navy!

Tomorrow we celebrate the 243rd birthday of the US Navy, I want to thank all sailors, past and present, for their service and courage defending our great nation. The Navy has endured some of the most difficult tasks and carried out numerous missions critical to the safety and well being our nation. The US Navy transported our soldiers and guided them to the beaches of Normandy under heavy fire on D-day and shifted the momentum of WWII at the battle of Midway, destroying 4 Japanese carriers enabling the U.S. to go on the offensive and eventually onto victory in the war. Our country owes a great debt to the nautical men and women who protect our seas and defend our sovereignty. Happy Birthday US Navy!

￼

Events and presentations for Navy veterans and the USS Texas
                                                                                                                                

Pearl Harbor Survivor presented with overdue Service Medals
 Earlier this year I met Master Chief Petty Officer Bill Hughes, U.S. Navy (Ret.), of Coppell, while working to document his experiences in WWII through the Veterans History Project and to present to him his service medals, which he unfortunately did not receive upon discharge from the U.S. Navy.
MCPO Hughes’ earned the Pearl Harbor Survivor’s Medal, which is awarded to survivors of Pearl Harbor who participated in combat actions against the surprise attack on December 7, 1941. This award was commissioned by Congress in 1990 to be given to those veterans on the 50th anniversary of the attack. 
After conducting a search of his military records and working with the DOD, we were able to acquire his National Defense Service Medal (w/ Bronze star), WWII Victory Medal, Combat Action Ribbon, and Navy Good Conduct Medal. However, I was notified by the Department of Defense that there were no longer any Pearl Harbor Survivors Medals in possession by the DOD, or U.S. Government, to present to him. Upon hearing this my staff and I began communicating with the U.S. Mint, National Personnel Records Center, and U.S. Navy in hopes of finding one last medal to present to MCPO Hughes.
After weeks of searching, the U.S. Navy notified me that they finally located the last un-awarded Pearl Harbor Survivors Medal in existence. I then had the opportunity to present this medal to MCPO Hughes in front of an audience of his family, friends, and fellow veterans who helped to thank him for his service and commemorate this wonderful accomplishment. Please join me in thanking this outstanding veteran for his service.
￼


Justice Kavanaugh's First Day on the Supreme Court
Justice Kavanaugh took the bench for the first time this past Tuesday, receiving a warm welcome from Chief Justice John Roberts per tradition. The high court heard arguments regarding prison sentences for repeat offenders and despite recent tensions and protesting outside the court, it was an amicable and respectful showing for the justices. Justice Kavanaugh's confirmation was a big win for conservatism and protecting our Constitution. I look forward to following the new Supreme Court Justice's career and I want to congratulate him on this tremendous achievement.  
￼
￼
