Subject: The Importance of Social Security
Message:
October 13, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
Protecting Social Security is one of my highest priorities as your Congressman. More than 200,000 people in our area receive Social Security, and roughly half depend on it as their primary source of income.

I wanted to let you know that the Social Security Administration just announced that benefits will increase 2.8 percent in January of 2019 – the highest Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) in seven years. 

This increase is long overdue after years of little or no growth.

The last six years have been very difficult for seniors who live on fixed incomes. Last year’s COLA was 2 percent, but the year before that it was 0.3 percent and in 2015 it was 0 percent.
 
We must never lose sight that seniors have worked their entire lives so they can retire with the dignity and benefits they have earned.
 
As a senior member of the Social Security Subcommittee in Congress I will continue fighting to protect and strengthen the program for today’s seniors and future generations.

Social Security and Medicare are two of government’s most successful programs, and we need to do everything possible to keep them strong and solvent. 

Please let me know if you or anyone you know depends on Social Security.

Vern

Subject: An Update from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez to Constituents of the 15th District of Texas
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
The past couple of weeks have proven to be very busy, but I wanted to take the time to update you onour recent work in Washington, D.C. and the 15th District of Texas. 
It is an honor to serve as your congressman. 
As we continue to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month, I would like to thank the 1.2 million Hispanics currently serving in the U.S. Armed Forces. Join me in celebrating the many more Hispanics working in our school districts, medical field, and law enforcement in the 15th District of Texas!
￼ 

Recently, Northern District Director Albert Martinez attended the grand opening and ribbon-cutting ceremony for Brick’s Hardware and Feed Store in Benavides, Texas. The 15th District of Texas has proven, time and time again, to be a suitable host for small businesses. I look forward to the many successes of Brick’s and the support it willprovide local agribusiness.
￼ 
Recently, I stood before a very remarkable group of individuals on a day that neither they, nor I, will ever forget – the day that they became American citizens. It was truly an honor to speak atlast week’sNew Citizenship Ceremony in McAllen, Texas and to welcome them as neighbors, educators, and innovators. To my newly minted fellow Americans – welcome home. 
￼ 
Recently, I presented the Martinez family with Congressional Record honoring the life of their late son, Javier A. Martinez. Mr. Martinez was only 11-years-old when he was tragically diagnosed with Ewings Sarcoma but he was a fighter. Stories of Javier’s strength and courage have inspired me, and I thank him for being a role model for every resident in the 15th District of Texas. Javier, I will continue to work in Congress, on your behalf, to bring more federal funding to research and studies to put an end to this disease. Godspeed, my friend.
￼ 
While I am pleased to see the U.S., Mexico, and Canada reach a deal on the U.S.–Mexico-Canada Agreement, I believe we missed an opportunity to address a key barrier and cost to doing business in Mexico: insecurity. We must make this a top priority as we engage with the incoming Mexican Administration. 
Find out more by clicking the picture below: 
￼ 
On Tuesday, I joined Congressman Filemon Vela (TX-34) to announce that the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has moved forward on a remediation plan for the Donna Canal and Reservoir Superfund site. This will improve the health of residents in Donna, Texas, and surrounding communities.  
Find out more by clicking the picture below: 
￼ 
Recently, I cosponsored H.R. 1017, the Removing Barriers to Colorectal Cancer Screening Act of 2017. This bill helps eliminate unexpected costs for Medicare beneficiaries when a polyp is discovered and removed. Thank you to fellow Texansfrom Seguin, Brownsville, Laredoand elsewhere for your advocacy. 
Find out more by clicking the picture below: 
￼ 
The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) = jobs in the 15th District of Texas. Therefore, it will remain my mission to be vocal about NAFTA 2.0, or the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, and work to ensure that Central and South Texas remains protected and profitable as the process moves forward. 
Find out more by clicking the picture below: 
￼ 
On Tuesday, I highlighted a new Associated Press report showing soaring prescription drug prices. Little is being done to fix America’s prescription drug market. Millions of families, senior citizens, and sick Americans only continue to see rising prescription drug prices.
I pledge to reversethis unacceptable trend and lower prescription drug prices For The People. I encourage all Members of Congress to support A Better Deal to Lower the Cost of Prescription Drug Prices which would create a new “price gouging” enforcer to stop outrageous behavior in its tracks, allow Medicare Part D to negotiate drug prices and require drug manufacturers to publicly release hard data and information justifying any significant price increase.
Find out more by clicking the picture below: 
￼ 
On Thursday, October 11, 2018, I announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Rural Development program has awarded a $174,857 grant for the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV). It is my belief that every person in rural Texas deserves the same access to economic opportunity and long-term financial stability as people living in urban communities. I thank the USDA for providing women and Hispanics in our region with the tools necessary to harness their skills and talents. UTRGV will serve as the vehicle to provide technical assistance to these folks, and I thank the university for leading such efforts. I will continue to work to ensure that the door remains open for all people to be able to pioneer their own success. Read more here by clicking here. 
Friday, October 12, 2018 was National Farmer’s Day. The 15th District of Texas boasts over 4.3 million acres of farm land and 8,000 farming operations that make us more competitive in local, state, national, and global markets. During my first term in Congress, I have worked to give farmers and farmworkers the resources they need to thrive. And as we continue to face crop and cattle diseases, droughts and flooding, labor shortages, and other issues, I am working with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) and other federal agencies to ensure that Central and South Texans are heard and have access to whatever assistance they may need.
￼ 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.    
  
Sincerely, ￼  Vicente Gonzalez Member of Congress
￼

Subject: A New Supreme Court Justice
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email 
￼ 
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
October 13, 2018

A NEW SUPREME COURT JUSTICE Last Saturday, the Senate voted to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. He was sworn in by President Trump on Monday night. Judge Kavanaugh’s fortitude and resilience throughout his confirmation process is beyond admirable. His commitment to the rule of law, justice, and the Constitution will serve this country well while he sits on the bench for the many years ahead. My congratulations to Judge Kavanaugh on his confirmation to the United States Supreme Court. There is no one more qualified or more deserving to serve on the highest court in the land.
DISCUSSING JUSTICE KAVANAUGH ON FOX BUSINESS On Monday, I joined Maria Bartiromo on Fox Business to talk about the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and the Trump effect on our communities and our economy. Click here to watch a clip about the economy and click here to watch a clip about Justice Kavanaugh. 
￼
MOBILE OFFICE STOPS FOR VETERANS  
￼
In the Second District, I have offices located in Claremore, Muskogee, and McAlester. However, I understand that many constituents don’t live near one of my offices, or don’t have the time to travel to one. Our veterans deserve first-class service no matter where they live. That’s why I’m sending my veterans caseworker to you so that a member of my team can assist you in your own town.
Members of my staff will stop in five southeastern counties in OK-2 this month. The stops below are coming up next week. Visit my website to see the full list of dates and locations. Stop by if my team can help you!
LeFlore County Mobile Office Stop Tuesday, October 16, 2018 1:00PM – 4:00PM CT American Legion Post 26 29959 Main St. Bokoshe, OK 74930
McCurtain County Mobile Office Stop Thursday, October 18, 2018 1:00PM – 4:00PM CT American Legion Post 501 NW Veterans Dr. Idabel, OK 74745  
VISITING WITH OKLAHOMANS I was able to tour Home2Suites in Muskogee, which is a property associated with the Oklahoma Hotel and Lodging Association. I got to meet and speak with many employees onsite. The Oklahoma Hotel and Lodging Association provides employment for nearly 24,000 Oklahomans, representing more than 200 lodging operators and members in the state. Associations like these are providing great opportunities for economic growth across our state.  
￼
I met with Nelita Cash of the Alzheimer’s Association to discuss current topics and legislation relating to Alzheimer’s disease. As a member of the Alzheimer’s Caucus, it is important to me to keep informed on what those impacted have to say and see how we can help from a federal level.  
￼
Enjoyed visiting with Drushane Teehee and her family.  
￼
Thanks to members of Direct Traffic Control who stopped by my Muskogee office for a meeting to talk about improving infrastructure in Oklahoma.  
￼

I had the chance to talk to Ken Snyder, a U.S. Army Veteran, about his difficulties and frustrations with the VA appeals process. If we can help you or a veteran you know with problems with the VA, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

￼

Thank you to Vallourec Star for the tour of their production facility in Muskogee. Manufacturing plays a vital role in our economy and I am grateful to the team at Vallourec Star for showing me around and sharing their thoughts about the new trade deal between the United States, Mexico, and Canada.  
￼

I was able to talk with students at the College of the Muscogee Nation and at OSUIT this week. I updated them on current happenings in D.C., and then engaged in a Q&A with them afterwards.

￼
Great to be with students at the College of the Muscogee 
Nation. (Photo courtesy of Muscogee (Creek) Nation)

￼
Nice to have a discussion over lunch at OSUIT.

I toured Tiger Mountain Recovery facility in Henryetta. It was great to speak with Leah Ledford about updates on the latest opioid package and more on patient safety.

￼
It was an honor to be the keynote speaker at the NAHB Area 11 Leadership Conference. I talked to the attendees about the importance of leadership and how important those aspects are in Congress.  
￼
I wasn't able to meet with these members of FCCLA since I wasn't in Washington this week, but I'm glad to see they were still able to get a great tour of the U.S. Capitol!

￼

See more from my week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way. 

Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin
Member of Congress

Subject: Now Law: Protections for Disaster Victims
Message:
News from Congressman Tom MacArthur

￼ 

Home
Contact
Services
Media


  
Friend, 
Since day one in Congress, I made supporting Sandy Victims and all South Jersey residents during a natural disaster a top priority. In the immediate aftermath of Superstorm Sandy, we saw families and business owners struggle to rebuild their lives and the federal government fail them. 
That’s why I introduced legislation to address issues many South Jersey families faced when dealing with FEMA and other federal disaster aid programs. 
ENACTED INTO LAW: Disaster Assistance Fairness for Sandy Victims 
Following Superstorm Sandy, the federal government made it difficult for some in our community to recover because of the actions of a few bad actors. Before my provision was enacted into law, FEMA could change their mind on disaster assistance grants and make disaster victims pay back previously awarded disaster assistance, sometimes years after the award. This happened to many South Jersey residents after Sandy and I am grateful I am in the position to stop this practice once and for all. 
ENACTED INTO LAW: Greater Access to Federal Disaster Aid for South Jersey Residents 
The federal government should make it easier, not harder for those who have just gone through a natural disaster. I championed a policy that allows Small Business Administration (SBA) loan recipients to also be eligible for FEMA disaster aid grants. The last thing families should have to worry about is whether taking an SBA loan will disqualify them for FEMA disaster grants that become available later on. Now, the president can waive the duplication of benefits during a federally declared disaster, allowing disaster victims to have both loans and other forms of federal aids available to them.
I won’t ever be blinded by partisanship and I refuse to take part in the partisan dysfunction that prevents progress. The nonpartisan Lugar Center at Georgetown University recently named me again among the most bipartisan members of Congress, because I work against Washington dysfunction and stand up for Burlington and Ocean Counties. If I can ever be of any assistance, please visit my website or contact my office: http://macarthur.house.gov.  
  
Sincerely,  
￼ 
Tom MacArthur

506 Cannon House Office Building
Washington, DC 20515
Ocean County Office
Township of Toms River Hall
33 Washington St
Toms River, NJ 08753
Burlington County Office
535 East Main Street
Marlton, NJ 08053

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

October 13, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review
 



October 8

Trade in the Lowcountry: About a month ago now, I made it a point to attend the grand opening of the new Mercedes Benz plant in Ladson. It was neat to be there and see the ways in which the plant had grown since I was at a ribbon cutting years ago as governor.
At that time, bizarre trade requirements dictated that they build the Sprinter van in Germany, disassemble it, ship it to Charleston...and then reassemble it for sale in the domestic United States. Talk about a waste of money and time!
But that was the most we could do based on the tariffs that were in place, and it did get our foot in the door with regard to production. Demand has grown from 8,559 units in 2010 to 28,519 units by 2015, and they’ve moved past the break-even point in dealing with tariffs so that they could go ahead with production.
So, I guess last month’s celebration is a reminder of two things. Click here to read more.
￼

October 9

Big News of the Week: The political world was shocked today by news of Nikki Haley’s upcoming resignation.
It’s a reminder of how we can never say never in life. Life indeed is a world of perpetual surprises and new wrinkles, and given her success as US Ambassador to the United Nations, this certainly surprised everyone.
In its wake, I’m left with a couple of different thoughts.
One, I wish her well. By all accounts, she’s risen to the challenges that that UN posting brought with it and, accordingly, proved her critics wrong. You may remember at the beginning of her tenure, some had suggested that because she had only been governor of South Carolina, this international posting was beyond her resume. That’s positively not the case. It’s the reverse. If you’ve been governor of South Carolina, a posting like the UN position is relatively simple in form compared to all the moving parts that come with different political bodies, a cabinet, tens of thousands of state employees, and the whirlwind that is South Carolina politics. Click here to read more.
￼

October 10

Military Academy Nomination Deadline: It’s hard to believe, but we are just nine days away from our service academy application deadline on Friday, October 19th. While we currently have a host of applications here at the office, I don’t want any interested high school juniors or seniors to miss the incredible leadership and academic opportunity that the service academies represent.
In fact, I can’t say enough about the quality of the training received by students at these academies. You obviously have impressive young people entering these institutions, but these students find themselves in a setting where they’re no longer first or top in the class but rather participants in a world wherein every one of their peers were the same. In this regard, iron sharpens iron, and the bearing, demeanor, and impressiveness of the students I’ve seen graduate is none other than inspiring.
For those unfamiliar with the process, my office has the chance to nominate a number of students from the First District to attend four of the five national military academies each year: West Point, the United States Naval Academy, the US Air Force Academy, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. While admission is determined by each academy, graduating students must have the recommendation of a Member of Congress to be considered. The opportunity to attend a service academy comes with a commitment to serve in the military for a minimum of five years upon graduation.
For more information and to see the application, visit my website at the link below…. And if you happen to know of any high school juniors or seniors who might be interested, my simple ask would be that you share this post or maybe tag them in a comment below!
￼
 Click above to fill out the form

￼


October 11

New Ethanol Standard: Earlier this week at a rally in Iowa, President Trump announced that he’s pushing to raise the ethanol content of year-round sales of gasoline from 10% to 15%. Currently, the higher ethanol-blend gasoline is not allowed for summer sales, based on its impact with smog and the environment of the warmer months of the year.
This is horrible policy at two different levels.
One, the EPA restriction is there for a reason, given the smog consequence in places like Atlanta, New York City, or Los Angeles. Making bad air worse during the summer months doesn’t seem like good policy.
Two, it continues to make our country less efficient with regard to the fuel that we burn. While it’s certainly pure pandering to the corn belt and to Iowa voters, it’s not good for the country as a whole. And at some point, we’ve got to get back to policy that watches out for the whole of our nation rather than particular voting blocks.
The ethanol industry has been propped up by taxpayer dollars to the tune of about $45 billion in subsidies over roughly the last thirty years. Former US Senator Tom Coburn made this a particular crusade in looking at both the subsidy in ethanol and the inefficiency that it brought to internal combustion engines of all sorts. Click here to read more.
￼

October 12

The Reconstruction Era National Historical Park Act: Last month, the House passed H.R. 5532, the Reconstruction Era National Historical Park Act, which will redesignate Beaufort’s Reconstruction Era National Monument as a Historical Park and allow for the creation of a national “Historic Network.” This bill will build upon the recently created park that celebrates South Carolina’s importance in our nation’s Reconstruction era by celebrating locations like the Camp Saxton Site in Port Royal, the Brick Baptist Church, and the Penn School.
Outside of the historical significance that this bill attempts to commemorate, highlight, and protect, here are a few things that are important about this bill that Rep. Clyburn and I passed through the House.
One, it’s going about the protection of land in the right way. I believe that the Antiquities Act has been abused by Republicans and Democrats alike. It has shifted power from the legislative body, which should control the purse strings of our country, to the executive branch so that a president can by proclamation protect areas of our country. Doing so is at odds with the legislative tug of war that our Founding Fathers intended when we go to committing your and my financial resources as taxpayers. So though protection of Penn Center began with President Obama’s use of the Antiquities Act, this bill attempted to codify what happened there with actual legislation. And I believe that’s the right way to protect natural and historic resources of our country. Click here to read more. 
￼
 Rep. Sanford at Reconstruction Era Monument Ceremony in January

Subject: Praying for Our Fellow Americans Facing Devastation
Message:
Share on: 
￼￼ 
 
￼
￼


Dear Friend,  This week our country saw great devastation rip through the South. My thoughts and prayers continue to be with our fellow Americans who lost their homes, personal belongings, and for some, family or friends because of Hurricane Michael. America stands with you during this tragic time. My thoughts and prayers are also with the first responders who continue to work day and night to keep their communities safe. And with the utility and transportation teams in the area who are working around the clock to reopen roads and restore power to the areas affected by this catastrophic storm.  Social Security Beneficiaries  The Social Security Administration announced this week that due to changes in the cost of living throughout the country, monthly benefits will be increased by 2.8 percent beginning December 2018.  Wins for the American People  This week, the President signed three very important pieces of legislation into law. Having served in law enforcement for 33 years, I was proud to see the Justice Served Act signed into law, which I cosponsored. This bill addresses the growing backlog of violent crime cases involving DNA evidence, ensuring criminals receive the justice they deserve for their crimes. It also brings much-needed closure to victims and their families.  The Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act and the Know the Lowest Price Act were also signed into law this week. These two bills are an important step in helping improve transparency in drug pricing for patients across the country.  American Flags and Tours of Washington, DC  Constituents of Washington’s 8th District looking to book tours in Washington, DC or order U.S. flags from my office must submit their requests before November 15th. Any requests after this date and before 2019 can be submitted to one of the Washington Senators Patty Murray or Maria Cantwell.  Discussing Today’s Top Issues  It was good to see Paul Benz and his friends with the Faith Action Network. They stopped by to discuss immigration and the farm bill. 
￼
District Events  TODAY: Leavenworth Oktoberfest  Join the Leavenworth Oktoberfest for its 20th celebration of authentic Bavarian culture! Hosted over three weekends, Oktoberfest showcases Bavarian food, drink, and musical performances for over 10,000 visitors. Tickets are required for general admission, but members of the military and children under 12 enter free. Group discounts are also available.  EVENT DETAILS: When: Saturday, October 13 12pm-1am Where: Leavenworth Festhalle, 1001 Front St., Leavenworth, WA  THIS WEEKEND: Harvest Festival  This weekend, the 13th Annual Harvest Festival at Suncadia’s Historic Nelson Farm continues. The free, family-friendly event celebrates the arrival of fall with an array of seasonal activities including a hay maze & hay pyramid, a petting zoo, pony & wagon rides, pumpkin archery, and face painting. Live music will be provided by Chinook Entertainment, while Sunday features the Big Dirty Run 5K.  EVENT DETAILS: When: Saturday, October 13 and Sunday, October 14, 10:00am-5:00pm  Where: Suncadia Resort, 3600 Suncadia Trail, Cle Elum, WA  Thank you all for joining me for this update on the week. Wishing you all a fun and safe weekend!  Sincerely,
Dave

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Saturday, October 13, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week I attended various meetings and events with different individuals and organizations, including the promotion of my Legislative Fellow David Kolcun to Chief Master Sergeant of the U.S. Air Force. 

In the district, my staff attended several meetings and events including the Atascosa Animal Shelter Ribbon Cutting Ceremony, the FACE Coalition SAMHSA Drug-Free Communities Grant Announcement Ceremony, and the Pleasanton Fire Station Ribbon Cutting Ceremony, among others. 

Lastly, I have included a submission deadline reminder to potential participants of The Congressional App Challenge, as well as a video from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) concerning teenage depression awareness. 

As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Presenting U.S. Flag to Chief Master Sergeant David Kolcun 
￼

On Thursday, September 27, I attended the promotion ceremony for my Legislative Defense Fellow David Kolcun as he was promoted to Chief Master Sergeant of the U.S. Air Force. Pictured from left are Congressman Henry Cuellar and CMSgt David Kolcun.


Guided Tour of the Capitol 
￼

On Thursday, October 11, my Legislative Correspondent Patrick O’Connor guided a tour of the U.S. Capitol in Washington for constituents from Adkins, TX Angelica Christian and her daughter Grace. 


Atascosa Animal Shelter Ribbon Cutting Ceremony 

￼

On Friday, September 21, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente attended the Atascosa Animal Shelter Ribbon Cutting Ceremony in Jourdanton. During the event, he met with Commissioners to discuss the benefits of this new shelter in the county. He also met with newly elected State Senator from Pleasanton, Peter Flores. Top photo: Ribbon Cutting Ceremony at Atascosa Animal Shelter in Jourdanton. Bottom Photo: pictured from left are Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente and State Senator from Pleasanton, and Peter Flores.


FACE Coalition SAMHSA Drug-Free Communities Grant 
￼

On Wednesday, October 3, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties Francis Atwell attended the Family Assistance & Community Empowerment (FACE) Coalition SAMHSA Drug-Free Communities Grant Announcement Ceremony at the Laredo Holding Institute. This is a $125,000 grant which will be administered over the next 5 years to assist FACE with drug treatment, education, and prevention. Pictured from left are FACE WestCare Program Coordinator Ricardo Hinojosa, FACE Co-Chair Jaime Arizpe, FACE Chairwoman Julie Bazan, Outreach Coordinator Francis Atwell, and FACE Co-Chair Calixto Seca. 


Outreach Coordinator Meets with UPS Representative
￼

On Thursday, October 4, my Outreach Coordinator for Bexar County Pete Arguello met with Senior Pricing Analyst, West Region at UPS Barbara Reyes. She provided our office with a business update and discussed upcoming events and initiatives. Pictured from left are Senior Pricing Analyst Barbara Reyes and Outreach Coordinator Pete Arguello. 


Presentation of CIENCIA Award 
￼

On Thursday, October 4, my Outreach Coordinator for Hidalgo and Starr Counties Nicole Hernandez attended the HESTEC VIP Reception at the UT-RGV Performance Art Complex in Edinburg. Along with former Congressman Ruben Hinojosa, she helped present the “Champions in Engineering and Science Advancement” CIENCIA AWARD to Tina Aguirre, ITSO 2.0 Progromme and Transformation Manager at Shell. Pictured from left are Vice President for Government & Community Relations Veronica Gonzalez, Former TX-15 Congressman Ruben Hinojosa, ITSO 2.0 Progromme and Transformation Manager at Shell Tina Aguirre, Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez, and UT-RGV President Dr. Guy Bailey. 


Pleasanton Fire Station Ribbon Cutting Ceremony 
￼

On Friday, October 5, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente attended the Pleasanton Fire Department Ribbon Cutting ceremony. Top Photo: Attendees gather in anticipation for the ceremony. Bottom Photo: Pictured from left are Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente and Pleasanton Fire Department Chief Chuck Gerris. 


Meeting with City Officials from Pleasanton 
￼

On Friday, October 5, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente also met with officials from the City of Pleasanton to receive an update on upcoming projects and priorities for the community. Pictured from left are Mayor Pro Tempore and Council Member District 1 Robert Leonhardt, Council Member District 2 Kenneth Hernandez, Council Member District 5 Robert Earl Wood, Council Member District 6 Britni Van Curan, Mayor Travis Hall Jr., City Manager Johnny Huizar, Council Member District 4 JR Gallegos, and Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente. 


Staff Spotlight: Travis Knight 
￼

Meet our Legislative Assistant, who is based in my Washington, D.C. office. Travis is responsible for advising me on legislative and legal matters. His grandmother was born in Laredo and he maintains close family ties to Webb County. He earned his JD from the University of Texas at Austin after graduating from Vanderbilt University. 


Intern Spotlight: Sara Gong 
￼

Meet our intern, Sara Gong. She is currently completing her second year at the University of Southern California, where she is pursuing majors in economics and math and a minor in philosophy. Sara is originally from Las Vegas, Nevada lives in Los Angeles during the school year. She completed her summer internship in our Washington, D.C. office. To learn more about Sara and our other interns, please click here. 


Congressional App Challenge: Last days to submit your apps! 
￼

The Congressional App Challenge is a nationwide competition intended to engage high school students' creativity and encourage their participation in STEM Fields. It gives students the opportunity to create and exhibit their software applications for mobile phones, tablets, or computer devices on a coding platform of their choice. 

Deadline for submissions is October 15. For additional information click here. 


National Institute of Mental Health: Teen Depression Study 
￼

In honor of October 7—13 being Mental Health Awareness week, this video from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) covers the warning signs of teenage depression and what they are doing to help. 


 
 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Putting “America First” in our Trade Deals
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Putting "America First" in our Trade Deals
President Donald Trump has repeatedly promised to put “America First” in his policies, and there is a lot of evidence he is delivering on that promise. Earlier this year, the President announced he was willing to withdraw from the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada unless Mexico and Canada renegotiated terms of the agreement. The President also warned those countries they could be subjected to tariffs if trade talks fail. Last week, President Trump announced a renegotiated arrangement that had been agreed to by all three countries, which he is referring to as the USMCA (the United States-Mexico-Canada trade agreement). I am glad our countries were able to find common ground, and it appears the new agreement will enhance American businesses’ ability to compete. I look forward to carefully reviewing this agreement when it is brought up in Congress for a vote. 
I support free trade, but agree with the President that trade must be fair also. I watched as my father lost his manufacturing job to a factory in Mexico, and I still hear all too often similar stories from people across the First District of Tennessee. The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is 24 years old and was in need of modernization. However, I also have talked to a lot of businesses and farmers throughout the First District in the past several months who were concerned about an escalating trade war with our neighbors, and the need to maintain access to markets throughout North America. One of the greatest benefits of this deal will be the stability it provides to thousands of East Tennessee workers whose businesses rely on both free and fair trade.  
The announced framework of the USMCA appears to benefit American manufacturers and farmers; protect intellectual property; and ensure safe working conditions for laborers. East Tennessee has worked hard to rebuild our manufacturing sector and any agreement must not only maintain those gains, but also ensure further growth. For example, in East Tennessee, the motor and equipment manufacturing industry employs over 4,200 individuals – these are good-paying jobs that support a middle class family. I firmly believe we should encourage growth of these job opportunities for American workers.  
Canada and Mexico are our first- and third-largest export markets for U.S. food and agricultural products, making up 28 percent of total food and agriculture exports in 2017, while supporting 325,000 American jobs. That’s why it’s particularly good news for our farmers that the updated arrangement will maintain strong markets where they sell their goods.  
Some of the other benefits of the agreement that President Trump and his administration have negotiated are removing provisions from NAFTA that are no longer relevant; discouraging the practice of offshoring jobs while creating opportunities for additional auto manufacturing in the U.S.; and ensuring more market access for our farmers. Specifically, this deal should increase access to the Canadian market for our dairy farmers, many of whom are right in East Tennessee. Canada is also providing full access for other U.S. dairy products, eggs and poultry to be sold in their market. This is great to hear, particularly after so much turmoil earlier this year for many of the dairy farmers in East Tennessee 
I look forward to carefully reviewing the USMCA and learning more about how it affects East Tennesseans. I also hope this agreement will provide momentum to complete trade discussions with other countries, notably Europe, to continue the great economy we have right now. 
My door is always open to East Tennesseans. Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.

Subject: Lowest unemployment rate since 1969
Message:
￼ 


Saturday, October 13, 2018


Lowest unemployment rate since 1969



Dear Friend: 
Welcome to your weekly update. As always, you can learn more about these and other legislative issue at my website: upton.house.gov. 
Lowest unemployment rate since 1969
September’s job report showed sustained economic growth and a strong labor market fueled by pro-growth tax cuts and regulatory reform.
This past month, 134,000 jobs were created and the unemployment rate fell to 3.7% the lowest rate since 1969. 
Recently, the House passed the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act which would make tax cuts permanent for middle class families and small businesses across Southwestern Michigan and help individuals save for their future and have retirement security. 
To learn more about my work on tax reform, please click here. 
Supporting innovative PFAS research
This week, I sent a letter to the Acting Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) expressing support of a research proposal being developed by doctors at Western Michigan University and Michigan State University. 
The research being done at Western Michigan University and Michigan State University is vital to our understanding of plumes of contaminates and how they affect residents around them. 
It is critical that we are able to alleviate some of the major data and knowledge gaps regarding the PFAS sites with the highest levels of contamination. 
To read the full letter, please click here. 
Learn more about my work on this PFAS issue here.
Back in Southwest Michigan
With no votes in the House this week, I am home in Southwest Michigan. 
October 10th was International Walk to School Day and I was happy to join students at El Sol Elementary in Kalamazoo for their morning commute to promote a healthy lifestyle, a cleaner environment, pedestrian safety, and a strong sense of community. 
I was able to celebrate the Seita Scholars Program at Western Michigan University, met with veterans at Van Buren County Project Connect and Veteran’s Stand Down in Hartford, and attended the Red Bud Motocross of Nations Event in Buchanan. I also visited the Kalamazoo Metro for a facility tour to highlight the $2.8 million grant we announced that will go towards modernizing the Central Transportation Authority’s fleet of fixed-route buses which provides nearly 3 million rides annually. Just to name a few! 
To stay up to date on my work here at home, follow my Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages.
Have a great weekend and God bless,

￼
Fred Upton
Member of Congress

Subject: News and Updates from Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett
Message:
￼ 
  
October 2018   
Disaster Related Unemployment Assistance Extended for USVI



This week, Stacey introduced the Plaskett Amendment to the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018. The Amendment provides for an additional 26 weeks’ worth of unemployment assistance to Virgin Islanders who lost employment as a result of hurricanes Irma and Maria. The extension is retroactive from the time of expiration in late March, up to 52 weeks after each disaster declaration for Hurricanes Irma and Maria. It amounts to the longest Disaster Unemployment Assistance period ever extended by Congress. An extension of disaster-related unemployment assistance is critical to Virgin Islanders who work in the industries most impacted by the devastation of hurricanes Irma and Maria and will serve as a much-needed lifeline for many Virgin Islands families.

Addressing the Needs of the USVI's Public Education System in Congress





￼
Congresswoman Stacey Plaskett with 
St. Croix AFT President Rosa Soto-Thomas, 
(left) and St. Thomas AFT President 
Carol Callwood, (far right).
Recently, Stacey and other Democratic Members of the House Education and Workforce Committee hosted a forum to examine whether recovery efforts in the U.S. Virgin Islands were meeting the needs of local students, parents, and educators. At the forum, Rosa Soto-Thomas, President of AFT Local 1826 and Carol Callwood, President of AFT Local 1825 presented compelling testimony regarding the needs of the students and teachers of the territory. Before the forum, Stacey visited local schools as they opened for the new school year, and shared what she saw at those schools during the forum and at a press conference held outside the Capitol Building. View the full press conference here.  
Military Service Academy Information


The deadline to apply for a nomination to one of the U.S. Military Academies is October 31. Stacey encourages all Virgin Islands students who meet the eligibility requirements and are interested totake advantage of this opportunity! You can contact the district offices in both St. Thomas and St. Croix for more information. 340-774-4408 (STT) and 340-778-5900 (STX). Download a nomination packet here.

Upcoming Town Hall Meetings with the National Park Service



This month, Stacey will host two town hall meetings with the National Park Service in St. Croix and St. John. The first town hall is scheduled for 6:00 pm Tuesday, October 16 and will be held in the Danish West India & Guinea Company Warehouse (Old Post Office) in Christiansted, St. Croix. The second town hall is scheduled for 6:00 pm Wednesday, October 17 and will be held in the Cleone Creque Legislative Conference Room in Cruz Bay, St. John. Both town halls will focus on CUA opportunities, business concessions, park entrance fee structures, and employment opportunities, with particular focus paid to the Slave Wreck Project on St. Croix and road access through the park in St. John. 

FEMA Awards $42 Million in Hurricane Recovery Grant Funding to the Water and Power Authority




Stacey announced recently that the territory is slated to receive four grants totaling over $42 million toward the post hurricanes Irma and Maria rebuilding effort. The grants come through the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and will go to the V.I. Water and Power Authority for contracted power debris removal throughout the islands of St. Thomas, St. John and Water Island as a result of Hurricane Maria.

Subject: Tariffs
Message:
News from Representative Crawford 
￼ 
￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   ￼   
￼
Tariffs
China has repeatedly demonstrated an inability to play by the rules of international trade. Following the United State’s decision to respond to unfair Chinese trade practices, President Xi had an opportunity to  make simple, fair reforms and fully integrate China into the international market. Instead, China implemented retaliatory tariffs. 

On a level playing field, the US can compete and mutually benefit from trade with any other country. However, China’s retaliatory tariffs are precision crafted to harm American firms and consumers. Congress and the Administration must establish a formal exclusion process to allow US companies to seek relief if there is no alternative to Chinese suppliers or if other special circumstances exist. The process must be fact-based, and have stringent but reasonable criteria for companies to meet for exclusion. 

Exclusions exist and have been successful for the first 2 rounds of tariffs, so there is no reason not to continue the policy with the most recent list of products. This week, 130 of my colleagues and I asked the US Trade Representative to create an exclusion process for American companies so that these tariffs do not weaken America’s competitive advantage in key industries.
 
FAQ (What folks have been calling/texting my office about this week)
Q: What's the latest update on the Farm Bill?  A: It's no secret that our farmer's need a farm bill to ensure security at a job that comes with a lot  of uncertainty and risk. Two versions of the Farm Bill currently sit at a committee made up of both Senators and Congressman as they hash out the differences between the two. Many things are delaying the process which I've discussed in a previous newsletter as well as in this interview with KASU. 
You can text me legislative concerns or questions at 870-292-6747
￼ 
TB&P
Helena puts hope in Civil War, music histories for tourism spur

A Civil Rights Park is being planned near Freedom Park, Miller said. U.S. Rep. Rick Crawford, R-Jonesboro, has agreed to bring the park proposal before a congressional committee. If it survives the committee process, it will be voted on by Congress, he said. How long it will take and how much it will cost are not known, he added.
“Our thoughts are that a civil rights park would be a natural fit,” he said.
￼

Subject: McKinley Talks Workforce, Economic Growth With Local Businesses
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online. 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT  |   SERVICES  |   ISSUES  |   MEDIA  |   OUR DISTRICT  |   CONTACT 
October 13, 2018 
McKinley Talks Workforce, Economic Growth With Local Businesses 
This past week we have traveled across the district to meet with several companies to discuss how the government and local businesses can work together to face economic challenges. We continue to discuss ways to create more jobs , increase production and manufacturing, combat the opioid epidemic, and incentivize workforce training for the people of West Virginia. After all, these businesses are vital for our economy and our communities. There is a lot of optimism about things turning around for our state.  Click on the following to read more about our meetings:   Rep. McKinley Priorities: Opioids, Healthcare, and Economic Revitalization  McKinley Discusses Workforce Training in West Virginia  McKinley Meets with Local Chemical Manufacturer  Congressman McKinley Meets with Representatives of Morgantown Addivant USA  
￼

New York Times Captures West Virginia's Small-Town Revival
The New York Times publicized what many of us in West Virginia already know; communities like Thomas and Davis have much to offer, from natural beauty to great craft beer. We hope that those who live outside of West Virginia will come and see everything our beautiful state has to offer.    Click here to read more 
￼

President Trump Signs Bills to Lower Drug Prices
This week we were glad to see President Donald Trump signed two bills at the White House aimed at lowering pharmaceutical drug prices by promoting greater disclosure in drug pricing. This is a common sense step to end the "gag clause" that prevents pharmacists from discussing lower cost options with patients.  Click here to learn more 
￼

West Virginia Mourns Loss of Esteemed House Delegate
This week we mourn the loss of a great West Virginian. Frank Deem devoted a lifetime of service to the citizens of his district and to the people of our state. Mary and I send our condolences to the family of Wood Co. Delegate Frank Deem, who I had the honor of serving with in West Virginia Legislature. Frank was an institution in WV politics and will always be remembered for his dedication to the community. Rest in peace.
￼

Water Infrastructure Bill Moves One Step Closer to Law
Investing in our water infrastructure is important both for our economy and quality of life. The bipartisan America’s Water Infrastructure Act of 2018 will modernize drinking water infrastructure, promote hydropower development, and increase Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) transparency. We are happy to see this bill one step closer to law.  Click here to read more

Subject: The Scoop: Justice Kavanaugh, E15 Sales Year-Round, Missing Children
Message:
￼ 

About Grassley
Constituent Services
News Center
Contact Grassley


Grassley Direct
On my weekly "Capitol Hill Report," I spoke with Darin Svenson of KDEC in Decorah and Eric Vansickle from Waverly Newspapers about Justice Brett Kavanaugh, E15 and the Farm Bill.  
Q&A: E15 Year-Round
Q. What is the Renewable Fuel Standard? Q. Why is the Trump administration's E15 announcement good for the Iowa economy? 
Quick Links
The Senate confirmed Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court in a 50-48 vote. Justice Kavanaugh was one of the most qualified nominees in history. His 12 years of experience on the most important federal circuit court in America proved that he was unquestionably qualified to serve on the Supreme Court. Justice Kavanaugh has a lifetime of public service, teaching, coaching and volunteering. He also stands out as a devoted husband and father. Justice Kavanaugh will serve the Supreme Court and the American people honorably. 
Watch my first television interview after Justice Kavanaugh’s confirmation below. 
￼  
Opening the door for year-round sales of higher blends of ethanol is a victory for farmers, Rural America and the nation as a whole. Allowing an open marketplace with more fuel options for consumers encourages competition, drives down consumer fuel costs and is good for the environment. It also maintains and creates jobs in parts of the country that need them most and decreases America’s dependence on foreign oil. I want to thank President Trump for his leadership and for keeping his promise to the farmers and agricultural workers in Iowa and throughout the nation. 
Senator Joni Ernst and I joined Senate colleagues in sending a letter to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) urging them to investigate and respond to recent cases a serious nervous system condition that causes polio-like symptoms in patiences, such as weak muscles. Because the causes of this condition are unknown, we urge the CDC to provide more information immediately about preventive measures and treatments.
President Donald Trump nominated Iowan Douglas J. Strike to serve as the United States Marshal for the Northern District of Iowa after a joint recommendation from Senator Ernst and me. Mr. Strike has served Iowa as a law enforcement officer for more than 34 years, most recently as the Chief of Police for the Iowa Falls Police Department. His exemplary record will continue to serve the people of Iowa well in this new role. I thank President Trump for carefully considering our recommendations and making such an outstanding selection.
The Missing Children’s Assistance Act of 2018, which I authored, was signed into law. This legislation extends and updates programs that make resources available to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) for the continued fight against child abduction and exploitation. Organizations like the NCMEC provide families, caregivers, schools and other community leaders with critical support to prevent and respond to child exploitation.

Subject: Pastor Brunson Released From Prison
Message:
A message from Senator Thom Tillis 
￼ 





Pastor Brunson Released From Prison  
 ￼
North Carolina native Pastor Brunson is on his way home to the United States, where he will be reunited with his family. While the Brunson family has been caught in the middle of a diplomatic and political nightmare for the last two years, their unwavering optimism and faith kept them strong during this very difficult and stressful time. Despite the anguish Pastor Brunson has had to endure locked away in prison with his fate uncertain, I was personally inspired when I watched him stand up in a Turkish courtroom during his trial – facing an effective lifetime sentence – and announce that he harbored no animosity or bitterness towards the individuals who falsely accused him. That is a testament to his incredible character and devotion to the principles of his faith, which he shared with the Turkish people for more than twenty years.  
When I first met with Pastor Brunson in a Turkish prison earlier this spring, he told me his greatest fear was that the American government would accept the indictment and forget about him. I told him we would never allow that to happen, and over the last several months, Americans from every corner of the country have prayed for his release, and leaders from both parties have worked together behind the scenes. Securing Pastor Brunson’s release was truly a bipartisan, all-hands-on-deck effort. I’m grateful for the efforts of President Trump, the State Department, and my colleagues in the Senate. We pursued a number of diplomatic and policy channels that kept the pressure on. The Turkish Government ultimately made the right decision, which will undoubtedly help improve U.S.-Turkey relations moving forward. While the outcome took longer than anyone would have liked, Pastor Brunson is finally coming back home as a free man. 


Contact My Office

Subject: Fort Report: Infrastructure
Message:
News from Representative Fortenberry
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
 
Home
About Jeff
Legislation
Services
News
Contact Me
 
Dear Friend,  From the interstate highway system to the Erie Canal, the transcontinental railroad to the Hoover Dam, infrastructure projects have transformed our nation, lifted our spirits, and caused the world to marvel at the incredible ingenuity of America.  As your representative, it is my duty to ensure that the guardrails of community, prosperity, health, and security are maintained.  Robust, reliable, innovative, cost-effective, and often aesthetically breathtaking infrastructure plays a critical role in achieving these ends.  Our government recently initiated some necessary infrastructure projects that directly affect Nebraska.  After a long process, including intense interactions with various heads of the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) across several administrations, I’m happy to report that Lincoln’s historic VA campus has been chosen as the location for a new state-of-the art VA clinic.  This is an important victory for the economic regeneration of a unique historic property.  It arrives subsequent to a similarly successful public-private partnership to expand, improve, and innovate at the Omaha VA Medical Center.  Nebraska continues to lead the nation with creative public-private partnerships to assist our veterans.  As a critical part of our national defense infrastructure, the Air Force’s 55th Wing conducts surveillance, intelligence, reconnaissance, and United States Strategic Command cyber missions from the Offutt Air Force Base in Bellevue.  Among its several dozen airplanes is the OC-135B, which fly in critical support of the Open Skies Treaty, a 34-member global agreement that enables unarmed observation of signatory compliance with international nuclear arms agreements, particularly that of the Russian Federation.  To ensure continued successful oversight of treaty compliance, I recently joined with members of the Nebraska Congressional delegation to secure funding for the OC-135B Aircraft Replacement Program as part of the 2019 Defense Appropriations Act.  One plane is funded for 2019; another will be funded in 2020.  The replacement of these aircraft is vital to our national defense strategy.  Their advanced age and maintenance issues had impacted the Air Force’s ability to fully execute the mission of the Open Skies Treaty—one of the last remaining functional arms control regimes between the U.S. and the Russian Federation.  On the heels of a new headquarters for United States Strategic Command at Offutt Air Force Base, work is also underway to repair the Offutt runway.  As part of this effort, the Lincoln Airport will soon begin infrastructure improvements to pave the way for intelligence-gathering aircraft from the Air Force’s 55th Wing while the Offutt runway is rebuilt.  Along with other improvements, the Lincoln Airport’s maintenance hangar will be expanded to accommodate the larger military aircraft.  Once the Offutt runway project is completed in December, 2020, the improved facilities will be returned to the Lincoln Airport for its ongoing use.  Other recent infrastructure accomplishments concern civilian aviation.  Late last week, the President signed into law the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act, which the House passed late last month.  The bill authorized funding for the FAA for five years and makes several changes designed to help airline passengers.  This is a big bill, but even small things can matter in it.  The community of Columbus brought to my attention a particularly local problem.  And we offered an amendment that allowed the Columbus Airport to use their fair share of federal funding to fix something that seems silly: Snow removal equipment bought with local funds could not be housed in federally financed facilities.  Now the Columbus Airport has access to funding for a new, much larger storage facility.  One of the more colorful characters in our nation, Elon Musk, who sort of runs Tesla I guess, and has all kinds of other Iron Man visions for the world, spends a lot of sleepless nights dreaming about the future of infrastructure.  In the meantime, as Mr. Musk figures out a way to get us to the moon, let’s make sure the everyday stuff works well on earth.    Sincerely, ￼  Congressman Jeff Fortenberry 

P.S. If you would like to send my office an email reply, please visit my website, Fortenberry.house.gov, or communicate with me on my Facebook and Twitter pages.

Subject: Wrongly imprisoned American pastor coming home!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





Pastor Brunson released!
￼
Pastor Andrew Brunson. Photo: www.uscirf.gov
What's new:  Earlier today, Andrew Brunson, a Christian pastor from the United States, was released from house arrest in Turkey and is free to return home after being unjustly detained for over two years. This is great news and I applaud President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence for their work to help secure his release. I also have long pressured the Turkish government to free Pastor Brunson as no evidence substantiated any of the alleged terrorism charges against him. Pastor Brunson’s release was long overdue, and I hope he can return to the U.S. as quickly as possible.  Why it matters:   Pastor Brunson’s release is important as it demonstrates the Trump Administration’s continued commitment to religious freedom at home and abroad. It further highlights the need to continue to advocate and work hard to secure the release of other Americans and prisoners currently detained for exercising their freedom of religion. The freedom to practice your religion without a fear of persecution is a human right that knows no borders and the United States must hold governments around the world accountable when those inalienable and universal rights are infringed upon. 
What’s next:
Pastor Brunson is returning to North Carolina. And whether it’s in Turkey, China, or elsewhere around the globe, I will continue to be a strong advocate for supporting religious freedom at home and abroad.

Steve Daines United States Senate

Subject: Work Week with Congressman Faso
Message:
￼ 
  

Share on: 
￼ ￼
Work Week with Congressman Faso
Table of contents
	•	In the Wake of Tragedy, Schoharie Residents Unite
	•	Advocating for Increased Transparency and Lower Costs for Patients
	•	U.S. Thwarts Chinese Espionage
	•	Meeting with MAMCO Precision Molding in Oneonta
	•	Concerns with Expanded Ethanol Sales
	•	Working to Minimize Impact of Soaring Recycling Costs
	•	Delivering Books to the Stamford Village Library
	•	Touring our Nation's Capital
	•	Social Security Beneficiaries to Receive Significant COLA Bump in 2019
	•	Next Week: Dutchess County Veterans Resource Fair

In the Wake of Tragedy, Schoharie Residents Unite
The tragic limo accident in Schoharie shocked the conscience of our Upstate New York communities. My prayers are with all who were impacted by this horrific accident, including the families and friends that lost loved ones and the emergency personnel that responded to the scene.
On Wednesday evening, I joined members of the Schoharie community who gathered to remember the 20 innocent lives lost and to thank the brave first-responders for their service. Resilience is a thread that runs through this community. In a time of great sadness, our neighbors in Schoharie have come together with unity and strength to support each other and to honor the legacies of those they’ve lost.
You can read more about the touching vigil here: https://bit.ly/2OXqgfQ  
￼

Working to Increase Transparency and Lower Costs for Patients
On Wednesday, President Trump signed two bills into law to prohibit pharmacy “gag clauses.” These gag clauses have severely distorted prescription costs by preventing pharmacists from telling patients about cheaper drug options. Signing this bipartisan legislation will increase transparency and lower healthcare costs for consumers.   I helped to pass these important bills in the House, and I will continue to work to remove barriers to affordable, quality care for our seniors and families in Upstate New York. You can read more about this legislation here: https://nbcnews.to/2CEPBWm

U.S. Thwarts Chinese Espionage
“China has for years used spycraft and cyberattacks to steal American corporate, academic and military information to bolster its growing economic power and political influence.”
China continues to develop its economy and influence by swindling American innovation. By charging a Chinese agent with economic espionage and extraditing him to the U.S. to stand trial, we are taking an important step in halting China’s dangerous activity. 
You can read more here: https://nyti.ms/2PskhNj

Meeting with MAMCO Precision Molding in Oneonta
Earlier this week, I joined the team at MAMCO Precision Molding to tour their state-of-the-art facilities in Oneonta. MAMCO is a leading custom plastic injection molder, with clients in New York State, across the U.S., and around the world. In addition to manufacturing parts for various industries, including automotive and aerospace, MAMCO also produces cutting-edge anti-microbial maple spouts used in maple sugaring operations.   As Upstate New Yorkers, we value fresh, high quality local maple syrup and recognize the importance of our state's growing maple industry. These spouts help prevent bacterial growth, which leads to increased sap yields and syrup production.

￼

￼

Concerns with Expanded Ethanol Sales
President Trump recently proposed removing restrictions on the sale of gasoline with 15-percent ethanol (E15) to expand the sale of E15 year-round. Currently, the sale of E15 is prohibited during the summer months due to concerns that it will produce more smog in hotter temperatures. 
I am opposed to this expansion. When ethanol is mixed with gasoline, it draws moisture into the fuel system which accelerates corrosion and fouls many engines - we should not be adding more. I am also concerned that this increased amount will result in emission levels that will exceed the Clean Air Act during the summer months and that is unacceptable.
Read more about the directive here: https://bit.ly/2CGHQ27

Working to Minimize Impact of Soaring Recycling Costs
Restrictive changes to recycling standards by the Chinese government have had serious impacts on local recycling agencies across Upstate New York. Costs have soared, and these agencies are left with few options. Columbia County, for example, is considering a resolution to allow the county Solid Waste Department to charge a $50 fee for those who utilize its recycling services to offset the rising costs associated with processing recyclables.
I have been working with local leaders to address this issue and urged U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to intervene during ongoing trade negotiations to ensure that we have a cost-effective way of removing recyclable materials. You can read the letter I sent to Ambassador Lighthizer here: https://bit.ly/2OW5gpS
Additional information about the proposed fee hike in Columbia County can be found here: https://bit.ly/2QMANrL

Delivering Books to Stamford Village Library
Reading is an important way in which we expand our knowledge, boost our creativity, and foster a lifelong love of learning. I had the pleasure of stopping by the Stamford Village Library this week to deliver books my office collected through the Library of Congress' Surplus Book Program.  The Surplus Book Program allows for the donation of books from the Library of Congress to public libraries, schools, and museums, as well as to other nonprofit organizations and government offices. This is a great program that allows local schools and libraries to continue to build their book collections at no cost to them. 
Library Manager, Pat Parks, and members of the Board of Trustees were kind enough to show me around and discuss the many programs the library offers to the greater Stamford community.
￼

￼


Touring our Nation's Capital
If you are in the Washington D.C. area and would like to tour the U.S. Capitol, White House, or the many other sites throughout the city, please contact my office at (202) 225-5614. Recently, my wife, Mary Fran, brought two groups to the White House - Joan and Laura from Staatsburg and Robert, Joann, Thomas and Theresa from East Schodack.
￼

￼

Social Security Beneficiaries to Receive Significant COLA Bump in 2019
The Social Security Administration announced a 2.8 percent cost of living adjustment (COLA) for 2019 – the largest increase in seven years. With over 60 million beneficiaries on Social Security, these benefits often serve as a financial lifeline for our seniors in Upstate New York. As estimates show that over 15 million seniors rely on their social security benefits to stay out of poverty, it’s important that their payments continue to adequately reflect the cost of living. 
I am working with my colleagues in the House on thoughtful and effective long-term solutions to ensure the continuation of this important program. I am an original cosponsor of H.R. 3423, the Social Security Commission Act of 2017, legislation that would create a committee to advise Congress on guaranteeing the strength and stability of Social Security for the next 75 years.
You can read more about the 2019 COLA adjustment here: https://on.mktw.net/2RKlIrI
If you or anyone you know is having difficulties with social security benefits, my office may be able to help. Feel free to call my Kinderhook District Office at (518) 610-8133 and my staff will be available to assist you.  

Next Week: Dutchess County Veterans Resource Fair
On October 20th, I am hosting a Veterans Resource Fair at the Pleasant Valley Town Hall, located at 1554 Main Street in Pleasant Valley. At this event, local veterans can learn about important opportunities and resources available to them. They will have the chance to meet and speak with representatives from community outreach programs as well as from county, state, and federal agencies.

One of my greatest priorities as your Representative is to ensure veterans have access to the benefits earned through their brave and heroic service to our country. Should you have any questions about this event, please feel free to contact my office at (845) 514-2322. 

￼

Subject: CORRECTED: Newsletter from Congresswoman Carol Shea-Porter
Message:
Open this e-mail in its own browser window  
News from Congresswoman Shea-Porter
￼
NEWS FROM THE FIRST DISTRICT
Dear Friends, 
We got some very good news across the state this week. I was pleased to announce that several organizations and cities across New Hampshire will be receiving resources from multiple federal agencies to help support victims of sexual violence, secure our schools, and help children impacted by the opioid crisis. The City of Manchester will also be receiving nearly $1.6 million to prepare students for postsecondary education. 
The week before last in Washington, I introduced legislation to address wildlife diseases that hurt species we need for pollination, like the Little Brown Bat, which has been devastated by white-nose syndrome in New Hampshire. And in the district, I presented Korean War Veteran Donald Medbery with four service medals he earned while serving in the US Air Force. 
Presenting Donald Medbery with his service medals 
This week, I presented Korean War Veteran Donald Medbery with four service medals he earned while serving in the US Air Force and Air Force Reserve from 1953-1960. Mr. Medbery is an American patriot, and we are all inspired by his service. Mr. Medbery earned the Good Conduct Medal, National Defense Service Medal, Korean Service Medal, and the United Nations ‘Korean’ Service Medal. Like many veterans from the Korean War era, Mr. Medbery did not receive the medals he was awarded while he was serving, and his records were lost in the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) fire in 1973. At my request, and with supporting documents provided by Mr. Medbery, the NPRC authorized the shipment of Mr. Medbery’s medals. Like all of the other veterans we have had the pleasure of serving in our office, he is modest about his service but happy to tell the funny stories. It was a great honor to present him with his medals. 
￼ 
Standing up for Wildlife Refuges and working to address wildlife diseases 
Last week, I led a letter with the top Democrat on the Natural Resources Committee, Raul Grijalva, to the National Wildlife Refuge System requesting additional information on their decision to disarm refuge managers who also have a law enforcement role stopping illegal hunting and other illegal activities on refuge lands. I am concerned that removing these dual function officers, and replacing them with fewer full-time officers, will lead to less geographic coverage for the more than 560 refuges across the United States and could put them in danger.  
I also introduced legislation that would help address wildlife diseases that are devastating important species. In New Hampshire, only one Little Brown Bat was found this past winter compared to the more than 3,000 that would regularly hibernate before the population was decimated by white-nose syndrome. Wildlife diseases are a threat to our nation’s economy, food security, and environmental health. The Interior Department has to have the ability to monitor wildlife diseases and coordinate an effective response to these emergencies as they arise. This bill would help address the threats posed by wildlife diseases by allowing the Interior Department to declare and rapidly coordinate responses to wildlife disease emergencies such as white-nose syndrome, which have devastated bat populations in places around the country. My legislation would create a federal Wildlife Disease Committee to help federal agencies and state governments respond to these diseases, and it would establish a grant program to fund states’ efforts to counter these diseases.
Calling for faster action from DOD to replace dangerous PFC-based firefighting foam 
While I appreciate the Department of Defense’s efforts to address PFAS contamination and to develop and field a replacement firefighting foam that does not contain PFAS chemicals, it is clear that this work will take many more years and is not progressing as quickly as is needed. I secured a provision in this year’s Defense Authorization to require DoD to brief Congress on its efforts to replace this foam, and I expect this briefing to show considerably more progress towards attaining our shared goal of reducing the use of this dangerous foam. I commend those in New Hampshire and across the country who are speaking up and demanding action, and I agree with Ms. Amico, the founder of Testing for Pease, that these chemicals do not deserve the benefit of the doubt. Those who have polluted our groundwater, including DoD, must pay for the costs of cleaning up the contamination and for ensuring that the public has all the information it needs about these chemicals and their health impacts.
Funding programs that support victims of sexual assault 
Law enforcement must have the tools and resources it needs to investigate sexual assault cases, and this $650,000 in funding from the US Department of Justice will help our police departments and victims seek justice. I was pleased to announce this federal funding last week, which will help address the backlog of untested sexual assault kits. With these grants, the New Hampshire DOJ will also hire a specialist to work with victims to ensure their cases are investigated, and it will create an online system to allow victims to easily see the status of their assault kit test. It’s so important that victims have confidence that their assault kits will be tested and their cases investigated, and this funding will help our state achieve this goal.
Helping Manchester students 
Last week, the Congressional Delegation announced that the City of Manchester will be receiving nearly $1.6 million to help prepare students for postsecondary education. Too many middle and high school students struggle to access the support they need to help them prepare for secondary and higher education. By funding innovative approaches and traditional teaching supports, this grant from the US Department of Education will help current sixth- and seventh-graders throughout their time in Manchester’s schools to be better prepared for the next steps in their education. Congratulations to the City of Manchester, the New Hampshire College and University Council, and all those who partnered to design the GEAR UP Manchester program. This grant will help give these children a bright future. 
Supporting children impacted by the opioid crisis 
I was pleased to announce last week that the New Hampshire Department of Justice will be receiving $750,000 to bolster services for children who have been impacted by the opioid crisis. The opioid crisis doesn’t discriminate based on age, and children are especially vulnerable to the impacts of this devastating epidemic. I am pleased that our state will be receiving this essential federal funding to provide Manchester children with the support they need. These services will include mental health care in schools, trauma support groups for students, and training for school staff to help students who are exposed to trauma, including the trauma that occurs when a close family member is struggling with a substance use disorder. 
Protecting students in the classroom 
All children have a right to safe schools and classrooms. I am pleased that the Federal Bureau of Justice Assistance at the US Department of Justice has awarded $1.25 million to New Hampshire to help protect our students by supporting crisis training, threat assessment, and intervention response programs that prevent and stop violence in schools. These are important programs that need to be funded, but Congress must also take action to help stop gun violence by passing common sense reforms. 
Closing thoughts 
Last Monday was World Lung Day, when we highlighted the importance of healthy lungs and the need to prevent and find a cure for lung diseases. My interest in lung health has driven many of the issues I’ve worked on, from starting the Congressional Asthma and Allergy Caucus, to helping pass the Affordable Care Act and limiting the Defense Department’s use of burn pits overseas. www.Lung.org   
Last Monday was also National Voter Registration Day! Please take a moment to make sure you and your family are registered to vote. For more information, visit: https://www.usa.gov/register-to-vote 
It was great to run into veteran advocates from the Disabled American Veterans (DAV) New Hampshire at the Deerfield Fair! Thank you for continuing to serve our nation by helping other veterans. https://www.dav.org/ 
￼   Best Wishes, ￼  Carol Shea-Porter Member of Congress ￼￼ 
This Weeks Press Releases:

	•	Shea-Porter and Grijalva Question Trump Administration Decision to Disarm and Decommission Dual Status National Wildlife Refuge Officers
	•	Shea-Porter Introduces Legislation to Address Growing Threat from Wildlife Diseases
	•	NH Delegation Announces $650K to Support Victims of Sexual Assault
	•	Shaheen, Hassan & Shea-Porter Announce $1.6M to Prepare Manchester Students for Postsecondary Education
	•	NH Delegation Announces $1.2M to Support NH Youth Victimized by Opioid Crisis
	•	NH Delegation Urges Trump Administration to Prioritize the Dredging of Hampton-Seabrook Harbor

Two Democratic members of Congress are asking for answers from the administration regarding news that the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) is cancelling a key law enforcement program at National Wildlife Refuges.

The congressional delegation from New Hampshire is requesting that emergency dredging of Hampton Harbor be included in the Army Corps of Engineers’ work plan for the 2019 fiscal year.
  
Manchester schools to benefit from grant money aimed at getting low-income students into college 
Union Leader // Paul Feely 
City schools are being touted as the major beneficiaries of a federal grant that will provide $10.5 million over the next seven years to help prepare low-income students succeed in college.On Tuesday, U.S. Sens. Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan, both Democrats, and Rep. Carol Shea-Porter, D-NH, announced a Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) grant for $1,572,534 per year over the next seven years to the New Hampshire College & University Council.
