Subject: You’re Invited – Building Inclusive Workplaces for Women of Color
Message:
￼ 
  
 
Dear Lindsey, 
Women of color are strong, smart, and capable. We lead our communities, our families, and often the country. 
But all too often, we face discrimination, prejudice and closed doors in the workplace. 
Women of color face vast wage gaps. Black women earn an average of just 62 cents compared to white male men. Native American women earn just 57 cents on the dollars. And for Latinas, it’s even worse -- just 54 cents.
These wage gaps add up -- if we closed the disparity in earnings, the average black woman would earn enough every year to pay for two and a half years of child care! 
We need to do better.  
As we add new job opportunities in the tech, green energy, and health care industries, we need to ensure that women of color are at the table.  
I hope you’ll join me this weekend for a Summit on Women of Color in the Health, Justice, and Tech Workforces. I’ll be hosting a discussion with experts and fellow members of the Congressional Black Women & Girls Caucus on how to open doors for women of color in these growing industries. 
Our conversation will start at 9:30 am on Saturday, October 13th at Merritt College in Oakland, and we welcome your thoughtful participation. 
I hope to see you there, and as always, my office is happy to assist you and your family. If you need help with a federal issue, please call my Oakland office at (510) 763-0370. You can also connect with me via email, facebook, twitter, and Instagram. 
In Solidarity, 
￼ 
  
P.S. Space for the summit is limited. Please follow this link to register for the event.

Subject: Comstock Introduces Metro Oversight, Grant Legislation
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
The Comstock Connection
News From The Office Of Congresswoman Barbara Comstock
￼ 
Our District
Biography
Media Center
Services
Contact Me

￼  Comstock Introduces Metro Oversight, Grant Legislation  By Renss Greene 
Rep. Barbara Comstock has introduced legislation aiming to get more money into Metro—and more oversight of its operations.
Comstock said she introduced the “Grants for Reliable, Efficient, and Accountable Transit” or GREAT Act after conversations with local, state, and business leaders around her similar legislation last year. Although that bill, the Metro Accountability and Reform Act, stalled in committee, the Metro leadership and the states since then have agreed to a number of funding and administrative reforms.
 “In light of the reforms and changes that have been made collectively there, we wanted to try to scale back our bill to do a more narrow bill that would complement what DC, Maryland and Virginia did,” Comstock said. 
And she said the possibility of bringing Amazon’s new headquarters to the region brought the legislation new attention and urgency.
“Because of the whole Amazon situation, you all of a sudden had a renewed interest,” Comstock said. 
Among the bill’s measures: reauthorizing the federal Passenger Rail Investment and Improvement grant program for $1.5 billion of 10 years, contingent on $500 million matches from Virginia, Maryland and DC; new whistleblower protections, similar to federal whistleblower protections; moving Metro employees from defined pension plans to savings plans like 401Ks; and narrowing the role of arbitrators in labor disputes.
It also targets union power by creating new protections for union whisteblowers. 
The bill comes months after a contentious debate in the Virginia General Assembly on increased transit funding that resulted in some money being moved from the Northern Virginia Transportation Authority to Metro.
“We have to have people getting back to Metro and knowing it’s a reliable form of transportation,” Comstock said. “We have in this area—certainly in my district in Virginia—we have a high number of professionals, so when you have professionals going to work, they need reliable ways to get to work.”
The bill does not commit to filling a hole in the federal government’s contributions to Metro: capital costs. The federal government only contributes to Metro’s operating costs, while much of Metro’s cost overruns in recent years can be attributed to delayed or neglected capital expenditures like major rail and station maintenance and railcar replacements.
“We’re working to continue the money. I’ve gotten the full funding that has been committed, and we’ve fought for that even against my own guys sometimes, but what we haven’t got is some really just modest reforms that have been recommended by a bipartisan coalition,” Comstock said.
Del. Karrie K. Delaney (D-67) and David A. Reid (D-32), Loudoun’s representatives on the state House of Delegates transportation committee, were unavailable for comment. 
You may read the article at the Loudoun Now here.

Subject: Updates from Rep. Huffman
Message:
News from Representative Jared Huffman  Click here if having trouble viewing     Click here to open a plain text version     Forward 
￼
 
WEBSITE
BIOGRAPHY
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWSROOM
LEGISLATION
 
 ￼
 ￼
 ￼
 ￼
Dear Friend,  This month, I am back in my beautiful congressional district travelling up and down the coast from Marin to the Oregon border after a busy few weeks in Washington.  As always, I am grateful for all of the feedback and community engagement I get on the issues of the day, from climate change to health care to the Senate’s confirmation hearings on Brett Kavanaugh. Here’s an update on what else I’ve been working on, both locally and back in Washington.   In the Second District 
	•	Fighting Climate Change: I recently joined North Coast leaders to discuss strategies for maintaining forward progress in the fight against climate change. As a community, and a state, we must do everything we can to protect our earth. From abandoning the 2016 Paris Climate Accord to rolling back protections so corporate polluters can leak more methane into the air our kids breathe, the Trump administration regularly puts polluters over people. It was a productive discussion with community leaders and an amazing fellow panelist, Christiana Figueres, an architect of the Paris Climate Accord, about the power of state, local, and non-governmental organization leadership and the importance of accelerating our work to confront what I believe is one of the greatest environmental, economic and moral imperatives of our time.
	•	Hearing From You at Town Halls: Town halls are an important time for me to answer constituent questions and share my policy perspectives, and the response to the dozens of town halls we’ve held over the past two years has been remarkable – more than 13,000 constituents have participated (with additional participants joining us online). Most recently, I held a town hall in Marin on Holding the President Accountable with special guests, Audrey Cooper, Editor-in-Chief of the San Francisco Chronicle, and Melinda Haag, Former U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of California, as well as a town hall in Petaluma, where I got to answer your questions about a range of issues from the status of Judge Kavanaugh’s nomination to Special Counsel Mueller’s investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. This week, I’ll be heading to two more in Mendocino County on fire recovery and other topics. If you haven’t been able to attend one of our recent town halls, don’t worry – we’ll keep them coming!  I hope to see you at a community event soon. 
	•	Visiting Schools Across the District: One of my favorite parts of being a Representative is getting the opportunity to talk with students and visit schools throughout the district. Since school started, I have visited a number of schools including Fort Bragg High School, Miller Creek Middle School in San Rafael and  San Antonio High School in Petaluma. I enjoyed the wide ranging dialogue with these young, intelligent and civic-minded students about how their government works, current events, and some of my policy work in Congress. I also shared information about opportunities like the Veterans’ History project, Congressional App Challenge, and Congressional Art Competition.
￼ 
Back in Washington 
	•	I urged a postponement of Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination proceedings: I joined 65 of my colleagues in sending a letter to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell in response to the allegations of sexual assault and misconduct against Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh. In this letter, we urged a postponement of further nomination proceedings in response to the allegations of sexual assault and misconduct against Judge Kavanaugh. While the Constitution is clear that the review and approval of Supreme Court nominations are the responsibility of the Senate, I have expressed my strong opposition to Judge Kavanaugh -- both in my role as an elected member of the House of Representatives, and as an American.
	•	I sent a letter advocating for the preservation of our public lands: I sent a bipartisan letter to Speaker Paul Ryan and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi urging that the Land and Water Conservation Fund be permanently reauthorized and fully funded before it expires. Over the past 50 years, the Land and Water Conservation Fund has helped preserve public lands here in California and across the country and provided outdoor recreation opportunities for generations of Americans.
	•	My bipartisan bill authorizing long-term leases for historic ranches and dairies in the Point Reyes National Seashore passed the House!:  I introduced H.R. 6687  to reaffirm Congress’ longstanding intent to continue authorizing historic ranches and dairies in a portion of the Point Reyes National Seashore, consistent with all environmental laws and public planning processes.  This honors a policy directive from former Interior Secretary Ken Salazar six years ago to provide long-term permits so that multigenerational ranching families have the certainty and clarity they need to continue operating.  The bill is supported by the Marin County Board of Supervisors (unanimous vote), Marin Agricultural Land Trust, and Marin Conservation League, among other groups, and has received very positive editorials from the North Bay’s two largest newspapers, the Marin Independent Journal and Press Democrat.  For more information on the bill, click here. 
	•	I secured two key wins for rural air service and pilots on the North Coast: The bipartisan Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act of 2018 will provide vital long-term funding for aviation safety, improve passenger experience, and will set in motion critical reforms to FEMA’s disaster response and recovery programs to better prepare the North Coast for disasters. In addition to these national gains, the legislation includes provisions I authored to improve rural air service for small community airports like the California Redwood Coast - Humboldt County Airport and increase the equitable treatment of forestry and fire protection pilots.
	•	I introduced the Northwest California Wilderness, Recreation, and Working Forests Act: After hearing from countless constituents and stakeholders on my draft legislation to address these issues, I introduced this carefully developed bill to protect the communities and lands we value the most. This bill will guard communities against wildfires, provide local jobs, restore lands impaired by illegal marijuana growing operations, and protect many of Northwest California’s spectacular wild places and pristine streams. 
￼ 
Please don’t be a stranger. Contact me via Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, email, or call one of my district offices and we will continue to help to the best of our ability. And check out my Off the Cuff w. Rep. Huffman podcast to hear my longer take on pressing policy questions.    With Best Regards,  Jared Huffman Member of Congress

Subject: Standing Up For Americans With Pre-Existing Conditions
Message:
The Durbin Report: A message from Senator Richard J. Durbin
￼ 


Fellow Illinoisan, 
It was only one year ago that Congressional Republicans and President Trump cheered on efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and all of its patient protections for pre-existing conditions.  They fell just one vote short in the Senate of disrupting our entire health care system.
This week, Republicans in the Senate decided to continue on their path of health care sabotage and voted against Senator Tammy Baldwin’s (D-WI) resolution to overturn the Trump Administration’s “junk” health insurance plans.  These “junk” plans will be especially harmful for people with any kind of medical history or pre-existing condition such as asthma, diabetes, high blood pressure, or a history of cancer. 
So what exactly are “junk" health care plans? Earlier this year, the Trump Administration finalized a rule that would return the health care system to the dark days when insurance companies could refuse to cover people with pre-existing conditions and raise premiums significantly for older Americans.  Under the rule, health insurance companies will be able to peddle “junk” health insurance plans that don’t have to provide essential health benefits like maternity care, prescription drug costs, substance abuse treatment, mental health services, and emergency room visits. These plans will also be able to deny coverage to people with pre-existing conditions, or charge them prohibitively expensive premiums. 
￼ 
DURBIN SPEAKS ON OVERTURNING JUNK HEALTH INSURANCE PLANS 
I voted in favor of Senator Baldwin’s resolution to overturn President Trump’s “junk plan” expansion because more than five million Illinoisans with a pre-existing condition are counting on quality health insurance to be there when they need it most.  These Illinoisans depend on the fundamental protections guaranteed by the Affordable Care Act. I’m dismayed Republicans disagree with this basic premise. 
We have to remain vigilant when it comes to protecting our health care from the Trump Administration’s sabotage. No one should have to pay higher premiums or be tricked into buying a worthless junk plan. And no one should be denied coverage because they have a pre-existing condition or medical history. No one knows what tomorrow will bring, and that’s why I’ll always stand up against efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. What we should be doing now is working together to improve upon the law and make health insurance more affordable for working families still struggling to make ends meet. 
Sincerely, 
U.S. Senator Dick Durbin

Subject: Invite:
Message:
￼ 
Lindsey – No one should ever be denied an education because they can’t afford it. 

But today, skyrocketing costs are making college more and more unaffordable. We must make sure people can get the help they need to get ahead. 

That’s why my office is partnering with the Sacramento CAL-SOAP Consortium to hold Cash for College Workshops this fall to help young people and their families apply for financial aid.

Click HERE to RSVP for a Cash for College Workshops this October!

￼
Meeting with U.C. Davis graduate students in my Washington, D.C. office.

These workshops are a great opportunity to get free, in-person help from trained volunteers.

At these Workshops, folks can get help navigating their Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and other financial aid opportunities. Students and their families will likely need several documents when applying, so be sure to click here to learn what you should bring.

It’s been ten years since the 2008 economic crisis. Thankfully, our economy is stronger and many folks are back on their feet, but we still have more work to do to make sure our students are ready for the workforce – and that starts with a good education.

If you’re interested in attending a Cash for College Workshop, please visit my website to learn more or RSVP. You may also call my office at (916) 635-0505 to ask any questions!

Be well,
￼
Ami Bera, M.D.
Member of Congress
P.S. Your thoughtful suggestions always help my office do a better job of serving you.

Subject: BREAKING NEWS – Legislation Signed Into Law Prohibiting 'Gag Clauses' for Pharmacies
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
Can't see the pictures? Select "Always display images" or view this message in your browser 
￼

 
October 11, 2018
 

Do you support allowing pharmacists to share lower drug prices with patients?


Yes, I support allowing pharmacists to share lower drug prices with patients.

No, I oppose allowing pharmacists to share lower drug prices with patients

I don't know/have no opinion.

Click to open in a separate window

Dear Friend,
Good news! 
President Trump has signed two bills into law removing barriers preventing pharmacists from helping patients find the least expensive way to purchase their prescription drugs.
The “Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act (S.2554)” and the “Know the Lowest Price Act (S.2553)" prohibit pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) from imposing provisions in pharmacy contracts that bar pharmacists from sharing lower drug prices with patients, also known as “gag clauses.” 
A 2018 report by the Leonard D. Schaeffer Center for Health Policy & Economics determined patients overpaid for their prescription drugs at the pharmacy 23 percent of the time.  As a result, patients may be paying more for their prescriptions than is warranted because of the PBM gag clauses.
As a member of the House Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee I am proud to have helped steer these two bills through Congress.  Like you, I have long believed patients should always pay the lowest cost for their medications at the pharmacy counter.  These new laws will boost transparency in prescription drug purchasing and reduce prescription drug costs for patients. 
Thank you for taking the time to read this important legislative update.   Let me know your thoughts and views by replying to this e-mail or leaving me a message on my Facebook page.  I look forward to hearing from you. 
Best personal wishes,  
￼  Leonard Lance

Subject: Beyer Hosts Fourth Annual Women’s Conference Featuring Naomi Wadler And Del. Danica Roem
Message:
Beyer Hosts Fourth Annual Women’s Conference Featuring Naomi Wadler And Del. Danica Roem
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Congressman Don Beyer will host his Fourth Annual Women’s Conference, Breaking Through: Women Work For Change, to be held Saturday, October 13th, at 8:30 AM at George Mason University’s Arlington Campus. 
George Mason’s Dr. Toni-Michelle C. Travis, Professor of Political Science, will open the Conference and introduce Kaitlyn Oliver, who will lead the Pledge of Allegiance.
Congressman Don Beyer will then offer opening remarks, followed by an opening performance by Carla Dirlikov Canales from The Canales Project. After the performance, the Congressman will introduce Delegate Danica Roem who will deliver the keynote address. After the conclusion of the keynote, Mr. Beyer will present the Clara Mortenson Beyer Women and Children First Award to Naomi Wadler.
Delegate Danica Roem represents the 13th District in the Virginia House of Delegates. She is a 33-year-old step-mom, lifelong resident of Prince William County, and the former lead reporter of the Gainesville Times. Delegate Roem’s inspiring and transformative campaign gained national and international attention. Her victory was secured by sticking to the issues that matter most to her constituents, and never shying away from standing up for justice.  As the first out transgender woman elected to a state legislature, she is blazing a new and unique trail.
Naomi Wadler, 11, organized youth protests at her school in the aftermath of the mass shooting in Parkland, Florida earlier this year. Her subsequent address to crowds at the March For Our Lives in Washington D.C. became an international sensation. Beyer first met Wadler at his Alexandria town hall on gun violence, held weeks after the Parkland shooting.
After the presentation of the Clara Mortenson Beyer Award, Megan Beyer, the former Executive Director of President Obama’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, will moderate the plenary panel, Making History in Virginia with the ERA, with insightful perspectives on the history of the ERA and its future from Lynda Johnson Robb, Delegate Jennifer Carroll Foy and Bettina Hager.
Lynda Johnson Robb is a chairwoman, advocate for literacy, and the eldest daughter of President Lyndon Johnson. Ms. Robb chaired President Jimmy Carter’s Advisory Committee for Women that promoted women’s equality in American policy and culture. Delegate Carroll Foy currently represents the 2nd House District, part of Prince William and Stafford County, and is a public defender, lifelong Virginian, and foster mom. Bettina Hagar is the DC Director and COO of the ERA Coalition and Fund for Women’s Equality.
Following this, breakout sessions will be held on the following topics:
Starting a Movement – Mobilizing Support and Driving Solutions
Michelle Millben – CEO and Founder, MGMC Enterprises LLC. 
Kim Anderson – Executive Vice President, Democracy Alliance 
Jennifer Herrera – Virginia Chapter Leader, Moms Demand Action
Miriam Gennari – Environmental Advocate
Gender and the Supreme Court—Understanding the Impact on Women’s Issues
Jill Morrison — Executive Director Women’s Law & Public Policy Fellowship Georgetown University
Rebecca Buckwalter-Poza – Journalist
Emily Martin – Vice President for Education & Workplace Justice, National Women’s Law Center
Conference participants have the opportunity to choose which of the breakout sessions to attend after the plenary concludes.
This event is free to the public. Attendees must register online here or by contacting Rep. Beyer’s District Office at (703) 658-5403. 


Find Me On Social Media

Subject: Working for Wisconsinites
Message:

￼ 
Home 
About Ron 
Issues 
Wisconsin's 3rd District 
Constituent Services 
Newsroom

October 11, 2018 
Dear friend, 
As someone born-and-raised in western Wisconsin, I am proud to work every day on solutions for the issues that matter most to our communities.
Medicare Open Enrollment is Around the Corner From October 15 to December 7, all Wisconsinites with Medicare can change their Medicare health plans and prescription drug coverage for the following year to better meet their needs.  If you have questions about signing up or want to talk through your options with a trained professional, call 1-800-MEDICARE or visit Medicare.gov. My office can also help connect you with the right person to find more information about plans.
Fighting for Wisconsin Workers and Farmers Earlier this month, the President announced an updated North American Free Trade Agreement, better known as NAFTA. I agree that American workers, farmers and families need an updated NAFTA agreement for the 21st century. The trilateral deal announced is a step forward in this process, but now it’s time for us to come together to discuss the outstanding issues that remain.
Going forward, we need to demand the highest possible labor and environmental standards, lift tariffs hurting Wisconsin, and keep the pressure on the President to get the best deal for America’s Dairyland with both Canada and Mexico. I will continue working with my colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee to ensure our farmers and producers get the best deal possible, and markets stay open and accessible.
Here to Help My office is available to help you work through issues with government agencies and departments. This includes getting copies of service records, receiving benefits, and cutting through government red tape. You can reach the office by calling 1-888-442-8040 or visiting kind.house.gov.
Sincerely,
￼

Subject: Capitol Hill Update from Congressman Castro
Message:
A Message From Representative Joaquin Castro
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window 
Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
ABOUT ME 
LEGISLATION 
NEWS 
ISSUES 
Dear Friend, 
We recently learned that the Administration is shuttling hundreds of migrant children overnight to a tent city in Tornillo, Texas. In response, I wrote Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Secretary Alex Azar requesting more information on these midnight runs, and whether HHS plans to open other temporary shelters for migrant children.  
I also visited the South Texas Family Residential Center this week in Dilley, Texas to follow-up on a letter I led the Hispanic Caucus in asking the Department of Homeland Security for answers following reports that an 18-month-old died from an infection she contracted in this facility. 
We must continue to shed light on the issue of minors held in detention, and reuniting all those children who were separated from their parents as part of the Trump Administration’s zero-tolerance immigration policy. I joined MSNBC’s Ari Melber this week to discuss the latest on immigration. 
Federal Grants for San Antonio 
Congrats to the Education Service Center Region 20 for the $500,000 grant from U.S. Department of Education to improve childhood literacy.  
Congrats to San Antonio College for the $68,000+ grant received for cybersecurity education.  
Congrats to VIA Metropolitan Transit who received $6M from the U.S. Department of Transportation to advance efforts to grow and service VIAtrans fleets.  
Congrats to the University of Texas San Antonio and Northwest Vista College for the $1.5 million in federal funding from the United States Department of Education for the Developing Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program.  
Honoring Veterans in San Antonio 
It was an honor to present medals to World War II United States Army Veteran, Private First Class Milton Sauceda. I am grateful for his service to our nation. 
￼￼ 
Team Castro also attended the Unaccompanied Veteran Burials of US Army Veterans, Mr. David Morales and Mr. Fred Council Jr. On behalf of the San Antonio community, we thank the two Veterans for their service to our great nation.
￼￼ 
Community Outreach 
It was great to sit down with University of Houston-Downtown students in San Antonio to discuss matters surrounding urban Latino communities. I also joined UnidosUS to discuss the Republican tax bill’s harmful effects on San Antonians and the 100+ children who remain separated from their families as part of the Administration’s brutal immigration policies.
￼￼ 
District Updates 
Team Castro joined the University of Texas San Antonio’s Cyber Threat Defender Tournament over the weekend, where students ages 11 and up competed in a cybersecurity-based card tournament; attended the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Luncheon Featuring Dr. Mike Flores, new Alamo Colleges District Chancellor as he laid out his vision for the District in the coming years; and attended the San Antonio’s Single Member Districts Celebrating Equal Representation and a Civil Rights Pioneer discussion at St Mary’s University in remembrance of the first anniversary of the death of Choco Meza among other events around the district.
￼￼￼ 
Foreign Affairs 
Upon Nikki Haley’s resignation as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations, I believe the President should be picking a replacement that is a seasoned diplomat and can navigate the United Nations and U.S. diplomacy well. Watch my full interview with CNN’s Wolf Blitzer here. 
I am also deeply disturbed by the mysterious disappearance of Saudi Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Turkey this week. I joined my colleagues on Capitol Hill in a bipartisan, bicameral letter to the President urging him to raise this issue with the governments of Saudi Arabia and Turkey and for the United States to offer assistance in the investigation. You can also listen to my BBC Newshour interview here.  
As Congress continues to address issues that directly affect San Antonians’ daily lives, I want to hear from you. Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions for me by calling my office at 210-348-8216 or reaching out online through my website, castro.house.gov. 
Sincerely, ￼  Member of Congress

Subject: Montanans should have more say than illegal immigrants
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼





Montanans Should Have More Say Than Illegal Immigrants
￼
Image: ICE.gov
What’s New:  During a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee hearing this week, I pressed the nominee to lead the Census Bureau to support including a citizenship question in the upcoming 2020 Census. This sensible question would provide a simple breakdown of how many citizens and noncitizens—including illegal immigrants—we have in our country, which we currently do not know. Having this basic information is crucial to ensuring proper representation in Congress and proper allocation of federal resources.  Why It Matters:  The Census is conducted every ten years to count the number of individuals living in the United States for the purposes of representation in the U.S. House of Representatives and the distribution of taxpayer dollars to states and localities.  It is common sense for a sovereign nation to know how many citizens and noncitizens are in the country. Unfortunately, it is the total population of the states – including the millions of people here in our country illegally – that is used to make these determinations. That means the Census counts an illegal immigrant hiding in California the same as a hardworking, taxpaying citizen in Montana.  I believe citizens in Montana should have more say in Washington, D.C. than illegal immigrants harboring in sanctuary cities across the country. It makes no sense why a state like California that harbors millions of people here illegally is rewarded with additional representation in Congress and taxpayer resources at the expense of more rural states like Montana. That is rewarding illegal behavior.  What’s Next:  April 1, 2020 is the official date of the Census. Rest assured, I will continue fighting for Montanans to ensure taxpayer dollars are distributed fairly and that the citizens of this country, not illegal immigrants, are properly represented in Congress.   Survey:  
Do you support including the citizenship question in the 2020 Census? 
Yes
No
Unsure

Best Wishes, 
￼
Steve Daines United States Senate

Subject: Fighting Human Trafficking & Funding Alzheimer’s Research
Message:
￼
October 11, 2018 
Fighting Human Trafficking & Funding Alzheimer’s Research 
 


Dear Neighbor,
Recently, the House passed two important bills to fight sexual assault and human trafficking. H.R. 6847, the Preventing Child Exploitation Act of 2018, contains harsher penalties for repeat sex offenders and offenders that fail to register or provide important information to law enforcement. It also extends the statute of limitations for victims of sexual assault as minors. This ensures that that survivors of sexual assault can rightfully seek justice. 
Unfortunately, human trafficking is a big business, and human traffickers generate roughly $150 billion in illegal profits per year. Much of that money moves through our financial and banking system undetected. H.R. 6729, the Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act of 2018, would allow nonprofit organizations to help financial institutions better identify those who are moving around dirty money. Houston has the highest number of trafficking victims nation-wide, and I will continue to do everything in my power to fight modern-day slavery at home in Houston and worldwide. 
Another legislative victory for communities across the nation is the largest-ever funding increase for Alzheimer’s and dementia research at the National Institutes of Health (NIH). More than 5 million Americans are living with this disease and by 2050 this number is projected to rise to nearly 14 million. Because of the recent increases in NIH funding – something I have fought to increase every year I’ve served in Congress - scientists can now work at a more rapid pace to advance our knowledge about the disease, explore ways to reduce risk, uncover new biomarkers for early diagnosis and drug targeting, and develop new treatments. I’m committed to continuing my work in Congress to increase funding for scientific and medical research and to implement policies that improve access to these critical services.
It is an honor and privilege to represent you and Texas in the United States House.
Sincerely,   ￼  John Culberson

Subject: Last chance to curb climate change
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
About David    |     Serving You    |     Issues  |       Newsroom    |     Contact 
GET CONNECTED: 
￼ ￼ ￼  
Dear Lindsey,
  I believe we have a solemn responsibility to protect our natural environment against degradation and destruction. The impact of human activity on the environment is no longer in doubt, the only question is whether we will summon the collective will to mitigate or reverse the damage. On Monday, the Untied Nation’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) released a report indicating that the world has only 12 years to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to limit global warming to moderate levels. The report details the particularly dangerous consequences we will face if we don’t act: extreme food shortages, more frequent and extreme wildfires, continued rise in sea levels, and refugee crises around the globe.  
North Carolina faces particularly significant risks from the impact of climate change. Current and projected impacts for our region indicate additional increases in sea level, greater intensity of hurricanes and storms, heightened spread of diseases, and habitat alterations – especially along our coast.
The scientific evidence linking climate change to human activity is beyond dispute, yet despite progress in recent years, the current administration, along with the help of congressional Republicans, have severely damaged hopes of any comprehensive strategy for mitigating or reversing it.  Moving forward, it is clear that we need ambitious solutions, such as a carbon tax or ‘cap and trade’ policy that will dramatically reduce carbon emissions and incentivize clean energy practices.
As you may know, during the Obama administration, the House passed legislation with my strong support to adopt a “cap-and-trade” system to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but the measure died in the Senate.  Undeterred, the Obama administration also adopted new regulations limiting emissions from vehicles, power plants, and other sources, and negotiated the most sweeping international climate agreement in history, the Paris Climate Agreement. 
Unfortunately, from day one, President Trump has employed a scorched-earth approach to environmental policy, empowering climate deniers and anti-environmental extremists within his administration to systematically dismantle these accomplishments. I cosponsored a resolution along with 181 colleagues in the House condemning President Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris accords, an agreement signed by every country in the world. Equally concerning was his decision to roll back critical, common-sense regulations such as the Clean Power Plan, the ban on offshore drilling along the Outer Continental Shelf, and his relaxation of rules governing vehicle emissions.
As a member of the House Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition (SEEC), I helped lead the effort to oppose President Trump’s decision to re-open the Atlantic Ocean to seismic testing and offshore drilling, and even co-introduced a bill, the Safe COAST Act, to protect offshore drilling safety regulations from interference by the Trump administration. Additionally, as our state’s only member of the Appropriations Committee, I have advocated for robust funding for the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), supported additional funding and research for the Department of Energy’s (DOE) Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, and last year was instrumental in ensuring that the Department of Interior’s (DOI) Climate Science Centers remained open and funded in order to continue conducting important studies on how to adapt to the impacts of climate change. 
We cannot afford to ignore the threat of climate change any longer. I will continue working in Congress to pursue responsible policies that protect our environment, curb human activities that contribute to climate change, and mitigate the impact it has already had on our communities. As Congress continue to debate these issues, I will appreciate knowing of your views.   
Sincerely, 
￼
DAVID E. PRICE
Member of Congress

Subject: Rep. Blum Hosts 2nd Public Event to Combat Opioid Crisis
Message:
￼


October 11, 2018
Contact: Alexah Rogge Tel: 202-225-2911 Email 


Rep. Blum Hosts 2nd Public Event to Combat Opioid Crisis
Dubuque & Cedar Rapids Awarded Grants to Aid Crisis
After hosting an extremely productive Opioid Conference this past July focused on law enforcement efforts, Rep. Blum is planning a second conference on October 17th in Waterloo-- this time focused on health care. 

The conference will be held on October 17, 2018 from 5-7PM at the Iowa Veterans Museum (503 South Street) in Waterloo and will feature a legislative update from Rep. Blum, Keynote Speaker Ann Saba, MPH, Communications and Research Specialist, Injury Prevention and Research Center, University of Iowa, and a panel of area health professionals. 

This year, Congress has passed over 60 opioid bills. Last month, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)  awarded over $1 billion in grants to combat the opioid crisis. This funding includes specific grants to Cedar Rapids ($285,000) and Dubuque ($198,250) through the Expanding Access to Quality Substance Use Disorder and Mental Health Services (SUD-MH) awards. The SUD-MH awards support health centers in implementing and advancing evidence-based strategies that best meet the substance use disorder and mental health needs of the populations they serve.

Congressman Blum commented, “In addition to the millions of Americans dealing with an ongoing opioid addiction, there were 314 deaths in the state of Iowa caused by opioid overdose in 2016. I have worked with my Democrat and Republican colleagues in Washington, D.C. to pass legislation that activates assistance from the federal level. Still, there is more that we can do, and I will be hosting my second Opioid Drug Conference on October 17th to identify potential solutions and discuss the issue on a community level.” 


￼
To RSVP for the Opioid Drug Summit, visit: www.blum.house.gov/ConferenceRSVP
###

Subject: From the Desk of Matt Cartwright
Message:
MATT CARTWRIGHT
17TH DISTRICT, PENNSYLVANIA 


￼ 



October 11, 2018 

I wanted to take a moment and talk about a subject I know is of great importance to you: health care and how much it costs. 
As your Congressman, I am pursuing bipartisan solutions to lower costs, improve the quality of care, and expand coverage.  We need to stabilize the marketplaces so that families in Northeastern Pennsylvania have reliable access to health care.  I believe that Congress must explore policies that have been able to successfully keep costs down in the most innovative U.S. states and in other countries.
This year, I brought together local health care providers, insurers, small business owners, and community leaders in our district for a health care roundtable to help identify solutions that will work for the people of Northeastern Pennsylvania.  There is still more work to be done to guarantee reliable, affordable health care for everyone.  We must secure the critical protections provided by the Affordable Care Act and address the legitimate concerns of those still being left behind by our country's health care system.  I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to pursue improvements to the ACA.

If you would like to stay connected to our office with the latest news, legislation, and other useful information, please sign-up up for my e-newsletter or visit my website. Thank you again for writing, and please do not hesitate to contact my office with any future questions or comments. 
Sincerely, 
￼
Matt Cartwright
Member of Congress
MC/JN

Wednesday, October 10, 2018

Dear Friend, 
Arizonans know Washington is a mess, and they expect our leaders to stop the political games and get things done for everyday families. I recently worked across the aisle to cut through the dysfunction and pass three bipartisan bills through the House of Representatives. These are real solutions that fight human trafficking, protect our country from weapons of mass destruction, and help Arizona veterans pursue homeownership.
Here are some highlights:
I co-introduced the Improving Strategies to Counter Weapons Proliferation Act, with Congressman Scott Tipton (CO-03) to help choke off financing for terrorist organizations and rogue states engaged in weapons proliferation.
I helped pass the Protect Affordable Mortgages for Veterans Act, with Republicans Lee Zeldin (NY-01) and Claudia Tenney (NY-22). I was the lead Democratic cosponsor of this bill to make a critical fix to existing law that helps Arizona veteran homeowners save money and pay off their mortgages, all while ensuring they remain protected from shady lenders.
I also worked across the aisle to pass the Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act of 2018 through the House. The bill empowers qualified nonprofits to share information and report potential human trafficking and money laundering activities to financial institutions so that they can freeze assets and stop traffickers in their tracks.  Click here to watch my floor speech.
￼

I am honored to serve in Congress on behalf of Arizona families like yours. We always appreciate hearing from you on current topics and issues that are important to you. If there is an issue that concerns you, please let us know by clicking this link or by calling our Phoenix office: 602-956-2285. Be sure to stay connected through our Facebook and Twitter accounts, and let us know how we can be of service.
Sincerely,

Subject: State of Emergency Expanded for Hurricane Michael
Message:
￼

 Dear Friends,
Hurricane Matthew is nearing landfall and will be moving north toward Georgia in the coming hours. The hurricane was upgraded this morning to a Category 4 as it approached the Florida panhandle, and Governor Deal expanded the state of emergency in Georgia to include 16 additional counties, bringing the total up to 108 counties in Georgia.
￼  
The 108 counties under emergency declaration are: Appling, Atkinson, Bacon, Baker, Baldwin, Ben Hill, Berrien, Bibb, Bleckley, Brantley, Brooks, Bryan, Bulloch, Burke, Butts, Calhoun, Camden, Candler, Charlton, Chatham, Chattahoochee, Clay, Clarke, Clinch, Coffee, Colquitt, Columbia, Cook, Crawford, Crisp, Decatur, Dodge, Dooly, Dougherty, Early, Echols, Effingham, Elbert, Emanuel, Evans, Glascock, Glynn, Grady, Greene, Hancock, Houston, Irwin, Jasper, Jeff Davis, Jefferson, Jenkins, Johnson, Jones, Lamar, Lanier, Laurens, Lee, Liberty, Lincoln, Long, Lowndes, Macon, Marion, McDuffie, McIntosh, Miller, Mitchell, Monroe, Morgan, Montgomery, Muscogee, Oconee, Oglethorpe, Peach, Pierce, Pulaski, Putnam, Quitman, Randolph, Richmond, Schley, Screven, Seminole, Stewart, Sumter, Talbot, Taliaferro, Tattnall, Taylor, Telfair, Terrell, Thomas, Tift, Toombs, Treutlen, Turner, Twiggs, Upson, Ware, Warren, Washington, Wayne, Webster, Wheeler, Wilcox, Wilkes, Wilkinson and Worth counties.
We are praying for Georgia and our neighboring states as Hurricane Michael makes impact. Governor Deal, the Georgia Emergency Management Agency, the Federal Emergency Management Agency and our first responders, businesses and communities are taking precautions. 
We urge all Georgians to remain vigilant and heed officials’ advice as the storm makes landfall and progresses northward. We remain in close communication with Governor Deal, and Senator Perdue and I will work together in the Senate and do all we can to support preparedness, response and recovery efforts. We’ve written to President Trump urging expedited emergency resources to aid counties in Georgia expected to be impacted by Hurricane Michael.
Please take this time to prepare, hunker down and please follow the advice of all officials in the hours and days ahead. Resources that may be helpful are included below.
Additional Georgia hurricane resources can be found at the links below:
	•	View up-to-date emergency declarations from Governor Deal here .
	•	View updates from Georgia Emergency Management & Homeland Security Agency here . 
	•	Download the Ready Georgia app for weather alerts and emergency preparedness tips. 
	•	Follow Georgia 511 for real-time traffic information. 
	•	Learn what to do before, during, and after a flood here .
	•	Report power outages by contacting your power provider. The two main providers in Georgia are:
	◦	Georgia Power (contact here or at 888-891-0938)
	◦	Georgia electric membership cooperatives (EMCs) (find your local branch here )
	•	Call your local non-emergency police line to report a downed tree in a main road.

Sincerely, Johnny Isakson United States Senator  For future correspondence with my office, please visit my web site at http://www.isakson.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/email-me. You can also click here to sign up for the eNewsletter
￼

Subject: Helping Veterans in Crisis
Message:
Having trouble viewing this email? View it as a Web page.
￼

October 10, 2018
Dear Friend,
It's deeply troubling that our service men and women might return home from battle only to take their own lives because they are tortured by something they experienced during their service. I asked the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) how they are working with the Department of Defense (DOD) to curb veteran suicide during a meeting of the Veterans' Affairs Committee.

I was joined by the Somers family from Coronado, who lost their son, Daniel, to suicide after he suffered post-traumatic stress (PTS) following his service in Iraq. They are now tireless advocates for fixing and reforming the broken health care system at the VA.

Increasing Collaboration
￼
Watch my remarks here.
The National Director of Suicide Prevention for the VA said they would like more information from the DOD about risk factors for suicide. The VA could identify mental health issues sooner if they had access to information about servicemembers’ promotions, disciplinary action, and family support systems.
I also asked what kind of outreach was being done for veterans with other than honorable discharges. Only 115 servicemembers nationwide are enrolled in suicide prevention programs specifically tailored to them, and the VA agreed more outreach was needed.  

Fighting for San Diego Veterans
San Diego has the third largest population of veterans in the country, many of whom are battling mental health issues. Veterans who have experienced homelessness in the last year are particularly at risk, with suicide rates almost double those of veterans without a history of homelessness. We’ve made progress with the HUD-VA Supportive Housing (HUD-VASH) program, which assists San Diego veterans in their search for affordable housing, but there is still work to be done.
I will continue fighting for mental health care and homelessness services for San Diego veterans and will work with both the VA and the DOD to find solutions that ensure we don’t lose another veteran to suicide. 
Sincerely,

￼

Subject: The Latta Letter - October 10, 2018
Message:
￼ 
Home     Serving You     Contact     District     Legislation     Newsroom     About Bob 
Friends, 
As we move into the fall months and embrace the colder weather, I wanted to let you know what I’ve been working on. We have good news in the fight to combat the opioid epidemic, and I have also introduced legislation to help Ohio veterans.  
First, the House and Senate passed H.R. 6, the most significant congressional action against a single drug crisis in history. It’s now heading to the President’s desk and should be signed into law any day. The legislation includes my bill, the INFO Act. Read more below on how the provisions in the legislation will help turn addiction and overdose trends around.
Also, after meeting with members of my Veterans Advisory Group recently, I learned that some Ohio veterans had missed the window to appeal claims denials because delivery of their notification was delayed. It is completely unacceptable that a veteran could lose their ability to appeal a claim because of bureaucratic mistakes. I introduced legislation, the Veterans Right to Expediency Act, to fix this issue by requiring all claim denials be sent by certified mail. Sending these notifications by certified mail will make sure that veterans are made aware of their claim outcomes in a timely manner.
Speaking of veterans, it’s always a moving moment when Flag City Honor Flights make their way to Washington so veterans can see the monuments dedicated to their service and sacrifice. My staff was there on the National Mall to greet these American heroes. Thank you to all of our veterans for everything you’ve done for our great nation.
An update on recent happenings:
 In Congress
Tax Reform 2.0 Will Continue Economic Momentum
Since the passage of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, we’ve seen our economy take off. From record-low unemployment numbers (3.7% overall unemployment, the lowest in 49 years; 3.6% unemployment for women, the lowest in 65 years; and five months of unemployment below 4% this year) and rising wages to sky-high optimism among small businesses and manufacturers – tax reform is making a real difference in people’s lives.
I recently joined my colleagues in passing three pieces of legislation known as “Tax Reform 2.0” to build on this momentum by making the tax relief for small businesses and individuals permanent. Tax Reform 2.0 also includes new policies to help Americans save or start a business.
Tax Reform 2.0 makes permanent provisions from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that: -Lower Tax Rates -Double the Child Tax Credit for Families -Double the Exemption for the Death Tax -Provide the First Ever Paid Family Leave Tax Credit
According to the non-partisan Tax Foundation’s analysis, this will create 1.5 million new jobs, increase wages by 0.9%, and increase GDP by 2.2%. Ohio families are seeing more money in their pockets, American business are growing, and workers are getting jobs – let’s keep the good news going.  
Asking the Experts About the Increase in Deaths Due to Pregnancy-Related Complications
It is very concerning to know that the United States has one of the highest maternal mortality rates in the developed world. This is particularly scary for soon-to-be-mothers and new moms who live in rural areas that lack OBGYN services. I was able to ask March of Dimes President Stacey Stewart about this problem in a recent Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health hearing.  Stewart said many “maternity care deserts” that require women to travel to receive pregnancy care, and the closing of hospitals in rural areas, has been well documented and affect the quality of care women are able to receive. 
In addition, both Stewart and Dr. Lynne Coslett-Charlton, an OBGYN, said there is a significant impact of the opioid misuse crisis on maternal mortality, and solutions to improve these rates from mental health professionals are critical. You can watch my questions here. I'll continue to use my position on the Energy and Commerce Committee to find solutions to decrease maternal mortality rates and keep Ohio mothers healthy.  
Guardian of Small Business Award
I was honored to be named a “Guardian of Small Business” by The National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB), the nation’s largest small business organization. Small businesses create two out of every three new jobs and are the engines of our economy. 
I earned the award based on my 100% pro-small business voting record, and I'll continue to support legislation that helps Ohio’s small businesses and their employees. Because of new policies that decrease regulations, eliminate government red tape, and reduce taxes on small businesses, we’re seeing small business growth and increased job creation.   
Ensuring Our Energy Grid is Safe From Cyberattacks
Keeping our energy grid safe from cyberattacks is a serious national security issue, and one I don’t take lightly. Recently, I questioned a Department of Energy (DOE) official who is charged with heading up grid cybersecurity efforts about what is being done to modernize and upgrade the nation’s energy infrastructure. 
I asked Assistant Secretary Karen Evans at an Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing to talk about the work DOE is already doing to improve coordination between the agency and the private sector to identify and promote cyber-secure products that keep our grid safe. Evans explained that DOE has just begun a pilot program to improve communications between DOE and the private sector.    I’ve already introduced two bipartisan bills to improve this coordination and give the agency the tools needed to upgrade our energy infrastructure and protect our grid from cyber attacks.   
Around the District 
FEMA Grant for Local Fire Departments
I met with Sylvania Township Fire Chief Michael Ramm and other Chiefs from Lucas County recently to discuss a FEMA grant they received that will purchase updated radio equipment for eight area departments. The FEMA grant will help offset costs for equipment that will go a long way to help the men and women in their departments communicate, and better serve the public. Thank you to our first responders for all you do to keep our communities safe.  
Military Service Academy Night
We had a big turn-out of high school students and their family members at an informational meeting at Owens Community College in Findlay. It was inspiring to see so many students interested in attending an academy and serving their country. 
The students were able to talk with representatives from all of the military service academies and find out about the application process. I always look forward to meeting with our country’s future leaders and wish them all the best of luck as they work towards their goal.   Touring Penta Career Center  For the first time in our country’s history, the number of available jobs is greater than the number of people looking for work (6.3 million unemployed with 6.9 million job openings at the end of May). That means there is tremendous opportunity for Ohioans to begin careers – in high-paying fields – if they have the right skills and education. In Northwest and West Central Ohio, we’re blessed to have a number of excellent career centers that help prepare students for the jobs of tomorrow.   I recently toured Penta Career Center in Perrysburg Township to see the programs they have in place to educate students to enter the workforce including welding, fire safety, and advanced manufacturing.  I also spoke about my support of the Strengthening Career and Technical Education (CTE) for the 21st Century Act, legislation which was signed into law recently. The legislation makes a number of key reforms to career and technical education including encouraging better partnerships with employers and local business leaders and streamlining the application process for CTE programs.  
￼
Latta watches students in the fire safety program at Penta Career Center carry out an exercise
 INFO Act Included in Final Opioid Package
Ohio has been especially hard-hit by the opioid crisis with overdoses continuing to rise to record levels in 2017. After hearing from people affected by this crisis, I've worked to find solutions. I authored the Indexing, Narcotics, Fentanyl, and Opioids (INFO) Act after hearing from those on the front lines about difficulties they were having obtaining available funding and needed information.  The INFO Act was recently included the final opioid package negotiated between the House and the Senate and is now on its way to the President's desk. In fact, the Washington Examiner named the INFO Act as one of the 4 key provisions included in the final opioid bill.  The INFO Act will help health care providers, advocates, law enforcement, and local governments by creating a one-stop-shop for communities to find resources and information to combat this epidemic. With nearly $7 billion being made available to combat this epidemic in recent legislation, the INFO Act will help ensure that funding ends up in the hands of the people that can make the biggest difference. 
 
Sky-High Optimism for American Manufacturing 
Ohio's 5th Congressional District is home to more than 60,000 manufacturing jobs. When American manufacturing is doing well, it means Northwest and West Central Ohio are doing well. According to a recent survey by the National Association of Manufacturers, 95.1% of manufacturers have a positive outlook for their companies – an all-time high.   But what does this mean in real terms for the workers and small business owners that make up our manufacturing sector? 
We heard from manufacturers at a recent subcommittee hearing I chaired which included Nikki Moyers, VP of Operations at Perrysburg’s Jerl Machine. Hearing from these manufacturers, it's clear that pro-growth policies like the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act are making a difference for American businesses and their employees. Nikki told us about the impact that tax cuts are having for Jerl Machine which includes higher wages and bonuses for their workers, and more opportunities for their company to take on new business. 
Jerl’s story is just one of many successful companies around Northwest and West Central Ohio, but it paints a picture of the real impact that a booming economy can have. You can watch her opening statement here.

Subject: United States Senator Joe Manchin Newsletter - October 10, 2018
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
 
￼

October 10, 2018 

 
Upcoming Events
  
Manchin Mobile Monday  
Every Monday, my staff members are available in easily accessed locations across the state to assist with constituent services and to take your thoughts and concerns directly back to me.  Below are next week's times and locations for Monday, October 15.      
      
Point Pleasant:            
Mason County Public Central Library 
508 Viand Street 
Time: 2 p.m. - 3:30 p.m.    
Staff: Kim Good 
    
Clarksburg:    
Clarksburg-Harrison Public Library 
404 W Pike Street 
Time: 11 a.m. – 1 p.m.  
Staff: Michael Garcia 
  
To invite the senator to your event, click here. 



  
  





























From the Hill to the Mountains
Defending the Postal Service Against Privatization
I was proud to co-sponsor a Senate resolution opposing the privatization of the United States Postal Service (USPS). Under the previous consolidation implemented by the USPS under the Post Office Structure Plan (POST) in 2012, 478 post offices around West Virginia had their hours drastically reduced to as little as two hours per day. Given that the POST Plan was undertaken after significant backlash against the previous proposal to close thousands of post offices around the country, it stands to reason that nearly the nearly 500 post offices affected by this plan would be vulnerable to closure if USPS were privatized.  
In West Virginia, especially in our rural communities, we understand the importance of our post offices. In many small towns, they are the lifelines of their communities and a way to stay connected. They are more than just places to send and receive mail. I will continue defending rural communities across West Virginia and that includes fighting the privatization of the postal service. 
Read the full resolution here. 
In Your Community
Application Period Open for Hazard Mitigation Assistance Program Grants  
for Fiscal Year 2018  
  
On Monday, October 1, FEMA will begin to accept applications for the Hazard Mitigation Assistance (HMA) for Fiscal Year 2018 (FY 2018). HMA’s two competitive grants programs are Flood Mitigation Assistance (FMA) and Pre-Disaster Mitigation (PDM).  These programs provide funding to states, tribes, territories, and local governments for eligible mitigation activities to strengthen our nation’s ability to reduce disaster losses and protect life and property from future disaster damages.
  
  
  
 
This Week:
Fairmont Regional Job Fair 
Friday, October 12 
11 a.m. to 2 p.m. 
Robert Mollohan Research Center, High Technology Foundation 
  
 
Click here for more. 
 
On the Road
On Friday one of my Regional Coordinators, Mary Jo Guidi, joined the Follansbee Chamber of Commerce in celebrating National Manufacturing Day at Wheeling-Nisshin Steel.  I was honored to provide letters of commendation to Wheeling-Nisshin Inc., Eagle Manufacturing, Mountain State Carbon, and Koppers. 
￼ 
Mary Jo Guidi, Regional coordinator for Senator Manchin, is joined by Chamber President Debbie Puskarich, Executive Director Pat Ford of the Business Development Corp. of the Northern Panhandle, and John White and Jay Mitchell of Eagle Manufacturing. 
  
Key Federal Resources
When West Virginians compete, they win. 
Below are a few grants that were recently awarded through the U.S. Department of Agriculture-Rural Development (USDA-RD).  I encourage West Virginia communities to apply for federal funding opportunities and will be happy to provide a letter of support for eligible applications.  For further information, please contact my Martinsburg office at 304-264-4626 or click here to email me. 
	•	Solar Energy Solutions, LLC, USDA-RD, Rural Energy for America Program ($50,000.00 grant / $100,000.00 loan) This award will be used for the purchase and installation of a 133,894 kW solar array on the Williamstown High School. This project will replace 149,660 kWh (21%) per year and realize $12,224 of saving per year. The purpose of this funding program is to assist farmers, ranchers, and rural small businesses in developing renewable energy systems, and in making energy efficiency improvements to their operations.
	•	Eastern West Virginia Regional Airport, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($22,500.00) This award will be used to complete an economic impact study for the Eastern West Virginia Regional Airport located in Martinsburg, West Virginia. The purpose of the study is to assess the economic value that the airport has on the local and regional economy of the Eastern Panhandle and surrounding area.
	•	Innovative Community Solutions, LLC, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($29,796.00) This award will be used to continue an entrepreneurship and business leadership training program in Berkeley County, West Virginia.
	•	Greenbrier County Health Alliance, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($50,000.00) This award will be used for the development of the Local Foods Skill Center and Waste Not Produce Market in Lewisburg, WV. 
	•	West Virginia National Guard Foundation, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($50,000.00) This award will be used to provide education and technical support to rural businesses. 
	•	Mineral County Development Authority, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($50,000.00) This award will be used to support the purchase of equipment and installation costs associated with the extension of 100Mpbs + broadband service to the Fort Ashby Business Park located in Mineral County, West Virginia. 
	•	Canaan Valley Institute, USDA-RD, Rural Business Development Grant ($49,515.00) This award will be used to develop a hydroponics system to train entrepreneurs and farmers in nontraditional growing methods known as hydroponics.
	•	Town of Moorefield, USDA-RD, Community Facilities Grant ($2,100.00) This award will be used to purchase a new 2018 Dodge Charger Police Vehicle with all pertinent and necessary police equipment. The funding includes an $18,700.00 Rural Development Economic Impact Initiative Grant, and an applicant contribution of $11,022.00. 
 
To learn more, call my office Toll Free at (855) 275-5737, email me,or find me on social media:

Subject: Lewis addresses opioid epidemic
Message:
￼ 
  

Lewis addresses opioid epidemic

Dear Lindsey,
Our country is facing an unprecedented opioid epidemic. Addiction affects millions of individuals and families around the country, and sadly most of us know someone who has been affected by this crisis. Since coming to Congress, I have supported numerous initiatives and even introduced my own piece of legislation in an effort to help our communities stop this crisis.
This spring, I introduced a bill that would direct the Department of Labor to establish an advisory committee on opioids and the workplace. We must comprehensively study and analyze the ways in which addiction affects the lives of those afflicted, and I believe we all must look to how workplaces play a role in this. Many workplaces want to help support their employees, but do not know the best practices or proactive steps to take to help prevent or address addictions.
I’m thankful to have worked across the aisle with Congressman Matt Cartwright (PA-17) on this bill to help address the harmful effects of opioid abuse in the workplace and take proactive steps to see what actions employers can take to address affected employees. 
Additionally, I recently voted in favor of H.R. 6, The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, as it passed the House. This bill is the most significant congressional action against a drug crisis in history and will help support treatment, recovery, and prevention efforts in our communities as well as taking steps to address the growing threat of fentanyl. It also removes barriers in Medicare and Medicaid to help individuals with substance use disorders.
While we make great progress with this bill, I also believe we must do a better job in treating these addictions like the medical issue they are and not solely a criminal issue. That is why I will continue to work toward criminal justice reform that helps low-level, non-violent drug offenders get back on the right track and reduce their likelihood of recidivism by utilizing drug courts and treatment programs. 
We have made great progress in addressing this crisis, and I look forward in continuing to help address opioid addiction.
As I work on this and other issues, I always like to hear directly from you.  Please share any thoughts you may have through my website, and sign up for my e-mail newsletter for the latest updates from Washington, D.C. and around the district. You can also stay on top of my work by following my Facebook and Twitter pages. Please feel free to call my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2271 or my local Burnsville office at 651-846-2120 with any comments or for assistance with a federal agency.

Sincerely, 
￼
Jason Lewis
Member of Congress

Subject: JOIN ME: A community event to protect our public land
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT    |     CONTACT    |     ISSUES    |     MEDIA    |     SERVICES 
Dear ,
In August, the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) launched a year-long study that will ultimately determine whether or not to allow oil drilling and fracking across 1.6 million acres of public land, including in our own backyard. Once again, the Trump Administration is attempting to sell off our public lands to enrich private corporations. 
￼
 Rep. Carbajal Tours the Carrizo Plain National Monument

I invite you to join me for a community event TOMORROW, October 11th, at the Santa Barbara County Courthouse to speak out against the Administration's plans to expand oil drilling and fracking on the Central Coast.
RSVP to let me know you're coming!  Despite the magnitude of this proposal and its impact on our community, BLM only gave residents 30 days to share their concerns. I believe this is insufficient time for Central Coast residents to make their voices heard. You can submit a comment through my office by clicking here.  
￼ 
 

IMPROVING ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE HOUSING 
 Skyrocketing rent on the Central Coast has unfortunately forced some of the most vulnerable members of our community out, or put them at risk of poverty and homelessness. I'm fighting for federal resources that ensure every hard-working individual on the Central Coast has access to a safe and affordable place to call home.   Read more: People of All Incomes Deserve a Home by Rep. Salud Carbajal (Independent) 
￼
 Rep. Carbajal attends Johnson Court groundbreaking in Santa Barbara

On Monday, I attended the groundbreaking ceremony for Johnson Court, an affordable housing unit for homeless veterans in Santa Barbara. I'm excited about the new opportunities created by similar developments for struggling families, veterans, and seniors. 

STRENGTHENING OUR PIPELINE SAFETY
 It has been nearly a decade since Congress passed the Pipeline Safety Act, and yet the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) has still not enforced rules requiring automatic shutoff valves on new pipelines or strengthened leak detection standards.   The disastrous Refugio Oil Spill in 2015 spilled thousands of gallons of crude oil on our coastline, and raised questions about PHMSA's ability to properly oversee pipeline safety laws. Last week, I wrote to the Appropriations committee urging them to include funding in this year's spending bill that directs PHMSA to finalize critical pipeline safety standards.
￼
 Read the full letter here. 


CREATING RENEWABLE ENERGY OPPORTUNITIES ON THE CENTRAL COAST
 As our community faces the impending challenges of the Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant's decommissioning, one of my priorities is securing federal resources that would offset the closure's impact on San Luis Obispo County's economy.   Last month, my colleagues and I passed bipartisan legislation directing the Department of Energy to study funding sources available to assist communities, like ours, who are facing the challenges of a nuclear power plant's closure.   With this significant challenge also comes an opportunity to designate the Central Coast a renewable energy hub. That's why I introduced the Energy Opportunity Zones Act earlier this year, which would create and expand tax credits for renewable energy business development in regions impacted by nuclear power plant closures.  
￼
 

Read more:
Congress approves bill to provide funding for communities losing nuclear power plants (KSBY)
Congress looking for money for cities hit by nuclear plant closures — including Diablo Canyon (Tribune)
As always, I want to hear from you about issues that are important to you and your family. Call my office, find me on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram, or feel free to email me. It’s an honor to represent California's 24th Congressional District.   Sincerely,
￼
Congressman Salud Carbajal

Subject: UPDATE on Ethanol Market
Message:
News from Representative Noem

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
Great news out last night >> President Trump announced his administration will take steps to approve year-round E15.  
As many of you know, I've been putting tremendous pressure on the administration to make this move - and it's paid off. We're getting results. Under the president’s direction, the EPA will now begin the rule-making process that would allow for 15 percent ethanol blends to be used throughout the year – a market we’ve been unable to tap because of federal regulations. 
￼ 
President Trump and I have had many conversations about the expansion of E15. He knows where I stand, and that I wouldn't give up on this issue until we made it right for farmers in South Dakota and for consumers who are demanding more affordable, homegrown fuels. I am grateful that he has followed through on this promise to the American people. 
Have a great day! 
-Kristi
