Subject: Latest from Lamar: Confirming Justice Brett Kavanaugh to serve on the United States Supreme Court
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Confirming Justice Brett Kavanaugh to serve on the United States Supreme Court 
I voted to confirm Justice Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court because of his 26 years of distinguished public service and his reputation as a superior jurist, lawyer and teacher. It would be fundamentally unfair and a dangerous precedent not to confirm him because of an uncorroborated alleged sexual assault 36 years ago. I reviewed six FBI reports between 1993 and 2018, where 150 people were interviewed about Justice Kavanaugh, and in every case the interviewee was asked, do you know of any incidence of alcohol abuse? And the answer in every case was no. I also reviewed the seventh background check involving Justice Kavanaugh, which was conducted earlier last week. It confirmed that the only person who remembers the incident Dr. Ford alleges is Dr. Ford, including the four others she said were present, each of whom stated under penalty of felony that it didn’t happen or that they don’t remember any such incident. Senate Democrats have treated Justice Kavanaugh as innocent until nominated. They have victimized him and Dr. Ford and their families. They have diminished the United States Senate and its confirmation process by their embarrassing irresponsibility. I was glad to vote to confirm Justice Kavanaugh to the Court last week.
￼
I met with then-Judge Kavanaugh on July 26 and was impressed with his intelligence, his temperament, and his character.
 
￼
I joined Chuck Todd on Meet the Press on Sunday to talk about my vote to confirm Justice Brett Kavanaugh. I said: “It’d be hard to have public confidence if you go through an inquisition like he did arranged by the Democrats. If you read the 6 FBI investigations of him over 25 years and see, not just the bad things that were not said about him, but the remarkably good things that were said about him, you would be very glad he’d be on the Supreme Court. And it would be fundamentally unfair to allow people to make accusations against someone and simply by doing that, destroy their reputation and their opportunity to serve in public life.” You can watch here.
 
Republican Congress Getting Results for Tennesseans:
	•	Last week, the United States Senate passed “landmark” opioid legislation I sponsored that is now headed to President Trump’s desk to become law. This legislation will create an environment where states like Tennessee can fight back against our nation’s most deadly public health epidemic, which took more lives in our state last year than car accidents.
	•	The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee I’m a member of approved legislation I sponsored, called the Restore Our Parks Act, that will cut in half the maintenance backlog in the 417 National Park Service sites -- from the National Mall in Washington to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park to the Grand Canyon to Yosemite -- so future generations can enjoy the outdoors.
Important news from this past week:
	•	The Senate passed and the president signed into law legislation that included my proposal to ban cell phone calls on commercial airplanes. Imagine nearly two million passengers, hurtling through space yapping their innermost thoughts while you travel restrained by your seat belt and unable to escape. Keeping phone conversations off commercial flights may not be enshrined in the Constitution, but surely it is enshrined in common sense.
 
Bill to help Tennesseans fight the opioid crisis is headed to the president’s desk 
Last week, the Senate passed legislation I sponsored that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has called “landmark” opioid legislation, and the bill is now headed to President Trump’s desk to be signed into law. Last year, more Tennesseans died from opioid overdoses than were killed in car crashes. The opioid crisis is ravaging our Tennessee communities, and Congress has taken a big step to help Tennessee fight back. Here are 5 ways this bill will help Tennesseans: It will help reduce the influx of deadly illegal drugs at the border, like fentanyl; extend support for Medicaid patients seeking treatment for substance use disorders from 15 to 30 days; help increase services for babies born in opioid withdrawal; and help our state reach out and intervene early in the lives of Tennessee children who have experienced trauma. This bill will also spur the development of a non-addictive pain killer. There are 100 million Americans living with some pain, and there are 25 million who really hurt because they have chronic pain -- they need help, and we need more effective medicines and treatments for pain. A non-addictive painkiller could really be the ‘Holy Grail’ of solving the opioid crisis.
Congress is also backing up important policies like these with federal dollars -- $8.5 billion has been appropriated for fighting the opioid crisis since March.
I look forward to President Trump signing this important legislation into law so we can create an environment so that everyone -- governors, mayors, justices, counselors, law enforcement, doctors, nurses and families -- can succeed in fighting the crisis.
￼
Legislation to help fix backlog in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is one step closer to becoming law 
Last week, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee I am a member of approved the Restore Our Parks Act -- legislation I’m sponsoring that could cut in half the nearly $12 billion deferred maintenance backlog in our national parks over the next five years. This legislation could do more to restore national parks than anything that has happened in the last half century, and the reason we need to restore them is so Americans can enjoy the 417 sites -- from the National Mall in Washington, D.C., to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park to the Grand Canyon to Yosemite -- for generations to come. The bill will cut in half the nearly $12 billion deferred maintenance backlog in our parks and prevent situations such as with the Look Rock Campground on Chilhowee Mountain in the Smokies, which once served 5,000 families a year, but has been closed for repairs for five years. The bill has the support of President Trump, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke, and more than 100 groups. Approval of this bipartisan bill in Committee puts it one step closer to becoming law, and it is my hope that Congress is able to pass our proposal to help restore our parks this year.
Read more on why this legislation is so important to our state:
The Knoxville News Sentinel: Vesna Plekanis: Thanks to Senator Lamar Alexander for fighting for Smokies funding
The Jackson Sun: Senator Lamar Alexander works to restore Shiloh, other national parks
The Chattanoogan: Jennie Bartoletti: Our National Parks Are Desperate for Repairs
 
￼
 
 
I enjoyed showing my granddaughter, Taylor, and her eighth grade class from Nashville around the Capitol. It was nice to share with her and her classmates some of the Senate’s rich history, and its important impact on Tennessee.
 
 
Senate committee passes bill to fully fund program that helps preserve Tennessee’s great outdoors
Also happening in the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee last week, we reported out a piece of legislation that would permanently reauthorize and fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund, which has provided Tennessee over $73 million for the state grant program; $92 million for federal land acquisition; and $33 million for the Forest Legacy program within the state. The Land and Water Conservation Fund has played a large role in protecting Tennessee’s outdoors for over 50 years. In 2015, funding from the Land and Water Conservation Fund helped complete efforts to conserve a nearly 10,000 acre tract of land, known as Rocky Fork, in the Cherokee National Forest in East Tennessee. 
 
￼
 
I enjoyed meeting with Tennesseans at Tennessee Tuesday -- an event Senator Corker and I host every week Congress is in session. I always appreciate hearing from those I am here to represent. If you find yourself in Washington on a Tuesday, come by and see us! You can sign up here. 
 
 
 
New Tennessee State Museum will help future generations grow up knowing what it means to be a Tennessean 
￼
I had the privilege of speaking at the opening of the new Tennessee State Museum in Nashville last Thursday. Forty years ago, I walked across Tennessee in my campaign for governor, 1022 miles from Maryville to Mountain City to Memphis. My walk took six months. Today, at the new Tennessee State Museum, you can walk across the state in 30 minutes and get to know the state pretty well. Our children need to learn American history and Tennessee history, so they can grow up knowing what it means to be an American and a Tennessean. Learning history helps to understand what is happening today and helps to navigate tomorrow. This magnificent new Tennessee State Museum is full of our stories. This museum will give Tennesseans a chance to take a walk through our state -- and I recommend it.
 
Keeping phone conversations off commercial flights may not be enshrined in the Constitution, but surely it is enshrined in common sense 
This past week, the Senate passed and the president signed into law legislation that includes my proposal to ban cell phone calls on commercial airplanes. This proposal directs the U.S. Secretary of Transportation to issue regulations to prohibit cell phone calls during commercial flights. Stop and think about what we hear now in airport lobbies from those who wander around shouting personal details into their phones -- now imagine nearly two million passengers, hurtling through space yapping their innermost thoughts while you travel restrained by your seatbelt and unable to escape.
 
￼
 
Congratulations to the six Tennessee Schools that were named National Blue Ribbon schools this year by the U.S. Department of Education. I am proud of the hard work our teachers put in every day to provide Tennessee students with a top-notch education.
 
Urging an end to tariffs on steel and aluminum 
The Trump Administration announced last week a new trilateral trade agreement -- the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. Updating NAFTA makes sense, but I want to make sure that it also means the end of steel and aluminum tariffs among the United States, Canada and Mexico. This trade agreement is an opportunity to implement the President’s zero tariff goal. NAFTA’s zero tariff provisions have helped to nearly double the number of Tennessee auto jobs, which are one third of all our state’s manufacturing jobs. The cars and trucks Nissan makes in Tennessee and Mississippi are 70 percent steel. The price of steel is up 40 percent since January because of tariffs. It doesn’t take a math major to figure out what will happen to sales, revenues, profits and wages if we keep piling tariffs on top of tariffs.
 
Below are some articles from this week I thought you would enjoy:
Memphis Commercial Appeal: Democrats holding up Norris, Richardson appointments
The Tennessee Star: Op-ed by Lamar Alexander: Key Education Decisions Should Be Made in States, Schools and Homes – Not Washington
Washington Post: Senate easily passes sweeping opioids legislation, sending to President Trump
Maryville Daily Times: Parks funding bill passes Senate panel
The Memphis Commercial Appeal: How U.S. Sens. Bob Corker, Lamar Alexander are voting on Kavanaugh
 
Trust your first instinct, but don’t act on the first piece of information you receive.
#261 in Lamar Alexander’s Little Plaid Book

Subject: Poll: E15
Message:
￼ 

Poll: E15
Hoosiers,

Yesterday, President Trump announced that he will be directing the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to allow the year-round sale of E-15 (gasoline mixed with up to 15% ethanol). For too long, unnecessary federal restrictions hindered access to this clean and affordable fuel. Allowing the year-round sale will reduce our dependence on foreign oil, lower costs for families at the gas pump, help grow demand for Hoosier corn farmers, and support the economy of rural America.

Question of the Week: Given this announcement, do you support President Trump's efforts to ensure America's energy independence and reduce our reliance on foreign oil?

[_] Yes.
[_] No.
[_] I don't know.
[_] Other (share your thoughts).

Subject: BREAKING: Southern Storage Reservoir Authorized!
Message:
News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼ 
BREAKING NEWS: EAA SOUTHERN STORAGE RESERVOIR AUTHORIZED
Lindsey - 
Thanks to everybody who fought this fight with us: the EAA Southern Storage Reservoir has been authorized by Congress. 
The House has voted to pass this bill, the Water Resources Development Act, twice. And just now, the Senate voted 99 to 1 to send it to the President's desk to become law. It was a landslide! 
There are 9 sections I wrote in this bill, including authorizing the EAA Southern Storage Reservoir and redoing the regulation schedule (LORS) that determines when discharges happen. You can read all about it here. 
After years of hard work, passing this bill will help us send the water south and cut discharges! Now, our fight continues for funding and changing the Army Corps' priorities to account for public health and safety. 
Our fight is not over, but today is a momentous move in the right direction. Thank you! 
READ ABOUT THE BILL HERE 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media:
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman 
P.S. You can watch a replay of the vote here!

Subject: Tax Reform 2.0 Passes the House
Message:
￼
￼
Tax Reform 2.0 Passes The House
New hope and new optimism!
House Republicans decided to bet on the American people when we passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act  - letting families keep more of their hard-earned paychecks and helping small business owners invest in their workers and their company. The results have been incredible -- more jobs, bigger paychecks and historic Main Street optimism -- and we want to keep that momentum going.

Recently, the House passed Tax Reform 2.0 - three pieces of legislation meant to build on the results of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Each bill focuses on a specific way to further help our working families and small business owners, and you can learn more about each one below. 
￼
LEARN MORE
PROTECTING FAMILY AND 
SMALL BUSINESS TAX CUTS ACT
This first bill will lock in the individual and small business tax cuts, helping families and small businesses thrive. The Tax Foundation has estimated that making these tax cuts permanent will create 1.5 million new jobs and increase GDP over 2%. 
READ MORE »
￼
LEARN MORE 
FAMILY SAVINGS ACT
This second bill will help more middle-class American families and younger workers save for key life events like retirement, education and unexpected emergencies by expanding access to new and existing savings vehicles. Helping our families save money ensures they are prepared for anything life throws their way.
READ MORE »
￼
LEARN MORE 
AMERICAN INNOVATION ACT
This third bill will help entrepreneurs move from the kitchen table to main street and beyond. With a renewed focus on innovation and entrepreneurship, it will help these risk takers create jobs, invest in their communities, and continue strengthening America’s economy.
READ MORE »
It's so exciting to be part of changing the culture in Washington. Never again will we wait 30 years to fix our tax code. American companies have to think of new ways to stay competitive every day, and it's time that Congress does everything we can to foster an environment that helps our economy grow, puts working class families first, and allows our U.S. businesses to compete and win around the globe!

Subject: Getting Around the District - October 10, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Brat 
￼ 
Website 
Subscribe
To Newsletter 
Constituent
Services 
Legislative
Resources 
Press
Shop 
About 
Dave 
Contact
Dave 



Dear Friend, 

It is a privilege to serve you in Congress.  

One of my highest priorities is to ensure that the economy is thriving and providing good jobs for you and your kids. In September, the U.S. unemployment rate sank to 3.7% -- the lowest since 1969 and on top of that wage growth has hit a 17 month high. Economists are predicting we will continue to see record low unemployment continue in the months to come. As our economy continues to boom and businesses thrive due to deregulation, it’s the American worker who will get to reap the reward. You can read more about it here. 

Over the past 21 months, I have made over 400 official visits throughout the 7th District to meet with the people of Central Virginia. 

I enjoyed talking to the students of Massaponax High School in Spotsylvania about economics and much more. The next generation has an important role to play in the future of our country, and it is important to encourage our students to be active in their communities and government. As a former educator I know how crucial it is for our students to have the opportunity to ask questions which is why as your representative, I make time to visit schools throughout the 7th District. 

￼

I had a great time at the Virginia Cooperative Council meeting and hearing from farmers about how we can better support them.

          ￼    ￼

                                                 ￼

We owe so much to our EMS personnel. The work they do everyday to save lives at the risk of their own deserves our praise and gratitude. It was my privilege to thank the Chesterfield Fire and EMS officials last night at their Annual Awards Ceremony.

                             ￼      ￼
  
                                                
    ￼

Recognizing History in the 7th District
Mt. Zion Baptist Church in Orange County, VA should take pride in its rich, meaningful history. From its inspiring beginnings to becoming a pillar in its community, it is an honor to recognize this special church community and give it the acknowledgement it is due. You can read my press release on Mt. Zion Church by clicking here. 
                                 
           ￼    ￼
            
Protecting Furry Friends 
I am proud to be a co-sponsor of H. Res 776 which would recognize the first Saturday of October as National Animal Rescue Day. Already, our nation’s animal shelters secure forever homes for over 3.2 million animals every year, but there are still more than 1 million animals who end up being euthanized. There are more furry friends out there that need permanent, loving homes, and a national campaign will help.

￼
 

Stay in Touch  
I am always interested in hearing your thoughts. If you have any comments, questions, or concerns, you can contact me directly by clicking here or by calling my office at (202) 225-2815.

You can also follow me on Twitter, Facebook, or YouTube for updates on my work in Congress. 
Thank you,

￼

Congressman Dave Brat

Subject: Rounds Report: President Announces Plan to Allow Year-Round Sales of E-15
Message:
￼
 
     
 

Rounds Report: President Announces Plan to Allow Year-Round Sales of E-15  October 10, 2018
Yesterday, President Trump announced that gasoline mixed with 15 percent ethanol—E-15—will be sold year-round. Previously, sales of E-15 were banned in most states annually between June 1 and September 15, which includes the country’s busiest driving months.
Allowing year-round sales of E-15 will not only increase markets for South Dakota producers, it will increase consumer choice at the pump. South Dakota is a leading state in corn ethanol production. As the market for ethanol increases, the market for corn will grow, resulting in more jobs and increased revenue for South Dakota’s corn farmers. At a time when farmers are already struggling due to a decrease in farm income and trade uncertainty, providing year-round sales of E-15 is an opportunity to give our farmers a much-needed boost.
 As a strong supporter of corn ethanol, I welcome yesterday’s announcement.


        

 ￼

Come and Read It Report
Dear Texans, 
There's nothing quite like a Friday night in Texas - friends, family, and high school football! I was honored to attend the Burleson High School vs. Centennial High School football game and participate in the coin toss. It was a great game and congratulations to the Centennial football team on a hard-earned win - Go Spartans! 
￼ 
The American Economy 
The numbers are in: the US added 134,000 jobs during the month of September, and unemployment dropped to 3.7 percent - the lowest in 49 years! Right now is a great time for Americans to get their lives back on track and back into the workforce. Republican's pro-growth and pro-American policies are strengthening our economy every day, and we're just getting started! 
Supreme Court of the United States 
Last weekend, the United States Senate voted to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the nation's highest court. I am glad our country will have someone with Judge Kavanaugh's conservative leadership and integrity sitting on the bench, and I look forward to him serving on the Supreme Court for many years to come. 
I have included some articles and releases you may find interesting located on the right side of this newsletter. It is an honor and privilege to represent the people of Texas’ 25th Congressional District and as always, please reach out to me with any issues and concerns that are important to you.
In God we trust,

Subject: Huge Vote Today (Watch Live With Me)
Message:
News from Congressman Brian Mast
￼ 
EAA SOUTHERN STORAGE RESERVOIR VOTE TODAY!
Lindsey - 
Great news: last night the Water Resources Development Act cleared the last procedural hurdle. That means the final vote on the EAA Southern Storage Reservoir is today at 11:30 a.m. 
Fixing our water issues is without a doubt the most important priority for our community. We know people are getting sick, animals are dying and the environment is being absolutely demolished. 
That's why writing this bill has been my top priority. Working together, our community has fought hard for sections that I got inserted into the bill like the southern storage reservoir and a re-write of the Lake Okeechobee Regulation Schedule (LORS) that determines when the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is authorized to discharge water. 
The U.S. House of Representatives passed our bill twice with broad bipartisan support, but the Senate has been dragging their feet for months. That's why I recently implored Mitch McConnell to act, telling him our community is literally dying while he refused to bring the bill up for a vote. 
Today, we finally get that vote. You can watch it live with me at approximately 11:30 a.m. on my Facebook page. Its been a long road fighting together for this bill, so all I've got left to say is: let's send the water south!! 
WATCH LIVE HERE AT 11:30 AM 
To learn more about my work on your behalf, please visit my website. 
For more photos and videos, please join me on social media: 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
It is an honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Brian Mast United States Congressman

Subject: Lowest Unemployment Rate Since 1969
Message:
News from Representative Michael McCaul

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward

￼
 
WEBSITE
BIOGRAPHY
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
ISSUES
NEWSROOM
DISTRICT
 
Dear Friends, 
Last week, we cemented a conservative majority on the U.S. Supreme Court for decades to come. I am glad the Senate ultimately confirmed Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, despite the divisive political tactics from Senate Democrats. Tactics which betrayed a woman's trust by forcing her into the political spotlight against her will in an attempt to destroy the reputation and character of a qualified defender of our constitution. I am deeply disappointed with the political nature of this process and pray we can come together again as a country.
You can click here or on the image below to learn more about Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation. 
￼ 
United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) 
President Trump announced he has successfully renegotiated NAFTA, creating the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). I quickly applauded the Trump administration for bringing our close ally Canada into the fold to reach a trilateral agreement that expands market access for our exporters to further grow our economy. There is no doubt that we need improved trade agreements for the 21st century to promote the best interests of America’s small businesses, farmers, and workers. Now, this agreement goes to Congress to approve and ratify. I look forward to reviewing the agreement in full so we can ensure robust trade for Texas and the country.
You can read the new agreement between the United States, Mexico, and Canada by clicking here or on the image below. 
￼ 
Public Safety Officer of the Month 
I was honored to be recognized by Tomball Police Chief Billy Tidwell as the 'Public Safety Officer of the Month.' I look forward to continuing our work together in keeping our local communities safe, especially on the issue of human trafficking. Earlier this year, President Trump signed by Blue Campaign Authorization Act into law. This legislation will better equip the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to partner, educate, and coordinate efforts and intelligence sharing on multiple levels. It will provide resources to help deter, detect, and mitigate instances of human trafficking in our country. It will also safeguard victims and help raise public awareness of the threat human trafficking poses to our communities.
You can click here or on the image below to learn more about this legislation, which is now law. 
￼ 
My Bill to Counter Illicit Travel to the U.S. 
Last week, I introduced H.R. 6997, the Repatriation Assistance Act. This legislation gives the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) the authority to provide financial support to foreign governments so they can return individuals who pose a national security threat to the United States. 
Known or Suspected Terrorists, wanted criminals, and other bad actors are exploiting illicit pathways throughout our hemisphere and racing towards our border. These individuals pose a serious threat to our national security and to the security of the countries they travel through. By empowering DHS with this authority, our foreign partners will be able to better identify, detain, and transport these dangerous individuals back to their country of origin. This legislation will extend our borders and increase our homeland security by addressing the threats well before they reach U.S. soil.
You can click here to learn more about this legislation. 
Updated Terror Threats 
The United States and our allies have courageously fought terrorists on the battlefield and dismantled ISIS’ self-declared caliphate. Yet the terror group’s enduring ability to inspire, recruit, radicalize, and plot online still remains a very real threat. Ultimately, victory requires a long-term, sustained commitment to countering its ‘viral’ capabilities, while also taking the fight to them wherever they are.
I released a follow-up report on virtual terror efforts entitled, Terror Gone Viral 2.0, to capture the scope of ISIS’ activities by providing a high-level examination of ISIS-linked plots and attacks targeting Western countries, including the United States. 
You can also read October's Terror Threat Snapshot by clicking here or on the image below. 
￼ 
  
#TaxCutsandJobAct Update
Just when you think the economic numbers across our country cannot get any better, they do. It was announced that unemployment in the country dropped to the lowest levels since 1969. Remember to follow me on Twitter to get the latest news about how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act has helped to spur unprecedented economic growth. 
You can click here or on the tweet below to learn more.  
￼ 
Legislative Update 
Last week, Members were in their districts for a District Work Period. No votes were held. 
This week, Members will continue to be in their districts for the District Work Period. For this reason, there are no votes currently scheduled in the U.S. House of Representatives.
As always, I encourage you to visit my website, mccaul.house.gov, for more information on constituent services and legislative updates. Also, follow me on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and YouTube to get the latest updates on my work in Washington and the 10th District of Texas. It continues to be a great honor to represent you in the United States House of Representatives. 
  
 With Best Regards, 
￼ 
Michael T. McCaul
Member of Congress

Subject: Fighting Back Against the Opioid Epidemic
Message:
News from Martha Roby
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window          Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
Friends, 
As you may know, yesterday afternoon Governor Ivey issued a State of Emergency in preparation for Hurricane Michael. The declaration was issued in anticipation of the damage Hurricane Michael could potentially cause in our state. Please be safe and heed warnings. Follow Alabama Emergency Management Agency for timely updates.   JUSTICE KAVANAUGH CONFIRMED 
Brett Kavanaugh is a conservative, experienced jurist who I believe will be a strict constitutionalist on the Supreme Court. I am pleased that the United States Senate voted to confirm him this weekend, and I am confident he will serve the Court and the American people admirably. 
You can watch his confirmation ceremony here.  
COVINGTON REGION HONOR FLIGHT VISITS DC 
￼ 
The Covington Region Honor Flight was in Washington on Friday! This amazing program provides free trips to Washington, D.C., for veterans to visit sites like the World War II Memorial, Arlington National Cemetery, and the Korean and Vietnam Memorials. My staff had a great meal with the group Friday night. I hope they had a memorable and enjoyable trip!     UNEMPLOYMENT HITS NEW LOW 
￼ 
According to the September jobs report released last week, unemployment hit its lowest point in nearly 50 years — yet another sign that our pro-growth policies are helping American workers and our economy.   You can read more here.     OCTOBER IS BREAST CANCER AWARENESS MONTH 
￼ 
October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Did you know that about 1 in 8 women in America will develop invasive breast cancer? During my time in Congress, we have taken action to help survivors and recognize those who are still bravely fighting this terrible disease. I am continually inspired by the many personal stories I have heard from the people I represent. I hope that we will spend this month refocusing our commitment to work towards a cure.   FIGHTING THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC 
While the news of the day and partisan bickering often distract from the issue, it is important that we remember our nation is in the midst of an urgent public health epidemic that is ravaging virtually every community in this country. Hundreds of thousands of lives have been cut short by opioid addiction and abuse in recent years. Last year alone, more than 72,000 Americans lost their lives due to complications from drug overdose. Of those fatalities, nearly 50,000 were related to opioids.   In Congress, we have made great strides towards addressing this tragic epidemic that is gripping the State of Alabama and the entire country, and we recently made even more progress by passing H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act. This bill authorizes critical funding to assist states in combatting the opioid crisis, expand patient access to addiction treatment, and improve the detection of importation of illegal drugs, including fentanyl. H.R. 6 has passed both the House and Senate and now awaits President Trump’s signature. I am eager to see it become law.   In order to fight this battle with the aggression it requires, we must be unified and coordinated in our efforts. Action must be taken by leadership in local communities, in state governments, and in the federal government. I am glad that in Congress, this fight has garnered the widespread support it deserves. American lives depend on all of us, and our work is far from being complete. I’m eager to see President Trump sign H.R. 6 into law, and I will continue to support efforts to combat the opioid epidemic on behalf of Alabama’s Second District.   You can read my weekly column about this legislation here.   
You can stay up to date on my work in Congress by following me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.          It is an honor to serve you in Congress. Please never hesitate to let me know if there is a way my office can be of assistance.   Sincerely, 
￼  Martha Roby 
Member of Congress

Subject: Military and Veterans Update - September 2018
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼


￼
MILITARY & VETERANS UPDATE - September 2018
￼
Meeting with Lieutenant General Jack Weinstein.
TOP STORY
On Wednesday, September 26th, I met with Lieutenant General Jack Weinstein, the Air Force’s senior officer for strategic deterrence and nuclear integration—including the Minuteman III missiles currently dispersed across Montana, and the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent that will replace them in the mid-2020s. We also had a chance to discuss the new MH-139 helicopter that will replace the Vietnam-era UH-1N Huey. As a member of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee, I was pleased to see these, and other key Montana priorities included in the DoD Appropriations Bill signed into law by President Trump on September 28th.  SUPPORTING THE MILITARY, VETERANS, AND THEIR FAMILIES  n Labor Day, September 3rd, Colonel Karen Lloyd, USA (ret.), Director of the Veterans History Project attended the Crow Fair’s 100th celebration at Crow Agency to meet with Native American veterans and listen to their stories. Over the past four years, I’ve worked with Colonel Lloyd to preserve and make available personal interviews of Montana’s veterans in the Library of Congress. As Colonel Lloyd aptly notes, Native Americans are one of the few groups in American who welcomed Vietnam Veterans home with dignity and respect; and yet are underrepresented in the Library’s collection. I was pleased to invite Colonel Lloyd for this important endeavor.
￼
Assembling care packages for spouses of deployed service members.
On Wednesday, September 5th, I was honored to join representatives from the United Service Organizations (USO) on Capitol Hill to assemble care packages for the spouses of deployed service members. In May, the USO kicked off The Salute to Military Spouses, a six-month spotlight on military spouse contributions and challenges. Thank you spouses for your service to our country!
On Wednesday, September 12th, I had the pleasure of meeting with Tom Johnson, Commander of VFW Post 10010 in East Helena and newly appointed Legislative Representative for the Montana Veterans of Foreign Wars. We discussed ongoing challenges across the VA Healthcare System and upcoming changes under the MISSION Act.  We Will Never Forget
￼
Meeting first responders at the 9/11 Memorial at City College in Billings.
Earlier this month, our nation paused to remember the thousands of American lives lost and the courageous response by thousands more to the terrorist attacks on September 11, 2001. I was honored to join first responders, veterans, students, and families at the 9/11 Memorial at City College in Billings on the 17th anniversary of that fateful Tuesday morning.

Subject: Important Information in Preparation For Hurricane Michael
Message:
News from Representative Dunn

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email     Click here to forward this email
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Services
About
 
NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend,  Governor Scott has declared a state of emergency for 35 counties in Florida, most of which are in the Second Congressional District, as Hurricane Michael moves towards the Panhandle. At this time, we are urging all those who reside in evacuation zones to leave immediately. This is the strongest storm the Gulf Coast has experienced in decades and could be catastrophic for the area.  The National Weather Service (NWS) suggests taking the following steps before the storm:  1. Prepare a hurricane emergency kit with water, food, flashlights, batteries, a first aid kit, and more.  2. Create and review your family emergency plan – where you will go in the event of an emergency, how you will stay in contact with each other, and more. 3. Stay up to date on the weather and understand the meanings of the National Weather Service’s watches and warnings.   The NWS has published this Hurricane preparedness guide that you may wish to review. For updated information on Hurricane Michael and how to prepare, please visit the websites below:  National Weather Service: www.weather.gov  National Hurricane Center: http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/  Ready.gov: http://www.ready.gov/  Federal Emergency Management Agency: http://www.fema.gov/   Florida Division of Emergency Management: http://www.floridadisaster.org  Florida County Emergency Management: http://floridadisaster.org/counties   Thank you for your attention to this important matter. Please be safe and be prepared.     Sincerely, ￼  Neal Dunn Member of Congress

Subject: Job Surge
Message:
￼
 Job Surge
Dear Friends,

From record-low levels of unemployment to rising wages to record highs in consumer confidence, this Republican-led Congress has put in place legislative efforts that are producing real, positive results. In just two years of working in tandem with President Trump, we have helped create almost four million new jobs nationwide – bringing hope and opportunity to the State of Georgia.

With lower taxes and fewer burdensome regulations, we are putting the American people first, while spurring new business innovation and economic growth. On Friday, I joined more than a thousand people and the economic development offices of Newton, Greene, Jasper, Morgan, and Walton counties for the second annual Regional Job Fair in Covington. The sheer number of people who participated and the way that our community came together simply blew me away. With more than 60 employers present, I’m proud to see that Georgia is brimming with job openings, and this event is just another example of the growth and prosperity sweeping our Nation. To read more about the job fair, check out this great article from the Covington News. You can also watch my Facebook Live video from the event here.
￼
Congressman Hice talks with students about the importance of landing a good job
￼
Representative Hice greets a local employer at the 2018 Regional Job Fair
￼
Job seekers hear about employment opportunities
￼

Trading Places
It’s good news like the announcement of last week’s United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) that has already sent our economy skyrocketing and will continue to inspire confidence in the future. I applaud President Trump and Trade Representative Ambassador Lighthizer on reaching a new trilateral trade agreement with our closest trading partners. My staff and I will continue to review the details of the agreement to make certain it benefits industries vital to Georgia’s economy, such as agriculture and manufacturing. The role of Congress in ratifying trade deals is one that I take very seriously, and I will be examining this package very carefully to ensure that 10th District priorities are reflected in it.
 
Applications Due Tomorrow
Attending a United States Service Academy is a life-changing opportunity for young people in the 10th District and across the country, and I’m honored to nominate exceptional candidates from our community each year. The men and women who attend these schools go on to serve our Nation as future military leaders. For students seeking a nomination to one of our service academies, my office’s deadline is tomorrow! 

As part of the application, my office will need a current photograph, academic transcript, standardized test results, candidate fitness assessment, and three recommendation forms submitted electronically to GA10Noms@mail.house.gov by tomorrow at 5:00 p.m. 

I am excited to start reviewing the submissions of this next generation of young leaders. Their call to service is inspiring and commendable. If you have any questions or concerns, I encourage you to reach out to my Academy Director, Carolyn Dallas, at Carolyn.Dallas@mail.house.gov.

Weather Alert: Hurricane Michael
With severe weather on the horizon, Governor Nathan Deal has declared a state of emergency for much of Georgia, including Baldwin, Glascock, Hancock, Jefferson, Johnson, Warren, and Washington counties. 
Because potential power outages, flooding, and wind damage are expected soon, don’t wait a moment longer to prepare. Here are five basic hurricane preparedness tips from ready.gov:
	1.	Know where to go. If you are ordered to evacuate, know the local hurricane evacuation route(s) to take and have a plan for where you can stay. Contact your local emergency management agency for more information. 
	2.	Put together a go-bag, including a flashlight, batteries, cash, first aid supplies, medications, non-perishable food items, water, and copies of your critical information if needed. 
	3.	If you are not in an area that is advised to evacuate and you decide to stay in your home, plan for adequate supplies in case you lose electricity and water for several days and are not able to leave due to flooding or blocked roads.
	4.	Make a family emergency communication plan and monitor local radio and TV stations for updated emergency information. 
	5.	Many communities have text or email alerting systems for emergency notifications. To find out what alerts are available in your area, download the FEMA mobile app. 

By taking commonsense steps to prepare for severe weather, we can help ensure the safety of our families and ourselves during emergency situations. Please keep our fellow Georgians – and our neighbors in Florida and Alabama – in your thoughts and prayers. As always, my team and I are here to help. Please do not hesitate to call one of my offices if we can be of assistance:

Monroe District Office – (770)-207-1776
Milledgeville District Office – (478)-457-0007
Washington, D.C. Office – (202)-225-4101

Supreme Court News
On Saturday, the Senate advanced Judge Brett Kavanaugh's nomination for the next Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. After one of the most exhaustive background checks and politically contentious confirmation hearings in memory, I applaud my colleagues for confirming a justice who has been proven to have the integrity, judicial temperament, and dedication to the law required to serve on our Nation’s highest court.

Throughout this process, Senate Democrats repeatedly moved goalposts in their efforts to delay and obstruct. Accusations of sexual misconduct are very serious, and the Senate did its due diligence in pausing proceedings in order to further investigate these claims. All victims of sexual assault deserve justice, compassion, and for their voices to be heard. At the same time, our system of justice – and society as a whole – are founded upon the idea that the accused are understood to be innocent until proven guilty, and there was simply no corroborating evidence to support the claims made against Judge Kavanaugh. Furthermore, the Article II "Advice and Consent" authority of the Senate was never meant to be weaponized for such raw partisan purposes. Abandoning either of these foundational principles would create an unprecedented crisis for our republic and for Americans of all political persuasions.

What should have been a professional, non-partisan approach to investigating serious claims became an embarrassing display of partisan vitriol by Senators determined to oppose any nominee of President Trump.

I’m glad the high court has gained a brilliant jurist and devoted defender of our Constitution — and our entire country is better off for it. Congratulations again to Justice Kavanaugh and his family on this well-deserved appointment. I am confident he will serve honorably, as exactly the kind of jurist our founders envisioned. 

The Week Ahead
In addition to meeting with folks at home, I look forward to attending the grand opening of Shire’s state-of-the-art manufacturing facility in Social Circle this coming week.   As always, I’m honored to represent you in Congress, and my team and I are here to serve each and every one of you. Please contact my office with any questions, comments, or concerns. Be sure to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to keep track of upcoming legislation and events!  Sincerely,
￼


FOLLOW US
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 

￼ 

￼ 

TOP NEWS
Hundreds line up for Regional Job Fair Rockdale Newton Citizen – 10/6 Over 1,200 citizens gathered at Georgia Piedmont Technical College on Friday for the 2018 Regional Job Fair co-hosted by U.S. Congressman Jody Hice (GA-10) and the Newton County Office of Economic Development. “Our goal is to connect local talent with businesses so that they can land jobs and continue to work towards individual and communal success,” said Hice. “Whether looking for a fresh start or just beginning a career, this is the place to be. I wholeheartedly believe that the 10th District is a special place, and I’m particularly proud of this community and the regional partnerships that have helped to ensure that the I-20 corridor is a great place to do business and a powerful force in Georgia.” But before opening the doors to the hundreds of job seekers lined up outside, Hice and Ronnie Johnston, Covington mayor wanted to give a “hats-off” to all the businesses and individuals involved.
Battlefield land grants program moves forward in U.S. House News-Reporter – 10/4 Congressman Jody Hice, a member of the U.S. House Natural Resources Committee, praised the committee’s passage of H.R. 6108, the Preserving America’s Battlefields Act. The bill reauthorizes the Battlefield Land Acquisition Grants Program, a successful dollar for-dollar grants program that protects the preservation of Revolutionary War, War of 1812, and Civil War battlefields.
4th local REACH cohort commits to excellence Union-Recorder – 10/2 Numerous elected officials and distinguished community members took turns at the podium congratulating this year’s REACH scholars while pledging their support to them moving forward. U.S. Congressman Jody Hice was not present but did send field representative Daniel Lentz, who revealed at the ceremony that the local scholars’ names had been entered into Congressional record, which was something Floyd Griffin admitted to being a little jealous of. “I’ve done a lot of things in my 74 years,” stated the retired Army colonel, state senator, and former mayor of Milledgeville, “and my name has never been entered into the books of Congress. Here you are in the eighth grade and today your name is entered into the ledgers of the United States House of Representatives. That’s amazing.”
Blunt introduces bipartisan legislation to preserve Missouri, U.S. battlefields Farmington Press – 10/4 The Preserving America’s Battlefields Acts would increase the authorization of the Battlefield Land Acquisition Grants Program to $20 million a year, including up to $2 million a year for the restoration and interpretation of high-priority battlefields sites, helping to transform these sites into historic tourism destinations. Companion legislation, H.R.6108, has been introduced in the U.S. House of Representatives by U.S. Rep. Jody Hice (Ga.).

Subject: Knight Vision: October 9, 2018
Message:
￼ 
  

Around the District
INFRA money coming to Santa Clarita!
It was an honor to host U.S. Transportation Secretary Elaine L. Chao in Santa Clarita last week to commemorate the historic $47 million INFRA Grant to relieve trafice on the I-5/I-14 interchange. Read more HERE. You can also watch the entire event HERE.
￼

St. Francis Dam bill passes key Senate Committee
Yesterday, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee voted to unanimously approve my bill, the Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial Act. This bill is now just a few steps away from being signed into law! Read more HERE.
￼

Walk to End Alzheimer's
Started my day at the 2018 Walk to End Alzheimer's at Bridgeport Park. It was great to see so many friends out walking to support their family members and friends that suffer from this horrible disease and their caregivers as well. Thank you to Rick and all the volunteers for all you do in the fight against Alzheimer’s. Check out some photos HERE.
￼

Stand Down for Vets
Saturday members of our staff were at the “Stand Down” for veterans, which was hosted at Grace Chapel In Lancaster. We were able to offer support to veterans who are in need of assistance with the VA. Many other services were also available and we sure appreciate Steve Baker for coordinating a great event.
￼

Air Force National Defense Service Medal
Friday I had the honor of pinning medals on Mr. Eloy Valdez who served in the United States Air Force. He received his Air Force Good Conduct Medal and Air Force National Defense Service Medal. Please join me in thanking Mr. Valdez for his service to our country.
￼

Palmdale High School Hall of Fame
Friday night I attended the Palmdale High School Alumni Hall of Fame Induction Ceremony. This year Palmdale graduates Stephen A, Nicholls, Georgia (Grant) DiMeglio, Katie (Smith) Marr, Michael Tonkin, Edniesha Curry, Anthony Bonilla and Ryan Lauterio were all inducted. Some of the inductees parents accepted their students awards. Congratulations and Go Falcons!
￼

Care Net Women's Resource Center
Thursday I was very happy to speak at the Care Net Women’s Resource Centers 15th Annual Banquet. Thank you to Kim, her staff, board and volunteers for your tireless work, love and compassion on behalf of families in the Antelope Valley.
￼

Army National Defense Service Medal
I had the pleasure of presenting and pinning medals earned by Mr. Charles Rachell while serving in the US Army. He received his Army National Defense Service Medal and Marksman Badge with Rifle Bar. Thank you Mr. Rachell for your service to our country.
￼

Speaking at West Coast Baptist College
I was invited by Dr. Paul Chappell, Pastor of Lancaster Baptist Church to speak to the students from the West Coast Baptist College and Lancaster Baptist School. We covered current legislation and the students from both schools were very well versed on the issues we face today. Thank you to Pastor Chappell and all of the students for making today’s event a memorable one.
￼

Awarding the National Defense Service Medal
It was an honor and a privilege to pin medals on Vietnam War Navy Veteran, George Fierro. He received his National Defense Service Medal and Vietnam Service Medal. Please join me in thanking George for his service to our country.
￼

Pete Knight's Legacy
On October 3, 1967, my father set the world speed record for a manned aircraft. His record still stands today. Read more HERE.
￼

Antelope Valley Hispanic Chamber luncheon
I had the pleasure of attending the monthly luncheon hosted by the Antelope Valley Hispanic Chamber of Commerce Tuesday. Thank you for the warm welcome and all you do to promote local businesses.
￼

Santa Clarita Business Walk
Last week I took to the streets of Santa Clarita for a business walk. I had the honor of meeting local small business owners and members of their teams. Serving on the Small Business Committee, my goal is to assist in the locally owned companies grow and flourish. If you have any questions or concerns about your business feel free to reach out to any of our district offices. Check out some photos HERE.
￼



Around the Capitol
START Act receives funding
The Defense Appropriations Bill includes funding for a program I introduced with H.R. 5707, the Sexual Trauma Response and Treatment Act. Read more HERE.
￼

Breast Cancer Awareness Month
October is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Remember, early detection and treatment is still the best and most effective way to fight any form of cancer. Make sure you and a loved one get regularly screened and tested.
￼

Unemployment rate continues to drop!
The unemployment rate is at the lowest its been in 49 years as our economy continues its historic resurgence! Read more HERE.
￼

Subject: Thune Joins President Trump for Announcement on Approval of Year-Round E15 Fuel Sales
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼



October 09, 2018




Thune Joins President Trump for Announcement on Approval of Year-Round E15 Fuel Sales
 
Sen. Thune, a longtime member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, joined President Trump at the White House for today’s announcement that the administration will initiate a rulemaking process to permit the year-round sale of E15 fuel (15 percent ethanol-blended fuel) in the United States, a win for consumer choice and energy security that Thune has sought for 11 years, including significant and ongoing engagement with the current administration.
 
“After spending more than a decade advocating for higher blends of ethanol, I want to thank President Trump for upholding his commitment to America’s farmers,” said Thune. “Using homegrown resources like ethanol to keep America’s economy moving forward is a common-sense, true win-win solution." 
 
To read more on today's announcement, click here.
To stay up to date with Thune's activities in the Senate, visit www.thune.senate.gov.

Subject: A Quick Update
Message:
￼
Mission: To Help People

On Wisconsin 
￼
Class 60 of the Joseph Project kicked off in Milwaukee this week at Greater Praise Church of God in Christ. Eighteen participants completed a week-long class of interpersonal skills, interview skills and financial well-being. They will be interviewing with local companies for full-time positions. Classes are open to any constituents genuinely looking for employment opportunities, regardless of background. 
On the Hill 
Johnson votes to confirm Kavanaugh to Supreme Court 
On Saturday, the Senate voted to confirm Judge Kavanaugh's nomination for the role of associate justice on the Supreme Court. Prior to casting his vote in support of the nomination, Senator Johnson said, "The presumption of innocence is the backbone principle to America's system of justice. By all accounts, Judge Kavanaugh is a highly qualified jurist and has led an exemplary adult life as a husband, father and member of his church and community. The uncorroborated allegations against him as a youth - revealed only at the end of the confirmation process - do not overcome the presumption of innocence or detract from Judge Kavanaugh's lifetime of dedicated public service. That is why, having reviewed his lifetime of achievement - and having spent an additional five hours reviewing the supplemental FBI report - I will vote to confirm Judge Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court." 
Senate passes Johnson bills 
A key bill sponsored by Senator Johnson was included in the final Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization bill passed by the Senate this week. The Preventing Emerging Threats Act ensures the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice have the necessary authority to protect important buildings and sites when a security risk is posed by an unauthorized drone. "By including the Preventing Emerging Threats Act in the FAA reauthorization bill, Congress has provided law enforcement authorization to counter the malign use of drones. This is a necessary first step in addressing the growing threat posed by drones in the hands of terrorists and criminals," Senator Johnson said after the bill passed.
In addition to the FAA package, the Senate also passed the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Act. Senator Johnson led the effort in the Senate to pass CISA, which would rename the Department of Homeland Security's National Protection and Programs Directorate (NPPD) as the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) and would streamline functions.
Medicaid maximization schemes 
Continuing his oversight to root out waste, fraud and abuse in Medicaid, Senator Johnson sent a letterto Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services Administrator Seema Verma and a letterto Comptroller General Gene Dodaro of the U.S. Government Accountability Office. The letters seek information about state Medicaid funding schemes that may be costing federal taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars or more.
"At a time of rising federal deficits and increased federal Medicaid spending, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) should closely scrutinize these schemes," Senator Johnson wrote to Administrator Verma.
Making Government Function 
The Senate continued to process executive branch nominations, including positions in the Consumer Protection Safety Commission. Senator Johnson also introduced a bill to amend the Presidential Transition Act of 1963 to improve the orderly transfer of executive power. The bill is currently in Senator Johnson's committee, the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee.
Coming Up 
The Senate continues to work through executive branch nominations. Senators will also consider appropriations bills, the opioids package conference report, and a water infrastructure bill. 
Media Round Up 
	•	Senator Johnson on "The John Muir Show" discussing Judge Kavanaugh and the 2018 election 
	•	Senator Johnson on "The Jay Weber Show" discussing trade and Judge Kavanaugh 
	•	Senator Johnson on "The Vicki McKenna Show" discussing Judge Kavanaugh

Subject: The DeSaulnier Digest: October 9, 2018
Message:
￼
Home       About Mark       Our District       How Can Mark Help You?       Legislation       Newsroom       Contact Mark        
Dear Lindsey:
This past week, the Republican Party of President Trump hit a new low by confirming Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. I have heard people from across our district and across the country expressing their outrage at this process and the current situation in Washington.
We will be hosting a town hall this month in Richmond where I will talk about what is happening in Washington, DC, and I will take your questions. Details are below. We hope to see you there!
Richmond Town Hall Tuesday, October 23, 2018 6:30 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. Lovonya DeJean Middle School Multipurpose Room 3400 Macdonald Avenue Richmond, CA 94805 Doors Open at 6:00 p.m.
Please RSVP by visiting https://desaulnier.house.gov/town-hall-rsvp, or contact my offices in Walnut Creek or Richmond for more information about the event.
MARK'S STATEMENT ON THE CONFIRMATION OF BRETT KAVANAUGH
"This is a transformative moment in our history where women are speaking out and taking great risks to make their voices heard. While our Constitution and its subsequent amendments guarantee equality for women, we as a country have yet to fulfill that promise. Unfortunately, some people want to go back in time. They believe that an "enlightened" world of white males is what makes this country great.  Today, a black mark in our history was made by a President who forcefully elevated to the Supreme Court a man who was not properly investigated, committed perjury before the U.S. Senate, and has neither the moral character nor judicial temperament to be a judge in any court in the United States of America.  In times like these, things do not come easily - they come with a struggle, but we cannot let our voices be silenced. This is a country that should inspire merit irrespective of gender, ethnicity, or sexual preference. We must keep fighting for justice, equality, and a better America."

MARK'S LEGISLATIVE ACCOMPLISHMENTS
Aviation Safety Measures Signed into Law:
We are pleased to announce that four of our safety measures to help prevent runway accidents were signed into law on Friday as part of the bipartisan bill to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) for the next five years.  As a frequent flyer, I feel fortunate that our nation's air travel system is safe and the number of accidents have steadily declined in recent years. However, the recent rise in near-miss incidents across the country has given us reason to pause and evaluate if we are doing all we can to prevent accidents before a catastrophe occurs. Our safety provisions will address some of the challenges that contributed to high profile close calls and are a step in the right direction. Regardless, there is still more work to be done, and we are currently drafting legislation that will address remaining gaps in aviation safety. To learn more about our safety measures, click here. 
￼ 

MARK AROUND TOWN
Meeting One-On-One with Residents at El Cerrito Resource Fair
Mark stopped by the El Cerrito Senior Resource Fair and met one-on-one with residents to answer questions about federal legislation and assist with issues related to Social Security, Medicare, the Veteran's Administration, and other federal agencies. If you were unable to join us, please do not hesitate to reach out to our office for help.  
￼
Experiencing Richmond's Diverse and Rich History
As a history buff, Mark thoroughly enjoyed visiting the Richmond Museum of History to view books, newspapers, and periodicals that detail Richmond's history - from its early days as the birthplace of the idea for the transcontinental railroad, to WWII when the biggest wartime shipbuilding operation on the West Coast sprung up on its shores, to the colorful and diverse history of today. 
￼
Discussing the Importance of Guaranteeing Protections for People with Pre-Existing Conditions
Mark met with members of the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation of the Bay Area and children living with Type 1 Diabetes to discuss the importance of supporting the Special Diabetes Program, and his support for NIH funding, guaranteeing protections for people with pre-existing conditions, and ensuring access to insulin. 
￼

OPINIONS FROM THE DISTRICT  
Hearing directly from you not only informs my work in Congress, but also is my favorite part of being your Representative. To share your opinions with me you can either email me or take our survey.
Below are some of the top issues you shared with me over the last week:
	•	56 constituents called on me to oppose the Republicans' recent tax package, which will add at least $3.2 trillion to the national debt and dismantles the state and local tax program (SALT), which I voted against. 
	•	32 constituents wrote in favor of emphasizing benefits to American workers and protecting the environment in renegotiations of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

LEGISLATION MARK RECENTLY SUPPORTED 
Veteran Treatment Court Coordination Act (H.R. 4345) - helps facilitate the development of veteran treatment courts to keep veterans who commit crimes as a result of mental health issues out of jail and focused on treatment
Preventing Maternal Deaths Act (H.R. 1318) - supports initiatives to reduce pregnancy-related deaths

LETTERS MARK RECENTLY SENT
Letter to President Trump urging him to rescind Judge Kavanaugh's nomination to the Supreme Court
Letter urging Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar to treat immigrant children in his care humanely in response to reports that they have been moved to live in tent cities
Letter urging the State Department to resume issuing visas to unmarried same-sex partners of diplomatic personnel
Letter to President Trump opposing the Administration's moves to roll back important measures to reduce emissions of methane from the oil and gas industry
Letter to the Environmental Protection Agency opposing the Administration's proposed replacement of the Clean Power Plan
Letter urging Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) Alex Azar to resume collective bargaining with the union representing HHS employees
Sincerely, ￼  Mark DeSaulnier Member of Congress

Dear Lindsey, 
Supporting Those Struggling in the Opioid Crisis 
On Friday, I joined leaders in healthcare, education, nonprofits, and government to give remarks at the Dartmouth Opioid Collaborative Forum in Concord, where we discussed the impact of the opioid crisis on children and families and how to identify children who need help. In addition to passing legislation that provides support to children who are struggling, it’s so important to educate people about the signs of a child in need of assistance. I look forward to sharing the insights I heard at the Forum with my colleagues as we continue our work to combat this public health emergency. 
￼
Speaking at the Dartmouth Opioid Collaborative Forum on Friday 
On Wednesday, I joined my co-chair of the Bipartisan Heroin and Opioids Task Force, Congressman Tom MacArthur, in applauding the final passage of bipartisan, bicameral, and comprehensive opioid legislation by the Senate. Congressman MacArthur and I have spent this Congress developing policies and crafting an agenda to better serve our communities. Our measures bolster support for education and prevention, expand treatment and long-term recovery, as well as law enforcement and interdiction efforts. These were addressed in this compromise bill and will soon make communities in New Hampshire more resilient against the opioid crisis. Passage of this legislation shows that when Republicans and Democrats come together to tackle issues facing our constituents, real progress and solutions are made. 
Helping Veterans Get the Care They Need 
I introduced the Enhancing Veterans Experience with Telehealth Services Act (eVETS) last week to improve veteran access to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) treatment via telemedicine. This introduction comes less than a week after the Department of Veterans Affairs reported an alarming surge in the suicide rate among veterans. In rural communities in New Hampshire, the nearest VA facility can be an hours’ drive away, deterring many from obtaining help. By rapidly expanding the VA’s offering of telehealth to these areas, I hope to address obstacles that have kept far too many veterans from receiving care. 
Standing up for New Hampshire's Small Businesses 
On Wednesday, I signed on as a cosponsor of H.R. 6824, the Online Sales Simplicity and Small Business Relief Act. This bipartisan legislation was introduced by Congressman Jim Sensenbrenner as a response to the Supreme Court ruling in June on Wayfair v. South Dakota, and it would provide relief to retailers with more limited revenue by exempting them from collecting sales tax for other states. It would also put a reasonable timeline in place for when larger businesses are responsible for collecting. I’m pleased my colleagues on both sides of the aisle put politics aside and introduced this much needed check on the scope of Wayfair v. South Dakota, and I will continue to advocate for small businesses by fighting unfair and unnecessary tax regulations. 
Hearing from You 
As always, please do not hesitate to reach out to my Washington, DC office at 202-225-5206 or my Concord office at 603-226-1002 with any questions, concerns or ideas you have. Thank you for everything you do to make our state such a great place to live. I hope you have a good rest of the week!
Sincerely,                                                                          ￼

News from Representative Olson

October 9, 2018

￼

￼
 Pete’s Top Tweets  RepPeteOlson  FANTASTIC NEWS: In September, the unemployment rate fell to 3.7%, the lowest level in 49 years! #BetterOffNow http://bit.ly/2CAyxkr   RepPeteOlson   Check it out! #TX-22’s own @COPearland has the 3rd fastest growing economy in the entire United States! #TexasProud→ http://bit.ly/2ON2hzT  ￼   RepPeteOlson  Congratulations to @LamarCISD Jackson Elementary for being selected as a 2018 National Blue Ribbon School by @usedgov! They are one of only 24 schools in Texas to receive this prestigious honor! Way to go Jackson Jets! http://bit.ly/2CymHae 
Dear Friend,  Thank you for taking time from your busy schedule to read about some of last week’s highlights here in Texas.  POTUS Announces A New Trade Agreement With Mexico & Canada   Last week, President Trump announced that the U.S. reached an agreement on a new trade deal with Canada and Mexico, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). I am currently reviewing the details and I hope this agreement will mean a renewed, long-lasting deal that benefits all Americans and creates an even stronger economy through free trade between our three nations. In Texas alone we have two million trade-related jobs with 380,000 of those jobs depending specifically on trade with Mexico. Trade is the backbone of our economy and it is crucial that America enters into beneficial trade agreements with other countries.  Supporting Local Small Businesses   It was great to visit with some Brazoria County small businesses at the Alvin-Manvel Chamber of Commerce Business Expo and Taste of the Town. Events like this give me firsthand knowledge of how DC actions impact small businesses. It helps me convey their concerns to my colleagues in Washington. Small businesses are the job creators that keep our economy strong, employing many of our friends and neighbors and providing important goods and services to our community.  ￼  Rep. Olson and local real estate agents    Hearing From Fort Bend County Superintendents  At a recent Fort Bend Chamber event, I received an important update on the state of our local schools directly from superintendents from some of our Fort Bend County school districts. It was helpful to hear about the excellence, growth and diversity of our county’s schools from Lamar CISD Superintendent Dr. Randle, Fort Bend ISD Superintendent Dr. Dupre and Stafford MSD Superintendent Dr. Bostick. While education is primarily a local issue, it’s important for me to understand if any federal issues are impeding local success. Working together, we can maintain local control of education issues and improve access to a quality education for our students. I appreciate the great work of our local educators and will continue working closely with them on behalf of our students. ￼  Stafford MSD Superintendent Dr. Robert Bostick discusses the growth of Stafford MSD   I’m honored to represent you in Congress. For more information or to sign up for my E-newsletter, please visit my website, www.olson.house.gov.  Very respectfully, Pete Olson

Subject: September Highlights from the House
Message:
￼

 
Welch Bill Cracking Down on Medicaid Fraud Advances   At the Vermont State House last month, Peter unveiled his bipartisan legislation to combat Medicaid fraud and abuse. The Committee on Energy and Commerce recently approved his bill, sending it to the full House of Representatives which is expected to pass it this fall. “Medicaid provides vital health care services to over a third of Vermonters, including low-income seniors,” Peter said. “This bipartisan initiative will empower state attorneys general to crack down on bad actors exploiting Vermonters, while ensuring Medicaid remains an efficient and effective program.”  Combatting the Opioid Epidemic      Last month, the House approved a bipartisan package of bills to combat the opioid epidemic ravaging communities in Vermont and across the country. Included were several bills authored by Peter that will increase funding for the Medicaid Health Homes program, attack the root causes of overprescribing in the Medicaid and Medicare programs, educate seniors on alternatives to opioids, and fund National Institutes of Health (NIH) research into non-addictive drugs for pain management. While supportive of the package, Peter decried the lack of a more comprehensive approach to combatting this public health epidemic. He has repeatedly called for a full-scale opioids Marshall Plan that would provide significant resources to those working on the front lines.  Another Round of Tax Cuts for the One Percent? Welch Says No   In remarks on the House floor during debate on a second package of tax cuts for well-off Americans, Peter expressed his strong opposition. “This has nothing to do with the so-called entrepreneurial economy. This has to do with a Congress that has no conscience, that doesn’t stand up for everyday people and say we want policies that let you have a chance.” 
￼ 

WATCH HERE
Nomination of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court   After listening carefully to both Dr. Ford’s and Supreme Court nominee Judge Kavanaugh’s testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Peter urged the President to withdraw the nomination. “Dr. Ford is courageous, credible, and authentic. I believe her. Judge Kavanaugh’s testimony revealed that he does not have the temperament or regard for the truth required to serve on the nation’s highest court. I do not believe him, and the Senate should not confirm him.”   Winooski Main Street Revitalization    Joined by Senators Leahy and Sanders, Peter announced a package of loans and grants from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development totaling over $8.5 million for upgrades to Winooski’s drinking water and wastewater systems. The infrastructure upgrades are a key element of the City’s plan to revitalize Main Street north of downtown. “We fight hard for these resources in Congress precisely so that cities and towns like Winooski can use them to realize their vision for what they want their community to be,” Peter said in a joint statement with Senator Leahy and Senator Sanders.  Welcoming New Americans   Peter participated in an inspiring naturalization ceremony at the Vermont State House for 40 new American citizens hailing from 23 countries. He spoke of the importance of immigrants to our country’s successes and rich cultural fabric. “America was built on the efforts of hard working immigrants who have made valuable contributions to our culture and economy throughout history.”  
￼

Subject: Preparing for Hurricane Michael
Message:
￼

October 9, 2018 
 Dear Lindsey,  
Today, Governor Nathan Deal declared a state of emergency for 92 counties in Georgia, including all 17 counties in Georgia’s First District, ahead of Hurricane Michael. Now is the time to ensure you, your family, and your friends and neighbors are prepared. 
To be better prepared for a storm, you should consider: 
	•	Updating your disaster kit. Make sure to have a three-day supply of non-perishable food and bottled water, a battery-operated radio, a flashlight, extra batteries, cash, medicines, a first aid kit, pet foods, and important family documents.
	•	Knowing your evacuation routes and prepare options for overnight lodging. Storm surge can sometimes cut off evacuation routes, so do not delay leaving if an evacuation is ordered for your area. If you encounter floodwaters, remember – turn around, don’t drown.
	•	Developing an emergency communication plan, which includes the telephone number of a family member or friend outside the area—a point of contact—in the event of separation when a storm hits.
	•	Downloading the FEMA mobile app for a customizable checklist of emergency supplies, maps of open shelters and recovery centers, disaster survival tips, and weather alerts from the National Weather Service. The app also enables users to receive push notifications reminding them to take important steps to prepare their homes and families for disasters. 
Important Numbers 
For information regarding emergency services in local areas, contact your local emergency management agency:
Bacon: (912) 632-7979   Brantley: (912) 462-7874  Bryan: (912) 858-2799  Camden: (912) 729-5602  Charlton: (912) 496-1081  Chatham: (912) 201-4500  Clinch: (912) 487-3700  Echols: (229) 559-8500  Effingham: (912) 429-3615  Glynn: (912) 554-7734  Liberty: (912) 368-2201  Long: (912) 545-3683  McIntosh: (912) 437-5170  Pierce: (912) 449-2040  Ware: (912) 287-4394  Wayne: (912) 427-5979 
If you need assistance or have questions about State Hurricane Response, call the Georgia Emergency Management at 1-800-TRY-GEMA or (1-800-879-4362). 
For medical or health related questions, call the Georgia Department of Public Health at 1-866-PUB-HLTH (1-866-782-4584).   If you are in immediate danger call 911, but please reserve 911 for emergencies only. 
History shows that storm tracks can change quickly and unexpectedly. Residents and visitors in Coastal and South Georgia should continue to monitor local radio and TV stations for updated emergency information, and follow the instructions of state and local officials. Visit www.ready.gov  or http://ready.ga.gov/ for more severe weather and hurricane preparedness information and resources. 
Sincerely,
￼ 
Earl L. "Buddy" Carter 
Member of Congress

P.S. To stay up-to-date with my office on the latest news and developments, please sign up for my newsletter at http://buddycarter.house.gov/newsletter/. 
To opt-out of future e-mails, please click here.
