Subject: Tax Reform 2.0
Message:
E-news Sign-up
￼


Tuesday, October 9, 2018

CONTACT STEVEN


 
Tax Reform 2.0
 
 
Last year, Republicans in Congress worked with President Trump to pass the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that implemented pro-growth and pro-family tax cuts for Mississippi families.

Since we've reformed our tax code we've seen millions of Americans receive bonuses, companies investing back in the United States, small businesses expanding, and unemployment decreasing. Since late 2017, the number of jobs in Mississippi has increased by the thousands and we've achieved our fourth lowest unemployment rate ever recorded - 4.8%! These numbers are great and are a result of the hard work that we've accomplished through tax reform. 

Republicans want to continue lowering taxes and build on the economic successes we've already seen. As a result of this success, House Republicans passed a bill to lock-in the recently passed tax cuts, Tax Reform 2.0. This bill is estimated to create millions of more jobs, boost wages, and increase GDP for the long haul by locking in the individual and small business tax cuts that were included in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. 

I was proud to support this legislation because I believe you should keep the money you earn, not give it to the government. 

Supreme Court 
I am extremely pleased with the Senate’s decision to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to serve on the United States Supreme Court. Judge Kavanaugh has an excellent record of defending our constitution and upholding our American laws. The Democrats put him through one of, if the not the most, grueling confirmation processes in our nation’s history. Not confirming Judge Kavanaugh would have been a huge loss and would have paved the way for further obstruction and destruction of this institution and our country by Senate Democrats. However, Judge Kavanaugh showed tremendous strength in the face of adversity and continued to prove his unyielding commitment to serving our country. 

Securing our Maritime Border
I had the opportunity to meet with the Commandant of the Coast Guard Admiral Karl L. Schultz and the Vice Commandant Charles Ray to discuss the importance of securing our maritime border through the use of ships such as National Security Cutters built at Ingalls as well as other necessary resources. I was glad to secure funding for the 12th National Security Cutter in the most recent House Appropriations Homeland Security bill.
￼

In your service,
￼
Steven

October 9, 2018    

Welcome to the Guide to Grants! 
I am honored to represent the 7th Congressional District of Alabama. One of the most important responsibilities as your representative is to provide you with information about funding opportunities. Now more than ever, grant opportunities are vital to the success of our local governments, organizations and other entities. This weekly guide will identify federal and foundation grant opportunities to assist you in goals for our communities. This Guide will include links to grant writing resources to help you make your proposals more successful. This Guide will also describe new funding opportunities for economic development, infrastructure, healthcare and educational projects as example. In addition, I am pleased to provide a Letter of Support for grant application projects in the 7th Congressional District of Alabama. Please let us know when grants are awarded, especially if you found the opportunities in the Guide to Grants. 
For more information, please visit the website at http://sewell.house.gov/ and you can subscribe to Guide to Grants at: Subscribe to Weekly Guide to Grants | Congresswoman Terri Sewell or call 202-225-2665. Subject: Congressional Update
Message:
eNewsletter | Facebook | Twitter | Mac's Blog | YouTube | Video Mailbox 
￼
Dear Friends,
Over the last few weeks we have made important progress in rebuilding our military, reforming our tax code, taking care of our veterans, and combatting the opioid epidemic.  Below you can find more information about some of the bills Congress has passed since this summer.
Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2019
The President signed legislation to give our men and women in uniform the resources they need to defend our country, on time for the first time in a decade.  One or two bills cannot repair our military fully after years of neglect, but this bill will make a real difference. 
Highlights: 
	•	Continues to rebuild our military by boosting base funding, ensuring our armed services have the resources they need around the world, and provides funds for equipment procurement;
	•	Increases funding for readiness programs to make sure our warfighters are prepared for the missions we ask them to do;
	•	Updates our military for the future of warfare;
	•	Improves end strength by providing sufficient funds for our military personnel and pay;
	•	Includes funding for the Defense Health Program, which cares for our troops, military families, and retirees; and
	•	Makes steps toward reforming the Pentagon to ensure taxpayer dollars are well spent.
District Highlights: 
	•	Sheppard Air Force Base:  The bill appropriates funding for an increase in end strength of the Air Force and a 2.6% pay raise consistent with the FY19 NDAA.  It provides funding to address the readiness crisis including; increased flight hours, equipment upgrades, and depot maintenance.  It also provides funding for the care of our troops, military families, and retirees.    
	•	Bell:  Close to $2.4 billion is appropriated for Bell’s V-22 Osprey and helicopter programs, including the procurement of 13 new Ospreys and 25 new H-1 helicopters.
	•	Pantex: We also passed the Energy and Water Appropriations bill, which provides $44.46 billion for Fiscal Year 2019 (FY19) and provides funding for the Army Corps of Engineers, Department of Energy (DOE), and our nation’s nuclear weapons security programs.
	◦	Provides $11.1 billion for nuclear weapons activities, which supports operations at Pantex;
	◦	Includes $24 million for the Material Staging Facility at Pantex, which is the same amount authorized in the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA); and
	◦	Gives the Army Corps of Engineers $7 billion for ports, waterways, and flood protection infrastructure.
VA Mission Act
The VA MISSION Act was signed into law in June.  This bill will help ensure that veterans have access to the care they need with an updated VA program and a process that is efficient and timely. These men and women have put their lives on the line for our freedom, and they deserve the best care when they return home.
Highlights:
	•	Combines the VA’s community care programs into one cohesive program;
	•	Updates or realigns VA medical facilities;
	•	Expands the VA’s post-9/11 Caregiver program to all eras; and
	•	Includes funding for the Choice Program and permits family caregivers to receive support.
Opioid Package
The House and Senate passed the final version of H.R. 6, the “SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act.”  This bill combats illicit and synthetic drugs crossing the borders, encourages the development of new non-addictive painkillers, improves prescription drug monitoring, and continues to fight the opioid crisis in our country.
H.R. 6 also includes provisions I authored that mirrors the "Synthetic Abuse and Labeling of Toxic Substances (SALTS) Act,” which I introduced again earlier this year.  These provisions amend the Controlled Substance Act (CSA) to specify factors to be considered in determining whether a controlled substance was intended for human consumption.  Currently, synthetic drug producers, manufacturers, and sellers can easily skirt regulations by simply adding a “not for human consumption” label on their product.  Law enforcement and health officials are able to prosecute the sale of similar drugs and substances, but the law does not cover substances with that label.  These provisions close that loophole. 
I have held roundtables with local law enforcement, educators, and public health and medical officials in our area to discuss the problem and possible federal action.  This provision was a result of those meetings.
A big part of the problem is that young people and parents are not aware of the serious side effects of these poisons.  These drugs invoke dangerous behavior and cause irreparable damage to the health of those who ingest them. 
Tax Reform 2.0
Since tax reform was signed into law in December, we have seen jobs created, growth in our economy, and hardworking Americans keep more of the money they earn.  This September, the House passed three more tax reform bills that continue to take steps forward for our economy and our country. 
Highlights:
	•	Permanently extends tax reform provisions that currently expire in 2025, including:
	•	Allows individuals to deduct their medical expenses if they exceeded 7.5 (instead of 10 percent) percent of their adjusted gross income through 2020;
	•	Creates a new Universal Savings Account (USA) to offer a fully flexible savings tool that families can use at any time;
	•	Gives flexibility to also use education savings to pay for apprenticeship fees to learn a trade, cover the cost of homeschooling, and help pay off student debt;
	•	Allows families to access their retirement accounts on a penalty-free basis to use as they see fit when welcoming a new child into the family, whether by birth or adoption. And allows families to replenish those retirement accounts in the future;
	•	Makes the 20 percent deduction for pass-through business income permanent;
	•	Allows new businesses to write off more of their initial start-up cost;
	•	Allows start-ups to expand by bringing in new investors without triggering limits on their access to tax benefits like the R&D credit for activities conducted in their early years; and
	•	Helps local businesses provide retirement plans to their employees.
FAA Reauthorization

The House and Senate have both approved the "FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018," which reauthorizes the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) disaster programs at the Federal Emergency Management Administration (FEMA), the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB).  This bill updates aviation infrastructure, ensuring that airports are safer for travelers.  In addition, the FAA would have to set minimum dimensions for passenger seats required for safety within one year of the bill’s enactment.  It is also important to note that this bill does not privatize air traffic control (ATC).
If you have questions, concerns, or suggestions about these or any other issues please visit my website, contact me by phone, letter, e-mail, or on Facebook.  It is important that the people of District 13 know what we are doing in Washington for them, and that we continue to hear from you.  
As always, I appreciate hearing from you.

Sincerely,
￼
Join Mac's Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/repmacthornberry?sk=wall

Subject: Leveling the Playing Field for Trade
Message:
News from Congressman Dan Newhouse
￼  
Leveling the Playing Field for Trade 
￼ 
Last week, an agreement was reached on the new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) to modernize NAFTA. The USMCA is outstanding news for America's farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers. Under this deal, Central Washington wheat farmers gain fair treatment, and dairy producers gain greater access to the Canadian market. American workers need a level playing field, and President Trump kept his promise to renegotiate NAFTA with that goal. I applaud the work of President Trump and U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer in successfully pushing to modernize the trilateral agreement with our closest trading partners. I attended the President's announcement at the White House Rose Garden. You can watch here. 
Listen to Locals on Shoreline Transfer 
￼ 
Click here to watch KAPP-KVEW's coverage. 
I joined members of the Tri-Cities community to discuss the ongoing proposal to reconvey part of the Columbia River shoreline currently owned by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. I have encouraged public meetings like this, so all corners of the community have the opportunity to engage, ask questions, share concerns, and be included in the decisions being made at the federal level. Kennewick, Richland, and Pasco pay to maintain these shoreline lands. Local tax dollars operate the public parks and amenities along the waterfront, and these communities deserve to have these shoreline lands under their local control. So long as we can assure that all voices have the opportunity to be part of this community effort, I will continue to work to get it across the finish land. You can learn more about the reconveyance here and learn more about the progress being made in Congress here. 
Workforce for the Future 
￼ 
The Tri-Cities region is one of the fastest growing economies in the state, and there are many jobs that need skilled workers to fill them. It is important that the local workforce has the proper training to take advantage of these opportunities. I had the opportunity to attend Connect Tri-Cities in Kennewick, which is an annual event that brings together employers, job seekers, educators, labor groups, tribes, and veterans to build and develop strong future employees.  
Results for Local Businesses 
￼ 
At the West Richland Chamber of Commerce monthly luncheon, I was able to connect with business owners and community leaders to discuss their priorities in Congress. There is a lot of work being done to encourage small business growth and investment, and I am pleased to see optimism and positivity among Central Washington businesses. Stability and certainty are vital for business owners as they plan to invest in their communities or expand their services. I am proud to be able to deliver permanent tax cuts for individuals families, and small businesses by voting to support the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act of 2018.  
Spurring Economic Development 
￼ 
The Columbia Gardens Urban Wine & Artisan Village is a fairly new attraction in historic downtown Kennewick that is bringing together Washington's famous wine industry, local producers, artists, culinary experts, and sellers. I toured the still-developing location to see how the Port of Kennewick is encouraging tourists and locals to spur a revival of the area. The Village features a beautiful Latino Heritage Mural, and Columbia Basin College will use the space to jump start their new culinary program. I appreciate the opportunity to see one of the Tri-Cities' latest economic development projects. 
Encouraging STEM  
￼ 
I met with the FIRST LEGO League FOG Buster team from Richland, and they demonstrated their Funnel Interceptor project. The FOG Busters are utilizing their STEM education and skills to think like innovators, working to develop solutions to real-world problems, and they were one of only 20 teams worldwide to make it to the International Global League competition. Their project was designed to separate great from soap before it gets to the sewer lines, saving pipes from clogging. It is inspirational to see these brilliant young minds at work, and it gives me hope that our future is in good hands. 
The Highest Award 
￼ 
It was an honor to join the President as he awarded the nation's highest distinction, the Medal of Honor, to U.S. Army Staff Sergeant Ronald J. Shurer II from Washington state. Sergeant Shurer served as Senior Medical Sergeant in the Special Forces in support of Operation ENDURING FREEDOM. He and his team were engaged by enemy fire, and Sergeant Shurer bravely fought to treat, stabilize, evacuate, and protect his fellow brothers in arms. He was honorably discharged in 2009 and began his career with the Secret Service as a Special Agent. Our entire state and nation salute Shurer's bravery with the highest award. Learn more about Sergeant Shurer here. 
Thank you for reading this e-news update. It is an honor and privilege to serve you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Dan Newhouse Member of Congress

Subject: Kavanaugh Appointed to the Supreme Court, Congress Passes $1.68 Billion Disaster Relief Package
Message:
News from Representative Butterfield  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼  

HOME
ABOUT G.K.B.
ABOUT THE DISTRICT
NEWS
CONTACT
 
 
The Washington Rundown 
After a highly criticized consideration process, the United States Senate voted to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s appointment to the U.S. Supreme Court.  Last week, the House of Representatives passed H.R. 302, the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018, which included $1.68 billion in disaster relief.  $1.14 billion of this funding will support North Carolina’s recovery efforts from damaging winds and flooding caused by Hurricane Florence, including resources to rebuild housing and infrastructure. 
Butterfield Convenes Meeting on Hurricane Florence Recovery  
Last Monday, Congressman Butterfield convened a meeting with state officials to discuss the inclusion of small, women-owned, and minority-owned businesses in Hurricane Florence recovery efforts.  Butterfield thanked officials for their diligent work as our state continues to recover, and urged them to utilize more of these businesses to help recovery efforts. 
￼ 
￼ 
Reps. Butterfield & Sewell Examine New Voting Rights Report 
In September, Congressman Butterfield and Congresswoman Terri Sewell (AL) held a hearing in Washington, DC with commissioners from the United States Commission on Civil Rights to examine their latest report, An Assessment of Minority Voting Rights Access in the United States.  
The Report identified many of the same barriers to minority participation in voting that Congressman Butterfield has been fighting against since the Supreme Court’s decision in Shelby County v. Holder, which gutted core protections in the Voting Rights Act.  The report shows how states across the country have enacted laws to change voting procedures that wrongly prevent certain citizens, namely minorities, from having equal access to the ballot box.  These measures include: strict voter ID laws, early voting changes popular with minority groups, and challenges to voter eligibility.  The release of the report is timely as North Carolinians will vote in November on a constitutional amendment that would require voter ID in the state.  Republicans in the General Assembly passed a law to add the proposed constitutional amendment to the November ballot.  The proposed amendment to the North Carolina Constitution comes a year after the U.S. Supreme Court refused to consider an appeal by North Carolina Republicans to reinstate their strict voter ID law after Federal judges struck the law down because it was unconstitutionally discriminatory and targeted African American voters “with almost surgical precision.”
￼ 
￼ 
 Watch the video recording of the hearing here. 
Butterfield Announces 2018 Service Academy Day 
￼  
RSVP to attend here. 
Hurricane Florence Recovery Moves Ahead  
Anyone whose home was damaged by Florence is encouraged to begin the FEMA registration process by calling 1-800-621-FEMA to register via telephone or by visiting disasterassistance.gov to register online. People can also apply at disaster recovery centers open around the state in hard-hit communities. 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼

ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | CONTACT
STARTING TODAY: EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS ON MEDICARE ENROLLMENT
￼
Medicare is a sacred commitment we have made to our seniors, and part of keeping that promise is ensuring Hoosiers have all the information they need to secure their benefits. With the Medicare enrollment period coming up, we want to help answer your questions.
On October 9th, 10th, and 16th, a member of my staff and a Medicare specialist from Indiana’s State Health Insurance Program (SHIP) will hold “Medicare 101” educational sessions throughout the 2nd District. The events will take place in Elkhart, Goshen, La Porte, Peru, Plymouth, South Bend, Wabash, and Winamac.
If you are at or near retirement or are a caregiver for a Medicare beneficiary and you want to learn more about the program, I encourage you to attend our “Medicare 101” educational sessions to learn the basics of Medicare and have your questions answered by experts.
Information about the “Medicare 101” events can be found below:
Tuesday, October 9th, 10:00 – 11:30 a.m. ET Wabash Public Library Program Room 188 West Hill Street Wabash, IN 46992
Tuesday, October 9th, 1:00 – 2:30 p.m. ET Pulaski County Public Library Reading Room 121 South Riverside Drive Winamac, IN 46996
Tuesday, October 9th, 4:00 – 5:30 p.m. ET Peru Public Library Program Room 102 E. Main St. Peru, IN 46970
Wednesday, October 10th, 10:00 – 11:30 a.m. ET Plymouth Public Library Laramore Room A/B 201 North Center Street Plymouth, IN 46563

Subject: Unemployment is Lowest Since 1969, New Trade Deal Announced, Yoder Hosting Medicare Events
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
ABOUT  |  CONTACT  |  SERVICES  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATION  |  RESOURCES
￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
October 08, 2018
Last Week in Congress
Unemployment Rate Falls Again - Now Lowest Since 1969
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from CNN Business
Thanks to the economic growth being driven by tax reform, the unemployment rate hit its lowest level in 49 years - nearly half a century. Last month, the unemployment rate fell to 3.7%, and now there are even more jobs available than the total number of unemployed Americans. The economy has averaged an increase of 208,000 jobs per month in 2018 – exceeding the average monthly jobs growth of the last two years. The last time the roaring American jobs market was this strong, astronauts were still going to the moon. I am proud to be working on policies that are creating economic opportunities for every single American.
￼
U.S. Announces New Trade Deal with Mexico and Canada
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from the Washington Post
Last week, the United States, Mexico, and Canada struck a new trade deal to replace the 25 year old agreement known as NAFTA. The new deal, called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA is the result of more than a year of negotiating between the three nations, and would make major changes with regard to agriculture, automobile manufacturing, intellectual property protections, digital trade provisions, and also includes new policies on environmental standards and fair labor practices. USMCA will create more balanced, reciprocal trade that supports high-paying jobs for Americans and grow the North American economy.
The new agreement will benefit Kansas farmers and ranchers by allowing greater access to Canadian and Mexican dairy and poultry markets, in addition to creating a more even playing field for wheat farmers in Kansas and across the country. Under the modernized agreement, all other tariffs on agricultural products traded between the United States and Mexico will remain at zero. In addition, the deal improves trade rules on automobiles, intellectual property, and other key trade items. 
￼
Down Syndrome Awareness Month
￼ Team Yoder with Rachel Mast
Team Yoder and families went out for a fun dinner Sunday night at Olive Garden and surprised our friend and hostess Rachel Mast for Down Syndrome Awareness Month. Rachel was running the show at the Olive Garden and greeted us with a big smile. We are very proud of you, Rachel!
Over the years, I've had the privilege of working with organizations like the National Down Syndrome Society, Down Syndrome Guild of Greater Kansas City, and Inclusion Connections, and I've gotten to know a lot of remarkable people like Rachel Mast. When I was first elected to Congress, Jonathan, Jawanda, and Rachel Mast of Olathe came to me, shared their story, and advocated for policies that positively impact the lives of people with Down syndrome and their families. Together, we passed the ABLE Act into law, which helps families with children with special needs have the chance to save for a future of independence through tax free savings accounts.Their story shows that the voices of real people are heard in the halls of Congress. Thank you to Rachel and her family, and every person who advocates for legislation to help those with Down syndrome fulfill their dreams – I will continue to do my part in Congress.
￼
Around the District
Yoder Hosting Two Medicare Open Enrollment Assistance Events
￼ Kevin speaking with seniors at a previous Medicare enrollment event
I'm excited to announce that I will be hosting two Medicare Open Enrollment Assistance Events to provide help to seniors during the Medicare Open Enrollment Period, which extends from October 15 through December 7. These events will be held Wednesday, October 17 from 9:00 AM to 12:30 PM at Johnson County Central Resource Library and Tuesday, October 23 from 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM at Kansas City, KS West Wyandotte Library.
Trained volunteers from the Senior Health Insurance Counseling for Kansas (SHICK) program will be on hand at the event to provide one-on-one assistance to seniors who have questions or who wish to make changes to their plans.
For more information, please visit my website or call my office at (913) 621-0832.  
￼
Federal Investment in Kansas Career and Technical Education
￼ Kevin observing a teacher and student at Gardner Edgerton's ATC
Making sure Americans have the tools and training required by 21st century jobs is an important factor in the continued growth of our economy. Recently, the House voted to pass a spending bill which will increase funding for the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act, the primary source of federal funding for states to develop academic, career, and technical skills of secondary and postsecondary students. The impact of this legislation directly benefits our local community colleges and public school districts who receive these funds including the Gardner Edgerton School District.
Last week, I visited Gardner Edgerton School District High School’s Advanced Technical Center (ATC), which offers advanced courses in auto collision, welding, carpentry and culinary arts. This career and technical education is a great opportunity for students to learn about jobs in fields that are currently hiring and many students leave with certifications to work immediately. The teachers I met during the visit are professionals in their fields and passionate about teaching these skills to the next generation. I saw firsthand what the students are learning – and was particularly impressed by the students building decks, repairing cars and welding. All the slots are full at ATC, and there is a waiting list. Students enrolled in the ATC programs are doing better academically in other classes as well. Thank you to Superintendent Pam Stranathan and Coordinator of Student Services Melissa McIntire for your vision and leadership for this new program and facility only in its 2nd year. 
￼
Employee Townhall at Design Mechanical
￼ Kevin speaking to employees at Design Mechanical
I appreciated a chance to join an employee town hall at Design Mechanical in KCK. I listened to their comments and took questions on trade, immigration, the economy and prioritizing civility in Congress. It was great to hear what's on the minds of small business employees in the Third District right now, and I enjoyed our productive discussion.
￼
Overland Park Rotary Club
￼ Kevin with OP Rotary President Mike Tracy
It was great to be back at the Overland Park Rotary Club last week hearing about amazing research happening at Children's Mercy. It was also nice to see old friends and greet past President Jim Courtney and current President Mike Tracy. The Rotary motto of "service above self" is a guiding principle for me, and I am always honored to join other Rotarians who are committed to service as well.
￼
Yoder Receives Champion of Small Business Investing Award
￼ Kevin with SG360 employees
I enjoyed visiting the Lenexa headquarters of SG360, a local business that is working to “Keep it Clean” all across the country. We talked about the important role SG360, and all small businesses, play in driving our booming economy. While there, I was also honored to receive the Champion of Small Business Investing Award from the Small Business Investor Alliance, a leading trade association working to promote competitive markets and increased opportunities to invest in small businesses. I strongly support the partnership between the U.S. Small Business Administration and private companies that finance local businesses like SG360 who provide the jobs and services that are so important to our local and national economy. I will continue to work to ensure that small businesses have the tools and resources they need to expand and support our growing economy.
￼
KU Edwards Campus
￼ Kevin with KU Vice Chancellor David Cook
Last week, I enjoyed a visit to the KU Edwards Campus in Overland Park. Thanks to Vice Chancellor David Cook for meeting with me and sharing the exciting news that this fall semester enrollment at KU Edwards campus increased 12.5 percent from one year ago. We discussed the needs of students and our work in Congress to support student financial aid programs like Pell Grants, which I used to put myself through college at KU. These programs are critical for students in our District and can often be the deciding factor on whether a student can afford college. Recently, I voted in favor of restoring year-round Pell Grants, allowing students to use these funds for summer classes and enable them to finish their degrees more quickly and decrease student loan debt. In September, I’m also proud to have voted in favor of the Fiscal Year 2019 Labor, Health and Human Services Appropriations bill, which increased the maximum annual Pell Grant per student to a new record-high level.
￼
National Coffee with a Cop Day
￼ Kevin with Acting Deputy Chief Sonta Wilburn and Officer John Lacy
I participated in National Coffee With A Cop Day with the Overland Park Police Department at their Coffee with a Cop event at LaMar’s Donuts and Coffee to encourage communication between law enforcement and the public. Thank you to our local police who put their lives on the line each day to keep us safe.
￼
Fairfax Festival in KCK
￼ Kevin with Tony Privitera, Melissa Clark, and Mike Martin
It was great to be at the annual Fairfax Festival at Kaw Point Park in KCK, with fantastic views of the river and downtown. The event featured awesome music, food, and local history. The Fairfax Industrial District is home to over 120 businesses and is an important part of our local economy. I’m proud to represent the Fairfax industrial area, and thanks to Melissa Clark from the Fairfax Industrial Association (FIA) for her invitation and leadership.
￼
Coffee with Small Business Leaders
￼ Kevin speaking with the combined chambers
Last Friday I joined a multi-Chamber coffee including the Chambers of Commerce of Gardner Edgerton, Louisburg & Spring Hill at Shawnee Mission Health in Overland Park. It was great to hearing from small business owners about their experiences with this strong economy. The National Federation of Independent Business's Optimism Index is at an all-time high point, and that optimism was certainly reflected in the conversations I had with Third District small business owners last week.
￼
Annual Advice & Aid Banquet
￼ Kevin speaking at the Advice and Aid Banquet
On Saturday evening, Brooke and I attended the annual Advice & Aid Pregnancy Centers banquet in Overland Park. This amazing organization helps women and their families, during crisis and beyond. Thank you to Ruth Tisdale for your leadership and everyone who attended.
￼

Fact of the Week
Right now, the unemployment rates for African Americans workers, Hispanic American workers, and workers without a high school diploma are all at the lowest levels in history!
Third District Trivia 
The current unemployment rate is the lowest since 1969. Who was the Third District's Representative in the U.S. House of Representatives that year?
Send your answers to haley.brady@mail.house.gov and the first correct response will receive a shout out in next week's newsletter.
Congratulations to last week's winner Don Cook!
Last week's answer:  The Louisburg Cider Fest began in 1978 and is now celebrating its 40th anniversary.
National Taco Day in KCK
￼
I celebrated National Taco Day at one of my favorite local KCK small businesses, Ninfa’s Tortillas y Taqueria. Thanks to Mike and Alex Garza for the great tacos and the update on your small business.
Thank You Marvin Szneler
￼
Thanks to Marvin Szneler for his long time service as Executive Director of Jewish Community Relations Bureau at the American Jewish Community. Over the years, we’ve partnered on legislation, events, and I’m proud to call him a friend. Marvin, we’ve appreciated your advocacy work and we wish you the best!
Legislative Look Ahead
Members of the House of Representatives will work from their respective home districts this week.
Legislative Wrap Up
Members of the House of Representatives worked from their respective home districts last week.
￼

Subject: News From Washington And Across West Texas
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Congressman Arrington
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
NEWS FROM WASHINGTON AND ACROSS WEST TEXAS
Dear Friend, 
I had the opportunity to visit with many of you in Seminole, Big Spring, and Lubbock last week. From honoring a few of our fallen heroes to meeting with educators and community leaders, it is easy to see why the good people of West Texas are the finest in the nation.
Fair Trade 
With the new United States–Mexico–Canada (USMCA) Agreement, President Trump has delivered on his promise to renegotiate NAFTA in a way that works better for American workers, manufacturers, and agriculture producers. I believe in the extraordinary value of open markets, but the rules of trade must apply to all partner nations in a fair and reciprocal way. The main reason Canada and Mexico were willing to agree to new terms is simply this: we have a president who negotiates from strength and won’t fold under political pressure.
￼ 
Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh
Justice Kavanaugh was more thoroughly vetted than any Supreme Court Justice nominee in recent history, and I am pleased that the Senate confirmed him to the High Court. While the nature of the allegations were serious, they all remain completely unsubstantiated and uncorroborated. I am relieved that we still have a majority of Senators who believe in due process and the presumption of innocence. 
The personal attacks by some have reached an all-time low and, unfortunately, Justice Kavanaugh and Dr. Ford were both victims of this process. Justice Kavanaugh is eminently qualified, has unimpeachable character, and will appropriately render decisions based on the Constitution and Rule of Law - not on a political or policy agenda.
In spite of the drama and damage done in the process, I am pleased that Justice Kavanaugh has been confirmed and the Constitution will be restored to the High Court. My most heart-felt congratulations to my friends, Brett and Ashley - two of the most exceptional people I know. Justice Kavanaugh will be a fair, informed, and objective justice with the highest fidelity to the Constitution and Rule of Law. See here for a few more thoughts on his confirmation.  
￼ 
West Texas Warriors 
Rural America contributes the best of the best men and women in our armed forces – many have called West Texas home. This week it was my profound honor to be with the people of Big Spring and Lubbock to pay tribute to three of our fallen soldiers, Specialist Robert James "RJ" Volker, Petty Officer Mark Russell Cannon, and Specialist Geoffrey Golden Johnson. Their service and sacrifice has ensured our nation’s freedom and security. RJ, Mark, and Geoffrey are West Texas Warriors, and it is our duty to never forget them and to always strive to be a nation worthy of their sacrifice. 
￼ 
New Lubbock VA Clinic 
I’m excited about the partnership between the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and Texas Tech Health Sciences Center to provide thousands of veterans throughout West Texas with the highest quality of care. Veterans represent the best of our country, and they deserve the best from their country. Read here for more on VA’s announcement to award a new lease for a replacement for the Outpatient Clinic in Lubbock, Texas. 
As a member of the House VA Committee and throughout the 115th Congress, we have passed legislation and conducted oversight over the Department of Veterans Affairs, holding them to the highest of standards. The VA’s action to award new leases to facilities across the nation reaffirms their commitment to serving our veterans.
Growing Communities 
With a growing economy comes the confidence for our communities to invest in new projects that expand opportunity and improve quality of life for our citizens. Because of pro-growth policies supported by this Congress and administration and the hard work of the American people, business is booming and our communities are flourishing. 
It is exciting to see our local economy right here in Big Spring thriving. I was glad to be a part of the Big Spring Industrial Park Rail Project grand opening with Mayor Larry McLellan, the Big Spring Economic Development Corporation, the Big Spring Chamber of Commerce, and others that made this initiative possible. Big things are happening in Big Spring! 
￼ 
Future Leaders 
Our education systems are best run at the state and local levels. The more we pull the heavy hand of the federal government out of our schools, the more freedom they will have to do what’s best locally. It was good to visit Seminole High School and see how they are paving the way for our next generation of leaders. 
￼ 
Please know, it is an honor to be your representative. Feel free to reach out to my office and let me know how I can best serve you. 
Your friend and fellow West Texan, ￼  Jodey C. Arrington Member of Congress

Subject: A Message From Ann
Message:
A message from Congresswoman Ann Wagner 
￼ 

About
Contact
Services
Media Center
Issues


Dear Lindsey, 
An estimated 126 million women are missing from the world population due to gender-based violence, neglect, sex-selective abortions, and infanticide. It is heartbreaking when the lives of young girls are valued less than the lives of young boys, and Congress must stand up against the promotion of violence against girls around the world. That is why I along with Rep. Karen Bass (D-CA) introduced the Stop Gendercide Act of 2018. Violence against women and girls has led to skewed sex ratios in certain national and sub-national populations. In these populations, there is evidence that heightened demand for women can make them more vulnerable to human trafficking crimes, child marriage, and exploitation. This legislation will give the U.S. government, partner nations, and civil society the information they need to better respond to changes in human trafficking patterns driven by discriminatory environments.  Because of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed last year, the average family in Missouri’s 2nd Congressional District is saving an additional $3,700 a year. Now, the House has voted to make those tax cuts permanent. Before coming back to Missouri, I voted to pass Tax Reform 2.0, a comprehensive package for Missourians that protects middle-class and small business tax cuts, promotes family savings, helps local businesses provide retirement plans for their workers, and advances the next generation of entrepreneurs in America. It includes a doubled Child Tax Credit, the first ever Paid Family Leave Tax Credit, and expanded 529 education accounts that cover apprenticeship fees, the cost of homeschooling, and can help repay student debt. Tax Reform 2.0 creates a new baby savings mechanism which allows families to access their retirement accounts penalty-free upon welcoming a new child and to replenish those accounts later on. It also creates a new Universal Savings Account to offer a fully flexible savings tool that families can use any time they choose. 
￼
￼

Last week, President Trump announced the new North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which includes the Wagner Language to uphold the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (FOSTA). This new agreement creates more balanced and fairer trade for American workers. It stimulates U.S. manufacturing by supporting domestic vehicle and auto parts production, and sets new standards for agricultural biotechnology, a key industry here in Missouri’s 2nd District. The USMCA also modernizes IP standards and protects American innovation, and increases market access and stability for American farmers while providing a strengthened environment for food manufacturing and rural jobs across Missouri.

Importantly, I have worked with U.S. trade negotiators to guarantee this agreement includes specific language upholding my recently enacted law, FOSTA, to help stop the online sex trade here at home and now throughout North America. It was my pleasure to speak with Ambassador C.J. Mahoney about continuing to work together on U.S. trade agreements to reflect America's position on fighting human trafficking. The Wagner Language allows our trading partners to enact domestic laws that enable victims to sue the websites that facilitate the sex trade and empower law enforcement at all levels—federal, state, and local—to protect their communities. I hope that USMCA guides legislatures across our continent to enact strong laws that protect victims and dismantle the online sex trade.

￼
￼

While in the district, I had opportunities to meet with Colonel Michael Holland of the Army Reserve, JDRF patient-advocates, and attend the swearing-in ceremony for Ballwin Police Department Officer Shannon Schaper. I’m tremendously thankful to represent a community of such talented individuals who work hard every day to provide for a better tomorrow!

￼
￼
￼
Sincerely, 
￼  Ann Wagner Member of Congress 
￼
￼
￼

￼￼ 

Kansas Common Sense  October 8, 2018
Hello,
 
Welcome to “Kansas Common Sense.” Thanks for your continued interest in receiving my weekly newsletter. Please feel free to forward it on to your family and friends if it would interest them.
 
Confirming Judge Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court
After full consideration of all facts presented, I voted this weekend to confirm Judge Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court of the United States. Judge Kavanaugh is an extremely well-qualified nominee with a deep respect for the Constitution. His intellect and experience in the legal field will serve the Supreme Court well.
However, when someone comes forward with allegations of abuse or misconduct, they deserve to be heard. I appreciated that the Judiciary Committee took these allegations seriously and was committed to being transparent and following the precedented and necessary procedures to best evaluate these claims – including the decision to request that the administration instruct the FBI to conduct an additional FBI supplemental background investigation.
I commend Dr. Ford for telling her story before the nation, and inspiring others to come forward. Judge Kavanaugh also deserved the opportunity to defend his character, and he categorically denied these allegations. Throughout this process, I have been deeply saddened by the treatment of both Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh – and their families. 
After the supplemental FBI background investigation was delivered to the Senate, I carefully reviewed the FBI’s report, as well as the findings from the independent prosecutor. No witness named by Dr. Ford or Ms. Ramirez corroborated the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh. And there was no new information or evidence provided in the report that changed my earlier plan to vote for Judge Kavanaugh. 
Long-Term FAA Extension Takes Flight!
After years of negotiations, on Wednesday the Senate passed a five-year extension to the Federal Aviation Administration’s authority – this bipartisan, bicameral legislation is welcome news for travelers, aerospace manufacturers and industry innovators alike. Not only does this reauthorization elevate the over 40,000 Kansans who make a living manufacturing, operating and servicing the aircraft industry, but it includes important provisions I championed to close the aviation skills gap and to bring more women into this field.
Additionally, this extension does not include any misguided proposals to privatize our nation’s air traffic control system. ATC privatization threatens access to airspace for all but the largest cities with largest airports, causing significant harm to the long-term economic viability of rural America. I will continue to advocate instead for proposals that provide greater protections for the general aviation industry and small airports nationwide that are so critical to connecting Americans in rural communities with the rest of the world. Overall, this legislation will make airline travel smoother, safer and more transparent for all Americans.
Click here for more on the numerous wins for Kansans in this reauthorization. 
Reviewing the New U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement Over the past year and a half, I have expressed directly and repeatedly to President Trump, Ambassador Lighthizer, Secretary Ross and my colleagues in the Senate that we need more trade, not less. I have been clear that both Canada and Mexico – Kansas’ top two export markets – must be part of any final agreement. I appreciate the administration working to make certain these markets remain available to Kansas farmers, ranchers and manufacturers, providing them some much-needed certainty. 
Once the president signs the agreement, it will be up to Congress to consider and vote to approve the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, most likely next year. However, today, farmers and ranchers are breathing a sigh of relief as the announcement brings greater certainty at a time when producers are facing extended periods of low commodity prices. Agricultural conditions in our state – due to drought, commodity prices, and the uncertainty of export markets – are a significant challenge. Simply put, we produce more in this country than we can consume and we need export markets so we can continue to sell our goods and commodities. I will further analyze the details of this agreement, but this announcement is clearly a positive development. Watch my Senate floor remarks on what this agreement means for Kansas here.  
Holding My Subcommittee’s Fourth Hearing on Protecting Olympic Athletes from Abuse As the chairman of the Commerce Subcommittee with jurisdiction over the health and safety of amateur athletes, I convened my fourth hearing as part of our ongoing investigation into systemic failures to protect athletes from abuse within the Olympic movement. On Wednesday, the subcommittee heard testimony from and posed questions to the executive leadership of USA Swimming, USA Weightlifting, USA Bobsled and Skeleton, and US Figure Skating regarding policies that have already been implemented to prevent and report abuse and what changes still need to be made to provide a safe environment for amateur athletes. 
We were honored to be joined by survivors of abuse from multiple sports in the audience who continue to lend their stories and their voices to these important issues. I remain dedicated to continuing the bipartisan approach that this subcommittee has taken in its comprehensive investigation. In consultation with law enforcement, survivors and advocates, I will work closely with my Senate colleagues to identify meaningful reform in the best interests of athletes and their families. To watch my questioning, click here. 
 ￼
Securing Amtrak’s Commitment to Maintain Southwest Chief On Wednesday, I questioned in the Chief Operating Officer of Amtrak in a Senate Commerce Committee hearing, where I again expressed my disappointment in Amtrak’s handling of ensuring service on the Southwest Chief rail line – in recent months, Amtrak has put forth a misguided proposal to break up hundreds of miles of the Southwest Chief passenger rail line, swapping buses for trains. This proposal was unacceptable to me and the many Kansans who rely on the Southwest Chief, and I proposed an amendment that would forbid Amtrak from implementing such a proposal. This amendment passed the Senate in August, and is still waiting on a final vote from the House of Representatives. 
However, at this week’s hearing, Amtrak committed to continuing operation of the Southwest Chief as-is through the end of Fiscal Year 2019. This is a positive development for the riders who rely on this rail line, but there is still much work to be done. Amtrak has still not committed to honoring its $3 million pledge for track improvements, nor has it guaranteed continued service after FY’19. I will continue working with my colleagues and Amtrak to make certain the Southwest Chief continues to offer communities in Kansas – and along the entire passenger rail route – the service they need. 
 ￼ 
Honoring the Women of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion I am delighted that on Wednesday, the Senate unanimously passed my resolution honoring the women of the 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion. These soldiers were members of the only all-black, all-female battalion to serve overseas during World War II. The unit trained at home, and served in England and in France where they sorted and routed mail for millions of American servicemembers and civilians. 
A memorial, with a planned dedication this fall, will honor the battalion at the Buffalo Soldier Memorial Park on Fort Leavenworth in Kansas. I’m proud to see our nation continue to take measures like these to recognize these women and patriots, and the sacrifices they endured decades ago. This Senate-approved measure and the construction of a memorial at Fort Leavenworth will increase awareness of these brave soldiers’ service to make certain the Battalion and their sacrifices for our nation are not forgotten. 
Participating in a Senate Commerce Hearing on Rural Broadband On Thursday, I participated in a Senate Commerce Committee hearing entitled, “Broadband: Opportunities and Challenges in Rural America,” where we discussed the Committee’s ongoing efforts to assess the progress of broadband deployment to rural communities, with particular emphasis on the efficacy of the broadband deployment programs within the Federal Communications Commission’s Universal Service Fund and the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Rural Utilities Service. As Congress seeks to continue its mission of closing the Digital Divide by bringing high-speed broadband access to rural America, I will continue to prioritize timely deployment and related economic development in Kansas. Watch the full exchange here. 
￼ 
Speaking with the Kansas Chamber in Washington, D.C.
On Thursday, I joined members of the Kansas Chamber of Commerce during their annual Congressional visit to Washington, D.C. During our meeting, I offered updates on work I’m doing in the Senate and my priorities Congress, including judicial issues, the recently-passed FAA Reauthorization and the positive impacts it will have on Kansas, ongoing trade disputes and the recently-announced USMCA agreement, nominations in the Senate, as well as various economic and business policies. I also fielded questions from the group on issues important to their work. The Kansas Chamber of Commerce reaches many Kansans across the state and their work to support small businesses and create a pro-growth environment has benefitted communities of all shapes and sizes. I’m proud of our partnership and I look forward to working with them well into the future.
￼
Keynoting the Associated General Contractors of Kansas Legislative Dinner On Sunday, I gave the keynote address at the Associated General Contractors (AGC) of Kansas’ Legislative Dinner. During my remarks,  I discussed a number of items that I’m making progress on specifically related to the AGC's work. This included topics ranging from technical and career education, workforce development, trade and tariffs, veterans’ healthcare, tax cuts and regulatory relief. Thank you to AGC of Kansas Executive Vice President Mike Gibson for the invitation and Ben Hutton for the kind introduction. Thanks also to State Senator Dan Kerschen, State Representative Joe Seiwert and State Representative Jack Thimesch for joining me.
￼ 
Kansas Listening Tour Stop in Cowley County Thank you to the many Cowley County residents who took time to visit with me during my townhall meeting in Arkansas City on Monday. During this meeting, we discussed veterans' healthcare, the implementation of the VA MISSION Act, tariffs and ongoing trade disputes, Social Security and the need to work together and find common ground, both in society and in Congress. Thank you to Dan Deener and the Ark City Rotary Club for opening up their meeting to the public and for arranging my visit.
 ￼ 
Touring the Winfield Cotton Gin Prior to my townhall meeting in Arkansas City, I was in Winfield to tour the Winfield Cotton Gin and meet with members of the Southern Kansas Cotton Growers Cooperative. Recently, they've experienced both an increase in automation at the gin, as well as a growth in the amount of cotton being grown by area farmers. During this visit, I toured their facility and heard first-hand from members of their cooperative about challenges they’re facing during an increasingly hard time for our producers, especially related to weather and ongoing trade disputes. We also discussed the importance of agriculture research, and I offered an update on the Farm Bill. Thank you to Rex Friesen for arranging my visit and leading the tour of the gin, and to the many Southern Kansas Cotton Growers and local producers who were able to join our discussion. 
 ￼ 
Now Accepting Spring Internship Applications My own interest in public service was sparked by an internship for Kansas First District Congressman Keith Sebelius in 1974. As an intern, I had the chance to learn firsthand how a Congressional office operates and how the legislative process works. I am proud to be able to offer this same opportunity in my Senate office today, where I have interns year-round working closely with my staff on behalf of Kansans.  Applications for internships in my Washington, D.C. and Kansas offices for Spring 2018 are due next Friday, October 19. Congressional internships are open to qualified undergraduate and graduate students who have an interest in public service and have achieved academic excellence. Click here for more information. 
Honored to Serve You in Washington
It is an honor to serve you in Washington, D.C. Thank you to the many Kansans who have been calling and writing in to share their thoughts and opinions on the issues our state and country face. I appreciate the words of Kansans, whether in the form of a form of letter, a Facebook comment or a phone call, who wish to make their voice heard. 
Please let me know how I can be of assistance. You can contact me by email by clicking here. You can also click here to contact me through one of my Kansas offices or my Washington, D.C., office.
Very truly yours, Jerry

Subject: Announcing Gun Violence Prevention Activist Naomi Wadler To Be Honored At Annual Women's Conference
Message:
Announcing Gun Violence Prevention Activist Naomi Wadler To Be Honored At Annual Women's Conference
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
I wanted to share another update with you regarding the Fourth Annual Women’s Conference and Forum: “Breaking Through: Women Work For Change.” This year, I am proud to announce Alexandria’s Naomi Wadler will receive the Clara Mortenson Beyer Women and Children First Award for her advocacy in support of gun violence prevention.

Wadler, 11, organized youth protests at her school in the wake of the mass shooting in Parkland, Florida earlier this year. Her subsequent address to crowds at the March For Our Lives in Washington D.C. became an international sensation. 

I first met Naomi at my Alexandria town hall on gun violence, held weeks after the Parkland shooting. I am thrilled to welcome her back to speak to constituents about her experience as an activist, and to impart her wisdom to people who want to work for change. I doubt that anyone who heard her speak at my town hall in March has forgotten her inspiring words about the need to stop gun violence. Naomi is a prodigy of advocacy, and I look forward to continuing to learn from her next month at our Annual Women’s Conference in Arlington.

We first created the Clara Mortenson Beyer Women and Children First Award while I was an Ambassador to Switzerland in 2011.  It is named after my grandmother, who is credited with convincing the Roosevelt Administration to appoint Frances Perkins, the first female Cabinet Secretary in the United States. My grandmother served as Secretary Perkins’ right hand, working on child labor issues. She was the first woman appointed as US representative to the International Labor Organization in Geneva.

This year's conference will be held at Founder's Hall on October 13. Registration and additional information are available here.
  ￼
Naomi Wadler (Credit: Wadler Family)

Subject: One Year Later
Message:
￼ 
OCTOBER 8, 2018
￼

￼

￼  ￼  ￼ 
Dear Friend, 

One year ago, our lives were thrust into turmoil by the most destructive fire our state has ever seen. As we reflect on that night, we remember the everyday heroism of our friends and neighbors, the bravery of our first responders who rushed into danger to keep us safe, and kinship displayed as our community helped each other recover.

The last twelve months have not always been easy, but over and over I have been so proud of the dedication our community has shown in lending a hand to those who need it and pitching in as we rebuild. From teachers turning their classrooms into evacuation centers and greeting each person with a friendly smile, to neighbors offering hot meals to firefighters and law enforcement at the end of a long day, to local and state officials working around the clock, the service you have provided each other is truly inspiring.

I know that our work is not over. We must continue providing the support the survivors need and I am hard at work fighting for every single federal dollar we can bring to bear on this effort. Know that I will not stop working to help our community recover and come back even stronger.
If I can ever help or if you have any questions, please know you can always call my office. 
Sincerely,
￼
Mike Thompson
Member of Congress

Subject: A few quick things....
Message:
News from Congressman Austin Scott
￼

HOME
MEET AUSTIN
HELP CENTER
ISSUES
CONTACT

Dear Friend, 
Yesterday, Brett Kavanaugh was confirmed by the Senate and sworn-in as the newest Associate Justice to the United States Supreme Court.  
Although I do not directly participate in the Supreme Court confirmation process as a Member of the House of Representatives, I believe Justice Kavanaugh is a humble, intelligent, and qualified judge who will safely guard the Constitution. 
I congratulate Justice Kavanaugh on his confirmation and commend President Trump on a successful nomination.  
  
A NEW US-MEXICO-CANADA TRADE DEAL 
This past week, President Donald Trump announced a new trilateral trade agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. 
The announcement coincided closely with National Manufacturing Day, a day to recognize our nation’s rich heritage of building and innovation. It is certainly no secret that the number of manufacturing jobs in our country has diminished over the last few decades, but under the Trump Administration, our unprecedented economic growth, due in part to historic tax reform and the rollback of burdensome government regulations, has provided the opportunity for more manufacturing jobs to be brought back to the United States, creating good wages and new opportunities for millions of Americans.  
I congratulate President Trump on the announcement of reaching a new trilateral agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico to replace NAFTA. I look forward to carefully analyzing the text of the deal and working with the Trump Administration to ensure this proposal benefits America's farmers, businesses, and consumers. 
￼ 
National Manufacturing Day  
  
2018 MOBILE OFFICES WRAP-UP 
Over the last several weeks, our district offices held mobile office hours throughout the Eighth District to offer constituents individual assistance with federal issues ranging from Medicare and Social Security to veterans' benefits.  
If you were unable to make one of our events in Cochran, Jeffersonville, Forsyth, Eastman, Thomasville, Valdosta, Nashville, Adel, Ocilla, or Ashburn and would like to speak with a member of our staff, please call either our Tifton office at (229) 396-5175 or Warner Robins office at (478) 971-1776 for assistance.  
  
REMINDER: CONGRESSIONAL APP CHALLENGE UNDERWAY 
In case you missed it, we have kicked off the 8th District’s 2018 Congressional App Challenge.  
The Congressional App Challenge (CAC) is a public effort to inspire, include, and innovate efforts around STEM, coding, and computer science education. 
Current middle and high school students in Georgia's Eighth District can work individually or in a small team to code original applications for the chance to be selected to have their work put on display in the Capitol Building in Washington, D.C. 
Important dates for this year's App Challenge: 
	•	June 4: Congressional App Challenge launches
	•	September 10: Last day for Early Incentive Student Registration (but not mandatory)
	•	October 15: Deadline for students to submit their app.
	•	October 20: CAC Judging Period Begins
	•	October 22 - December 5: Winners Announced
Call our Warner Robins office for more details, or visit our website by clicking here. 
￼ 
 The 8th District's Congressional App Challenge is underway 
  
HERE TO HELP 
As always, my staff and I are here to help. If you need assistance with a federal agency or have comments or concerns to share with me, please do not hesitate to call my Warner Robins, Tifton, or Washington, D.C. offices. You can also contact myself or a member of my staff on my website by clicking here. 
Sincerely,  ￼  Austin Scott Member of Congress

Subject: Are you ready?
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼


 ￼
￼ 
￼



The Webster Wire
Listening to Floridians
Dear Friends: 
As Floridians, we are all too familiar with the havoc and destruction hurricanes can bring. As Hurricane Michael approaches, please stay informed, heed local officials' warnings and directions and make sure you have a disaster plan. Visit www.FloridaDisaster.org, for the latest information on Hurricane Michael and to sign up for state alerts. My website's Disaster Preparedness page, found here, has links to official updates and tips for making a disaster plan.   
_______________ 
￼  
I am pleased with everything this Republican Congress, working with President Trump, has accomplished.  I am delighted by the first-rate services my office has provided constituents. Since I’ve been in Congress, my staff and I have worked hard to provide our constituents and community with respected and principled representation. Since 2017, our office has been pleased to recoup more than 5.5 million in compensation, pension or retroactive payments for constituents upon the favorable completion of their claim or appeal.  
Assisting those who have a matter that involves a federal agency or whose claims have gone beyond the expected time frame for processing; booking tours for constituents who are visiting DC; and responding to emails, letters, and calls is taken seriously at my office. While we cannot guarantee a favorable outcome or compel an agency to decide an issue contrary to established rules and regulations, we can be a connection between you and the federal agency to confirm your claim has not slipped through the cracks. If you need assistance with a federal agency issue, please call our district office at (352) 241-9220.
_______________ 
I was honored to speak at the United Way Campaign Kickoff for Lake and Sumter Counties and join the celebration of our community’s success.Together with their community partners, United Way of Lake & Sumter Counties is strengthening our community by supporting programs that improve the overall quality of life in their communities.  
￼ ￼ 
_______________
I stopped by the Goodwill Industries-Suncoast Meet and Greet to give thanks, praise, and encouragement to Goodwill and their community partners for all they do to serve the communities of West Central Florida. Goodwill Industries-Suncoast serves people across 10 counties in West Central Florida, including Citrus, Hernando, Lake, Marion, and Sumter Counties. 
￼ ￼ 
_______________ 
Happy 100th Birthday to Ms. Olive Brasted! I enjoyed surprising Olive and wishing her a momentous 100th Birthday. 
￼ ￼ 
_______________ 
I stopped by the Lake Sumter Lions Club to thank them for their community service and discuss the different ways our office can serve constituents facing issues with various federal agencies. 
￼
_______________ 
I toured and visited with residents of Buffalo Crossing’s Assisted Living. During my visit, I was also able to stop in and say hello at The Villages H.E.A.R.T. Meeting. 
￼ ￼ 
_______________ 
I also spent time packing shoeboxes to go to children across the world at Christmas time with The Villages Operation Christmas Child Club through Samaritan’s Purse International Relief. 
 ￼ 
_______________ 
I was honored to be a part of the opening ceremonies for Sumter County National Night Out at Lake Sumter State College in Sumterville. It was great to see friends including Sumter County Sheriff Bill Farmer and thank him for the selfless sacrifice him, his deputies, and staff demonstrate through protecting our community. Our law enforcement are heroes in the community. They protect us and are willing to put their lives on the line every day in the course of their duties. 
￼ 
  
Your servant, 
￼
￼  Daniel Webster Member of Congress 
Constituent Corner
A constituent from Belleview received his permanent orders from the U.S. Military stationing him in Japan within the next few weeks, but his wife had not yet received her no-cost passport. The constituent and his wife were concerned that they would not be able to travel to Japan together and contacted my office for assistance. We sent an inquiry and learned that the passport had been processed and would be available for pick up. The constituents were thankful for our assistance in the matter. 
Constituent services is a critical element of our congressional office. The federal government is a massive operation, and my office is available if you ever need assistance in navigating the bureaucracy or cutting through red tape. We are here to serve you.  
District Update
My Community Relations Representative, Cindy, attended the blessing and grand opening of St. Theresa’s new Social Services Ministry Building. The new building will house the Social Services offices and the Soup Kitchen and Food Pantry. 
￼
October is Breast Cancer Awareness month. My Community Relations Representative, Pam, attended the Pinking Ceremony at Florida Hospital Waterman. Florida Hospital Waterman is hosting educational events throughout the month to promote the importance of early detection of breast cancer. 
￼ 
Legislative Update 
Approximately 115 Americans die every day due to Opioid addiction. Providing law enforcement, the healthcare industry and local communities the tools to combat this crisis has been a priority of the U.S. House of Representatives. In June, the House passed H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act to advance treatment and recovery initiatives, improve prevention, protect our communities, and bolster our efforts to fight deadly illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl. Last week, the Senate passed the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act and it will now go to President Trump.
The passage of this bill follows the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act and 21st Century Cures Act in 2016, which I cosponsored. Visit www.OpioidCrisis.gop for more information. 
￼ 
Survey
Do you think Judge Brett Kavanaugh deserved to be confirmed as the newest Supreme Court Justice? 
	•	Yes
	•	No
	•	Unsure
submit your response  
Results of last week’s survey which asked... "Do you support President Trump’s new trade deal, the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), that will replace NAFTA?" Yes -  85%, No - 6%, Unsure - 9%

Subject: Great News for Bucks and MontoCo
Message:
News from Congressman
￼ 

Home
About
About District
Conact
Media 


 Bucks County Receives Federal Workforce Grant
￼   
Here in Bucks and Montgomery County, substantive training and apprenticeship programs are integral to good paying jobs. I was pleased to announce a U.S. Department of Labor grant for the Bucks County Workforce Development Board alongside Commissioner Rob Loughery, BCWDB Director John Flanagan, and Bucks County Community College President Dr. Stephanie Shanblatt. This award allocates $1.7 million to provide education and work-based learning opportunities to dislocated workers in Bucks, Montgomery, and Philadelphia counties. 
Read more HERE.  
Saracini Aviation Safety Act Heads to President
￼ 
Earlier this year, I joined Ellen Saracini and Rep. Josh Gottheimer (D-NJ) to demand Congress act on the Saracini Aviation Safety Act. 
This week, the Senate passed a bipartisan FAA reauthorization that included the Saracini Aviation Safety Act to strengthen our air travel framework and keep our nation safe. Through the tireless efforts of Ellen Saracini, Rep Josh Gottheimer, and Senator Pat Toomey, the Saracini Aviation Safety Act is finally headed to the President’s desk. By requiring all new commercial aircraft to have secondary cockpit barriers, this bipartisan agreement seeks to prevent our airliners from being hijacked again. We will continue to fight alongside Ellen Saracini until all current passenger aircraft contain secondary barriers.
Learn more about our work HERE.  
Defending Social Security and Medicare
￼  
I appreciated the opportunity to listen to the concerns of the community at The Solana Doylestown. I am absolutely committed to defending the dignity of our seniors. I am actively working to protect and strengthen Medicare and Social Security.
Read my latest Op-Ed on Social Security and Medicare HERE.  
Attention Fire Departments
￼   
Our first responders are always there for us, willing to risk their lives to keep others safe. I’m pleased announce a grant opportunity for our local fire departments. These grants focus on issues such as fire prevention, emergency vehicle procurement, staff training, and EMS operations. These grants are a tremendous opportunity for those dedicated public servants in Bucks and Montgomery County.
Learn more details about the grant program HERE.

Subject: Honoring Angels
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window

News from Representative John Ratcliffe 
￼ 

WEBSITE
SERVICES

FACEBOOK

￼ 
Hi Friends, 
Each year, I select a family in Texas’ 4th District to honor as “Angels in Adoption.” This offers a way to highlight their impact on children through adoption or foster care.  
Last week, I had the privilege of recognizing this year’s honorees – Angela and Samuel Coston of Texarkana – at my office in Washington, D.C. 
The Costons have impacted many lives through a foster care ministry they founded called “For the Sake of One.” Their ministry aims to help encourage foster families through the difficulties of fostering by providing an array of programs and services to foster children, foster parents and case workers.  
 ￼ 
Rep. Ratcliffe congratulates Angela and Samuel Coston in Washington, D.C. 
On top of taking children into their own home, the Costons’ ministry has brought together many kind-hearted individuals and organizations in the community to help improve the lives of very deserving young people. I’m looking forward to the ongoing positive impact they will have in the years to come.
Sincerely, 
￼  John Ratcliffe U.S. Representative for Texas’ Fourth District
