News from Congresswoman Claudia Tenney
￼

Home
About District
News
Contact

Tenney’s Bill, Expanding Oversight of Opioid Prescribing and Payment Act Passes Senate, Headed to President’s Desk 
On Wednesday, my bill, H.R. 5723, the Expanding Oversight of Opioid Prescribing and Payment Act of 2018 which was included in H.R. 6, passed the Senate and is now headed to the President’s desk to be signed into law.   Often, an addiction to opioids begins with a prescription for pain management. My bill, the Expanding Oversight of Opioid Prescribing and Payment Act works to identify and roll back barriers that have inhibited the use of non-opioid alternatives to treat pain. I look forward to President Trump swiftly signing this important legislation into law and helping to put an end to this epidemic that tears families apart. 
Tenney Holds Press Conference with Local Officials Announcing Disaster Declaration for State of New York
On Thursday, I was joined by John Finch-Commissioner of Public Works, Gordon Kniffen-Supervisor to the Town of Kirkwood, Kevin McManus-Deputy County Executive and the Broome County Emergency Services to announce the Trump Administration’s actions granting a Major Disaster Declaration to seven counties in Upstate New York that experienced unprecedented rainfall and flash flooding from August 13-15. We outlined how the funds will provide critical assistance to municipalities impacted by the recent flooding. 
On September 21, 2018, I sent a letter urging the President to support New York State’s request for a Major Disaster Declaration in response to flooding caused by heavy rainfall in August 2018. You can read the letter here.  
Extreme levels of rainfall along with severe flash flooding, caused significant and costly damage to homes, infrastructure, and small businesses beyond the response capabilities of state and local governments. The major disaster declaration provides the much-needed support to ensure our communities in Broome, Chenango, and Tioga counties can address these costs and mitigate against future flooding.
￼ 
Tenney Visits First Ward Senior Center
On Thursday, I visited the First Ward Senior Center to highlight the unique challenges facing the senior citizen community. Throughout recent months, I have visited senior centers to discuss issues impacting seniors throughout the 22nd District, including Social Security and Medicare.  
It was great to tour the First Ward Senior Center and sit down with residents to discuss the issues that impact Upstate New York seniors, particularly Social Security and Medicare. While there, I discussed the many ways our office can provide assistance to seniors in navigating the federal government’s bureaucracy. It is important our senior’s voices are heard, and I will continue my advocacy in Congress to protect and strengthen Medicare and Social Security.
In Congress, I have fought to strengthen and preserve Social Security and Medicare. I voted in support of the Protecting Seniors’ Access to Medicare Act (H.R. 849). The bill passed the House with bipartisan support. 
Tenney: USMCA will Benefit Upstate Dairy Farmers
 Unfair trade deals have long disadvantaged local businesses and in particular local family farms, the backbone of our Upstate economy. Early reports of a modernized trade agreement between the U.S., Mexico, and Canada offer welcome news for Upstate dairy farmers. The United States, Mexico, Canada Agreement (USMCA) ensures greater access to the Canadian dairy market and the elimination of the Canadian Class 7 milk pricing scheme, a critical priority for which I have long advocated. I look forward to further reviewing the pillars of the agreement over the coming days and weeks.  I have also led the charge against the negative impact of the Canadian Class 7 milk pricing scheme. Rep. Tenney recently led a New York delegation letter to US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer emphasizing that the elimination of Class 7 should be a critical priority in any North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) renegotiation.  
Tenney Announces $536,000 GEAR UP Grant Awarded to MVCC
This is welcome news for students and families across the Mohawk Valley. GEAR UP will provide critical funding to ensure our students are prepared to enter the next step of their education and succeed. The team at MVCC leads the way in working alongside our local employers providing students with access to training and key programs that will prepare them to be successful in our workforce locally. Partnerships like this give our students a leg up, ensuring our leaders of tomorrow are equipped with the knowledge and tools they need to be successful well beyond high school and college.
The grant is designed to increase the number of low-income students who are prepared to enter and succeed in postsecondary education. GEAR UP funds are also used to provide college scholarships to low-income students.
Mobile Office Hours
On Wednesday, our staff held mobile office hours in Cortland and Norwich. During mobile office hours, staff from our district office were available to provide assistance to constituents facing issues with federal agencies, specifically the Social Security Administration.   Mobile office hours help us bring the wide range of constituent services our office offers to communities across the 22nd District to increase accessibility and give constituents an opportunity to meet directly with experienced casework staff. Most commonly, our constituents face issues with the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Social Security Administration. Social Security is an important program that seniors in the 22nd District rely on, and I’ve been a leading voice in working to preserve and protect Social Security benefits for all New Yorkers. That’s why our office is hosting mobile office hours to ensure seniors have access to the important Social Security benefits they need and rely on.  Overall, our office has worked with 1,120 constituents and helped recover over $172,000 in benefits. If you are having trouble with a federal agency, from problems with Social Security and Medicare benefits to obtaining a passport or questions about the Veterans Administration, our office is here to ensure you get the answers you need. 
USDA Announces Farm to School Grant Program Applications  
The FY 2019 Farm to School Grant Program Request for Applications (RFA) is now open to applicants. Due to additional funding made available to the Farm to School Grant Program through the FY 2018 Omnibus Bill, the Office of Community Food Systems(OCFS) seeks to award approximately $7.5M in FY 2019 funding. 
The RFA closes December 4, 2018, 11:59pm ET. Late applications will not be accepted. USDA anticipates releasing award decisions in late spring or early summer of 2019. 
Applicants should carefully review the RFA, including grant eligibility requirements, found in sections 3.0 through 3.3 of the RFA. More information can be found in the Farm to School Grant Program Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) Guidance Document. OCFS will also conduct webinars with important information regarding how to prepare a complete and competitive grant application. Recordings of these webinars will also be made available online for those who cannot participate in person. All of these resources can be found on the Grant Applicant Resources page. 
Assistance With Grants And Letters of Support
Whether you’re a fire department in need of new equipment or a community organization looking to grow, our office can assist you in navigating the federal grant process. By working with the Congressional Research Service, we can help find grants that may be appropriate for your needs. In many cases, we may even be able to furnish you with a letter of support. To find out how we can assist you in the grant process, contact our New Hartford District Office at 315-732-0713. 
￼   
  
In the District & D.C.
￼ 
It was an honor to present President Sean Fadale with a certificate of congratulations at the groundbreaking of the Community Memorial Hospital’s Family Health Center in Hamilton, NY. The hospital opened in 1952, and currently employs almost 400 people! 
￼ 
It was great to tour Matco Electric and see firsthand how the work they do benefits people throughout the 22nd District. While there, I learned that as a direct result of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, Matco Electric gave every employee a raise. Businesses like Matco Electric are proof that providing desperately needed relief from the failed ‘tax and spend’ status quo is the most effective way to improve and grow the economy. Upstate New York depends on small businesses and because of tax reform, these businesses can invest, grow, hire more staff and purchase new equipment.
￼ 
This October, it is important we raise awareness about the threat breast cancer poses to both women and men. Studies show that 1 in 8 women across the nation will be diagnosed with breast cancer in their lifetime and more than 268,670 people in the United States are diagnosed each year. 
Whether it’s wearing pink to raise awareness, or offering support to someone who is fighting the disease, let's all join together in the fight to end breast cancer. 
In the News
Talk! With Claudia Tenney Part 1: Trade Deal, Tax Cuts, Flood Relief, AARP Poll and Music WUTQ 
Huge turnout in Mexico as wounded warrior Wilcox gets keys to new house Oswego County News Now 
Claudia Tenney: It's time to confirm Brett Kavanaugh to Supreme Court Syracuse.com 
MVCC awarded grant to aid low-income students Rome Sentinel 
Tenney announces disaster declaration WICZ  
Tenney’s office to offer assistance in Norwich today Evening Sun 

  

Constituent Services
I would like to thank all who have taken the time to contact our office to provide vital feedback on legislation and our work on behalf of the 22nd District. In my time serving the 22nd District, our office has had the opportunity to respond to 124,294 individual constituent messages and taken 26,118 phone calls.  
If you would like to schedule a meeting with either myself or my staff, please send us a message on our website. 
As always, our office is here to serve you. Please do not hesitate to contact our office if you need assistance with any of the following: 
	•	Assistance with a Federal Agency 
	•	Grant Application
	•	Tours of the Capitol and the White House
	•	Military Academy Nominations 
	•	Flag Requests                                    
Sincerely, ￼  Claudia Tenney Member of Congress

Subject: Wicker Welcomes Progress on Trade With Canada and Mexico
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
October 08, 2018
Unsubscribe
Update My Profile
￼
Website | About Roger | How Can I Help You? | Newsroom | Issues | Mississippi | Visiting DC | Contact
Wicker Welcomes Progress on Trade With Canada and Mexico
Trump Administration Secures Deal to Replace NAFTA
Besides being our North American neighbors, Canada and Mexico are two of the largest international markets for products made in Mississippi.  These export markets, as well as others around the world, are a significant generator of jobs and economic growth in our state.  According to the most recent numbers available, Mississippi exports were directly responsible for more than 51,000 jobs.  Last year, the value of these goods totaled $11 billion. 
As the world grows more connected, it is important to get America’s trade deals right.  President Trump has made it a priority to ensure that U.S. businesses and American workers are not hurt by unfair trade practices.  His campaign promise to redo the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was a bold effort to fix the shortcomings of the 24-year-old deal.  After more than a year of negotiations, the President has delivered results.
Gains for U.S. Agriculture, Manufacturing
The new pact, formally titled the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), still needs to be ratified by all three countries.  In the United States, Congress will have an opportunity to approve the agreement.  I will continue to take a close look at USMCA and work with Mississippians to ensure the agreement maximizes our state’s potential.  
So far, there seems to be plenty in the deal that lawmakers from both political parties should like.  Overall, a strong trilateral agreement with our North American partners offers certainty to farmers and manufacturers, reaffirming the United States as a place for business investment and job creation.  More specifically, USMCA would encourage the domestic production of automobiles and auto parts.  It would give U.S. farmers greater access to Canadian markets, making sales of American-made dairy, eggs, and poultry more competitive there.
Additionally, U.S. innovators – who continue to seek solutions for the world’s most pressing problems – would have more protections over their intellectual property, thanks to the deal’s extension of copyrights and patents.  USMCA addresses digital trade and online purchases, recognizing the sharp growth of the Internet economy since the terms of NAFTA were set in 1994.
Safeguards on U.S. Intellectual Property
When it comes to protecting America’s trade interests, the Trump Administration’s tough stance extends far beyond this continent.  The President has not shied away from confronting China about the stealing of U.S. intellectual property.  In late March of this year, the United States Trade Representative released the findings from its investigation on these dishonest trade practices.  The report estimated that China’s theft of U.S. intellectual property could cost as much as $600 billion annually.  Such practices are unacceptable, and USMCA is a signal to China that the Administration is committed to safeguarding American ingenuity.
After a slow economic recovery, Americans are finally witnessing positive economic growth and low unemployment.  Keeping “Made in America” goods and services competitive in world markets can help advance these encouraging trends even further.  USMCA is a welcome step toward modern, equitable trade deals for our farmers, ranchers, manufacturers, and innovators.
Other news this week:

Subject: Cruz News: October 7, 2018
Message:
￼
 
 
October 7, 2018
Greetings,
On Saturday, I proudly voted with a bipartisan majority of my Senate colleagues to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the United States Supreme Court. He has proven to be a qualified nominee throughout his time on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit, and has a strong record of defending the Second Amendment, safeguarding the separation of powers, reining in the unchecked power of federal agencies, and preserving our precious religious liberties. Despite Senate Democrats’ efforts to delay and derail his nomination, we successfully delivered on our promise to the American people to confirm strong constitutionalists to the Supreme Court.
As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on The Constitution, I convened a hearing on Tuesday examining the threats to religious liberty within the United States and by oppressive regimes worldwide. Our nation has a rich tradition of religious liberty. But across the globe, people suffer under tyranny. Their stories are heartbreaking and must be told. The persecution of communities of faith precedes the erosion of all freedoms, and Americans must remain vigilant to ensure religious liberty is protected here at home. Watch the powerful hearing here.
I was also pleased the Senate took a stand for all Americans this week and passed a bill I voted for in September to address the ever-growing opioid crisis within our country. Too many families across our country, including my own, have been hurt by our country’s opioid epidemic. Millions of lives have been lost to the opioid crisis. The bill provides support for state efforts to combat drug addiction and funding for research on new non-addictive treatments. Further, this bill enforces stricter laws requiring the U.S. Postal Service to restrict shipments containing fentanyl from entering our country. I look forward to President Trump signing this bill into law.
This week, I was pleased the Senate passed the FAA reauthorization bill, which included my bipartisan Commercial Balloon Pilot Safety Act. Two years ago, tragedy struck Lockhart, Texas when a hot air balloon crashed. Since then, I have worked with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure commercial hot air balloon operators receive medical certificates to enhance safety precautions.
Countless hardworking teachers, first responders, law enforcement officials, and other public servants devote their time and talent to our classrooms and communities. But unfortunately, the current Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) has not always served our public servants fairly. That’s why I recently introduced the Equal Treatment of Public Servants Act with Reps. Kevin Brady (R-Texas) and Richard Neal (D-Mass.), to replace the current WEP with a fairer formula based on their work history and to ensure our public servants receive the Social Security benefits they deserve for their service to our communities.
The entire State of Texas continues to stand shoulder to shoulder with our fellow Americans in North and South Carolina who are recovering from the devastation of Hurricane Florence. As the Lone Star State continues to rebuild from Hurricane Harvey and the south Texas flooding, we must also take all steps necessary to prepare our homes and families for any future weather event. For those seeking preparedness information and resources, please refer to the federal and state resources listed here.
Please read below for an update from this last week.
Keep Texas Strong,
￼ Ted Cruz
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement on Friday's cloture vote on the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to be the next associate justice of the Supreme Court. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz, member of the U.S. Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation participated in a hearing last week focused on how leading technology companies handle American consumers’ privacy and security. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz congratulated Jim Allison, Ph.D., chair of Immunology and executive director of the Immunotherapy Platform at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, for receiving the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Read more...
￼
The Washington Free Beacon highlighted Sen. Cruz’s School Security Enhancement Act, which would permit Student Support and Academic Enrichment (SSAE) grants to be utilized by local communities for measures that reinforce school safety infrastructure and technology. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz last week introduced the Equal Treatment of Public Servants Act of 2018 (S. 3526), which would ensure that teachers, first responders, law enforcement officers, and other public servants receive Social Security benefits calculated from their work history. Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Space, Science, and Competitiveness, issued a statement commemorating the 60th anniversary of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement applauding the House of Representatives for passing a bill to make the individual tax cuts permanent, and urging his Senate colleagues to do the same. Read more...
￼
Sens. Cruz and John Cornyn’s (R-Texas) Red River Gradient Boundary Survey Act was reported by the U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources this week. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement following the vote in favor of the FAA reauthorization bill. Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on The Constitution, on Tuesday chaired a hearing titled: “Threats to Religious Liberty Around the World.” Read more...
￼
￼
Sen. Cruz issued a statement applauding the Senate’s passage of the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6). Read more...
￼
Sen. Cruz commended Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) for holding a subcommittee hearing on Wednesday titled “Rare Diseases: Expediting Treatments for Patients,” and called on Congress to swiftly pass the RESULT Act. Read more...
 
The full press releases may be viewed here.

Subject: Schweikert Review October 7th
Message:
District Update |October 7, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Hello Friends,   With a schedule change in Washington, I will be using October as a district work period in Arizona. I look forward to staying in the Grand Canyon state to meet with constituent groups and discuss how this Congress has made great changes for Arizonans. If you would like to schedule a meeting with me, please email Schweikert.Scheduling@Mail.House.Gov   
￼   Legislative Update   Healthcare Legislation  I wrote an op-ed article with Congressman Webster (FL-11) to amend the Public Health Service Act to establish a health insurance Federal Invisible Risk Sharing Program.   
According to Kaiser, 10% of the sickest individuals account for nearly two thirds of population health spending (graph below). This means that healthier individuals are covering the costs of a small number of high cost patients. This is especially true in the individual ACA marketplace because there is a smaller insurance pool for these costs to be allocated, as opposed to the large group or private market where costs can be disbursed over a larger number of people – the cost exposure to any one individual is limited.    ￼ Graph from Kaiser showing the percentage of sickest individuals and health spending. 
The Federal Invisible Risk Sharing Program gives insurers the ability to recoup the extraordinary costs of their highest cost patients without resulting in higher costs for healthier individuals participating in the marketplace. The Program seeks to ensure individuals have access to affordable health insurance at the lowest possible rates, whether they have a pre-existing condition or not.
H.R. 7003 offers predictability to the individual marketplace for individuals and insurers and, over time, gives states the ability to manage the program based on their own needs. This is a proven model to provide affordability and stability to the health insurance marketplace.
 Blockchain Legislation  Last week, I introduced two blockchain related bills that will increase Congress' support and knowledge for implementing blockchain technology.   H.Res. 1108 seeks to increase research and show Congress’s support for an “innovation friendly” regulatory approach of blockchain technology. We hope that this resolution will increase the support and growth of the technology’s implementation in the public and private sector, to improve overall privacy, transparency, and efficiency.
H.R. 7002 will amend the E-SIGN Act to confirm the applicability of blockchain to electronic records, electronic signatures, and smart contracts. We believe that this bill will provide clarity to the application of existing law during a time when several states have already enacted conflicting legislation regarding the validity of electronic signatures, records, and smart contracts using blockchain. This clarification will enable the technology to grow and reach its potential.  
Both H.Res. 1108 and H.R. 7002 include the NIST standard for the definition for blockchain. We look forward to increasing awareness about the potential and validity of blockchain technology. 

￼

Speaking at a Congressional Blockchain Caucus briefing, as I am one of the Co-Chairs of the Caucus. 


I am greatly honored to serve you in Congress, 

Sincerely, 

￼

Representative David Schweikert, Arizona's 6th Congressional District

Subject: Walker Weekly Report: October 7, 2018
Message:
￼
Walker Weekly Report
With another successful week in North Carolina, we are working hard to make a difference. Both at home and in Washington, we’re making strides on issues that matter to you and your family. From tax reform and government accountability to issues facing our community like human trafficking and opioid addiction, I am proud to report progress on all fronts.
While we have been working hard to keep our economic success rolling – delivering what is now the lowest unemployment rate since 1969 – we have also been fighting for hope and opportunity in our North Carolina communities struggling with the opioid crisis. I was proud to be a part of the effort to pass the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act to help turn stories of tragedy into triumph. I am pleased that President Trump will soon be signing this legislation into law.
This week, we honored our Community Heroes of the Month, celebrated the manufacturing sector and it’s impact on our North Carolina economy, and saw a former Ft. Bragg soldier receive our nations most prestigious military honor.
Keep reading for the full update. Have a blessed week.  Sincerely, ￼ Mark Walker
￼
HIGHLIGHTS
￼
Honoring Abolition NC Founders as Community Heroes of the Month for Work Combatting Human Trafficking
Cambre Weller and Chelsea Spohn are dedicated to helping our community be stronger and safer. Together, Cambre and Chelsea founded Abolition NC – an organization dedicated to fighting human trafficking. Through this, they have strived to make a difference for countless lives. Cambre’s background as a Guilford County Schools curriculum developer became a natural path for her role in leading Abolition NC’s prevention awareness program. Chelsea’s background in social work has her uniquely skilled to support and mentor survivors.
Human trafficking is one of the greatest injustices of our time, destroying, enslaving and exploiting human life. Together, through continued legislative efforts and community organizations like Abolition NC, we can continue to raise awareness of this issue and work together to end it.
People like Cambre and Chelsea keep us all inspired to make a difference and dedicate ourselves to our community. I am touched and impressed with their heartfelt efforts to fight this injustice on the front lines.
Learn More
￼
Celebrating National Manufacturing Day and Our Successes in Technical Education and the Economy
Friday, on National Manufacturing Day, manufacturers across North Carolina opened their doors to students, encouraging our next generation of builders and thinkers. 
Manufacturing is vital to our future and employs more than 10 percent of North Carolinians. That’s why I am proud to have led the charge to help the Miscellaneous Tariff Bill (MTB) Act become law. This legislation freed up $71 million for North Carolina’s manufacturers to reinvest in our community and people. This is the most of any state in the nation.
Builders and job-creators should not be punished for hiring and investing in our communities. With the MTB Act, North Carolina can continue to lead the nation in manufacturing and economic growth. It has been my priority to reform the system with transparency and accountability and we have done that with success. In the Sixth District, employers such as Syngenta of Greensboro and Glen Raven Inc. of Alamance County, as well as their employees, have already begun to feel the fruits of our hard work. This relief will help North Carolina’s manufacturers free up their resources, hire more employees and grow overall business in our local communities.
Our efforts for manufacturers coupled with our reforms to help small businesses are leaving people better off to pursue the American Dream. Our legislative efforts in the House have led to unemployment at record lows and job openings at record highs while wages are rising and employer benefits are expanding.
Learn More
￼
Former Ft. Bragg Soldier Ronald J. Shurer II Receives the Medal of Honor
This week, Ronald J. Shurer II was awarded the Medal of Honor for valor by President Trump at the White House. As a former Ft. Bragg US Army Special Forces Medical Sergeant, Shurer displayed exceptional patriotism when he braved enemy fire to save fellow soldiers. While he and his team were engaged in heavy combat in Afghanistan, he treated a wounded soldier and then fought his way back to a group of four more injured members of his Green Beret team. After treating and stabilizing the group, he evacuated them down a mountainside while using his body to shield them from enemy fire.
This award of valor reminds us of the everyday patriotism and sacrifice of all our military families that call North Carolina home. Our offices and staff are anxious to hear from our military families on any issue they face. We are committed to assisting our veterans and active military members.
In July, the House passed a defense bill to give troops the largest pay raise in nine years while also providing newer and safer military equipment. This legislation invests almost $250 million in military construction at North Carolina bases like Cherry Point, Camp Lejeune and Fort Bragg, to assist the brave efforts of soldiers like Shurer.
We thank all members of the military for their sacrifice and service.
Learn More
 
￼
FEATURED VIDEOS
￼
Community Heroes: Cambre Weller and Chelsea Spohn of Abolition NC
￼
A Haven of Hope: The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act
 
￼
MORE GOOD NEWS ABOUT TAX REFORM
￼
Reuters: "U.S. Weekly Jobless Claims Near 49-Year Low; Factory Orders Surge"
The last time unemployment was this low (3.7%), America put a man on the moon, we were singing Neil Diamond’s Sweet Caroline, and yours truly made his initial presence. In two years, we’ve created more than 3.8 million new jobs - bringing hope and opportunity to North Carolina.
From the article: "The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits fell to a near 49-year low last week, pointing to sustained labor market strength, which should continue to underpin economic growth."
"The labor market, which is viewed as being near or at full employment, is steadily boosting wage growth..."
Read More

Subject: Serving You
Message:
District Update | October 7, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Dear Friends, 
I had a special guest and good friend of mine in town this week, UK Member of Parliament, Rehman Chishti, who represents Gillingham and Rainham in the United Kingdom. We met last year through the State Department's British American Parliamentary Group (BAPG) exchange program, where a Member of Congress and a Member of Parliament are paired together to collaborate and visit the area each other represents.   The United States has a special relationship with the United Kingdom, and by partnering and sharing ideas, we can better strengthen our friendship as we work together on bilateral trade, education, and other important issues.  We had a productive week traveling around central Arkansas, meeting with veterans, students, firefighters, and more. Here are some of the highlights. 
￼

Hearing from White County’s Heroes 
￼
I held the 20th meeting of my Veterans Advisory Council in Beebe on Wednesday. It was an honor to visit with the men and women of White County who have served our country and talk with them about their needs and how my office can help them access the benefits they've rightfully earned.

Spending Time with Bright Arkansas Students 
￼
Since coming to Congress, I have made it a priority to visit schools across central Arkansas to talk with students about their future plans and share important lessons I've learned in the public and private sector. On Thursday, MP Chishti and I visited with students at Episcopal Collegiate School, Immaculate Conception Catholic School, and North Little Rock High School's European History class. We kicked off the visits with the 8th grade class from Immaculate Conception singing happy birthday to MP Chishti. I left these visits confident that the next generation of leaders will continue to lead this country in the right direction.

Honoring Fairfield Bay's Patrolman Fultz 
￼
Patrolman Lyle Fultz with the Fairfield Bay Fire Department is a true hero! He placed his life on the line to save a resident of Fairfield Bay by answering at a residence. When he heard a cry for help, he discovered an older gentleman was trapped inside the residence on fire. Patrolman Fultz entered the smoke-filled building and rescued the older gentleman and pulled him to safety. It was great to join Fairfield Bay Mayor Paul Wellenberger in congratulating him! 
What an honor to witness Patrolman Fultz receiving the well-deserved Regional Officer of the Year Award for the Northwest Region at the Law Enforcement Summit hosted by Arkansas Attorney General Leslie Rutledge.
Advocating for Long-term Health of Buffalo National River 
￼
Algae growth has plagued our nation’s first national river and one of Arkansas’s most prized rivers, Arkansas’s Buffalo National River, which is why Congressman Womack (R-AR) and I sent a letter to the National Park Service this week, advocating for its long-term health. Not only is the Buffalo National River the ultimate icon of the Natural State, it is an essential economic engine for the Ozark region. I am committed to taking additional action to ensure the Buffalo National River is protected and preserved for future generations.

Keeping Our Neighborhoods Safe
￼
I visited with the Fairfield Bay Fire Department that was awarded $150,000 from FEMA through the Assistance to Firefighter Grant Program. I supported their grant application and am excited they were awarded with these critical funds. I am thankful for the men and women of Fairfield Bay who risk their lives to protect their neighbors. With the new breathing apparatus, they'll be able to better perform their job while keeping them safer from the hazards they face daily.

Seeing the New Fairfield Bay Hotel and "Tiny Homes" Project 
￼
I enjoyed being in Fairfield Bay, touring the site of the new hotel and the new "Tiny Homes" project - both of which will support economic growth of the town and increase tourism. The progress on these two projects is a great testament to the strong leadership of Fairfield Bay Mayor Paul Wellenberger, Van Buren County Judge Roger Hooper, and the tight-knit Fairfield Bay committee that has worked tirelessly to ensure its long-term success.

Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I'm doing on your behalf. If I can be any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at (501) 324-5941 or Hill.House.Gov. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Representative French Hill

Subject: a special day of fishing
Message:
District Update | October 7, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Honoring cops, fire fighters, veterans... with a little fishing
￼
It was an honor to once again join Dion Hess,
Brandon Traeger, and The Fallen Outdoors at their
unique and special fishing event last month in
Vancouver. THANK YOU to all our heroes:
law enforcement, fire fighters and veterans.
￼
I will continue to work to be the best advocate I
can be for you in Congress. And I'll keep working
to reduce the number of sea lions overpopulating
the Columbia River. Because of your support, my
bipartisan bill passed the U.S. House -- now we just
need Senate approval so it can be signed into law!
Speaking out on behalf of mothers in Southwest Washington, and around country
￼
I testified September 27 at House Committee on Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health on behalf of my bipartisan bill, Preventing Maternal Deaths Act. Thank you to all the witnesses who spoke out about the devastating trend in our county: more mothers die from pregnancy-related causes here in the U.S. than any other developed country. 

As a mother and a lawmaker, I commit to doing more to prevent moms from dying in childbirth. My bipartisan bill would take an important step forward by establishing and supporting Maternal Mortality Review Committees so we can prevent such tragedies in the future. You can read more about this issue or watch the video of my testimony.
Celebrating successful space launch with nLight
￼
What a privilege to join nLight’s brilliant team in Vancouver on September 18 as they celebrated the successful launch of a laser in space that will measure the Earth's surface. This cutting-edge advancement in science and engineering is critical for our nation’s future.

TOP NEWS
REUTERS: U.S. weekly jobless claims near 49-year low; factory orders surge
READ MORE HERE

COLUMBIAN: County’s employment numbers remain strong in August
READ MORE HERE

COLUMBIAN: Herrera Beutler pledges to reinstate Obama-era oil train rules
READ MORE HERE

WAHKIAKUM EAGLE: STEM App Challenge competition deadline approaching
READ MORE HERE

COLUMBIAN: Thousands flock to Vancouver Waterfront Park unveiling
READ MORE HERE

COLUMBIAN: In Our View: Distillery Bill Only Fair
READ MORE HERE

Working to reinstate safer oil-by-rail standards
The U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT) finalized a proposal to revoke an important safety requirement for trains carrying oil and other hazardous material last week. That was the wrong decision. With trains already carrying oil through the Columbia River Gorge, we should be working to reduce the chance of an incident – but this action goes in the opposite direction. 

While I understand there are costs associated with this requirement, safety must remain paramount when it comes to transporting hazardous materials through our communities which is why I am currently developing legislation to reinstate the stronger safety requirement. 

I have consistently supported enhanced safety measures for crude-by-rail, including championing the Fire Department Proper Response and Equipment Prioritization Act (FD PREP Act) which directs FEMA to make grants that give firefighters the tools and training to respond to derailments of trains carrying crude oil a high priority. She also successfully fought to include $221 million for federal rail safety operations to improve the safety of grade crossings and the movement of crude oil in the funding package that passed earlier this year. 

You can read more about this important issue here. 

ASSISTING SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON RESIDENTS
NAVY SENDS PAYCHECK, BENEFITS TO RETIREE

Ms. Joyce Eastwick of Underwood reached out to our office because she had been waiting on her retirement orders from the Department of Navy, without which, she could not receive payments or medical benefits. 

After our office reached out to the Navy and got them all the necessary information, a retroactive paycheck was sent to Ms. Eastwick within a week. Additionally, the Navy sent Ms. Eastwick her long-awaited retirement orders, with information on how to obtain a retired ID card and sign up for Tricare. Ms. Eastwick is now receiving regular retirement payments.

HELPING A RESIDENT OBTAIN A NEW MEDICARE PROVIDER

Ms. Cathy Dahl of Kelso is an office manager for a local medical group. She contacted our office due to complications with the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid (CMS). She was trying to get a new provider through their credentialing process, but was told it would not be finished by the time the provider started practicing. 

After we reached out to CMS on Ms. Dahl’s behalf, she received notice that the paperwork had been processed and the provider was approved.

Are you having trouble with a federal agency? 

If you or someone you know needs assistance with a federal agency, please contact my Vancouver office at 360-695-6292, or through my website jhb.house.gov. While we can't guarantee an outcome, we will try our best to assist in any way we can.

October 7, 2018   Dear  @gmail.com,  I was pleased to hear that yesterday afternoon Brett Kavanaugh was confirmed by the Senate and sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts as the 114th Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.  
I believe Justice Kavanaugh is the right man for a lifetime appointment to the highest court in the land. As a federal judge for more than a decade he based his judicial opinions on the original meaning of the Constitution, and he has shown in more than 300 decisions that he will defend our system of federalism, checks and balances, and separation of powers.  
While I did not have a say in his confirmation process as a member of the House of Representatives, I commend Senate Republican leaders for their tireless efforts to fill not just two Supreme Court vacancies this session of Congress but an impressive number of other judicial vacancies as well. 
In fact, while the Senate confirmed 55 of President Obama's appeals court appointments in eight years, they have already confirmed 26 appeals court judges nominated by President Trump. This will have an impact on the federal judiciary for decades to come.  
Thank you for reading.  
Sincerely, ￼  John Shimkus Member of Congress

October 07, 2018
From the desk of Congressman Tom Marino:
Good Afternoon,
This week in Congress, I joined Congresswoman Karen Bass in the introduction of the bipartisan H.R. 7012, Supporting Kinship Connections Act.
￼
Ensuring Success for Foster Youth
Every child deserves to grow up in a healthy, safe, and loving home. H.R. 7012 would amend the Social Security Act to provide grants to develop and enhance or evaluate kinship navigator programs. Kinship navigator programs assist grandparents and other relatives who take primary responsibility for the care of children who need safe and stable placement. This legislation will help caregivers in finding and utilizing programs and services to meet their own needs and the needs of the children they are raising.
US Reaches Trilateral Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada
￼
The Trump Administration announced that the United States, Mexico, and Canada concluded negotiations for a modernized trade agreement, known as USMCA. Prior to USMCA, the North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) had not seen any major changes to its structure in 25 years. By making good on a pledge to renegotiate NAFTA, the Trump administration, led by Ambassador Lighthizer, has ensured that our trading partners will be held to the same standards as the United States. It has also ensured those that the manufacturers, farmers, and other industries in our country can count on a fair platform with which they can trade on. I look forward to reviewing USMCA, especially regarding its impact on dairy farmers.
US Employment Rate Falls to 50-Year Low
In September, the US economy added 134,000 jobs and the unemployment rate fell to 3.7% -- the lowest level since 1969. This good news is a result of a conservative initiative to improve the tax code and promote pro-growth policies that will ensure all Americans continue to reap the benefits of a booming economy. I will continue to advocate for policies that improve the economic well-being of the constituents of PA-10.
Celebrating American Manufacturers 
On Friday, I had the pleasure of visiting Videon for National Manufacturing Day. While touring their facility in State College, I learned a great deal about Videon’s work in developing solutions for consumer electronics. American manufacturers are the backbone of our economy and it is companies like Videon that drive American production and innovation. Thank you to all who stand behind the goods and services made in America.
FTC and DOJ Return a Record $505 Million to Consumers Harmed by Massive Payday Lending Scheme
It has come to my attention that some constituents in PA-10 have received checks from the Federal Trade Commission and are concerned about its legitimacy. After speaking with the FTC, they confirmed that over one million refund checks have been sent to those affected by a payday lending scheme operated by AMG Services.
For more information about the FTC’s case, click here or call 1-866-730-8147
Upcoming Events in PA-10
 
Domestic Violence Vigil 
Monday, October 15 at 4:45PM at Honesdale Central Park
Honesdale, PA 18431
Join the Victims’ Intervention Program in remembering victims of domestic violence in observance of Domestic Violence Awareness Month.
 
Youth Mental Health First Aid Training 
Thursday, October 18 from 9AM-5:30PM
Register by 10/11/18
Diocese of Scranton Pastoral Center
330 Wyoming Avenue, Scranton
Youth Mental Health First Aid is an 8-hour certification course that introduces participants to the unique factors and warning signs of mental health problems in adolescents, builds an understanding of the importance of early intervention, and teaches how to help adolescents in crisis or experiencing a mental health or substance use challenge.
To register, email clynd@ecneahec.org or call 610-379-2001. Course fee is $10.
 
Fight the Flu

Thursday, October 25 in Blooming Grove
Friday, October 26 in Matamoras
Flu shots will be distributed from 10AM-12PM. Please bring your insurance card with you.

Camp Ladore, 287 Owego Turnpike, Waymart
Tips, recipes, treats to eat for people with diabetes plus a presentation on eye health. Sponsored by Wayne Memorial Hospital and Northeast Pa Local Networking Group (NEPLNG) of the AADE. Registration requested. 570-253-8144.
As Always…
Please never hesitate to contact me at my offices in the district or in Washington, D.C.  I want to hear from you and learn what is most important to serve you in the best possible way.
For more information, you can visit my website or follow me on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
Respectfully,
￼
Tom Marino
Cogan Station, PA

Subject: CONFIRMED
Message:
News from Representative Bradley Byrne
  
￼
ABOUT BRADLEY | HOW CAN I HELP | CONTACT BRADLEY | WANT TO RECEIVE MY UPDATES?
￼

Dear Lindsey, 
The circus is over, and a good man will be joining the Supreme Court. The Senate has made the right choice for our country. Judge Kavanaugh has a clear record as a thoughtful jurist who respects, understands, and will defend our Constitution. Those who have worked with him over the years and know him best strongly defend his record as a good man who loves his family and our country. I applaud the Senators who helped support the nomination, including Alabama Senator Richard Shelby. This ridiculous spectacle is now over, and our nation will be better off with Judge Kavanaugh on the Supreme Court.
Our Booming Economy 
￼ 
On Friday, we received even more exciting news about our ever growing economy! The Department of Labor issued last month's jobs report which showed the lowest unemployment rate since 1969. This shows that the “resistance” can’t stop our conservative, pro-growth policies from working. We aren't stopping here, though. I promise to continue working to advance policies that grow the American economy and create good-paying jobs right here in Alabama. 
Around the District 
￼ 
I kicked off the October District Work Period this week by spending time catching up with folks in Southwest Alabama and letting people know what I’ve been up to in Washington. On Thursday, I had the opportunity to speak to students at the Alabama School of Math and Science in Mobile. We discussed the continued importance of STEM education to our ever evolving workforce. We are fortunate to have such a high quality school in the heart of Southwest Alabama. Also on Thursday, I joined Sean Sullivan live on FM Talk 106.5 for an update on everything from defense funding to the Kavanaugh confirmation. Click here to listen to the interview! I look forward to spending more time around Southwest Alabama over the next few weeks. 
Keeping our Children Safe 
I am very pleased to report that the City of Mobile, the Alabama State Law Enforcement Agency, and the Alabama State Department of Education have all received $1.6 million in grants from the Department of Justice to support school safety throughout Southwest Alabama. I was proud to support increased funding for school safety grants earlier this year, and I am thrilled to see that Alabama will benefit from the funds. With these grants, state and local officials will have more resources for school safety training, mental health training programs, and school violence prevention. I appreciate the Trump Administration and Attorney General Jeff Sessions for their help in securing this critical funding for our region.
A 21st Century Workforce 
￼ 
On Monday, I led 83 of my House colleagues in sending a bipartisan letter to Department of Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta calling for the modernization of the joint employer standard under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The current FLSA regulations were written roughly 70 years ago in 1958 and 1961 using language from bulletins dated 1939 and 1940. The FLSA’s joint employment requirements need to be modernized to limit needless lawsuits against small businesses. We must continue to advocate for greater protections for Main Street America and make sure our workforce is brought into the 21st Century. 
In Case You Missed It! 
Here are a few articles from this past week that are worth a read: 
“US unemployment rate falls to 49-year low of 3.7 percent” – ABC News 
“WATCH: Bradley Byrne takes to the House floor in support of Brett Kavanaugh.” - Yellowhammer News 
“Byrne tears into Senate Democrats’ handling of Kavanaugh nomination — ‘Just a zoo over there’.” - Yellowhammer News 
“Bradley Byrne: Fighting for those who fight for us.” - Alabama Today 
“Byrne celebrates school safety grants for Mobile, State of Alabama.” - STL News 
“Mobile Chamber’s business incubator awarded $1.5 Million grant.” - Lagniappe 
“Bradley Byrne leads bipartisan letter asking Labor Secretary Alexander Acosta to act on join employer.” - Alabama Today 
“Efficient work, Congressional clout have Austal humming in Mobile.” - Alabama Daily News 
Photo of the Week 
￼ 
On Friday afternoon, members of my staff in D.C. helped welcome Alabama veterans to our nation’s capital as part of an Honor Flight. Thank you to these proud veterans and all those who have served! I also want to share my deep appreciation with all the sponsors and those who helped make this special trip possible.
What’s Ahead 
I’m back in Southwest Alabama until early November, so there will be a lot of opportunities for you to come out and hear what we’ve been doing here in Washington this year and what work there is still to be done. Next week, I’ll be doing an interview Tuesday night with Armed Alabama Radio to give an update on our ongoing efforts to protect the Second Amendment, and I will also be talking with the Semmes Chamber of Commerce to discuss advancements we’ve been working on for small businesses here in Southwest Alabama. To keep up with my schedule and for more information on the work I’m doing in Washington for you, make sure to follow me on Facebook and Twitter! 
As always, if you need help with a federal agency or have questions about anything under debate in Washington, please contact my office. You can call my Mobile office at 251-690-2811 or you can click here to send me an email directly. I also invite you to follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to get up-to-the-minute updates on my travel in Southwest Alabama. At the end of the day, my staff and I are here to serve you!   
Stay in touch, 
￼
 
Congressman Bradley Byrne
 
 
PS: Do you enjoy my email updates? If so, please forward these updates to your friends and family. They can also sign up to get my updates by clicking here.

Issues

About
 
NEWS FROM THE SECOND DISTRICT
Dear Friend,

Today, Governor Scott will declare a state of emergency for the Florida Panhandle as we continue to monitor Tropical Storm Michael. As this storm continues to move towards Florida, the National Weather Service (NWS) suggests taking the following steps in preparation:

1. Prepare a hurricane emergency kit with water, food, flashlights, batteries, a first aid kit, and more. 
2. Create and review your family emergency plan – where you will go in the event of an emergency, how you will stay in contact with each other, and more.
3. Stay up to date on the weather and understand the meanings of the National Weather Service’s watches and warnings.

Click here for more information. 

This week, I spent time traveling the Second District, worked with a bipartisan coalition of members of Congress to improve school safety, and addressed a growing problem facing our veterans.

￼ 
On Tuesday, I visited with the Tallahassee Kiwanis Club. I was able to give an update on the work I am doing in Washington and answer questions. We discussed the improving economy and addressed what Congress can do to continue spurring job growth. Just this week we learned that September was a record month for raises and jobless claims dropped to a 49-year-low. 

Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh 
On Saturday, the United States Senate voted to confirm Brett Kavanaugh as our newest Supreme Court Justice. It was a great day for the Constitution and Rule of Law in the United States. Americans spoke loud and clear with the election of President Trump and he has kept his promise to nominate constitutional conservatives with outstanding judicial records to the Supreme Court.

Thank you to President Trump and the United States Senate for remaining resolute and just in your support of Judge Kavanaugh. Congratulations to our newest Associate Justice of the Supreme Court – Judge Brett Kavanaugh.

Fighting For Our Veterans 
On Monday, USA Today published a troubling article detailing the mass cancellations of more than 250,000 radiology orders at VA hospitals across the country. Over the last decade, the VA has dealt with scandal after scandal as we witnessed veterans dying on long waiting lists and being denied the care they have earned. These actions are completely unacceptable. As the Inspector General carries out his investigation, I will be working with the VA and my colleagues in Congress to address these issues. While our local VA hospitals in North Florida are not included in this investigation, I have already instructed my staff to look into whether these are systemic issues that plague veterans in the Second Congressional District of Florida. I am committed to addressing these issues to ensure that our veterans are receiving timely and quality care.
Click here to read the USA Today article. 

Improving School Safety
This week, I joined Senator Marco Rubio and a bipartisan coalition of members of the House and Senate in urging Department of Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to create a central authority to help school districts seeking to improve safety features within new and existing schools. The letter urges Secretary DeVos “to ensure tight coordination and collaboration of effort among all federal agencies that are working on different aspects of school safety in order to eliminate duplication, redundancy, and waste of valuable resources.”  We are taking concrete steps in Congress to improve school safety through increased funding for mental health, collaboration with law enforcement, and training students and educators on how to identify and prevent future acts of violence. 
Click here to read the full text of the letter.
Congressional App Challenge ￼  The deadline for the Congressional App Challenge is fast approaching. Students must submit their apps and additional materials by October 15th. The Congressional App Challenge is a programming competition for students in high school and younger. Students, individually or in teams, are tasked with creating, coding, and implementing a new and innovative computer application. The demand for computer programmers is rapidly growing and we cannot keep up. The Congressional App Challenge is a great way to highlight America’s talented young programmers and encourage students to develop their technology skills.  Click here to learn more.    Thank you for your continued energy and enthusiasm, as reflected in your letters and Facebook posts. If you haven’t already, LIKE my Facebook page. You can also follow me on Twitter @DrNealDunnFL2. 
Thank you for the opportunity to serve you in Congress! 
 Sincerely,  ￼  Dr. Neal Dunn Member of Congress 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
IN THE NEWS 
Marco Rubio Leads Group Of Lawmakers Asking Betsy DeVos For Help With School Safety 

   Constituent Casework Corner  After being prescribed the same medications for over a decade, a veteran could not understand why all of a sudden the Department of Veterans Affairs was not shipping his medications to him in a timely manner. For several months, the veteran would spend hours on the phone to get the prescriptions mailed, however, this month they never came. After contacting my office, we were able to work with the Department of Veterans Affairs to have the veteran’s prescriptions mailed overnight. Along with an apology, the veteran was given the direct contact information of who he can immediately contact in the future if this ever happens again.  
 
      Do you need help with a federal agency? Contact my office at 850-785-0812 or at www.dunn.house.gov

Subject: This Week In Washington
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Statement on Judge Brett Kavanaugh
I will be voting to confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court of the United States. His sterling academic credentials and outstanding legal record, which includes 12 years of exemplary service as a judge on the second highest court in the nation, make him exceptionally well qualified to serve as the Supreme Court's next Associate Justice.
Judge Kavanaugh's long career of public service displays a remarkable fidelity to the Constitution and understanding of the proper role of a judge. He is an impartial jurist who treats everyone fairly and decides cases neutrally on the basis of the law and not a preferred policy or outcome. Further, Judge Kavanaugh understands that changes to the law must be made by the American people, acting through the democratic process, and not by unelected judges. His record gives me great confidence that he will discharge his duties on the Supreme Court intelligently and faithfully.
I have long held that when considering judicial nominees, objective qualifications are more important than partisan politics. For example, although I knew I would disagree with many decisions made by then-Judge Sonia Sotomayor, her intellect, experience, and integrity clearly qualified her for the Supreme Court so I supported her nomination by President Obama. Unfortunately, during Judge Kavanaugh's nomination process, some abandoned this sensible standard. Today, the worst possible claims about a nominee are considered disqualifying by some, despite the absence of any corroborating evidence, because they disagree with the nominee's judicial philosophy.
Sexual assault is a terrible crime that is sadly far too prevalent in our society. We need to take seriously allegations of sexual assault, while at the same time providing due process to those who are accused of misconduct.
As this confirmation process concludes, my sincere hope is that all of my colleagues will seek to do the important work of restoring trust and civility in politics. The advice and consent role of the Senate for nominees would be a good place to start.
￼
￼
The Proposed New NAFTA
This week, the White House announced an agreement between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico to revise the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
There were concerns that Canada would not join this agreement, so their inclusion is a constructive development. Converting NAFTA to a bilateral agreement just between the U.S. and Mexico was always a nonstarter in Congress and would have dramatically undermined the benefits from our current, longstanding continent-wide free trade zone.
While this proposal improves some elements of the existing NAFTA, such as strengthened IP rights, increased market access for U.S. dairy processors, and a new chapter on digital trade, other provisions diminish NAFTA's economic benefits and create needless uncertainty.
Specifically, I am concerned about the proposal's new expiration date; weakening of protections for U.S. investors; new arbitrary wage mandates on auto imports; side deals establishing quotas on automobile and automobile parts imported from Mexico and Canada; and a failure to eliminate section 232 tariffs on steel and aluminum.
I will closely review the text of this proposal to see whether the proposed changes, on balance, enhance or weaken the enormous economic benefit we have derived from the original agreement. I also plan to work closely with my colleagues to explore how we may correct some of the agreement's flaws through the required implementing legislation.
￼
￼
An Important Step in the Fight Against the Opioid Epidemic
Congress took another important step forward in fighting the horrendous opioid crisis by overwhelmingly approving the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act.
This legislation, which includes four provisions I authored or coauthored, provides significant assistance to aid treatment, prevention, and law enforcement.
Notably, one provision I wrote plugs a glaring hole in the Medicare program by ensuring doctors are actually notified if their patient has previously overdosed before writing them another opioid prescription.
Click here for more details about the provisions I added to this important legislation. It now heads to the president for his signature.
In an effort to aid local communities battling this epidemic, the U.S. Department of Justice awarded two federal grants to Beaver and Carbon Counties to support efforts to provide alternatives to incarceration for nonviolent offenders of drug-related crimes. Programs that offer treatment to nonviolent offenders can help mitigate the social cost of this epidemic and address the underlying problem of addiction. With a crisis of this magnitude, I'm pleased to have supported these federal grants.
￼
￼
Honoring the 'Lost 74'
On June 3, 1969, the USS Frank E. Evans collided with the Australian aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne during a training exercise. As a result of the collision, 74 American sailors were killed. Since the sailors perished outside of the designated Vietnam War combat zone, their names were never added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.
This week, I introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) directing the Secretary of Defense to add the names of those brave sailors to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.
For too many years, these 'Lost 74' have been denied the honor given to service members who lost their lives during the Vietnam War. It is long overdue that we recognize their sacrifice. I hope my Senate colleagues will move swiftly to approve this measure.
￼
￼
Reauthorizing the FAA
This week, the Senate approved a five-year reauthorization of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). Included in the legislation is my bipartisan proposal to protect the traveling public from a terrorist who rushes the cockpit by requiring new commercial aircraft to have a ‘secondary' barrier. This lightweight wire-mesh gate is installed between the passenger cabin and cockpit door. During times in flight when cockpit doors are opened, the secondary barrier can be locked into place, blocking access to the flight deck.
This crucial measure would never have passed Congress without the work of Congressman Brian Fitzpatrick, and most of all, the tireless efforts of Ellen Saracini, whose husband, Victor, was the captain of United Flight 175 when it crashed into the south tower of the World Trade Center.

Subject: Good News
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
Meet Richard | How Can I Help You? | Issues | Media Center | Contact Me





Friends, 
 
We’ve all heard the phrase, “Bad news travels fast.” That seems like the case these days. In fact, a reporter once told me the news doesn’t report on planes landing. I guess no one would read a story with the headline, “Plane Successfully Lands at Charlotte Douglas.” 
 
That’s why I’m very happy to see folks here in North Carolina report on good news that really matters.
 
Last week, WSOC-TV Channel 9’s headline read, “Senate sends President Trump bipartisan opioids bill.” This comprehensive, bipartisan package will help get to the root of the opioids epidemic that’s ravaging communities across the country, including many right here in North Carolina. The package includes three of my bipartisan bills to help get unused opioids out of medicine cabinets and off the streets. While this might seem minor at first glance, it’s a huge issue – did you know over 70% of heroin addictions begin in the medicine cabinet? And that as many as 92% of patients don’t use their full opioid prescription? Making sure we safely dispose of opioids before they fall into the wrong hands is a critical step in solving this national problem.
 
As your voice in Congress, I’ve worked to combat the opioid crisis for years, and I’m proud to be a leader on this front. My bipartisan legislation has been applauded as one of “the most important opioid bills in the House” and legislation that “could make a more serious difference.” This isn’t a partisan issue – it’s an American one, and I’ll continue to work with my colleagues, President Trump and local leaders to stop the deadly cycle of opioid addiction.
 
In the Fayetteville Observer, another headline last week read, “Trump signs spending plan, avoiding government shutdown.” Representing Fort Bragg, the epicenter of the universe, I was proud to not only support this critical funding bill, but also to have my amendment included to provide more training for our Special Forces. Overall, this bill provides $17 billion to our military to increase training for our troops and improve warfighter preparedness. And it gives out troops a well-deserved 2.6% pay raise – this is in addition to another pay raise last year.
 
The Charlotte Business Journal also reported, “Ivanka Trump talks higher education, workforce pipeline during Mooresville visit.” As Senior White House Advisor, Ivanka joined Congressman Ted Budd and me at the NASCAR Technical Institute to discuss job training. As a former trustee of Rowan-Cabarrus Community College, I know these programs are some of the best avenues we have to train workers for jobs in high-demand fields that would otherwise go unfilled. That’s exactly why I’ve made this a top priority and worked with the Trump Administration to transform our career and technical education system. We’ve made incredible progress – especially with the recent signing of the Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act (H.R. 2353). I will continue to work to close the skills gap and help equip workers with the tools they need to get good jobs.
 
Last, but not least, the News & Observer reported last week, “Washington sends $1.7 billion to the Carolinas in Hurricane Florence aid.” Getting responsible disaster relief funding was truly a bipartisan effort. This is just the first installment to help families in North Carolina rebuild and I’m glad to see this bill head to President Trump’s desk to be signed into law.
 
You see, if you look closely, there is a lot of good news out there. We’ve taken major bipartisan steps on issues that impact our daily lives, and we’ll continue to do so through the end of this year and beyond.
 
 
Until next week, 
￼
Richard Hudson
Member of Congress (NC-08)

Subject: Kavanaugh Confirmed to Supreme Court
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼ 
WEBSITE 
CONSTITUENT SERVICES 
VISITING DC
￼   ￼   ￼ 
October 07, 2018 
Kavanaugh Confirmed to Supreme Court
This week, the Senate confirmed Justice Brett Kavanaugh to serve as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. The Senate’s constitutional responsibility is to provide advice and consent to the President on his nominee, and the Senate fulfilled that responsibility.
Democrats made it clear they would stop at nothing to block President Trump’s Supreme Court pick before Justice Kavanaugh was even chosen as the nominee. Despite these attempts, Justice Kavanaugh has proven himself to be a fair, impartial and qualified jurist, who will continue his distinguished record of service for years to come.
His qualifications speak for themselves. He is a Yale undergraduate and law school graduate, a Harvard Law School professor, and has been a Judge on the District of Columbia’s Circuit Court of Appeal for the last 12 years. As a judge, he decided more than 300 cases, with 10 opinions adopted by the Supreme Court. Justice Kavanaugh is as qualified as they come, and I look forward to his years of continued service to our country on the Supreme Court of the United States.

Message:
News from Congressman Davidson
￼

Home
Contact Me
Our District
News
About Member

Warren Davidson E-Newsletter
Dear Friend, 
Thank you for subscribing to my e-newsletter. Here you can get the latest updates on the work I am doing on your behalf in Washington and at home in Ohio. I encourage you to stay connected with our office through my website, Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter pages. It is an honor to represent you. 
Sincerely, ￼ 
Warren Davidson Member of Congress 


￼ 
Trade, Tax Reform Fix
Congressman Warren Davidson has been working in Ohio since Congress is not in Session. 
On Monday, President Trump introduced a new trade deal with Mexico and Canada. Davidson said he looks forward to reviewing the new agreement to see how it might impact Ohio families and American companies. He said he’s happy Canada is part of the agreement, but that as long as tariffs are included, the agreement is far from completed. The new trade agreement is subject to approval by Congress.
On Tuesday, Davidson and Congresswoman Martha McSally (AZ-02) led a group of 56 lawmakers in a letter to Speaker Paul Ryan and Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady, urging them to bring legislation to the House floor to fix the "retail glitch." Fixing this issue will let restaurants and retailers on Main Street take full advantage of the expensing provisions in the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act. Read the press release here. 
On Wednesday, Davidson was invited to share his viewpoints about the latest trade deal with Mexico and Canada on Fox Business News with Melissa Francis. Watch the full interview below.  
On Saturday, Davidson congratulated Justice Brett Kavanaugh on his confirmation to the Supreme Court.
￼
￼

￼
National Manufacturing Day
Congressman Davidson celebrated National Manufacturing Day touring Midmark’s production facility in Versailles. A group of 10th graders from joined the tour too to learn more about the opportunities in manufacturing.

Subject: Congressman McHenry Weekly Update
Message:
￼ 
October 7, 2018
Congressman McHenry Weekly Update 


More Good News



Since the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act we’ve seen consumer confidence go up, small business optimism rise, unemployment at record lows, and millions of job openings. A recent study shows that wage growth has hit a 17 month high and they are going to continue to grow. This month's Department of Labor job report once again brought great news for our economy. This time they reported that unemployment is at the lowest rate it has been since 1969. Click here to learn more about how tax reform is helping improve lives right here in North Carolina and all across the country.

￼





Appealing For Disaster Relief for May's Severe Storms in NC-10



In May, severe storms, flooding, and landslides caused significant damage that our Tenth District neighbors are still recovering from. Below are the images from when I visited some of the areas impacted by these storms back in May. This past week, I joined with my colleagues Senator Richard Burr and Senator Thom Tillis, to send a letter to FEMA Administrator Brock Long regarding Governor Cooper’s appeal for a major disaster declaration. If this appeal is granted, it would make it easier for those impacted to receive the help and assistance they need to recover from these deadly storms. Click here to read the full letter.  

￼





Ending the Opioid Crisis



The opioid crisis has caused pain and suffering in communities all across the country including here in western North Carolina. Last week, the House voted on a bipartisan, bicameral bill that addresses all sides of this devastating crisis from addiction prevention to providing resources for law enforcement and families as they combat this crisis in their communities and in their own homes. Click here to read my statement on last week's passage. This week, the Senate voted to send this important bill to the President's desk and President Trump released a statement highlighting the significance of this bill in ending opioid addiction. Click here to read President Trump's statement on the SUPPORT Act. Learn more about what else the House has done to combat the opioid crisis—courtesy of the House Energy and Commerce Committee—by clicking here.

￼





What I Have Been Reading



'Bravest officer I've known': South Carolina officer killed was 30-year veteran of the force

WCNC 

Our law enforcement officers put their lives on the line to keep our communities safe. We were reminded of the sacrifices they make this week in South Carolina. Please join me in praying for the Florence County Sheriff's Office, the Florence Police Department, and the families of Officer Terrence Carraway and the others wounded in this tragedy. 


Canada, US confirm new deal with Mexico updating NAFTA

Fox Business 

When running for President, Donald Trump committed to renegotiating our trade deals so that they actually benefit American consumers and workers. With this week's announcement of the United States Mexico Canada Agreement on Trade, President Trump has followed through on that promise. I’m confident the USMCA will correct the errors of NAFTA and truly work for the people and industries here in western North Carolina. 


Gaston celebrates Manufacturing week

Gaston Gazette 

On Friday, we celebrated the innovators, the entrepreneurs, and the workers that make manufacturing such a vital part of our communities. Gaston County joined in the celebrations with tours of the local manufacturers and by honoring the over 20,000 people employed by the manufacturing industry in the region.

￼

Subject: South Carolina Strong
Message:
District Update 
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
 
South Carolina Strong 
 
 
Wednesday night's shooting in Florence was devastating. The day after the shooting, we headed to Florence to show our support for everyone impacted by this senseless tragedy. It was one of the most heart wrenching days I've experienced as your Congressman. We visited injured officers in the hospital and prayed with their families for strength, healing, and comfort. We also joined hundreds of people at a vigil honoring Sergeant Terrence Carraway. Words cannot describe our emotions as the community remembered this father, husband, officer, mentor and friend. I'm incredibly thankful for the outpouring of support and love as our community heals together. We are South Carolina strong. 

Read More »
 

￼
 
 
Florence Relief Updates 
 
 
All eight counties in the Seventh District- Chesterfield, Darlington, Dillon, Florence, Horry, Georgetown, Marion, and Marlboro- have been granted Individual Assistance and Public Assistance from FEMA. You can register with FEMA by applying online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov or by phone at 1-800-621-3362.  By registering with FEMA, you may qualify for federal disaster assistance such as help paying for rent or a temporary place to live as well as financial awards for essential home repairs or other disaster related needs not covered by insurance. If you have a homeowner's or flood insurance policy, file your insurance claim immediately before applying for disaster assistance. 

Additionally, President Trump signed the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 into law on Friday. This legislation includes $1.68 billion in Community Disaster Block Grant – Disaster Recovery (CDBG-DR) funding for Hurricane Florence Recovery that I led my colleagues in requesting. I will work to ensure this initial down payment is followed by a comprehensive funding package to address the long-term recovery and resiliency needs of those impacted by the storm.
 

 
Disaster Recovery Centers Open
 
 
Disaster Recovery Centers and Business Recovery Centers are open across the Seventh District. At these centers recovery specialists from FEMA, the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA), and state agencies will be available to help you fill out your disaster relief applications and assist you with finding recovery resources. Click the link below to find a recovery center near you. 
Find a Recovery Center »
 

￼
 
 
Resources to Rebuild
 
 
Cleaning up after Hurricane Florence and beginning to rebuild can be overwhelming. Below are some resources that will hopefully make this process easier for you and your family.

If you need assistance cleaning up your property following Hurricane Florence, Crisis Cleanup is a nonprofit group that can assist you with this process. Call 843-212-0552 to be connected with local volunteers. FEMA mitigation specialists will be in home improvement stores in Myrtle Beach and Murrells Inlet to offer advice on how to repair and rebuild structures to be safer and more resilient. Click here for a list of times and locations that FEMA advisers will be in stores to assist you! For more information on strengthening structures visit www.fema.gov/what-mitigation.

Additionally, SCEMD suggests that you hire a professional licensed contractor for home repairs to protect your home and your finances. To find a professional licensed contractor, visit the South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation at http://llr.sc.gov  and click licensee lookup. 
 

 
Lowest Unemployment Rate Since 1969 
 
 
September's job report showed sustained economic growth and a strong labor market fueled by pro-growth tax cuts and regulatory reform. The unemployment rate fell to 3.7% and 134,000 jobs were created. When we say that our economy hasn't been this strong in decades, we aren't exaggerating. Do you know the last time the unemployment rate was this low? 1969 - the same year that Neil Armstrong walked on the moon and the same year that “Na Na Hey Hey Kiss Him Goodbye" was the number one song in the country. With last week's vote on Tax Reform 2.0, we are committed to locking in the benefits of tax cuts for families and businesses in South Carolina and across the country!

Read More » 
 

￼
 
Have a great week,
￼
 Tom Rice

I'm so proud to represent people who are passionate about giving back to their community and helping their neighbors even as they are recovering themselves. If you are interested in lending a hand, click here for good volunteer opportunities!
