Subject: Reforming the Tax Code and Growing the Economy
Message:
￼
Home
Serving You
Issues
Newsroom
Contact Adrian
About the District
About Adrian

Congressman Smith's E-news: October 6, 2018 
￼  Thanks to the National Federation of Independent Business for awarding me the Guardian of Small Business Award. I’m proud to support Nebraska's farmers, ranchers, and small businesses through tax reform, trade, and regulatory relief. 
  Reforming the Tax Code and Growing the Economy  Tax reform and reduced regulations have set the American economy on an upward trajectory with growth eclipsing four percent. New jobs have outpaced the labor force, increasing wages and setting off a bidding war for workers in many sectors of the economy. The impact of cutting taxes and decreasing regulation cannot be understated, which is why I helped to produce a second round of reform aimed at small businesses and individuals as a member of the House Ways and Means Committee.   This second round of cuts and reforms, which passed the House during the last week of September, was comprised of three bills, each with a distinct purpose: making individual and small business tax cuts permanent, encouraging families to save more earlier for retirement, and incentivizing entrepreneurship. The Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act will make provisions such as the tax cuts for families and the 20 percent deduction for farmers, ranchers, and small businesses permanent in order to ensure individuals and small business throughout Nebraska enjoy the same benefits as larger corporations.   It also included the bipartisan “grain glitch” fix, which sought to mimic Section 199a treatment of cooperatives under the previous tax code to ensure as many producers as possible see reductions in their taxes. It was a top priority for me to ensure language making this treatment permanent was included in the second round of tax reform. Due to Senate rules which limited certain changes to the tax code beyond ten years, these provisions couldn’t be made permanent in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.    The purpose of the second bill, the Family Savings Act, is to make a number of changes to the laws governing retirement accounts to encourage more families to save for retirement. For example, by allowing families to make a onetime withdrawal for the birth or adoption of a child, families can feel confident saving more because they will also have better access to their own money when they need it most.    It will also make pooled employer plans more feasible, which currently face a number of bureaucratic hurdles, allowing small businesses to join together in order to offer better retirement vehicles for their employees. Further changes include the elimination of age limits for Individual Retirement Account (IRA) contributions as well as exemptions from Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) for accounts with relatively smaller balances.   Finally, the American Innovation Act quadruples the deduction allowed for startup expenses for new businesses from $5,000 to $20,000 and indexes this amount for inflation. It will also allow for losses incurred in the early stages of new businesses to be carried forward in the event of shifts in majority ownership. These changes are intended to help more ideas develop from concepts and ideas into viable businesses to create jobs and strengthen our economy.  This second round of reform is important to ensure as many Americans as possible benefit from lower rates and simplified compliance. As always, any changes to our tax code should allow the American people to keep more of their paychecks in order to spend or save their dollars in ways only they know best. I’m proud to have done my part to guide these bills through the process, and I appreciate everyone who attended my tax roundtables throughout the Third District to contribute to the discussion.

At mobile offices, Third District residents can meet directly with one of my staff members about federal issues and take advantage of the services available through my offices.  Tuesday, October 9  Pierce County Mobile Office Pierce County Courthouse 111 W Court St, Pierce 9:15am to 10:15am CDT  Boone County Mobile Office Boone County Courthouse 222 4th Street, Albion 12:00pm to 1:00pm CDT

Douglas Street, O’Neill 11:00am to 12:00pm CDT  Knox County Caseworker in Your Community Creighton Public Library 701 State Street, Creighton 2:00pm to 3:00pm CDT  Thursday, October 11   Sherman County Caseworker in Your Community Loup City Public Library 800 North 8th St, Loup City 9:00am to 10:00am CDT  Harlan County Caseworker in Your Community Hoesch Memorial Public Library – Meeting Room 1114 2nd St, Alma 1:00pm to 2:00pm CDT  Franklin County Caseworker in Your Community Franklin Public Library 1502 P St, Franklin 3:00pm to 4:00pm CDT

Subject: The U.S. Economy is Roaring
Message:
Click here to forward this email    Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window    Click here to open a plain text version of this email
A message from Georgia's 6th Congressional District
￼

Home
About District 6
How Can I Help?
Issues
Newsroom
Contact


 
October 6, 2018
The U.S. Economy is Roaring
This week, the Federal Reserve provided its outlook on the state of our nation’s economy. The positive report shows continued growth and optimism. Here are a few highlights from the report:
	•	Unemployment is the lowest in almost 50 years
	•	Consumer confidence is at a 17-year high
	•	The holidays are right around the corner, and sales are expected to be nearly $720 billion
	•	Unemployment filings dropped by 8,000 indicating an increase in jobs in the labor force and continued economic growth
	•	U.S. factories are producing more “Made in America” products with 2.3% growth — the largest in nearly a year. Manufacturing is 12% of the U.S. economy and critical to the success of Georgia and the country
A strong economy means more jobs and greater opportunity for all. With lower taxes and the rollback of onerous regulations, President Trump and Congress are working together to put the American people first and create more opportunities for every American.
Opioid Legislation Headed to the President’s Desk
The U.S. House and Senate worked together to address the opioid epidemic by passing The SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act (H.R. 6). In an extraordinary show of bipartisan support, hundreds of lawmakers in both the House and Senate collaborated to bring forward legislation to support prevention, treatment, and recovery for those dealing with addiction. 
Keep your eye out for the legislation to come to President Trump’s to be passed in to law.
Celebration of the Double Tenth
Yesterday, I joined my friends at the celebration of the 107th National Day of the Republic of China (Taiwan), which is recognized on October 10th. The relationship between Taiwan and the state of Georgia is quite remarkable, and I look forward to hearing more about how we can continue to grow together.
￼ 
Thank you for taking the time to read this note. To stay current on what's going on in Congress, please follow me on Facebook by clicking here or visiting Facebook.com/RepKarenHandel. If you find this update helpful, please take a second to forward it along to a few of your friends and neighbors.  
In addition, because of rules from the House of Representatives, I will not be able to conduct live tele-town halls after August 8th through Election Day. As always, feel free to call (202) 225-4501 or (770) 998-0049 if you need assistance from me or anyone in my office.

Sincerely, ￼  Karen C. Handel Member of Congress

Subject: Long overdue
Message:
Enews Sign Up  |  Visit My Website   
￼ 
ABOUT ED  |   HOW CAN WE HELP  |   ISSUES & LEGISLATION  |   NEWSROOM  |   CONTACT 
GET CONNECTED: 
￼ ￼ ￼  
GETTING THINGS DONE
 Several pieces of legislation I have been working on were either signed into law or took a big step forward in September. 
￼
Learn more about two of these pieces of legislation below or visit my website at perlmutter.house.gov for additional information.  

TWO BILLS LONG OVERDUE
 I’m particularly proud of two pieces of legislation that recently became law.
On Friday, my legislation to require all newly manufactured helicopters to be built with safer fuel systems was signed into law. This is long overdue and too many people have been killed or badly injured as a result of this more than 20-year old loophole. 

Going forward, this will significantly reduce the risk of post-crash fires and help save lives. I want to thank Chris Vanderveen at 9NEWS (KUSA) for his tireless reporting and Karen Mahany for her advocacy on behalf of her late husband, Patrick. Click below to learn more about this issue. 
￼
The other bill is to allow individuals diagnosed with cancer to defer payments on public student loans while actively receiving lifesaving treatment without interest accruing during the deferment period. This will provide desperately-needed peace of mind for those battling cancer. As the Denver Post reported:
The aim of the bill is to help mitigate the financial strains young adults face after being diagnosed with cancer.
Medical expenses coupled with student loan payments can be a “double-whammy” for students, said Ken McConnellogue, spokesperson for the University of Colorado.
Undergoing cancer treatment is not just costly itself, but there are other indirect costs as well, such as housing, transportation, child care and fertility preservation that young adults have to juggle while seeking care, said Kate Houghton, president and chief executive officer of Critical Mass: The Young Adult Cancer Alliance in Washington, D.C. 
 

NATIONAL CYBER SECURITY AWARENESS MONTH 
 As a member of the House Financial Services Committee, one of my top concerns is the security of personal data, especially in light of several recent high-profile breaches. October is National Cyber Security Awareness Month to help make all Americans aware of their digital footprint and provide resources on how to stay safer and more secure online.
Just last week, we learned that 50 million accounts had been compromised due to a hack at Facebook. It is important to take steps to protect your privacy regardless of whether you have been a victim of a hack.
1. Change your password – Create a password that is complex and do not reuse a password from a different site. Create a password that is long in length and contains numbers, special characters, or phrases.   2. Device audit – Audit your devices to see if someone has gained access to your account. You can do this by visiting Facebook’s Security and Login page, under “Where You’re Logged In” you can see a list of devices that are signed into your account and their locations. If you see a device you do not recognize, you can click “Remove.”   3. Two-factor authentication – Facebook offers a security feature that texts a secure code to your phone. You must enter this code after you type in your password. This is meant to make it more difficult for someone to gain access to your account without the code. 
Unfortunately today it’s not a matter of if your personal information has been breached - it’s how many times. The 2017 Equifax breach alone exposed sensitive information of nearly half of all Americans. In response to the Equifax breach and other recent hacks, a few additional steps to help protect your sensitive information include examining all accounts thoroughly and regularly, activating two-step authentication and alerts to know when a change or a charge is made to your accounts, and signing up for credit monitoring. 
For additional resources or assistance, visit the Department of Homeland website or call my office at (303) 274-7944.   

ICYMI - NEW MEDICARE CARDS
 For those currently enrolled in Medicare, new Medicare cards are in the process of being mailed out. The new card will be sent automatically and will include a new, unique Medicare number rather than your Social Security number to help protect your identity. New cards will arrive anytime between April 2018 and April 2019. 
￼
More information at https://www.medicare.gov/newcard.  

UPCOMING EVENTS

Where: Wheat Ridge Rec Center - 4005 Kipling Street | Wheat Ridge, CO 80033

Welcome to the weekend! 
Earlier this week, the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) responded to my request and approved a grant to fund construction for an East River Veterans Cemetery. 
South Dakota has a proud legacy of military service and patriotism, and this grant will help expedite the process of establishing a peaceful resting place to remember and honor those who have served our country. 
The grant money could be awarded as early as next year, so I’m hopeful we’ll soon have another cemetery in our state to pay tribute to those who’ve dedicated their lives to freedom, patriotism, and American values. 
To all those who have served, thank you. 
-Kristi

Subject: Weekly Update: September Snapshot
Message:
￼
HOME
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
CONTACT
Friend-
Congress accomplished a great deal of work this September. We passed landmark legislation to combat the opioid crisis. We also sent a government funding bill to the President's desk that delivers on-time, reliable funding for our military for the first time in a decade. These resources will allow our service members to meet current national security threats and plan for the future.   The House also took the first step to build on the incredible economic growth we've seen this year by passing Tax 2.0. This bill would make the tax cuts for working-class families and small businesses permanent, promote family savings, and spur new business innovation.   When I wasn't in Washington working on these critical issues, I was out and about in the First District continuing my work to expand access to rural broadband, promote key workforce development programs, and ensure our service members have the tools they need. Check out some of the visits I had this past month below: 
￼

The Greater Williamsburg Ducks Unlimited Chapter held its 14th Annual Fall Event, where I joined some area Greenwings in activities including coloring, decoy painting, calling tips, and dog handling. Today's youth are the conservationists of tomorrow. 
 
￼

I stopped by Modern Day Marine at MCB Quantico to speak with some our service members. 

         ￼

I spoke at the National Wildlife Refuge Expo about how I worked across the aisle with Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) to pass the Keep America's Refuges Operational Act that authorizes the volunteer programs critical to keeping our refuges up and running. 
 
￼
I dropped off some school supplies and visited with teachers and school officials at Rosa Parks Elementary in Woodbridge. 
￼
I spoke with folks at the Prince William County Chamber of Commerce about the strength of our economy. From record low levels of unemployment to rising wages to record high consumer confidence, the polices this Congress has put in place are working.  
￼
I received the Guardian of Small Business Award from the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB). Virginia’s First District has a plethora of small businesses that are critical to the health of our economy, and I'm proud to fight for the policies that help them succeed.  
￼
I toured Diaz Foods Distribution center in Manassas to hear about the role tax reform has played in their business.
￼

I spent an evening with International Association of Fire Fighters Local 3886 to celebrate their 20th anniversary and thank them for their service to our community. 

￼
I joined the Fredericksburg Regional Chamber of Commerce to talk about ways Congress can work alongside states and localities to eliminate barriers to expanding broadband access in rural Virginia. 
￼
I stopped by Brentsville Day in Bristow to talk with the Daughters of the American Revolution.
￼
I spoke with the New Kent Educational Foundation about my work to connect students with good paying jobs through CTE and STEM programs.
￼
I had the pleasure of visiting Rappahannock Goodwill Industries to meet with their CEO, tour the facility, and learn more about their mission and services to folks in our area. 
￼
I heard from the firefighters at Stafford Local 4012 about ways Congress can continue to support our first responders.
￼
I received the "Guardian of Seniors' Rights Award" from the 60 Plus Association for my commitment to protect Medicare and Social Security.
￼
I met with the New Kent Chamber of Commerce for a business roundtable discussion to hear from business owners on how I can continue to be a voice for the polices that help our Virginia small businesses succeed.
￼
I stopped by Proclaiming Grace Outreach to hear how they serve folks in New Kent and James City Counties through their food pantry and thrift shop. 
￼
I hosted a Hanover Veterans Forum at VFW Post 9808 to learn more about what issues First District veterans are experiencing and share some of the bills we’ve passed this Congress to expand and improve veterans’ access to their hard-earned benefits. 
￼
I toured Anton-Paar USA Inc in Ashland to meet with employees, provide a Capitol Hill update, and hear how this Congress can continue working to alleviate the regulatory and compliance burden on businesses.  This month's press releases:  

Bipartisan, Bicameral Resolution Introduced to Celebrate Urban Wildlife Refuges
Wittman Votes to Fully Fund Military

Wittman Continues to Fight for Broadband Access at Fredericksburg Chamber Event

I really enjoyed getting out in the community to interact with constituents regarding the issues most important to you. Please do not hesitate to contact me so I can best represent you.  Sincerely,  Rob

Subject: Jackie's Reads for October 6, 2018
Message:
News from Representative Speier

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

October 6, 2018 
Dear Friends,  Given these turbulent political times, it's more important than ever that we remain engaged and knowledgeable of current events.  
That is why I am sharing with you my reading picks for this week. These are the articles and editorials that have captured my interest and, I believe, are crucial to our understanding of the forces seeking to shape the future of our government, our country, and the world. When we empower ourselves to seek out the truth with verified, factual reporting, we are better equipped to make crucial decisions and create positive change. 
Happy reading and all the best,    ￼ 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼

￼ 

As a Member of Congress, it is my honor and privilege to share information with my constituents in California's 14th District.

If you would like to receive more information from my office, please sign up for my online newsletter by clicking the signup button above.

You can also remove yourself from the email list at any time by selecting the unsubscribe option at the bottom of this page.
All the Ways a Justice Kavanaugh Would Have to Recuse Himself
Given his blatant partisanship and personal animosity toward liberals, how could he be an effective member of the Supreme Court?
￼
By Laurence H. Tribe, professor of constitutional law at Harvard Law School
Much might be said about Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s possible confirmation to the Supreme Court: in terms of his still only partly disclosed professional record, the allegations of sexual assault and his candor, or lack of it, in testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee. 
But apart from all that — and apart from whatever the reopened F.B.I. investigation might reveal — the judge himself has unwittingly provided the most compelling argument against his elevation to that court. 
His intemperate personal attacks on members of the Senate Judiciary Committee and his partisan tirades against what he derided as a conspiracy of liberal political enemies guilty of a “calculated and orchestrated political hit” do more than simply display a strikingly injudicious temperament. They disqualify him from participating in a wide range of the cases that may come before the Supreme Court: cases involving individuals or groups that Judge Kavanaugh has now singled out, under oath and in front of the entire nation, as implacable adversaries. 
To read the complete New York Times op-ed, please click here. 
The Health 202: Patrick Kennedy shepherded a major mental-health bill into law. Ten years later, big barriers remain.
￼
By Colby Itkowitz, The Washington Post
It was fall 2008 and the economy was plummeting. The financial crisis was the only issue on anyone's mind. 
So, as Patrick Kennedy tells it, he called his ailing father to ask for a favor. 
Kennedy, then a Democratic congressman from Rhode Island, was the lead sponsor of legislation aimed at getting insurance companies to cover behavioral health services in the same way they did physical health. But, with Congress focused on saving the economy, Kennedy saw chances for his bill's passage slipping away. 
The late-Sen. Ted Kennedy (D-Mass.) had co-sponsored a similar measure in the Senate. The young congressman asked his father to use his goodwill to press colleagues to take up their mental health bill. The elder Kennedy called his friend, then-Sen. Chris Dodd (D-Conn.), who at that moment was the most powerful man in Washington, as the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, to see what could be done. 
And something could: Dodd used Rep. Kennedy's mental-health bill as the vehicle for the bank bailout known as the Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP. 
"I'm the sponsor of the largest federal bailout in American history," Kennedy said in a recent interview. "The good news was [mental health parity] passed. The bad news was that no one knew about it because it was overshadowed by the economic aspect of the bill." 
To read the complete Washington Post report, please click here. 
Donna Strickland's long journey from laser jock to third woman ever to win physics Nobel
By Denise Chow, NBC News
The 5 a.m. phone call changed Donna Strickland's life in an instant. 
It was Tuesday, Oct. 2. A representative from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences was on the line from Stockholm calling to inform Strickland, an associate professor at the University of Waterloo in Canada, that she had won the Nobel Prize in physics. 
Strickland, a self-described "laser jock," recalled that it was a surreal moment: "No one can be ready for such an honor." 
In winning the coveted award, which she shares with American physicist Arthur Ashkin and Gérard Mourou of France, Strickland became only the third woman ever to win the physics prize and the first woman to win since 1963. Ashkin will receive half of the $1.4 million prize, and Strickland and Mourou will split the other half. 
To read the complete NBC article, please click here.

Subject: A Better Trade Deal
Message:
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email 
￼ 
WEBSITE | SUBSCRIBE TO ENEWSLETTER 
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
October 6, 2018


A NEW, MODERNIZED NAFTA President Trump promised the American people a better trade deal with our North American trading partners. On Monday, he delivered on yet another of his promises to the American people by modernizing an outdated and unfair NAFTA. Canada is Oklahoma’s number one customer and I am confident this agreement with Mexico and Canada will benefit Oklahoma farmers, ranchers, workers, manufacturers, and businesses in the future. I fully support the Trump Administration’s efforts to bring home American jobs and look forward to finalizing the agreement under the Congressional Trade Priorities and Accountability Act (TPA). Learn more about the new deal at this link.
HONOR FLIGHT On Tuesday, I was in Washington to greet an Oklahoma Honor Flight at the Lincoln Memorial. Honor Flights allow veterans who have served our nation courageously to come to Washington for the day and pay their respects at the war memorials on the National Mall. It was an honor to be a part of their day and to thank them for their sacrifice.  
￼

￼
 
￼
 AGENT ORANGE EXPOSURE FAIRNESS ACT I joined Congressman Charlie Crist of Florida in introducing bipartisan, bicameral legislation to reestablish the highest level of care for our Vietnam veterans. The Agent Orange Act of 1991 required the Secretary of the VA to recommend new illnesses associated with Agent Orange until the requirement lapsed in 2015. The Agent Orange Exposure Fairness Act simply puts back in place the same recommendation requirements that were in place for 25 years. When it comes to taking care of our veterans, we owe it to them to be proactive rather than reactive. Read more on my website at this link.
NGVAMERICA 2018 PUBLIC POLICY CHAMPION Last week, NGVAmerica presented me with its 2018 NGV Public Policy Champion award. Congress has no business picking winners and losers in the energy industry. I am proud to sponsor the Natural Gas Parity Act to level the playing field for all energy producers and ensure that natural gas vehicles receive fair treatment.  I want to thank NGVAmerica for recognizing me as a 2018 Public Policy Champion, and I look forward to getting this bill across the finish line alongside Congressman Larson.  
￼
BACK IN OKLAHOMA On Thursday, I spent the day in Sallisaw and Van Buren, Arkansas. Thanks to People, Inc., Experian, and Sallisaw Hospital and Pafford EMS for taking the time to meet with me.  
￼
Good to visit with Sallisaw Hospital and Pafford 
EMS about their emergency services in rural OK.
 
￼
Nice to meet with People, Inc. about their work to
provide quality community-based services in Sallisaw. 

￼
Thank you for the tour of Experian!

On Friday, I had the opportunity to speak with students at Miami High School. It’s always great to visit with the future leaders of our communities and I enjoyed their questions.

￼
Thanks to these Miami High School 
students for their questions!


Friday was National Manufacturing Day and I celebrated with Ceradyne, Inc., a 3M Company by touring their plant in Quapaw. Ceradyne, Inc. makes ceramic sand screens, defense protection systems, fused silica, specialty glass, and more.

￼
Thanks for having me!

My final stop of the week was at the Quapaw Nation Fire Department. I enjoyed meeting a few of the firefighters, seeing their equipment, and touring the facility. Many of their team members recently returned from helping the victims of floodwaters in the aftermath of Hurricane Florence in North Carolina.

￼
Thank you to the Quapaw Fire Department for 
your service to the community and country.
OK IN DC
Great to see these Oklahomans in D.C. this week.
￼
Always love having the McAAP Stampede in town!

￼
Enjoyed visiting with the Jones family. 

￼
Great to see the Wiserman family!

￼
Thank you to Brett and Marcus of Optronics in Muskogee for
representing the National Association of 
Trailer Manufacturers in D.C. this week.


￼
Enjoyed seeing the Oklahoma Contractors this week.


WEEKLY WRAP-UP
No matter how far this country has come, we should never forget our history and where we came from. Watch the weekly wrap-up on my Facebook or YouTube page.
￼

See more from my week by visiting my Facebook, Twitter, and Flickr pages. As always, don’t hesitate to contact me if I can help in any way. 

Thank you, ￼
Markwayne Mullin
Member of Congress

Subject: Hultgren Huddle - Weekend Update
Message:
News from Representative Randy Hultgren
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window  Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

HOME
ABOUT RANDY
SERVING YOU
NEWSROOM
OUR DISTRICT
CONTACT
￼
￼
￼


In this Issue:

	•	STEM Scholars Program Kicks-Off Third Year
	•	Hultgren Praises Additional Resources in Opioid Fight
	•	Looking Back at Achievements of the FSC in the 115th Congress
	•	There is Still Time to RSVP for Upcoming Hunger Forum
	•	The US, Mexico and Canada Adopt New Trade Agreement
	•	Randy on the Issues - Veterans
	•	Randy in the News

STEM Scholars Program Kicks-Off Third Year
Last Saturday we kicked off the third class of STEM Scholars at FONA International. 
STEM Scholars is a youth leadership program I launched two years ago to expose high school students to the exciting possibilities provided by STEM fields. 
This year’s program is made up of 26 incredibly impressive students from all around the 14th District. I joined the STEM Scholars for their first meeting and hands-on learning experience at FONA International in Geneva. STEM Scholars met with experts in flavor chemistry, food science, sensory science, research and innovation as they create all manner of food flavors. The Scholars had an opportunity to learn about FONA, the food industry and the science behind how we taste and experience food.
Over the next year, Scholars will interact with other practitioners in the STEM fields and develop their leadership skills to advance the understanding of how science, math and technology can contribute to their future careers and communities.  
2018-2019 STEM Scholars: Storey Childs, St. Charles East High School  Matthew Cleveland, Sycamore High School Katie Dunteman, St. Charles North High School James Forbis, Warren Township High School Brady Hare, Aurora Central Catholic Hamelynn Harzman, Yorkville High School Ricardo Herrera, Huntley High School Jonathan Hess, Batavia High School Sophia Jedziniak, Yorkville High School Michael Jedziniak, Yorkville High School Sarah Jochum, Rosary High School Madison Karamagianis, Johnsburg High School Paige Klmavicius, Rosary High School Rebeca Marston, Batavia High School Caitlyn Mathews, Mundelein High School Brendan McCluskey, Nequa Valley High School Samantha McGreevy, Oswego High School Teague Merrill, Marmion Academy Oliver Miller, Homeschooled Addy Novak, Batavia High School Neha Rajan, Batavia High School Audrey Schero, St. Charles East High School Aidan Smith, St. Charles East High School Justin Suess, Marmion Academy Willem Vandermeij, Geneva High School 

Hultgren Praises Additional Resources in Opioid Fight
I am pleased to report that $1.5 million in grants have been awarded to the 14th Congressional District by the Department of Justices' Office of Justice Programs. These resources will bolster the DeKalb County Opioid Dependency Diversion Program, in addition to providing the Oswego school system with funding for enhanced safety measures.
It’s all hands on deck in the effort to stem the flow of Opioids and the havoc they reap upon the communities of the 14th Congressional District. Providing additional support empowers local assets to direct a more comprehensive approach to help those who have fallen prey to the false allure of opioid addiction.
The grant announcement came on the heels of the House-passed legislation last week, the annual Health and Human Services Department funding bill that will provide $6.7 billion in additional funding for opioid-related programs.  

Looking Back at Achievements of the FSC in the 115th Congress
As the House adjourns for the fall break, we cannot help but to turn our attention to the last 21 months since the 115th Congress was convened. As a member of the Financial Services Committee (FSC) I can tell you all, we have been busy and there are a lot of accomplishments that I am very proud of.
Here is just a highlight of a few of the great things that came out of the FSC in the 115th Congress: 
	•	Passed H.R. 1511, the “Homeless Children and Youth Act to meet the needs of homeless children, youth, and families, and honor the assessments and priorities of local communities.
	•	Worked to support those recovering from opioid addiction by passing The THRIVE Act which is designed to support transitional housing for individuals recovering from opioid addiction
	•	Played key roles in rollback of harmful Obama-era regulations. 
	•	Passed the most significant pro-growth community banking bill in nearly a generation. 
	•	Ensure America can compete globally with countries like China with policies that help sustain 3% plus economic growth. 

There is Still Time to RSVP for Upcoming Hunger Forum
Our communities have worked to raise awareness of the problem of hunger in our region just as others have sought to bring attention to it on a worldwide level. Although the challenges to overcome hunger are daunting, they are not beyond our ability to confront and in many cases resolve them.
I will be hosting a forum, “Confronting the Scourge of Hunger”, which will focus on the issue of global hunger and hunger as experienced by many in our own region, and approaches to address and alleviate hunger both locally and globally.  
According the Northern Illinois Food Bank, nearly 600,000 people in northern Illinois rely on food pantries and meal programs to feed themselves and their families. I look forward to hearing about constructive approaches to address the scourge of hunger and expert insight into how we as a community, both locally as well as globally, can participate in finding solutions and helping those whose lives are afflicted by hunger.
“Confronting the Scourge of Hunger” 
Baker Community Center in St. Charles Wednesday, October 17th  10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. 
To RSVP for the event, here. 

The US, Mexico and Canada Adopt New Trade Agreement
For more than a year the United States, Mexico and Canada have worked on a renegotiation of NAFTA. Just a few days ago the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) was announced.   I am very excited for our farmers and producers that Canada has joined Mexico and the United States to modernize a free trade agreement which expands markets for our exporters and further allows our economy to grow. I have long called for the move from tariffs to trade agreements and I look forward to reviewing this new trade deal closely to ensure it provides certainty and opportunities for the hard-working farmers of Illinois so they can utilize the fertile soil of the 14th District to the benefit of their family and community. 
I will always work to ensure that the best interests of our farmers and manufacturers are protected. 
In Your Service,  ￼  Randy Hultgren Member of Congress 14th District, Illinois 
Randy on the Issues - Veterans
We must support the brave men and women who have sacrificed so much in the defense of our freedoms and country. I continue to hold forums across the 14th District to hear from veterans & address issues important to them. I re-introduced the Protecting Veterans Credit Act to provide veterans with consumer protections when they receive adverse credit reporting as a result of VA mishandling. I cosponsored and supported the Hire More Heroes Act, which encourages small businesses to hire veterans. I also supported passage of the Veterans Opioid Abuse Prevention Act to assist veterans in their efforts to overcome opioid addiction and the Homeless Veterans Reintegration Programs Reauthorization Act that allows homeless veterans to access federal grants to assist in securing housing. 

Randy in the News

Subject: An Update from Congressman Vicente Gonzalez to Constituents of the 15th District of Texas
Message:
News from Representative Vicente Gonzalez  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
 
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
About
 
Dear Lindsey, 
Fiscal Year (FY) 2018 came to a close on Sunday, September 30, 2018. I wanted to take the time to give you all an update on recent federal dollars that have been awarded to the 15th District of Texas. 
It is an honor to serve as your congressman.
Recent Federal Funding Awards for Fiscal Year (FY) 2018
Nearly $500,00 for HIV Research Awarded to UTRGV
On July 11, 2018, I announced that the National Institutes of Health National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, has awarded The University of Texas at Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) nearly $500,000 in federal funding. The grant will finance the research and development of a Nano formulated Anti-HIV drug.
I remain in awe of the exemplary research taking place in South Texas. Dr. Schweller and Dr. Wylie have broken barriers on a molecular level - putting UTRGV on the world stage of top tier research. I will continue to work with UTRGV to bring federal dollars to grow this and other programs that help humankind. Read more by clicking here. 
Nearly $500,000 NSF Grant for UTRGV Computer Science
On July 18, 2018, I announced that the National Science Foundation (NSF) has awarded the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) $495,042 to assist Department of Computer Science studies on the algorithmic self-assembly of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).
It is a joy to know that the Rio Grande Valley, and UTRGV, will be at the forefront of medicine that could change the world. This cutting-edge drug delivery research will help to stimulate a robust research environment at our leading minority-serving institution and also expose students to a thriving biomedical research environment. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $2 Million for McAllen International Airport
On July 31, 2018, I announced that the Federal Aviation Administration has awarded the City of McAllen, Texas, $2,006,000 in funding to improve drainage and rehabilitate existing terminals at the McAllen Miller International Airport.
With these improvements, more businesses and travelers will continue to take off and land in the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing our airport and the surrounding communities in Hidalgo County thrive. Read more by clicking here. 
Almost $1.5 Million for UTRGV’s STEM and Diversity Programs
On August 13, 2018, I announced that the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) has received $1,480,002 in funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to stimulate the university’s Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) Program and Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) courses. STEM programs present limitless opportunities for students of all backgrounds.
This new funding will allow UTRGV to continue engaging students in developing fields. I will continue to work with UTRGV, and all partners in the Rio Grande Valley, to secure federal funds that create opportunities for all South Texans. Read more by clicking here. 
$70,000 for Brooks County Airport Improvements
On August 14, 2018, I announced that the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), on behalf of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), has awarded a $70,000 grant to Brooks County for lighting improvements at the Brooks County Airport.
Better quality aviation facilities means better business. I look forward to these airport improvements representing a more streamlined flow of economic development directly to South Texas. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $200,000 for UTRGV and UTD Collaboration Funding from the NSF
On August 15, 2018, I announced that the National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Division of Mathematical Sciences (DMS) has awarded $239,713 to the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV). This funding will fuel a partnership between UTRGV’s mathematical sciences units with those of the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD). 
The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley is cultivating meaningful partnerships that benefit students and promote research. When higher education institutions work together to face the challenges of tomorrow, a more vibrant, diverse group of students are given the resources necessary to approach these issues today. I’ll continue to advocate for federal funds that foster collaboration and investment in South Texas. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $657,000 for Alzheimer’s Research at UTRGV
On August 28, 2018, I announced that the National Institute of Aging (NIA), under the direction of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the National Institute of Health (NIH), has awarded $657,603 to the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley’s (UTRGV) Alzheimer’s Disease Resource Centers for Minority Aging Research (AD-RCMAR). The NIA awarded UTRGV $3,276,391 to establish the Partnerships for Progress Center. The Center is one of the AD-RCMAR’s aimed to enhance the diversity of the research workforce of minority aging devoted to Alzheimer´s disease.
This funding creates the potential for unprecedented breakthroughs in Alzheimer’s research at UTRGV. This unfortunate disease has robbed the health of millions of Americans. I give my full backing to Dr. Maestre and her team to support and enrich the well-being of every American, including those in South Texas. I will continue to work with my colleagues in Washington to ensure that every dollar necessary continues to make its way to UTRGV. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $7 Million Continuation Grant for UTRGV’s Early Head Start-Child Care Partnership Initiative
On August 30, 2018, I announced that the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Administration for Children and Families (ACF) has awarded a $7,231,095 continuation grant to the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) Early Head Start-Child Care Partnership (EHS-CCP) initiative. This funding will allow the University’s Early Head Start-Child Care Partnership to continue providing critical comprehensive family-centered services.
These programs provide every child in the 15th District of Texas with the foundation to achieve academic success at every level. I would like to thank UTRGV for keeping our children ahead of the curve. Read more by clicking here. 
$100,00 Award for South Texas College Workforce and Economic Development Plan
On August 31, 2018, I joined Congressman Henry Cuellar (TX-28) to announce that the Economic Development Administration (EDA) has awarded $100,000 to South Texas College (STC) in McAllen, Texas for workforce and economic development.
There is untapped economic potential in our region. This funding holds the power to allow the incredible minds at South Texas College to break workforce barriers and invigorate our economy. Read more by clicking here. 
$750,000 in Border Security Funding for Duval and Jim Hogg Counties
On September 7, 2018, I announced that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has awarded $750,000 in federal funds to Duval and Jim Hogg Counties for Fiscal Year 2018. These awards are through the Operation Stonegarden Program (OPSG) for their efforts in prevention, protection and response to security issues on our border.
This funding gives Duval and Jim Hogg Counties the ability to maintain the safety and security of South Texas. The efforts in improving technological readiness and increasing coordination between law enforcement agencies show their dedication to ensuring the well-being of the region. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $1.2 Million to Enhance Edinburg Fire Department Capacity
On September 11, 2018, I announced that the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has awarded the City of Edinburg a $1,288,821 Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response (SAFER) Grant. This funding will allow the City of Edinburg Fire Department to hire an expected 12 new firefighters.
The Edinburg Fire Department provides vital emergency services to the community. I would like to thank FEMA for investing in the Rio Grande Valley’s first responders. I will continue to work in Congress to bring this type of funding to fire departments across the 15th District of Texas. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $2 Million in CDBG Funds for Edinburg and Pharr
On September 19, 2018 I announced that the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Office of Community Planning and Development (CPD) has awarded $1,044,198 and $1,202,024 for Fiscal Year 2018 to Edinburg and Pharr, Texas, respectively. This funding comes in the form of Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) which provides communities with resources to expand access to affordable housing, create jobs, and retain business growth.
Community Development Block Grants empower communities to address some of their most pressing housing, infrastructure, community development and economic challenges. I look forward to working with city, state, and federal officials to continue building a brighter future for Central and South Texans from all walks of life. Read more by clicking here. 
Almost $1 Million for Affordable Homes of South Texas, Inc.
On September 21, 2018, I announced that the U.S. Department of Treasury’s Community Development Financial Institutions Fund (CDFI) has awarded $950,000 to Affordable Homes of South Texas, Inc. in McAllen, Texas for Fiscal Year 2018. The funding will jumpstart additional affordable housing projects in South Texas communities.
No one in the 15th District of Texas should be without a home. This funding from the U.S. Department of Treasury will help Affordable Homes of South Texas create new housing developments and empower families to purchase and own their own home while building equity and a patrimony for themselves and their families. Read more by clicking here. 
$1.2 Million for Infrastructure and Employment Opportunities in Hidalgo City
On September 24, 2018, I announced that the U.S. Economic Development Administration (EDA) awarded the City of Hidalgo and Hidalgo Economic Development Corporation $1,200,000 for infrastructure and employment projects.
Now, more than ever, areas in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley are making strides to improve infrastructure and create new jobs. This investment will bring more than new roads and water systems, it will improve the overall quality of life for every resident in the City of Hidalgo. Read more by clicking here. 
$125,000 for Tropical Behavioral Health
On September 25, 2018, I announced that the Center for Mental Health Services (CMHS) has awarded $125,000 to Tropical Texas Behavioral Health (TTBH). Funding will be used to expand mental health services.
This funding will help Tropical Texas Behavioral Health offer more consistent and reliable support to individuals with a mental illness. It is my hope that mental health professionals across Central and South Texas will take advantage of funding opportunities like this to improve the mental health and well-being of our communities. Read more by clicking here. 
Over $88,000 for UTRGV’s International Studies and Foreign Language Departments
On September 26, 2018, I joined Congressman Henry Cuellar (TX-28) to announce that the U.S. Department of Education’s (ED) Undergraduate International Studies and Foreign Language (UISFL) Program has awarded $88,160 to the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) for Fiscal Year (FY) 2018.
The ability to communicate without barriers can transform and strengthen relationships not just in Texas, but around the world. With this funding, UTRGV can empower even more students to go into the world and create meaningful, lasting relationships in education, business, the medical field, and beyond. I thank the U.S. Department of Education for entrusting UTRGV with this funding and will continue to partner with Congressman Cuellar to support educators and students in South Texas. Read more by clicking here. 
More than $600,000 for Bus Shelter Improvement Across the Rio Grande Valley
On September 26, 2018, I announced that Federal Transit Administration has awarded $661,342 from its Buses and Bus Facilities Infrastructure Investment Program to the Lower Rio Grande Valley Development Council (LRGVDC) for Fiscal Year (FY) 2018. The funding will assist LRGVDC with the design and construction of new bus shelters – enhancing the experience of riders traveling between Brownsville, Edinburg, and Harlingen.
Public transportation opens doors and keeps our community moving forward. This new funding will improve the current bus system in South Texas and improve the lives of many more. Read more by clicking here. 
$600,000 for UTRGV to Support Beginning Farmers and Ranchers
On September 27, 2018, I joined Congressman Henry Cuellar (TX-28) today announced that U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) awarded $600,000 to the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV) for Fiscal Year (FY) 2018. This funding will assist the Frontera Beginning Farmers and Ranchers Development Project which supports Hispanics and veterans in South Texas with development and sustainability in the farming and ranching market.
This new funding will allow the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley to support beginning farmers and ranchers in pursuit of prosperity. I thank Congressman Cuellar for his collaboration in this endeavor and will continue to work with our federal partners to plan, develop, and implement strategies that allow UTRGV and our farmers and ranchers to thrive. Read more by clicking here. 
$929,800 Grant for South Texas College
On September 28, 2018, I joined Congressman Henry Cuellar (TX-28) to announce a $929,800 grant awarded by the U.S. Department of Education to South Texas College (STC) through their Child Care Access Means Parents in School (CCAMPIS) Grant program. The college will receive a $232,450.00 yearly grant over the next four years, totaling $929,800.00 in federal funds.  The grant was funded through the fiscal year 2018 omnibus appropriation bill, which funds the government for the remainder of the fiscal year. 
We should be doing all that we can to support and celebrate every student in the Rio Grande Valley. This new funding for Project ACCESS will allow South Texas College to continue offering childcare opportunities for Valley residents seeking a higher education. I thank Congressman Cuellar for his continued collaboration to break down barriers for South Texas students. Read more by clicking here. 
Almost $200,000 USDA Rural Development Federal Funds Awarded to UTRGV
On October 2, 2018, I announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Rural Development program has approved a $199,613 grant for the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV). 
I thank the USDA for recognizing the needs of rural Texans and commend UTRGV for its commitment to harnessing the untapped potential in our communities. This important funding will unlock opportunities that allow even more Texans to thrive. Read more by clicking here. 
As always, please let me know if there is anything I can do to better serve you. To contact any of my offices in South Texas or in Washington, D.C. click the "contact me" icon above.   
Please click “sign up for my newsletter” to register for updates to learn more about how I am serving the 15th District of Texas. I look forward to seeing you soon in Washington or back in Texas.   
Your friend and neighbor,
 ￼ 
Vicente Gonzalez
Member of Congress

Subject: Congressional Report
Message:
￼


Saturday, October 6, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: 
￼
￼



Congressional Report

Dear Friends, 
This week I attended various meetings and events with different individuals and organizations, including The Hill’s Newsmaker Series and met with representatives from the Texas Automobile Dealers Association and the Mexicans and Americans Thinking Together Foundation.   In the district, my staff attended several meetings and events including the Delia Gonzalez Elementary Ribbon Cutting Ceremony in Roma, the Walk to End Alzheimer’s in Laredo and a series of National Night Out events.
Lastly, I have included a video from The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that raises awareness about important influenza (flu) prevention actions, including receiving a flu vaccine every year.

As always, please contact one of my offices if you need assistance with any federal agency. 


Rep. Cuellar Meets with Mexicans and Americans Thinking Together Foundation  
￼

On Wednesday, September 27, I met with Executive Director Aracely Garcia-Granados and Program Analyst Jonathan Peterson-Ruiz from the Mexicans and Americans Thinking Together Foundation to discuss their Bordernonomics Alliance program. Pictured from left are: Congressman Henry Cuellar, Aracely Garcia Granados, and Jonathan Peterson-Ruiz. 


Rep. Cuellar Meets with the Texas Automobile Dealers Association 
￼

On Wednesday, September 27, representatives from the Texas Automobile Dealers Association visited with me to discuss tariffs on automobiles, tax reform, and Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) reform. Pictured from left are: Jeff Martin, Mark Jones, Martin Garcia, Erika Blankenship, Congressman Henry Cuellar, Efrat Bogoslavsky, and Ariad Sommer. 


Rep. Cuellar Addresses the Value of Bipartisanship at The Hill’s Newsmaker Series 
￼

On Wednesday, September 27, I spoke at The Hill’s Newsmaker Series to discuss the value of bipartisanship in our nation, and the importance of working across the aisle to take action on the issues that matter most to Americans. Pictured from left are The Hill Editor-in-Chief Bob Cusack and Congressman Henry Cuellar. 


Delia Gonzalez Elementary Ribbon Cutting Ceremony 
￼

On Thursday, September 20 representatives from my office presented a Congressional Certificate of Recognition and framed flag to Roma ISD for their newly opened Dalia Gonzales Garcia elementary school. Pictured from left are Librarian Anna Guillen, Counselor Elizabeth Guerra, Assistant Principal Carmelita Cantu, Mrs. Delia G. Garcia, Principal Edgar Garza, and Facilitator Manuel Lopez. 


Presenting U.S. Flag to Poteet Police Department 
￼

On Tuesday, September 25, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente Poteet Police Cfficer Noe Rodriguez with a new U.S. flag to be flown over the department. Pictured from left are Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente and Police Officer Noe Rodriguez. 


Walk to End Alzheimer's in Laredo 
￼

On Saturday, September 29th, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties Francis Atwell attended the Alzheimer’s Association Walk to End Alzheimer’s in Laredo. At the event he presented the Alzheimer’s Association with a Congressional Certificate of Recognition to recognize the Alzheimer’s Association’s work in bringing awareness to this disease. Pictured in the photo above are Outreach Coordinator Francis with members and volunteers from the Alzheimer’s Association. 


National Night Out Events in Texas' 28th District:
Laredo National Night Out 
￼

On Tuesday, October 2, my Outreach Coordinator for La Salle, Webb, and Zapata counties Francis Atwell attended the City of Laredo National Night Out event. The event was held to educate the public on the services offered by the law enforcement community. It also gave members of the community a chance to meet the first responders who keep our communities safe. Pictured from left are Ofcr. Luis Raines, Ofcr. Ricardo Martinez Jr., Laredo Police Department Deputy Chief Miguel Rodriguez Jr., Mayor Pete Saenz, Outreach Coordinator Francis Atwell, Laredo Police Chief Claudio Trevino Jr., Assistant Police Chief Manuel Maciel, and Ofcr. Jose Ceballos Jr. 


Windcrest National Night Out 
￼

On Tuesday, October 2, my Outreach Coordinator for Bexar County Pete Arguello also attended the National Night Out gatherings in Live Oak, Roosevelt High School, and Windcrest. Pictured from left are Windcrest Police Chief Al Ballew and Outreach Coordinator Pete Arguello. 


The Estates & Mission Hills Homeowners Association National Night Out 
￼

On Tuesday, October 2, my Outreach Coordinator for Atascosa, Bexar, McMullen and Wilson counties Gilbert Lafuente attended The Estates/Mission Hills Homeowners Association National Night Out. Pictured from left are Architectural Control John Beck, Outreach Coordinator Gilbert Lafuente, President Mary McConnel Smith, Secretary Deborah Beck and Treasurer Greg Lltis.


Staff Spotlight: Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez 
￼

Meet our Outreach Coordinator Nichole Hernandez. Nichole is responsible for outreach projects in Starr and Hidalgo counties where she attends events on my behalf and meets with public officials and constituents. Nichole is originally from the Rio Grande Valley and graduated from The University of Texas-Pan America (now known as UT-RGV). When she’s not working on various projects, Nichole enjoys spending time with her family and friends. 


Intern Spotlight: Olivia Perez 
￼

Meet our intern Olivia Perez. She is a Senior at the Baylor University pursuing a double major honors degree in Political Science and Great Texts. She completed her summer internship in our Washington, D.C. office. To learn more about Olivia and our other interns, please click here. 


The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Prevent Flu! Get a Flu Vaccine and Take Preventive Actions 
￼

This video from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention raises awareness about important influenza (flu) prevention actions, including receiving a flu vaccine every year. Preventive actions, including covering your nose and mouth when you sneeze or cough and limiting your contact with others if you become sick, can also help prevent the spread of flu. 

 
 

Sincerely,
￼
Henry Cuellar

Subject: Congressman Mark Sanford's Weekly Review
Message:
￼

October 6, 2018
View Online 

Weekly Review
 



October 1

Funding the Land & Water Conservation Fund: In light of the fact that I went out paddling yesterday morning with a group to Crab Bank, allow me to muse just a little bit more about the issue of conservation and open space. It’s certainly part of the fabric of what makes the Lowcountry special, but frankly it’s part of the fabric of what makes so many areas of our country unique.
But it doesn’t just happen. Our national parks are in place because people were proactive on making them so. The ACE Basin is unique because people like Charles Lane were pioneers in pushing for conservation easements on lands that had been held by Lowcountry families for years.
Where am I going with all of this? I’m going to the fact that yesterday, the Land and Water Conservation Fund expired. That’s a blow for all of us who care about preserving and protecting unique and special places or access to them across our country.
I’ve said it many times now in many different ways, but we live in the craziest of political times. At one level, we see it in things like the Kavanaugh hearing and the media circus that surrounded it. Or at another level, we see it with the termination of funding for the Land & Water Conservation Fund.
Doing so is a remarkable breach of public trust. Click here to read more.
￼

October 2


Revitalizing Crab Bank: Let me follow up on the Land and Water Conservation Fund. In this case, let me make it more local and talk just a little bit about what I mentioned yesterday, as I joined a couple hundred others on Sunday morning for a paddle out to Crab Bank in support of the revitalization of the island.
To me, the paddle and the conversations that came with it had less to do with Crab Bank in many ways than it did about two important themes I think all of us need to think about in the Lowcountry.
One, we need to be proactive about saving open space and unique components of what make our part of the world special relative to so many other places out there. It is unique to have a bird rookery in one of the busiest container ports in the United States. Crab Bank represents another little feature to the world of distinct here in the Lowcountry. And not being like any place else has real benefit...not just for the birds on Crab Bank but in the economic engine of what drives our economy as we have a different look and feel to the Lowcountry that brings in tourists and retirees.
Two, it’s about the importance of all of us making our voices heard with things we’d like to see come our way or in this case, stay as part of our coast. It was really neat to see a few hundred folks paddle out to Crab Bank on a glorious morning, and there is a collective voice that goes well beyond our individual voices in the world of politics. We need to be bold, whether it’s speaking up for natural wonders…or against growth in the not-so-wonderful national debt.
This weekend, The Post and Courier published an op-ed I wrote on the importance of conservation efforts in the Lowcountry...addressing Crab Bank as well as the Tri-County Waterfront Park - the park of scale I hope collectively we can bring about on the tip of Daniel Island. 
￼
Click above to read the Post & Courier op-ed 
￼

October 3

Unsustainable Government Spending and the Debt: I continue to believe that we are walking our way toward the most predictable financial crisis in the history of man. 

I believe that the financial storm that will confront us will be more damaging than the Great Depression. 

I say this because, at that time, people weren't as dependent on their federal government as they are today. 

What people now demand of their federal government - and will demand in a time of crisis - is a quantum leap from what people expected of their federal government in the 1920s. 

We all know that what they came to expect from the government in the wake of the Great Depression was pronounced relative to what it had been in the 1920s, but it still pales in comparison to what people expect and get from their federal government today. When Social Security started, it was but a 1% tax on payroll. Today, it’s over 13% when you combine the employer and employee contributions. Medicare and Medicaid didn’t exist. I could go on with a lot of other examples, but what they all point to is that when this storm kicks off, people are really going to get hurt. 

If you look at the Congressional Budget Office numbers, the federal government has run out of spending room to correct financial difficulty, as they attempted to do in the wake of the 2008 and 2009 financial meltdown. Our Fed has boxed itself in in the same way, given the balance sheet exploded from about $800 billion in size at the time of the 08-09 crisis to over $4 trillion on the balance sheet and a consequent inability to grow at much more than what it is today without sparking inflationary consequences. The same is true with the overall rate environment. We’ve been in a period of declining rates for a long time now, and despite the recent upticks by the Fed, there’s still not a lot of wiggle room in the event a financial storm comes our way. 

I could expand on this in great detail, but I will spare you. It doesn’t mean that we shouldn’t batten down the financial hatches, though. I appreciate the way that many see me as pessimistic or Dr. No on spending, but trust me, there has been a method to the madness, given the way in which numbers have a way of proving themselves over time. 

I spoke on a few of these themes the other night on the House Floor, and for that reason, I thought I'd share the clip below. 

I'd love your thoughts….

￼
Click above to watch Rep. Sanford's floor speech
￼


October 4

Promoting Responsible and Free Trade Act: Tariffs are just a fancy word for taxes...imposed at a country’s border.
I’ve said this multiple times, but it bears repeating...particularly at a time when tariffs or just the threat of tariffs seem to be piling up.
What I find so interesting and relevant about this issue is not whether tariffs themselves are good or bad. (I do take a decidedly free market view of the global trading system, but that’s beside the point here.) What matters here is simply this: the Constitution clearly vests Congress with the responsibility to impose tariffs.
In spite of this, modern history is filled with examples of the executive branch imposing tariffs without Congress’s approval...or even a congressional debate.
This happened in 1971, when President Nixon - under a 1917 law allowing presidents to restrict trade during times of war - imposed a 10 percent tariffs citing the Korean War. Nevermind the fact that the war was never officially declared and had, in any case, ended almost 20 years earlier. President George W. Bush imposed tariffs on steel imports in 2002 under Section 201 of the Trade Act of 1974, which gives the executive broad authority to impose tariffs in several instances - such as when responding to other countries’ unfair trade practices.
Over the years, no matter whether the White House is occupied by a Democrat or a Republican, Congress’ role in tariffs has eroded. Click here to read more.
￼

October 5

Opposing Drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge: In keeping with the conservation theme from earlier this week, I want to circle back on the notion of drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge…
Just last week, I did two things to express my opposition to drilling in the Refuge. One, I signed onto a letter authored by Dave Reichert from Washington State and two, I cosponsored a bill introduced by Jared Huffman of California that would ban the administration’s efforts to allow oil and gas activities within the refuge.
These actions are important for three reasons…
One, there is a value to ideas that have been time-tested. This is the case with the moratorium on drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The moratorium was put into place by President Eisenhower and it stayed through republican and democratic presidents alike over the last sixty years. When something has been in place for that long through the cross-currents of a whole host of different political perspectives, with perhaps Clinton or Carter on the left and someone like Reagan on the right, we should pause before making a change.
Two, on national policy, we should listen to our grandmother or grandfather as they may have said to us to remember moderation in all things. Click here to read more. 



￼  ￼  ￼  ￼

Subject: SPECIAL UPDATE: You Get to Keep More of Your Hard-Earned Money
Message:
Open in its own browser window   Open a plain text version
News from Representative Lou Barletta 
￼
 


 
 October 6, 2018  
SPECIAL UPDATE: Providing Economic Security for Pennsylvanians 
For too long, high taxes and overregulation led to millions of jobs fleeing our country, unfair trade deals leaving our farmers and manufacturers at a disadvantage back home, and the federal government taking more and more money out of hardworking Americans’ paychecks.  But I’ve been working with President Trump over the past two years to make sure the American worker and middle class families are no longer forgotten.  
￼
It’s always a pleasure getting to know  
Pennsylvania workers. I’m pleased to report
that the Commonwealth's unemployment
rate has dropped to its lowest since 2007.
In Pennsylvania alone, we have created over 115,000 jobs, and across the United States, millions of Americans have seen increased benefits, wages, and bonuses.  Small business and consumer confidence are at all-time highs, employment is at historically low rates, and jobless claims are the lowest in nearly 50 years.    This new era of American prosperity is a direct result of actions taken by Congress and the Trump Administration to cut red tape, roll back burdensome regulations, and pass the historic Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the most comprehensive reform of our broken tax code in over thirty years.  This landmark legislation, which I proudly voted for, cut individual rates, doubled the standard deduction and child tax credit, and created a 20 percent deduction for small businesses, the backbone of our economy.  It also eliminated disastrous Obama Administration policies that rewarded companies for shifting jobs, profits, and manufacturing plants overseas.  By cutting our uncompetitive corporate tax rate, we have seen hundreds of billions of dollars that corporations left sitting overseas reinvested into in American workers and businesses.  Thanks to Tax Reform, the United States is once again the home to business innovation and prosperity.  To maintain this economic momentum, I voted for three bills last week known as “Tax Cuts 2.0,” making sure American workers can keep more of their paycheck, supporting small businesses, and providing our nation’s seniors with more flexibility and security in their retirement.  
￼
Apprenticeships and Career and Technical
Education programs like the one I toured at  Luzerne
County Community College help ensure workers
have the skills they need to succeed.
On top of making key provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act permanent – such as the doubled standard deduction, decreased individual rates, small business deduction, and enhanced child tax credit – Tax Cuts 2.0 expands 529 accounts to cover the costs of homeschooling and apprenticeship programs, while also allowing parents to withdraw money they have in retirement accounts penalty-free for expenses related to the birth or adoption of a child.   Tax Cuts 2.0 also helps entrepreneurs develop their passions by ensuring they are able to deduct start-up costs for new businesses, while also allowing older Americans to contribute to their retirement account later in life.  Furthermore, this legislation creates new Universal Savings Accounts so individuals and families can save for college, retirement, or a car payment without being taxed.  Since Tax Reform was signed into law, paychecks got bigger, jobless claims got smaller, and confidence is now soaring throughout the United States.  Now, with Tax Cuts 2.0, Pennsylvanian families don’t just get to keep more of their hard-earned money, they’ll have new ways to save it for the future.  I am proud to fight alongside President Trump to provide a renewed chance of prosperity for working families across Pennsylvania, and I look forward to continuing to fight for you and ensure economic security and success for American workers and businesses across the country.  It remains an honor to serve you in the U.S. House of Representatives.  All my best, ￼  Lou Barletta  Member of Congress 





How I Can Help You

How You Can Help Me




I remain convinced that some of the best solutions to America’s problems come from outside of Washington, D.C. I encourage you to voice any questions, concerns, or suggestions you may have by contacting one of my offices.

Subject: Progress for Washington's Trade Economy
Message:
Share on: 
￼￼ 
 
￼
￼


Dear Friend,  Early this week I was very glad to hear that Canada agreed to join the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement. This effort for an updated NAFTA agreement is beneficial for our workers, businesses, and farmers here in Washington State because 40% of our jobs are tied to trade. I look forward to taking a closer look at the agreement and discussing it with my colleagues to determine whether it meets our objectives. I am optimistic that a strong partnership will continue to create jobs and growth here in America.  Drawing Awareness to Safety on Our Roads  I joined with my fellow Congressional Law Enforcement Caucus Co-Chair, Representative Bill Pascrell, Jr., in introducing House Resolution 1107 supporting the designation of National Secure Your Load Day on June 6th. Each year, thousands of drivers are injured as a result of unsecure loads and road debris on our nation’s highways. In fact, according to a study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, in 2016 more than 90,266 incidents were caused by unsecured loads, resulting in approximately 19,663 injuries and 683 deaths. This resolution we introduced honors the lives of those who have been impacted, including the daughter of one of our fellow Washingtonians, Robin Abel. After her daughter was catastrophically injured by an unsecured load, Robin has dedicated her time and energy to raising awareness about these avoidable tragedies. I was proud to introduce this resolution to highlight the need to make our roads safer by securing loads and preventing road debris. 
￼
District Happenings  THIS WEEKEND: Ellensburg Film Festival   The annual Ellensburg Film Festival brings film enthusiasts from across the Northwest to the Kittitas Valley each year. There is something for everyone with short films, documentaries, national films and international features playing throughout the weekend.  EVENT DETAILS When: October 5th: 7pm-10pm, October 6th: 10am-10pm, October 7th: 11am-8:30pm Where: Central Washington University’s McConnell Theatre, 400 E University Way, Ellensburg, WA  THIS WEEKEND: Harvest Festival  The Harvest Festival in Cle Elum is being held at Suncadia’s Historic Nelson Farm. Open for the next two weekends, celebrate the beginning of fall with seasonal activities and events such as a hay maze, pumpkin patch, crafts, a petting zoo, pony rides, pumpkin archery, wagon rides, and face painting in an environment that is fun for the whole family.  EVENT DETAILS When: October 6 & 7 and 13 & 14, 10am-5pm Where: Suncadia, 3600 Suncadia Trail, Cle Elum, WA  MONDAY: Leavenworth Community Farmers Market Locals Night  Leavenworth Community Farmers Market Locals Night takes place every second Monday of the month at Watershed Café. At the event you can indulge in local food, wines, and drinks from Watershed. Come and enjoy some good food and support the local farmers market!  EVENT DETAILS When: October 8, 5pm-9pm Where: 221 8th Street, Leavenworth, WA  Thank you for reading about the work I am doing for you in Congress. Wishing everyone a fun and pleasant fall weekend!
Sincerely,
Dave

Subject: Weekly Newsletter 10.6.2018
Message:

Follow Jackie: 
￼￼￼￼￼
￼
ABOUT JACKIE | NEWS | ISSUES | SERVING YOU | 2ND DISTRICT | CONTACT
THE FUTURE OF MANUFACTURING
￼
Yesterday was National Manufacturing Day, and I had visited General Stamping & Metalworks in South Bend to help kick off an exciting day in our community.
I am grateful to the South Bend Regional Chamber for this opportunity to speak to some bright young Hoosiers who are the future of this growing industry.
Manufacturing is opening new doors to prosperity and opportunity in our region and across the country.
￼
With the skills these students are learning now, they will be ready to walk through those doors and write the next chapter in American manufacturing.
Northern Indiana is full of businesses of all sizes that make products to sell all over the world. From RVs and boats to military equipment and medical devices, our region has a long tradition of invention and innovation.
￼
It takes incredible skill, hard work, and innovative thinking to keep building American-made products.
I know our next generation is going to do groundbreaking things, and I am so excited to see where the future takes us.
EDUCATIONAL SESSIONS ON MEDICARE ENROLLMENT
￼
Medicare is a sacred commitment we have made to our seniors, and part of keeping that promise is ensuring Hoosiers have all the information they need to secure their benefits. With the Medicare enrollment period coming up, my office is here to help answer your questions.
On October 9th, 10th, and 16th, a member of my staff and a Medicare specialist from Indiana’s State Health Insurance Program (SHIP) will hold “Medicare 101” educational sessions throughout the 2nd District. The events will take place in Elkhart, Goshen, La Porte, Peru, Plymouth, South Bend, Wabash, and Winamac.
If you are at or near retirement or are a caregiver for a Medicare beneficiary and you want to learn more about the program, I encourage you to attend our “Medicare 101” educational sessions to learn the basics of Medicare and have your questions answered by experts.
Information about the “Medicare 101” events can be found below:
Tuesday, October 9th, 10:00 – 11:30 a.m. ET Wabash Public Library Program Room 188 West Hill Street Wabash, IN 46992

Subject: Health Insurance Costs are Dropping Under Republican Leadership
Message:
Having trouble reading this email? Click here to view in your browser.
￼
Website | About Phil | First District | Constituent Services | Newsroom | Issues | Legislation | Contact Me

Health Insurance Costs are Dropping Under Republican Leadership 
As a physician with more than 30 years of experience and co-chair of the House GOP Doctors Caucus, I am working to ensure every American has access to the health care they need and coverage they can afford. It’s not just a priority for me – it’s been my life’s work. That’s why I’ve stayed committed to repealing Obamacare and replacing it with free-market, patient-centered care. The goal of Obamacare was to provide affordable health care to every American, a goal we all support. Although access to health insurance increased, the law resulted in less choice and higher costs – with too many Tennesseans unable to afford coverage at all. In Tennessee alone, the average premiums on the exchange have risen 176 percent over 10 years, a staggering amount. I have helped lead the fight to bring back affordable health care to Americans, and while we still have a lot of work to do, we are starting to see some positive results.
Since President Trump took office, Democrats have made claims that our proposed reforms will cut off access and result in even higher costs. House Democrat Leader Nancy Pelosi stated, “Republicans will force tens of millions of families to pay more for worse coverage -and push millions of Americans off of health coverage entirely,” and Senate Democrat Leader Chuck Schumer stated, “The Republican plan to cut health care wouldn’t make America great again, it would make America sick again and lead to chaos instead of affordable care.” Well, I’m pleased to report their doomsday predictions were wrong. Just last week U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar announced at a speech in Tennessee that for the first time since Obamacare was enacted, average premiums are expected to drop nationwide. In Tennessee, rates will drop an average of 26 percent. This is great news. 
What were some of the changes we’ve made? As part of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, signed into law last year, we repealed the penalty associated with the individual mandate, which required everyone to purchase government-approved health insurance or pay a penalty. To me, this was the most troubling aspect of Obamacare because for first time in our country’s history the government was forcing you to buy a product. Now that we repealed this unfair mandate, Americans can shop for the coverage based on their needs and what they can afford. Free market reforms are designed to spur competition, lower costs and improve quality of care; because of this fundamental idea we are now seeing progress. 
Additionally, I led the effort to repeal arguably the worst part of Obamacare, the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB) – an unelected, unaccountable board of bureaucrats that would have been given the authority to propose immediate cuts to Medicare to meet a budget. Those cuts could have resulted in seniors having been denied access to health care services, so I was thrilled when the IPAB was fully repealed in H.R. 1892, the Bipartisan Budget Act 2018, and signed into law on February 9, 2018. 
President Trump has also implemented several Executive Orders to help reduce the regulatory burden and to promote the competition and quality in our health care system. Most recently, his administration put out an executive order to encourage association health plans, which – if done correctly – would allow small businesses to band together to purchase health insurance just like large corporations do. Actions like this will help spur competition and reduce health care costs, and as part of that effort, we will continue to protect those with pre-existing conditions. In each of the past three Congresses I have introduced the American Health Care Reform Act, which fully repeals Obamacare and replaces it with expanded access to Health Savings Accounts; includes tax code reforms that encourage choice and competition in health insurance; and promotes greater transparency on cost. There’s no question further reforms are necessary, but I’m hopeful my bill can serve as a platform for future reforms that we consider.  
My door is always open to East Tennesseans. Feel free to contact my office if I can be of assistance to you or your family.
