Subject: Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 10.5.18
Message:
October 5, 2018
Share this email:
￼
￼
￼

￼
Congressman Griffith's Weekly E-Newsletter 10.5.18
Friday, October 5, 2018 –                                 
Energy and Commerce Work
As you know, I serve on the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The following are some of the issues we are working on.
Progress on Prescription Drug Prices
High prescription drug prices are a burden on many Ninth District residents. There are a variety of reasons why prices have soared, but one necessary factor in order to bring them down is transparency.
Thanks to legislation that has passed the House of Representatives and the Senate, transparency will be coming to drug prices. Both chambers of Congress passed the Know the Lowest Price Act of 2018 and the Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act. These bills prohibit “gag clauses,” which I have discussed in this column before.
In some circumstances, a person could save money by paying cash for a prescription instead of using health insurance, but gag clauses imposed by pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) have prohibited pharmacists from telling their customers that information.
This practice is unfair, and I was an original cosponsor of the Know the Cost Act to ban gag clauses. This legislation was unanimously voted out of the Energy and Commerce Committee in September and is similar to the bills that later passed the House and the Senate, both of which are supported by President Trump.
More work remains to be done to make prescription drugs affordable, but banning gag clauses and encouraging transparency will help achieve this goal.
Caring for New Mothers
The death of any new mother in childbirth or due to its complications is a tragedy. Unfortunately, such tragedies have occurred more frequently in recent years in the United States.
Among numerous indicators of this trend, a 2016 report found a near-27 percent increase in the maternal mortality rate for 48 states and Washington, D.C. from 2000 to 2014.
The House Energy and Commerce Committee’s Health Subcommittee, on which I serve, held a recent hearing to look more closely at this disturbing trend. We heard testimony from medical professionals and advocates, including a man who had lost his wife after she gave birth via cesarian section due to inattention by medical staff.
We examined draft legislation, the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act of 2018, with the hope of reducing these tragedies.
To address the problem, we first need better information. This legislation improves data collection on maternal mortality. Having more comprehensive information would serve the Ninth District well by letting us compare data at a regional and national level. This would be accomplished by reporting this information to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. When an area is near several states, as ours is, having information only at the state level offers limited benefits.
Rising maternal mortality in America is a troubling trend. We can and will do better.
Energy Security
Energy powers our country’s economy, our national security, our leisure and recreational activities, almost our entire way of life. Because energy is pervasive, it is vulnerable to risks, whether accidents, natural disasters, or people who wish to do harm.
Threats to energy infrastructure require vigilance on the part of government and the energy industry. Vulnerabilities need to be assessed, plans need to be made for contingencies, and awareness needs to keep up with threats that constantly evolve. In a wireless world, cyber threats are as real a danger as physical threats.
The Energy Subcommittee I serve on recently held a hearing to consider this important topic, featuring testimony from the U.S. Department of Energy’s Assistant Secretary for Cybersecurity, Energy Security, and Emergency Response.
I used my time to ask the Assistant Secretary about pipeline security, a topic critical for American energy security and personally meaningful for Ninth District residents with property currently crossed by or near pipelines and residents in the pathway of new pipelines.
Technology exists that can sense problems, such as leaks, where they occur. The same technology can tell you when someone is walking, driving, or shoveling near the pipeline. Requiring this technology to be added to any new pipelines and any pipelines that are being repaired would be a great asset for ensuring the security of vast lengths of pipelines. Accordingly, I urged the Assistant Secretary to look at it as a solution.
If you have questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to contact my office.  You can call my Abingdon office at 276-525-1405 or my Christiansburg office at 540-381-5671. To reach my office via email, please visit my website at www.morgangriffith.house.gov. Also on my website is the latest material from my office, including information on votes recently taken on the floor of the House of Representatives.
###

Subject: Tax Reform 2.0
Message:
￼ 
October 5, 2018

Dear Friend, 

When the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was signed into law, we knew it would boost the economy.  What we are seeing in Mississippi and across the nation has far exceeded our expectations.  The impact is profound.  More take-home pay is enabling the majority of Americans to improve their quality of life and plan for the future.  Tax reform combined with regulatory rollbacks is enabling companies to share their tax savings with their employees in the form of higher wages, bonuses, and benefits.  Not only that, companies are investing in their operations, expanding, and creating more jobs.

Click here to see examples of tax reform good news in Mississippi provided by Americans for Tax Reform (ATR).

The next step is to make these changes permanent.  Legislation we call "Tax Reform 2.0" is the answer.  This package, consisting of three bills, will secure the reforms initiated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.  These bills will protect middle class and small business tax cuts, promote family savings, and boost the confidence of potential entrepreneurs.  To learn more about these important pieces of legislation, please click on the links below.

H.R. 6760, the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act of 2018

H.R. 6757, the Family Savings Act of 2018

H.R. 6756, the American Innovation Act of 2018
                                
ACTIONS IN THE HOUSE
 The opioid crisis continues to wreak havoc on the lives of people in Mississippi and across the nation.  We have made significant progress to address this situation through passage of legislation which will improve treatment, recovery, and prevention.  In June, the House passed a series of bills to help achieve our objectives.                                                
￼
 Last week, we made additional progress to address this crisis with passage of H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act.  The bipartisan bill encourages the development of new, non-addictive painkillers, improves prescription drug monitoring programs, improves access to care, addresses the impact of opioids on families, and establishes comprehensive opioid recovery centers.
 Treatment and Recovery:                                             
	•	Improve and expand access to treatment and recovery services
	•	Provide incentives for enhanced care, coordination, and innovation
	•	Establish comprehensive opioid recovery centers
Prevention:
	•	Encourage non-addictive opioid alternatives to treat pain
	•	Improve data to identify and help at-risk patients and families
	•	Address high prescribing rates while enhancing prescription drug monitoring program
Protecting Communities: 
	•	Give law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of communities
	•	Better intercept illicit opioids at international mail facilities
	•	Improve access to federal resources for local communities
Fighting Fentanyl:
	•	Better tackle ever-changing drugs
	•	Crack down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs
	•	Provide grants for local communities to combat Fentanyl                 

GOLD STAR MOTHER'S AND FAMILY'S DAY

On Sunday, September 30, our nation recognized Gold Star Mother's and Family's Day.  These families lost a loved one who served on active duty in the United States Armed Forces.  Recently, 
Gold Star families were recognized at the Honor Our Troops Classic in Olive Branch.

￼
Kelly Bagwell, Donna Bagwell, Jim Fleming, 
Pam Fleming, Tamela Bussard, 
Mike Morel, Molly Morel, and Pearlie Gordon
  
Mrs. Pearlie Gordon was among those in attendance.  PFC Shedrick Deon Gordon, Jr., Mrs. Gordon's son, was a soldier serving in the Hernando-based Company A 2/198th Combined Arms Battalion when he passed away on August 29, 2009.  The 22-year-old native of Sardis served as a recruiter.  Mrs. Gordon said it was always her son's goal to serve in the military.  "I'm very proud," Mrs. Gordon said.  "Deon was a loving person who reached out to the community.  He was a true leader who went above and beyond to encourage others to serve."

￼

PFC Gordon is survived by his parents, Shedrick Deon Gordon, Sr. and Pearlie Gordon; and his two sisters, Shameka Shaw and Shavetta Gordon.

￼
Pearlie and Shedrick Gordon, Sr.

My thoughts and prayers are with all of our Gold Star families.  The service and sacrifice of their loved ones will always be remembered.


ACADEMY DAY 2018

Academy Day 2018 is coming soon! It is a privilege to host this event which offers middle and high school students an opportunity to learn more about serving our nation as an officer in the U.S. Armed Forces.  Over the years, we have had a tremendous response from young people, parents, teachers, and Service Academy representatives.  Every year, officers have shared their personal experiences which inspired others to follow in their footsteps.  I look forward to more of the same on October 13 in Oxford.  Hope to see you there.

￼


CADET CONNOR SPROUT

Cadet Connor Sprout was born and raised in Olive Branch.  He knew at a young age that he wanted to pursue a military career.  When he was in middle school, Connor attended his first Academy Day.  In 2016, it was my pleasure to nominate Connor to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point.  Conner, a junior at West Point, said attending Academy Day helped him to learn more about his options.  "Academy Day gave me the opportunity to talk directly with Service Academy and ROTC representatives," Conner said.  "I listened to what they had to say."

￼

Connor said his experience at West Point has been challenging and rewarding.  "It is time consuming," Connor said.  "There are academic and physical demands that will test your mental and physical abilities.  It is tough, but definitely rewarding."  Those who plan to attend one of the military academies should pursue leadership positions while in high school.  Making good grades is essential.  Connor is looking forward to graduation in 2020.  I wish Connor well as he pursues a career as an officer in the U.S. Army.        


A WEEK IN PICTURES

STAY IN TOUCH

Let me know if there is anything my office can do to assist you. You can keep up with the latest news by signing up for my newsletter and following me on Facebook and Twitter.


Thanks for reading,

Subject: U.S. Service Academy Applications Due by October 15
Message:
￼


For Immediate Release
laura.lington@mail.house.gov


Friday, October 5, 2018
(202) 225-3465


 
 ***ADVISORY***
U.S. Service Academy Applications Due by October 15 
 CRESCENT SPRINGS, KY - Each year, Members of Congress have the privilege of recommending exceptional young people for admission to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, the Naval Academy, the Air Force Academy, and the Merchant Marine Academy, known collectively as the U.S. Service Academies.
The U.S. Service Academies offer a unique opportunity for motivated young men and women to serve their country while improving all facets of their character through a rigorous scholastic curriculum and a disciplined moral and physical regimen. In place of tuition, the Academies ask for military service after graduation. Cadets and Midshipmen graduate as Officers in the United States Military, and many have gone on to be great leaders in our nation’s history.
Competition for the limited number of opportunities is extremely high. Nominees are chosen based on several factors including character, leadership, academic excellence, physical aptitude, and extracurricular activities. Congressman Massie will recommend the most qualified applicants from the Fourth District.
The deadline to submit an application is Monday, October 15th, 2018. Applications must be received at Congressman Massie's Northern Kentucky office by 5:00 p.m. that day.
To apply, please request a U.S. Service Academy Nomination Application from Congressman Massie's Northern Kentucky Office: 
Northern Kentucky Office 541 Buttermilk Pike, Suite 208 Crescent Springs, Kentucky 41017 Phone: (859) 426-0080 Fax: (859) 426-0061 Hours: Monday-Friday 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
For more information, please visit Congressman Massie's website or contact our Northern Kentucky District Office by calling 859-426-0080.
  ###

Congresswoman Bustos with last year’s military academy nominees 
Applications are now open for high school students from across Illinois’ 17th District for nominations to the United States Service Academies for the class entering the fall of 2019! 
Each year, I have the honor of nominating up to ten qualified individuals from our region for attendance at four service academies: the U.S. Military Academy in West Point, NY, the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, MD, the U.S. Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, CO, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, NY. 
Our military academies provide our nation’s young people with not only a first-class education, but the tools to become the next generation of leaders. If you or a young person you know are interested in applying, applications are due before the November 2nd deadline.

Subject: Tax Reform 2.0, Updated NAFTA, Sweeping Opioid Legislation, and more...
Message:
News from Representative Darin LaHood

Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward
￼ 
 
WEBSITE 
CONTACT
SERVICES 
NEWS
 
￼ 
￼
￼
￼


Dear Lindsey, 
From a trilateral trade agreement to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), to reforming our tax code, to harvesting corn across the 18th District, the last couple weeks have been busy both here at home and in Washington, D.C. Continue on to read my latest update:
Changing the Culture in Washington D.C.  
￼
￼
Last week, House Republicans renewed our commitment to the American taxpayer. In the last nine months, we have seen the results of pro-growth tax reform that puts the interests of hard-working families above those in Washington. Take home pay is up 4.9%, Jobless claims are at a 49 year low, and in Illinois' 18th District the average middle-class family has seen a savings of $2,100. The economy is booming and with passage of Tax Reform 2.0 we are making sure the economic prosperity is here to stay.
In Tax Reform 2.0, we provide certainty to taxpayers by making the tax cuts from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act permanent, incentivize individuals and families to start saving early in life, and unleash America’s innovative spirit so startups can move to Main Street and beyond. As a member of the Committee on Ways and Means I was proud to work with Chairman Rep. Kevin Brady and the entire committee to provide relief to hard working families in central and west-central Illinois. 
Release: House Passes Tax Reform 2.0, Ensuring Economic Gains Are Here to Stay 
ICYMI: My Op-ed on Tax Reform 2.0
￼ 
I penned an op-ed, setting the record straight on tax reform and highlighting the important work we are doing on the Committee on Ways and Means to further the economic gains hard-working families in Illinois have seen over the past nine months with Tax Reform 2.0. You can read the op-ed in the Peoria Journal Star here. 
An Updated NAFTA for the American Farmer
￼ 
As we are currently in the middle of harvest, farmers are trucking strong yields to the elevators. We are seeing lines and piles of corn and soybeans at the elevators and the news of this deal will come with eagerness as farmers work to sell their products to our neighboring markets. Free trade is vital to Illinois’ 18th District and modernizing NAFTA into the 21st Century will ensure that exporters in Illinois have access to important international markets without being hit with burdensome tariffs, keeping them competitive in the global economy. I applaud the efforts of President Trump and his Administration in working to bring Canada and Mexico together for the USMCA and look forward to reviewing the provisions and working with my colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee and the Administration to ensure this revamped agreement protects the interests of central and west-central Illinois.
Release: Rep. LaHood Applauds Trilateral Agreement to Replace NAFTA 
Talking Opioid Crisis with Bloomington Fire Department
￼ 
First responders are crucial to combating the opioid epidemic and I was pleased hear directly from the Bloomington Fire Department on ways we can reduce overdoses and equip responders with the necessary resources to save lives. I am grateful for the brave service of these men and women and look forward to continued dialogue about keeping our community safe.
Congress Passes Sweeping Legislation to Battle Opioid Crisis
￼ 
Since joining Congress, I have made combating the opioid epidemic a top priority of mine. I am proud that the Opioid Addiction Action Plan, legislation I introduced along with Rep. Adam Kinzinger, and Democrats, Rep. Danny K. Davis, and Rep. Yvette D. Clarke, was included in this strong bipartisan effort to fight the opioid crisis, which has ravished families in central and west-central Illinois. Our bill will require the Centers for Medicare/Medicaid (CMS) to develop an “Opioid Action Plan” along with stakeholders, to find innovative ways we can combat this ongoing public health crisis.
As a whole, this represents the largest legislative effort to fight the opioid epidemic and will incentivize the development of non-addictive painkillers, alternative pain management, expand grant funding for local law enforcement to combat the flow of fentanyl, and provide additional funding for rehabilitation opportunities. This legislation passed the House, with my support, 396-14 and the Senate 98-1.
Families in central and west-central Illinois are looking for solutions to ease the burden the opioid epidemic has placed on their lives. While there is still work ahead of us, this bipartisan effort is a step in the right direction towards saving lives.
Release: Rep. LaHood's Bill Included in Sweeping Bipartisan Opioid Legislation 
Congress Sends FAA Reauthorization to the President's Desk
￼ 
Last week, the House and Senate passed the five-year reauthorization  for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), sending the legislation to President Trump's desk.  This bipartisan legislation provides long-term certainty for America’s airport infrastructure, air travelers, and innovators, and I was happy to support this bill to ensure the Federal Aviation Administration can continue making air travel safer and more efficient while remaining the world-leader in aviation. Our regional airports in central and west-central Illinois play a vital role in bringing economic prosperity to our local communities and this legislation will help in making sure that we continue that progress for years to come. Read more here. 
Conversation with the McLean County Chamber of Commerce
￼ 
I recently visited with the McLean County Chamber of Commerce Government Affairs Committee where we discussed various topic impacting McLean County and the 18th District such as a growing economy, continuous demand for skilled workers, healthcare costs, infrastructure, trade, and tax reform.
Thank you to all committee members who joined me for a great discussion and thank you for all you do to help grow economic opportunities for McLean County. 
Bipartisan Celebration of Illinois' Bicentennial
￼ 
My friend and colleague Raja Krishnamoorthi and I introduced legislation last week to designate an area within Anacostia Park in Washington, D.C. as the “Illinois Bicentennial Grove,” where four White Oak trees have been planted. As the state tree of Illinois, these trees have been planted in honor of four prominent abolitionists from the Land of Lincoln—Edward Coles, Mary Brown Davis, and Elijah and Owen Lovejoy. As we continue to recognize our state’s bicentennial alongside the collaborative efforts of the Illinois State Society of Washington, DC, this grove will serve as a distinct reminder of the rich history that our home state holds over the past two centuries. 
Illinois Wesleyan Helping Local Entrepreneurship
￼ 
Special thanks to the Small Business Development Center at Illinois Wesleyan University for showing me the incredible work being done to guide local entrepreneurs who are looking to start, manage, or expand their small businesses. Whether it’s navigating the numerous regulations that affect their industries, understanding and analyzing financials, developing a marketing campaign, or just wondering what needs to be considered when starting a small business, the SBDC is there as a reliable resource for their 240+ clients.
Thank you for all you do in helping all of McLean County entrepreneurs get started or become better at following their passions. 
Helping After Hurricane Florence
￼ 
Following the devastating impact Hurricane Florence had on the East Coast, I was pleased to join the Central Illinois Community Blood Center to encourage support for victims of Hurricane Florence. As response units work to day and night, they rely on blood donations to save lives and keep their supplies replenished. It has been great to see so many from Central Illinois lend a hand and I encourage all those who are able to donate to roll up their sleeves and help our friends in need.
Celebrating Sam Johnson
￼ ￼
Last week, I was honored to sit on the Committee on Ways and Means Subcommittee on Social Security hearing as Sam Johnson presided over the Subcommittee for the final time as Chairman. Chairman Johnson is an American hero. A retired U.S. Air Force Colonel, Mr. Johnson is a decorated fighter pilot veteran from both the Korean and Vietnam War, where he was a prisoner of war for nearly seven years. During his time as Subcommittee Chairman, he committed himself to protecting Social Security benefits, and I am grateful I was able to play a role in his mission. I am thankful for Chairman Johnson's service to our country and his friendship on the Committee. We will miss him greatly!
Release: Chairman Johnson, American Hero, Gavels Final Hearing as Subcommittee Chair 
Basketball for Charity
￼ 
Last week, it was great to join a bipartisan group of colleagues to play in the Congressional Basketball game to support the Hoops for Youth Foundation. Hoops for Youth provides opportunity to at-risk youths through basketball and teaches kids the skills they need to succeed both on and off the court. It was great to celebrate 20 years of supporting kids in the community!
￼   Sincerely, ￼  Darin LaHood Member of Congress

News from Representative ￼ Serrano
￼

Biography
Services
Press Releases
Issues
Legislation


￼
The Serrano Report -October 5, 2018
￼ 
In Washington, DC 

Congressman Serrano and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus Requests Meeting With Smithsonian Institution 
Congressman Serrano, Congresswoman Michelle Lujan Grisham, Chairwoman of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus (CHC), Senator Robert Menendez and members of CHC leadership, sent a letter to Smithsonian Institution Secretary David Skorton, requesting a meeting to discuss concerns about the recent findings from a University of California study that found that the Smithsonian has failed to heed its own recommendations and take measures to improve the representation of Latinos and Latinas across exhibitions and its workforce.
Congressman Serrano and Senator Robert Menendez are the primary Democratic sponsors of the National Museum of the American Latino Act (H.R. 2911/S. 1364). The National Museum of the American Latino Act is a bipartisan, bicameral legislative effort to establish the National Museum of the American Latino within the Smithsonian Institution and help share and celebrate the history, culture, arts, and contributions made by Latinos in the United States. Full text of the letter follows and can be found here. 
Last week Congressman Serrano also attended a reception to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month and support the campaign for a Smithsonian Latino Museum. 
￼ 
On 1 Year Anniversary of Hurricane Maria, Congressman Serrano Introduces COMPROMISO Act 
In commemorating Hurricane Maria's passage through Puerto Rico a year ago, Congressman Serrano introduced the COMPROMISO Act - the Continuing Our Mission in Puerto Rico to Optimize and Modernize Infrastructure and Sustain Obligations Act. Co-sponsored by Reps. González-Colón, Velázquez, Soto, and Gutiérrez, the bill would extend 100 percent cost share waivers for FEMA categories A and B in Puerto Rico. This will ensure that the federal government continues covering the costs of emergency assistance to the island after Hurricane Maria.
In 2007, in the aftermath of Hurricanes Katrina, Wilma, Dennis and Rita, similar language was incorporated into Public Law 110-28 to extend local cost share waivers for the Gulf Coast states that had been affected by these hurricanes. Click here for background info and more details on this change. 
“One year after Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico is still struggling to fully recover. While we’ve made tremendous progress in Congress by securing significant emergency relief funding for the island, most of this funding hasn’t been disbursed and the island is still going through a financial crisis. Puerto Rico’s local government still can’t bear the burden of FEMA’s cost share requirement, and demanding that it do so now will only further slow and hinder local recovery efforts. This bill will extend the cost share waivers to ensure the federal government continues covering this cost as it did in the Gulf Coast states after Hurricane Katrina,” said Congressman Serrano.
Congressman Serrano also published an Op-Ed on The Hill today on the one year anniversary of Hurricane Maria’s passage through Puerto Rico, the federal government’s response, and the need for the federal government to commit itself to the island’s reconstruction. To read the article click here.  
Congressman Serrano has been a vocal advocate for Puerto Rico for many years, he has been a leader in seeking adequate resources for the rebuilding of Puerto Rico post Hurricane Maria:  
￼
Congressman Serrano, Congresswoman Velazquez, Senator Gillibrand, Senator Warren and Senator Sanders Continue Pressuring Secretary DeVos and Dept. of Education for Answers on Status of Emergency Funding 
Congressman Serrano led a letter, along with Congresswoman Velázquez, and Senators Kirsten Gillibrand, Elizabeth Warren, and Bernie Sanders, to U.S. Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos following up on two previous letters to inquire about the status of federal disaster aid allocated to help displaced students and directly impacted institutions of higher education affected by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria.
The members questioned again why only such a small percentage of the funding appropriated for these purposes had been disbursed; why numerous application hurdles hadn’t been fixed or addressed, and why the Department continues to ignore criticism and recommendations from members of Congress.
“As you are aware, the Puerto Rican government’s official estimate of the lives lost in Puerto Rico from these hurricanes and their aftermaths was recently revised, indicating that 2,975 individuals perished in the storms. Many communities, particularly in rural areas, continue to struggle to recover. Nevertheless, it appears the Department has only spent $5.4 million, or just seven percent, of the $75 million Congress appropriated in disaster aid for displaced students affected by the hurricanes. Of the $100 million Congress appropriated for directly impacted institutions of higher education, the Department has only disbursed $63 million, leaving nearly $37 million of that funding left unspent. It was Congress’s intent to have this funding disbursed as quickly as possible to help affected students recover and to complete their studies. Unfortunately, it appears that the Department fails to see any sense of urgency in the matter—even as a new hurricane season has begun,” the members wrote.
“It is unfortunate that the Department appears to be doing only the minimum to provide funding to students and institutions of higher education impacted by last year’s hurricanes. We hope that you actively work to change that perception by making recovery efforts in Puerto Rico and other impacted areas a high priority for the Department, just as you would any other state. Additionally, it is essential for the Department to act expediently in order to be able to adequately respond to storm damage that may occur during the current hurricane season. We look forward to your prompt response to the questions above,” the group added.
Click here to read the full text of the letter 
In the Bronx 

Congressman Serrano Meets with SoBro  
Last week Congressman Serrano met with SoBro representatives to discuss the U.S. Department of Commerce Minority Business Development Agency Business Center program which helps minority businesses start and thrive. As the Ranking Member of the Commerce, Justice and Science Subcommittee, part of the Appropriations Committee, Congressman Serrano oversees funding for the agency and the program. Congressman Serrano has been a long time supporter of the Business Center program which has helped organizations such as SoBro assist thousands of people in the Bronx find jobs, create jobs, and continue to make our community stronger.  
￼ 
Congressman Serrano Meets with Constituents With the Food Bank of New York City 
Congressman Serrano also met last week with constituents that traveled to Washington D.C. to be part of the annual Anti-Hunger Advocacy Day to discuss the 2018 Farm Bill. Congressman Serrano has been a strong supporter of robust funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and the federal Emergency Food Assistance Program (TEFAP), which are vital for our community's most vulnerable populations, and will continue to support these programs.  
￼

Subject: Can't we do better than this?
Message:
￼
October 5, 2018
Dear Friend,
Republicans are rushing to confirm a lifetime appointment to our nation's Supreme Court in the wake of both credible allegations of sexual misconduct leveled against the nominee, Judge Brett Kavanaugh, and serious questions concerning his judicial temperament. 
I hope you can take a moment to watch and share a speech I gave on the Senate Floor last night urging my colleagues to oppose this nomination.
￼
VIDEO: U.S. Senator Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) speaks out against the nomination of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to serve on the Supreme Court, October 4, 2018.
I have already made it clear that I oppose Judge Kavanaugh's nomination based on the substance of his views and the broken process being used to rush his nomination through the Senate on a partisan basis. From the very start, Republicans have pushed this nomination through at a breakneck pace, hiding from the public Judge Kavanaugh's record and the dangerous consequences of his extreme views on many important issues. That willful blindness, the absence of a thorough vetting process, and the mad dash to hastily confirm their nominee at all costs before this fall's election has led us to the crisis we face today.
Even beyond what we could learn from a real investigation, there is already reason to doubt Judge Kavanaugh's credibility and his candor. Despite the fact that the White House tried to limit the scope of the FBI's work--so drastically that I wouldn't even characterize it an investigation--the FBI's report still manages to raise very serious questions about Judge Kavanaugh's truthfulness.
Moving forward on this nomination sends a harrowing message to women and girls all around the nation who have been victims of sexual violence. We must not toss aside a fair and impartial process in favor a hurried political endgame. 
The integrity of the highest court in the land--and what we stand for as a nation--hangs in the balance. 
Sincerely,
￼
MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator

Subject: Public Health and National Security Threats
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Brooks
￼
 
RESOURCES
ISSUES
LEGISLATION
CONTACT
 
￼ 
￼ 
 
 
Dear Friend, 
Last week, the House passed a comprehensive bill I introduced earlier this year, H.R.6378, the Pandemic and All Hazards Preparednessand Advancing Innovation Act of 2018 (PAHPA). PAHPA works to make sure we are prepared to respond to and combat chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear threats, pandemic diseases such as influenza or Ebola, as well as natural disasters such as the hurricanes that most recently hit the Carolinas. 
This bipartisan effort ensures our health care professionals are trained to respond to possible pandemic outbreaks, prioritizes the further development of our national stockpile of vaccines, medical equipment and diagnostics, and establishes new advisory groups focused on protecting vulnerable populations such as senior citizens and people with disabilities during public health threats and emergencies. 
In last Sunday’s edition of the Indy Star is an op-ed I wrote about the importance of PAHPA and ensuring we are fostering a culture of preparedness in our country. You can read it HERE or below: 
￼  ￼ 
Seventeen years ago, on 9/11, nearly 3,000 Americans lost their lives as a result of three unforgettable terrorist attacks on American soil. But it is commonly overlooked that more than 6,000 other people were injured, many of them first responders. 
Firefighters, police officers and other emergency personnel from across the country traveled to Ground Zero, the Pentagon, and a field near Shanksville, PA., in hopes to save lives, often without the equipment necessary to protect their health. For months on end, they continued working through ash, debris and smoke which devastatingly resulted in exposure to toxic chemicals.    
In 2016, IndyStar reported 26 of the 62 members of Indiana’s Task Force One who deployed to Ground Zero in the aftermath of the attacks were diagnosed with health complications related to such exposure. Two of those heroes died of cancers related to their deployment. While Congress has ensured there is continued funding for the World Trade Center Health Program and the Victim Compensation Fund through the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Reauthorization Act, there is more we can do to ensure first responders have better access to equipment to keep themselves safe while working to save lives. 
As September, National Preparedness Month, comes to a close, we need to focus more on fostering a culture of preparedness for all kinds of threats to our public health and national security. 
That’s why I introduced a reauthorization bill, which overwhelmingly passed out of the House of Representatives this week, known as the Pandemic and All Hazards Preparedness and Advancing Innovation Act of 2018 (PAHPA). PAHPA ensures our nation is prepared to respond to public health emergencies and modern threats resulting from chemical, biological, radiological or nuclear attacks, natural disasters or emerging infectious diseases. I’m proud this strong bipartisan bill incorporates significant input from the full range of public health preparedness and response stakeholders, including many Hoosiers.  
PAHPA strengthens the Strategic National Stockpiles located across the country with a robust supply of vaccines, basic equipment like gloves, masks and more, so first responders have the equipment they need to protect themselves from harm while selflessly working to save lives. 
PAHPA also ensures more health care professionals can be hired and trained through the National Disaster Medical System, which provides grants to our regional health care network. It strengthens federal resources available to organizations like the Indianapolis based MESH Coalition whose mission is to strengthen the collaboration between first responders, hospitals and local health departments to create a culture of preparedness.  
Medical countermeasures — diagnostics, treatments and vaccines for deadly and dangerous diseases such as Ebola or Zika, whether naturally occurring or through weaponized substances — are often difficult, costly and risky to develop by the private sectors. This bill works to streamline the development and approval process of such medical countermeasures. 
After last year’s devastating hurricanes in Florida and Puerto Rico, and the recent flooding in the Carolinas due to Hurricane Florence, we know we need to do better to ensure the well being of our nation’s most vulnerable populations — our children, senior citizens and people with disabilities. PAHPA ensures there is a coordinated health care response to hurricanes for those who can’t help themselves. 
Hoosiers expect the government to step up quickly and work to keep them safe in times of disaster and public health emergency, whether the threats are man-made or naturally occurring. 
Now, it’s up to the Senate to act swiftly to consider and pass this critical legislation because we may not always be able to foresee or prevent disasters, but we can make sure that if the worst should happen, the tragedy isn’t compounded by more disease and death. 

I was honored to be invited to join the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) Commission on Strengthening America’s Health Security as a commissioner due to my work on PAHPA. This week, we considered how to best build a ten-year strategy focused on global health security that can more predictably and reliably protect our national interests. Other members of the Commission include public health and national security professionals and Members of Congress, including Senator Todd Young. 
Implementation of PAHPA is critically important to increase our preparedness and response efforts to public health and national security threats, and I hope the Senate swiftly passes this legislation so it can be signed into law by the President.  
Thank you for taking the time to read this newsletter. As always, feel free to be in touch with any questions or comments you may have. 
Sincerely, ￼  Congresswoman Susan W. Brooks 
**BONUS** ￼  WATCH my remarks on the House Floor on #PAHPA here.

Subject: Agriculture update - New trade deals!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼

                  AGRICULTURE Update - August/September 2018   
TOP STORY
￼
Meeting with members of the Montana Farmers Union
Trade is important to producers and consumers in Montana and across our country. Tens of millions of Americans are employed at small businesses that engage in trade and it is critical for Montana agriculture as well. For example, roughly 80% of Montana’s wheat is exported. Overall, this is not surprising considering that 95% of the world's population is outside of the United States.
That’s why I applauded President Trump, after extensive renegotiations, for recently reaching an agreement to modernize and improve trade with both Mexico and Canada. This agreement is a positive step and will help provide certainty for our farmers, ranchers, and businesses. Among other things, it will also help level the playing field for Montana grain growers by ending Canada’s unfair grain grading system that discriminated against Montana wheat. Moving forward, I will continue to review the deal and work with the President to ensure Montanans have the right opportunities to succeed
TRADE HIGHLIGHTS  I also applaud the Trump Administration for moving forward with trade talks with Japan. I recently pressed both the Chief Agricultural Negotiator for the U.S. Trade Representative and the U.S. Department of Agriculture in a Senate Ag hearing to engage Japan and other important markets in the Asia Pacific. Like our North America partners, reducing trade barriers in these countries will greatly benefit Montana farmers and ranchers.  FARM BILL UPDATE AND WHAT'S AHEAD
 
￼
Meeting with Montana Farm Bureau President
Hans McPherson
As you may know, Farm Bill negotiations between the Senate and the House have been ongoing for the past several months. While the Farm Bill did expire, the vast majority of farm programs will be maintained through the crop year. I will continue to work to get a strong Farm Bill to Montana on the President’s desk as quickly as possible.
As new trade deals and promising talks unfold, the Trump Administration has developed an aid package for U.S. farmers and ranchers impacted by retaliatory tariffs imposed by other countries. Visit farmers.gov to find more information about the program and whether you’re eligible.     
Survey:
Do you support President Trump's new trade deal with Canada and Mexico? 
Yes
No
Unsure

*By answering this survey, you are subscribing to my newsletter.
If you are having trouble, click here.
Best Wishes, 
￼
Steve Daines United States Senate

Subject: The Art of the Deal
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Representative Graves
￼
 
Website
Meet Sam 
Legislation
News 
Services
6th District
Contact Sam
 
October 4, 2018
￼ 

E-mail Updates
Yes, please periodically send me e-mail updates.* 
 ￼ 
 *By subscribing to my e-mail updates, you are authorizing me to send regular e-mail updates from my office to your e- mail account.

Dear Friend, 
President Trump has made it no secret that he isn’t a fan of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and other trade deals he considers unfair to the United States. 
I agree with the President that we need to have fair trade deals that are beneficial to our country. According to the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative, the U.S. goods and services trade deficit with Mexico alone was $63.6 billion in 2017. That’s unacceptable. 
At the same time, we can’t just throw out a deal completely. Not only is Mexico the number one destination for Missouri corn exports, it’s reported that the U.S. economy earns more than $127 billion from the revenue generated from NAFTA trade.  
We’ve seen some very positive results from NAFTA and we’ve seen some very harmful side effects especially locally. After 24 years, renegotiation was necessary not only to make sure we had the best deal, but to compete in the 21st century. 
Earlier this week, the White House announced that a new agreement had been reached with Canada and Mexico on a renegotiated NAFTA. A 21st century NAFTA will better serve American farmers, manufacturers and workers.  
Agriculture already saw many benefits under the old agreement. However, with this new agreement, they will see even greater benefits. Canada will no longer be able to undersell U.S. dairy products. Additionally, dairy products, eggs and poultry from the United States will gain new access in the Canadian market. These are all big wins for agriculture.
Another key provision in the new agreement deals with automobiles. Now, more cars and trucks will be made in North America by workers who are being paid a decent wage. There will be less incentive to move auto plants to Mexico. American workers win as a result of the new agreement. 
This improved version of NAFTA has been a long time coming. It’s obvious that our trade agreements have to be in line with the economy as it exists today while working toward improving the American economy of tomorrow. I commend the President and his administration for working tirelessly with Canada and Mexico to come to terms on this deal. It just proves that that, with a little patience, diligence, and hard work, we can change the status quo and bring even greater benefits to our country. It’s critical that Congress works together to approve this deal in the very near future. 

Sincerely,
￼ 
Sam Graves

Subject: Brett Kavanaugh = Unfit to serve on Supreme Court
Message:
News from Representative Evans
￼

Home
Contact
Services
Media
 
FBI Kavanaugh Investigation 
After watching his behavior during the historic hearing last week and reading early reports about the FBI investigation which was released this morning, I believe Brett Kavanaugh is unfit to serve as a Supreme Court justice – a judgment affirmed today by lifelong Republican former Supreme Court justice. 
The investigation of Kavanaugh was intended to examine further evidence that could corroborate the accusation of sexual assault made by the survivor, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford. The report is over 1,000 pages long and available only to senators as they contemplate whether the man in question is deserving and uniquely qualified to serve a lifetime appointment on the highest court in the nation.
According to my Senate Democratic colleagues, the FBI probe - which lasted only THREE days - appears to be incomplete. FBI agents did not to interview key sources who were willing and ready to testify, such as Dr. Ford herself. Although the White House supposedly instructed them to be meticulously thorough, only nine people were interviewed throughout this probe.
The American people have a right to know the truth -- the entire truth -- about Judge Kavanaugh before he is confirmed to sit on the Supreme Court and make life and death decisions that will affect millions of people for generations to come.
Our Supreme Court justices are supposed to remain level-headed and non-partisan. Vulnerable populations in Philadelphia and across our great country cannot afford to have a Supreme Court justice who makes partisan statements such as “What goes around comes around!” towards Senate Democrats on the Judiciary Committee and even asking a senator if they have a drinking problem when asked tough questions about his experiences with alcohol. 
I will say it again, and emphatically: Brett Kavanaugh is UNFIT to serve on the Supreme Court.  
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Dwight Evans 
Member of Congress

Subject: Island Time
Message:
Having trouble viewing this email? View it on our website. 
￼ 
Home 
Services 
Issues 
Media Center 
Contact 

October 4, 2018 
Island Time 
           ￼ 
Dear Friends,  
Most people know Block Island as a vacation destination. Travelers flock to the island in droves during the summer months to enjoy the sandy beaches, boutique-lined streets, and pristine nature trails. However, for just over 1,000 Rhode Islanders, Block Island is something much more than a seaside retreat – it is their home.  
I am fortunate to represent the residents of this beautiful community, and I always enjoy the time I spend there. This past September, I traveled to New Shoreham to meet with my constituents across the island.  
My first stop off the ferry was a visit to the Block Island School where Principal Kristine Monje assembled the student council. We had a fascinating discussion covering a range of topics, and I was very impressed with the students’ insightful questions. Before leaving the school, I had the pleasure of meeting with Mason Miro, an inspiring 4th grade student who is a Special Ambassador for the Muscular Dystrophy Association.  
The remainder of the day included multiple stops around town. I visited the Block Island Power Company to discuss the impact of transitioning service from diesel generators to renewable energy provided by the Block Island Wind Farm. I also took the opportunity to visit the only manufacturer on the island, North Light Fibers, and to stop by the Block Island Medical Center to meet with their staff. Lastly, I had the honor of presenting a Certificate of Special Congressional Recognition commemorating the 150th anniversary of Block Island’s North Light  
Overall, the trip was very productive. Meeting constituents in person through visits to their communities is essential to my work in Congress – even when it takes a ferry ride to get there!  
For more information on my visits around the Second District, and for updates on many other topics, please visit my website and follow me on Twitter, Facebook, YouTube and Instagram.  
            Sincerely,  
           ￼ 

￼ 
Protecting Air Travelers with Disabilities 
Several components of the Air Carrier Access Amendments Act I introduced with Senator Tammy Baldwin (D-WI) were included in the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act that just passed Congress. These provisions include a bill of rights for passengers with disabilities, a disabilities advisory committee, and a review of regulations regarding the assistance that airline and airport personnel must provide to passengers with disabilities 
  
￼ 
Fighting Suicide in Washington County 
Suicide is a complex public health concern, but it is important to realize that there are proven policy solutions, like suicide prevention hotlines, that can help people struggling with suicidal thinking. Senator Jack Reed, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse and I recently announced $2 million in federal funding for South County Healthy Bodies, Healthy Minds’ Zero Suicide in Washington County program to help reinforce successful intervention strategies that save lives. Remember, help is only a phone call away – you can reach the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.

Subject: Trump’s Taxes & Self-Made Myth: My MSNBC Interview Clip
Message:
￼



 October 4, 2018   
  



10849 E. Walking Stick Way 


San Antonio, Texas 78205- 
  
  
Dear Lindsey,   
Last night, I joined MSBNC to discuss the major investigation by the New York Times into Trump’s taxes, showing that the Trump family has had little regard for our tax laws. I also shared my plan to ensure Congress examines his tax returns. I welcome your advice on this and other federal issues. You can watch the brief interview here: 
￼ 
Donald Trump is a self-made myth, not a self-made man. In January, if the American people have supported a new Congress that will engage in oversight, not just overlook, then we do not even need a subpoena to examine his tax returns. As the Ranking Member of the Tax Policy Subcommittee on Ways and Means Committee, I have put forward seven motions to release the tax returns, all of which have been blocked by Republicans. But I will not relent until Congress performs its oversight duty—over an out-of-control President. Trump has some 564 business entities that he receives income from, in addition to his personal returns. When I have put forward my seven motions, one as recently as last month, the Republicans have covered up and blocked every one. They do not want to look under that rock and see what they might see. 
We need to look at exactly how much Trump may have enriched by this Republican tax bill that he promoted—with a special interest provision added at the last moment that benefits families just like his. And we certainly need to explore the Russian connection. There was a time when Don Jr. said the Russians were among their top investors; let’s look at those Trump entities that stretch from Manhattan to Azerbaijan and see what’s in there and who’s been involved. 

Especially in these difficult times, I welcome your good counsel. I also hope that you will take this opportunity to visit my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter, follow me on Instagram, or send me an e-mail at Lloyd.Doggett@mail.house.gov. 
Sincerely, 
￼         Lloyd Doggett
 ￼ ￼ ￼ 


  
  
  



￼

Subject: Rep. Adams' Congressional Update | A Look Back at a Busy Summer
Message:
￼ 
  

￼ 


Dear Friends,

Summer was here and then gone before we knew it. I've been keeping busy, both in D.C. and at home in the district! Here are some updates on what I've been up to. 

Best,
￼
Congresswoman Alma S. Adams, Ph.D.

￼ 
June
￼ 
On June 4th, I was joined by Mayor Woody Washam to announce the launch of the 12th District’s Cornelius Satellite Office hours. We’re pleased to expand office hours across the district in order to serve our constituents. Come visit my team on the first Thursday of every month from 3-5 pm at 21445 Catawba Avenue, Cornelius, NC 28031. 
￼ 
June 21st was The Longest Day, which is dedicated to Alzheimer’s awareness. It is critical that we increase awareness and support important research that may lead to breakthroughs on the disease. My office and I wore purple in support of efforts to end Alzheimer’s.
 July
￼ 
On July 10th, I managed debate on the House Floor for the passage of the SCORE Small Business Support Act (H.R. 1700) and the Small Business Innovation Protection Act (H.R. 2265). As Vice Ranking Member of the House Committee on Small Business, I was proud to support these bills that provide counseling and support for small business owners and help to protect intellectual property and innovative ideas. 
￼ 
On July 17th, I stood with House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA), and fellow Democratic women in Congress, to stop the confirmation of United States Supreme Court Justice nominee Brett Kavanaugh due to major concerns about his potential impact on women’s rights and other vital rights and liberties.  
￼ 
Also on July 17th, the Committee on Small Business Subcommittee on Investigations, Oversight, and Regulations and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations met for a hearing titled, “Achieving Government-Wide Verification of Service-Disabled Veteran-Owned Small Businesses.” During this hearing, we heard from experts and leaders on how to expand opportunities for disabled veterans to be successful small business owners.
￼ 
On July 18th, the House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi appointed me to serve as a conferee for the 2018 Farm Bill reauthorization. This bill has significant provisions that impact food security, farm communities, and the future of agriculture in our country. 
￼ 
Also on July 18th, I met with the interim Chief Executive Officer of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Fern Fernandez, to discuss how to expand small business and labor opportunities for Hispanic business owners and workers. 
￼ 
On July 19th, I hosted “HBCUs: The Key to Diversifying Tech” with the National Urban League, the Bipartisan HBCU Caucus, and the Congressional Black Caucus. This roundtable brought together leaders from the HBCU community, tech sector, and Congress to discuss how government and industry can work together to build a more diverse and inclusive workforce. During the roundtable, we evaluated best practices in creating a diverse pipeline through partnerships between businesses and HBCUs.     

￼ 
I and my staff attended the Mechanical Trades Carolina seventh annual graduation program on July 21st. The graduates included those pursuing careers in heating and air conditioning, plumbing and other professional trade careers.  
￼ 
On July 24th, I was delighted to attend the Girls Who Code Congressional Hackathon sponsored by the Business Software Association Foundation and AT&T. Girls Who Code is a nonprofit organization which aims to support and increase the number of women in computer science. The organization is working to close the gender employment gap in technology and change the image of what a programmer looks like.
￼
I closed out this busy day with a guest lecture at the Davidson College Washington Program. I shared my story of political activism and what it means to live the “American Dream” with this brilliant class of Davidson students.  
￼ 
On July 25th, The House Committee on Education and the Workforce hosted a bipartisan Innovation Showcase to highlight 25 innovators who are running education and workforce development programs in their communities. I was proud to be joined by Danielle Frazier from Charlotte Works. Charlotte Works is a workforce development board that provides opportunities that prepare people for education and available careers, while connecting businesses to skilled workers.
￼ 
August
￼ 
There is a national shortage of professional truck driverrs. On August 1st, I visited Trans/Tech Inc., a local driving school that trains individuals to be professional truck drivers. I enjoyed touring the facility, meeting with the instructors and students, and getting behind the wheel of a “Big Rig”.  
￼ 
My staff and I visited a local Home Depot in Pineville. Within the 12th District, there are seven Home Depot stores that employ nearly one thousand associates. 
￼ 
National Night Out was on August 7th. I visited events throughout Charlotte to support stronger police and community relationships that make our neighborhoods safer for all.
￼ 
On August 8th, I hosted my Merge Mobility Community Conversation. This was a community discussion on the factors that contribute to economic mobility and how they impact the residents of the 12th District.
￼ 
On August 8th and 9th, I hosted the inaugural Diversity in Tech Summit with the Congressional Bipartisan HBCU Caucus. The tech summit, held on the campus of NC A&T, brought together over 200 government, tech, and HBCU leaders.
￼ 
On August 14th, I visited Pat’s Place Child Advocacy Center in Charlotte. Pat’s Place is the only child advocacy center in the city that provides critical investigative and treatment services for victims of severe physical and/or sexual abuse along with witnesses of violent crimes
￼ 
On August 15th, I visited Novant Health Presbyterian Medical Center in Charlotte to tour their Neonatal and Pediatric Intensive Care units. After speaking with the amazing NICU and PICU staff, I was moved by their efforts to save the lives of children. 
￼ 
On August 16th I joined my colleague, Congressman Richard Hudson, to present the Congressional Award to 78 young North Carolinian leaders. The Congressional Award is presented to students who have completed requirements in personal development, public service, fitness, and exploration.
￼ 
On August 18th, I attended the opening kick off for the Charlotte Pride Festival in Charlotte. Our district presents this festival every year. It is the largest Pride Festival in the state of North Carolina. I gave remarks at the festival and continue to support the LGBTQ+ community. 
￼ 
On August 22nd, I joined Johnson C. Smith President Clarence Armbrister to announce a $325,000 grant provided by Blue Cross Blue Shield of North Carolina. The grant will strengthen their Sustainability Village and work to end Charlotte’s growing hunger crisis.
￼ 
On August 23rd, I was honored to accept the Lifetime Achievement Award from the NC Justice Center at the “Let Her Rise: Workplace and Gender Equity” Forum. As a leading progressive research and advocacy organization in North Carolina, their mission is to eliminate poverty by ensuring that every household in the state has access to resources to achieve economic security. 
￼ 
On August 29th, I gave remarks at the grand opening of the Zechariah Alexander CDC and St. Paul Baptist Church Centra Affordable Housing Development. This new housing development will provide housing to residents at the 60% average media income or below, in collaboration with Laurel Street Residential, the North Carolina Housing Finance Agency, and Bank of America. 
 One Meck Community Recognition 
Every month, I present a constituent with the, One Meck Community Recognition Award. The award is presented to constituents who have exhibited exemplary character and service to improve the quality of life for the citizens of the 12th Congressional District

Congratulations to this summer's award recipients: 

￼
June: Cindy Quinlan, International Director of Youth4Abolition. Youth4Abolition brings awareness of sex trafficking. To learn more visit their website: http://www.youth4abolition.com/

￼
July: Patrick Hill, Executive Director of A Cultivated Mindset, works to provide members of the Charlotte- Mecklenburg community with training and assistance to create and market their own businesses.

￼
August: Khalia Braswell is the Founder & CEO of INTeach Camp for Girls, a nonprofit organization whose mission is to inform and inspire girls to innovate in the technology industry. 
￼ 
District Corner 
 June:
	•	On June 2nd, Congresswoman Adams attended St. Mark’s United Methodist Church’s Community Gospel Expo. There, she updated attendees on her legislative efforts in D.C.
	•	On June 2nd, Congresswoman Adams addressed graduates from Communities in Schools’ Safe Journey Program, which supports teenage mothers working to balance motherhood, school, and their families.  
	•	On June 6th, our office participated in the Economic Mobility Conversation held at the Mosaic Village in Charlotte.
	•	On June 7th, we participated in the annual inter-faith (IFTAR) event which brought together community and civic leaders to highlight unity.  
	•	June 8th, district office staff attended ourBridge’s end-of-year celebration. ourBridge is a not-for-profit organization that supports children of newly arrived refugee and immigrant families. 
	•	June 9th, to close out the 2018 Black Enterprise Entrepreneurs Summit, I had the chance to speak to attendees, urging them to continue to be the visionary leaders we need for our district’s economic prosperity.
	•	On June 12th, our office met with local organizations to discuss their loss of Emergency Food and Shelter funding and how our office can assist in addressing the shortfall. See our July section for our victory update.
	•	June 13th, Rep. Walker and I welcomed, to Capitol Hill, our third class of Congressional Bipartisan HBCU interns! This year, we to hosted Jameia Booker from Johnson C. Smith University and Tony Watlington Jr. from North Carolina A&T State University. We started this internship in 2016 to increase diversity on Capitol Hill by providing an opportunity for HBCU students and alumni. 
	•	On June 16th, district staff attended the Unity in CommUNITY event in Davidson, where District Attorney Spencer Merriweather spoke on issues pertaining to criminal justice. 
	•	On June 18th, I hosted the Adams Hunger Initiative Advocacy Training event to provide attendees with the skills needed to advocate on behalf of Farm Bill inclusions.
	•	On June 19th, our staff attended the Juneteenth Celebration at the Rosa Park Farmers Market in Charlotte.
	•	On June 29th, my district office staff toured Charlotte Mecklenburg Library's Idea Box Makerspace. This community learning environment allows citizens to explore new technologies while designing and building ideas from start to finish.   
	•	June 30th, during an event held in Charlotte, I stood in solidarity with families being ripped apart at the border. Broken families don’t reflect American values, which is why I was proud to be joined by so many that demand families be immediately reunited.   
         July:
	•	In July, I helped to secure funds for Emergency Food and Shelter Programs in Mecklenburg County. Through a coordinated effort between United Way of Central Carolinas (UWCC), local nonprofit, civic and political leaders, our office helped to bring over $600,000 back to Mecklenburg County, after a disappointing loss of $500,000. The loss of EFSP funding would have deprived local organizations that provide food and shelter for Mecklenburg County’s most vulnerable residents.
	•	On July 8th, I went to Brownsville, Texas to visit the Southwest Key Children’s Detention Center. I toured the center and spoke with staff to ensure that the administration was not neglecting its duty to care for the well-being of children separated from their parents due to the administration’s policy.
	•	 On July 24th, I participated in a photo campaign with fellow African American women in Congress as a part of Heart and Soul Magazine’s campaign for women’s health awareness. 
	•	Also on July 25th, my staff attended a reverse trade meeting organized by the U.S.-U.A.E. Business Council, in partnership with the Economic Development Partnership (EDPNC), the Research Triangle Region Partnership (RTRP), the U.S Commercial Service, Charlotte Chamber of Commerce, and the World Affairs Council Charlotte (WACC). The event addressed on increasing business and trade relations between the U.A.E and U.S, with a specific focus on Charlotte, NC. 
	•	On July 26th, I spoke to the Gray Classic Business Roundtable to share legislative updates regarding small business. 
	•	On July 29th, my staff attended the groundbreaking of the $90 million Gateway Station in Charlotte. The station will serve as a hub for Amtrak service, Charlotte Area Transit System and intercity bus services, taxis and ride-sharing companies. 
	•	On July 30th, I attended the Charlotte North Rotary Club, where I gave remarks on social and economic mobility activities, initiatives, and support mechanisms in Charlotte. 
         August:
	•	As a former professor and teacher, I value all that teachers and staff do for their students. On August 2nd, I spoke at the Charlotte Day of Discovery, discussing the importance to prepare Charlotte’s students for the 21st century economy. I took the opportunity to thank teachers and staff for their commitment to ensuring Charlotte students are positioned to thrive. 
	•	On August 4th, my staff participated in an HBCU panel and provided a legislative update to HBCU Alumni Associations Foundation Conference attendees gathered on the campus of North Carolina Central University. 
	•	On August 11th, my District Office hosted a Constituent Services Fair. We provided information about the services and assistance that my office offers to residents. Various federal agencies shared information about their programs during the event. To find out more about the services provided by my District Office, visit my website at adams.house.gov. 
	•	On August 12th I gave greetings at the Charlotte Pride Annual Interfaith Ceremony at St. John’s Baptist Church to celebrate the LGBTQ+ community. Our focus was on spreading love and equality, in spite of religious differences. 
	•	I attended the grand opening for Regions Bank in Uptown Charlotte. Regions Bank is creating new jobs in Charlotte and helping to grow the economy. 
	•	On August 22nd, my staff attended the Charlotte Community Health Clinic Dental Ribbon Cutting Ceremony. The clinic is staffed solely by volunteers who are professionals in primary care, behavioral health, health and wellness education, preventive services, acute and chronic disease management and dental services for children and adults. 
	•	On August 30th, I spoke at the Department of State/ Global Ties US Regional Summit on economic development and entrepreneurship in our district. I also spoke about the importance of global connectivity and international exchange in regional economic development.   
￼ 
Legislative Update 
June 
 Introduced Bills
H.R. 6091 – The REAL Opportunity Act – This bipartisan legislation creates six centers of excellence at 1890 Land-Grant Universities to ensure Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) are able to expand their research capacity and extension outreach to farmers, ranchers, and local communities.
Learn More
Key Letters 
Letter to Secretary DeVos regarding the challenges facing students of color in the federal student loan system: This letter, sent on June 18th, was led by Rep. Adams along with Reps. Mark Takano and Adriano Espaillat and Senators Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren. It urges the Department of Education to fully enforce borrower protections, continue process pending borrower defense claims, fully discharge and refund the loans of students who have been defrauded, and collect and report data on student loan repayment status disaggregated by race and ethnicity.
Letter to the National Science Foundation supporting their proposed reforms regarding sexual harassment:  In light of the National Academies’ report released entitled Sexual Harassment of Women: Climate, Culture, and Consequences in Academic Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, this letter encouraged NSF to swiftly implement their proposed policy changes to address sexual harassment within institutions receiving NSF grant funding.
Letter to the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Homeland security regarding the status of young girls and infants who have been separated at the border: Sent on June 20th, this letter raises concerns about young girls who have been separated from their families at the border. The photos and videos released as of the date of the letter only showed boys aged 10 and up. On June 18th, Secretary Nielsen was unable to speak to the whereabouts and living conditions for the many girls and infants who were taken from their families.
Letter to the Chief of the National Guard Bureau regarding a new cyber-battalion:  This letter was sent on June 25th by the North Carolina, Ohio, and West Virginia Congressional Delegations. It strongly supports the efforts of the tristate partnership and urges a timely decision for a new cyber-battalion, and encourages its placement in North Carolina, Ohio or West Virginia given the states’ programs, infrastructure, and willingness to immediately support this critical mission.
Letter demanding a full accounting of taxpayer funds spent on separating families: Sent on June 26th, this letter demands from Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar and Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen a full accounting of taxpayer money spent to shelter, transport, care for, and to reunite children who were separated from their parents at the Southern border.
Letter conducting oversight of Trump Administration’s policy of separating immigrant families: This letter was sent of June 28th by the House Committee of Education and the Workforce. It demands answers to questions regarding the health and safety of separated immigrant children, including trauma caused by family separation, the provision of general and special education services, and the process for family reunification.
Key Co-sponsorships
H.Res.405 to recognize June 26th as LGBT Equality Day 
Learn More
H.R. 1298, the CT Colonography Screening for Colorectal Cancer Act
Learn More
H.R. 5129 the Global Food Security Reauthorization Act 
Learn More
H.R. 6080, The Workers’ Freedom to Negotiate Act 
Learn More
H.Res.948 – Recognizing June 19, 2018, as this year's observance of the historical significance of Juneteenth Independence Day (Rep. Jackson Lee)
Learn More
H.R.6135 - Keep Families Together Act
Learn More
July
Introduced Bills
H.R. 6382, Clarity on Small Business Participation in Category Management Act of 2018: This bill would require the Small Business Administration to include in their annual report, information on “best in class” contractors, which are the companies that overwhelmingly benefit when Category Management is used in federal procurement. In doing so, this bill would provide lawmakers with necessary information on whether Category Management is reducing the role of small firms, women-owned firms, minority-owned companies and veteran-owned enterprises in federal contracting.  
Learn More
Key Letters 
Letter to State Department supporting TPS re-designation for Somalia: This letter, sent July 13th, expressed concern over the Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) consideration of allowing Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Somalia to expire. TPS allows immigrants from countries that are experiencing ongoing armed conflict or environmental disasters to remain in the U.S. temporarily. After this letter, DHS announced that TPS for Somalia would remain until March 17, 2020.
Letter to Brazil's ambassador to the U.S. in support of human rights and democracy in Brazil:  Sent on July 24th, this letter formally condemns the crackdown on democracy and human rights in Brazil. The letter goes on to request Brazil’s judicial and political authorities to ensure fair elections and human rights protections. According to Global Witness, a human rights NGO, Brazil is currently the most dangerous place in the world for defenders of land rights and natural resources.
Letter to the Department of Education asking for information on proposed implementation of direct debit card plan for student loan disbursement: This letter was sent on July 30th to seek clarification and information regarding the Dept. of Ed’s proposed Payment Card Program Pilot. There have been concerns that this program, used to disperse student financial aid on a debit card, could be used to restrict access to certain goods and services, as well as create privacy breaches for users.
Letter to the President expressing profound concern about the administration’s recent actions relating to a resolution on breastfeeding at the World Health Organization: This letter expressed concern regarding the Trump Administration’s attempt to water down a World Health Organization (WHO) resolution that recognized breastfeeding as resulting in improved infant and maternal health outcomes. Reportedly, the Trump Administration objected to the language due to pressure from the infant formula industry.
Letter to HHS’s Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality urging them to reconsider their decision to shut down Guideline.gov: Sent on July 24th, this letter expresses concern on the shutdown of a database that provides up-to-date, evidence-based guidelines on how to diagnose, treat, and prevent hundreds of medical conditions or diseases.
Key Co-sponsorships
H.R. 3207, the Zero Tolerance for Domestic Abusers Act 
Learn More
H.R. 6336, the Fair Access for Farmers and Ranchers Act of 2018 
Learn More
H.R. 6543, the Aim Higher Act
Learn More
H.R. 5034, the International Violence Against Women Act
Learn More
H.R. 6504, Stop the Tax Hike on Charities and Places of Worship Act 
Learn More
H.R. 6542, Restoring Tax Credits for Affordable Housing Act 
Learn More
August
Key Letters
Comment Letter to Dept. of Ed. voicing opposition to proposed Borrower Defense rules: This letter was sent on August 30th to express concerns with the Department’s revised Borrower’s Defense rules. The letter takes issue with the new rule’s heightened standard for loan discharge, shortened time frame for filing an application, and forced arbitration provisions, among others.
Letter to DOL raising concerns regarding the weakening of hazardous work protections for minors in nonagricultural occupations: Sent on August 1st, this letter asked for clarification on the Department of Labor’s proposal to weakening workforce protections for 16- and 17-year-olds. Additionally, the letter asks whether this determination was based on expert review of data and scientific literature regarding workplace hazards for young workers.
Letter to State Department supporting TPS re-designation for El Salvador, Honduras, and Haiti: This letter was sent on August 2nd to express concerns over the State Department’s decision to recommend the termination of Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for the countries of El Salvador, Honduras, and Haiti. TPS allows immigrants from countries that are experiencing ongoing armed conflict or environmental disasters to remain in the U.S. temporarily. All three of these countries are scheduled to have their TPS expire in the second half of 2019.  
Letter to the USPTO requesting the collection of demographic data on patent applicants: This letter, sent on August 6th, helps illuminate the fact that women, racial minorities, and low-income individuals are significantly underrepresented amongst patent owners. To rectify this, the letter asks for the collection of demographic information, including race, gender, ethnicity, national origin, age, and income level, so Congress has a basis upon which to address this disparity. 
Key Co-sponsorships
H.Res.993, Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that Congress should take all appropriate measures to ensure that the United States Postal Service remains an independent establishment of the Federal Government and is not subject to privatization.

Subject: hydropower = jobs
Message:
￼

Hello,
I'm in Walla Walla today, and just participated the National Hydropower Association Conference. Leaders from across the country are here to see how our region's hydropower and river systems are supporting jobs and clean, reliable energy. As your voice in Eastern Washington, I wanted to make sure you also received this critical update that I shared with them this morning.
Hydropower helped build the Northwest and provides the region with clean, renewable, reliable, and affordable energy. Energy that powers our homes, businesses, and our communities. Thanks to my provisions I fought for, the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA):
	•	Protects upgrades to our non-federal dams. 
	•	Allows early action dam investments to be made outside of the relicensing window. 
	•	Permits new technology to be installed as it becomes available to increase power generation or fish passage or BOTH.  
	•	Authorizes a land transfer between the Port of Whitman and the Army Corps of Engineers.
>> CLICK HERE to learn more about how my provisions are encouraging investment in hydropower and supporting cleaner energy in Eastern Washington.
 River systems are the lifeblood of our economy here in Eastern Washington, which is why I'm determined to protect the Columbia and Snake River dams. This Congress I passed bipartisan legislation through the House that would provide reliability and certainty in the region. My bill will:
	•	Allow scientists in our region to continue to build consensus, manage our river system, and further improve fish recovery efforts. 
	•	Allow our dams to properly function without further endangering our salmon population. 
	•	Halt the increase in court-mandated spillover of the dams. 
>> CLICK HERE to learn more about how I am fighting to protect the Columbia and Snake River dams.
 Waterways are critical in ensuring that agriculture remains Eastern Washington's number one industry. I was proud to see WRDA pass the House which authorizes critical funding to support our locks, dams, and river system, which is the superhighway for our wheat, potatoes, and other agriculture products. In addition, I secured nearly $2 million in funding to support the Columbia Basin Project, which will:
	•	Develop a pumping plant and pipeline delivery system for the Odessa Ground Water Replacement Program. 
	•	Ensure Columbia Basin irrigation districts can provide water to grow our crops and fuel our economy. 
Our economy is booming right now. Consumer confidence is at a near 17-year high. Wage growth also just hit a 17-month high. The unemployment rate in Washington's 5th District is one of the lowest figures ever recorded. This is the economic comeback Republicans said was possible with lower taxes and smarter regulations. As a result, Americans are Better Off Now. For jobs in our community, I'm working to make sure hydropower and our river systems continue to be a part of this story. 
Thanks, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress

Message:
