The Comstock Connection
News From The Office Of Congresswoman Barbara Comstock
￼ 
Our District
Biography
Media Center
Services
Contact Me

Comstock Statement On Federal Employee Pay Raise
Washington, D.C. - Congresswoman Barbara Comstock (R-VA) released the following statement on the proposed federal employee pay raise, for which she fought: 
“I am pleased that an agreement has been reached to provide our federal employees with the raises they have earned and deserve.  This is an important complement to our providing the largest pay raise to our military in almost a decade and it  is a strong sign of our respect and support for the essential work done by our federal employees.   I appreciate the support of Chairman Frelinghuysen and Chairman Graves in working with us to achieve this important priority,” said Congresswoman Barbara Comstock (R-VA).  “With our strong, booming economy, it is essential that we keep our federal salaries competitive so we attract the talent in the civilian workforce that is needed for our national security, homeland security, law enforcement, and medical research jobs and more.  The pay freezes that occurred for 3 years during the Obama Administration hurt our federal employees and we will continue fighting for competitive compensation and work with the coalition of Members throughout the country who represent our federal employees – 5 out of 6 of whom live outside the Washington Metropolitan area.” 
“NARFE appreciates the Congresswoman’s hard work and dedication to advance a modest pay raise for federal employees in 2019. While her efforts were supported by a bipartisan group of members of Congress, Representative Comstock’s leadership on this issue should be commended. A modest increase in pay not only acknowledges America’s hardworking, middle-class federal employees, but also serves as an investment that will help maintain and strengthen the federal workforce and align it more competitively with the private sector,” commented NARFE National President Richard G. Thissen. 
Timeline Of Events  August 30th- Administration announces a proposed pay freeze for civilian federal employees in 2019. 
August 30th-  I contacted White House immediately to let them know of my strong opposition and relayed my concerns about how this negatively impacted our quality federal workforce.  I was the first Member of Congress in the local delegation to oppose this proposed pay freeze.  I spoke with the Appropriations committee and House leadership to have the House agree to the Senate increase in pay if the White House does not reverse their decision. 
August 31st- The President said he’ll reportedly reconsider this decision.  
September 7th- I joined with a bipartisan coalition of my colleagues in asking the President to reiterate on behalf of our collective constituencies “to reconsider canceling the federal civilian employee pay raise”

Subject: The Banks Brief: Commissioning the USS Indiana
Message:
News from Congressman Banks  Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version 
￼

 
About
Contact
Issues
Media
Services
 
Dear  ,   Thank you for signing up to receive my email newsletter. These newsletters will cover a variety of topics, including events happening in northeast Indiana, legislation being considered in Congress, and my perspective on current issues. My hope is to keep you updated and informed on how issues in Washington may impact our region. I welcome your feedback.  
Thanks for reading, ￼  Jim Banks Member of Congress Indiana's Third District 
USS Indiana Joins U.S. Navy Fleet
￼ 
It was an incredible honor to deliver the principal speech at the U.S. Navy’s commissioning of the USS Indiana in Port Canaveral, Florida on Saturday. This Virginia-class boat is the best attack submarine in the world. Godspeed to the men and women who will sail her throughout the world’s oceans, protecting our country from those who wish us harm. Click here to watch my full remarks. 
Making Tax Cuts for Families and Small Businesses Permanent
￼ 
Last week, I voted in support of the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act. This legislation is one of three bills the House passed that comprise a Tax Reform 2.0 plan.  
When I travel across northeast Indiana, I constantly hear about the positive results from the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Because of tax reform, Hoosiers are seeing more opportunities and taking home larger paychecks. These three pieces of legislation contain key provisions to make many of the tax cuts that help families and small businesses permanent.
With the tax cuts for individuals currently set to expire in 2025, I encourage my colleagues in the Senate to quickly consider these important pieces of legislation. Click here for more information.
Combating the Opioid Crisis
￼ 
I recently voted for bipartisan legislation to combat the opioid crisis and save lives. This comprehensive bill will advance treatment and recovery, improve prevention, protect our communities, and bolster efforts to fight deadly fentanyl. 
Defense Security Cooperation Agency
￼ 
On Friday, I led a bipartisan Congressional delegation to the Defense Security Cooperation Agency to learn more about our Foreign Military Sales program, which provides vital support to our allies around the world.
Hoosiers on the Hill
It is always great to spend time meeting with Hoosiers from northeast Indiana who are visiting Washington. Hearing directly from you helps me better represent our region in Congress. Here are some recent highlights: 
￼
 
 
Indiana Chamber of Commerce
Thanks to the Indiana Chamber of Commerce for coming out in full force last week. I appreciate you all taking the time to talk about issues important to the Hoosier economy during your DC fly-in.  
￼
 
 
Michael “Shooter” Shutt 
Northeast Indiana’s Michael “Shooter” Shutt (USAF), his wife Doris, and three children stopped by my office for a Capitol tour. The family is currently stationed at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland and I am grateful for their service to our great country. 
￼
 
 
Indiana Bankers Association
Senator Todd Young, Rep. Larry Bucshon and I met with members of the Indiana Bankers Association. It was great to have this group of Hoosiers in DC.
In the News
	•	Journal Gazette | Senate OKs Smith Field museum in FAA bill

Subject: A serious matter:
Message:
￼ 
Lindsey – I hope you’ll join me this October in bringing attention to a serious issue that impacts millions of Americans every year. 

This month is Domestic Violence Awareness Month, a recognition that started more than 30 years ago to shine light on the far too widespread problem of both the visible and invisible violence women, men, and children experience. 

• Nearly 1 in 4 women (and 1 in 7 men) experience severe physical violence from an intimate partner in their lifetime. 

• About 1 in 6 women experience sexual violence from an intimate partner. 

• For many, violence begins as early as high school or younger, and can continue throughout life.1

As a doctor, I’ve seen the physical and emotional trauma of domestic violence firsthand. We need to make sure that all survivors get the help they need to rebuild their lives.

If you or someone you know needs help, please call the National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-7233 or visit them online at www.thehotline.org.

￼

The National Domestic Violence Hotline was created after the passage of the Violence Against Women Act in 1994. Since then, the hotline has helped more than 4 million people access the help they need. 

One of my first, and proudest, moments as your Congressman was voting to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act. This reauthorization updated the law for modern needs and expanded its scope to protect more women than ever before. It gives medical professionals and police resources to prevent violence and go after abusers, improves evidence tracking, and helps victims access emergency housing.

But now, the time has come for Congress to do its job once again. Congress must pass another reauthorization to keep these programs going and make improvements.

No woman or family should live in the shadow of fear or abuse. This cannot be about politics – it’s about saving lives and standing with survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault.

Together we can break the cycle of violence.

Please feel free to contact me to share your thoughts and concerns.

Be well,
￼
Ami Bera, M.D.
Member of Congress

P.S. Your thoughtful suggestions always help my office do a better job of serving you. 

What did you think about this email update? 
￼ I liked it. Thank you! 
 ￼Sorry, I thought it could have been better.
 
Other: Not sure / I have a suggestion.

Listening to you is my most important job. Thank you for taking a moment to share your thoughts.




Footnote 1: https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/ipv-factsheet.pdf

Subject: How I’m working for you
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
News from Congresswoman Rosen
￼
Dear Friend, 
This past week, I joined our community in Las Vegas honoring the memories of the 58 innocent lives that we tragically lost on 1 October and paid my respects.  I also visited with health professionals in Henderson about my efforts to protect Nevadas’ access to quality, affordable health care.
HONORING THE MEMORIES OF THOSE WE LOST ONE YEAR AGO ON 1 OCTOBER 
￼
￼
Last Friday, I spoke on the House floor in honor of the 58 innocent lives that were taken from us on 1 October. I’m forever grateful to our first responders, medical professionals, hotel security and staff, and to the kindness of strangers who helped the wounded to the hospital and stood in line for hours to donate blood.
￼ 
I also spent time in Las Vegas paying my respects to the 1 October victims and heroes who risked their lives for others.
As we continue to heal, what we have always known about our community remains true: we are Vegas Strong. We are resilient, and even in our darkest hour, we came together stronger than ever. 
Read my full House floor speech here. 
WORKING TO INCREASE CONSUMERS PROTECTIONS AND LOWER PRESCRIPTION DRUG COSTS 
This week, the House has passed two bipartisan bills I co-sponsored to increase consumer protections so that Nevadans can better afford their prescription drugs. The Patient Right to Know Drug Prices Act (S. 2554) would guarantee that health insurance issuers and group health plans do not prohibit pharmacy providers from providing certain information to enrollees. The Know the Lowest Price Act of 2018 (S. 2553) would ban gag clauses that prohibit pharmacies from disclosing to consumers that they can, in certain cases, save money by paying out-of-pocket rather than with Medicare or Medicare Advantage. I am a proud co-sponsor of identical companion legislation to these two Senate bills, which passed the House last week. These bills will now go to the President to be signed into law.
No Nevadan should have to worry about affording prescription medications or going back to a time when insurance companies could charge you more based on a pre-existing medical condition. My visit with patients and health care workers at Touro underscored again how important this fight for quality, affordable health care is for hardworking Nevada families. I’m hopeful that these bipartisan bills will be small solutions that increase transparency and enable Nevadans to better afford their life-saving medications. I’ll continue to support efforts to reduce the cost of medications and work to pass my bill to cap prescription drug costs. 
￼
You can read more about these bipartisan prescription drug bills here and read about my visit to Touro Health Center here. 
I WANT TO HEAR FROM YOU 
As always, I want to hear from you. Call my office; find me on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram; or email me. Sign up for my e-newsletter here to receive regular updates on my legislative work. 
It’s an absolute honor to represent you in Congress. 
Sincerely, ￼  Jacky Rosen Member of Congress

Subject: September Seven - A Month in Photos
Message:
News from Representative Noem

Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼
September is always a busy time of year – harvest is in full swing, the school year is off and running, football season begins, and fall is in the air! 
I had a busy month in DC too, so I wanted to share just a few highlights.
1. Honoring Veterans – 50+ of South Dakota’s bravest traveled to Washington with the Honor Flight program. It’s so important we show gratitude to our veterans – in doing so we inspire the next generation to serve by showing them sacrifice doesn’t go unnoticed.
￼ 
2. Locking in the New Tax Code – Tax Reform 2.0 PASSED the House! The tax cuts we passed last year have made a big difference for many South Dakotans, but we’re not stopping there. This package locks in family savings, incentivizes innovation, and gives you more opportunities to save. Learn more HERE or by clicking the video below.  
￼
3. Impacting Education – Impact Aid helps ensure we maintain a level playing field for all SD school districts. It’s been my privilege to work with these folks over the years, so being named a friend of their association meant the world to me. Curious about Impact Aid? Check this out. 
￼ 
4. Announcing Angels in Adoption – It was an honor to name Danny and Amanda Oaks of Rapid City as Angels in Adoption. Their story is such an inspiration on how to make a difference right in your community. Read about their journey here.  
￼ 
5. Pushing for Year-Round E15 – It’s long past time the government allows year-round E15, and I pushed the EPA to approve it. By expanding ethanol, we have a big opportunity to help farmers and our ag economy, save consumers money, and reduce our reliance on foreign oil. Thank you to the folks at Growth Energy for recognizing my work to expand ethanol markets.  
￼ 
6. Celebrating Women in Business - Over 80 percent of South Dakota women are in the workforce, so American Business Women’s Day is a big reason to celebrate! Click HERE to read more about my work to improve the lives of women in the marketplace. 
￼ 
7. And finally… We celebrated National Daughter Day! My kids are rockstars, so they make days like this easy to celebrate. Enjoy this throwback picture! 
￼ 
Have a great day! 
-Kristi

Subject: Thune-Led Federal Aviation Administration Bill Includes Multiple Wins for South Dakota
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼



October 04, 2018




Thune-Led Federal Aviation Administration Bill Includes Multiple Wins for South Dakota
 
￼
Click here or on the image above to watch the video.
 
Sen. Thune, chairman of Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, which has jurisdiction over the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), this week praised the bipartisan passage of the five-year FAA reauthorization bill. This Thune-led legislation, the longest reauthorization since the 1980s, would reauthorize federal aviation programs to modernize airport infrastructure, improve service for the flying public, enhance safety, and boost aviation industry innovation. The bill was approved by a vote of 93-6 and now heads to the president for his signature.
 
“In creating new protections and enhancements for the flying public, this bill creates five years of stable policy direction for the aviation community,” said Thune. “Travelers, utilizing small and large airports, will benefit from investments in infrastructure, more efficient security screening, and the prompt return of fees for services they don’t receive. Innovators also get a needed boost from provisions enhancing the competitiveness of our aircraft manufacturers and the continued integration of unmanned aircraft into our airspace.”
 
For the full press release and a list of how this FAA bill will affect South Dakota, click here.
To keep up to date with Thune's activities in the Senate, click here.

Subject: Congresswoman Beatty Recognizes the Importance of Breast Cancer Awareness Month
Message:
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
Congresswoman Beatty Recognizes the Importance of Breast Cancer Awareness Month
October is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, a month-long initiative aimed at increasing awareness around breast cancer prevention, detection, and treatment. As a strong supporter of women’s health and member of the Democratic Women’s Working Group, U.S. Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (OH-03) issued the following statement:
“Did you know an astounding one in eight American women will develop breast cancer over the course of their lifetime? It is important to know that detecting and treating breast cancer early on can be done by taking immediate action, including getting regular mammograms if you are over 50-years old, talking with your doctor, and conducting self-examinations. Ultimately, however, the universal goal is to find a cure and prevent breast cancer altogether. To that end, I am fighting hard in Congress to increase funding for federal agencies like the National Institutes of Health and the National Cancer Institute—as well as non-governmental organizations committed to finding a cure.”
￼

Congresswoman Beatty encourages Central Ohio to #GoPink during National Breast Cancer Awareness Month (October 3, 2018).
During National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, please visit Congresswoman Beatty’s Facebook and Twitter for useful information, facts, and resources. Be sure to join the conversation online, and share your own story, by using: #BreastCancerAwarenessMonth, #BCAM, #BCAM2018, and #FindTheCure.  For more information on National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, please visit the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s website.

Subject: Agriculture update - New trade deals!
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼

                  AGRICULTURE Update - August/September 2018   TOP STORY  Trade is important to producers and consumers in Montana and across our country. Tens of millions of Americans are employed at small businesses that engage in trade and it is critical for Montana agriculture as well. For example, roughly 80% of Montana’s wheat is exported. Overall, this is not surprising considering that 95% of the world's population is outside of the United States.  That’s why I applauded President Trump, after extensive renegotiations, for recently reaching an agreement to modernize and improve trade with both Mexico and Canada. This agreement is a positive step and will help provide certainty for our farmers, ranchers, and businesses. Among other things, it will also help level the playing field for Montana grain growers by ending Canada’s unfair grain grading system that discriminated against Montana wheat. Moving forward, I will continue to review the deal and work with the President to ensure Montanans have the right opportunities to succeed.  TRADE HIGHLIGHTS  I also applaud the Trump Administration for moving forward with trade talks with Japan. I recently pressed both the Chief Agricultural Negotiator for the U.S. Trade Representative and the U.S. Department of Agriculture in a Senate Ag hearing to engage Japan and other important markets in the Asia Pacific. Like our North America partners, reducing trade barriers in these countries will greatly benefit Montana farmers and ranchers.  FARM BILL UPDATE AND WHAT'S AHEAD
￼
Meeting with Montana Farm Bureau President
Hans McPherson
As you may know, Farm Bill negotiations between the Senate and the House have been ongoing for the past several months. While the Farm Bill did expire, the vast majority of farm programs will be maintained through the crop year. I will continue to work to get a strong Farm Bill to Montana on the President’s desk as quickly as possible.
As new trade deals and promising talks unfold, the Trump Administration has developed an aid package for U.S. farmers and ranchers impacted by retaliatory tariffs imposed by other countries. Visit farmers.gov to find more information about the program and whether you’re eligible.

Subject: Mental Health Counselors in Every K-12 Public School in America
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
￼

A Note from Jeff on Brett Kavanaugh’s Confirmation Process 
I feel strongly and passionately that Judge Kavanaugh is the wrong person for this job, and understand that others feel strongly the other way. But everyone should be unified that sexual assault is intolerable, and that survivors should be respected and treated with dignity. I have heard from so many women over the last two weeks whose wounds have been reopened by these events and the hearing. I hope all of us, regardless of politics, can work to give care and support to those who have been traumatized and to work towards a society where sexual violence is far less common than it is today.  

Protecting Our Communities from Wildfire and Smoke 
In August, Jeff drove around Southern Oregon under a neon pink sphere glowing through a gray film. The mountain ranges were invisible. The air was barely breathable.   Smoke from massive wildfires had transformed Southern Oregon’s big, blue skies and fresh country air into a heavy, toxic fog.   This cannot become the new normal. That’s why Jeff has used his seat on the Senate Appropriations Committee to address short-term fixes—like training and deploying Oregon National Guard members to fight fires—and long-term fixes—like ending fire borrowing and funding successful forest management programs.   But we can’t stop there. So Jeff introduced the Wildfire-Resilient Communities Act—bold new legislation to substantially reduce the risk of catastrophic wildfires, while also creating jobs and opportunities in timber communities.   Jeff knows how desperate Oregonians are to find a real solution to the longer, more intense wildfire season. He will use every tool available to him to help address this urgent issue. 

New Legislation to Put Mental Health Counselors in Every K-12 Public School in America 
Marking National Suicide Prevention Week, Jeff announced the introduction of the Elementary and Secondary School Counseling Act, new bicameral legislation to put school-based mental health services providers in every elementary and secondary school in America. Mental health care is essential health care. But right now in our schools, we’re treating it like an optional afterthought. That’s unacceptable, and it puts our students’ lives and academic futures at risk.   Currently the national average student-to-counselor ratio is nearly twice the recommendation. The Elementary and Secondary School Counseling Act would tackle this crisis head-on by finally providing the necessary resources for schools to provide the mental health counselors their students need and rely on—making a big difference to our students, in Oregon and across the nation. 

New Legislation to Extend Electric Vehicle Tax Credit for 10 Years 
It’s crazy that we might allow the electric vehicle tax credit to run out just as the American EV market is starting to gain a foothold. Every day, we see the effects of climate chaos all around us—record-setting droughts, out-of-control wildfires, destructive mega-storms, and spreading insects and ocean acidification. Market-based incentives that help EVs compete with gas-powered cars are not only good for our economy, they’re essential to our future.   Currently, a federal tax credit of up to $7,500 is available for the purchase of electric vehicles. However, federal statute caps the number of vehicles eligible for the tax credit at 200,000 for each manufacturer. With many American manufacturers expected to hit this cap as early as this year, federal action is needed to ensure that American EV makers stay competitive and we don’t smother this critical technology in the cradle, as fossil fuel giants want to do. Jeff and Senators Martin Heinrich and Catherine Cortez Masto are tackling this problem with the introduction of the Electric Cars Act of 2018, legislation to extend the electric vehicle tax credit for 10 years and lift the manufacturer cap.   The Electric Cars Act stands up for our American manufacturers and invests in the clean energy future we need. 

Thank you!  
Thank you for reading -- and don't forget, you can see the latest updates by liking Jeff on Facebook and following Jeff on Twitter, and Instagram. And be sure to check Merkley.senate.gov for more information on current events. 
￼ 
￼

Subject: The Huizenga Huddle: October 4, 2018
Message:
The Huizenga Huddle
October 4, 2018
Share this email:
￼
￼
￼
￼
The Huizenga Huddle: October 4, 2018
Tax Reform 2.0  Last week, the House passed and I strongly supported the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act. This legislation, also known as Tax Reform 2.0, made tax cuts permanent for middle class families and hardworking small business entrepreneurs across West Michigan. 
￼
An independent analysis by the Tax Foundation found that this tax reform package will create an additional 1.5 million jobs, increase GDP by 2.2% and boost wage growth. By making these important tax cuts permanent, we can chart a course of economic prosperity that lowers taxes and promotes small business growth and job creation in communities across West Michigan for generations to come.  How Tax Reform 2.0 Impacts West Michigan 
In addition to permanently doubling the child tax credit and lowering tax rates for middle class families, this legislation builds on the preservation of the adoption tax credit by creating a new opportunity to help pay for the costs associated with welcoming a child into a home. It also expands education savings opportunities for families across West Michigan while also creating a new flex account to meet their individual needs.

￼

Here are three examples of how West Michigan families will benefit from Tax Reform 2.o:

USA accounts. Creating a new Universal Savings Account (USA) to offer a fully
flexible savings tool that families can use any time that’s right for them.

Expanded 529 Education accounts. Building upon the improvements to education
savings accounts in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act by providing families with the
flexibility to also use their education savings to pay for apprenticeship fees to learn a
trade, cover the cost of home schooling, and help pay off student debt.

New Baby savings. Allowing families to access their own retirement accounts on a
penalty-free basis to use as they see fit when welcoming a new child into the family,
whether by birth or adoption. Families also have the ability to replenish these retirement
accounts in the future.


Ripped From The Headlines: Tax Reform Is Delivering 

Since passage of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act last December, our economy is growing at an impressive pace, wages are rising, and good-paying jobs are being created.  Here is a quick look at some of the headlines from across the nation talking about the economy. 

	•	CNBC: Small business optimism surges, topping previous record under Reagan
	•	Marketwatch: American manufacturers growing at fastest pace in 14 years, ISM finds
	•	Fox Business: US workers see biggest pay, benefit increase in 10 years
	•	Wall Street Journal: U.S. jobless claims fall to 49-year low for third straight week
	•	Bloomberg: U.S. Consumer Confidence Unexpectedly Jumps to 18-Year High
The Great Lakes 

There has been big news on the Great Lakes over the last few weeks. A new report published by the Great Lakes Commission found that on average, for every dollar invested by the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI) $3.35 of economic activity will be generated. This is major news. 

￼

I have successfully led multiple bipartisan efforts to fully fund the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative. We have seen the positive impact this program has had on Muskegon, Holland, and communities across West Michigan. A healthy Great Lakes ecosystem generates more tourism, more economic opportunity, and more Made in Michigan memories. This latest study was evaluated by economists at the University of Michigan and provides critical evidence that restoring the ecological health of the Great Lakes and preventing invasive species from entering the lakes will strengthen our economy and help future generations enjoy these incredible resources. 

￼

In August, I was honored to be recognized by The Nature Conservancy in Michigan for my bipartisan efforts to protect the Great Lakes, fully fund the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI), and combat the spread of invasive species. Thank you to the Nature Conservancy for being an active part of the effort to preserve the Great Lakes and stop Asian carp!

￼

On September 17th, I visited the Outdoor Discovery Center to see the impact of the GLRI first-hand. This particular project is helping restore wetlands, reduce flooding, and stop harmful runoff from flowing into rivers, Lake Macatawa, and even Lake Michigan.

￼

There was also major news in Washington regarding Great Lakes infrastructure. When I began the bipartisan effort to restore the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund, only 47% of the funding designated for harbor maintenance was actually used for that purpose. Under the bipartisan action signed into law in September, 92% of the funds collected in the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund will actually be used for dredging and harbor maintenance. 

Specifically, this year’s appropriation includes maintenance funding for Grand Haven Harbor, Holland Harbor, and Ludington Harbor. Having our harbors along the Great Lakes properly dredged is vital to economic growth and job creation in West Michigan. With the enactment of this legislation, we take a very positive step toward fully funding this objective. 

Honoring Those Who Have Served

Our veterans put their lives on the line for this nation and we have a responsibility to make sure they have the best care available. On September 13th, I proudly supported bipartisan legislation that strengthens oversight and accountability at the VA while prioritizing resources for the MISSION Act, mental health care services, suicide prevention, opioid abuse prevention, and rural health care. 

￼

Additionally, this much needed legislation also provides additional resources and reforms to help eliminate the claims processing backlog and improve results for veterans in West Michigan and across the nation.  While there is much more work to be done to improve the VA and the care our veterans receive, this legislation was another step in the right direction.

￼

In August, I had the honor of presenting Keith Cole and Al Johnson each with a Congressional Gold Medal for their service to the nation as members of the Office of Strategic Service (OSS). The OSS was established during World War II and is considered the foundation of modern day intelligence operations.  

Hearing both Keith and Al share their stories seemed more like something out of a Jack Ryan novel, or perhaps a video game, or television show than what you might expect from two veterans from Hudsonville. Both Keith and Al are unsung heroes who served our country with distinction. 

Since the ceremony in August took place, I recently learned that Mr. Cole, picture above in the hat, passed away. My heart goes out to Keith's family whom I had gotten to know over these past few months. Keith was a wonderful person, who served his country with distinction. Every day we lose more of the men and women who answered the call and sacrificed so we could be free. If you see a veteran, be sure to say thank you. 

Across West Michigan

￼

At the end of August, Lake County was hit by severe storms that included two confirmed tornadoes touching down. On September 1st, I traveled to Baldwin to see the damage first-hand, get an update from emergency personnel and speak with residents. Thank you to the first responders, volunteers, and members of the surrounding communities for helping our neighbors through this difficult time. We are so thankful that there were no lives lost from the storm. 

￼

About mid-September, I had the opportunity to visit Ottawa Area Intermediate School District’s Career Line Tech Center to discuss and observe the hands-on learning and training students receive. Whether students are learning a trade or a vocational skill, the Career Tech Center provides greater flexibility and a unique opportunity for students to be job-ready coming right out of high school or shortly there after. It was a great day speaking with instructors and students!

￼

Last month I also toured Quality Tool and Stamping in Muskegon Heights. It's wonderful to see investment, job creation, and manufacturing come back strong across Muskegon County. The highly skilled manufacturing that is done at Quality Tool and Stamping was impressive.  

￼

On September 18th, I joined a packed house at the Wyoming Kentwood Chamber for a legislative update on improving and funding the VA, rebuilding infrastructure across the Great Lakes, and reforming Dodd-Frank in a bipartisan manner. Additionally, I discussed how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is delivering positive results for small businesses, middle class families, and hardworking individuals across West Michigan.

￼
On September 20th, joined members of the Ottawa County Farm Bureau in Allendale to discuss the Farm Bill, immigration, Great Lakes infrastructure, and the economy. During the event I was honored to receive the “Friend of Farm Bureau” award for my record of supporting policies that empower West Michigan farmers.
￼
On Saturday, I joined community leaders in Holland to celebrate the reopening of the Civic Center. This iconic building means so much to the community and with these upgrades,  a new generation of West Michigan residents will be able to enjoy all that it has to offer!   The Michigan Minute 
	•	Huizenga Recognized as “Guardian of Small Business” by NFIB
	•	VP Pence talks tax cuts in West Michigan, calls Mill Steel 'an American success story'
	•	Huizenga, Michigan Republicans: Tax reform is delivering for Michigan 
	•	YUM! Hudsonville Ice Cream to invest, create jobs, open tasting room in Holland 
	•	Rich DeVos: Thank you for your leadership, dedication, and service to West Michigan
	•	Huizenga one of only 66 named Friend of Taxpayer by National Taxpayers' Union
	•	Remembering 9/11, Meeting with West Michigan Firefighters in Walker
	•	Congratulations Michelle! Kent County appoints first female sheriff
	•	Corps of Engineers' Grand Haven chief to retire after 40 years
	•	Growth & opportunity are on Kentwood's horizon with $6.5M industrial expansion
	•	Medical manufacturer's $3.5M expansion to add 43 jobs in Kent County
	•	Arconic plans $100M Whitehall expansion, to add 45 jobs
	•	80 new jobs coming to Fruitport after company announces $3.7 million investment 
	•	Huizenga: 3% annual growth is within striking distance

Subject: Opioid Legislation Passes Senate With Comstock Provisions
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
The Comstock Connection
News From The Office Of Congresswoman Barbara Comstock
￼ 
Our District
Biography
Media Center
Services
Contact Me

Opioid Legislation Passes Senate With Comstock Provisions
Washington, D.C. - Congresswoman Barbara Comstock (R-VA) released the following statement after H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, legislation to address our nation’s heroin and opioid crisis, passed the Senate. 
“Today Congress has taken a bipartisan, commonsense step in addressing our nation’s heroin and opioid crisis by overwhelmingly passing H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act. This legislation will make a tangible and immediate difference in the lives of those battling addiction, the families supporting loved ones struggling with substance use disorder, and healthcare treatment providers helping the sick get well. I am pleased that Congress has finally recognized that the deadly epidemic of opioid addiction requires a multipronged approach drawing on the resources of our entire community, including the need to develop non-addictive treatment alternatives.  
“I am pleased that provisions of my bill to facilitate better clinical data and standards on non-opioid alternatives, H.R. 5473, the Better Pain Management Through Better Data Act, were included in the final legislation.  Medical use of opioids should be a decision that is made with care and these provisions will better inform the choices made by patients and physicians who need accessible data when considering treatments. Addiction is a disease.  As our friend and recovery advocate, Nick Yacoub says, this is about sick people getting well.   With more prescribing options and fewer prescribed opioids, we can lower the risk of addiction. I’m pleased that the President will be signing this legislation into law, ensuring help for our communities battling this crisis.”

Subject: BREAKING: Tester's Bill to Protect Yellowstone's Doorstep Clears Senate Committee
Message:
￼
 
￼
 
Tester's Bill to Protect Yellowstone's Doorstep Clears Senate Committee
Senator's bill will preserve Yellowstone gateway and Paradise Valley's outdoor recreation economy
￼
 
(U.S. Senate) - U.S. Senator Jon Tester's bill to permanently protect Montana's iconic Paradise Valley from hardrock gold mining cleared a major hurdle Tuesday.  The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee passed Tester's Yellowstone Gateway Protection Act permanently withdrawing mineral rights on 30,000 acres of federal public land north of Yellowstone National Park. The bill passed on a unanimous vote.   "Some places are more precious than gold," said Tester, the only Senator in the delegation to sponsor the bill. "My bill will ensure outdoor recreation businesses can continue to thrive in the region, and will protect one of our nation's greatest treasures for generations to come."  The Yellowstone Gateway Protection Act preserves land on the Custer Gallatin National Forest adjacent to the Absaroka Beartooth Wilderness, and eliminates the ability for proposed mines to expand onto unclaimed public land.   Tester's bill is supported by dozens of groups and businesses in the Yellowstone region that rely on the area for their business. Yellowstone National Park visitors spent an average of $196 million in Park County in 2014 that helped create and sustain nearly 3,000 jobs.  Tester testified before the committee on behalf of his bill last July, and has been fighting to protect the Yellowstone Gateway for the past three years.  Last week, the House Natural Resources Committee passed companion legislation on a 28-4 vote.

Subject: a note on bipartisanship
Message:
￼
These days, I know things in Washington often seem like one big partisan fight with both sides more and more dug in to their trenches. But in my time in the Senate, I've seen one thing to be true time and time again: good things happen when we put our differences aside and work together. 




I've seen the D.C. dysfunction you might've heard of firsthand -- but I've never been one to succumb to the chaos.   That's not why I'm here -- I'm here in Washington to get down to business, solve tough problems, and make sure Missourians are heard. 
I know the harder job than pointing fingers is reaching across the aisle, putting aside our differences, and finding what we can agree on. And I know *that* is how we get things done.  From pushing for healthcare transparency to stopping surprise medical bills to funding opioid initiatives in our state, bipartisanship and common sense keep the legislative wheels turning. So I'm proud to often find myself squarely in the middle of things, working with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle who feel the same way.
I know that at the end of the day, what matters most is this: saving Missourians money on their prescriptions, preventing fraud and abuse of taxpayer dollars, and creating a healthcare system that works for everyone. And when both parties come together and do the hard work of compromise, these are things we can achieve. 
If you know me, you know I don't hesitate to fight if it means delivering results for the folks in our state. I know that's why I'm here -- to represent Missourians. Fighting unfair practices and making healthcare affordable shouldn't be partisan issues, and I'll continue to make sure that's the case. And I'll be right where I've always been, smack dab in the middle -- where we get real results for Missouri.

￼
Senator Claire McCaskill
Visit my website: 
www.mccaskill.senate.gov

Subject: September in Photos

￼

￼
 September in Photos 
Fall is here, and that means our fields are just about ready for harvest. While my colleagues and I spent much of September negotiating the 2018 Farm Bill, we passed legislation to grow our economy, care for our veterans, and fulfill our commitment to rebuild our military. 
Here are five photos that show some of my favorite moments from the month of September: 
1. Farm Bill Focused – During the month of September, the Farm Bill conference committee held a public hearing where conference committee members could outline their priorities. While we are still working to gain consensus on the final version, I remain committed and focused on delivering a strong Farm Bill that supports our producers.
￼ 
2. King Crop – Cotton is king in West Texas, and there is no better way to celebrate cotton and what it means to our region than with Texas Tech football. It’s been a blast watching our Red Raiders play this year, especially so against Houston during the Celebrate Cotton Game. Wreck ‘em!  
￼ 
3. Veteran Employment – Too often our veterans are not served and cared for in a timely manner when returning home from service in the military. I was fortunate enough to join a few in the veteran employment industry for a panel at the Texas Tribune Festival to discuss how we can better assist our veterans in their transition from deployment to employment.  
￼ 
4. Freedom Fighting – The 317th Air Lift Wing, led by Col. Jeffrey Menasco, contributes not only to our national security, but also to our region’s economic prosperity. The good people of West Texas, myself included, are grateful to have both Col. Menasco’s leadership and our freedom fighters at Dyess sacrificing daily for the safety and security of the United States.
￼ 
5. American Unity – On the 17th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, I reflected on my experience in the White House when the attack occurred. Out of all that I will remember from that fateful day, one thing remains: Americans stand united, regardless of our differences. As we remember 9/11, we would do well to remember the late John McCain’s words: ‘we are Americans first, we are Americans last, and we are Americans always.’” Read here as I recalled my experience with Roll Call. 
￼

Subject: Jobs Fair this THURSDAY in Philly >>>
Message:
News from Representative Evans
￼

Home
Contact
Services
Media
 
Philadelphia Job and Resource Fair
Hello Friends, 
This Thursday, October 4th, there will be a Philadelphia job & resource fair at the Pennsylvania Convention Center. At the Philadelphia job & resource fair, you'll get the opportunity to create your resume on-site, complete a job application, practice your interview skills with experts, and so much more!
I've been told participants will get connected to much-needed resources, such as information about job training programs.  
If we want to tackle our city's staggering 26 percent poverty rate, the federal minimum wage -- $7.25/hour -- needs to change, residents must be equipped with more in-demand skills and companies need to continue hiring individuals from the community.  
Although poverty won't diminish overnight, the jobs fair in Philadelphia is just one of the many tools in our toolbox that will help to lift people out of poverty throughout the city. 
To register for the fair, click on the link and share it amongst your family & friends!                                         
Prison Re-Entry Summit
On Friday, October 5th, I will be participating in the "BEYOND THE WALLS: Reentry Summit and Prison Healthcare, " which will run from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Pennsylvania Convention Center to discuss the need for criminal justice reform on a federal level and how these changes would immensely help communities of color! I'll be speaking during the opening session, which will run from 8:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. 
According to the ACLU of Pennsylvania, our state has the 7th largest prison population in the country and the HIGHEST incarceration rate in the northeast. In addition, nearly 30 percent of the Commonwealth's prisoners have a mental illness and in Philadelphia, African-Americans are currently incarcerated at 5 TIMES the rate of their white counterparts.
These statistics are unacceptable and that is why it is critical we address the problems within our justice system and talk among scholars, activists, and state & local government representatives about the necessary steps to fix our failing justice system. 
Click on this link to learn more.  
Your VOTE is Your Voice!
Tuesday, October 9th is the deadline to register to vote in Pennsylvania or to update your registration due to a change of name or address. Most Pennsylvanians can take care of this quickly and easily online at www.votespa.com. For questions, please call your county voter registration office: Philadelphia, 215-686-1591; or Montgomery County, 610-278-3280.  
  
  
Sincerely, 
￼ 
Dwight Evans

Subject: President Trump is attacking assault survivors
Message:
￼ 
  

Dear Lindsey, 
Last week, Dr. Christine Blasey Ford changed the course of our democracy. 
We watched her speak truth to power. We witnessed her bravery and her pain. And we saw her courageously face down Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee. 
But instead of being applauded for her courage, Dr. Blasey Ford is being attacked. 
I won’t repeat the despicable comments that President Trump made about her last night.  
Let me be clear: we are watching the White House attack survivors of sexual assault. We are paying attention. And we won’t forget this ugly act of cruelty and indifference. 
This is not over - the FBI must follow through on their investigation into Judge Kavanaugh. Women should keep coming forward to tell their stories. And millions of Americans should keep marching, calling, and organizing for justice.
You are what democracy looks like. It’s because of your activism that we are one step closer to stopping this nomination. 
But our work is not done. The Senate could vote as early as this week on Judge Kavanaugh’s confirmation --- long before the American people or the US Senate has time to fully review the FBI’s findings. 
We cannot let them push through this confirmation. I will keep fighting to defeat this dangerous nomination and standing up for sexual assault survivors, and I know that you will too. 
As always, I am here for you. You can reach my East Bay office at (510) 763-0370 or connect with me via email, facebook, twitter, and Instagram. 
In solidarity, 
￼ 
  
P.S. I know this was a difficult week for many of us. If you are a survivor, please know that you are not alone. You can call 800-656-HOPE for confidential help.

Subject: Update
Message:
￼ 

Home
About Ken
About Our District
News
Contact

                                        
Weekly Newsletter  
Dear Friend, 
We had a packed weak of legislating, so I wanted to give you an update on some of the most important items, including a few of my own efforts.  
Free and Fair Aluminum Market 
I introduced legislation this past week to ensure a free and fair aluminum market. By clarifying the statutory authority of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) to conduct oversight over the aluminum market, I'm confident that any pricing irregularities that have been plaguing the market can be successfully uncovered and resolved.  
Reclaiming Congressional Authority over War Powers 
Congress has the responsibility to declare and oversee war-making in this country. That's how the Founding Fathers wanted it. That's what the Constitution demands. Unfortunately, the legislative branch has abdicated its responsibility. I wrote an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal to describe both the problem and the solution: https://www.wsj.com/articles/congress-take-your-war-powers-back-1537831277 
￼
Congress has a Constitutional responsibility to oversee war-making in the United States.
Combatting America's Opioid Epidemic 
The House and Senate have passed a bicameral, bipartisan agreement to combat the opioid crisis in our country. I was thankful to have my legislation, HR 6779, included in the agreement text. Opioid addiction is a serious problem in Colorado, and Congress has a responsibility to the American people to fight for solutions. Visit opioidcrisis.gop to learn more about House Republicans' efforts to fight this epidemic. 
Tax Reform 2.0 
I voted for Tax Reform 2.0, which passed the House of Representatives last week. This legislation makes permanent most of the tax cuts that impact individuals and families. It also helps new businesses, allowing more of their startup costs to be written off. I've heard from so many Coloradans about the benefits of the first tax reform bill, and I'm confident this one will only further help our district. 
Protecting Innocent Life 
Taxpayer dollars should never contribute to the trade of fetal tissue. I joined 84 colleagues this month calling on the Department of Health and Human Services to cancel an FDA contract with Advanced Bioscience Resources, a company that procures human fetal tissue for research. I'm thankful that HHS decided to cancel that contract. 
Keep an eye on my website for more upcoming events. And as always, for more frequent updates on legislation and events, please follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. I look forward to hearing from you; please do not hesitate to contact my Greeley, Castle Rock, or Washington office should you need any assistance. If you'd like to send me a message, you can do so on my website. 
Sincerely,

Subject: A Step Forward in Fighting the Opioid Epidemic
Message:
￼ 
￼
  
Dear Professor  ,
Earlier today, I supported a comprehensive bill to help combat the ongoing opioid epidemic. This crisis has touched every part of our state, where we have lost more than 2,100 Rhode Islanders to accidental drug overdoses since 2010.
Today's important legislation will provide more flexibility and funding for states to offer mental and behavioral health care at psychiatric hospitals and facilities through Medicaid, and it will allow more medical professionals to treat people in recovery to prevent relapses and overdoses. The bill also makes improvements to state prescription drug monitoring programs, and encourages further research and development of opioid alternatives for pain relief.
I also helped craft and pass this year's Labor-HHS-Education appropriations law, which provides over $3.7 billion to fight opioid abuse, including:
	•	$1.9 billion in enhanced state grants to address the opioid epidemic and mental health.
	•	$495 million to improve access to opioid and substance use disorder treatment in rural and underserved areas.
	•	$350 million for opioid overdose surveillance and prevention at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as well as enhancement of State Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs.
	•	$100 million to address the needs of children who are affected by parental substance use.
The opioid epidemic continues to have a devastating impact on our state and nation, and these new funds and authorities dedicate real resources to help fight it. In spite of the current political climate in Congress, know that I am continuing to work hard to promote policies that help keep our communities safe and healthy.
Sincerely,
 
Jack Reed
United States Senator

Subject: My Met Council review was ordered!
Message:
￼ 
  

My Met Council review was ordered!

Dear Lindsey,
For years I have been a strong proponent of bringing Minnesota’s Met Council into federal compliance and, as your Representative, I have worked on numerous initiatives to get this accomplished. 
Recently, the Department of Transportation (DOT) ordered a much-needed official review of the Met Council’s standing, at my request.
CLICK HERE to take my MET COUNCIL SURVEY and feel free to share with friends and neighbors!
Currently, the board is out of compliance by intentionally omitting elected representatives from serving, and this has compromised the transparency and taxpayer accountability of the Met Council. It is the only Metropolitan Planning Organization in the country to exclude elected officials, and yet they have the independent authority to raise taxes on citizens of the seven-county metro area while also having a budget greater than 17 of the top 20 MPOs combined. 
It’s high time the DOT officially reviewed the Met Council’s standing, as it is grossly unacceptable for them to continue acting outside of federal law. 
The Department of Transportation under the Obama Administration even recommended that the Met Council move to have elected officials on their board—yet they still disobeyed. 
It’s great to see the DOT follow through on my request, and I will continue in my efforts to bring the Met Council into compliance. 
Take my MET COUNCIL SURVEY HERE. 
As I work on this and other issues, I always like to hear directly from you.  Please share any thoughts you may have through my website, and sign up for my e-mail newsletter for the latest updates from Washington, D.C. and around the district. You can also stay on top of my work by following my Facebook and Twitter pages. Please feel free to call my Washington, D.C. office at 202-225-2271 or my local Burnsville office at 651-846-2120 with any comments or for assistance with a federal agency.

Sincerely, 
￼
Jason Lewis
Member of Congress

Subject: This may not make headlines
Message:
￼
October 3, 2018
Dear Friend,
These days, it can be frustrating to watch the news about the toxic political climate in Washington. Believe me, I share those same frustrations. With that in mind, I wanted to share some good news with you about my work to protect the places where New Mexicans love to get outdoors. Yesterday, in the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, I was proud to advance several major pieces of legislation I've been working on to grow our outdoor recreation economy, promote access to our public lands, and support sustainable use of New Mexico's land and water for generations to come.
The Every Kid Outdoors Act will allow every fourth-grader in America to visit our nation's parks, forest, wildlife refuges, and public lands free of charge--and bring their families along with them. Connecting kids to the outdoors can inspire a lifelong connection to conservation, while reaping all of the health benefits that go along with an active lifestyle. 
I was also proud to secure a vote out of committee to permanently reauthorize and fully fund the Land and Water Conservation Fund. In New Mexico, LWCF has protected iconic landscapes like the Valles Caldera, Ute Mountain, and Valle de Oro, without costing taxpayers a single cent. It has also provided for community projects like baseball and soccer fields, playgrounds, and picnic areas. This bill will make sure our kids and grandkids will be playing ball, catching fish, and chasing mule deer on our public lands for many years to come.
I've been hard at work forging a compromise between Republicans and Democrats on how to address the maintenance backlog at our national parks. I'm proud we've finally passed a bill out of committee that will help restore and rebuild roads, buildings, campgrounds, trails and water systems in New Mexico's national parks and monuments. National Parks are a major economic driver in New Mexico, drawing millions of visitors and generating over $100 million in economic activity. We must invest in our Park Service infrastructure to ensure our national parks are safe and accessible to the visitors from near and far who pass through their gates each year. 
Finally, I welcomed the passage of two major New Mexico priorities that I've worked on closely with local communities and Senator Tom Udall for the last few years. The Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks Conservation Act would complete the community proposal the region included in the Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks National Monument by designating over 200,000 acres of new wilderness. And the New Mexico Drought Preparedness Act will give communities critical resources and technical assistance to use our limited water supplies more efficiently.   These may not be the type of developments that make headlines. But I want you to know that I remain focused on using my role in the Senate to deliver results on what matters to New Mexico. I hope you and your family are able to get outdoors and enjoy some beautiful fall colors in the places we all own and love. Please stay in touch about this or other issues important to your community. 
Sincerely,
￼
MARTIN HEINRICH United States Senator

Subject: Recipe for Disaster
Message:
October 3, 2018

￼
 
Website
16th District
About Vern
News
Services
Resources
Legislation
Contact
 
￼
After months of suffering from the toxic effects of red tide, the last thing we need is another catastrophic oil spill off the Gulf Coast. Read what I’m doing to protect our coastal waters -- Vern 
￼ 
Buchanan opposes Trump plan to weaken offshore drilling protection in the Gulf  Ryan Callihan   U.S. Rep. Vern Buchanan is once again taking a hard stance against the Trump administration’s plans for offshore drilling.  Buchanan, R-Longboat Key initially fought back against Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke when he drafted a plan to put Gulf water up for lease as offshore drilling locations in January. At the time, Buchanan said it was a “recipe for disaster,” calling for legislation to prevent the move.  Now he’s doubling down with legislation that seeks to keep current oil and gas safety rules in place.  On Monday, Buchanan co-sponsored the Safe COAST Act that was introduced by Rep. Nanette Diaz Barragan, D-California, in January. The bill would codify the Oil and Gas Production Safety Systems and Well Control rules — two sets of guidelines that ensure “protections for worker safety, the environment and coastal environments — into law.  “It would be a monumental mistake to lift these safeguards. The last thing we need after suffering through the devastating impact of red tide is to open the door to another catastrophic oil spill,” Buchanan said.  The Interior Department has gone back and forth over its plan to remove these restrictions, but on Friday the agency announced it would officially lift regulations put in place under the Obama administration. The rollback is set to take effect Dec. 27, if no action overrides it.  Experts say the move unnecessarily places Gulf waters in jeopardy. Miyoko Sakishima, director of the oceans program at the Center for Biological Diversity, said the plan, “isn’t just regulation, it’s willful ignorance.”  Other changes proposed by the Interior Department are: removing the requirement for oil companies to receive independent verification of safety measure used on offshore platforms; getting rid of the requirement that professional engineers certify the safety of the design of offshore drilling equipment; and eliminating the requirement that third-party auditors confirm safety and pollution prevention equipment are functional under extreme conditions.  The department said the rules were “potentially unduly burdensome requirements,” but Buchanan challenged the need to remove these guidelines, citing the oil industry’s recent success and profitability.  “If these safeguards are so burdensome, then why is the oil industry enjoying record profits? The U.S. is currently producing over 11 million barrels of oil per day — a level we have not reached since the 1970s, rivaling the world’s top producers, Russia and Saudi Arabia.
￼

Subject: Celebrating the Integral Role the Latino Community Plays in Shaping Our Nation
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼





Dear Friend,  Every year, from September 15th to October 15th, we come together to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month and honor the integral role the Latino community has and continues to play in shaping our great nation.  From enriching our communities through civic engagement and participation at every level of government, to the countless cultural contributions through literature and the arts, to fostering our economic growth, the Latino community has had a profound impact on Ventura County.  As we celebrate this month, we also recognize that America is made stronger because of our diversity. The hard work, skills, and talent that Latinos bring to our economy has been vital to the success and growth of our community -- and our country as a whole. That is why I will continue to focus on the policies that invest in all of our working families and ensure everyone has a fair shot at the American Dream, including strengthening our K-12 education system, making higher education more affordable, protecting our environment, and increasing access to quality healthcare.  As your representative in Congress, you can count on me to protect the rights of the more than 57 million Latinos throughout the United States and continue to foster, invest in, and highlight their contributions to the social and economic fabric of our country.  Thank you, and Happy Hispanic Heritage Month!  Sincerely,
￼
JULIA BROWNLEY Member of Congress  P.S. Your suggestions help me do a better job of serving you. Did you find this email informative? [Yes] [No] [Other]

Subject: SIGNED! United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
  
￼ 

 Home | Newsroom | Helping Iowans | Contact 

Good morning – 
I am so excited to let you all know that after intense negotiations, the United States, Mexico and Canada have reached a new trade agreement! The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) modernizes the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) by rebalancing how goods and services are exchanged to better serve the interests of American workers, farmers and businesses.
President Trump is making good on his promise to get deals done that will boost confidence, provide certainty and unleash optimism across farm country in Iowa and the rest of the U.S. From this deal, farmers will see increased market access and updated regulatory standards that will strengthen trade and foster a more fair trade environment.  

 Why is the USMCA good for Iowa?  
	•	Food and agriculture will trade more fairly, including dairy and wheat: Canada will eliminate its “Class 7” program that allows low-priced dairy ingredients to undersell U.S. dairy products in both Canada and other developing countries. Canada also will provide equal treatment when assessing the quality of imported wheat.
	•	U.S. farmers will have new access to Canadian agriculture markets: Canada will provide important new access for the full range of United States dairy products, eggs and poultry.
	•	New standards will strengthen ag trade: The new agreement sets unprecedented standards for agricultural biotechnology, establishes commitments to reduce trade-distorting policies and enhances rules for science-based sanitary and phytosanitary measures.

Fighting for our Farmers . . . 
 ￼ 
Ernst Joins CBS This Morning to Discuss USMCA 
￼ 
Sen. Ernst meets with producers to talk trade, tariffs, other concerns 
￼ 
Editorial: Ernst correct on views 

For more updates on what's happening in Washington, D.C. and Iowa, be sure to 'Like' my Facebook page, follow me on Twitter @SenJoniErnst, and subscribe to my YouTube channel. 
Thank you!

Subject: Agreement paves way for Enbridge to permanently shut down, replace Line 5 beneath the Straits of Mackinac
Message:
￼

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE:  Oct 3, 2018
 


Agreement paves way for Enbridge to permanently shut down, replace Line 5 beneath the Straits of Mackinac

Accord between the state and company requires Enbridge to pay all costs for a multi-use tunnel beneath the Straits, compels safety improvements on other water crossings
The state of Michigan and Enbridge Energy today announced an agreement that will lead to major safety enhancements along the entire length of the Line 5 petroleum pipeline crossing the state, permanently shut down the current segment that crosses the Straits of Mackinac, and construct a multi-use utility tunnel beneath the Straits. All costs for the tunnel will be paid by Enbridge.
Under the agreement signed today, Enbridge would pay for all design, construction, operation and maintenance of the tunnel for up to 99 years, subject to approvals by the Mackinac Bridge Authority. Tunnel construction is estimated to cost between $350 million to $500 million over the 7- to 10-year duration of the project. This major infrastructure initiative for northern Michigan, which would be owned by the Mackinac Bridge Authority and in which Enbridge would lease space, also could house additional infrastructure, such as broadband and electrical lines.    “Since taking office 20 months ago, I’ve worked closely with Gov. Snyder to ensure our Straits remain safe while maintaining the flow of pipeline commerce,” said U.S. Rep. Jack Bergman. “The proposed tunnel is a forward-thinking, innovative approach ensuring safety and continued economic stability. Michigan’s First District is long overdue to benefit financially from the continuous flow of products transiting our area. I will work tirelessly to ensure that the economic advantages from our energy infrastructure directly benefit the constituents of the First District.”
“This common-sense solution offers the greatest possible safeguards to Michigan’s waters while maintaining critical connections to ensure Michigan residents have the energy resources they need,” said Gov. Rick Snyder. “The historic agreement will result in eliminating nearly every risk of an oil leak in the Straits and provide added protections to the Great Lakes. It also will allow for multiple utilities to be housed and protected, better connecting our peninsulas, improving energy security and supporting economic development. The taxpayers of Michigan will benefit greatly from this project but won’t have to pay for it.” 
The new accord, which builds on a November 2017 agreement between the state and Enbridge, also demands specific actions at sensitive Line 5 water crossings other than the Straits, expanding protections along the length of the pipeline in Michigan.
“Pipeline safety has always been a top priority for me,” said U.S. Rep. Fred Upton, chair of the House Subcommittee on Energy. “I led the bipartisan effort on two major pipeline safety and accountability bills in the last several years. Getting Enbridge to pay for 100 percent of the Line 5 replacement tunnel is the right approach and one I’ve sought since day one. I want to thank the State of Michigan, and Governor Snyder, for their clear-headed leadership on this issue. This agreement needs to get done as quickly as possible for the protection of our Great Lakes.”
Assessments to date of the Line 5 Straits crossing confirm the pipeline’s integrity. However, the agreement will demand additional measures to reduce risk during tunnel construction. Those safety measures will:
* Assure the Straits pipeline is not operating when high waves would severely hamper response to a potential oil spill. The agreement requires that Enbridge staff be present at the Straits to be able to shut down the line within 15 minutes – even if power is lost – when wave heights hit 6.5 feet for at least an hour. Enbridge must continue to shut down the Straits pipeline when wave heights hit 8 feet for at least an hour. 
* Provide a new radar system to supply improved, real-time wave-height data at the Strait
* Assure at least $1.8 billion in available funds be provided by Enbridge to respond to a potential oil spill in the Straits or anywhere on Line 5 in Michigan, providing added protections as tunnel construction is completed. 
* Provide consistent state supervision of Line 5 through regular meetings between Enbridge and the state. 
* Install cameras in the Straits, paid for by Enbridge, to support new regulations from the U.S. Coast Guard prohibiting ships in the area from dropping their anchors. This has been identified as one of the most serious threats to Line 5 and other utility lines on the bottom of the Straits. The cameras will allow the Coast Guard to monitor vessels entering the waterways and immediately communicate with those that are operating dangerously.
The new agreement would also:
* Require immediate additional safety measures at 13 priority Line 5 water crossings, in addition to requiring actions at 68 other crossings as identified in a previous report. 
* Prohibit heavy crude oil from ever traveling through Line 5. 
A previous report conducted by Enbridge and overseen by the state identified a tunnel beneath the Straits as a feasible replacement alternative to the existing Line 5 Straits crossing.
In compliance with the 2017 agreement, Enbridge has already applied for authorizations and approvals to replace the Line 5 crossing at the St. Clair River, a key water body that provides drinking water to a large population in southeast Michigan. That work will begin upon the receipt of those authorizations and approvals. 
Line 5 is 645 miles long and transports up to 540,000 barrels a day of light crude oil and natural gas liquids, including propane. Below the Straits of Mackinac, the pipeline splits into two lines that lie on the lake bottom within an easement issued by the state of Michigan. A new pipeline in the tunnel would not increase volumes or alter the types of products transported through the existing Line 5.  

bergman.house.gov  
###

Subject: Sign up for the Congressional App Challenge!
Message:
￼  ￼  ￼  ￼  ￼ 
￼ 
HOME  |   ABOUT SUZAN  |   HOW CAN I HELP?  |   NEWSROOM  |   ISSUES  |   CONTACT 
 
Dear Friend,

Before becoming a Member of Congress, technology shaped my career. That’s why I’m thrilled to be the Co-Chair of the 2018 Congressional App Challenge. This national competition enables middle and high school students in each congressional district to use their coding skills to cultivate an entrepreneurial spirit. 

Students can sign up for the Congressional App Challenge as individuals or in groups of up to four. The winners are publicly recognized and invited to Washington, D.C. to show their app at the #HouseofCode reception in the Spring. Interested students can click here to register. 

I am also excited to host my annual Congressional App Challenge “Appathon” on October 13th and 14th at UW Bothell. This event will give students a jumpstart in creating their apps and an opportunity to collaborate in a team environment while working with industry professionals. At the end of the challenge, students will get the chance to pitch their ideas to judges and win prizes! Interested students can sign up for the “Appathon” here. 

As always, my office is here to serve you. If you have questions or comments about the topics that matter most to you, I encourage you to contact me through my website. You may also keep up-to-date on what I’m doing by following me on social media or signing up for my eNewsletter. If you need assistance in dealing with a federal agency, such as the VA, IRS or Department of Education, please do not hesitate to contact my Bothell office at (425) 485-0085.

Sincerely,

Suzan

Trump Engaged in Suspect Tax Schemes as He Reaped Riches From His Father  The New York Times President Trump participated in dubious tax schemes during the 1990s, including instances of outright fraud, that greatly increased the fortune he received from his parents, an investigation by The New York Times has found. 
McConnell Presses Kavanaugh Vote as FBI Probe Nears an End  The Wall Street Journal Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell pressed to hold a vote as soon as possible on Judge Brett Kavanaugh, with the FBI expected to wrap up its probe into allegations of sexual assault and misconduct by the Supreme Court nominee as soon as Wednesday. 
How Will Kavanaugh Shape the Midterms?  Roll Call Debacle over his Supreme Court nomination likely to yield mixed results.  Drug firms, oil industry win big in trade deal  The Washington Post The “USMCA” delivers big wins to drugmakers, oil companies and tech firms.

Subject: Poll: Manufacturing Day
Message:
￼ 

Poll: Manufacturing Day
Hoosiers,

This Friday is Manufacturing Day, an annual celebration of modern manufacturing meant to inspire the next generation. This industry is vital to Indiana's economy. Manufacturers in Indiana account for 28.8 percent of the total output in the state, employing 16.8 percent of the workforce.

Manufacturing not only plays an important role in the United States economy, but across the world. That is why Congress passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act last year - to modernize our domestic and international tax code and incentivize American companies to expand their businesses already here, to bring back jobs we had lost to overseas competitors, and to innovate and create new jobs and opportunities for a modern manufacturing economy.

Question of the Week: Do you believe the government should continue to remove barriers and reduce incentives for companies to move abroad, keeping jobs and economic prosperity in the United States?

[_] Yes.
[_] No.
[_] I don't know.
[_] Other (share your thoughts).

Take the poll here.

Subject: Rothfus Report: Our Multi-Faceted Secret Service
Message:
Open in its own browser window   Open a plain text version
News from Representative Keith Rothfus
￼

 
SERVING 
YOU
CONTACT KEITH
OUR 
DISTRICT
ISSUES & LEGISLATION
NEWSROOM
ABOUT 
KEITH
 


Dear Lindsey, 
Did you know that the Unites States Secret Service (Secret Service) was originally formed to stop counterfeiters after the Civil War? While their mission has grown and includes protecting the President and other public officials, the Secret Service continues to investigate financial crimes. During my recent meeting with Special Agent in Charge Tim Burke and other agents in the Pittsburgh Office, productive discussions were held with the Financial and Electronic Crimes Task Force. A review of the National Threat Assessment Center’s new operational guide to help prevent school violence and its rollout in the District was one meeting highlight.
￼  Pittsburgh Secret Service Team 
Local Programs Tackling Big Challenges 
Youth drug addiction and mental illness are two major problems facing Western Pennsylvania. A coordinated effort of local, state, and federal authorities helps ensure that our communities have the resources to assist our constituents.  
I am pleased to announce that several Western Pennsylvania communities have received beneficial federal grants to address drug addiction and mental illness. 
 ￼
The BC-SCORES Coalition was awarded a $125,000 grant through the Office of National Drug Control Policy’s (ONDCP) Drug Free Communities program! This grant supports their efforts in preventing youth drug abuse. 
￼  
Beaver County’s Behavioral Health and Developmental Services received a four-year grant totaling $1.6 million from the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). It will be awarded in four annual $400,000 installments. Resources will be provided to Beaver County’s “Dear Mind” campaign and support families and young people at high risk of mental illness.
￼ 
Additionally, the Cambria County Drug Coalition received their first of five $125,000 annual grants from the ONDCP’s Drug Free Communities program! This money will help them in their mission of restoring a safe, drug-free Cambria County.
Learning More about our Minds 
￼
Recently, I toured Carnegie Mellon University’s (CMU) Institute for Neuroscience. Their medical team, led by Dr. Alison Barth, told me about their research in the field of neuroscience. The dedicated team continues to pursue methods to identify and treat diseases early, including Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, and dementia. Additionally, they draw on the excellent capacity of the University’s information technology resources as they strive to extend the quality of life of many Americans. It is gratifying to see the CMU and U.S. government partnership making such progress.
Supporting our Young People 
Launched two years ago, the Beaver County Youth Ambassador Program continues its mission to destigmatize mental health issues and promote healthy ways for students to cope with stress and loneliness. This program equips student ambassadors with the resources for their peers and create a culture of understanding and support. Thank you to our students and the Beaver County Rehabilitation Center Supervisor of Youth Services, Maureen Hawk, and her team for their work. Read more here. 
Supporting the Bruce Mansfield Power Station 
￼ 
During my recent visit to the Bruce Mansfield Power Station, I reassured the employees that I will continue to fight to maintain a diversified, independent, and resilient power grid nationwide. This includes continuing the use of clean coal and nuclear energy as power sources. Maintaining a resilient power grid is essential to our national security. My commitment to “keeping the lights on” in this growing economy is vital to Western Pennsylvania and the region. 
Addressing Human Trafficking 
Tragically, human trafficking is still a huge problem in the US and around the world. Human traffickers continue to misuse the internet, especially the so-called “Deep Web” and “Dark Web” to facilitate their crimes. 
My work on the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Terrorism & Illicit Finance and the Judiciary Committee provides me a unique platform to advance legislation that fights human trafficking. We have passed many bills in the House to fight human trafficking, such as the bipartisan bill I introduced with my colleague, Representative Juan Vargas [CA-51], the Fight Illicit Networks and Detect (FIND) Trafficking Act. This bill requires the Government Accountability Office to analyze and report on the use of virtual currencies in marketplaces facilitating sex and drug trafficking.
More Than Crumbs 
Over the past few months, constituents across our district have shared how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is helping them and their families put more money in their pockets. Check out a few highlights below.
￼ 
These are just a few of the success stories from Pennsylvania’s 12th Congressional District. If you would like to share how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act is benefitting you and your family, please go to https://rothfus.house.gov/tax-reform-survey. 
Thank you for taking time to keep up with the work I’m doing on your behalf! If I can be of any assistance to you or your family, please reach out to my office at 412-837-1361 or go to my website at rothfus.house.gov. Also, if you need help with Social Security, Medicare, or another federal agency or program, my office his here to help! Drop by our mobile office hours and my staff will help you. Click here to learn more. 
 Sincerely,  ￼                                                Keith

News from Representative Brat
