About 
Dave 
Contact
Dave 



Dear Friend, 

The 7th District of Virginia is home to nearly 55,000 veterans who deserve our gratitude and respect. In Congress, I have been a strong supporter of legislation that helps our veterans such as the VA Mission Act. My office has also assisted over 350 veterans help cut through the bureaucratic red tape at the VA. 

Last week I held a veterans' townhall in Henrico with Rep. Phil Roe, Chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Committee and author of the VA Mission Act. My goal was to facilitate a dialogue between our veterans and their chief advocate in Washington. Throughout the townhall they were able to hear more about the work being done in Washington to reform the VA and ensure our veterans are getting the care they need. 

￼

The VA Mission Act is a key step towards this reform. Under this bill our veterans will receive more timely scheduling of medical appointments and will have more access to care outside the VA system if they live too far away from a VA medical facility. This bill was a great achievement, but there is still more to be done. I will continue to advocate for our veterans in Washington and will fight for those who fought for our nation. 

￼

Stay in Touch  
I am always interested in hearing your thoughts. If you have any comments, questions, or concerns, you can contact me directly by clicking here or by calling my office at (202) 225-2815.

You can also follow me on Twitter, Facebook, or YouTube for updates on my work in Congress. 
Thank you,

￼

Congressman Dave Brat

Subject: Permanent Middle Class Tax Cuts, Upholding Promise to Troops, Funding Boost for Medical Research
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
ABOUT  |  CONTACT  |  SERVICES  |  MEDIA CENTER  |  LEGISLATION  |  RESOURCES
￼
￼
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
October 02, 2018
Last Week in Congress
Yoder Votes to Make Middle Class, Small Business Tax Cuts Permanent
￼
Last year's tax reform legislation has launched a surge of growth in our economy, as business have created more jobs and the middle class has seen their take-home pay rise. But there's still more that we can do to bring permanent tax relief to American taxpayers, and the House took a major step in that direction this week.
I proudly voted in favor of a package of legislation known as Tax Reform 2.0, all aimed at setting up our economy for long-term and sustained growth. The cornerstone of this legislation is permanently locking in the middle class and small business tax cuts that were implemented last year. Tax Reform 2.0 included three separate bills:
	•	H.R.6760, the Protecting Family and Small Business Tax Cuts Act: makes permanent the tax cuts for the middle class and small businesses, as well as other family-focused provisions like the doubled Child Tax Credit.
	•	H.R. 6757, the Family Savings Act: reforms the tax code to help Americans save for important life events, like the birth of a child, education, and retirement.
	•	H.R. 6756, the American Innovation Act: creates new incentives to help start-up businesses get off the ground.
I voted in favor of each of these bills, which passed the House with bipartisan support. H.R. 6760 alone is projected to create 1.5 million new jobs in our country, and together these bills will help ensure that the economic boom we're seeing right now continues in the long run.
￼
Congress Passes Funding Increases for Defense, Medical Research, Education
￼
Last week, I took a vote to uphold the promise that I have made to support our military, when the House passed a major appropriations package that included the Department of Defense Appropriations Act. This was the first time Congress has completed the defense funding bill on schedule in over 20 years. The legislation secures $674.4 billion, giving our military certainty that they will receive the vital resources they need to ensure operational continuity and maintain our military presence around the world. Importantly, this legislation gives our brave men and women fighting for our freedom a 2.6% raise, the largest pay raise in almost a decade. The bill also provides funding for 16 new ships, 2 new submarines, 173 new aircraft, 124 new helicopters and upgrades for 135 tanks. When our brave warfighters put their lives on the line to protect our nation, we need to be able to say we have given the safest and most effective tools to complete their missions. I am proud that America is providing for our armed forces again, and will continue to working to support those who are on the front lines keeping America safe.
 
￼ Click here to watch Kevin's recent speech about NIH funding
This bipartisan funding bill also included full-year funding for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education - the first time this funding has been completed before the end of the fiscal year in two decades. It boosts funding for lifesaving programs at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) by $2 billion, provides a $100 million increase in the Cancer Moonshot research initiative, and calls for an additional $425 million for Alzheimer’s disease research. The great work done by the NIH has helped cause a 26% decrease in U.S. cancer deaths from 1991 to 2015, saving 2.4 million lives, and the funding increases in this bill will allow us to build on that great progress.
In addition to NIH, this legislation directs historic levels of funding to fight and end the opioid abuse epidemic, increases crucial education programs like Head Start, and supports college students through increased Pell Grants. Plus, the bill includes temporary funding through December 7, 2018 for all pieces of appropriations legislation that Congress has not completed yet - ensuring that our government stays open and running smoothly.
￼
Economy Continues Strong Growth
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from MarketWatch
More great news for the economy - all signs are pointing toward sustained growth for the long run. Last quarter our economy expanded at an outstanding 4.2% pace, and recent indicators project that we will grow at a rate of at least 3% for the remainder of the year. This continuous growth is encouraging consumers, and the Consumer Confidence Index rose in September to its highest point in 18 years - close to an all-time record. Consumers drive our economy, and their optimism signals that people all across the country are feeling the positive effects of our pro-growth agenda. The economy in Kansas is surging too - wages in our state grew faster than the national average in the second quarter, and we had the 10th largest wage growth in the nation.
￼
House Approves Major Legislation to Combat Opioid Epidemic
￼ Click here to read more about the bill from the Energy and Commerce Committee
The opioid crisis has touched communities across the country as drug overdoses are now the leading cause of death for people under the age of 50. This week, the House gave final approval to H.R. 6, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act, a landmark piece of legislation to combat this epidemic. This bill will give our communities the resources they need to provide treatment and support to those who are suffering from this debilitating disease. This bipartisan legislation will help advance treatment and recovery initiatives, improve prevention efforts, protect our communities and bolster our efforts to fight the deadly illicit drugs like fentanyl. On top of the $10.7 billion dollars appropriated in response to this crisis in recent funding bills, the SUPPORT for Patients and Communities Act will be another step towards healing our communities in the face of this heartbreaking challenge
￼
Yoder Votes for FAA Reauthorization and Hurricane Florence Aid
￼
Last week, the House passed bipartisan legislation that provides long-term stability to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and transforms federal disaster programs to help communities be better prepared. I voted for this widely supported legislation, which passed by a vote of 398 – 23. The bill includes provisions to reauthorize and reform the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) and the Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), modernize airport infrastructure, promote safety and American leadership in aviation, and strengthen consumer service.
The bill also reforms programs to help communities better prepare for disasters. Last year, over 26 million Americans were affected by at least one natural disaster. This legislation increases the federal emphasis on pre-disaster planning and mitigation, which will reduce the potential for future loss of life and address the rising costs of disasters in America. Plus, the bill includes $1.68 billion for the Department of Housing and Urban Development to use to help communities recover from Hurricane Florence
￼
Yoder Receives Small Business Award
￼ Kevin with NFIB President Juanita Duggan
Our pro-growth policies of tax and regulatory reform have kicked the economy into high gear, and businesses and job creators across the country are reporting their optimism about the direction we're heading. The National Federation of Independent Business's (NFIB) measure of small business optimism recently hit its highest point in 35 years, and is nearly at the highest point ever. Small businesses everywhere are reporting that they want to expand their operations and add more jobs. This week, I was honored to receive the Guardian of Small Business Award from NFIB for supporting issues crucial to the success of small business like tax cuts and regulatory reform. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act delivered significant tax and now Tax Reform 2.0 will lock in this incredibly important provision so that our small businesses can continue to hire, invest, and grow in their communities.
￼
Childhood Cancer Awareness Month at the National Cancer Institute
￼ Kevin viewing the work at NCI's Pediatric Oncology Branch
September is Childhood Cancer Awareness Month and a time to highlight our work in Congress to make medical research a priority to eradicate this horrible disease. Last Tuesday, I toured the National Cancer Institute’s (NCI) Pediatric Oncology Branch with NCI Director Dr. Ned Sharpless, Chief of the Pediatric Oncology Branch at NCI Center for Cancer Research Dr. Brigitte Widemann, and Dr. Jack Shern. I saw firsthand the outstanding research on childhood cancer genomics by Dr. Shern, and saw a demonstration of an innovative device he and his team designed to perform single cell analysis to study relapsed disease, in an effort to identify specific cell characteristics driving therapy resistance and relapse. I also heard about Dr. Widemann’s promising results from a trial to shrink neurofibromatosis (NF) tumors in children and young adults, and give these kids a better quality of life. These doctors at NCI are working to solve some of the most pressing health issues of our time. It is critical that Congress provide the support researchers need now to find the cures of the future. I will continue to support federally funded NIH research and the resulting life-saving innovations in cancer detection and treatment.
￼
Yoder Receives American Society of Clinical Oncology Award
￼ Kevin receiving the award from Dr. Monica Bertagnolli, President of ASCO
I was honored to receive the 2018 Congressional Leadership Award from the American Society of Clinical Oncology. This award is given each year to the Member of Congress who has supported policies to advance the field of oncology and improve care for cancer patients. As Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus, I have worked hard to support efforts that are searching for a cure for cancer, such as the medical research being done at the National Institutes of Health. In addition to the award, I was also glad to meet with constituents who are clinical oncologists, like Dr. Joshua Mammen from KU Medical Center. We discussed how clinical oncologists like him are seeing real results from NIH-funded research leading to improved outcomes for cancer patients.  
￼
Meetings in D.C.
Bread for the World
￼
On Wednesday, I was excited to meet with constituents representing Bread for the World, to talk about the importance of global nutrition programs. These programs offer a hand up, rather than a hand out, to communities facing hunger and nutrition deficits that can stunt children’s physical and developmental growth. I was proud to support this cause by voting in favor of S. 2269, the Global Food Security Reauthorization Act, which will help combat famine and chronic hunger by providing support and resources to farmers in developing countries. Programs associated with the Global Food Security Act lead to more productive societies, help children perform in school, and strengthen foreign economies, which become more robust trade partners with the United States. 
￼
Merck Animal Health
￼ Kevin with Rick DeLuca
It was a pleasure seeing my good friend and constituent, Rick DeLuca. Rick serves as the President of Merck Animal Health, whose North American Headquarters is located in DeSoto. During our visit we discussed the ongoing expansion of the Merck campus and all of the great work the fine people there are doing for the agriculture economy in Kansas and across the nation. As a result of the benefits from Tax Reform, Merck will be breaking ground on a new building at the site in the next few months, adding close to 100 new jobs in the district
￼
Around the District
Yoder Hosts Annual Third District Job Fair
￼
We had a great turnout last week at my annual Job Fair, held at Johnson County Community College. I was excited to see 75 employers, with a focus on manufacturing and technology, accepting resumes and meeting with hundreds of local job seekers about employment opportunities. This was my tenth Job Fair in the 3rd District, and with such a strong national and local economy, I remain committed to connecting Kansans looking for work with employers. Thank you to Keely Schneider and her team from Workforce Partnership for helping to make last week's Job Fair a success. If you missed the Job Fair, and would like a list of employers, please contact my District Office at (913) 621-0832.
￼
Olathe School District Wins Major Federal Grant
￼ ￼ Click here to read more from KCUR
Literacy skills are vital to the development of young minds – and that’s why I’m working to provide federal funding for literacy programs in Kansas. Recently, the state of Kansas received a $27 million grant from the U.S. Department of Education to be used on comprehensive literacy programs. This was one of the largest competitive education grants ever awarded to Kansas. The money will go to school districts across the state, including our own Olathe School District. As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I supported strong funding for this grant program, and I am proud to see our local school districts putting this money to good use, helping all children gain the literacy skills they need to be successful.
￼
Prioritizing Constituent Services
￼ Click here to read more from Fox 4 News
Constituent service is my top priority, and one of the most important functions of a Congressional office. We continually navigate through red tape bureaucracy at federal agencies to help constituents of the Third District. Thanks to Fox 4 News for sharing this example of a positive outcome that we were able to achieve. If you or someone you know ever needs help with the federal government - a veteran who needs help at the VA, a senior having trouble navigating Medicare, or any other issue - please contact my district office at (913) 621-0832.
￼
Puerto Rico Delegation at Church of the Resurrection
￼ Kevin with Rev. Adam Hamilton and Rev. Eric Hernandez
It was an impactful Sunday morning at my church, the Church of the Resurrection Leawood, as I joined Pastor Adam Hamilton in welcoming Rev. Eric Hernandez from the Methodist Church of Puerto Rico, along with a delegation from Puerto Rico that was participating in the Leadership Institute and thanking our community for their support. In Congress, we are working to bring relief and rebuild Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria. It was great to see Rev. Hernandez again and hear firsthand about the rebuilding.
￼

The Midwest saw opioid overdoses increase by 70% between July 2016 and September 2017.

Send your answers to haley.brady@mail.house.gov and the first correct response will receive a shout out in next week's newsletter.
Congratulations to last week's winner Charlie Carson!

Subject: Update on Supreme Court & Hispanic Heritage Month
Message:
￼

 

Dear Friend, 
The Kavanaugh Nomination 
This week is a pivotal one in the Supreme Court nomination of Brett Kavanaugh and for the future of our country. Following the credible testimony by Dr. Christine Blasey Ford who has accused Judge Kavanaugh of sexual assault, the Senate agreed to postpone a vote on the nomination until the FBI finishes a one-week background check into Judge Kavanaugh. This is important. 
First and foremost, victims should be believed, as I believe Dr. Ford. That is why, on Friday – the final day of the hearings – I joined my House colleagues to attend the hearing and support Dr. Ford. As the Republican Senators indicated plans to move ahead with the nomination while ignoring the allegations, we stood up in silent protest. Shortly thereafter, the Capitol Police moved us out of the room. The skepticism shown by Republicans is part of the reason rape and assault are severely under-reported. This is a moment when we can give a voice to victims. The Supreme Court is a place of justice, and so justice should be at the center of this process. 
Second, before being promoted to a life-long position, with influence over laws for a generation, Brett Kavanaugh should be closely examined, and all accusations investigated. But already there are reports that President Trump was trying to limit the scope of the investigation. There have been at least 3 accusations against Brett Kavanaugh, with others confirming that his drinking went beyond even what he admitted to the Senate. These contradictions in his testimony – including answers about his high school year book – must also be examined. 
It is important that we get this right. While I have expressed deep concerns with Judge Kavanaugh already, like his hostility to women’s reproductive rights, his questioning of the constitutionality of Native Hawaiian programs, and his reluctance to condemn Japanese internment during WWII, I believe these charges go beyond whether he is qualified to be a Supreme Court Justice. This is a chance for us as a country to empower more women to speak up when they have been attacked, and to tell men that this behavior will not be ignored any longer. I want to see this investigation conducted seriously, fairly, and comprehensively. Any hint of deception or misbehavior by Brett Kavanaugh – after denying it completely – should be disqualifying. 
Hispanic Heritage Month 
Happy Hispanic Heritage Month!  
One of the great joys of representing the San Gabriel Valley is the diversity that can be heard, seen, tasted, and experienced every day. Diversity and multiculturalism have always and will always make our country stronger. And this month is an incredible opportunity to celebrate the many ways Hispanic Americans add to that vibrancy. In California alone, 800,000 Hispanic owned small-businesses contribute over $98 billion to the economy each year.
And this is true across our country. Hispanic Americans – whether they have been here for generations or a few months - are entrepreneurs, innovators, veterans, parents, children, and neighbors. Hispanic cultural pride is our pride as well.  
That is why, in Congress, as chair of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, I am proud to work hand in hand with the Congressional Hispanic Caucus on issues like equal access to education and healthcare. And of course, immigration reform. 
I’m also fighting back on the attacks on Hispanic immigrants and communities Threats of deportation are threats to tear families apart and uproot communities. We know this because we live this reality in Southern California, every day. The antidote to the venom of xenophobia is exposure – getting to know our neighbors and understand that America does not belong to one group or another. But ideas like the border wall are meant to reinforce fear by painting one group as an enemy and making it impossible for different communities to build our nation together. That is why I am promising to stand up to fear and division and to continue fighting for comprehensive immigration reform that will grow our country and keep families whole. 
I am proud of the contributions from Hispanic Americans. And as we celebrate this Hispanic Heritage Month, let us also look ahead to the future successes we will celebrate together.  
Sincerely, 
￼

Subject: Educating Our Community On The Threat Of Breast Cancer
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
The Comstock Connection
News From The Office Of Congresswoman Barbara Comstock
￼ 
Our District
Biography
Media Center
Services
Contact Me

Dear Friend,
October is Breast Cancer Awareness month, where we take the time to educate our broader community to the persistent threat Breast Cancer poses to our friends and loved ones.  Like so many women, I have had family and loved ones touched by breast cancer.  But over our lifetimes we have seen the breast cancer survival rates increase and we continue to fight for earlier detection and better treatment.
In August I visited the Novant Health UVA Haymarket Medical Center and met medical staff to discuss how they are administering unique, high-quality cancer care in our area. Novant Health’s high-tech breast cancer center has comprehensive breast cancer care and utilizes advanced 3-D digital scans to best detect breast cancer in women. Their specialists provide a multidisciplinary approach to treatment and even offers a unique second opinion on breast cancer diagnoses. By bringing more state-of-the-art treatment facilities such as these to Northern Virginia, we can present more opportunities to treat, educate, and ultimately cure breast cancer for our friends and families facing this challenge.
This year Congress has dedicated $34.4 billion for defense health programs, which includes funding for the Breast Cancer Research Program (BCRP). The BCRP is a unique partnership between Congress, the military, and the public to fund innovative and impactful medical research in targeted program areas, including breast cancer. These funds will support the BCRP mission to achieve a world without breast cancer. These appropriations are on top of the unprecedented $39.1 billion in funding for the National Institutes of Health (NIH), which will support research to improve the prevention, treatment, and find cures for life-threatening illnesses and diseases such as breast cancer, Alzheimer’s, HIV/AIDS, and diabetes. 
On behalf of the many woman who are living with breast cancer and those who will be diagnosed in the future I joined with my colleagues to send a letter to the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) to ensure that fabricated breast prosthetics are covered under Medicare. It is only right that women who have battled breast cancer be given options that best suit their recovery, and it is my hope CMS recognizes this important matter.  As your elected representative, I will continue to fight for more resources to support new research, ensure equal treatment for survivors, and further raise awareness regarding breast cancer.  
Thank you, ￼  Barbara Comstock Member of Congress

Subject: Mark's Weekly Update
Message:

News from Representative Mark Meadows 

￼
￼
￼
￼ 
￼
ABOUT    SERVICES    ISSUES & LEGISLATION    MEDIA CENTER    DISTRICT    CONTACT    RESOURCES 



October 2, 2018 



Hurricane Florence Recovery Update 
I wanted to give an update on some of the ongoing recovery efforts in North Carolina from Hurricane Florence.  
Recently I had the chance to go to Bladen County, North Carolina—one of the areas most impacted—to meet with first responders, assess damage, and see what we can do to help with recovery efforts. While the damage is severe, we were incredibly encouraged by the community coming together. These are the best people you'll find—they’re working long hours and putting everything they have into assisting families in the area who are suffering. Several people have come in from other parts of the state to offer their help as well. 
Please continue pray for the folks affected. They have a long road ahead, but NC's people are the best in the country. 
Additionally, for those who may have seen: North Carolina has formally appealed a denial from FEMA for major disaster assistance—a request which included several of our NC11 counties (Buncombe, Caldwell, Henderson, Madison, McDowell, etc). This is a huge deal and will be critical for some of our counties that got hit with significant flood damage. Last week I spent some time with one of our teams in McDowell County and they’re working hard on response measures to flooding in the district. I joined a full delegation letter backing a request to get them expedited assistance. 
We will keep you posted. Our first responders are doing an incredible job and people from all over the state are stepping up to help their friends and neighbors in need.
As a reminder, for any resources you may need, we’ve compiled a list on our website and would be glad to help however possible. You can see that page here. 
￼  Meeting with first responders in McDowell County 
￼  Meeting with first responders in Bladen County, NC 
￼  Pray for those recovering in North Carolina 
￼  Meeting with first responders in Bladen County, NC 
￼  Speaking with Sheriff Jim McVicker in Bladen County, NC 
Tax Reform 2.0 Passes House 
A new round of tax reform passed the House last week, focused on individuals, small business, and family savings plans—and I was proud to be an original cosponsor. 
Here are some of the specific things this package of tax reform accomplishes: 
- It makes the individual tax cuts permanent (remember, the individual rates were forced to be temporary in the original bill, due to Senate budget rules)   - It creates new savings accounts options for families, particularly with 529 education accounts and “baby savings” plans  - It removes financial barriers and burdens from small business creators by creating more flexibility for write-offs on start-up costs 
These are the types of pro-family, pro-growth, and pro-worker reforms we need to keep pushing. Read more about some of the reforms here. You can also watch my full floor speech in support of the package here. 
￼  Speaking on the floor in support of ‘Tax Reform 2.0’  
Update on DOJ/FBI Investigation 
We saw major developments this week on two fronts with our investigation into FBI/DOJ actions during the 2016 election and early stages of the Trump administration.
First, House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte has subpoenaed the memos from former Deputy FBI Director, Andrew McCabe. This is critical. We have been asking for these memos for months and the Department turned us down every time—but they should provide some insight into what was going on at DOJ and FBI during 2016 and 2017, according to McCabe’s own words.
Second, House Leadership has agreed to call Rod Rosenstein before Congress, for a closed-door hearing with our investigative task force, so he can explain his alleged comments on "wiring" POTUS—as well as other inconsistent statements. This will allow Mr. Rosenstein to explain his side of the New York Times report and answer other questions to the task force. If Mr. Rosenstein fails to attend voluntarily, we will subpoena him. 
Whether or not the reports regarding Mr. Rosenstein are true, here's what we know to be true: this story underscores the desperate need for transparency at the DOJ. Release the documents. It is time to declassify everything, only protecting sources and methods. Stop the games and show Americans the truth about this Russia investigation. If they have nothing to hide, they should act like it.
You can watch my discussion on the issue with Laura Ingraham here. 
￼  Discussing Rod Rosenstein’s status with Laura Ingraham 
Bryson City Fire Department 
Some important news for NC-11 first responders this week: I was honored to present the Bryson City Fire Department with a grant check for $182,000, as part of a DHS program supporting first responders, going toward their recruitment program! It’s very well deserved and huge for Swain County.
Thanks so much to the team for everything they do. 
￼  With the Bryson City Fire Department 
A Win for American Farmers and Workers 
If you missed it, President Trump and the White House just secured a major win for America on trade—successfully renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with Canada and Mexico. This is a crucial win for the country and for the administration. The President continues to deliver on his 'America First' promise!
Congratulations to President Trump and the White House team on a job well done on the renegotiation –this will be a major victory for American workers and farmers. The deal will now go to Congress for review, where I look forward to working with my Republican and Democrat colleagues on helping see it through. 
You can read more details about the agreement here. 
 
My Bill to Extend Opportunity Zones 
The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 included a popular provision implementing a new mechanism called “Opportunity Funds.” These funds allow investors to defer and reduce their capital gains tax bills in exchange for investing in projects located in economically disadvantaged areas, known as “Opportunity Zones.” Opportunity zones are designated by the Department of the Treasury and typically have an unemployment rate of about 14%, a lower than average median household income, and are usually located in counties where 20 percent (or more) of the population has been living below the poverty line for 30 years.
Essentially, this part of the tax cuts bill creates an incentive for Americans to invest in less-fortunate communities. That’s exactly what our government should be doing—creating tax incentives and allowing market forces to work. 
The current law allows designations to expire after 10 years, but this week, I introduced a bill (H.R. 6890) that would allow for the designation of new opportunity zones every 10 years. Under this bill, the policy’s benefits could build and compound rather than expire.
Opportunity Funds benefit the state of North Carolina directly. On May 18 of this year, the Treasury Department certified 252 areas in NC as official Opportunity Zones, with more than 450 unique North Carolina census tracts identified for further review. This is a major catalyst for economic development and increased opportunity for under-privileged residents and families.
Read all about the bill here. Helping economically disadvantaged communities through market incentives is a huge priority of mine—we’re looking forward to working on it!
￼  Debating on the House floor about the need to help workers and families 
Supporting Israel – U.S. - Israel Cooperation Expansion Act 
Our office is continuing to support Israel with common sense reforms dedicated to security. This week, I was proud to introduce a bipartisan bill with Rep. Brad Schneider from Illinois and Rep. Doug Lamborn from Colorado. You can read all about the bill here. 
The bill addresses modernized threats against Israel and the U.S. by enhancing the partnership between our two nations, particularly in the area of law enforcement training and development for security. It formally supports the inclusion of Israel in American International Law Enforcement Academies, in which Israel does not currently participate. Including Israel in this organization would facilitate enhanced cooperation between our two countries and give Israel’s law enforcement and security teams access to the tools and training needed to better deal with modernized threats.
The United States has not just a responsibility but an obligation to stand with Israel, our strongest ally in the Middle East and around the globe. It’s on Congress to pass common sense reforms like these that will allow for better cooperation, coordination, and partnership for our two nations to face modernized threats together. 
I’m proud to be a part of this and look forward to seeing it through. Thanks to Mr. Schneider and Mr. Lamborn for working with us. 
Rallying Conservatives in Washington 
I was honored to meet so many great conservatives from all over the country last week at the ‘FreedomWorks’ rally in Washington, D.C., supporting my good friend and House Freedom Caucus colleague Rep. Jim Jordan for speaker! 
Jim is one of the finest men, leaders, and conservatives in all of Washington—I’m proud to give him my full support. 
There is a tremendous amount of grassroots energy demanding change in Congress, much like what we’ve seen take place in the White House this year under President Trump’s leadership. Well, we hear you, and we are committed to doing everything we can to returning power back to you on Main Street.
Thanks so much to everyone who made time to take the trip. We had people take time off of work just to be there—and we even had students from North Carolina make time to attend! You can watch a portion of my speech to the crowd here.

￼  With students from Mars Hill University & North Carolina Student Legislature 
￼  Meeting fellow conservatives at the rally

Subject: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month
Message:
If you are having trouble viewing this message or would like to share it on a social network, you can view the message online.￼
￼
ABOUT
ISSUES
NEWS
SERVICES
DISTRICT
CONTACT
￼
Dear Friend,
It's Hispanic Heritage Month, a time where we honor the contributions of Hispanic Americans to our nation’s history and culture. Whether though music, film, technology, education, or politics; the Latino impact on American culture is undeniable. Each day, I am proud to honor this legacy in Washington as your representative.  
The history of Latinos in this country is a history of activism. From the farmlands of Arizona to the U.S. Supreme Court, our place in this country has been shaped by struggle and hard-won victories. Now, President Trump and his administration have implemented policies that attack our community and attempt to erase our claims to the American Dream. Despite these attacks, I remain committed to protecting and strengthening our legacy and inheritance—not just today—but for the generations that follow. Battles over access to quality education, livable wages, affordable health care, immigrant justice, and important civil rights protections are critical to ensuring the long-term success of our children and grandchildren. The battles we fight and the victories we obtain today directly impact their futures.
Each day that I vote in Washington, I think about this history and the legacy that we will pass on to future generations. It’s why I’m fighting for policies that ensure our long-term success and prosperity. Quality schools, affordable health care, a humane immigration system, and good-paying jobs aren’t just talking points, they are the building blocks for our children’s and grandchildren’s futures. This Hispanic Heritage Month, let’s honor the legacy of those who fought for the rights we enjoy today and recommit ourselves to ensuring their strength. 
Peace,
￼
￼
 
Click here to watch my Hispanic Heritage Month video message.
 
Querido Amigo,
 
El 15 de septiembre constituye el comienzo del Mes Nacional de la Herencia Hispana, en celebración y reconocimiento de la historia y cultura de los hispanoamericanos. Ya sea a través de la música, el cine, la tecnología, la educación o la política; el impacto latino en la cultura estadounidense es innegable. Cada día, me enorgullece honrar este legado en Washington como su representante.
La historia de los latinos en este país es una historia de activismo. Desde las tierras de cultivo de Arizona hasta la Corte Suprema de EE.UU., nuestro lugar en este país ha sido formado por luchas y victorias difíciles de conseguir. Ahora, el presidente Trump y su administración han implementado políticas que atacan a nuestra comunidad e intentan borrar nuestras demandas al sueño americano. A pesar de estos ataques, sigo luchando por la protección y el fortalecimiento de nuestro legado y herencia, no solo hoy, sino para las siguientes generaciones. Las batallas para el acceso a una educación de calidad, a unos salarios dignos, a la atención médica accesible, a la justicia de los inmigrantes y las protecciones importantes de los derechos civiles son fundamentales para garantizar el éxito a largo plazo de nuestros hijos y nietos. Las batallas que luchamos y las victorias que obtenemos hoy impactan directamente su futuro.
Cada día que voto en Washington, pienso en esta historia y en el legado que transmitiremos a las generaciones futuras. Es por eso que lucho por políticas que garanticen nuestro éxito y prosperidad a largo plazo. Las escuelas de calidad, el cuidado de la salud accesible, un sistema de inmigración humano y empleos bien remunerados no son solo puntos de discusión, sino que son los cimientos para el futuro de nuestros hijos y nietos. Durante este Mes de la Herencia Hispana, honremos el legado de aquellos que lucharon por los derechos que disfrutamos hoy y reafirmemos nuestro compromiso para garantizar su fortaleza.
Paz,
￼

Subject: Protecting Children and Families from Identity Theft
Message:
￼ 
￼
←
Click to sign up for our E-Newsletter
By subscribing to our email updates, you are authorizing us to send 
regular email updates from our office to your email account.
￼ ￼ ￼ ￼
Tuesday, October 2, 2018
WEBSITE | SHARE ON: ￼ ￼ 
Dear Friend, 

Earlier this year, I met Jill, a Peoria mom whose daughter’s Social Security number was stolen and used to commit identity fraud. It took seven years to recover her identity and change her social security number. Jill was even forced to change her daughter’s name. It was unacceptable.

That’s when I went to work to help ensure fraud victims or their families don’t have to go through this horrible experience.

￼

                  ABC15 highlighted our successful efforts to protect kids from identity fraud. Watch here.

I worked across the aisle to pass a bill called the Protecting Children from Identity Theft Act. This bill cracks down on the dangerous form of identity theft used against Jill’s daughter, and directs the Social Security Administration (SSA) to modernize its identity verification system. The president signed our bill into law in May, making it more difficult for scammers to create fake identities with stolen Social Security numbers.

There was more work to do. I pushed the Social Security Administration to learn from Jill’s experience and make changes. As a result of our action, the agency implemented important steps at its offices across the country to make sure families facing child identity theft get help in a timely and effective manner.

I recently sat down with ABC15’s Angie Koehle to discuss these successes on behalf of fraud victims. Watch my interview here.

￼

                                                             Watch the interview with ABC15 here.

I am honored to serve in Congress on behalf of Arizona families like yours. We always appreciate hearing from you on current topics and issues that are important to you. If there is an issue that concerns you, please let us know by clicking this link or by calling our Phoenix office: 602-956-2285. Be sure to stay connected through our Facebook and Twitter accounts, and let us know how we can be of service.
Sincerely,
￼
Kyrsten

Subject: Recent Valley Water Wins
Message:
News from Representative Costa  Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window     Click here to open a plain text version of this email 
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼
￼


Dear Friend,  
The people of the San Joaquin Valley deserve a reliable water supply, which is why I have spent decades fighting for Valley water. This month, we’ve had some success in advancing multiple policies to build a more reliable water supply, and I wanted to take this opportunity to share them with you.
Upgrading Water Infrastructure Projects in Merced  
On September 13th the House of Representatives passed America’s Water Infrastructure Act (AWIA), a bipartisan agreement reached by the House and Senate. The bill includes provisions that I championed in the House with my fellow Valley Congressmen that increase surface water storage in the Valley. It is a victory for Merced County and the people of the Valley, but we cannot stop working to secure reliable, safe water for our communities. I will continue to work with my colleagues – Republicans and Democrats alike – to protect Valley water and increase our access to the water we need to continue our way of life. 
More specifically, AWIA includes a bill I authored earlier this year with Republican Congressmen Jeff Denham (CA-10) and Tom McClintock (CA-4) that will allow Merced Irrigation District to move forward with a project to raise the spillway gates at New Exchequer Dam. This would enlarge the storage capacity of Lake McClure, increasing water supplies for eastern Merced County up to 57,000 acre-feet.
AWIA also includes a provision which I led with Rep. Denham that will expand an EPA loan guarantee program to include private and Reclamation facilities. This will make it easier to finance surface storage projects in the future, ultimately reducing the cost of the water from them. 
Additionally, AWIA includes two more programs I supported. The first will extend funding for a program that is being used to restore and eventually expand the San Luis Reservoir. The second provision creates a pilot program in the Russian River Basin to develop a system for incorporating weather forecast into reservoir operations.
For video of Congressman Costa advocating for his measure to improve reservoir operations, including those at Lake McClure, click here: 
￼ 
  
Valley Wins in Energy and Water Spending Bill 
This month we passed the Fiscal Year 2019 Energy and Water Development, Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, and Legislative Branch appropriations bill. This spending bill includes multiple areas of funding that will allow for investment in water infrastructure and drought prevention in the San Joaquin Valley, such as: 
	•	An additional $196 million to fund California and Western drought programs under the WIIIN Act, including:
	◦	$134 million for water storage 
	◦	$20 million for water recycling
	◦	$12 million for desalination
	◦	$30 million for environment and science projects 
	•	$540 million for the Army Corps of Engineers and Bureau of Reclamation water infrastructure programs specifically in California 
	•	$34 million for WaterSMART grants and almost $59 million for the Title XVI Water Reclamation and Reuse program 
	•	$35 million for the San Joaquin River Restoration Project to move forward on the infrastructure needed to protect Valley water supplies
	•	$8 million – a 45% increase from last year – for improved research, monitoring, and forecasting of atmospheric river storms
Expanding Shasta Reservoir 
Last week the Bureau of Reclamation announced it was moving forward with the Shasta Dam and Reservoir Enlargement Project. The project currently aims to add an additional 630,000 acre-feet when completed, which will increase the reliability of our water supply for our communities as well as for agricultural, industrial, and environmental use.
After 14 years, I’m glad to see the much-needed expansion of Shasta Reservoir finally moving forward. It’s beyond clear that California needs more water storage, which is why I worked to ensure that the WIIN Act provided $335 million in funding for projects like expanding Shasta Reservoir, expanding San Luis Reservoir, and building Sites and Temperance Flat. This is a step in the right direction, but it’s taken too long, and much more needs to be done to ensure the security of the Valley’s water supply.
For more information on the Shasta Dam Reservoir Enlargement Photo, click here:  
￼ 
Water is the lifeblood of the San Joaquin Valley, and agriculture is a cornerstone of our economy. Ensuring the people of the Valley and Valley agriculture have the water we need to continue our way of life has always been – and continues to be – one of my top priorities. As we prepare for the next rainy season, I will continue to work with local, state, and federal officials for bipartisan progress on enhancing water storage throughout the Valley.
Additionally, our Valley needs strong agriculture policy that feeds Americans and allows our food producers to continue to be some of the most productive in the world. As a member of the Farm Bill Conference Committee, I will work to ensure the next Farm Bill serves our Valley farmers, families, and communities. I hope that we can reach a bipartisan agreement on such a Farm Bill in the coming weeks.
￼ 
Thank you for taking the time to read this newsletter update. As always, please do not hesitate to contact me regarding any federal issues of your concern. To stay up-to-date on the work I am doing in Congress, please visit my website at costa.house.gov and sign up for my e-newsletter here. You can also follow my work and events in our Valley on my Facebook page and Twitter account. 
  
Sincerely, 
￼  Jim Costa Member of Congress

October 2, 2018

Remaining 2018 Job Fairs:
Fairmont

lori.l.turner@wv.gov           
      
Click here for more.     
     

To invite the Senator to your event, click here. 



  
 





























From the Hill to the Mountains
  Bipartisan Effort to Direct Rural Broadband Funding to High-Cost Areas 
I was proud to join a group of bipartisan group of senators in writing a letter urging U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Sonny Perdue to designate a high cost set aside within the e-Connectivity Pilot Program established in the Consolidated Appropriations Act to reach rural and geographically challenged areas of the country that need it most. According to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), of the 24 million American households that do not have reliable, affordable, high-speed internet, 80 percent are located in rural areas.
To read the full letter, click here. 
  
NASA Facility to Potentially be Renamed for West Virginian, Katherine Johnson 
I applaud my Senate colleagues for passing this legislation, which I was proud to cosponsor, to rename Fairmont’s NASA IV&V facility. Not only did Katherine Johnson, broaden our nation’s perceived physical limitations with her contributions to the space program, she also broke down discriminatory barriers that stood in the way of so many other women and people of color advancing in the workplace. Katherine Johnson is one of West Virginia’s finest and a groundbreaking, brilliant mathematician. No individual is more worthy of this honor than her. Through her brilliance, strength, and courage, she proved to the country that anyone—regardless of race, gender, or background—can touch the stars.
The bill now heads to the House of Representatives for consideration. 
  
Key Federal Resources
Assistance to Firefighters Grant Applications Webinars Occurring through October
The 2018 AFG application period is OPEN now and will close on Friday, October 26 at 5:00 PM EST. 
For more information on the AFG Program, click here. 
  
 
On the Road
It is always a pleasure to get a surprise visit from my fellow West Virginians visiting our nation's capital. If you are planning a trip to Washington, be sure to stop by and say hello!
￼ 
Senator Manchin enjoys a visit from Jefferson County residents, Meredith Wait, Debbie Dickinson, Marellen Ahern and Patience Wait. 
I stopped by the Travelling Vietnam Wall in Parkersburg and placed a flag for a dear friend of mine, Victor Tarasuk. Our Vietnam Veterans know better than anyone that our state gave more during the Vietnam War than any other state in the country. I sincerely thank them, and all Veterans, for their unwavering service and sacrifice.
￼ 
Senator Manchin visits the Travelling Vietnam Wall in Parkersburg. 
￼ 
Senator Manchin speaks during a ceremony for the Travelling Vietnam Wall in Parkersburg. 
Last week, my office was a part of two job fairs in Martinsburg and Parkersburg. I have participated in or hosted nearly 40 job fairs since October 2015. Thank you to the hundreds of employers who participated, to the volunteers, and to all the job seekers who came out to explore the opportunities available in their region. I wish you all the best of luck!
 ￼  
Senator Manchin attends the Parkersburg Regional Job Fair. 
￼ 
Hundreds of job seekers participate in the Martinsburg Job Fair. 
￼
Students from Musselman High School and Martinsburg High School student councils volunteer to help at the Martinsburg Regional Job Fair. (Many thanks toTanner Boeckmann, Precious Navarre, Alisha Joseph, Imani Hunter, Sean Albons, Matt Van Duzer, Jacob Antolini, Eli Demick, and Randy McFarland.) 
  
One of my Regional Coordinators, Mary Jo Guidi, attended a ribbon-cutting ceremony last week to mark the opening of the new West Virginia Department of Veterans Assistance Wheeling Field Office. 
 ￼ 
Mary Jo Guidi attends the grand opening of the West Virginia Department of Veterans Assistance Wheeling Field Office. 
  
Spotlight
“Integrity First, Service Before Self, Excellence in All We Do” 
  
This week I am highlighting the U.S. Air Force Academy, the youngest of the service academies and the last of my highlighted series.
  
The mission of this esteemed academy in Colorado Springs is to educate, train, and inspire men and women to become leaders of character.  The Air Force Academy is one of the largest tourist attractions in Colorado.  Just like the other service academies, admission is extremely competitive. 
  
The Air Force Academy is centered on military training, academics, athletics and character development.  Cadets like Isaac Childers, class of 2019 will receive the skills and knowledge needed for success as future officers. Graduates will receive a Bachelor of Science degree and are commissioned as second lieutenants in the United States Air Force.
  
￼ 
Isaac Childers, U.S. Air Force Academy cadet 
  
￼ 
Isaac Childers, U.S. Air Force Academy cadet 
  
Air Force Academy alumni include 39 Astronauts, 35 Rhodes Scholars, 11 Legislators, 3 authors, and a Medal of Honor recipient.
 If you are interested in becoming part of the prestigious Air Force Academy alumni,I encourage you to apply for a nomination from my office.  My application is available online at www.manchin.senate.gov.  
  
The deadline to submit applications is October 5.   
  
The United States Air Force Academy 
Admissions Office

USAF Academy CO 80840-5651 
(719) 472-3070

How May We Help You?
Mr. George Bossie contacted our office requesting 203 West Virginia state flags.  He was going on a trip to visit his sister overseas and wanted to make the trip even more meaningful, so he mapped out the American Cemetery in Normandy, and decided he would take the flags and some West Virginia soil along with him to place on all of the graves of fallen West Virginia soldiers.  I was so pleased that my office was able to get him the flags and that he was able to honor our fallen heroes with such a special tribute.
￼ 
George Bossie honoring fallen West Virginia Veterans in Normandy, France. 
￼ 
George Bossie honoring fallen West Virginia Veterans in Normandy, France.

Subject: Congressman Cook's Newsletter: October 2, 2018
Message:
District Update | October 2, 2018
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
CONNECT: 
￼ ￼ ￼ 
￼ 
￼ 
￼
Congressman Cook Votes for Comprehensive Bill to Combat the Opioid Crisis 
Congressman Paul Cook voted for HR 6, the Substance Use-Disorder Prevention that Promotes Opioid Recovery and Treatment (SUPPORT) for Patients and Communities Act. The bill passed overwhelmingly.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), on average, 1,000 people are treated for opioid misuse in emergency departments per day and an average of 115 Americans die per day. The opioid crisis has also created a massive burden on our economy, causing the loss of almost 1 million workers between 1999 and 2015 and the loss of $702 billion in real output. 

HR 6 is a bipartisan bill that will advance treatment and recovery initiatives, improve prevention, protect our communities, and bolster efforts to fight deadly illicit synthetic drugs like fentanyl. 

Specifically, the bill includes several provisions, including:

Treatment and Recovery
- Improve and expand access to treatment and recovery services
- Provide incentives for enhanced care, coordination, and innovation
- Establish comprehensive opioid recovery centers 

Prevention
- Encourage non-addictive opioid alternatives to treat pain
- Improves data to identify and help at-risk patients
- Address high prescribing rate while enhancing prescription drug monitoring programs

Protecting Communities
- Give law enforcement tools to get dangerous drugs out of our communities
- Better intercept illicit opioids at international mail facilities
- Improve access to federal resources for local communities

Fighting Fentanyl
- Better tackle ever-changing synthetic drugs
- Crack down on foreign shipments of illicit drugs
- Provide grants for local communities to combat fentanyl

Congressman Cook said, “The opioid crisis has continued to spiral out of control, wreaking havoc on families and burdening the economy. This year, Congress has already passed an unprecedented amount of legislation targeting the opioid crisis and this bill is another important step. I look forward to this legislation becoming law.” 

For a complete look at legislation Congress has passed targeting the opioid crisis, please visit: energycommerce.house.gov/opioids-legislation/ 

Congressman Cook Votes to Protect Right to Vote for US Citizens
Congressman Paul Cook voted for H. Res 1071, which recognizes that allowing illegal immigrants the right to vote devalues the franchise and diminishes the voting power of US citizens. The bill passed the House 279-72. 

Currently, the US Constitution prohibits discrimination in voting based on race, sex, poll taxes, and age. Federal law, meanwhile, prohibits non-citizens from voting in elections for federal office. However, in 2016, voters in the city of San Francisco approved a measure allowing non-citizens, including those without legal status, to vote in school board races.

Congressman Cook said, “The right to vote is one of the most important duties of being an American citizen. San Francisco has set a dangerous precedent by allowing people here illegally to affect governance for American citizens. This resolution sends a strong message that citizens alone enjoy the right to vote.” 

To view the full text of H. Res 1071, click here. 

Congressman Cook Votes for Critical National Security Funding 
Congressman Paul Cook voted for HR 6157, which funds our national defense through September of 2019. After clearing the Senate, the House voted for the bill overwhelmingly and it was signed by President Trump. This marks the first time in 22 years that this critical funding bill was passed on time to fund our Soldiers, Sailors, Airmen, and Marines. 

The legislation includes several important provisions:
	•	This bill supports our warfighters and includes a 2.6% pay increase for our troops – the largest pay raise for our brave men and women in nine years.
	•	Helps rebuild our Armed Forces by increasing funding for personnel requirements, operational needs, equipment upgrades, and support for key allies.
	•	Restores military readiness by fully funding training requirements, maintenance operations, and research and development into new technologies.
Congressman Cook said “I’m very pleased that Congress passed this vitally important bill to support our troops, military families, and retirees. Without this legislation, our national security would be at risk and we would leave our military ill-equipped to protect our way of life. Our troops defend our freedom every day, all around the world; they deserve the best and most modern technology to carry out their critical mission."


￼
U.S. Department of State High School Study Abroad Scholarships
￼
￼

I was pleased to hear that one outstanding student from Lee Vining High School in our very own district had been selected by the U.S. Department of State for the highly competitive merit-based scholarship Congress-Bundestag Youth Exchange (CBYX). CBYX is a study abroad exchange program that gives participants the opportunity to study German culture and language.

The U.S. Department of State has created a variety of high school exchange programs funded through the Education and Cultural Exchanges (ECE) congressional appropriation. Each year, these high school exchange programs prepare over 1,000 young Americans to succeed on the 21st century's international stage by developing their foreign language skills, increasing their cross-cultural understanding, strengthening their leadership capacity, and fostering new academic insights and ambitions. Many exchange program alumni go on to pursue education and careers vital to the country's national security.

I strongly encourage all high school students to take part in this incredible opportunity organized by the U.S. Department of State. Studying abroad allows students to engage with local schools, communities, and share American culture and values while building long-lasting relationships in an educational and eye-opening environment.

Click here for more information.

Rebecca Raymond Memorial Foundation: 5K Run and Walk
￼
The Rebecca Raymond Memorial Foundation 5k Run/Walk is an event for everyone! Competitive runners, casual walkers, families, friends, and everyday joggers are all encouraged to come out and participate.

The event is 5k (1 loop) around Silver Lakes with a beautiful view overlooking the lake.

The mission of the Rebecca Raymond Memorial Foundation is to provide support to individuals interested in pursuing a career in public safety, organizations associated with public safety training and partnering with organizations that contribute to the community well-being. 

High Desert Opportunity Summit: Education Fueling Economic Development
￼

￼
The new, one-day event will combine the 37th annual High Desert Opportunity conference with the VVC Foundation’s High Desert Economic Summit, usually held in the spring.

The conference will focus on marketing the High Desert region for business retention and attraction, while also featuring an economic forecast of the Victor Valley and Inland Empire Region.

This year’s conference will include an economic forecast and educate attendees about the economic future of the High Desert, Inland Empire and state as a whole.

Proceeds from the conference will benefit the Victor Valley College Foundation, which provides scholarship and grant opportunities to students at VVC.

The HDO conference has a long history in the area and was formally designed to draw business owners and site scouts from out of the area and introduce them to the benefits of expanding or relocating to the High Desert region.

In Case You Missed It
Hultgren to Host Hunger Forum
￼

Our communities have worked to raise awareness of the problem of hunger in our region just as others have sought to bring attention to it on a worldwide level. Although the challenges to overcome hunger are daunting, they are not beyond our ability to confront and in many cases resolve them.
I will be hosting a forum, “Confronting the Scourge of Hunger”, which will focus on the issue of global hunger and hunger as experienced by many in our own region, and approaches to address and alleviate hunger both locally and globally.   
According the Northern Illinois Food Bank, nearly 600,000 people in northern Illinois rely on food pantries and meal programs to feed themselves and their families. I look forward to hearing about constructive approaches to address the scourge of hunger and expert insight into how we as a community, both locally as well as globally, can participate in finding solutions and helping those whose lives are afflicted by hunger.

"Confronting the Scourge of Hunger"
Baker Community Center in St. Charles Wednesday, October 17th  10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m.

Subject: how tax reform is making a difference in our community
Message:
￼

Hello,
One of my favorite things about being home in Eastern Washington is getting to talk with so many people. As I listen to their stories, and hear from them directly, I'm constantly reminded that you just never know who you're going to meet -- and what their story is.
Since passing the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act last December, I have heard many stories from people who have hope and are optimistic again. Here are a few of the stories from right here at home about why Eastern Washington is Better Off Now thanks to tax reform and our growing economy:
	1.	The Tin Roof: Consumer confidence is at a near 18-year high. For this family-owned furniture store in Spokane, business is better. So they are purchasing two new trucks, increasing wages, and offering health insurance to their employees for the first time in nearly a decade.   
	2.	Home Depot: Employees at the Home Depot's 45 locations in Washington state, including in Spokane, received bonuses because of tax reform.   
	3.	Sonderen Packaging: As a result of tax reform, 90% of Americans saw their paychecks increase. That includes employees at Sonderen Packaging in Spokane, who saw their paychecks go up by $70-300 each month.   
	4.	Hope House: Because of tax reform, Hope House, a woman's shelter in Spokane, received $1 million from Premera Blue Cross to triple its capacity and help more women find permanent homes.   
	5.	Dry Fly Distilling: The owner of this small business said tax reform is responsible for a reduction in his Spokane distillery's production cost. As a result, he's investing in an expansion, special projects, and more jobs.    
	6.	"For me, they're not crumbs": In February, a young woman from Spokane called to tell me that she was so excited to see $47.98 more in her paycheck each month. That is about $1,200 per year. She said, "For me, they're not crumbs. It's more money to help me put food on the table. I'm so happy I wanted to tell everybody, the whole world, that these tax cuts work... I'm so excited."   
	7.	Northwest Bancorp: INB banks in Spokane have raised their starting wage to $15 per hour and awarded $500 bonuses to each of their employees.   
	8.	Starbucks: Thanks to tax reform, Starbucks expanded its sick and parental leave policies for their employees. Now, working parents, like Brian in Spokane, have more flexibility at work to take care of their children.   
	9.	Children with Disabilities: One family told me they are seeing $400 more in their take home pay each month. This pay increase has made a real difference in helping them care for their daughter living with a disability.   
	10.	Vaagen Brothers: This family-owned lumber business logs and provides timber and is one of the largest employers in Colville. Because of tax reform, they gave pay raises not once, but TWICE, to their employees. 
In our community, Republican pro-growth policies are making a difference and improving people's lives. With more jobs, fairer taxes, and bigger paychecks, families and workers in our community are Better Off Now.
Warmly, ￼ Cathy McMorris Rodgers Member of Congress  P.S. in case you missed my email last week: An accountant with decades of experience in Spokane ran his own analysis of Republican tax reform. He ran 30 scenarios of typical families in Eastern Washington, and found that every household type at every income level is saving money under the Tax Cuts & Jobs Act.  Click here to read more in the Spokesman-Review.

Subject: Announcing Del. Danica Roem Will Deliver Keynote At Annual Women's Conference
Message:
Announcing Del. Danica Roem Will Deliver Keynote At Annual Women's Conference
Click here if you have trouble viewing this email
￼
Last week, you received my message announcing my Fourth Annual Women’s Conference and Forum: “Breaking Through: Women Work For Change.” I also wanted to let you know that Delegate Danica Roem will be delivering this year’s keynote address.
Delegate Danica Roem represents the 13th District in the Virginia House of Delegates including the City of Manassas Park, Town of Haymarket, and Prince William County portions of Manassas and Gainesville. She is a 33-year-old step-mom, lifelong resident of Prince William County, and the former lead reporter of the Gainesville Times. She ran for office to bring a reporter's eye to Richmond and to speak truth to power.
Delegate Roem’s inspiring and transformative campaign gained national and international attention.  Her victory was secured by sticking to the issues that matter most to her constituents, and never shying away from standing up for justice.  As the first out transgender woman elected to a state legislature, she is blazing a new and unique trail.
During her first legislative session this year, she was proud to champion bills important to her constituents, and to help expand Medicaid to 400,000 people across the state of Virginia.  She continues to fight every day for her constituents in the 13th District.

Delegate Danica Roem

Subject: Reply from Congressman Duncan Hunter
Message:
News from Representative Duncan Hunter  Open in its own browser window     Open a plain text version     Forward to friend 
￼
 
WEBSITE
ABOUT ME
CONSTITUENT SERVICES
NEWS
CONTACT ME
 
￼
￼
￼
￼
Dear Friend,

With fall in full swing, our economy is looking better than ever.  By reforming our tax code and regulatory environment, we have grown our economy, given business owners the confidence needed to grow their businesses and hire new workers, and families have more money in their pockets—in fact, recent census data shows that between 2016 and 2017, the median income for households in our district rose 7.6 percent, or $5,463.  Those are real results that make a meaningful difference in the lives of families in our district. 
Fiscal Year 2019 Funding  Of all my responsibilities as a member of Congress, among the most important is ensuring that our men and women in uniform have the resources they need to successfully complete their mission.  Unfortunately, for the past 10 years, our military has been subjected to unstable and unpredictable funding, which has harmed readiness and contributed to unneeded risks and training accidents for our service members.  Last week, the House and the President acted to reverse that course.   
I was proud to support the Fiscal Year 2019 Department of Defense Appropriations bill, which was signed into law by President Trump.  It provides the funding needed to rebuild our military.  That includes replacing aging and broken planes that put service members at risk, and providing new ships, aircraft and tanks needed to confront emerging threats.  It also provides a 2.6 percent pay raise for our troops – the largest in nine years. 
As the House moves forward to complete the appropriations process for the remaining departments and agencies by years end, a number of issues will continue to be discussed, and I remain committed to fight for additional resources to strengthen border infrastructure.   
The FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has existed for decades to ensure safety and efficiency in our nation's airspace, and after several weeks of negotiations, I’m proud to let you know that the House and Senate agreed on a bicameral, bipartisan multi-year reauthorization of the FAA. 
The measure supports American aviation jobs and will help drive innovation in the aviation sector.  The bill sets the stage for our country to be the leader in unmanned aircraft technology (UAS), and begins the process to integrate UAS devices into our airspace, and provides safeguards against errant UAS devices that could do us harm.  The measure also improves aviation safety and contains important consumer protections to protect you and your family from unfair practices—including limiting the involuntary bumping of passengers once they have boarded an aircraft.
Wildfire Preparedness Community Workshop 
Mark your calendar.  On October 18, 2018, the Ramona West End Fire Safe Council will be hosting a Wildfire Preparedness Community Workshop in partnership with Ramona Ranch Winery and Hatfield Creek Winery.  This is a free event, giving residents in our district an opportunity to connect with emergency first responders to better prepare businesses, residents and their families in the event of a wildfire.
This event is scheduled between 6:00 PM and 8:00 PM at Ramona Community Library on Main Street (1275 Main St, Ramona, CA 92065).  To find this and even more information, including a link for registering, the Ramona Community Library has created a convenient and informational Facebook event page that you can access by clicking here. 
Why is this workshop important? It gives residents in our district an opportunity to meet, hear and question our local fire, law enforcement and animal service professionals to better prepare yourself and your loved ones for emergency fire response.  Topics include evacuation, emergency communications, emergency response, emergency preparedness, creating your own evacuation plan, and more.
Participants Include:  
	•	Bureau of Land Management
	•	CAL FIRE, Battalion Chief Randy Scales
	•	CAL FIRE/Ramona Fire, Battalion Chief Larry Converse
	•	California Highway Patrol
	•	SD County Fire Authority / Community Group Support, Bob Uribe
	•	SD County Fire Authority/Fire Prevention Specialist, Jeremy Davis
	•	County Department of Animal Services, Lt. D.J. Gove
	•	County Office of Emergency Services, Ryan DeHart
	•	Internal Revenue Service, Neki Cox – Personal & Business Financial Record Preparedness
	•	Ramona Outback Amateur Radio Society (ROARS), Steve Sampson
	•	Ramona Sheriff’s Substation, Lt. Chris Davis
	•	Small Business Administration
I am supporting every effort to bring fire relief resources to California.  It is important that we continue to pursue legitimate fire prevention and control measures for public safety concerns such as access to communication and emergency services, particularly for disabled and senior citizens, that are far too often overlooked. 
For more information, please contact Kristi Mansolf at: 760-445-8545 or at kmansolf@gmail.com.  
Military Academy Nomination Applications 
Each year I have the privilege of nominating a limited number of candidates of the 50th District to four of the five U.S. Service Academies.  Applications for a service academy nomination for this year are due by October 31st.  For more information on Military Academy Nominations, please contact Angelica Rodriguez in my El Cajon office at 619-448-5201 or by email at Angelica.Rodriguez@mail.house.gov. 
Social Media 
If you haven’t already, visit my home page at hunter.house.gov or be sure to follow me online on Facebook and Twitter to stay up to date on our work in Congress. 
In the meantime 
Hearing from my constituents is crucial to my ability to represent our District in Congress. My positions on legislation are based on the effect they will have on California’s 50th District and the future of our country as a whole, regardless of which party occupies the White House.  Especially right now while our country is facing a number of major decisions, it is important for me to hear your views on how the laws passed in Washington will affect families in California.  I hope that you will take the time to let me know about the issues that are important to you and your family.
Sincerely, ￼  Duncan Hunter

Subject: Baldwin Takes Action to Improve Health Outcomes for New Moms
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email


￼ 


  
Dear Lindsey, 
To help improve maternal and infant health outcomes, Senators Tammy Baldwin, Cory Booker (D-NJ), Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Ben Cardin (D-MD), Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) and Kamala Harris (D-CA) have introduced new legislation to reduce the United States’ rising maternal mortality rates and close the disparities that continue to put mothers and children of color at risk. 
“Wisconsin is seeing troubling increases in maternal and infant mortality, so we need to do everything we can to make sure women and families have access to quality, affordable health care,” said Senator Baldwin. “We know that healthier pregnancies lead to healthier babies. That’s why I’m proud to work on this important legislation by enhancing Medicaid and CHIP support so mothers and pregnant women can get the care they need at a price they can afford.”
Between 2000 and 2014 the maternal mortality rate in the United States has increased by 26 percent, while it has decreased in other developed countries. Stark disparities in maternal deaths exist, as black women are nearly four times as likely to die from childbirth complications as white women. Furthermore, for every woman who dies due to a pregnancy-related complication, dozens more suffer from severe maternal morbidity.    
The Maximizing Outcomes for Moms through Medicaid Improvement and Enhancement of Services (MOMMIES) Act would improve maternal health outcomes by enhancing coverage for pregnant women covered by Medicaid--which covers nearly half of all births in the United States. Specifically, the MOMMIES Act would improve maternal health outcomes by:  
	•	Extending Medicaid coverage for postpartum women to a full year after giving birth, rather than the current limit of 60 days that many women face
	•	Ensuring that all pregnant and postpartum women have full Medicaid coverage, rather than coverage that can be limited to pregnancy-related services
	•	Establishing a maternity care home demonstration project to study this innovative model of care in several states
	•	Extending the Affordable Care Act’s primary care bump to ensure that Medicaid beneficiaries have access to primary care and women’s health providers
	•	Encouraging increased access to doula care to provide pregnant women on Medicaid with emotional, physical, and informational support
	•	Studying telemedicine and its effectiveness and potential to improve Medicaid beneficiaries’ access to maternity care
Read more about the MOMMIES Act and see why the Association of Maternal & Child Health Programs, Black Mamas Matter Alliance, Black Women's Health Imperative, Center for Reproductive Rights, Every Mother Counts, In Our Own Voice, March of Dimes, MomsRising, National Asian Pacific American Women's Forum, National Health Law Program, National Latina Institute for Reproductive Health, National Partnership for Women & Families and the National Women's Law Center all support the bill here.

Subject: I Believe Dr. Christine Blasey Ford, And I Will Oppose Brett Kavanaugh’s Nomination
Message:
The Durbin Report: A message from Senator Richard J. Durbin
￼ 



Fellow Illinoisan, 
Last week, the Senate Judiciary Committee heard from Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett Kavanaugh in a historic hearing.  As a member of the Committee, I took the responsibility of questioning Dr. Blasey Ford and Judge Kavanaugh seriously. 
Dr. Blasey Ford was credible, cooperative, and resolute in her testimony.  When I asked her directly, under oath, her degree of certainty that Brett Kavanaugh assaulted her, she responded, "100 percent."  She told us she had a responsibility as a citizen to come forward and tell her story.  She said she came forward because she wanted to be helpful to the Committee and to the nation. I believe her. 
The exchange I had with Judge Kavanaugh was an honest effort to loosen the Gordian Knot the Committee faces when two sworn witnesses are in direct contradiction.  I asked him if he would support a non-partisan FBI investigation, to let professional FBI investigators interview witnesses, connect the dots, and present their findings.  He refused, repeatedly.
There was a glaring difference between the witnesses last week: one person embraced a full FBI investigation, and one rejected it. Dr. Blasey Ford welcomed participation in a neutral investigation, while Judge Kavanaugh repeatedly denied my requests to submit to one.  
I have serious concerns about Judge Kavanaugh’s credibility, temperament, and judgment, and I will be voting no on his nomination to the Supreme Court.  I am encouraged that the FBI has now reopened its background investigation into the serious and credible allegations against him.  The American people deserve transparency and the truth. 
Sincerely, 
U.S. Senator Dick Durbin

Subject: BREAKING NEWS -- EPA finalizes $74M cleanup plan for American Cyanamid Superfund Site in Bridgewater
Message:
Click here to open this e-mail in its own browser window   Click here to open a plain text version of this email
Can't see the pictures? Select "Always display images" or view this message in your browser 
￼

 
October 2, 2018
￼
EPA finalizes $74M cleanup plan for American Cyanamid Superfund Site in Bridgewater 

Do you like this breaking news update?


Yes, I like it.

No, I don't like it.

I don't know/have no opinion.

Click to open in a separate window

Bob Makin, Bridgewater Courier News 
Published 8:00 a.m. ET Oct. 1, 2018
A final plan to clean up acid tars, benzene, and other chemicals at the American Cyanamid Superfund site in Bridgewater has been approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 
The cleanup will cost $74 million, according to a news release issued by the federal agency.
￼
The remedy selected in this Record of Decision will clean up the two most contaminated impoundments in a manner that is protective of the Bridgewater community and the workers at the site,” said Acting EPA Administrator Andrew Wheeler in a statement released Friday. “This final cleanup plan reflects our commitment to prioritize the Superfund Program and ensure these sites are cleaned up as quickly and safely as possible.”
EPA Regional Administrator Pete Lopez added in a statement. “More than 44,000 tons of hazardous waste will be removed from the Bridgewater community and permanently destroyed. Approximately 2.3 million gallons of contaminated liquid will be collected and treated. This action safeguards people’s health and arrests a threat to the Raritan River.”
Both U.S. Rep Leonard Lance (R-7th) and Bridgewater Mayor Daniel J. Hayes Jr. expressed relief with the plan. 
“Bridgewater is counting on the EPA to remove these 44,000 tons of waste," said Lance, a member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, in a statement. "These hazards need to be out of our community as soon as possible. I am pleased the EPA is implementing a final plan and moving forward in getting this job done. I believe the final plan to be responsible and the disposal of the approximately 2.3 million gallons of contaminated liquid will result in the contaminants’ safe removal and permanent destruction.”
Hayes added, “I am happy to see that the EPA has come to a community based resolution on the two most contaminated impoundments. Public safety remains our priority. We look forward to working with our partners EPA and Pfizer on cleaning up this site.”
